superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter b b
The second letter of the alphabet: called baMCN and baA; (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp;) the latter of which forms is used in spelling; like as are its analogues, as tA [and vA] and HA [and xA and rA] and TA [and ZA and fA and hA] and yA; because in this case they are not generally regarded as nouns, but as mere sounds: (Sb, M:) [these are generally pronounced with imáleh, i. e. bé, té, &c., with the exception of HA, xA, TA, and ZA; and when they are regarded as nouns, their duals are bayaAni, tayaAni, &c.:] the pl. of baMCN is baMCaAtN; and that of baA is OabowaMCN (TA ubi suprà.) It is one of the letters termed majohuwrah [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; and of those termed XafahiyRap [or labial]; and of those termed culoq [or pronounced with the extremity of the tongue or the lips]: Kh says that the letters of the second and third classes above mentioned [the latter of which comprises the former] are those composing the words rubRa mano lafRa; and on account of their easiness of utterance, they abound in the composition of words, so that no perfect quinqueliteral-radical word is without one or more of them, unless it is of the class termed muwalRad, not of the classical language of the Arabs. (TA at the commencement of bAb AlbMC.) ― -b2- In the dial. of Mázin, it is changed into m; (TA ubi suprà;) as in bakRapu, which thus becomes makRapu [the town of Mekkeh]. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.) ＝ -A2- bi is a preposition, or particle governing the gen. case; (S, Mughnee, K;) having kesr for its invariable termination because it is impossible to begin with a letter after which one makes a pause; (S;) or, correctly speaking, having a vowel for its invariable termination because it is impossible to begin with a quiescent letter; and having kesr, not fet-h, to make it accord with its government [of the gen. case], and to distinguish between it and that which is both a noun and a particle. (IB.) It is used to denote adhesion (Sb, T, S, M, Mughnee, K) of the verb to its objective complement, (S,) or of a noun or verb to that to which it is itself prefixed; (TA;) and adjunction, or association: (Sb, T:) and some say that its meaning of denoting adhesion is inseparable from it; and therefore Sb restricted himself to the mention of this meaning: (Mughnee:) or Sb says that its primary meaning is that of denoting adhesion and mixture. (Ibn-Es-Sáïgh, quoted in a marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee.) It denotes adhesion [&c.] in the proper sense; (Mughnee, K;) as in Oamosakotu bizayodK, (M, Mughnee, K,) meaning I laid hold upon, or seized, [Zeyd, or] somewhat of the body of Zeyd, or what might detain him, as an arm or a hand, or a garment, and the like; whereas Oamosakotuhu may mean I withheld him, or restrained him, from acting according to his own free will: (Mughnee:) and it denotes the same in a tropical sense; (Mughnee, K;) as in mararotu bizayodK [I passed by Zeyd]; (S, Mughnee, K;) as though meaning I made my passing to adhere to Zeyd; (S;) or I made my passing to adhere to a place near to Zeyd: accord. to Akh, it is for mararotu EalaIi zayodK; but mararotu bihi is more common than mararotu Ealayohi, and is therefore more properly regarded as the original form of expression: (Mughnee:) accord. to F, the vowel of this preposition is kesr [when it is prefixed to a noun or a pronoun]; or, as some say, it is fet-h when it is with a noun properly so called; as in marRa bazayodK: so in the K; this being the reverse of what they have prescribed in the case of [the preposition] l: but in the case of b, no vowel but kesr is known. (MF.) It denotes the same in the saying bihi daMCN [In him is a disease; i. e. a disease is cleaving to him]: and so [accord. to some] in Oaqosamotu bQllRehi [I swore, or, emphatically, I swear, by God; and similar phrases, respecting which see a later division of this paragraph]. (L.) So, too, in OaXoraka bQllRehi, because meaning He associated another with God: and in wakRalotu bifulaAnK, meaning I associated a wakiyl [or factor &c.] with such a one. (T.) [And so in other phrases here following.] Ealayoka bizayodK Keep thou to Zeyd: or take thou Zeyd. (TA voce EalaI.) Ealayoka bikacaA Keep thou to such a thing: (El-Munáwee:) or take thou such a thing. (Ham p. 216.) fabahaA wanaEomato Keep thou to it, fbhA meaning faEalayoka bihaA, (Mgh in art. nEm,) [or let him keep to it, i. e. faEalayohi bihaA,] or thou hast taken to, or adopted and followed, or adhered to, the established way, or the way established by the Prophet, i. e. fabiQlsRunRapi Oaxacata, (Mgh,) or he hath taken to, &c., i. e. fabiQlsRunRapi Oaxaca, (IAth, TA in art. nEm,) or by this practice, or action, is excellence attained, or he will attain excellence, i. e. fabihecihi AlxaSolapi Oawi AlfaEolapi yunaAlu AlfaDolu, or yanaAlu AlfaDola; (IAth ubi suprà;) and excellent is the practise, the established way, or the way established by the Prophet, wnEmt meaning waniEomati AlxaSolapu AlsRunRapu, (Mgh,) or and excellent is the practice, or the action, i. e. waniEomati AlxaSolapu, (S and K in art. nEm,) or waniEomati AlxaSolapu Ouwi AlfaEolapu: (IAth ubi suprà:) and it also occurs in a trad., where the meaning is [He who hath done such a thing hath adhered to the ordinance of indulgence; and excellent is the practice, or action, &c.: for here fbhA is meant to imply] fabiQlrRaxoSapi Oaxaca. (TA in the present art. See also art. nEm.) ― -b2- It is also used to render a verb transitive; (Mughnee, K;) having the same effect as hemzeh [prefixed], in causing [what would otherwise be] the agent to become an objective complement; as in cahabotu bizayodK syn. with Oacohabotuhu [I made Zeyd to go away; or I took him away]; (Mughnee;) and hence, [in the Kur ii. 16,] cahaba QllRehu binuwrihimo [God taketh away their light]; (Mughnee, K;) which refutes the assertion of Mbr and Suh, that cahabotu bizayodK means [I went away with Zeyd; i. e.] I accompanied Zeyd in going away. (Mughnee.) J says that any verb that is not trans. you may render so by means of bi and A [prefixed] and reduplication [of the medial radical letter]: you say, TaAra bihi and OaTaArahu and TayRarahu [as meaning He made him to fly, or to fly away]: but IB says that this is not correct as of common application; for some verbs are rendered trans. by means of hemzeh, but not by reduplication; and some by reduplication, but not by hemzeh; and some by b, but not by hemzeh nor by reduplication: you say, dafaEotu zayodFA biEamorKw [as meaning I made ' Amr to repel Zeyd, lit. I repelled Zeyd by ' Amr], but not OadofaEotuhu nor dafRaEotuhu. (TA.) ― -b3- It also denotes the employing a thing as an aid or instrument; (S, M, * Mughnee, K; *) as in katabotu biAlqalami [I wrote with the reed-pen]; (S, Mughnee, K;) and najarotu biAlqaduwmi [I worked as a carpenter with the adz]; (Mughnee, K;) and Darabotu bAlsRayofi [I struck with the sword]. (M.) And hence the bi in bisomi QllRehi, (Mughnee, K,) accord. to some, because the action [before which it is pronounced] is not practicable in the most perfect manner but by means of it: (Mughnee:) but others disallow this, because the name of God should not be regarded as an instrument: (MF, TA:) and some say that the b here is to denote beginning, as though one said, OabotadaOu bisomi QllRehi [I begin with the name of God]. (TA.) ― -b4- It also denotes a cause; as in UinRakumo Zalamotumo Oanofusakumo biQtRixaAcikumu QloEijola [Verily ye have wronged yourselves by, i. e. because of, your taking to yourselves the calf as a god (Kur ii. 51)]; and in fakulRFA OaxaconaA bicanobihi [And every one of these we have punished for, i. e. because of, his sin (Kur xxix. 39)]; (Mughnee, K) and in lano yadoxula OaHadakumu AljanRapa biEamalihi [Not any of you shall enter Paradise by, or for, or because of, his works]. (TA from a trad.) And so in laqaytu bizayodK AlOasada I met, or found, by reason of my meeting, or finding, Zeyd, the lion: (Mughnee:) or the b in this instance denotes comparison; [i. e. I met, or found, in Zeyd the like of the lion;] as also in raOayotu bifulaAnK Alqamara [I saw in such a one the
like of the moon]. (TA.) Another ex. of the same usage is the saying [of a poet],
qado suqiyato MbaAluhumo biAlnRaAri
waAlnRaAru qado taXofiI mina AlOuwaAri
[Their camels had been watered because of the brand that they bore: for fire, or the brand, sometimes cures of the heat of thirst]; i. e., because of their being branded with the names [or marks] of their owners, they had free access left them to the water. (Mughnee. See also another reading of this verse voce naArN.) [In like manner] it is used in the sense of mino Oajoli [which means bisababi (Msb in art. Ajl)] in the saying of Lebeed,
gulobN taXacRara biAlcRuHuwli kaOanRahaA
jinRu AlbadiIRi rawaAsiyAF OaqodaAmuhaA
(S) Thick-necked men, like lions, who threatened one another because of rancorous feelings, as though they were the Jinn of the valley El-Bedee, [or of the desert, (TA in art. bdw,)] their feet standing firm in contention and obstinate altercation. (EM pp. 174 and 175.) It is also used to denote a cause when prefixed to OanRa and to maA as in celika biOanRahumo kaAnuwA yakofuruwna biMyaAti QllRehi [That was because they used to disbelieve in the signs of God]; and in celika bimaA EaSawoA [That was because they disobeyed]: both instances in the Kur ii. 58. (Bd.) ― -b5- It is also used to denote concomitance, as syn. with maEa; (Mughnee, K;) as in AiXotarayotu Alfarasa bilijaAmihi wasarojihi [I bought the horse with his bit and bridle and his saddle]; (TA;) and in lamRaA raMniI biAlsRalaAHi haraba, i. e. When he saw me advancing with the weapon, [he fled;] or when he saw me possessor of a weapon; (Sh, T;) and in AihobiTo bisalaAmK [Descend thou with security, or with greeting (Kur xi. 50)]; and in waqado daxaluwA biQlokufori [They having entered with unbelief (Kur v. 66)]; (Mughnee, K;) bAlkfr being a denotative of state. (Bd.) Authors differ respecting the b in the saying, fasabRiHo biHamodi rabRika, in the Kur [xv. 98 and ex. 3]; some saying that it denotes concomitance, and that Hmd is prefixed to the objective complement, so that the meaning is, sabRiHohN HaAmidFA lahu [Declare thou his (thy Lord's) freedom from everything derogatory from his glory, praising Him], i. e. declare thou his freedom from that which is not suitable to Him, and ascribe to Him that which is suitable to Him; but others say that it denotes the employing a thing as an aid or instrument, and that Hmd is prefixed to the agent, so that the meaning is, sabRiHohu bimaA Hamida bihi nafosahu [declare thou his (thy Lord's) freedom from everything derogatory from his glory by means of ascribing to Him that wherewith He hath praised himself]: and so, too, respecting the saying, suboHaAnaka QllRehumRa wabiHamodika; some asserting that it is one proposition, the, being redundant; but others saying, it is two propositions, the w being a conjunction, and the verb upon which the b is dependent being suppressed, so that the meaning is, [I declare thy freedom from everything derogatory from thy glory, 0 God,] wabiHamodika sabRaHotuka [and with the praising of Thee, or by means of the praise that belongeth to Thee, I declare thy freedom &c.]. (Mughnee. [Other explanations of these two phrases have been proposed; but those given above are the most approved.]) You also say, EalaIRa bihi, meaning Bring thou him, [i. e.] come with him, to me. (Har p. 109.) DaAqato Ealayohimu QloOaroDu bimaA raHubato, in the Kur ix. 119, means biruHobihaA [i. e. The earth became strait to them, with, meaning notwithstanding, its amplitude, or spaciousness]. (Bd.) Sometimes the negative lA intervenes between bi [denoting concomitance] and the noun governed by it in the gen. case; [so that bilaA signifies Without;] as in jiYotu bilaA zaAdK [I came without travelling-provision]. (Mughnee and K in art. lA.) ― -b6- It is also syn. with fiI before a noun signifying a place or a time; (Mughnee, * K, * TA;) as in jalasotu biAlmasojidi [I sat in the mosque]; (TA;) and walaqado naSarakumu QllRehu bibadorK [And verily God aided you against your enemies at Bedr (Kur iii. 119)]; and najRayonaAhumo bisaHarK [We saved them a little before daybreak (Kur liv. 34)]: (Mughnee, K, TA:) and so in biOayRikumu Qlomafotuwnu (T, K,) in the Kur [lxviii. 6], (TA,) accord. to some, (T, Mughnee,) i. e. In which of you is madness; or in which of the two parties of you is the mad: (Bd:) or the b is here redundant; (Sb, Bd, Mughnee;) the meaning being which of you is he who is afflicted with madness. (Bd. [See also a later division of this paragraph.]) ― -b7- It also denotes substitution; [meaning Instead of, or in place of;] as in the saying [of the Hamásee (Mughnee)],
falayota liI bihimu qawomFA UicaA rakibuwA
XanRawA AlUigaArapa furosaAnFA warukobaAnaA
[Then would that I had, instead of them, a people who, when they mounted their beasts, poured the sudden attack, they being horsemen and camel-riders]; (Ham p. 8, Mughnee, K;) i. e., badalFA bihimo (TA:) but some read XadRuwA AlUigaArapa, [and so it is in some, app., the most correct, of the copies of the Mughnee,] for XadRuwA liloUigaAripi [hastened for the making a sudden attack]. (Ham, Mughnee.) So, too, in the saying, AiEotaDotu biheciA AlvRawobi xayorFA minohu [I received, in the place of this garment, or piece of cloth, one better than it]; and laqiytu bizayodK baHorFA [I found, in the place of Zeyd, a man of abundant generosity or beneficence]; and hecaA bicaAki [This is instead, or in the place, of that; but see another explanation of this last phrase in what follows]. (The Lubáb, TA.) ― -b8- It also denotes requital; or the giving, or doing, in return; (Mughnee, K;) and in this case is prefixed to the word signifying the substitute, or thing given or done in exchange [or return; or to the word signifying that for which a substitute is given, or for which a thing is given or done in exchange or return]; (Mughnee;) as in the saying, AiXotarayotuhu biOalofi dirohamK [I purchased it for a thousand dirhems]; (Mughnee, K; *) [and in the saying in the Kur ix. 112, UinRa QllReha QXotarI mina QlomuWominiyna Oanofusahumo waOamowaAlahumo biOanRa lahumu QlojanRapa Verily God hath purchased of the believers their souls and their possessions for the price of their having Paradise;] and kaAfaOotu UiHosaAnahu biDiEofK [I requited his beneficence with a like beneficence, or with double, or more], (Mughnee,) or kaAfOotuhu biDiEofi UiHosaAnihi [I requited him with the like, or with double the amount, or with more than double the amount, of his beneficence], (K,) but the former is preferable; (TA;) [and xadama biTaEaAmi biTonihi (S and A &c. in art. wgd) He served for, meaning in return for, the food of his belly;] and
hecaA bicaAka walaA EatobN EalaI AlzRamani
[This is in return for that, (an explanation somewhat differing from one in the next preceding division of this paragraph,) and no blame is imputable to fortune]: and hence, AudoxuluwA QljanRapa bimaA kunotumo taEomaluwna [Enter ye Paradise in return for that which ye wrought (Kur xvi. 34)]; for the b here is not that which denotes a cause, as the Moatezileh assert it to be, and as all [of the Sunnees] hold it to be in the saying of the Prophet, lano yadoxula OaHadukumu AljanRapa biEamalihi [before cited and explained]; because what is given instead of something is sometimes given gratuitously; and it is evident that there is no mutual opposition between the trad. and the verse of the Kur-án. (Mughnee.) ― -b9- It is also syn. with Eano; and is said to be peculiar to interrogation; as in faQsoOalo bihi xabiyrFA [And ask thou respecting Him, or it, one possessing knowledge (Kur xxv. 60)]; (Mughnee, K;) and accord. to IAar in the Kur lxx. 1; (T;) and in the saying of ' Alkameh,
faUino tasoOaluwniI biAlnRisaMCi faUinRaniy
baSiyrN biOadowaMCi AlnRisaMCi xabiyru
[And if ye ask me respecting the diseases of women, verily I am knowing in the diseases of women, skilful]: (A' Obeyd, TA:) or it is not peculiar to interrogation; as in wayawoma taXaqRaqu QlsRamaMCu biQlogamaAmi [And the day when the heavens shall be rent asunder from the clouds (Kur xxv. 27)]; (Mughnee, K) and maA garRaka birabRika (K) i. e. What hath beguiled thee from thy Lord, and from believing in him? in the Kur lxxxii. 6; and so in the same, lvii. 13: (TA: [but see art. gr:]) or, accord. to Z, the b in bAlgmAm means by, as by an instrument; (Mughnee;) or it means because of, or by means of, the rising of the clouds therefrom: (Bd:) and in like manner the Basrees explain it as occurring in faQsoOalo bihi xabiyrFA, as denoting the cause; and they assert that it is never syn. with Eano; but their explanation is improbable. (Mughnee.) ― -b10- It is also syn. with EalaIi; as in Uino tiOomanohu biqinoTaArK (Mughnee, K *) or bidiynaArK (S) [If thou give him charge over a hundredweight or over a deenár (Kur iii. 68)]; like as EalaI is sometimes put in the place of bi as after the verb raDiIa: (S, TA:) and so in lawo tusawRaI bihimu QloOaroDu [That the ground were made even over them], in the Kur [iv. 45], (TA,) i. e. that
they were buried; (Bd) and in mararotu bizayodK [I passed by Zeyd], accord. to Akh, as before mentioned; (Mughnee, in the first division of the art. on this preposition;) and in zayodN biAlsRaToHi [Zeyd is on the roof]; (TA;) and in a verse cited in this Lex. voce vaEolabN. (Mughnee.) ― -b11- It also denotes part of a whole; (Msb in art. bED Mughnee, K;) so accord. to As and AAF and others; (Msb, Mughnee;) as syn. with mino (Msb, TA:) IKt says; the Arabs say, Xaribotu bimaMCi kacaA, meaning minohu [I drank of such a water]; and AZ mentions, as a saying of the Arabs, saqaAka QllRehu mino maMCi kacaA, meaning bihi [May God give thee to drink of such a water], thus making the two prepositions syn.: (Msb: [in which five similar instances are cited from poets; and two of these are cited also in the Mughnee:]) and thus it signifies in EayonFA yaXorabu bihaA EibaAdu QllRehi [A fountain from which the servants of God shall drink, in the Kur lxxvi. 6; and the like occurs in lxxxiii. 28]; (Msb, Mughnee, K;) accord. to the authorities mentioned above; (Mughnee;) or the meaning is, with which the servants of God shall satisfy their thirst (yarowaI bihaA); (T, Mughnee;) or, accord. to Z, with which the servants of God shall drink wine: (Mughnee:) if the b were redundant, [as some assert it to be, (Bd,)] the meaning would be, that they shall drink the whole of it; which is not right: (Msb:) thus, also, it is used in waQmosaHuwA biruWuLsikumo [in the Kur v. 8], (Msb, Mughnee, K,) accord. to some; (Mughnee;) i. e. [And wipe ye] a part of your heads; and this explanation has been given as on the authority of EshSháfi'ee; but he is said to have disapproved it, and to have held that the b here denotes adhesion: (TA:) this latter is its apparent meaning in this and the other instances: or, as some say, in this last instance it is used to denote the employing a thing as an aid or instrument, and there is an ellipsis in the phrase, and an inversion; the meaning being, AimosaHuwA ruWuLsakumo biAlmaMCi [wipe ye your heads with water]. (Mughnee.) ― -b12- It is also used to denote swearing; (Mughnee, K;) and is the primary one of the particles used for this purpose; therefore it is peculiarly distinguished by its being allowable to mention the verb with it, (Mughnee,) as Ouqosimu biQllRehi laOafoEalanRa [I swear by God I will assuredly do such a thing]; (Mughnee, K) and by its being prefixed to a pronoun, as in bika laOafoEalanRa [By thee I will assuredly do such a thing]; and by its being used in adjuring, or conjuring, for the purpose of inducing one to incline to that which is desired of him, as in bQllRehi halo qaAma zayodN, meaning I adjure thee, or conjure thee, by God, to tell me, did Zeyd stand? (Mughnee.) [See also the first explanation of this particle, where it is said, on the authority of the L, that, when thus used, it denotes adhesion.] ― -b13- It is also syn. with Uilay as denoting the end of an extent or interval; as in OaHosana biI, meaning He did good, or acted well, to me: (Mughnee, K:) but some say that the verb here imports the meaning of laTafa [which is trans. by means of b, i. e. he acted graciously, or courteously, with me]. (Mughnee.) ― -b14- It is also redundant, (S, Mughnee, K,) to denote corroboration: (Mughnee, K:) and is prefixed to the agent: (Mughnee:) first, necessarily; as in OaHosino bizayodK; (Mughnee, K;) accord. to general opinion (Mughnee) originally OaHosana zayodN, i. e. SaAra caA HusonK [Zeyd became possessed of goodness, or goodliness, or beauty]; (Mughnee, K; *) or the correct meaning is Hasuna zayodN [Good, or goodly, or beautiful, or very good &c., is Zeyd! or how good, or goodly, or beautiful, is Zeyd!], as in the B: (TA:) secondly, in most instances; and this is in the case of the agent of kafaI; as in kafaI biQllRehi XahiydFA [God sufficeth, being witness, or as a witness (Kur xiii., last verse; &c.)]; (Mughnee, K [and a similar ex. is given in the S, from the Kur xxv. 33;]) the b here denoting emphatic praise; but you may drop it, saying, kafaI QllRehu XahiydFA: (Fr, TA:) thirdly, in a case of necessity, by poetic licence; as in the saying,
Oalamo yaOotiyka waAlOanobaMCu tanomiI
bimaA laAqato labuwnu baniI ziyaAdi
[Did not what the milch camel of the sons of Ziyád experienced come to thee (yaOotiyka being in like manner put for yaOotika) when the tidings were increasing?]. (Mughnee, K.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the objective complement of a verb; as in walaA tuloquwA biOayodykumo UilaI QltRaholukapi [And cast ye not yourselves (bOydykm meaning biOanofusikumo) to perdition (Kur ii. 191)]; and in wahuzRiI Uilayoki bijicoEi AlnRaxolapi [And shake thou towards thee the trunk of the palm-tree (Kur xix. 25)]: but some say that the former means and cast ye not yourselves (Oanofusakumo being understood) with your hands to perdition; or that the meaning is, by means, or because, of your hands: (Mughnee:) and ISd says that huzRiI, in the latter, is made trans. by means of b because it is used in the sense of juzRiI: (TA in art hz:) so, too, in the saying,
naDoribu biAlsRayofi wa narjuw biAlfarajo
[We smite with the sword, and we hope for the removal of grief]: (S, Mughnee:) and in the trad., kafay biAlmaroCi kacibFA Oano yuHadRiva bikulRi maA samiEa [It suffices the man in respect of lying that he relate all that he has heard]. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the inchoative; as in biHasobika [when you say, biHasobika dirohamN, meaning A thing sufficing thee is a dirhem; a phrase which may be used in two ways; as predicating of what is sufficient, that it is a dirhem; and as predicating of a dirhem, that it is sufficient; in which latter case, bHsbk is an enunciative put before its inchoative, so that the meaning is, a dirhem is a thing sufficing thee, i. e. a dirhem is sufficient for thee; as is shown in a marginal note in my copy of the Mughnee: in the latter way is used the saying, mentioned in the S, biHasobika qawolu AlsRawoCi A thing sufficing thee is the saying what is evil: and so, app., each of the following sayings, mentioned in the TA on the authority of Fr; Hasobuka biSadiyqinaA A person sufficing thee is our friend; and naAhiyka biOaxiynaA A person sufficing thee is our brother: the b is added, as Fr says, to denote emphatic praise]: so too in xarajotu faUiciA bizayodK [I went forth, and lo, there, or then, was Zeyd]; and in kayofa bika UicaA kaAna kacaA [How art thou, or how wilt thou be, when it is thus, or when such a thing is the case?]; and so, accord. to Sb, in biOyRikumu Qlomafotuwnu [mentioned before, in explanation of bi as syn. with fiI]; but Abu-l-Hasan says that bOyRkm is dependent upon AisotiqoraAr suppressed, denoting the predicate of Aalmftwn; and some say that this is an inf. n. in the sense of finonapN; [so that the meaning may be, bOayRikumu Almafotuwnu musotaqirRN In which of you is madness residing?]; or, as some say, bi is here syn. with fiI [as I have before mentioned], (Mughnee.) A strange case is that of its being added before that which is originally an inchoative, namely, the noun, or subject, of layosa, on the condition of its being transferred to the later place which is properly that of the enunciative; as in the reading of some, wujuwhakumo] layosa QlbirRa biOano tuwalRuwA [qabala QlomaXoriqi wa Qlomagoribi [Your turning your faces towards the east and the west is not obedience (Kur ii. 172)]; with AlbrR in the accus. case. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the enunciative; and this is in two kinds of cases: first, when the phrase is not affirmative; and cases of this kind may be followed as exs.; as layosa zayodN biqaAYimK [Zeyd is not standing]; and wamaA QllRehu bigaAfilK EamRaA taEomaluwna [And God is not heedless of that which ye do (Kur ii. 69, &c.)]: secondly, when the phrase is affirmative; and in cases of this kind, one limits himself to what has been heard [from the Arabs]: so say Akh and his followers; and they hold to be an instance of this kind the phrase, jazaMCu sayRiYapK bimivolihaA [The recompense of an evil action is the like thereof (Kur x. 28)]; and the saying of the Hamásee,
wamanoEukahaA biXaIoCK yusotaTaAEu
[And the preventing thee from having her (referring to a mare) is a thing that is possible]: but it is more proper to make bmvlhA dependent upon AisotiqoraAr suppressed, as the enunciative; [the meaning being, jazaMCu sayRaYapK musotaqirRN bimivolihaA, or yasotaqirRu bimivolihaA, i. e. the recompense of an evil action is a thing consisting in the like thereof]; and to make bXIC dependent upon mnEkhA; the meaning being, wa manoEukahaA biXaIoCK mRaA yusotaTaAEu [i. e. and the preventing thee from having her, by something, is possible: see Ham p. 102]: Ibn-Málik also [holds, like Akh and his followers, that bi may be redundant when prefixed to the enunciative in an affirmative proposition; for he] says, respecting biHasobika zayodN, that zyd is an inchoative placed after its enunciative, [so that the meaning is, Zeyd is a person sufficing thee,] because zayodN is determinate and Hasobuka is indeterminate. (Mughnee. [See also what has been said above respecting the phrase biHasobika dirohamN, in treating of bi as added before the inchoative.]) It is also redundantly
prefixed to the denotative of state of which the governing word is made negative; as in
famaA rajaEato bixaAYibapK rikaAbN
Hakiymu bonu AlmusayRabi munotahaAhaA
[And travelling-camels (meaning their riders) returned not disappointed, whose goal, or ultimate object, was Hakeem the son of El-Museiyab]; and in
famaA QnobaEavota bimazoWudK wa laA wakali
[And thou didst not, being sent, or roused, go away frightened, nor impotent, committing thine affair to another]: so says Ibn-Málik: but AHei disagrees with him, explaining these two exs. as elliptical; the meaning implied in the former being, biHaAjapK xaAYibapK [with an object of want disappointed, or frustrated]; and in the second, biXaxoSK mazoWuwdK, i. e. macoEuwrK [with a person frightened]; the poet meaning, by the mzWwd, himself, after the manner of the saying, raOayotu minohu OasadFA; and this is plain with respect to the former ex., but not with respect to the second; for the negation of attributes of dispraise denoted as intensive in degree does not involve the negation of what is simply essential in those attributes; and one does not say, laqiytu minohu OasadFA, or baHorFA, [or raOayotu minohu OasadFA, as above, or baHorFA,] but when meaning to express an intensive degree of boldness, or of generosity. (Mughnee.) It is also redundantly prefixed to the corroborative nafosN and EayonN: and some hold it to be so in yatarabRana biOanofusihinRa [as meaning Shall themselves wait (Kur ii. 228 and 234)]: but this presents matter for consideration; because the affixed pronoun in the nom. case, [whether expressed, as in this instance, in which it is the final syllable na, or implied in the verb,] when corroborated by nafos, should properly be corroborated first by the separate [pronoun], as in qumotumo Oanotumo Oanofusukumo [Ye stood, ye, yourselves]; and because the corroboration in this instance is lost, since it cannot be imagined that any others are here meant than those who are commanded to wait: [the preferable rendering is, shall wait to see what may take place with themselves:] bOnfshnR is added only for rousing them the more to wait, by making known that their minds should not be directed towards the men. (Mughnee.) Accord. to some, it is also redundantly prefixed to a noun governed in the gen. case [by another preposition]; as in
fOaSobaHona laA yasoOalonahu Eano biOabihi
And they became in a condition in which they asked him not respecting his father; which may perhaps be regarded by some as similar to the saying,
yaDoHakona Eano kaAlbaradi AlmunohamRi
but in this instance, ka is generally held to be a noun, syn. with mivol]. (The Lubáb, TA.) ― -b15- Sometimes it is understood; as in AllReh lAfElnR [i. e. AllRehi laOafoEalanRa and AllReha laOafoEalanRa By God, I will assuredly do such a thing; in the latter as well as the former, for a noun is often put in the accus. case because of a preposition understood; or, accord. to Bd, in ii. 1, a verb significant of swearing is understood]: and in xayorK [for bixayorK In a good state], addressed to him who says, kayofa OaSobaHota [How hast thou entered upon the time of morning? or How hast thou become?]. (TA.) ― -b16- [It occurs also in several elliptical phrases; one of which (fabihaA wa niEomato) has been mentioned among the exs. of its primary meaning: some are mentioned in other arts.; as biOabiI and binafosiI, in arts. Abw and nfs: and there are many others, of which exs. here follow.] Mohammad is related, in a trad., to have said, after hitting a butt with an arrow, OanaA bhaA OanaA bhaA, meaning OanaA SaAHibuhaA [I am the doer of it! I am the doer of it!]. (Sh, T.) And in another trad., Mohammad is related to have said to one who told him of a man's having committed an unlawful action, laEalRaka biceliki, meaning laEalRaka SaAHibu AlOamori [May-be thou art the doer of that thing]. (T.) And in another, he is related to have said to a woman brought to him for having committed adultery or fornication, mano biki, meaning mano SaAHibuki [Who was thine accomplice?]: (T:) or mani AlfaAEilu biki [Who was the agent with thee?]. (TA.) OanaA bika walaka, occurring in a form of prayer, means I seek, or take, refuge in Thee; or by thy right disposal and facilitation I worship; and to Thee, not to any other, I humble myself. (Mgh in art. bwA.) One says also, mano liI bikacaA, meaning Who will be responsible, answerable, amenable, or surety, to me for such a thing? (Har p. 126: and the like is said in p. 191.) And similar to this is the saying, kaOanRiI bika, meaning kaOanRiy OaboSuru bika [It is as though I saw thee]; i. e. I know from what I witness of thy condition to-day how thy condition will be to-morrow; so that it is as though I saw thee in that condition. (Idem p. 126.) [You also say, kaOanRaka bihi, meaning Thou art so near to him that it is as though thou sawest him: or it is as though thou wert with him: i. e. thou art almost in his presence.] ― -b17- The Basrees hold that prepositions do not supply the places of other prepositions regularly; but are imagined to do so when they admit of being differently rendered; or it is because a word is sometimes used in the sense of another word, as in Xaribona bimaMCi AlbaHori meaning rawiyna, and in OaHosana biI meaning laTafa; or else because they do so anomalously. (Mughnee.) ＝ -A3- [As a numeral, b denotes Two.]

Q. 1. baOobaOahu, (Lth, T, S, M, K,) and bObO bihi, (Fr, M, K,) inf. n. baOobaMapu (Lth, T, M) and baYobaMCN; (Fr, M;) [as also bOabiI; see art. biOabiI Oanota;] He said to him, biOabiy, (Fr, M,) or bOabaA, (M,) or biOabiI Oanota, (Lth, T, K,) [all meaning With my father mayest thou be ransomed! or] meaning Oafodiyka biOabiI [I will ransom thee with my father]; (Lth, T;) or he said to him, biOabiI Oanota waOumRiI [With my father mayest thou be ransomed, and with my mother! or I will ransom thee &c.; see art. Abw]; (S;) the current phrase of the Arabs being that which includes both parents: (TA:) i. e., a man said so to another man, (Lth, T, M,) or to a child; (Fr, S, M;) and in like manner to his horse, for having saved him from some accident: (IAar, T:) the verb is derived from biOabiI. (Lth, T, M.) Hence AlbiOabo, in an ex. cited voce OabN, in art. Abw, q. v.; (M;) or AlbiYabo; (TA in art. Abw;) or Albiyabo. (S in that art.) ― -b2- And [hence,] baObaWuwhu They made a show of treating him with graciousness, courtesy, or blandishment; as also Ealayohi tabaOobaWuwA↓. (M.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] baOobaMCN↓, with medd, [used as an inf. n.,] A woman's dandling, or dancing, of her child. (AA, T.) ＝ -A2- baOobaOa also signifies He (a child) said baOobaOo↓ (M, K) [in some copies of the K written baAbaA, both meaning Papa, or Father,] to his father. (M.) [Accord. to the TA, the verb is trans. in this sense, as in the senses before explained; but I think that baOobaOahu has been there erroneously put for baOobaOa.] ― -b2- And He (a stallion [meaning a stallion-camel]) reiterated the sound of the letter b [or b] in his braying. (M.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] baOobaON↓ [or, more probably, baOobaMCN↓, with medd, agreeably with analogy, used as an inf. n.,] The chiding of the cat, or act of chiding the cat; (AA, T, Sgh;) also termed gasRN. (AA, T.) ＝ -A3- Also He hastened, made haste, or sped: and tabaOobaOonaA↓ we hastened, &c.: (marginal note in a copy of the S:) or tabaOobaOa↓ signifies he ran. (ElUmawee, T, K.)

buWobuWN c
buWobuWN The source, origin, race, root, or stock, syn. OaSolN, (AA, Sh, T, S, M, K,) of a man, (Sh, T,) whether noble or base. (AA, T.) You say, huwa kariymu AlbuWobuWi He is of generous, or noble, origin; lit., generous, or noble, of origin. (TK.) And fulaAnN fiIbuWobuWi Alkarami Such a one is of [a race] the source (OaSol) of generosity, or nobleness. (S. [In the PS, mn is here put in the place of fI: but fI is often used in phrases of the same kind and meaning as that above, in the sense of mino.]) IKh cites from Jereer,
fiI yuWobuWi Almajodi wabuHobuwHi Alkaramo
[Of a race the source of glory, and the very heart of generosity, or nobleness]: but Aboo-'Alee El- Kálee quotes the words thus;
fiI DiYoDiYi Almajodi wa buWobuwoCi Alkaramo
[which may be rendered, of a race the source of glory, and the very root of generosity]; whence it appears that buWobuwCN is a dial. var. of buWobuWN in the sense here given. (TA.) ― -b2- The middle of a thing; (K;) [and app. the heart, or very heart, thereof; the middle as being the best part of a thing;] like buHobuwHN. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, perhaps,]
The pupil, or apple, or the image that is seen reflected in the black, (Eayor AA, T, or UinosaAn K,) of the eye. (AA, T, K.) Whence the saying, huwa OaEazRu EalaIRi mino buWobuWi EayoniI [He is dearer to me than the apple of my eye; a saying common in the present day, with the substitution of UinosaAn for buWobuW]. (TA.) ― -b4- A generous, or noble, (ISk, T,) or a clever, an ingenious, or an accomplished, or a well-bred, or an elegant, (M, K,) and a light, an active, or a sprightly, (M,) lord, master, chief, or personage: (ISk, T, M, K:) fem. with p. (IKh, TA.) ― -b5- Also, (AA, T, S, * [but I find it only in one of three copies of the S,]) or buWobuWoCN↓, and baOobaMCN↓, (K,) the last from the M, (TA, [but it is not in the M as transcribed in the TT,]) A learned man (AA, T, S, K) who teaches; (AA, T;) but the teaching of others is not a condition required in the application of the epithet; (TA;) like sarosuwrN. (S [in which this last word is evidently given as a syn.: but in the K it is given to show the form, only, of buWobuwoCN].) ― -b6- Also The body of a locust, (K,) without the head and legs. (TA.) ― -b7- And, accord. to the K, The head, or uppermost part, of a vessel in which [the collyrium called] kuHol is kept: but it will appear, in art. yO, that this is [perhaps] a mistranscription for yuWoyuWN. (TA.)

baAbuwnajN bAbwnj
baAbuwnajN [from the Persian baAbuwnaho Chamomile; or chamomile-flowers: both called by these names in the present day]: a certain herb, of several different colours; yellow-flowered, and whiteflowered, and purple-flowered: (Avicenna [Ibn-Seenà] i. 139:) i. q. OuqoHuwaAnN: (S, Msb, K, all in art qHw:) i. e. the AqHwAn is the bAbwnj with the Persians: (Msb in that art.:) or the flower of the AqHwAn: (S in art. qrS:) or of the yellow AqHwAn, (TA in art. qrS,) when it has become dry: (S, TA, both in art. qrS:) a well-known flower, of great utility, (K, TA,) or of which the oil is of great utility: (CK:) commonly known in El-Yemen by the name of mwns [app. muWonisN, because of its pleasant odour, or its medical properties]. baOojN c
baOojN, also pronounced baAjN, without C, (IAar, S, Msb, K,) but the former alone is mentioned by Th in the Fs, and is the chaste word, (TA,) arabicized, from the Persian baAhaA, (S,) A sort, or species, (S, K,) of food, or viands. (S.) Hence the saying, AijoEali AlbaOojaAt baUojAF waAHidFA [Make thou the sorts, or species, of food, or viands, to be one sort, or species]: (S, K:) occurring in a trad., in which it is without C in each case, accord. to IDrst: several different sorts of food being brought to 'Omar, he asked respecting them, and it was said, [They are] sikobaAj and zirobaAj and UisofiydobaAj; whereupon he ordered that the bowls should be brought, and their contents were emptied into one; he saying the words above. (Marginal note in a copy of the S.) IKh says that a man would bring various sorts [of food], and one would say, AijoEalohaA bOojAF waAHdiA [Make thou them to be one sort]. (TA.) The pl. is [baOojaAtN, as shown above, as though the sing. were baOojapN, and] OabowaAjN. (Msb, TA.) laOajoEalanRa AlnRaAsa kulRahumo baOojFA waAHidFA is [likewise] a saying of 'Omar, (Msb, TA,) meaning [I will assuredly make the people, all of them, to be] one body or assemblage; baOojN signifying a state of assembling, or collecting together: (Kz, TA:) or [of] one uniform way or mode or manner, (Msb, TA,) as El-Fihree says in the Expos. of the Fs, on the authority of ISd in the book entitled El-'Awees; (TA;) i. e., in respect of gifts, or allowances: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, it is from baOojN or baAjN signifying a uniform line of road. (TA.) You say also, AlnRaAsu baOojN waAHidN The people are [as] one thing. (TA.) And humo fiI OamorK baOojK They are [in one and the same, or] in an equal, or a uniform, case. (K.) And jaEala AlkalaAma baOojAF waAxidFA He made the speech, or language, to be [uniform, or] of one mode, or manner. (TA.) And AijoEalo hecA AlXRaIoCa baOojFA waAHidFA Make thou this thing to be [uniform, or] of one way, or mode, or manner. (ISk.) And AijoEali AlOamora baOojFA waAHidFA Make thou the affair, or case, [uniform, or] one uniform thing. (Fr.)

baAcanojaAnN c
baAcanojaAnN, [or baAcinojaAnN, commonly pronounced in the present day baAdnojaAn and bayodinojaAn and biydinojaAn, from the Persian baAdinokaAno,] a word of well-known meaning, often mentioned by the author of the K, [in explaining the words OanabN and HadaqN and magodN and wagodN,] but not in its proper place in the lexicon. (TA.) [It signifies The solanum melongena, mad-apple, or egg-plant; both the black, distinguished by the epithet Oasowadu, and the white, distinguished by the epithet OaboyaDu. And the solanum lycopersicum, or solanum Aethiopicum; also called love-apple, and so by the Arabs, tufRaAHN AlHubRNi; and golden apple, tufRaAHN cahabiIRN; and tomato; and distinguished from the former species by the epithet OaHomaru, and by the appellation bAcnjAn quwTap.] ― -b2- [baAcanojaAnN tiroyaAqiIRN Xanthium.]

1 baWusa c
1. baWusa, aor. yaboWusu, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. baOosN, (S, Msb, K,) or baOosapN; (M; [so I find in a copy of the M, but perhaps it is a mistranscription for baMsapN;]) and baYisa, [aor. yaboOasu,] inf. n. baOosN; (M;) He was, or became, mighty, or strong, in war or fight; (K;) courageous, or valiant: (M, Msb, K:) or very mighty or strong in war or fight. (AZ, S.) ＝ -A2- baYosu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaboOasu (S, M, K) and yaboYisu, the latter extr., like yanoEimu aor. of naEima, (M,) [and some other instances, (see Hasiba,)] inf. n. buWosN (S, Msb, * K) and buWuwsN and buWosaI (K) and baOosN (TA) and baYysN, (S, K,) [in measure] like OamiyrN, (TA,) [accord. to the CK biYosN, which is a mistake,] and baYiysaI, (TS, TA,) incorrectly written in the copies of the K biYosay; (TA;) or baWusa; (A;) or both these forms; (M;) He was, or became, in a state of distress; straitened in his means of subsistence, or in the conveniences of life; (M, Msb;) in a state of poverty: (M, A, Msb, * TA:) or in a state of pressing want: (S, K, TA:) and baWusa, inf. n. baMsapN and baYiysN, whence the subst. baWosaI, he was, or became, in a state of trial, or affliction: (M:) and [in like manner,] OaboOasa↓, (inf. n. UiboMsN,S,) distress, or poverty, or misfortune, or calamity, (AlbaOosaMCu,) befell him. (IAar, S, * M, TA.) ＝ -A3- biYosa, also written baYisa and biYisa and baOosa, (S, K,) is a word of dispraise or blame, (S,) implying all kinds of dispraise or blame, (TA,) [or superlative dispraise or blame; signifying, Very evil or bad is he, or it: or superlatively evil or bad is he, or it:] contr. of niEma: (S, M, TA:) a pret. verb, imperfectly inflected, (S, K,) like niEoma, (S,) [having only one variation of form, namely, the fem. biYosato, though the masc. is more commonly used even when the agent is fem. or pl.,] because it is translated from its original application, (S, K,) i. e. from baYisa fulaAnN signifying OaSaAba buWosFA [he found, met with, or experienced, distress, &c.], to signify dispraise or blame. (S, TA.) When it is accompanied by a gen. n. without the article Al, this is always in the accus. case: but when the n. has the article Al, it is always in the nom. case: (TA:) you say, biYosa rajulFA zayodF [Very evil or bad, or superlatively evil or bad, as a man, is Zeyd; rjlA being a specificative]: (K:) and biYosa AlrRajulu zayodN [Very evil, &c., is the man, Zeyd]; and biYosati AlmaroOapu hinodN [or more commonly biYosa AlEayoru in this case also, Very evil, &c., is the woman, Hind]. (S.) Some argue that it is a noun, from the saying, niEoma AlsRayoru EalaI biYosa AlEayoru, because it has a prep.; but this is explained as elliptical, and meaning, niEama AlsRayoru EalaI EayorK maquwlK fiyhi biYosa AlEyoru [Excellent is the journeying upon an ass of which it is said Very evil, &c., is the ass]. (I 'Ak p. 232.) Zj says that when it is followed by maA, then maA, with it, is regarded as occupying the place of an indeterminate noun; [namely, XayoYFA, as a specificative; as in the Kur ii. 84,biYosa maA QXotarawA bihi Oanofusahumo, or biYosamaA, &c., Very evil, &c., as a thing, is that for which they have sold, or exchanged, themselves:] (TA:) but some say that it is the agent, and is a determinate noun; and this is the opinion of Ibn-Kharoof, which he ascribes to Sb. (I 'Ak ubi suprà.) [For further illustration, see niEoma.]

DararN (assumed tropical:) [Harm, injury, &c.]: so in the phrase laA baOosa [There is, or will be, no harm, &c.; and laA baOosa bikacaA, and fiI kacaA, (assumed tropical:) There is, or will be, no harm in such a thing]. buWosN (also written buwsN, with the suppressed, Msb) Distress; straitness of the means of subsistence, or of the conveniences of life; poverty: (M, Msb,* TA:*) or a state of pressing want: (S, K:) or misfortune; calamity: (A:) and buWuwsN↓ and buWosaI↓ (K, TA) and baOosaMCu↓ (M, A) and baOosN↓ (TA) and baYiysN↓ (S, K) and baYiysaI↓ (TA) and maboOasapN↓ (M, TA) [all of which, except baOosaMCu↓ and maboOasapN↓, are said to be inf. ns. (see baYisa)] signify the same as buWosN: (S, M, A, K, TA:) buWosaI↓ and baOosaMCu↓ are both from buWosN [with which they are syn. accord. to authorities indicated above]; (Zj, IDrd, TA;) the former is contr. of nuEomaI, (S, TA,) and in like manner the latter is contr. of naEomaMCu: (TA:) the latter is of the measure faEolaMCu without any OafoEalu, because it is a subst.; like as OafoEalu occurs among substs. without any faEalaMCu, as in the instance of OaHomadu: (Akh, S:) or buWosaI↓ signifies a state of trial or affliction, and is a subst.; and baYiysN↓ and baMsapN↓ signify the same, but are inf. ns.: (M:) and baOosaMCu↓ is syn. with XidRapN [like buWosN in the first of the senses explained above]; (S, TA;) and maXaqRapN [meaning distress, or difficulty]: (TA:) or it signifies misfortune, or calamity, (A, K,) like buWosN; (A;) and so OaboWusN: (S, K:) or rather this last signifies misfortunes, or calamities; for it is pl. of baOosN↓, i. e., a pl. of pauc.; not of buWosN, as J asserts it to be; for the pl. of pauc. of buWosN is OaboMsN: (IB, TA:) but OaboWusN may be used as pl. of baOosaMCu↓. (Fr, in S, voce DarRaMCu, q. v.) [See exs. of these two pls. in what follows.] You say yawomu buWosK wayawomu nuEomK [A day of distress, or poverty, &c., and a day of ease and plenty]. (S, TA.) And buWosFA lahu [May distress, or poverty, &c., befall him]: a form of imprecation. (Sb, M, TA.) And buWosa Qboni sumayRapa, app. an expression of pity [meaning Alas for the distress, &c., of Ibn-Sumeiyeh!]. (TA, from a trad.) And EasaIa Alguwayoru OaboWusFA Perhaps the little cave [may be attended with] calamities; not calamity, as in the S [and K]: (IB:) a prov.; (S;) originating from a cave's having collapsed upon some men in it; or from an enemy's having come to some men in a cave, and slain them; wherefore it is applied to anything whence evil is feared: (As, S, K, in art. gwr:) or it is applied to him who is suspected of a thing: (IAar, TA:) or Alguwayoru was the name of a certain water, which belonged to the tribe of Kelb, and the words of this prov. were said by Ez-Zebbà, when Kaseer turned aside from the plain road, and took the way to Alguwayoru: (Ibn-El-Kelbee, S, K, in art. gwr:)AbWsA is in the accus. case by reason of yakuwnu understood. (Mughnee.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 94.] ElKumeyt also says,
qaAluwA OasaMCa banuw kurozK faqulotu lahumo
EasaI Alguwayoru biOaboMsK waOgowaAri
[They said, Benoo-Kurz have done evil: and I said to them, Perhaps the little cave may be attended with calamities and connected with other caves]: OaboMs is here pl. of buWos. (IB, TA.) [In the S, the last words are written biUiboMsK waUiEowaArK, in one copy: in another, wUigowaAri: both of which are app. wrong.] ― -b2- See also baAYisN.

babogaMCu (Msb, K) and babRagaMCu (K, Kzw) [in modern vulgar Arabic babagaAn, The parrot;] a certain well-known bird; (Msb;) a certain green bird, (Sgh, K, TA,) well known; (TA;) the bird called in Persian TuwTiy, beautiful in colour and form, mostly green, but in some instances red, and yellow, and white; having a thick bill and tongue: it hears the speech of men and repeats it, without knowing its meaning; and utters letters rightly: when they desire to teach it, they put a mirror in its cage, so that it sees therein its own form, and they speak to it from behind the mirror, and when it hears, it repeats, desiring to do as its like; and thus it learns quickly: one of the wonders relating to it is [said to be this], that it never drinks water; for if it drank, it would die: (Kzw:) the affix renders fem. the word, but not the thing named thereby, like the p in HamaAmapN and naEaAmapN; for the word applies to the male and the female, so that one says, babogaMCu cakarN [a male parrot] and babogaMCu OunovaI [a female parrot]: and the pl. is babogaAwaAtN [or babRagaAwaAtN], like as SaHoraAwatN is pl. of SaHoraMCu. (Msb.)

(Mgh.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) In want, or poor. (M, K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Suffering loss; syn. xaAsirN. (M, K.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) One from whom all good, or prosperity, is cut off. OabotaEu c
OabotaEu: see batiEN, in three places. ＝ -A2- It is also a word used as a corroborative: you say, jaAWuwA OajomaEuwna OakotaEuwna OabotaEuwna [They came, all of them, or all together]: (S:) and jaMCa Alqawomu OakotaEuwna OabotaEuwna OaboSaEuwna [the people, or company of men, came, all of them, or all together]: (AHeyth:) and jaAWuwA kulRuhumo OajomaEuwna OakotaEuwna OabotaEuwna [they came, all of them, all together]: these words which follow AjmEwn being imitative sequents to it, not occurring save after it [in the order above]: (O, K:) or one may begin with whichsoever of them he will, after it. (Ibn-Keysán, K.) And [the fem. is batoEaMCu:] you say Alqabiylapu kulRuhaA jamoEaMCu katoEaMCu baSoEaMCu batoEaMCu [The tribe, all of it, all together: in the CK, erroneously, kuvoEMCu (with damm and v) and buSoEACu and butoEACu]. (K.) And [the pl. of batoEaMCu is butaEu↓, originally batoEaAwaAtN:] you say AlnRisaMCu
kulRuhunRa jumaEu kutaEu buSaEu butaEu [The women, all of them, all together: in the CK, erroneously, jumaEN kutaEN buSaEN butaEN, though it is well known that each of these is determinate, and imperfectly declinable]. (K.) It is only necessary that he who mentions all these words should mention first kulR, and follow it with the word formed from j m E, then add the rest in whatsoever order he will; but the more approved way is to put the word formed from k t E before the rest. (TA.) Fr mentions the phrases OaEojabniI AlqaSoru OajomaEa [The palace pleased me, all of it, or altogether], and AldRaAru jamoEaMCa [the house, all of it, or altogether], with the accus. case, as denotative of state; but does not allow OajomaEuwna nor jumaEu to be used otherwise than as corroboratives: IDrst, however, allows OajomaEiyna to be used as a denotative of state; and this is correct; and accord. to both these ways is related the trad., faSalRuwA juluwsFA OajomaEiyna and OajomaEuwna [And pray ye sitting, all of you, or all together]; though some make AjmEyn [here] to be a corroborative of a pronoun understood in the accus. case, as though the speaker said, OaEoniykumo OajomaEiyna [I mean you, all of you, or all together]. (K.) [But see OajomEu.]

(MF.) [See, under the words qado and qaTo, what is said respecting qadoniI and qaToniI.] In the saying of Jábir Ibn-Ra-lán Es-Simbisee,
lamRaA raOato maEoXarFA qalRato Hamuwlatuhumo

[When she saw a company whose beasts of burden were few, So'ád said, Is this your property, sufficing you?] meaning, when she saw the fewness of our camels: the last word occupies the place of a denotative of state, and is made to end thus by poetic license: Abu-l-'Alà says that this word may be put in the accus. case as meaning not exceeding what I see; or it may be for bajaliI, after the manner of some of the Arabs who are related, by Akh and others, to have said gulaAmaA for gulaAmiI. (Ham pp. 299 and 300.) [See also 2: and see bajalN.] ＝ -A2- It is also a particle, (Mughnee,) meaning naEamo [Yes; yea; or even so]. (Mughnee, K.)

like SabuwrN; (TA;) or, accord. to some, suwrapu AlbuHuwvi, (L,) pl. of baHovi; (TA;) a name of The chapter of the Kur-án called suwrapu AltRawobapi, (L, K,) and AlbaraMCapi; (L;) [chap. ix.;] given to it because it inquires respecting the hypocrites and their secrets. (L.)

baHiyvN Hyv bHyv
baHiyvN: see baHovN. ― -b2- A secret: whence the prov., badaA baHiyvuhumo [Their secret became apparent, or revealed]. (TA. [But in the S, in art. njv, q. v., we find badaA najiyvu Alqawomi; and so in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 159.])

buHaAvapN bAHv bHAv bHAvh bHAvp

AlbuHayovaI AlbHyvI AlbHyvy
AlbuHayovaI: see AlbuHovapu.

baAHivN bAHv
baAHivN [act. part. n. of 1; Scraping up dust or earth: &c.]. kaAlbaAHivi Eani AlXRaforapi [Like him who is scraping up the dust, or earth, from over the great knife with which he is to be slaughtered,] is a prov.: (S, L:) and so kabaAHivapK Eano HatofihaA biZilofihaA [Like one searching for her death with her hoof]: originating from the fact of a ewe's digging up a knife in the dust, or earth, and then being slaughtered with it. (L.)

baAHivaMCu bAHvMC

maboHavN mbHv
maboHavN A place, and a time, of scraping up or digging; of searching, inquiring, investigating, scrutinizing, or examining: pl. mabaAHivu. (KL.) You say, tarakotuhu bimabaAHivi Albaqari (S, K*) [I left him in the places where the wild oxen scrape up the ground]; meaning, in a desert place, destitute of herbage, or of human beings; (S, K;) in an unknown place; (K;) i. e., so that it was not known where he was. (S.)

Q. 1 baHovara bHvr
Q. 1. baHovara, [inf. n. baHovarapN,] He took, drew, or pulled, a thing out, or forth; and uncovered it, laid it open, or exposed it; (Abu-l-Jarráh, S, K;) as also baEovara. (Abu-l-Jarráh, S.) It is said in the Kur [c. 9], accord. to one reading, buEovira buHovira maA fiI Alqubuwri, [instead of buEovira,] meaning [When that which is in the graves is taken forth and uncovered; i. e.,] when the dead are raised to life; syn. buEiva; and it is not improbable that baHovara may be composed of baHava and Oavara [app. a mistranscription for OavaAra], accord. to the opinion of those who hold that quadriliteral and quinqueliteral words are composed of two. (TA.) ― -b2- He searched, or sought, for, or after, a thing in the dust or earth, or the like; syn. baHava [which Ibr D thinks may be a mistake for baEava: but see baEovara]. (L, K, and Bd in c. 9.) ― -b3- He separated, disunited, scattered, dispersed, or dissipated, (S, K,) a thing. (S.) He scattered, or dispersed, his household goods, or his commodities, and turned them over, one upon another; as also baEovara. (Fr, S.) ＝ -A2- It (milk) curdled, or coagulated, and formed little clots of curd; syn. taqaTRaEa wa taHabRaba. (S, K.)

Q. 2 tabaHovara bHvr tbHvr
Q. 2. tabaHovara It (a thing, S) became separated, disunited, scattered, dispersed, or dissipated. (S, K.)

labanN mubaHovirN lbn mbHvr
labanN mubaHovirN Milk curdling, or coagulating, and forming little clots of curd. (K. [See Q. 1.]) When the upper portion is thick and the lower thin, it is termed haAdirN. (TA.)

,] inf. n. baHorN, (K,) He slit; cut, or divided, lengthwise; split; or clave; (K, TA;) and enlarged, or made wide. (TA.) Hence the term baHorN [as meaning “ a sea ” or “ great river ”] is said to be derived, because what is so called is cleft, or trenched, in the earth, and the trench is made the bed of its water. (TA.) ― -b2- baHarahaA, (M,) or baHara OucunahaA, (S, A, Msb,) aor.
baHara
, (M, Msb,) inf. n. baHorN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He slit her (a camel's, S, M, A, Msb, and a sheep's or goat's, M) ear, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) in halves, or in halves lengthwise, (M, TA,) widely; (B;) and in like manner, baHarahu he slit his (a camel's) ear widely: (B:) and bHRr↓ McaAna AlOanoEaAmi, inf. n. taboHiyrN, He slit [&c.] the ears of the cattle. (Az, TA in art. btk.) ＝ -A2- [baHura, aor.

, inf. n. baHaArapN, It was, or became, wide, or spacious. The inf. n. is mentioned in the A: see baHorN: and see also 10.]

4. AbHr He embarked [or voyaged] upon the sea or a great river. (Yaakoob, S, M, K.) [Opposed to OabarRa.] ― -b2- (tropical:) It (water, K, sweet water S, A) was, or became, salt. (S, A, * K.) ― -b3- OaboHarati AlOaroDu The land abounded with places where water stagnated. (T, K. * [In the latter, manaAfiEuhaA is put by mistake for manaAqiEuhaA. See baHorapN.]) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) He found water to be salt; not easy, or pleasant, to be drunk. (K, TA. [In some copies of the K, for lamo yasugo, we find lamo yamotaniEo, which is evidently a mistake.]) ＝ -A3- He met, or met with, a man unintentionally: (M, K:) from the phrase, laqiytuhu SaHorapa baHorapa. (TA.)

5. tbHRr: see 10. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a pastor) took a wide range in abundant pasturage. (TA.) ― -b3- tbHRr fiI AlmaAli (tropical:) He enlarged himself, or he became, or made himself, ample, or abundant, in wealth, or camels, or the like; (K, * TA;) as also fyhAstbHr↓. (TA.) ― -b4- tbHRr fiI AlEilomi (tropical:) He went deep into science, or knowledge, and enlarged himself, or took a wide range, therein, (S, A, K,) wide as the sea; (TA;) and in like manner one says with respect to other things: (S:) and so fyh AstbHr↓. (A, TA.)

10 AstbHr OstbHr AstbHr QstbHr
10. AstbHr (tropical:) It (a place) became wide, or spacious, like the sea: (A:) it spread wide; became expanded; (K;) as also tbHRr↓. (TA.) [See also baHura.] ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a poet, A, K, and a xaTiyb, [i. e. a speaker, an orator, or the like,] A) expatiated in speech; was, or became, diffuse therein. (M, A, K.) ― -b3- See also 5, in two places.

baHorN Hr bHr
baHorN [A sea: and a great river:] a spacious place comprising a large quantity of water; (B;) a large quantity of water, (K, TA,) whether salt or sweet; (TA;) contr. of barRN; (S, A;) so called because of its depth (S, TA) and large extent; (S, Msb, TA;) from AlbaHaArapu; (A;) or because its bed is trenched in the earth; see 1: (TA:) or a large quantity of salt water, only; (K;) and so called because of its saltness: (El-Umawee, TA: [but accord. to the A, this word as an epithet meaning “ salt ” is tropical:]) or rather this is its general meaning: (TA:) for it signifies also any great river; (S, M, TA;) any river of which the water does not cease to flow; (Zj, T, TA;) such as the Euphrates, for instance; (S;) or such as the Tigris, and the Nile, and other similar great rivers of sweet water; of which the great salt baHor is the place of confluence; so called because trenched in the earth: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaboHurN and [of mult.] biHaArN and buHuwrN. (S, Msb, K.) The dim. is OubayoHirN↓, (K,) which is anomalous; and buHayorN↓, which is the regular form: accord. to the K, the latter is not used; but this is untrue; for it is sometimes used, though rare. (MF.) ― -b2- Hence its application in the saying of the Arabs, yaA haAdiIa AllRayoli jurota UinRamaA huwa AlbaHoru Oawi Alfajoru, which Th explains by saying that the meaning is, (tropical:) [O guide of the night, thou hast deviated from the right way:] it is only destruction or thou wilt see the daybreak: the night is here likened to the sea [and with the night is associated the idea of destruction]: but accord. to one recital, it is Albajoru, instead of AlbaHoru. (TA. [See art. bjr.]) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) Salt; as an epithet, applied to water. (S, A.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse; (As, K;) that runs much; (As, TA;) that takes a wide range in his running; (S, A, Msb, B;) that runs like the sea, or a great river; or like the sea, or a great river, when it rolls wave over wave. (Niftaweyh;, TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A generous man; (K, TA;) one who takes a wide range in his beneficence, bounty, or kindness; who abounds therein. (TA.) You say, laqiytu bizayodK baHorFA (tropical:) [I found, in the place of Zeyd, a man of abundant generosity or beneficence]: b here denoting substitution. (The Lubáb cited in the TA voce bi.) And laqiytu minohu baHorFA (tropical:) [I found him to be a man of exceeding generosity]; a phrase expressing an intensive degree of generosity: and raOayotu minohu baHorFA [signifies the same]. (Mughnee in art. bi.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A man of extensive knowledge or science; one who takes a wide range in his knowledge or science. (B.) ― -b7- (tropical:) Any person, or thing, that takes a wide range in a thing. (B.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Land of seed-produce and fruitfulness; or a tract, or region, in which are green herbs or leguminous plants, and waters; or the part of a country near to water; syn. riyfN: (Aboo-' Alee, K:) and the dim. buHayorN↓ is used in the same sense; or, by poetic licence, for buHayorapN↓. (TA.) So in the Kur [xxx. 40], Zahara AlfasaAdu fiI AlbarRi wa AlbaHori (assumed tropical:) [Corruption hath appeared in the desert, or deserts,
and in the land of seed-produce and fruitfulness; &c.]: (Aboo-'Alee, TA:) or the meaning here is, [in the desert, or deserts, and in the towns, or villages, in which is water: (see barRN:) or in the open country and] in the cities [or towns] upon the rivers; by sterility in the former, and scarcity in the latter: (Zj, TA, and T in art. br:) or in the land and the sea; i. e., the land has become sterile, or unfruitful, and the supply of the sea has become cut off. (Az, TA.) See also baHorapN. ― -b9- Also, AlbaHoru, (S, K,) or baHoru AlrRaHimi, (A, Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) The bottom (Eumoq, S, A, Mgh, K, or qaEor, IAth, TA) of the womb; fundus uteri: (S, A, Mgh, K:) whence blood of a pure red colour, (S,) or intensely red, (Mgh,) is termed baHoraAniIRN (S, Mgh) and baAHirN. (S.)

baHorapN Hr Hrp bHr bHrh bHrp
baHorapN A wide tract of land: so accord. to Aboo-Nasr: but in one place he says, a small valley in rugged land: pl. biHaArN. (TA.) ― -b2- A land, country, or territory, belonging to, or inhabited by, a people; syn. balodapN. (S, K.) One says, hecihi baHoratunaA This is our land, &c.; syn. OaroDunaA. (S.) It occurs also in the dim. form [buHayorapN↓], as in the Towsheeh of El-Jelál. (TA.) ― -b3- Any town, or village, that has a running river and wholesome water: (K:) and [absolutely] any town, or village: of such the Arabs say, hecihi baHoratunaA This is our town, or village: and the pl. biHaArN they apply to cities, as well as towns, or villages. (TA.) ― -b4- Low, or depressed, land: (IAar, K:) occurring also in the dim. form [buHayorapN↓]. (TA.) ― -b5- A meadow; or a garden; syn. rawoDapN: (T, TA:) or one that is large, (K,) and wide. (TA.) ― -b6- A place where water stagnates. (Sh, K.) ― -b7- The pl. is baHorN↓, (as in some copies of the K, [or this is a coll. gen. n. of which baHorapN is the n. un.,]) or biHarN, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) or buHorN, (as in the CK,) and biHaArN. (K.) ＝ -A2- laqiytuhu SaHorapa baHorapa, (S, K,) and SuHorapa buHorapa↓, as in the Expositions of the Tesheel, &c., (MF,) and SaHorapF baHorapF, (K,) and SuHorapF buHorapF↓, (MF,) I met him out, with nothing intervening between me and him; (S, L;) both of us being exposed to open view; (TA;) without anything concealing, or intervening. (K, TA.) SHrpa bHrpa, without tenween, is a compound denotative of state; not, as some say, consisting of two inf. ns.: and sometimes naHorapF is added; in which case each of the three words is with tenween, decl.; and they do not form a compound. (MF. [But see SaHorap.)]

SuHorapa buHorapa SHrp bHrh SHrp bHrp
SuHorapa buHorapa and SuHorapF buHorapF: see baHorapN.

baHoriIRN Of, or relating to, or belonging to, the sea, or a great river; rel. n. of baHorN. (S, K.) ― -b2- A seaman; a sailor; (TA;) as also baHRaArN↓: (K:) and [baHoriyRapN↓ and] baHRaArapN↓ seamen; sailors. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [In the dial. of Egypt, North; northern; because the Mediterranean Sea lies on the north of that country: like as, in Hebrew, יָם signifies “ west; ” because that sea lies on the west of Palestine.]

baHoriyRapN Hr Hry Hryp bHr bHry bHryh bHryp
baHoriyRapN: see baHoriIRN.

buHoraAnN HrAn bHr bHrAn
buHoraAnN, a post-classical word, (S, K,) used by the physicians, signifying The crisis of a disease; the sudden change which happens to a sick person, (S, TA,) and the commencement of convalescence, (TA,) in acute diseases; (S, TA;) at a time fixed by some motion in the heavenly bodies, mostly by a motion of the moon; being a change to health or to the contrary: a word [said to be] of Greek origin. (The Nuzheh of the sheykh Dáwood El-Antákee, cited in the TA.) [Pl. baHaAriynu.] They say, hecaA yawomu buHoraAnK and yawomN baAHuwriIRN↓ [This is the day of a crisis of a disease]: bAHwrIR being anomalous: (S, K:) [perhaps from AlbaAHuwru signifying “ the moon, ” because the crisis of a disease is thought to be mostly fixed by a motion of the moon: or] as though it were a rel. n. of baAHuwrN and baAHuwraMCu meaning the “ vehemence of heat in [the month of] tamRuwz. ” (S.)

damN baHoraAniIRN dm bHrAnI dm bHrAny
damN baHoraAniIRN (assumed tropical:) Blood of the menses; accord. to El-Kutabee: or (assumed tropical:) intensely red blood: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) intensely red, and thick, and abundant, menstrual blood: (IAth:) or (tropical:) black blood: (A:) or, as also damN baAHirN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) (assumed tropical:) blood of the womb: (K:) or (assumed tropical:) blood of a pure red colour: (S, M, K:) or (assumed tropical:) such blood from the belly: (M:) or (assumed tropical:) pure blood of an intensely red colour: (Msb:) both from AlbaHoru signifying “ the bottom of the womb: ”: (S:) the former is a rel. n. therefrom, (A, IAth, Msb,) in which the A and n are added to give intensiveness to the signification, (IAth,) or to distinguish it from the rel. n. of AlbaHoru [in its most common sense]: (Msb:) or it is a rel. n. of AlbaHoru [in its most common sense], because of its abundance. (IAth.) ― -b2- OaHomaru baHoraAniIRN, and baAHirN↓, (TA,) and baAHiriIRN↓, (IAar, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Intense red. (TA.)

buHayorN Hyr bHyr
buHayorN dim. of baHorN, which see, in two places.

baHiyrapN Hyr Hyrp bHyrh bHyrp
baHiyrapN A she-camel having her ear slit: (S, * A, Msb, K *:) [and, as a subst., or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] a she-camel of which the mother was a saAYibap; (Fr, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) i. e., of which the mother had brought forth ten females consecutively before her, and of which the ear was slit; (Mgh;) or of which the mother had brought forth five, of which five the last, if a male, was slaughtered and eaten, but if a female, her ear was slit and she was left with her mother; (Mgh, * Msb;) the predicament of which was the same as that of her mother; (Fr, S, K;) i. e., what was unlawful with respect to her mother was unlawful with respect to herself: (TA:) or a she-camel, or ewe, or she-goat, that had brought forth five young ones, and of which the fifth, if a male, was slaughtered, and its flesh was eaten by the men and women; but if a female, her ear was slit, and it was unlawful to the Arabs to eat her flesh and to drink her milk and to ride her; but when she died, her flesh was lawful to the women: (K:) so says Az, on the authority of Ibn-'Arafeh: (TA: [but it appears from the explanation in the Msb, quoted above, that it was the slit-eared young she-camel here mentioned, not the mother, that was thus termed:]) or a she-camel, or ewe, or she-goat, which, having brought forth ten young ones, had her ear slit, (K,) and no use was made of her milk nor of her back, (TA,) and she was left at liberty to pasture, (K,) and to go to water, (TA,) and her flesh, when she died, was made unlawful to the women of the Arabs, but was eaten by the men: (K:) or one that was left at liberty, without a pastor: (K:) or, as some say, syn. with saAYibapN; i. e., say they, a she-camel which, having brought forth seven young ones, had her ear slit, and was not ridden, nor used for carrying: (Msb:) or a she-camel that had brought forth five young ones, the last of which was a male, in which case her ear was slit, and she was exempted from being ridden and from carrying and from being slaughtered, and not prevented from taking of any water to which she came, nor from any pasturage, nor even ridden by a weary man who, having become unable to proceed in his journey, his means having failed him, or his camel that bore him stopping with him from fatigue or breaking down or perishing, might chance to find her: (Aboo-Is- hák the Grammarian, TA: [and the like, but less fully, is said in the Mgh:]) or, applied specially to a ewe, or she-goat, one that, having brought forth five young ones, had her ear slit: (L, K, TA: [in the CK, for buHirat is put nuHirat:]) it also signifies a she-camel (L) abounding in milk: (L, K:) the pl. is baHaAYiru and buHurN; (L, K;) the latter a strange form of pl. of a fem. sing. such as bHyrp; and said to be the only instance of the kind except SurumN pl. of SariymapN, meaning “ having her ear cut off. ” (TA.) It is said in a trad., that the person who instituted the practices relative to the bHyrp and the HaAmiI, and the first who altered the religion of Ishmael, was 'Amr the son of Loheí the son of Kama'ah the son of Jundab; and these practices are forbidden in the Kur v. 102. (TA.)

buHayorapN Hyr Hyrp bHyrh bHyrp
buHayorapN A small sea; a lake: as though they imagined the word baHorapN [as syn. with baHorN]: otherwise there is no reason for the p. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also baHorN: and see baHorapN, in two places.

baHRaArN HAr bHAr bHr
baHRaArN: see baHoriIRN.

baHRaArapN HAr HArp bHAr bHArh bHArp bHr
baHRaArapN: see baHoriIRN.

baAHirN OHr bAHr bOHr
baAHirN: see baHoraAniIRN, in three places.

baAHiriIRN OHr OHrI bAHrI bAHry bOHrI bOHry bOHryy
baAHiriIRN: see baHoraAniIRN, in three places.

baAHuwrN OHwr bAHwr bOHwr
baAHuwrN and baAHuwraMCu↓ The vehemence of heat in [the Syrian month of] tamRuwz or tamuwz [corresponding to July, O. S.]: (S, K:) [pl. of the former bawaAHiyru:] both are [said to be] post-classical words: (S:) but they are [classical words,] arabicized; for they occur in verses of the kind called rajaz of some of the [early] Arabs. (MF.) ＝ -A2- AlbaAHuwru The moon. (Aboo-' Alee, K.)

baAHuwraMCu bAHwrMC
baAHuwraMCu: see baAHuwrN.

baAHuwriIRN OHwr bAHwrI bAHwry bOHwry bOHwryy
baAHuwriIRN: see buHoraAnN.

OubayoHirN c
OubayoHirN: dim. of baHorN, q. v. (K.)

R. Q. 1 baxobaxa bxbx
R. Q. 1. baxobaxa, (S, K,) inf. n. baxobaxapN and bixobaAxN, (TA,) [a verb imitative of the sound
which it signifies,] He (a camel [in a state of excitement]) brayed, (S, K,) so that his XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag] filled his mouth: (S:) or, as some say, began to bray. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] He (a man) said [baxo] or baxo baxo [&c.]. (TA, and Har p. 556.) ― -b3- And [hence,] baxobaxa biSuHobatiI He rejoiced in my company. (Har ubi suprà.) ― -b4- And baxobaxa AlrRajula He said baxo or baxo baxo &c. to the man. (S.)

baxo bx
baxo, (S, A, K, &c.,) [in some copies of the K written baxRa, which is wrong, for it is] like balo, (A,) [i. e.] like qado, (TA,) [perhaps, as I have suggested above, from the sound made by a hecamel in a state of excitement,] a word used on the occasion of praising; (S, A;) on praising one from whom has proceeded a good and wonderful action; (Har p. 142;) on approving a thing; (T, S, Msb, K;) on being pleased with it, or having one's admiration excited by it; (A, K;) or on the occasion of glorying and of praising; (K;) in pronouncing a thing great in estimation, (IAmb,) or excellent; (AHeyth;) in deeming a thing great in estimation, (AHei,) or good; (Mgh;) or it means wonder, or admiration; (R;) and sometimes it is used [ironically] to denote disapproval; also, as an exhortation to gentleness with a thing, and to taking extraordinary pains; (TA;) and in a case of expertness, or skilfulness: (AHei:) it means niEoma AlrRajulu and niEoma AlfiEolu [Excellent, or most excellent, is the man! and, the deed!]; (Har p. 142;) [or simply, excellent! or most excellent! how good! how goodly! well done! bravo! and the like;] or EaZuma AlOamoru and faxuma [great in estimation is the thing, or affair, or event, or case!]: (K:) MF observes, [probably from finding baxRa in the place of baxo in his copy or copies of the K,] that this explanation is like an express assertion that it is a verb in the pret. tense, which requires consideration. (TA.) It is used alone; and in this case you say, baxo, (K,) and baxi, (Msb, K,) with kesr for its invariable termination, (Msb,) and baxK, and baxN; (K, TA; [but in the CK, in the place of baxK and baxN, we find buxN;]) without tesh-deed, (T, Msb,) in most cases; (Msb;) but also with teshdeed, (T, S, A,) like a noun; so that one says, baxK laka and baxRK [&c., meaning I say excel-lent! &c., to thee]: (S:). and one repeats it, (S, A, K, &c.,) for the sake of emphasis; (S, A;) saying, baxo baxo, (IAmb, S, A, K, &c.,) with the x quiescent like the l in halo and balo, (IAmb,) and baxK baxK, (S, A, R, K,) pronounced in the latter manner, with tenween, when in connexion with a following word, [and in this case only, whereas it is pronounced in the former manner in any case,] (S, A,) and baxRK baxRK, (S, * A, * R, K,) and baxK baxo, (K,) and baxRi baxRi. (R.)

jamalN baxobaAxu Alhadiyri A camel that fills his mouth with his XiqoXiqap [or faucial bag] when he brays. (S.)

UibilN muboxobaxapN Camels to which one says baxo baxo; being pleased with them: (ISd, TA:) or largebellied camels; (K;) as also muxaboxabapN, which is formed from the former by transposition; from baxo baxo, or baxK baxo, which is said by the Arabs in praising a thing; as though, by reason of their greatness, the people, seeing them, said, How goodly are they! (TA.)

baAxisN Any one who acts wrongfully, or unjustly. (TA.) It is said in a prov., taHosibuhaA HamoqaMCa wa hiIa baAxisN; (S, A, K;) so runs the prov.; but accord. to Th, (S,) you may also say baAxisapN; (S, K;) i. e., [Thou thinkest her stupid,] but she is wrongful, or unjust: applied to him who feigns himself to be of weak understanding when he is crafty and cunning. (K, TA.) The origin of the prov. was this: a man of the Benu-l-' Ambar, of Temeem, mixed his property with that of a woman, coveting the possession of it, and thinking that she was stupid, and that she did not take care of her property nor know it: then he made a division with her, after he had mixed; but she was not content with the division until she took her property: she complained of him to those in authority, so that he released himself from her by giving her what she desired of the property: and the man was reproved for his conduct; it being said to him, “ Thou cheatest a woman: is not this wrongful conduct (baxos)? ” whereupon he replied in the words above, which became a proverb. (Th, K, * TA.)

AbdR fiyhimu AlEaTaMC, (As, T,) and AbdR bayonahumo AlEaTaMCa, (S, M, L, K,) and OabadRahumo AlEaTaMCa, (M, A, Mgh,) He divided among them the gift, giving to each of them his lot, or share, or portion, (S, M, A, Mgh, L, K,) singly, not giving a portion to be shared by two: (As, T, M, * Mgh, L:) said with respect to food and property and any other thing. (M.) You say, Oabodadotuhumo AlmaAla wa AlTRaEaAma I divided among them, in shares, the property and the food. (IAar, T.) [Hence,] OabidRiyhimo tamorapF tamorapF (T, S, A, Mgh, from a trad.) [Give thou to each of them a date; or] distribute thou among them to each a date: (T:) said by Umm-Selemeh, (T, A, Mgh,) to a slave-girl, when beggars had become numerous. (A.) UibodaAdN in relation to a gift signifies The giving [persons] one by one; and qiraAnN, the “ giving two by two. ” (A 'Obeyd, T.) [See also 3.] ― -b2- yubidRuhumo is used by a poet, referring to a saying, and is explained by IAar as meaning It (the saying) shall be distributed among them (yufRarqu fiyhimo); opposed to yajomaEu [i. e. yajomaEuhumo; which shows that the former means it shall be addressed to them one by one, or separately]. (M, TA. [The author of the former adds, “ I know not, in discourse, Oabodadotuhu as meaning farRaqotuhu: ” but this is not what I Aar means.]) ― -b3- OabidRahumaA naEojatayona Allot thou to them (namely, two lambs,) two ewes, to each lamb a ewe, to suckle it: said when one ewe is not sufficient for both the lambs. (T, * S.) ― -b4- AbdR DaboEayohi He extended his upper arms, separating them from his sides, in prostrating himself in prayer. (T, A, Mgh, L.) ― -b5- AbdR yadahu Uilay AlOaroDi He extended his arm, or hand, to the ground, or earth, (T, S, Mgh, L,) as one does when he takes up something from it. (L.) ― -b6- AbdR naZarahu He prolonged his look. (T, L.) And AbdRhu baSarahu (T, A, L) He prolonged his look at him, or it; as one does when he sees a thing that he dislikes. (T, L.)

AstbdR He was, or became, alone; independent of others; (S, M, L, Msb, K; in the first and last expl. by tafarRada; and in the others, by Ainofarada;) exclusively of others; (L;) without any to share, or participate, with him; or he had none to share, or participate, with him: (Msb:) bihi [in it; i. e. he had it, or kept it, to himself, exclusively, with none to share with him in it]: (K:) and bikacaA [in such a thing]: (S, L:) and biraOoyihi [in his opinion; i. e. he followed his own opinion only, with none to agree with him; or he was singular in his opinion]: (M, L:) and biOamorK [in a thing, or an affair]: (L, Msb:) and biOamorihi [in his affair]; meaning he obtained [absolute] predominance, or control, over his affair, so that people would not hear [or obey] any other. (A.) It is said in a trad., kunRaA naray OanRa lanaAfiIi hecaA AlOamori HaqRaA faQsotabadotumo EalayonaA [We used to opine that we had a right to act in this affair, and ye have been alone the actors, predominant over us]. (IAth, and Ham p. 823.) ― -b2- Also the first, A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in the place of, or in exchange for, another thing; a compensation; syn. jaMCati Alxayolu badaAdi; (T, S;) in which bdAd is indecl., with kesr for its termination because it deviates from its original form, i. e., the inf. n. badadN; and it is indecl. because it deviates from its original form and is of the fem. gender and has the quality of an epithet; for two of these causes render it imperfectly decl., and the three render it indecl.; (S;) or badaAdi badaAdi, and badaAda badaAda, (Lh, M, K,) the last indecl. with fet-h for its termination, (TA,) and badada badada↓, (Lh, M, K,) also indecl., with fet-h, (TA,) and composed in the same manner as xamosapa EaXara, (Lh, M, TA,) and badadFA badadFA↓; (Lh, M, K;) all of these indecl. except the last, and each virtually in the accus. case as a denotative of state, except the last, (MF,) which is literally in the accus. case, as an inf. n.; (M, MF;) The horses, or horsemen, came in a state of dispersion: (T, S, M, K:) or one by one; or one after another. (T, L.) And tafRrRaqa Alqawomu badaAd The people, or company of men, became separated, in a state of dispersion. (S.) And cahaba Alqawomu badaAdi badAdi The people, or company of men, went away [in a state of dispersion; or] one by one; or one after another. (T, L.) [See also OabaAdiyd.] It is said in a form of prayer, AallehumRa OaHoSihimo EadadFA Qqotulohumo badadFA↓ [O God, slay them one by one, and reckon them by number]: (M:) or OaHoSihimo EadadFA wa QloEanohumo bidadFA, or, accord. to one recital, waQqotulohumo bidadFA, pl. of bidRapN↓, the meaning being [reckon them by number, and] curse them, or slay them, with a cursing, or slaughter, distributed among them by shares. (Mgh.) ― -b2- yaA qawomi badaAdi badaAdi means O my people, take each one of you his adversary, or opponent [with whom to fight]. (As, T, S, K. *) Here bdAd is indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is an imperative verbal noun, and the imperative is alike uninfluenced with respect to its termination by any governing word; and it is said to be with kesr because two quiescent letters would otherwise occur together, [and] because it occupies the place of an imperative verb [which in like manner is terminated with kesr when it is necessary to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together]. (S.) ― -b3- With the article, you say, AlbadaAdu, (As, T,) which signifies The going forth to encounter another in fight, or to single combat; as in the saying, lawo kaAna AlbadaAdu lamaA OaTaAquwnaA Had we gone forth to encounter them in fight, (As, T, S, K,) man to man, [they had not been able to cope with us;] (As, T;) or man by man. (S, K.) You say also, laquwA badaAdahumo, explained above: see 6. ＝ -A2- See also budRN. ＝ -A3- And see 3.
