baAdRN The inner side of the thigh: (M, A, K:) or the part of the horseman's thigh that is next the saddle: (T, M, A, L:) or the part between the legs: (M, L:) the inner sides of the two thighs are called the baAdRaAni, (S,) because the saddle separates them; (IAar, M;) and if so, baAdRN is of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; or it may be a possessive epithet [meaning cuw badRK]. OabadRN A man wide between the thighs, (ISk, S, M, K,) by reason of abundance of flesh: (ISk, S, M:) or wide between the arms; (K;) having the arms far from the sides: (M:) or wide between the shoulder-joints: (M:) or (so in the K; but accord. to the S, “and”) large in make, (T, S, M, K,) having one part far from another: (M, K:) and wide in the breast: (Aboo-Málik, T:) fem. badRaMCu: (S:) which also signifies a woman (M, L) large in the UisokataAni [or labia majora of the vulva], (M, L, K,) having their edges far apart: (M, L:) or having much flesh in the thighs. (T, L.) AlOabadRN is used to signify The weaver, (T, M, K,) because of the distance between his thighs. (M.) The following saying, (K,) quoted by J, from the rájiz Aboo-Nukheyleh Es-Saadee,
OaladRu yamoXiI miXayapa AlOabadRi
is incorrect, and should be thus,
badRaMCu tamoXiI miXoyapa AlOabadRi
[A woman of large make, walking in the manner of the man of large make; or a woman wide between the thighs, &c.]; (K;) for it is descriptive of a woman, as IB and Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee have observed before the author of the K. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A horse [or any quadruped (see badRa)] having the fore legs far apart: (M, K:) or having the fore legs far from the sides: (TA:) or wide between the legs: (Ham p. 348:) and a camel having the elbows far from the sides: (TA:) and the fem. badRaMCu, a cow having her fore legs far apart. (S.) [Hence,] AlOabadRu AlzRaniymu [in the CK AlrRaviymu] The lion; (M, K;) the former epithet being applied to him because his fore legs are far apart, and the latter because he is [often] alone. (TA.) ― -b2- cahabuwA OabaAdiydu, (M, K,) and tabaAdiydu↓, (K,) or yabaAdiydu↓, (as in the T, from Fr, and in the M and L, and in some copies of the K, [but see above,]) [as also OanaAdiydu, and yanaAdiydu, or tanaAdiydu,] They went away in a state of dispersion. badaAa
, (Mgh, K,) inf. n. badoCN, (T, S, M, Msb,) i. q. bh AbtdO↓; (S, Msb, K;) [He began with it;] he made it to have precedence, or to be first; gave precedence to it; syn. qadRamahu: (Mgh, Msb:) in the dial. of the Ansár, badiYa bh is used in this sense of qdRmh; (M;) or badiIa bh [without C]; (IKtt, TA; [see badpCN;]) [and badaI bh; see art. bdI;] and bh AbdO↓ signifies the same. (Msb.) [So in the Kur xii. 76, fabadaOa biOawoEiyatihimo qabola wiEaMCi Oaxiyhi And he began with their bags, before the bags of his brother. And badaOahu is sometimes used in the sense of badaOa bihi; whence, in the Kur ix. 13, wahumo badaWuwkumo OawRala marRapK And they, it was, began with you the first time; i. e., as Bd says, by acting with hostility, and fighting.] You say also, badRaA vumRa EaAda He began, or did a first time, or the first time: then repeated, or did a second time. (Az, TA in art. Ewd.) And badaOa fiIi AlOamori [He began, or made a beginning, in the affair.] (M.) ― -b2- badaOa also signifies It (a thing) began; began to be; originated; or came into existence. (Msb.) [See also 5.] ＝ -A2- badaOa AlXRayoCa, (S, M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) [He began the thing; commenced it; set about it; as also AbtdOhu↓: accord. to the Mgh, the latter has this meaning, or, agreeably with the authority of the M and K, the meaning which here next follows:] he did the thing first, for the first time, by way of beginning, or originally; (S, M, K;) as also AbdOhu↓ and AbtdOhu↓; (M, K;) i. e., not after the example of anything preceding. (TA. [But this addition seems rather to belong to another explanation to be mentioned below.]) One does not say, zayodFA AbtdO↓ nor badaOahu, because these two verbs [signifying as last explained above] do not have for their objects corporeal things. (Mgh.) [El-Mutanakhkhil El-Hudhalee uses the phrase saOaboduWuhumo bimaXomaEipK I will begin with them (meaning his guests) by sporting and jesting; like the phrase in the Kur ix. 13 cited above: but different from these is the saying in the Kur xxxii. 6, wabadaOa xaloqi QloUinosaAni mino TiynK And He began the creation of man from clay.] The saying, faUino kaAna AlsRabuEu QbotadaOahu↓ means AbtdO Oaxocahu Oawo EaDRahu [But if the beast, or bird, of prey has begun the seizing of him, or the biting of him]; the noun that is prefixed [to the pronoun] being suppressed. (Mgh.) You say also, kaAna celika fiI AlOamori QbotidaMCi↓ That was in the beginning, or first, of the affair. (Msb.) [See also badoCN, below.] ― -b2- He originated the thing; brought it into being or existence; made it, or produced it, for the first time, it not having been before; (Mgh;) [and] so AbdOhu↓, said [of God, and] of a man, as the agent; (Msb;) and AbtdOhu↓. (Mgh in art. bdE.) [Hence,] badaOa QllRehu Alxaloqa, and OabodaOahumo↓, God created, or brought into existence, mankind, or the created beings: (M, Msb, K:) both signify the same. (S.) AlbaATilu wamaA yuEiydu maA yubodiYu↓ [in the Kur xxxiv. 48, means What doth that which is false, or the Devil, originate, or produce in the first instance? and what doth it, or he, reproduce after it hath perished?]: Zj says that maA, here, is in the place of an accus., meaning in each Instance OaIRa XaIoCK: or it may be a negative; and AlbATl here is Iblees; i. e., Iblees createth not, nor raiseth to life after death. (M.) You say also, wamaA yuEiydu maA yubodiYu↓, meaning walaA maA yatakalRamu↓ EaAYidapK, (S, K,) i. e. He does not say anything for the first time, nor anything for the second time; or anything original, nor anything in the way of repetition; AlkalaAmi baAdiYapu↓ signifying what is said for the first time; and EaAYidapu AlkalaAmi, what is said for the second time, afterwards: (TA:) or he says not anything: (A in art. Ewd:) and he has no art, artifice, or cunning. (IAar, TA in art. Ewd; and A in the present art.) ― -b3- badaOa AlbiYora He dug the well [for the first time: see badiIoCN]. (Msb.) ＝ -A3- badaOa mino OaroDK UilaI OaroDK, (T,) or mino OaroDihi, (K,) He went forth from a land to a land, or from his land; as also AbdO↓. (T, K.) ＝ -A4- budiYa, (inf. n. as above, S, M, K,) He (a man, S, M) had the small-pox: (AZ, As, T, S, M, K:) or the HaSobap [i. e. measles, or spotted fever]: (S, M, K:) or, as AZ says, and the HSbp: (T:) or, as Lh says, there came forth upon him pustules resembling the small-pox: but he adds, some say, the small-pox itself: (M:) the epithet applied to a person affected therewith is maboduwoCN↓. (AZ, As, Lh, T, S, M.) ― -b2- Also He fell sick. (IAth, TA.) In a trad. of ' Áïsheh occur the words, fiI Alyawomi AlRaciI budiYa fiyhi rasuwli QllRehi [meaning In the day in which the Apostle of God fell sick]: and IAth says, mataI budiYa fulaAnN meaning When did such a one fall sick? is a phrase used in inquiring respecting the living [who has been attacked by illness] and respecting the dead. (TA.)

Golius mentions, but without giving the authority, and without the vowel-signs, the saying, haAti AlqiSRapa mino ciI tubudRiYato; but writing the last word tbdyt, stating only that it is in the passive form; as meaning Relate thou the story, or history, from the beginning.]

badCN bdC
badCN inf.n. of 1; (T, S, M, Msb;) [The act of beginning;] or the doing a thing first. (M.) You say, laka AlbadoCu, (M, K,) and AlbudoCu↓, (As, TA,) and AlbadoOapu↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) and AlbudoOapu↓, (S, M, K,) and AlbidoOapu↓, (L,) and AlbadaMCapu↓, (M, K,) and AlbudaMCapu↓, (S, M, K,) and AlbudaAhapu, with h substituted for C, (M, Mtr,) and AlbidaMCapu↓, (Mtr, TA,) and, accord. to IKtt, AlbidaAyapu, but see what follows, (TA,) and AlbadiYapu↓, (M, K,) and AlbudRaMCapu↓, (AZ, TA,) It is for thee to begin, (S, M, Msb, K,) before any other, in shooting or casting, &c.: (S:) as to AlbidaAyapu, mentioned above, accord. to Mtr [and Fei], (TA,) it is a vulgar word, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) as IB and several others have stated, (Msb, TA, *) a corruption of AlbidaMCapu↓, (Mgh, Msb,) signifying the first; as also AlbudaMCapu↓; and AlbadoOapu↓: (Msb:) but IKtt says that it is a word of the dial. of the Ansár; badaOotu biAlXRaIoCi and badiytu bihi signifying qadRamotuhu: [see 1:] and he cites the following verse of Ibn-Rawáhah:
walawo EabadonaA gayorahu XaqiynaA
biQsomi QloUilaAhi wa bihi badiynaA
[In the name of God, and with it we begin; and if we worshipped any other than Him, we should be miserable]: see art. bdI. (TA. [This verse is also cited in the S in art. bdw, where, in one copy I find it as above; in another, with badayonaA instead of badiyonaA.]) And you say, faEalahu EawocaA wabadoCFA, (T, S,) and Eawodahu Ealay badoYihi, (M,) and fiI Eawodihi wabadoYihi, and fiI Eawodatihi wabadoOatihi↓, (S, M,) [He did it returning and beginning again; or returning to his beginning; i. e. he did it again from the beginning; he recommenced it: or you say this] meaning like as is meant by the saying next following. (TA.) rajaEa Eawodahu EalaI badoYihi, (S, K,) and EawodFA EalaI badoCK, in both of which [and in the last following] the verb may be trans., and the noun following therefore in the accus. case, (TA,) and fiI Eawodihi wabadoYihi, and fiI Eawodatihi wabadoOatihi↓, [in both of which, if correct, the verb must be intrans.,] and EawodFA wabadoCFA, [as though meaning EaAYidFA wabaAdiYFA, used as a phrase denotative of state,] (K,) [but in this last, and the two next preceding, accord. to the TA, the verb should be faEalahu, as in the next preceding sentence, instead of rajaEa, and this is confirmed by what is said in the K in art. Ewd,] He returned in the way whence he had come: (S, K:) [accord. to the TA, the literal meaning of the first and second may be he made his returning to revert to his beginning, and he made a returning to revert to a beginning:] or the meaning of the first, (Sb, TA in art. Ewd, and K in that art.,) and of the second, (K in that art.,) is, he returned without stopping after he had gone away: (Sb, K:) and sometimes it signifies the stopping in one's coming and then returning: (Sb:) [and it returned to its first state; it recommenced:] and you say, rajaEotu EawodiI EalaI badoYiI, meaning I returned like as I had come.
(Sb ubi suprà.) ― -b2- Also First, or former; preceding all others, or preceding another; as also AlbadoCu badiIoCN↓; and AlbadiICu being syn. with AlOawRalu. (S, K.) Hence the saying, AifoEalohu baAdiI badoCK, and baAdiI badiIoCK↓, meaning Do thou it the first thing, or the first of everything; [accord. to different copies of the S;] the I in bAdI being quiescent, in the place of the accus. case, accord. to usage; and sometimes they omit the [altogether], on account of frequent use [of the phrase], as will be stated in art. bdw, (S in the present art.,) saying baAdiI badK, and baAdiIbadiI (S in art. bdw.) You say also, AifoEalohu badoCFA, and OawRala badoCK, (Th, M, K,) and badoCa badoCK, (CK,) and badaA badoCK, (M, K,) and badoCK baAdiYa↓, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, K,) and baAdiIa badK, (K,) and baAdiIo badFA, (M, K, [in the CK baAdiIo badK,]) and baAdiIo badFA, (M,) and badiIoCK baAdaYa↓, (K,) and baAdiIo badaA, (M, K,) and badiIoCK↓ baAdiYa↓, (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, CK,) and badiIRK baAdiYa↓, which is anomalous, (M,) or baAdiIa badRiIi, (K,) and baAdiIo badiyRK, (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S, M,) and badiYK↓ baAdiYa↓, (S, CK,) or baAdiIa badiYK↓, (K, TA,) and baAdiIo badoOapa↓, (M, K, TA,) the former word being the act. part. n. of badiIa, which is of the dial. of the Ansár, as mentioned above, and the latter being indecl., with fet-h for its termination, (TA, [in the CK the latter word is written badoCap,]) and badoCK badoOapa↓, (CK,) and badoOapa badoOapa↓, (M, K,) and badiIoCK↓ badoOapa↓, (S,) and badoCK badiIoCa↓, (S, CK,) and badoCa ciI badoCK, (Fr, T,) and ciI badoCK badoOapa↓, (Fr, T, S, K,) and badoOapa ciI badoOapK↓, and ciI badiIoCK↓ badoOapa↓, (S, K,) and ciy badaMCapa↓ badaOapa↓, (K, TA,) not bdACp [as in the CK], (TA,) and badiIoCa ciI badiIoCK↓, (S, K, TA, [in the CK the last word is written badoCK,]) and ciI badiIoCK↓ badaMCapi↓, (K,) meaning Do thou it the first thing; (Fr, T, K;) so in a correct copy [of the K, and so I find in a MS. copy of the K and in the CK]: accord. to another copy, the first of everything: (TA:) or the first of first; (S;) thus in the L: (TA:) the words here put in the accus. case [literally or virtually] are so put [in some instances] as adverbial nouns; or, accord. to MF, they may be [in some instances] denotatives of state, with respect to the agent; the meaning being AifoEalohu HaAlapa kawonika baAdiYFA, i. e. mubotadiYaA bihi [lit. do thou it in the state of thy being beginning it]. (TA.) [In like manner,] you also say, badoCa AlrRaOoIi, and [more commonly] AlrRaOoIi baAdiYa↓, At first thought; or on the first opinion: (Lh, M:) [badoCu AlrRaOoIi and] AlrRaOoIi baAdiYu↓ signifying the first, and beginning, of the idea, thought, opinion, or judgment; or what is perceived before considering well or thoroughly: (M:) [and badoCN alone signifying a first idea, thought, opinion, or judgment; as is implied in the A, voce SayRuwrN, q. v.:] hence, AlrRaOoyi faEalahu fiI baAdiYi↓ [He did it at first thought, &c.]: (M:) and AlrRaOoIi turiydu Oanota baAdiYa↓ ZulomanaA, and AlrOI mubotadaOa↓, i.e. Thou at first thought, &c., desirest to wrong us: and one says also, baAdiIa AlrOI, without; meaning on the occasion of what appeared of opinion; i. e. at the first of what appeared thereof; [or at the first opinion's presenting itself;;] in which case, the phrase does not belong to this art. [but to art. bdw]: it occurs in the Kur xi. 29: (M:) AA alone there read baAdiYa, with; all the other readers pronounced it without C (TA.) ― -b3- Also A chief, or lord, (S, M, Msb, K,) who occupies the first place in chieftainship or lordship: (S:) or, as some say, a youth, or young man, whose judgment, or opinion, is deemed good, and who is consulted: (M:) or it signifies also an intelligent youth or young man: (K:) pl. buduwoCN. (M.) A poet (namely, Ows Ibn-Maghrà Es-Saadee, TA) says,
vunoyaAnunaA Uino OataAhumo kaAna badoOahumu
wabadoWuhumo Uino OataAnaA kiAna vunoyaAnaA
[Our second chief, if he came to them, would be their first chief; and their first chief, if he came to us, would be a second chief]. (S.) ― -b4- Also, and badoOapN↓, A share, or portion, of a slaughtered camel: (S, K:) or the best share or portion thereof: (T:) or the former word has the latter signification; and the latter word, the former signification: and the former signifies also a bone with the meat, or flesh, that is on it: (M:) and a joint; syn. mafoSilN; (AA, T, M;) and so badFA q.v.: (AA, T:) the pl. [of pauc.] of badoCN is OabodaMCN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] buduwoCN; (S, K;) the former of which is the more common: (TA:) or this is pl. of badFA. (AA, T.) The shares abovementioned [as commonly divided for the game called Almayosir q. v.] are ten; namely, the two haunches, the two thighs properly so called, the two thighs commonly so called (i. e. the tibiæ), the two shoulders, and the two arms; which last are the worst, because of the many veins [therein]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also badiIoCN.

badoOapN c
badoOapN: see badoCN, in thirteen places. ― -b2- Also The beginning, or outward course, of a military expedition; opposed to rajoEapN, meaning the returning, or homeward course, thereof: occurring in a trad., in which it is said that the Prophet gave, in the case of the former, a fourth [of the spoil], and in the case of the latter, a third; i.e., when a troop went forth from the main body of the army and attacked a party of the enemy, they were to have a fourth of the spoil that they took, and the rest of the army was to share with them the remaining three fourths; and if a troop did so in returning, they were to have a third of all the spoil that they took, because of the greater difficulty and danger attending this case. (T, Mgh.) ― -b3- kaAna celika fiI badoOatinaA, and budoOatinaA↓, and bidoOatinaA↓, (K,) and badaMCatinaA↓, (Lh, M, TA,) and budaMCatinaA↓, and bidaMCatinaA↓, (TA,) and badaOatinaA↓, (Lh, M, K,) but [ISd says,] I know not how that is, (M,) and mubodaYinaA↓, and mubodaYinaA↓, (K,) and mabodaOatinaA↓, (Lh, M, and so in some copies of the K,) or mabodaAtinaA, (so in other copies of the K,) thus in the baAhir of Ibn-'Odeys [in the CK Ibn-'Adebbes], (K,) which is said to indicate that we should hesitate respecting them [before admitting them to be of classical authority], are phrases meaning That was in the first of our state, and in our adolescence. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (so in a copy of the M, there written badoOap,) or budoOapN↓, with damm, (K,) A certain plant; (M;) a black thing, resembling a truffle (kamoC), of which no use is made: so says AHn. badiIoCN: see badoCN, as signifying First, or former; in eight places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a thing, or an affair, i. q badiyEN, (S, and so in a copy of the K,) or mubodaEN: (so in other copies of the K:) [thus it signifies] Originated; brought into being or existence; made, or produced, for the first time, not having been before, or not after the similitude of any former thing: (TA:) and created: (M, K:) and wonderful: (M, Msb, TA:) and strange, or extraordinary, as not being after the similitude of any former thing. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, as is implied in the Mgh,] biYorN badiIoCN A well newly dug; (T, Mgh, Msb;) i. q. badiyEN; (M;) or dug since the era of ElIslám (S, K;) not ancient; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also badoCN↓: (S:) the former epithet [in this sense] is generally pronounced [badiIRN] without C: (T:) the well thus called is one dug in a waste land that has no owner: (TA:) AO says, (TA,) this epithet, and badiyE, are applied to a well when thou hast dug it; but if thou findest it to have been dug before thee, it is termed xafiyRap; and thus the well of Zemzem is termed xfyRp, because it was Ismá'eel's, and was filled up or covered over [after his time]: (T, TA:) the term qaliyb is [said to be] applied to an ancient well of which neither the owner nor the digger is known: (TA:) it is said in a trad., that the Hariym of a well such as is termed bdIC [i. e. the space surrounding it and belonging to it] is five-and-twenty cubits: (T, S: [but see HariymN:]) the pl. is buduwoCN: (M:) and AO says that buwdaAnN is pl. of badiIoCN applied to a well, and is syn. with qulobaAnN [a pl. of qaliybN which I have not found elsewhere] and rakaAyaA, being formed by transposition of letters from budoyaAnN [which is for budoMnN, as badiIRN is for badiIoCN; the d and I being transposed, the word becomes buyodaAnN, and this, by a rule of permutation, becomes buwdaAnN]. ; and bAdrhu Alyh; (M;) He hastened with another, or vied or strove with him in hastening, to it [or to do or attain or obtain it]: syn. EaAjalahu, (M, K, TA,) and OasoraEa Uilayohi. , inf. n. badorN, TA, [or buduwrN, as above,]) the thing, or event, came to him, or happened to him, hastily, quickly, or speedily; and, beforehand [or before he expected it]; syn. Eajila, (M, K,) and sabaqa, (M,) or Aisotabaqa: (K:) [and minohu qawolN badara↓, and fiEolN, a saying, and an action, proceeded from him hastily, without premeditation: see baAdirapN.] It is said in a trad., baAdiruwA biAloOaEomaAli haramFA [Strive ye to be before decrepitude with good works; i. e., to perform them before decrepitude]. (El-Jámi' es- Sagheer.) And in another, baAdiruwA AlSRuboHa biAlowitori [Strive ye to be before daybreak with the prayers termed wtr; i. e., to perform them before daybreak]. (Idem.) And in another, baAdiruwA biSalAapi Almagoribi qabola TuluwEi AlnRajomi [Hasten ye with, or to perform, the prayer of sunset before the rising of the star]. (Idem.) You say also, fulaAnN yubaAdiru fiI Oakoli maAli Alyatiymi [Such a one hastens in consuming the property of the orphan before the latter is of full age]. (A.) And baAdara kibara Alyatiymi [He hastened to be before the orphan's attaining to full age in expending his property]; said of a guardian; i. q. fiy maAli Alyatiymi Oabodara↓: (K:) and thus, bidaArFAOano yakobaruwA, in the Kur [iv. 5], means hastening to be before their attaining to full age in expending their property. (Bd, * Jel.) And bAdrhu AlgaAyapa and UilaI AlgaAyapi [He strove with him in hastening, or strove to get before him, to the goal]. (A.) And AlgaAyapa Abtdr↓ and UilaI AlgaAyapi [He strove in hastening, or strove to get first, to the goal]. (Ham p. 46.) And baAdara baEoDuhumo baEoDFA UilaI OamorK, and OamorFA AbtdrwA↓, and tbAdrwhu↓, They vied, or strove, one with another, in hastening to a thing, or an affair, trying which of them would be first. badorN bdr dr
badorN, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) originally an inf. n., (Msb,) The full moon; (M, A, Msb, K;) as also baAdirN↓; (L, K;) the moon in its fourteenth night: (S:) or the latter signifies [simply] the moon: (IAar, T:) the moon in its fourteenth night is called bdr because it hastens to rise before the sun sets; (S, M;) and to set before the sun rises: (TA:) or because of its fulness; (S, TA;) as being likened to a badorap: or, as Er-Rághib thinks to be most probable, it is itself a primitive word: (TA:) pl. buduwrN. (M, A.) Hence, layolapu Albadori [The night of the full moon; which is] the fourteenth night [of the lunar month]. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A lord, master, or chief, (M, K,) of a people: so called as being likened to the full moon. (M.) ― -b3- Applied to a boy, (Zj, M, K,) (tropical:) Full of youthful vigour and of flesh: (Zj:) or full, or plump: (M:) or i. q. mubaAdirN↓ [precocious]. (T, K.) TabaqN: (Ibn-Wahb, K:) because resembling the full moon, being round: so Az thinks. (TA.) ― -b5- See also badorapN, in two places.

butter, EukRap: when it has been weaned, its skin for milk is called badorap; and for clarified butter, misoOad: and when it is in its second year, its skin for milk is called waTob; and for clarified butter, niHoI: (AZ, S:) pl. (of the former, M) bidarN and buduwrN: (M, K:) the former said by El-Fárisee to be the only instance of the kind except hiDabN pl. of haDobapN, and biDaEN pl. of baDoEapN [or this may be pl. of biDoEapN]. (M. [But the assertion of El-Fárisee is incorrect (see HayoDapN), unless it be meant to apply only to sound words; and in this case, at least one addition should be made, namely qiSaEN pl. of qaSoEapN.]) ― -b2- Hence, (M,) the former word, (S, M, A, K, &c.,) and ↓the latter also, (K,) The sum of ten thousand dirhems: (S, A:) or a purse containing a thousand, (T, M, K,) or ten thousand, dirhems, (T, M, * A, K,) or seven thousand deenárs: (K:) pl. buduwrN, (TA,) and pl. of pauc. bidaraAtN. baAdirapN Hastiness of temper; passionateness: (S:) or a hasty saying, or action, that suddenly proceeds (yaboduru, in the CK yaboduw,) from one in anger: (M, A, * Mgh, * Msb, * K:) and a slip; a mistake; an error; (S, Msb;) on an occasion of one's being angry: (S:) or a bad, an abominable, or a foul, word or saying: and a quick fit of anger: (IAar, T:) pl. bawaAdiru, (S, A.) You say, OaxoXaI Ealayoka baAdiratahu I fear for thee his hastiness of temper, or passionateness: (S:) or what may hastily proceed from him in his anger. (A.) And minohu yawaAdiru gaDabK badarato↓ Slips, mistakes, or errors, on an occasion of his being angry, hastily proceeded from him. (S.) And baAdirapu AlXRarRi signifies What hastily, or suddenly, befalls one, of evil, or mischief. (M.) ― -b2- An intuitive knowledge, notion, or idea; or a faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence; or a faculty of extemporizing; syn. badiyhahN. (S, K.) You say, fulaAnu Hasanu AlbaAdirapi Such a one has a good intuitive knowledge, &c. (TA.) ― -b3- The point of a sword. (M, K.) ― -b4- The extremity of an arrow, next the head. (A.) ― -b5- The head of a plant; (M;) the first part thereof from which the earth cleaves asunder. (M, K. *) ― -b6- The first that appears of the [plant called] HinRaMC. (M.) ― -b7- The leaves of the [herb called] HuwRaMCap. (K.) ― -b8- The best, and freshest in growth, of the [plant called] waros. (M, K. *) ― -b9- Also, (M, K,) or bawaAdiru, (S, A,) which is the pl., (K,) of a man &c., (S, M,) The portion of flesh, (S, M, K,) or the portions thereof, (A,) between the shoulder-joint and the neck, (S, M, K,) or between the necks and the shoulderjoints: (A:) or the former, (K,) or its dual, (M,) of a man, the two portions of flesh that are above the rugavaAwaAni and below the vanoduwap: (M, K:) or the dual, [relating to a camel, signifies] the two sides of the kirokirap [or callous lump on the breast]: or two veins on either side thereof. (M.) ― -b10- bawaAdiru Alxayoli badarato↓ The first, or fore parts, (OawaAYil,) of the horses appeared [or suddenly came in view]. (Msb.)

4 AbdEhu ObdE ObdEh AbdEh AbdEp bdE
4. AbdEhu He originated it; invented it; devised it; excogitated it; innovated it; made it, did it, produced it, caused it to be or exist, or brought it into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing; syn. AixotaraEahu laA EalaI mivaAlK, (S,) and Asotaxorajahu, and OaHodavahu, (Msb,) and OabodaOahu; (K, TA; but in both without the pronoun;) as also AbtdEh↓; (Msb;) syn. AibotadaOahu, and OaHodavahu, (Mgh,) and OanoXaOahu, (K,) and badaOahu; (TA;) and so badaEahu↓, aor.
badaEa
, (K, TA,) inf. n. badoEN; (TA;) but OabodaEa is more commonly used than badaEa. (TA.) You say, AbdE QllRehu Alxaloqa God created the creation, not after any similitude. (Msb.) And in the Kur [lvii. 27], we find, wa rahobaAniyRapF QbotadaEuwhaA↓ And monkery which they originated, or innovated. (TA.) And you say, badaEa↓ AlrRakiyRapa, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. badoEN, (IDrd,) He produced, or fetched out, by his labour in digging, the water of the well; (IDrd, K;) and originated it; or made it to be for the first time, it not having been before. (IDrd.) And AbdE AlrRajulu The man introduced an innovation, or what is termed a bidoEap; [the object being understood;] as also AbtdE↓. (TA.) And AbdE AlXRaAEiru The poet produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (S, * K, * TA.) ― -b2- AbdEt AlrRaAHilapu, (S, K,) or AlrRikaAbu, (Ks, Mgh,) The ridden camel, or travelling camel, became fatigued, or jaded, and broke down, or perished; (Ks, S, Mgh, K;) as though doing a new thing: (Ks, Mgh:) or the former phrase, (K,) followed by bihi, (TA,) she limped [with him], halted, or was slightly lame: (K, TA:) or she lay down upon her breast in the road, by reason of emaciation or disease: or she ceased from going on, by reason of fatigue, or of limping, or halting, or slight lameness; as though she did a new and unaccustomed thing: (TA:) or AbdAE is not without limping, or halting, or slight lameness, (K, TA,) accord. to certain of the Arabs of the desert; but, says AO, this is not at variance with the explanations given. (TA.) And OubodiEa biAlrRajuli The man's camel which he rode became fatigued, or jaded: (S:) or OubodiEa bifulaAnK (Mgh, K) such a one's camel which he rode ceased from going on, by reason of fatigue or lameness: (Mgh:) or broke down, or perished, (K, TA,) or became fatigued, or jaded, (TA,) and he became unable to prosecute his journey; (K, TA;) and his beast became so fatigued that it was left to remain where it was; or stood still with him. (TA.) [See also OuEobida bihi.] It is said in a proverb, UicaA Talabota AlbaATila OubodiEa bika [When thou seekest what is vain, or false, thou wilt be prevented from attaining thine object]. (TA.) ― -b3- OabodaEa fulaAnN bifulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one prevented such a one from attaining his wish, (qaTaEa bihi,) and abstained from aiding, or assisting, him, and did not undertake the accomplishment of his want, (Lh, K, TA,) and was not [at hand] when he thought he would be. (TA.) ― -b4- OabodaEato HujRatuhu (tropical:) His argument, or plea, or the like, was, or became, vain, or false, or ineffectual: (Aboo-Sa'eed, K:) or was, or became, weak. (A, TA.) And OubodiEato HujRatuhu (tropical:) His argument, or plea, &c., was rendered vain, or ineffectual. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K, * TA.) OabodaEa birRuhu biXukoriI wafaDoluhu wa UyjaAbuhu biwaSofiI (assumed tropical:) [His kindness has crippled my power of thanking, and his bounty, and the obligation which he has imposed, my power of description]: so in the L; but in the O and K, qaSoduhu [his intention] is put in the place of fDlh; and in the K, wAyjAbh is omitted: (TA:) said when one thanks another for his beneficence, acknowledging that his thanks are inadequate to his beneficence. (K.) ＝ -A2- AbdE biAlHajRi, and biAlsRafari, He determined,
resolved, or decided, upon pilgrimage, and upon journeying. (TA.) ― -b2- AbdE yamiynFA He rendered an both binding, or obligatory. (IAar.) ＝ -A3- AbdEwA bihi They beat him, or struck him. (TA.)

bidoEN bdE bdEp
bidoEN i. q. badiyEN↓, q. v., and mubotadaEN↓; (S;) [but generally used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; signifying] A novelty; or thing existing for the first time: (K:) and i. q. badiyEN↓ and mubotadiEN↓, a first doer; as though meaning one who has none among his fellows to share, or participate, with him in a thing, or an affair: (Msb:) pl. OabodaAEN. (Akh, S.) You say, fulaAnN bidoEN fiI hecA AlOamori, (S, Msb,) i. e. badiyEN↓, (S,) meaning Such a one is the first doer in this affair; the first who has done it. (Msb.) And hence the saying in the Kur [xlvi. 8], qulo maA kunotu bidoEFA mina AlrRusuli (S, Msb, TA) Say thou, I am not the first who has been sent of the apostles: (Msb, TA:) or the meaning is, I am not an innovator among the apostles; inviting you to that to which they do not invite you; or able to do that which they were not able to do: and accord. to one reading, it is bidaEFA↓; as being [a sing. epithet] like qiyamN; or for caA bidaEK [in which the latter word is pl. of bidoEapN]. (Bd.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, (TA,) Superlative (Ks, K) in his kind (Ks) in anything; (K;) in good and in evil; (Ks;) or in knowledge, or courage, or nobility: (K:) fem. with p: pl. of the mase. OabodaAEN [a pl. of pauc., which is also, as is said in the L, applied to women,] and buduEN [a pl. of mult.]; and pl. of the fem. bidaEN. (K.) ↓A man liberal in disposition; syn. gamorN. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- A full body. (K.)

bidaEN bdE bdEp
bidaEN: see bidoEN. ― -b2- It is also pl. of bidoEapN, [both as a subst. and] as fem. of bidoEN. (K.)

bidoEapN bdE bdEh bdEp dEp
bidoEapN An innovation; a novelty; anything originated, invented, or innovated; anything made, done, produced, caused to be or exist, or brought into existence, newly, for the first time, it not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing: (ISK:) a dissentient state or condition: (Msb:) a subst. from AibotidaAEN, like rifoEapN from AirotifaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) and xilofapN from AixotilaAfN: (Mgh:) subsequently and generally applied to an addition, or an impairment, in religion: (Mgh, Msb:) or a novelty, or an innovation, in religion, after the completion [thereof]: (S, K:) or an opinion declining, or swerving, from the right way, and an action, innovated after [the time of] the Prophet: (Lth, K:) or an action at variance with the Sunneh: (KT:) [generally a heretical innovation; or a new heresy: but] there is a bdEp not disapproved, termed bidoEapN mubaAHapN [an allowed, or allowable, innovation]; which is that whereof the goodness is attested by some principle in the law, or which is required to prevent some cause of evil; such as the Khaleefeh's seclusion of himself from the promiscuous classes of the people: (Msb:) there are two kinds of bdEp; namely bidoEapN hudFI [an innovation of a right kind], and bidoEapN DalaAlK [an innovation of an erroneous kind]. (IAth.)

badiyEN bdyE
badiyEN i. q. bidoEN, which see in three places, (S, Msb,) and mubotadaEN↓; [i. e. Originated; invented; innovated; made, done, produced, caused to be or exist, or brought into existence, newly, for the first time, not having been or existed before, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing;] (S, Msb, K;) new; wonderful; unknown before. (TA.) You say, jiYota biOamorK badiyEK Thou hast done a new thing; a wonderful thing; a thing unknown before: and OamorN baAdiEN↓ signifies the same as OamorN badiyEN. (TA.) And jaMCa biA lbadiyEi, (S,) or OataI biAlbadayEi, (K,) said of a poet, (S, K,) He produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (TA.) And HabolN badXyEN A new rope: (AHn:) or a rope begun to be twisted, not being yet a rope, but undone, then spun, then twisted again. (K.) And zimaAmN badiyEN A new nose-rein of a camel. (TA.) And rakiyRapN badiyEN A newly-dug well. (TA.) [See also badiIoCN.] And badiyEN alone, A skin for wine &c.: (S:) or a new skin for wine &c.: (K:) and a new skin for water or milk: an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.) Hence the trad., UinRa tihaAmapa kabadiyEi AlEasali HulowN OawRaluhu HulowN Mxiruhu [Verily Tihámeh is like the skin, or new skin, of honey: the first part thereof is sweet: the last part thereof is sweet]: (S, K *:) because honey does not change in flavour, whereas milk does change. (S.) ― -b2- Fat; as an epithet: (As, K:) pl. budoEN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. mubotadiEN↓ [An originator, inventor, or innovator; one who makes, does, produces, causes to be or exist, or brings into existence, newly, for the first time, and not after the similitude of anything pre-existing]: (S, K:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN, like qadiyrN in the sense of qaAdirN; from badaEa. (TA.) [See also bidoEN.] You say, AallRehu badiyEN AlsRamewaAti waAlOaroDi God is the Creator of the heavens and the earth, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (Aboo-Is-hák, S. *) And hence AlbadiyEu is a name of God, meaning The Originator of the creation, according to his own will, not after the similitude of anything pre-existing. (TA.)

[badiyEapN A new, and an admirable, or a wonderful, thing; and especially such in speech, or language, in poetry, and in answering, or replying: pl. badaAYiEu: see an ex. voce badiyhapN.]

baAdiEN bAdE
baAdiEN: see badiyEN.

mubotadiEN: see bidoEN and badiyEN, each in two places.

1 badala bdl bdlp dl
1. badala, inf. n. badaAlN: see 2, in three places.

2 tabodiylN tbdyl
2. tabodiylN properly signifies [The changing, or altering, a thing; or] the changing, or altering, the form, or fashion, or semblance, or the quality, or condition, [of a thing,] to another form, &c., while the substance remains the same; (Th, T, TA;) or the changing a thing from its state, or condition; (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA;) or the changing a thing without substitution: (S:) but the Arabs have used it also in the sense of UibodaAlN↓, (Mbr, T, TA,) which signifies [the changing a thing by substitution; exchanging it; replacing it with another thing; or] the removing, or displacing, the substance [of a thing], and introducing anew another substance. (Th, T, TA.) You say, badRalotuhu, inf. n. tabodiylN, (M, * Msb, K,) meaning I changed it, or altered it; (M, K) or I changed, or altered, the form, or fashion, or semblance, or the quality, or condition, of it; (Msb;) as in the phrase, badRalotu AlxaAtama biAlHaloqapi [I changed, or altered, the signet-ring into the simple ring], said when one has melted the former and made of it a simple ring; (Fr, T, TA;) and badRala QllRehu AlsRayiYRaAti HasanaAtK [God changed the evil deeds into good deeds]; the verb being doubly trans. by itself because it has the meaning of jaEala and SayRara. (Msb. [But see what follows.]) Oabodalotuhu↓ bikacaA, [in the S, Oabodalotu AlXRaIoCa bigayorihi, without explanation,] inf. n. UibodaAlN, [I changed it by substituting for it such a thing, or exchanged it for such a thing, or replaced it with such a thing,] is said when one has removed the first, and put the second in its place; (Msb;) as in the phrase, Oabodalotu AlxaAtama biAlHaloqapi [I changed the signet-ring by substituting for it the simple ring; exchanged the signet-ring for the simple ring; or replaced the signet-ring with the simple ring]; said when one removes the one, and puts the other in its place: (Fr, T, TA:) and this verb is also made doubly trans. by itself, like badRalotu, (Msb,) which is used in the sense of Oabodalotu [as shown above]; (Mbr, T, TA;) for instance, where it is said, [in the Kur lxvi. 5,] EasaI rabRuhu Uino TalRaqakunRa Oano yubodilahu OazowajFA xayorFA minokunRa [May-be, his Lord, if he divorce you, will give him in exchange wives better than you]; accord to one reading, yubadRilahu (Msb.) An ex. of the latter of these two verbs in the sense of the former is the saying in the Kur [xxv. 70], yubadRilu QllRehu sayRiMtihimo HasanaAtK [God will change their evil deeds by substituting for them good deeds]; i. e. will cancel the evil deeds and put in their place good deeds: but in the saying in the Kur [iv. 59], kulRamaA naDijato juluwduhumo badRalonaAhumo juluwdFA gayorahaA [Whenever their skins are thoroughly burned, we will change the condition thereof to them into the condition of other skins], the meaning is, that the first condition of their skins shall be restored;
so that the substance is one, but the condition is different. (Mbr, T, TA.) You say also, badRalahu QllRehu mana Alxawofi OamonFA [God gave him in exchange for fear, or in lieu of fear, security]. (S.) [And badRalahu bihi kacaA He gave him in exchange for it, or in lieu of it, such a thing: see Kur xxxiv. 15. And bdRl makaAnahu kacaA He gave in exchange for it, or in lieu of it, such a thing: see Kur vii. 93 and xvi. 103.] badRala HusonFA baEoda suwoCK, in the Kur [xxvii. 11], means He hath done good [by way of exchange after evil]; i. e., repented; (Jel;) or badRala canobuhu biAltawobapi [hath exchanged his sin for repentance]. (Bd.) tabodiylN and UibodaAlN↓ both signify The act of exchanging [a thing for another thing]; or making [a thing] to be a substitute [for another thing]; (KL, PS;) and so does badaAlN↓. (KL.) You say, bdRl AlXRaIoCa mina AlXaIoCi, (M, K, *) and minohu Abdlhu↓, i. e. AitRaxacahu minohu badlFA [here meaning He exchanged the thing for the thing; or, more literally, he made the thing a substitute for the thing]. (M, K. [In the text of the former of these, as given in the TT, instead of AitRaxacahu, I find taxica (a dial. var. of AitRaxaca) without the affixed pronoun, which is meant to be understood or is omitted inadvertently by the transcriber: and here it should be observed, that the explanation which I have rendered as above admits of another meaning, namely, Oaxacahu minohu badalFA “he took it as a substitute for it:” in the M, immediately before, Oaxacahu minohu badalFA is given as the explanation of the phrases tbdRl AlXRaIoCa and biAlXRaIoCi, and Astbdlhu and bihi: see 10.]) You say also, AlvRawoba bigayorihi badalotu↓, aor.
badula
, [inf. n. badaAlN, mentioned and explained above, I exchanged the garment, or piece of cloth, for another; or made it to be a substitute for another;] and Aisotabodalotuhu↓ bigayorihi signifies the same. (Msb. [But the latter phrase has more frequently another meaning, explained below: see 10.]) [Abdlhu↓ in the phrases Abdlhu kacaA as meaning He changed it into, or substituted for it, such a thing, and Abdlhu mino kacaA as meaning he changed it from, or substituted it for, such a thing, is more common than bdRlh, which is used in the same sense; as badalahu↓ is also; for] AO applies the term maboduwlN↓ [in lieu of the more common term mubodalN↓] to a letter that is changed from another letter, as in madahotuhu for madaHotuhu; and this shows that badalotu is trans. [and signifies I changed, &c.]. (Az, TA.)

3 mubaAdalapN mbAdl mbAdlh mbAdlp
3. mubaAdalapN and tabaAdalN↓ signify the same, (S,) namely, The act of exchanging with another or others. (PS.) You say, bAdlhu, inf. n. mubaAdalapN and bidaAlN [in the CK erroneously written with fet-h to the b], He exchanged, or made an exchange, with him; or] he gave him the like of that which he took, or received, from him; (IDrd, * M, K;) for instance, a garment, or piece of cloth, in the place of another; (Lth, T, Msb, * in explanation of the former inf. n.;) and a brother in the place of a brother. (Lth, T.) And tabaAdalaA↓ They exchanged, or made an exchange, each with the other; or each gave to the other the like of that which he took, or received, from him. (TA.) nubaAdiluho, ending a verse of El-Kulákh, means for whom we would take a substitute: El-Marzookee says, it is for nubaAdilu bihi AlnRaAsa [for whom we would make an exchange with the people]; the preposition being suppressed. (Ham p. 465.)

4. Abdlhu, inf. n. UibodaAlN: see 2, in five places.

5. tbdRl It (a thing, M) became changed, or altered. (M, K.) ― -b2- In the saying of the rájiz,
fabudRilato waAldRahoru cuw tabadRuli
the meaning is, cw tabodiyl [i. e. the meaning of the whole is, And, or but, she was changed, or altered; for time has the property of changing, or altering]. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also 10, in three places.

6: see 3, in two places.

10 Astbdl AlXRaIoCa 10 and biAlXRaIoCi
10. Astbdl AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaIoCi, and tbdRlhu↓ and bihi, (M, K, *) He took a substitute, or a thing in exchange, for the thing. (M.) You say, Astbdl AlXRaIoCa bigayorihi, and bihi tbdRlhu↓, He took the thing [as a substitute, or in exchange, for another; or] in the place of another. (S.) And Astbdl vawobFA makaAna vawobK [He took a garment, or piece of cloth, in the place, or in lieu, of a garment, &c.]; and OaxFA makaAna OaxK [a brother in the place, or in lieu, of a brother]. (Lth, T.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 58], Oatasotabodiluwna QlRaciI huwa OadonaI biAlRaciI huwa xayorN Will ye take in exchange that which is worse for that which is better? (Jel. [See also other exs. in the Kur ix. 39 and xlvii. last verse.]) And Alkufora biAloUiymaAni mano yatabadRali↓ [Whoso adopteth infidelity in lieu of faith]. (Kur ii. 102. [See also other exs. in the Kur iv. 2 and xxxiii. 52.]) ― -b2- See also 2, last sentence but one.

bidolN bdl bdlp dl
bidolN: see the next paragraph, in four places.

badalN bdl bdlp dl
badalN and bidolN↓, (Fr, T, S, M, Msb, K,) like mavalN and mivolN, and XabahN and XibohN, (Fr, T, S,) and nakalN and nikalN, the only other instances of the kind, i. e. of words of both these measures, that have been heard, accord. to AO, (S, TA, [but in one copy of the S, I find A'Obeyd,]) and badiylN↓ (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) all signify the same; (S, M, Msb, K;) namely, A substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in place of, in lieu of, or in exchange for, another thing; a compensation; syn. xalafN, (M, K,) and EiwaDN: (Kull:) badalu AlXRaIoCi [and Albadalu mina AlXRaIoCi] and bidoluhu↓ badiyluhu↓ meaning Alxalafu minohu [the substitute for the thing; &c.]; (M, K;) i. e., another thing: (S:) pl. OabodaAlN, (IDrd, Msb, K,) which, as pl. of badiylN↓, has few parallels. (IDrd, TA.) Sb says, [making a distinction between badalN and badiylN↓,] you say, UinRa badalaka zayodN, i. e. Verily Zeyd is in thy place: but if you put badal in the place of badiyli, you say, UinRa badalaka zayodN, i. e. UinRa bidaylaka↓ zayodN [Verily thy substitute is Zeyd]: and a man says to another, Go thou with such a one; and he replies, maEiIa rajulN badaluhu, i. e. With me is a man who stands in his stead, and is in his place, or who will stand &c. (M.) You say also, bala kacaA [and badalFA mino kacaA], meaning Instead of, in the place of, in lieu of, or in exchange for, such a thing. (Kull.) [And badala Oano tafoEala kacaA Instead of thy doing thus.] ― -b2- AlOabodaAlu (IDrd, S, M, K, &c.) and AlbudalaMCu (TA) [The Substitutes, or Lieutenants;] certain righteous persons, of whom the world is never destitute; when one dies, God substituting another in his place: (S:) certain persons by means of whom God rules the earth; (M, K;) consisting of seventy men, (IDrd, M, K,) according to their assertion, of whom the earth is never destitute; (IDrd, TA;) forty of whom are in Syria, and thirty in the other countries; (IDrd, M, K;) none of them dying without another's supplying his place, (M, K,) from the rest of mankind; (K;) and therefore they are named AbdAl: (M:) accord. to Abu-lBakà, as stated by El-Munáwee, it seems that they meant [by this appellation] the substitutes and successors of the prophets; and accord. to some, they were seven, neither more nor fewer, by means of whom God takes care of the seven climates; one being successor of Abraham (ElKhaleel), and to him pertains the first climate; the second, of Moses (El-Keleem); the third, of Aaron; the fourth, of Idrees; the fifth, of Joseph; the sixth, of Jesus; and the seventh, of Adam: (TA: [in which is also mentioned a treatise denying their existence, and disapproving of the assertion that by means of them God takes care of the earth:]) the sing. is badalN and bidolN↓, (T,) or badiylN↓. (IDrd, S.) ― -b3- Huruwfu Albadali (M, K) The letters of substitution; those which are substituted for other letters; not those which are substituted in consequence of idghám. (M.) [The letters included under this appellation differ accord. to different authors: see De Sacy's Gram. Ar. 2nd ed. i. 33.] ― -b4- bidolN↓ (Kr, M, K) and badalN (M, K,) applied to a man, also signify Generous, and noble: (Kr, * M, K:) and used in these senses, [says ISd,] they are, in my opinion, not devoid of implication of the meaning of a substitute: (M:) the pl. is OabodaAlN (M, K.)

badiylN bdyl
badiylN: see badalN, in six places

badRaAlN bdAl dAl
badRaAlN A seller of eatables (A Heyth, T, K) of every kind: thus he is called by the Arabs; (A Heyth, T;) because he changes one sale for another; selling one thing to-day and another to-morrow: (AHát, TA:) the vulgar say, baqRaAlN. (A Heyth, T, K.) ― -b2- Also One who has no more property than is sufficient for his purchasing one thing, and who, when he sells this, buys another thing in exchange for it. (TA in art. jdl.) [Hence,] hecaA raOoIu AljadRaAliyna waAlbadRaAliyna is a phrase used as meaning This is flimsy opinion. (TA in the present art. and in art. jdl, [but in the latter without the w,] on the authority of AHeyth.)

mubodalN mbdl

mabodalN mbdl
mabodalN: see 2.

1 baduna bAd bdn bdnn bdyn
1. baduna, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
baduna
; (T, S;) and badana, aor.
baduna
; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) inf. n.
badaAnapN (T, S, M, &c.,) of the former, (ISk, T, S, &c.,) and budonN, (T, S, M, K,) also of the former, (ISk, T,) or of the latter, (S,) and badonN, (M, K,) accord. to AZ, (T,) and badaAnN, (M, K,) or buduwnN is the inf. n. of the latter verb; (Msb;) said of a man, (ISk, T, S,) and of a camel; (Msb;) and badunato and badanato, said of a woman, (AZ, T, M, K,) and of a badanap, q. v.; (Zj, T, &c.;) He, and she, was, or became, big, bulky, big-bodied, or corpulent; (ISk, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) abounding in flesh; (T;) fat: (Zj, T, M:) or the former verb has this last signification, that of fatness; and the latter verb is syn. with badRana q. v. (Ham p. 158.) [See also budonN, below.]

2 bdRn bAd bdn bdnn bdyn
2. bdRn, inf. n. tabodiynN, He (a man, T, S, M) was, or became, aged, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and weak: (M, K:) or he was, or became, heavy by reason of age; as also badana↓. (Ham p. 158.) ＝ -A2- He clad a man with a badan, i. e. a diroE [or coat of mail]. (K,* TA.)

budonN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn
budonN [properly an inf. n.; see 1:] Fatness and compactness; as also budunN↓. (S.) ― -b2- And Fat; i. e. the substance termed XaHomN. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also a pl. of badanapN: (T, S, &c.:) ― -b2- and of baAdinN. (M, TA.)

badanN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn
badanN The body, without the head and arms and legs; (M, Msb, K;) so says Az: (Msb:) or the body without the arms and legs: (Mgh:) or [the part] from the shoulder-joint to the posteriors [inclusive]: (TA [as from the Mgh, in my copy of which it is not found]:) or the jasada [generally meaning the body together with the members] of a man; (S;) often applied. to the whole of the jasad; (Az, TA;) and in the Kur x. 92 it is said to mean the body without soul: (S:) pl. OabodaAnN; (M, Msb;) whence the phrase, mentioned by Lh, UinRahaA laHasanapu AlOabodaAni [meaning Verily she is beautiful in respect of the body], as though the term badanN were applied to every portion of her. (M.) Xirokapu AlOabodaAni is originally XirokapN biAlOabodaAni, meaning Copartnership in bodily labours for the acquirement of gains. (Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) The part of a shirt, (Mgh, Msb,) and of a [garment of the kind called] jubRap, (Mgh,) that lies against the back and the belly, [i. e. the body thereof,] without the sleeves and the daxaAriyS [or gores with which it is widened]: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. as above. (Msb.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A short diroE [or coat of mail], (S, M, K,) of the measure of the body: (M:) or it is [a coat of mail] like a diroE, except that it is short, only such as covers the body, with short sleeves: (T:) or, as some say, any diroE: (M:) and so it is said to mean in the Kur x. 92 by IAar (T) and by Th; (M;) but Akh says that this assertion is of no account: (S:) pl. as above. (M, K.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A small [garment of the kind called] jubRap; as being likened to a coat of mail. (TA.) ― -b5- Accord. to Kr, (M,) A limb, or member: or, specially, the limbs, or members, of a slaughtered camel: (M, K: [in the latter of which, the former of these two explanations is improperly connected with the first in this paragraph by the conjunction Aw:]) to these he specially applies it in one instance: pl. as above. (M.) ― -b6- Also An old, or aged, man: (K:) or so rajulN badanN. (T, S, M.) [In like manner, baAdinN↓ and badinN↓ are said by Golius, as on the authority of the S, to signify annosus et senior, applied to a man, and also to a woman; but this explanation is wrong; and the latter word I do not find in any lexicon.] ― -b7- And An old mountain-goat: (M, K:) or so waEilN badanN: (S:) [in the present day, badan is applied to the wild goat of the Arabian and Egyptian deserts and mountains; the capra jaela of Hamilton Smith; called by some an ibex; as is also tayotal, properly vayotalN:] pl. [of pauc.] Oabodunu (M, K [in the CK, erroneously, OabodanN]) and [of mult.] buduwnN, which is extr. [with respect to rule], on the authority of IAar. (M, TA.) The rájiz says, describing a bitch (S, M) and a mountain-goat, (M, TA,)
qado qulotu lamRaA badati AlEuqaAbu
waDamRahaA waAlbadana AlHiqaAbN
jidRiI likulRi EaAmilK vawaAbu
AalrRaOosu waAlOakoruEu waAlUihaAbu
(S, * M, * TA,) [I had said, when El-' Ikáb appeared, and El-Hikáb comprised her and the old mountain-goat, “Exert thyself: for every worker there is a recompense: the head and the shanks and the hide shall be thine”]: AlEqAb is the name of a bitch, and AlHqAb is a certain mountain: he says, “Catch thou this goat, and I will make thy recompense to be the head and the shanks and the hide.” (TA.) [Hence Golius has been led to mistake AlHiqaAb for a signification of Albadanu.] ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The lineage, or parentage, of a man, and his grounds of pretension to respect or honour. (M, K.)

badinN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn
badinN: see badanN

budunN bAd bdn bdnn bdyn
budunN: see budonN. ＝ -A2- It is also a pl. of badanapN. (M, K, &c.)

badanapN bAd bdn bdnh bdnp bdyn
badanapN A she-camel, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and a male camel, (T, M, Mgh, K,) and a cow, (T, S, M, Mgh, * Msb, K,) and a bull, (M, K,) accord. to some, (Msb,) or properly the first of these, (Mgh, Msb,) and the second, (Mgh,) but made by the Sunneh to apply to a cow also, (Mgh, * Msb,) that is slaughtered at Mekkeh, (S,) or that is, (M, K,) or may be, (T,) brought thither for sacrifice; (T, M, K;) so called because they used to fatten them, (S,) or because of their greatness, or bulkiness: (T, Mgh, Msb:) not applied to a sheep or goat: (T, Msb, TA:) En-Nawawee erroneously cites the T as asserting that it is thus applied; misled, it is said, by an omission in his copy: (MF, TA:) pl. badanaAtN, (T, Mgh, Msb,) a pl. of pauc., (Mgh,) and budonN, (T, S, M, Msb,) or budunN, (Mgh, K,) or both, (M, Msb, TA,) the former being a contraction of the latter, which seems to be pl. of badiynN: (Msb:) one should not use badanN as a pl. of badanapN; though they used to say xaXabN and OajamN &c. (M, TA.)

badaniIRN OdnI bd bdn bdnI bdny bdyn dny
[badaniIRN Of, or relating to, the badan, or body; corporeal. ― -b2- See also baAdinN.]

badiynN bdyn dyn

baAdinN bAdn
baAdinN, applied to a man, Big, bulky, big-bodied, or corpulent; (ISk, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also badiynN↓ (Msb, K) and mubadRanN↓ (M, K) [and badaniIRN↓]: and fat; as also mubadRanN↓: (T, M:) or heavy in body; heavy by reason of age: and badiynN↓ signifies fat: (Ham p. 158:) baAdinN is likewise applied to a woman, (S, M, Msb, K,) as are also baAdinapN (M, Mgh, K) and badiynN↓ (S, K) and mubadRanapN↓: (T, M:) the pl. is budRanN (M, Msb, K) and budonN (M, TA) and budunN; (Msb, K;) the first of these being pl. of baAdinN, (M, Msb,) and so the second; (M;) and the third being pl. of badiynN↓. (Msb.) See also badanN.

mubadRanN mbdn

mibodaAnN mbdAn
mibodaAnN That becomes fat quickly, with little fodder [or food]. (M, K.)

badaha
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. badoCN, (JK, S, Msb,) He, or it, came upon him, or happened to him, suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it; surprised him, or took him unawares; (JK, S Msb, K;) as also bAdhhu↓, inf. n. mubaAdahapN: (JK, Msb:) the former verb has this signification said of an affair, or event. (S, K.) And badahahu biOamorK, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (JK, TA,) signifies Aisotaqobalahu bihi, (JK, T, S, K,) i. e. He met him, or encountered him, with a thing, or an affair, or an action, (TK,) suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it: (T, TA:) or he began with him by it, or with it; syn. badaOahu bihi; (K;) the h being a substitute for the A (TA:) and bihi bAdhhu↓, (S,* K,) inf. n. mubaAdahapN and bidaAhN, (K,) he came upon him suddenly, unexpectedly, or without his being aware of it; surprised him, or took him unawares; (S, K;) with it. (K.) ― -b2- See also 2.

2. bdRh, inf. n. tabodiyhN, He answered, or replied, quickly: (IAar, TA:) and badaha↓ he answered, or replied, or he spoke, extempore; without premeditation. (Har p. 64.)

6. huma yatabaAdahaAni biA lXRiEori (S, TA) They two dispute, or contend together [extemporaneously, or extemporizing, with verses or poetry]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 8.

8. Abtdh AlxuTobapa (K, TA) He extemporized the discourse, or sermon, or oration; spoke it, or composed it, extemporaneously, impromptu, without premeditation. (TA.) And humo yatabaAdahuwna↓ AlxuTaba (K, TA) They extemporize discourses, &c.: here the measure tafaAEulN has not its proper quality [of denoting participation in the manner of contention, though it has in a phrase mentioned before]. (TA.)

badohN bd bdh bdp

EalaI badiypK Ely bdyh Ely bdyp
EalaI badiypK, and badiyhFA: see badiyhapN

badaAhapN bdAhh bdAhp
badaAhapN: see budaAhapN, in two places.

budaAhapN bdAhh bdAhp
budaAhapN (S, K) and badaAhapN↓ (Sgh, K) and badiyhapN↓ (JK, S, K) and badohN↓ and budohN↓ (K) substs. from badahahu biOamorK, (JK, S,) meaning The first of anything; and an occurrence thereof by which one is taken unawares: (K:) or the first occurrence of a thing, that happens to one unexpectedly. (M, in explanation of the first word, in art. bdO.) ― -b2- Also the first (S, TA) and ↓second (JK) and ↓third (TA) The first part of the running of a horse; (JK, S, TA;) opposed to EulaAlapN, signifying [the “remaining part of the running,” or “an afterrunning,” or] “a running after a running.” (TA.) You say, waEulaAlapK huwa cuw badiyhapK↓, and budaAhapK, [He has a first running and an after-running, differing, the one from the other]. (Az, TA.) And laHiqahu fiI budaAhapi jaroyihi [He overtook him in the first part of his running]. (Z, TA.) ISd thinks that in all these cases the h is a substitute for C. (TA.) [Hence,] gamoru Albadiyohapi↓ [properly Fleet in the first part of his running; meaning] (tropical:) a man who takes by surprise with large bounty. (TA, in art. gmr.) ― -b3- See also the next paragraph. in three places.

badiyhapN bdyhh bdyhp
badiyhapN: see budaAhapN, in four places. You say, laka Albadiyhapu, (K,) in which ISd thinks the h to be a substitute for C, (TA,) It is for thee to begin; (K;) and so lk AlbudaAhapu↓, with h substituted for C. (M, Mbr, TA art. bdO.) And OajaAba EalaI Albadyhapi (K) He answered, or replied, on the first of his being taken unawares. (TA.) [EalaI badiyhK↓ is mentioned by Freytag, but on what authority he does not say, as meaning Unpreparedly, suddenly, or unexpectedly; and so badiyhFA↓ by Golius, as on the authority of J, but I do not find it in the S in the present article.] And raMhu badiyhapF, signifies He saw him suddenly, or unexpectedly. (TA.) And badiyhapu AlrRaOoIi, Suddenly formed, unpremeditated, judgment or opinion. (Msb.) ― -b2- badiyhapN and budaAhapN↓ both signify The coming, of speech, without premeditation: and the coming suddenly, unexpectedly, or unawares. (KL.) ― -b3- And ↓the latter, [and more commonly the former,] An intuitive knowledge, notion, or idea; such as that one is the half of two; being, with respect to knowledge, like badiyEN with respect to intellect: (Kull:) [or] the former signifies the faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence: [intuition, or intuitive perception:] accord. to ' Alee-Ibn-Dháfir El-Haddád, it signifies primarily AirotijaAlN fiI AlkalaAmi [i. e. the faculty of extemporizing: or speaking, or composing, extemporaneously, impromptu, without premeditation]: and predominantly, the poetizing, or versifying, impromptu, without premeditation or consideration: except that ArtjAl is quicker than bdyhp. (TA.) You say, huwa cuw badiyhapK (K) He has a faculty of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence. (TA.) And fulaAnN cuw badiyhapK HasanapK Such a one has a good faculty of extemporizing; or of uttering, or relating, things by means of the promptness of his intelligence. (TA, in art. bdO: see badiyoapN.) And hecaA maEoluwmN fiI badaAYihi AlEuquwli [This is known among the intuitive notions of intellects; i. e., intuitively]. (K, * TA.) badaAYihu seems to be pl. of badiyhapN, as in the phrase, (TA,) lahu badaAYihu, i. e. badaAYiEu [He has new, or admirable, things that he utters], (K, TA,) in speech, or language, and poetry, and in answering, or replying: but here it is not improbable that the h may be a substitute for the E. (TA.)

badiyhiIRN bdyhI bdyhy
badiyhiIRN [Intuitive knowledge;] such that its origination does not rest upon speculation, and acquisition by study, whether it do, or do not, require some other thing, as conjecture or experience &c.; (KT, Kull;) so that it is [sometimes] syn. with DaruwriIRN [and opposed to naZariIRN]: and sometimes it means such as does not require anything whatever after the intellect has directed itself; so that it is more particular than DaruwriIRN: (KT:) as the conception of heat and cold, and the assent of the mind to the position that negation and affirmation cannot be co-existent, nor be simultaneously non-existent, in the same instance. (KT, Kull.) ― -b2- [And hence,] A mere simpleton or fool: but this is post-classical. (TA.)

rajulN mibodahN rjl mbdh rjl mbdp
rajulN mibodahN (S) A man possessing in a large degree the faculty of extemporizing, or of judging rightly at the first of an unexpected occurrence; firm, or steady, in speech or discourse, or whose tongue makes no slip in contentions, when he is taken unawares. (Har p. 64.)

1 badaA bd bdA
1. badaA, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yaboduw, (S, Msb,) inf. n. buduwRN (S, M, Msb, K) and badowN and badaMCN (M, K) and badaMCapN (K) and badFA, (M, on the authority of Sb,) for which last we find, in [some of] the copies of the K, buduwRN, a repetition, (TA,) or buduwoCN, (so in other copies of the K,) It appeared; it became apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) and tbdRI↓ [signifies the same; or he showed himself, or it showed itself; (see an ex. in art. jyX, voce jaAXa, last sentence;) or] he, or it, came in sight, or within sight. (KL.) ― -b2- badaA lahu fiI AlOamori, (T, M, Msb, K, and Har p. 665,) inf. n. badowN (M, K) and badFA (M, and so in a copy of the K) and badaMCN, (T, M, and so in the CK,) or badaMCapN and badaApN; (as in some copies of the K;) or badaA lahu fiI AlOamori badaMCN↓, (S, IB,) the last word being in the nom. case because it is the agent; (IB, TA;) An opinion presented itself, or occurred, to him, or arose in his mind, syn. naXaOa, (S, K, and Har ubi suprà,) or appeared to him, (M,) [respecting the affair, or case,] different from his first opinion, so that it turned him therefrom: (Har ubi suprà:) or there appeared to him, respecting the affair, or case, what did not appear at first: (Msb:) accord. to Fr, badaA liI badaMCN↓ means another opinion appeared to me: accord. to Az, badaA liI badFA means my opinion changed from what it was. (TA.) Esh-Shemmàkh says,
laEalRaka wa AlmawoEuwdu HaqRN wafaAWuhu
badaA laka fiI tiloka AlqaluwSi badaMCu
[May-be (but it is right that the promise be fulfilled) an opinion different from thy first opinion hath arisen in thy mind respecting that youthful she-camel]. (M, TA.) vumRa badaA lahumo mino baEodi maA raOawuA QloMyaAti layasojunanRahu, in the Kur [xii.35], means badaA waqaAluwA layasojununRahu lahumo badaMCN↓, [i.e. Then an opinion arose in their minds, after they had seen the signs of his innocence, and they said that they should certainly imprison him,] because lysjnnRh, being a proposition, cannot be the agent: so says Sb. (M.) badaA lilRhi Oano yaqotulahumo, occurring in a trad., means (tropical:) God determined that He would slay them: for, as IAth says, badaMCN signifies the deeming to be right a thing that is known after its having been not known; and this may not be attributed to God: but as is said by Suh, in the R, one may say, [of God,] badaA lahu Oano yafoEala kacaA, [properly signifying It occurred to him, or appeared to him, that he should do such a thing,] as meaning (tropical:) He desired to do such a thing; [as also badaA lahu fiI fiEoli kacaA;] and thus the phrase in the trad., here mentioned, has been explained. (TA.) [One says also, AifoEalo kacaA maA badaA laka Do thou thus as long as it seems fit to thee: see, a verse of El-Ahmar cited voce jalRa.] ― -b3- badaA Alqawomu, (T, S, M, K,) inf. n. badowN, (S,) or badaMCN; (M, K;) [the latter of which is said in the TA to be the right;] or badaA UilaI AlbaAdiyapi, inf. n. badaAwapN and bidaAwapN; (Msb;) The people, or company of men, went forth to the baAdiyap [or desert]: (M, Msb, K:) or, the former, went forth to their baAdiyap: (S:) or went forth from the region, or district, of towns or villages or of cultivated land, to the pasturingplaces in the deserts: (T:) [ISd says,] badowN may be used as meaning bidaAwapN, which is the contr. of HiDaArapN: (M:) [J says,] badaAwapN and bidaAwapN signify the dwelling, or abiding, in the baAdiyap [or desert]; the contr. of HiDaArapN: but Th says, I know not badaAwapN, with fet-h, except on the authority of AZ alone: (S:) As says that bdAwp and HDArp are with kesr to the b and fet-h to the H; but AZ says the reverse, i. e. with fet-h to the b and kesr to the H: (T:) both are also explained as signifying the going forth to the baAdiyap: and some mention budaAwapN, with damm; but this is not known: (TA:) tbdRI↓ like wise signifies he went forth from the constant sources of water to the places where herbage was to be sought [in the desert]; (T;) or he dwelt, or abode, in the baAdiyap. (S, K.) It is said in a trad., mano badaA jafaA, i. e. He who abides in the desert becomes rude, rough, coarse, or uncivil, like the desert-Arabs. (S.) And in another, kaAna yaboduw UilaI hecihi AltRilaAEi [He used to go forth to these water-courses in the desert, or these high grounds, or low grounds, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] badaA He voided his excrement, or ordure; (M, K;) as also AbdI↓ (T, K) [and AbdO]: because he who does so goes forth from the tents or houses into the open country. (T.) ＝ -A2- badaAniI bikacaA, aor. yaboduw, is like badaOaniI [i. e. He began with me by
doing such a thing]. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- badiyati AlOaroDu The land produced, or abounded with, badaAp, i. e. truffles: (K, * TA:) or had in it truffles. (TK.) ― -b2- And The land had in it badaAp, meaning dust, or earth. (K, * TK.)

2 bdRI bd bdI bdy
2. bdRI, inf. n. tabodiyapN, He showed, or made apparent, a want that occurred, or presented itself, to him. (TA.) [See bdaMCapN.] ― -b2- He sent forth a horse [or beast] to the place of pasture [app. in the baAdiyap, or desert]. (TA, from a trad.)

3 mubaAdaApN mbAdAh mbAdAp
3. mubaAdaApN The going, or coming, out, or forth, in the field, to encounter another in battle, or war. (TA.) ― -b2- And [more commonly] The showing open enmity, or hostility, with any one: (KL, TA:) [a meaning more fully expressed by the phrase mubaAdaApN biAlEadaAwapi: for you say,] baAdaI biAlEadaAwapi He showed open enmity, or hostility, [with another;] syn. jaAhara bihaA; (S, K; *) as also tbAdI↓: (K:) or you say, bAlEdwAp tbAdwA↓ they showed open enmity, or hostility, one with another; syn. tajaAharuwA bihaA. (S.) You say also, bAdI AlnRaAsa biOamorihi He showed, or revealed, to the people, or to men, his affair, or case. (TA.) [Thus, bAdAhu biAlOamori and lahu AlOamora AbdI↓ signify the same; i. e. He showed, or revealed, to him the affair, or case.] ― -b3- And bAdI bayonahumaA He measured, or compared, them both together, each with the other. (A, TA.)

4 AbdAhu Obd ObdAh ObdI AbdAh AbdAp
4. AbdAhu He made it apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, exhibited, manifested, evinced, discovered, or revealed, it; (S, M, Msb, K;) and it has been said [correctly, as will be seen below,] that AbdI Eanohu signifies the same. (MF, TA.) It is said in a trad., mano yubodi lanaA SafoHatahu naqama Ealayohi kitaAbu QllRehi, i. e. (tropical:) Whoso showeth, or revealeth, to us his deed [or crime] which he was concealing, [the book of God shall execute vengeance upon him, meaning] we will inflict upon him the punishment ordained by the book of God. (TA.) AbdI lahu SafoHatahu also means (tropical:) He showed open enmity, or hostility, with him. (A and TA in art. SfH.) And AbdI Eano qaEorihi, said of water, means It showed its bottom, by reason of its clearness. (L in art. mkd.) See also 3. ― -b2- Oabodayota fiI manoTiqika Thou deviatedst, or hast deviated, from the right way in thy speech. (S.) ― -b3- See also 1.

5 tbdRI ObdI bd bdA tbdI tbdy
5. tbdRI: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- In the common dial. of the people of El-Yemen, it signifies He ate the morning-meal; syn. tagadRaI. (TA.)

6 tbAdI ObAd bAdI tbAdI tbAdy
6. tbAdI: see 3, in two places. ― -b2- Also He affected to be like, or imitated, the people of the baAdiyap [or desert]. (S, K.)

badK bd
badK: see badowN, in two places.

badFA The excrement from the anus (M, K *) of a man. (M.) [And badaMCN, from OabodaOa, signifies the same.] ― -b2- A joint (mafoSil) of a man; (AA, M, K;) as also badoCN: (AA, M:) pl. OabodaMCN. (AA, M, K.) ＝ -A2- badaA for badFA: see badowN, in two places.

badowN bdw bdwy
badowN: see baAdiyapN: ＝ -A2- and see also baAdK. ＝ -A3- Also The first of a thing; originally [badoCN,] with hemzeh: (Har p. 583:) and badiIRN↓, also, [originally badiIoCN,] signifies the first: (TA:) [and badK↓ and badaA↓, the latter for badFA, are used for badoCK. Hence,] one says, AifoEalo celika baAdiI badK↓, (S,) or baAdiIa badK, (M, K,) and baAdiI badiI↓, (Fr, S, M,) or baAdiIa badiI, (as in some copies of the K,) or bAdI badiIK↓, (as in other copies of the K and in the TA,) and baAdaIa badFA↓, (M, K,) mentioned by Sb, who says that it is without tenween, though analogy does not forbid its being with tenween, (M,) meaning Do thou that first; (S, TA;) or, the first thing: (Fr, TA:) originally [baAdiYa badoCK, &c.,] with hemz. (S, K. [See badoCN.]) Hence also the phrase, AlHamodulilehi badiyRFA↓ [Praise be to God in the first place]. (TA.)

badiy bd bdI bdy
badiy for badK: see badowN.

badaApN bd bdAh bdAp bdwy dAhy
badaApN: see badaMCN: ― -b2- and see also baAdiyapN. ＝ -A2- Also, (K, TA,) like qaTaApN, (TA, [but in the CK badoOap, q. v.,]) Truffles; syn. kamoOapN. (K.) ― -b2- And Dust, or earth. (K.)

badowapN bd bdA bdwh bdwp bdwy
badowapN Either side of a valley. (AHn, M, K.)

badawiIRN bdwI bdwy dwAyp dwI dwy
badawiIRN [Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the badow, or desert: and, used as a subst., a man, and particularly an Arab, of the desert:] a rel. n. from badowN, (S, M, K,) extr. [with respect to rule], (M, K,) for by rule it should be badowiIRN; (ElTebreezee, TA;) or it is an irregular rel. n. from baAdiyapN: (Msb:) and badaAwiIRN↓ and bidaAwiIRN↓ are similar rel. ns., (M, K,) from badaAwapN and bidaAwapN, as syn. with badowN and baAdiyapN, agreeably with rule; or the former of these two may be a rel. n. from badowN and baAdiyapN, and therefore extr. [with respect to rule]; but it is said that when a rel. n. may be regarded as regular or irregular, it is more proper to regard it as regular; (M;) or the former is a rel. n. signifying of, or belonging to, or relating to, AlbadaAwap as meaning the dwelling, or abiding, in the desert, (S, TA,) accord. to the opinion of AZ; and the latter is a rel. n. from AlbidaAwap accord. to the opinion of As and others; and is held by Th to be the chaste form: (TA:) but badawiIRN is the only one of these rel. ns. that is known to the common people: (M:) it is opposed to a townsman or villager. (TA.) [The pl. is badaAwaI, and vulg. bidowaAnN. See also baAdK, often applied to a man as syn. with badawiIRN.]

badawaAtN bdAp bdwAt
badawaAtN: see badaMCN, in three places.

badaMCN bdMC
badaMCN [An opinion that occurs to one, or arises in the mind; and particularly one that is different from a former opinion;] a subst. from badaA in the phrase badaA lahu fiI AlOamori. (Msb.) See 1, in four places. One says also, huwa cuw badawaAtK↓ He is one who has various opinions occurring to him, or arising in his mind, (IDrd, S, * K, * and Har p. 665,) of which he chooses some and rejects others: (IDrd, TA:) it is said in praise, (IDrd, TA, and Kzz in Har ubi suprà,) and sometimes in dispraise: (Kzz in Har ubi suprà:) badawaAtN is pl. of badApN↓, [which is therefore syn. with badaMCN,] like as qaTawaAtN is pl. of qaTaApN. (IDrd, TA, and Har ubi supra.) One says likewise Oabuw AlbadawaAti↓, meaning The father [i. e. originator] of opinions that present themselves to him. (IDrd, TA.) And AlsRuloTaAnu cuw EadawaAtK wacuw badawaAtK↓ (S, [in which the context indicates it to mean The Sultán is characterized by deviations from the right way:] but accord. to SM, it is) a trad., meaning the Sultán ceases not to have some new opinion presenting itself to him. (TA.)

bidaMCN bdMC
bidaMCN, in the common dial. of the people of ElYemen, signifies The morning-meal; syn. gadaMCN. (TA.)

badiIN bd bdI bdy
badiIN: see baAdiyapN: ― -b2- and see badowN, in three places. ― -b3- Also, [or biYorN badiIRN,] originally badiIoCN, q. v. in art. bdO, (TA,) A well: (T:) or a well that is not ancient: (TA:) pl. buwdaAnN, formed by transposition from budoyaAnN. (T.)

badaMCapN bdMCh bdMCp
badaMCapN What appears, or becomes apparent, of wants, or needful things: pl. badaAMtN; for which one may also say, badaAwaAtN. (T.) These two pls. also signify Wants that appear, or become apparent, to one. (TA.) [The latter of them is likewise pl. of what next follows.]

badaAwapN bdAwh bdAwp
badaAwapN and bidaAwapN: see baAdiyapN. ― -b2- The former also signifies The first that appears, or becomes apparent, of a thing. (Lh, M, K.) [See badaMCapN.]

badaAwiIRN bdAwI bdAwy
badaAwiIRN and bidaAwiIRN: see badawiIRN.

baAdK Ud bUd bAd bAdy
baAdK Appearing, or apparent; or becoming, or being, apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident. (Msb.) [Hence,] baAdiIa AlrRaOoIi At the [first] appearance of opinion; (Fr, Lh, M;) or according to the appearance of opinion; (Zj, S, K; *) which may mean either insincerely or inconsiderately: (Zj, TA:) so in the Kur xi. 29; (Zj, S;) where only AA read it with hemz: (TA:) if with hemz, it is from badaOotu, and means at first thought, or on the first opinion. (S; and Lh in M, art. bdO: see badoCN.) For baAdiI badK, or baAdiIa badK, and baAdiI badiI, &c., see badowN, in four places. ― -b2- baAdiI badiI is sometimes used as a name for Calamity, or misfortune: it consists of two nouns made one, like maEodiIo kariba. (S.) ― -b3- baAdK also signifies A man going forth to the baAdiyap [or desert]: (M, * Msb, K, * TA:) or one who is in the baAdiyap, dwelling in the tents, and not remaining in his place: (TA:) pl. baAduwna and budRFA [in the TA erroneously said to be budFI like hudFI] and budRaMCN: (M, K:) and badowN↓ is a quasi-pl. n. of baAdK; (M, TA;) or is for Oaholu badowK, meaning people who go forth to the desert; (M;) or it means dwellers in the desert, or people of the desert: (MF:) baAdiyapN↓ also signifies the same as baAduwna, i. e. people migrating from the constant sources of water, and going forth to the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; contr. of HaADirapN; and bawaAdiI [or bawaAdK] is pl. of baAdiyapN. (T.)

baAdaApN OdAp bOdAp bAd bAdAh bAdAp bAdI
baAdaApN: see what next follows.

baAdiyapN bAdy bAdyh bAdyp
baAdiyapN (T, S, &c.) A desert; so called because of its being open, or uncovered; (TA;) contr. of HaDarN; (M, K;) as also badowN↓, (S, * M, Msb, K,) and baAdaApN↓, (M, K,) or badaApN↓, (TA, [thought by SM to be the correct form because found by him in the M, in which I find bAdAp,]) and badiIRN↓, said to be used as syn. with baAdiyapN in a verse of Lebeed cited among the exs. of the preposition bi, p. 142, (TA,) and bdaAwapN↓ (M, K) and bidaAwapN↓; (M;) [of which the last two and the second (namely, badowN,) seem to be originally inf. ns.; see 1:] or a land in which are no towns or villages or cultivated soil: (Lth, T:) or the places to which people migrate from the constant sources of water, when they go forth to the desert, seeking the vicinity of herbage; also termed mabaAdK, which is syn. with manaAjiEu, contr. of maHaADiru, and pl. of mabodFI↓, (T,) this last signifying the contr. of maHoDarN: (S:) the pl. of baAdiyapN is bawaAdK. (T, Msb.) ― -b2- See also baAdK.

mabodFI mbdI mbdy mbdyy
mabodFI: pl. mabaAdK: see baAdiyapN.

1 badiytu biAlXRaIoCi c and badayotu bihi
1. badiytu biAlXRaIoCi badayotu bihi i. q. [badaOotu and] AibotadaOotu [I began with the thing; or made it to have precedence, or to be first]; (M, K;) of the dial. of the Ansár: (M:) the people of ElMedeeneh say, badayonaA, or badiynaA, [accord. to different copies of the S,] in the sense of badaOonaA: (S:) [the right reading seems to be badayonaA; for] IKh says, none says badayotu in the sense of badaOotu, except the Ansár: all others say, badiytu and badaOotu; when the hemzeh is suppressed, the d is pronounced with kesr, and therefore the hemzeh is changed into I. (IB, TA.) [See a verse of Ibn-Rawáhah cited voce badoCN.]

bidaAyapN rky mbd
bidaAyapN, said by Mtr to be a vulgar word, and by IB to be erroneous, but by IKtt to be of the dial. of the Ansár: see art. bdO [voce badoCN, second sentence, in two places]. (TA.)

1 bacRa c
1. bacRa, (M,) sec. pers. bacicota, (S, Mgh, K,) aor. yabacRu, (L, K,) inf. n. bacaAcapN (S, M, Mgh, K) and bucuwcapN (S, M, K) and bacacN (M, Mgh, K) and bacaAcN, (K,) or bicaAcN, with kesr, (TA,) [of all which, the third is the regular form,] He (a man) was, or became, threadbare, and shabby, or mean, in the state of his apparel, (Ks, S, M, Mgh, L,) and in an evil condition; (M, L, K;) slovenly with respect to his person: (Ks, M, L:) or he neglected the constant adornment of himself: or he adorned himself one day, and another day left his hair in a shaggy or dishevelled, or matted and dusty, state: (T, L:) or he was humble in his apparel, not taking pleasure therein. (IAth, L.) bacaAcap is said in a trad. to be a part of religion; (Ks, T, M, Mgh, L;) meaning, in this instance, The being humble in dress, and wearing that which is not conducive to self-conceit and pride. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- bacRahu, aor. yabucRu, (T, S, M, L,) inf. n. bacRN (S, M, L, K) and baciycapN↓, (K,) [or this may be a simple subst.,] He overcame him; (T, S, M, L, K;) he surpassed him in goodliness or beauty, or in any deed: (T, L:) he outstripped him. (M, L.) It is said in a trad., bacRa AlqaAYiliyna He outstripped, or surpassed, and overcame, the speakers. (L.)

, (T,) inf. n. bacaMCN and bacaMCapN, (M, K,) the former written in one copy of the K bacaON, and the latter in some copies written bacoOapN; (TA;) and bacaOa, and baciYa, (K,) aor. of both

[a garment used in service or work, or] an old and worn-out garment: (M, K:) and the latter, [if not a mistranscription for the former,] neglecting the adorning of himself, by way of humility. mutabacRilN (T, M, K) and mubotacilN↓ (M, K) A man who employs his own self in doing a thing; (T;) a man who performs his own work. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also what next precedes.

1. bacuwa, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yabocuw, (T, S,) inf. n. bacaMCN (S, M, Msb, K) and bacaMCapN, (K,) or the latter is the original form, but the p is elided, as in jamaAlN, inf. n. of jamula, (S,) or bacaMCapN is an inf. n. of the verb with C, but that of bcw is bacaMCN; (IB;) and some say, baciIa, (T,) which is a dial. var. of the former, (Msb,) aor. yabocaI, inf. n. bacaMCN; (T in art. bcO;) He (a man) was, or became, foul, unseemly, or obscene [in tongue]; (T, S, M, K;) evil in speech; (T in art. bcO;) as also bacuWa, (T, M, K, in that art.,) and bacaOa, (Msb and K in art. bcO,) and baciYa: (K in that art.:) and AbcI↓ he uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, speech or language. , inf. n. bacaMCN; (Msb;) and Oabocayotu↓ Ealayohimo, (S, Msb, *) or Oabocayotuhumo, (M, IB, K,) or both, (TA,) I uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against the people, or company of men: (S, M, K, TA:) or behaved in a lightwitted, weak, stupid, or foolish, manner, or ignorantly, towards them; and uttered foul, unseemly, or obscene, language against them; and so though with truth.
