OabociyaMCu. (T.)

1 barRa br
1. barRa, [first pers. barirotu,] aor. yabarRu, (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. birRN, (M, Msb, K,) He was pious [towards his father or parents, and (tropical:) towards God; (see the explanations of the verb as used transitively;) and was kind, or good and affectionate and gentle in behaviour, towards his kindred; and kind, or good, in his dealings with strangers]: (Msb:) he was good, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest: (T, Msb:) [or he was amply, largely, or extensively, good or beneficent:] and he was true, or veracious. (M, Msb, K.) [Authorities differ as to the primary signification of this verb, and as to the subordinate meanings: see birRN below.] You say also, barRa fiI qawolihi, (Msb, TA,) and fiI yamiynihi, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) first pers. barirotu (T, A, Mgh, K) and bararotu, (K,) aor. yabarRu (M, Msb) and yabirRN, (M,) inf. n. birRN (S, M, K) and barRN, (K,) or buruwrN, (Msb,) He was true, or veracious, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) in his saying, (Msb, TA,) and in his oath. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b2- barRa Eamalahu, and burRa, inf. n. birRN and buruwrN; and OabarRa↓; [His deed, or work, was, or proved, good; or was well, or sinlessly, performed;] all signify the same. (M.) And burRa AlEamalu, i. e. AlHajRu, a form of benediction, said to a person come from pilgrimage, May the deed, or work, i. e. the pilgrimage, have been sinlessly performed. (TA.) And barRa HajRuhu, (T, S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yabarRu, (T,) inf. n. birRN (S, Msb,) or buruwrN; (T;) and burRa HajRuhu, (Fr, T, S, M, K,) aor. yubarRu, inf. n. birRN; (T;) His pilgrimage was sinlessly performed: (Sh, T:) or was characterized by the giving of food, and by sweetness of speech; as explained by Mohammad himself: was accepted: was rewarded. (TA.) ― -b3- barRa, (A, Msb, K,) aor. yabarRu (T, M, K) and yabirRu, (M, K,) inf. n. birRN (M, Msb, K) and barRN and buruwrN, (M, K,) It (a saying, Msb, and an oath, T, A, M, Msb, K) was, or proved, true. (M, A, * Msb, * K, * TA.) [See an ex. voce OaliyRapN, in art. Alw.] ― -b4- barRato biI siloEatuhu, inf. n. birRN, (tropical:) His commodity, or article of merchandise, was easy of sale to me, (Aboo-Sa'eed, T, A, *) and procured me gain: (A:) originally meaning it recompensed me, by its high price, for my care of it. (T.) [See also barRahu, below.] ＝ -A2- barRa waAlidahu, (M,) [and app. biwaAlidihi, (see barRN,)] first pers. barirotu (S, M, Msb, K) and bararotu, (M, K,) aor. yabarRu (S, M, Msb, K) and yabirRu, (M, K,) inf. n. birRN (S, M, Msb, K) and mabarRapN (S, K, Msb *) and buruwrN, (Msb,) He treated, or behaved towards, his father with filial piety, duty, or obedience; (TA;) or with ample obedience; (B;) the inf. ns. signifying the contr. of EuquwqN: (S, M, A, K:) he treated, or behaved towards, his father with good obedience, and with gentleness, or courtesy, striving to do the things that were pleasing to him, and to avoid what were displeasing to him. (Msb.) And [hence, app., for accord. to the A it is tropical.] barRa xaAliqahu, (S,) or rabRahu, (A,) aor. yabarRu, (S, A,) inf. n. birRN; (T, S, M, K;) and tbrRrhu↓; (S, K; *) (tropical:) He obeyed his Creator, or his Lord; (S, M, * A, K; *) [was pious towards Him;] served Him; rendered religious service to Him: (TA:) or rendered Him ample obedience: the obedience here meant is of two kinds; namely, that of belief and that of works; and both these kinds are meant by AlbirR in the Kur ii. 172. (B.) [And app. barRato waladahaA, or biwaladihaA, She behaved with maternal affection towards her child, or offspring. (See barRN.)] And barRahu, (M,) and barRa raHimahu, (T,) first pers. barirotu, (T, M,) inf. n. birRN, (T, M, K,) He behaved towards him, and towards his kindred, or relations, with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his, or their, circumstances; syn. waSalahu [and waSalahumo]: (T, M, K:) such is said to be the signification of the verb as use in the Kur lx. 8. (M, B, TA. [See also 3.]) And AallRehu yabarRu EibaAdahu (assumed tropical:) God is merciful to his servants: (M, TA:) or barRahu, inf. n. birRN, said of God, means He recompensed him, or rewarded him, for his obedience. (B, TA.) [barRahu bikacaA (occurring in the S and K in explanation of OaloTafahu bikacaA) may be rendered He showed kindness, &c., to him by such a thing, or such an action, &c.: and also he presented him with such a thing; like waSalahu bikacaA.] ― -b2- barRa QllRehu HajRahu, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yabarRu, (Msb,) inf. n. birRN, (S,) or buruwrN, (Msb,) God accepted his pilgrimage; (S, Msb;) as also AbrRhu↓: (T, S, M, Msb:) the latter alone is allowed by Fr: (M, TA:) [though burRa HajRuhu and Eamaluhu, mentioned above, are well known; as is the pass. part. n. maboruwrN, which see below:] and one says, [in like manner,] QllRehu Eamaluhu AbrR↓ [God accepted his deed, or work, as good; approved it]. (M.) ― -b3- See also 4, in three places. ＝ -A3- barRa, (TK,) inf. n. birRN, (S, K,) He drove sheep or goats: (IAar, S, K:) or he called them. (Yoo.) [See also birRN below.]

(S and K in art. lTf: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned. [See also 1.])

(Msb,) and Alyamiyna, (T, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He executed, or performed, the saying, and the oath, truly. (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K.) Accord. to El-Ahmar, one also says, qasamiI barirotu↓; but none other asserts this. (T, TA.) ― -b3- AbrQllRehu qasamahu, (T, TA,) inf. n. UiboraArN; and barRahu↓, inf. n. birRN; God verified his oath. (TA.) ― -b4- AbrR fulaAnN qasama fulaAnK Such a one assented, or consented, to the conjurement of such a one: OaHonavuhu signifies “ he assented not, ” or “ consented not, thereto. ” (T, TA.) ＝ -A3- AbrR Ealayohimo, (S, M, K,) inf. n. as above, (T, TA,) He overcame them: (T, S, M, K:) he subdued them, or overcame them, by good or other actions; (TA;) by actions or sayings; (TA;) as also barRahumo↓, aor. yaburRu: (T, K, TA:) he was refractory, or stubborn, and overcame them. (TA, from a trad.) You say, AbrR EalaI xaSomihi [He overcame his adversary]. (A.) And AbrR Ealayohimo XarRFA [He overcame them in evil]: and hence AbrR is used in the sense of fajara [he transgressed, &c.]; as in the saying of a poet,
falasotu OubaAliI mano OabarRa wa mano fajaro
[Then I care not who acts wickedly and who transgresses]. (IAar, M.) ＝ -A4- AbrR [from barRN] He rode, or journeyed, upon the land. (ISk, S, A, K.) Opposed to OaboHara. (A.)

5. tbrRr [He affected, or endeavoured to characterize himself by, birR, i. e. filial piety, &c.]. ― -b2- qado tabarRarota fiI OamorinaA Thou hast abstained from crime, or sin, or the like, in our affair, or business, or case. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- tbrRr xaAliqahu: see 1.

6. tbArRwA They practised mutual birR [meaning kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for each other's circumstances]. (S.)

R. Q. 1 barobara brbr brbry
R. Q. 1. barobara, inf. n. barobarapN, He talked much, and raised a clamour, or confused noise, (M, K,) with his tongue: (M:) he cried, or cried out, (S, K,) and talked in anger, (S,) or talked confusedly, with anger and aversion. (TA.) And barobara fiI kalaAmihi He was profuse and unprofitable in his talk. (Fr.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He (a goat) uttered a cry or cries, [or rattled,] (M, K,) being excited by desire of the female. (M.)

barRN br
barRN [originally barirN] (M, Msb, K) and baArRN↓ (Msb) Pious [towards his father or parents, and (tropical:) towards God; (tropical:) obedient to God, serving God, or rendering religious service to God; (see 1;) and kind, or good and affectionate and gentle in behaviour, towards his kindred; and good in his dealings with strangers]; good, just, righteous, virtuous, or honest: (Msb:) true, or veracious: (M, Msb, K:) and both signify also abounding in birR [or filial piety, &c.]: (K:) the former is [said to be] a stronger epithet than the latter, like as EadolN is stronger than EaAdilN: (B:) [but its pl. shows that it is not, like EadolN, originally an inf. n.: it is a regular contraction of barirN, like as baArRN is of baArirN:] the fem. of each is with p: (Lh, M:) the pl. (of the former, S, M, Msb, or of the latter, B) is OaboraAN; and (of the latter, S, M, Msb, or of the former, B) bararapN: (S, M, Msb, K:) the former pl. is often specially applied to saints, those who abstain from worldly pleasures, and devotees; and the latter, to the recording angels. (B.) You say, OanaA barRN biwaAlidiI, and baArRN↓, I am characterized by filial piety, dutifulness, or obedience, to my father: (S, M, A: *) the latter is mentioned on the authority of Kr; but some disallow it. (M, TA.) And AlOumRu barRapN biwaladihaA [The mother is maternally affectionate to her child, or offspring]. (S.) And rajulN barRN biciI qaraAbatihi, and baArRN↓, A man who behaves towards his kindred with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for their circumstances. (T.) And rajulN barRN sarRN A man who treats with goodness and affection and gentleness, and rejoices, or gladdens, his brethren: pl. barRuwna sarRuwna. (S, * K, * TA, in art. sr.) And barRN fiI qawolK, and fiI yamiynK, and baArRN↓, True, or veracious, in a saying, and in an oath. (Msb.) And yamiynN barRapN and baArRapN↓ [A true oath; or an oath that proves true]. (Ham p. 811.) AlbarRu is also a name of God; (M, K;) meaning (assumed tropical:) The Merciful, or Compassionate: (M:) or the Very Benign to his servants; (IAth;) the Ample in goodness or beneficence: (B:) AlbaArRu is not so used. (IAth.) It is said in a trad., tamasRaHuwA biAlOaroDi faUinRahaA barRapN bikumo (assumed tropical:) Wipe yourselves with the dust, or earth, [in performing the ceremony termed AltRayamRumu,] for it is benignant towards you, like as the mother is to her children; meaning, ye are created from it, and in it are your means of subsistence, and to it ye return after death: (IAth:) or the meaning is, that your tents, or houses, are upon it, and ye are buried in it. (M.) ＝ -A2- barRN Land; opposed to baHorN [as meaning “ sea ” and the like]: (S, Msb, K:) from birRN signifying “ ampleness, ” “ largeness, ” or “ extensiveness; ” (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee], MF;) or the former word is the original of the latter. (B, TA. [See the latter word.]) [Hence, barRFA wa baHorFA By land and by sea.] ― -b2- A desert, or deserts; a waste, or wastes. (T, TA. [See also barRiyRapN, voce barRiyRN.]) So, accord. to Mujáhid [and the Jel] in words of the Kur [vi. 59], wa yaEolamu maA fiI AlbarRi wa AlbaHori And He knoweth what is in the desert, or deserts, and the towns, or villages, in which is water, (T, TA,) or which are upon the rivers. (Jel.) [So too in the phrase nabaAtu AlbarRi The plants, or herbage, of the desert or waste; the wild plants or herbage. And Easalu AlbarRi Honey of the desert; wild honey. And HayawaAnu AlbarRi The animal, or animals, of the desert; the wild animal or animals.] ― -b3- A wide tract of land. (Bd in ii. 41.) ― -b4- [The open country; opposed to baHorN as meaning the “ cities, ” or “ towns, ” “ upon the rivers: ” see the latter word.] ― -b5- Elevated ground, open to view. (T.) ― -b6- The tract, or part, out of doors, or where one is exposed to view; contr. of kinRN: used by the Arabs indeterminately; [without the article Al;] as in the phrase, jalasotu barRFA (Lth, T) meaning I sat outside the house; (A;) and xarajotu barRFA (Lth, T) meaning I went forth outside the [house or] town, (A,) or into the desert: (TA:) but [Az says,] these are post-classical phrases, which I have not heard from the chaste-speaking Arabs of the desert. (T.) ― -b7- You say also, Oariydu jawRFA wa yuriydu barRFA I desire concealment, or secrecy, and he desires publicity. (A.)

burRN br
burRN Wheat; and the grain of wheat; syn. qamoHN, (S, * Msb,) or HinoTapN; (M, K;) but it is a more chaste word than qamoHN and HinoTapN: (M:) pl. of burRapN; (S, M;) or [rather] burRapN is the n. un. [signifying a grain of wheat, like qamoHapN]: (IDrd, Msb:) the pl. of burRN is OaboraArN; (K;) or this pl. is allowable on the ground of analogy, accord. to Mbr, but is disallowed by Sb. (S.) It is said in a prov., (TA,) huwa OaqoSaru mino brRapK [He, or it, is shorter than a grain of wheat]. (A, TA.) And you say, OaToEmanaA Qbona burRapK He fed us with bread. (A.)

birRN br
birRN inf. n. of 1: (T, S, M, &c.:) it is said by some to signify primarily Ampleness, largeness, or extensiveness; whence barRN as opposed to baHorN: then, ― -b2- Benevolent and solicitous regard or treatment or conduct [to parents and others; i. e. piety to parents; and (tropical:) towards God]: and goodness, or beneficence: and kindness, or good and affectionate and gentle behaviour, and regard for the circumstances of another: (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee], MF:) or barRN, as opposed to baHorN, [or as signifying “ a wide tract of land, ” (Bd in ii. 41,)] is the original of birRN, (Bd in ii. 41, B, TA,) which signifies ample, large, or extensive, goodness or beneficence, (Z, in the Ksh, ii. 41, [but he regards it as the original of barRN,] and Bd on the same passage, and B, K, TA,) to men; (TA;) or comprehending every kind of goodness: (Ksh and Bd ubi suprà:) and hence it is said to be in three things: in the service of God: in paying regard to relations; acting well to them: and in dealing with strangers: (Bd ubi suprà:) or every deed that is approved: (Ksh and Bd in ii. 172:) and [particularly] obedience to God: (T, S, M, &c.: [see also barRapu:]) [and every incumbent duty: and hence,] the pilgrimage to Mekkeh: (K:) and fidelity to an engagement: (TA:) also a gratuitous gift, or favour; and a bounty, or benefit; syn. faDolN; (Msb;) and UiHosaAnN; as also mabarRapN↓ [an inf. n., but when used as a simple subst. its pl. is mabaArN and mabarRaAtN]. (Har p. 94.) In the Kur [ii. 172], where it is said, lukinRa AlbirRa mano Mmana biAQllRehi, by AlbrR is meant caA AlbirRi [i. e. But the pious, or obedient to God, is he who believeth in God]; (T, M, Ksh, Bd, Jel;) and some read AlbaArRa: (Ksh, Bd, Jel:) or the meaning is, lknR AlbirRa birRu mn Mmn bA llReh i. e. but the obedience of which it behooveth one to be mindful is the obedience of him who believeth in God: (Sb, T, IJ, M, Ksh, Bd:) and this explanation is preferable to the former. (Bd.) It is said in a prov., (T, S,) laA yaEorifu hirRFA mino birK, (S, A, K, but in the T and M maA is put in the place of lA,) meaning He knows not him who dislikes him, or hates him, from him who behaves
towards him with kindness, or goodness and affection and gentleness, and regard for his circumstances: (S, M, A, K, * TA:) or undutiful conduct to a parent from gentleness, or courtesy: (ElFezáree, T, K:) or altercation, (T,) or dislike, or hatred, (K,) from honourable treatment: (T, K:) or the calling of sheep, or goats, from the driving of them: (IAar, S, K:) or the driving of sheep, or goats, from the calling of them: (Yoo, T:) or the calling of them to water from the calling of them to fodder; (K;) which last rendering is agreeable with an explanation of birRN by IAar [mentioned in the T]; (TA;) and birobirN↓, also, has the signification here assigned to birRN: (K, * TA:) or Alharoharap from Albarobarap; (A'Obeyd, T, K;) i. e. the crying of sheep from the crying of goats: (A'Obeyd, T:) or the cat from the rat, or mouse: (IAar, T, M, K:) and birRN also signifies the [species of rat called] jurac: (Aboo-Tálib, T, K:) or a small animal resembling the rat or mouse: (M:) and the young of the fox. (K.) ― -b3- Also Good, as a subst., not an adj.; syn. xayorN; (Sh, T, Mgh, Msb, K;) which comprises all that has been said in explanation of birRN (Sh, T, Mgh) as used in the saying of Mohammad, Ealyokumo biAlSRidoqi faUinRahu yahodiI UilaI AlbirRi [Keep ye to truth; for it guides to good, or to a good, or right, state]: some render it in this instance by Alxayor; and some, by AlSRalaAH. (Sh, T.) It signifies also The good of the present life, consisting in spiritual and worldly blessings, and of that which is to come, consisting in everlasting enjoyment in Paradise: so in the Kur iii. 86: (T:) or [simply] Paradise. (K.) ― -b4- Also The heart; or the mind. (K.) So in the saying, huwa muTomaYinRu AlbirRi [He is quiet, or at rest, in heart, or mind]. (TA.)

barRapu br brh brp
barRapu a subst. in the sense of AlbirRu, (S, M, K,) meaning Obedience [&c.]; (K;) determinate, (S, K,) being a proper name; for which reason, combined with its being of the fem. gender, it is imperfectly decl. (M.) [It is opposed to fajaAri. See a verse of En-Nábighah in the first paragraph of art. Hml.]

bariyrN bryr
bariyrN [a coll. gen. n.] The fruit of the OaraAk [q. v.], (S, M,) in a general sense: (M:) or the first thereof; (K;) [i. e.] the first that appears, or when it first appears, and is sweet: (M:) or when it has become hard: (Msb:) or when it is larger in its berries (HabR) than such as is termed kabaAv, and smaller in its clusters; having a round, small, hard stone, a little larger than the HimRaS; its cluster filling the hand: (AHn, M:) n. un. with p. (AHn, S, M, Msb.)

burRaI br brI bry ry
burRaI A good, sweet, or pleasant, word or expression or saying: (K:) from birRN signifying “ benevolent and solicitous regard or treatment or conduct. ” (TA.)

barRiIRN br brI bry ry
[barRiIRN Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the land as opposed to the sea or a great river. ― -b2- And Of, or belonging to, or relating to, the desert or waste; growing, or living, or produced, in the desert or waste; wild, or in an uncultivated state. ― -b3- And hence,] OaroDN barRiyRapN Uncultivated land; without seed-produce, and unfruitful; without green herbs or leguminous plants and without waters; contr. of riyfiyRapN. (IAar, M, K. *) And, simply, barRayRapN↓, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and barRiytN↓, (A'Obeyd, IAar, Sh, S, K,) the latter a variation of the former, the I being made quiescent, and the p therefore being changed into t, as in EiforiytN, originally EiforiyapN, (S,) a rel. n. from barRN, (Sh, T, Msb,) A desert; a waste; a spacious tract of ground without herbage; syn. SaHoraMCu: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) [see also barRN:] or a tract nearer to the desert (AlbarR) than it is to water: (Sh, T:) [but some write the latter word birRiytN↓; and it is said that] birRiytu, (T and K in art. brt,) of the same measure as sikRiytN, (K in that art.,) signifies flat, even, or level, land: (T, K:) or a barren, flat, even, or level, land: a poet says,
birRiytu OaroDK baEodahaA birRiytu
[A barren, flat land, after which is a second barren, flat land]: (T:) ISd says that birRiytN, in a poem of Ru-beh, [from which the ex. given above is probably taken,] is of the measure fiEoliytN from AlbarRu; and that art. brt is not the place in which it should be mentioned: (TA:) Lth says, AlbarRiytu is a noun derived from AlbarRiyRapu; the I becoming quiescent, and the p becoming an inseparable t, as though it were a radical letter, as in the case of EiforiyapN, which thus becomes EiforiytN: (T, TA:) the pl. of brRyRp is baraAriIRu; and that of brRyt is baraAriytu. (S.)

barRiyRapN bry bryh bryp ry rYp
barRiyRapN and barRiytN and birRiytN: see barRiIRN.

barRaArN brAr
barRaArN as signifying A possessor of burR, i. e. wheat, though agreeable with prevailing analogy, is not allowable, not being sanctioned by usage. (Sb, M.)

barRaAniIRN brAnI brAny brI brnyp
barRaAniIRN External; or outward: apparent; public. (T.) Hence the saying of Selmán, (T,) mano OaSolaHa jawRaAniyRahu OaSolaHa QllRehu barRaAniyRahu (T, A, K) Whoso maketh his inner man (sariyratahu) to be good, God will make his outward man (EalaAniyatahu) to be good. (T.) barRaAniIRN is a rel. n., irregularly formed, (K,) from barRN signifying “ elevated ground, open to view; ” and jawRaAniIRN, from jawRN signifying “ any low, or depressed, part of the ground. ” (T.) You say, AfotataHa AlbaAba AlbarRaAniIRa He opened the outer door. (A.)

barobaru, (S, K,) or Albarobaru, (Mgh, Msb,) [a coll. gen. proper name, of which the n. un., or rel. n., is barobariIRN↓,] a foreign word, (S,) [probably of African origin, the primary form of which is the source of βάρβαρος, &c.,] arabicized; (Msb;) or, as some say, from barobarapN in speech; (TA; [see R. Q. 1;]) and AlbaraAbirapu, (S, M, Msb, K,) the pl. of barobaru, (K,) or of Albarobaru, (Msb,) [or of barobariIRN, agreeably with what follows and with analogy,] the p being added because the sing. is a foreign word, or [so in the M and TA, but in the S “ and, ”] a rel. n., (S, M,) but it may be elided; [so that one may say AlbaraAbiru;] (S;) A certain people, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of the inhabitants of El-Maghrib [or Northern Africa west of Egypt], (Mgh, * Msb, K, *) like the Arabs of the desert in hardness, and coarseness, or rudeness, (Mgh, * Msb,) and in slightness of religion, and littleness of knowledge: (Mgh:) and another people, [the Colobi mentioned by Diodorus Siculus and Strabo,] between the Abyssinians and the Zinj, who amputate [the glans of] the penis, and make it a dowry for a wife. (K.) [There are various opinions of the origins of these races. The appellation of AlbaraAbirapu, sing. barobariIRN↓, is also applied by late historians, and in the present day, to The races inhabiting the portion of the valley of the Nile which we commonly call Nubia.]

baraAa
, (T, M, &c.,) inf. n. baroCN (T, S, M, K) and buruwoCN, (AZ, Lh, M, K,) God created mankind, or the beings, or things, that are created, syn. xalaqa, (Fr, T, M, Msb, K,) after no similitude, or model, (TA,) [but, properly, though not always meaning so, out of pre-existing matter; for] Bd says [in ii. 51] that the primary meaning of the root brC is to denote a thing's becoming clear, or free, of, or from, another thing; either by being released [therefrom], as in bariYa AlmariyDu mino maraDihi and Almadoyuwnu mino daynihi [both sufficiently explained above]; or by production [therefrom], as in baraOa QllRehu Mdama mina AlTRiyni [God produced, or created, Adam, from, or out of, clay]. (TA.) This verb relates to substances [as in the exs. given above] and to accidents; and hence, [in the Kur lvii. 22,] mino qboli Oano naboraOahaA [Before our creating it, if hA refer to muSiybap, preceding it; but, as Bd says, it may refer to this, or to AlOaroD, or to Oanofus]: (M:) but AlbaroCu has a more particular application than Alxaloqu; the former being particularly applied to the creation of animate beings, with few exceptions: you say, baraOa QllRehu AlnRasamapa wa xalaqa AlsRamewaAti waAlOaroDa [God created, or produced, man, or the soul, and He created the heavens and the earth]. (TA.) [To this verb, or perhaps to baray, or to both, בָּרָ is the Hebrew equivalent, properly (though not necessarily always) signifying “ he created out of pre-existing matter, ” or “ he fashioned. ”]

2. brROhu, inf. n. taborYapN: see 4, in four places. [Hence,] laA AltRaboriYapi The lA that denies in a general manner, absolutely, or to the uttermost; i. e. the lA that is a universal negative. (Mughnee &c.) ― -b2- Also He verified his being free [from a thing], clear, or quit, [of it,] guiltless [of it], or irresponsible [for it]. (Mgh, TA.)

3 bArOhu c
3. bArOhu, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) inf. n. mubaAraOapN (T, M, Mgh) and biraMCN, (M,) He made him (his copartner) free, clear, quit, or irresponsible, the latter doing to him the same: (Mgh:) he compounded, or made a compromise, with him (his hired man, T, M) for their mutual separation: (M:) he separated himself from him (his copartner, S, O), the latter doing the same. (S, O, K.) And baAraOotu AlrRajula I became free, clear, quit, or irresponsible, to the man, he becoming so to me. (M.) And bArO AlmaroOapa, (T, M, K,) or QmoraOatahu, (S,) inf. n. as above, (M,) He compounded, or made a compromise, with the woman (or his wife, S) for their mutual separation; (M, K;) i. e. he divorced her for a compensation [which she was to make him, such as her giving up a portion of her dowry remaining due to her, in order that they might be clear, each of the other]: it occurs also [without C] in art. brI. (TA.)

4 AbrOhu c
4. AbrOhu He (God, S, M, K) [recovered him, or] restored him to convalescence, (M, K,) mina AlmaraDi [from the disease, sickness, or malady]. (S.) ― -b2- OaboraOaka mina AlOamori and barRaOaka↓ (M, K *) He (i. e. God, TA) made thee, pronounced thee, or held thee, or hath made thee, &c., or may He make thee, &c., to be free from the thing or affair, or clear or quit thereof, or guiltless thereof, or irresponsible for it; (TA;) [or He acquitted thee, or hath acquitted thee, or may He acquit thee, thereof; or He showed thee, or hath showed thee, or may He show thee, to be free from it, &c.: see also 2, above:] said in relation to [a fault or the like, and] a debt, and a claim, and religion [&c.]. (M.) You say, mina AlEayobi barRaOotuhu↓ I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be free from the fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 69], fabarRaOohu↓ QllRehu mimaA qaAluwA (M) But God showed him to be clear of that which they said. (Bd.) You say also, OaboraOotuhu mina AldRayoni I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be clear, or quit, of the debt; irresponsible for it; or in a state of immunity with respect to it; i. e., exempt from the demand thereof: (Msb:) and OaboraOotuhu mimRaA liI Ealayohi; and barRaOotuhu↓, inf. n. taboriYapN; [I acquitted him of that which he owed me:] (S:) and OaboraOotuhu [alone] I made him, pronounced him, or held him, to be clear, or quit, of a claim that I had
upon him, or a due or right that he owed me. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- AbrO [in the T (as on the authority of Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee) OaboraI] He entered upon [the night, or day, called] AlbaraMC, q. v. (K.)

10 AstbrO c
10. AstbrO, (T,) or AstbrO mina Albawoli, (Msb,) He took extraordinary pains, or the utmost pains, in cleansing the orifice of his penis from the remains of urine, by shaking it and pulling it and the like, until he knew that nothing remained in it: (T:) or he purified, or cleansed, himself from urine; syn. tanazRahu Eanohu: (Msb:) or AstbrO, (M,) or AstbrO AlcRakara, (K, TA,) signifies he took extraordinary pains, or the utmost pains, in cleansing the penis from urine; or he cleansed it entirely from urine; (M, * K, * TA;) and so AstbrO Alfaroja: and in like manner, AstbrOti Alfaroja said of a woman: (El-Munáwee, TA:) but the lawyers make a distinction between AsotiboraMCN and AisotinoqaMCN [which are made syn. in the M and K]: see the latter word. (TA.) ― -b2- And AstbrO AljaAriyapa, (T, S, Mgh,) or AlmaroOapa, (M, Msb, K,) He abstained from sexual intercourse (T, M, K) with the girl whom he had purchased or whom he had taken captive, (T,) or with the woman, (M, K,) until she had menstruated (T, M, K) at his abode, once, and then become purified: (T:) the meaning is, (T,) he sought to find her free from pregnancy. (T, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- Hence, (Mgh,) AstbrO AlXRayoCi, (Z, Mgh, Msb,) or AlOamora, (TA,) He searched, searched out, or sought to find or discover, the uttermost of the thing, or affair, (Z, Mgh, Msb, TA,) in order that he might know it, (Mgh,) to put an end to his doubt. (Z, Mgh, Msb, TA.) You say, AisotaboraOotu maA Einodaka [I searched, or sought to find or discover, or I have searched, &c., the uttermost of what thou hast, of knowledge &c.]. (S, TA.) And AstbrO OroDa kacaA famaA wajada DaAlRatahu [He searched the uttermost of such a land and found not his stray beast]. (TA.) It is said in the Expos. of the Jámi' es-Sagheer that AisotiboraMCN is an expression denoting The seeking, or seeking leisurely and repeatedly, to obtain knowledge of a thing, until one knows it; considering it with the endeavour to obtain a clear knowledge of it; taking, in doing so, the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, or good judgment. (Mgh.)

[At it (a source of water mentioned in the context) were hunters' lurking-places, like young palmtrees covered over: for tender young palm-trees are often covered over with a kind of coarse matting]. (T, S, M.)

baraMCN: see bariIoCN, in six places. ― -b2- AlbaraMCN The first night of the [lunar] month; (El-Mázinee, T, S, K;) called thus, (S,) or layolapu AlbaraMCi, (M,) because the moon has then become clear of the sun: (S, M:) or the first day of the month: (AA, T, K:) or the last night thereof: (As, T, K:) or the last day thereof; (IAar, T, K;) a fortunate day; every event happening therein being regarded as a means of obtaining a blessing; (IAar, T;) but most hold that the last day of the month is termed AlnRaHiyrapN; (TA;) as also Aibonu AlbaraMCi: (K:) or this is the first day of the month: (IAar, T, TA:) pl. OaboriYapN. (Th, M.)

bariIoCN Free, (Msb,) minohu from it; namely a fault, defect, imperfection, blemish, or vice; (Mgh, Msb;) and, also followed by minohu, clear, or quit, of it; irresponsible for it; or in a state of immunity with respect to it; i. e. exempt from the demand thereof; namely a debt, (Msb,) or a claim, or due, or right; (Mgh;) as also baAriIN↓ and baraMCN↓. (Msb.) You say, OanaA bariIoCN minohu [I am free from it, &c.]; (T, * S, M, K; *) and baraMCN↓, used alike as sing. and dual and pl. (Fr, T, S, M, K) and masc. and fem., (Fr, T, M, K,) because it is originally an inf. n.; (Fr, T, S;) and buraMCN↓: (S, M:) the pl. of bariIoCN is bariyWuwna (T, S, K) and buraOCu (T, S, M, K) and buraMCN, (T, M, K,) of the measure fuEaAlN, (T,) like ruxaAlN, (M, K,) of an extr. measure, disapproved by Suh, who says, in the R, that it is a contraction of buraOCu, and has tenween because it resembles [words originally of the measure] fuEaAlN, and that the rel. n. formed from it is buraAwiIRN↓, (TA,) but it is mentioned by AAF as a pl. of bariIoCN, and as being like ruxaAlN, and Fr mentions buraMCu as a pl. of the same, imperfectly decl., with one of the two hemzehs suppressed, (M,) and biraMCN (S, M, K) and OaboraMCN (S, K) and OaboriYaMCu, (T, S, K,) the last two anomalous: (TA:) the fem. of bariyoCN is bariyoYapN; pl. bariyoMtN (T, S, M, K) and bariyRaAtN (Lh, M, K) and baraAyaA. (T, S, M, K.) You say, OanaA bariIoCN minohu and xaliIRN minohu [I am free from it; or, more commonly, I am clear, or quit, of it, or him]; and minohu OnaA baraMCN↓ and xalaMCN minohu; (S;) and minohu OanaA AlbaraMCu↓: (M:) and naHonu minoka AlbaraMCu↓ and AlxalaMCu [We are clear, or quit, of you]; (Fr, T;) i. e., cawuw AlbaraMCi: so says Aboo-Is-hák; and As says the like of what Fr says. (T.) It is said in the Kur [xliii. 25], mimRaA taEobuduwna UinRaniI baraMCN↓ [Verily I am clear of that which ye worship]; (T, M;) or bariIoCN, or buraMCN↓; accord. to different readers. (Bd.) bariIoCN occurs in several places in the Kur. (M.) Accord. to IAar, it signifies Clear of evil qualities or dispositions; shunning what is vain and false; remote from actions that occasion suspicion; pure in heart from associating any with God: and it signifies sound in body and intellect. (T.) See also baAriYN, in two places.

AlbariyRapu The creation; as meaning the beings, or things, that are created; or, particularly, mankind; syn. Alxaloqu: (T, S, M:) pronounced without C; (T, S;) originally with C, like nabiIRN and curRiyapN; (M;) and the people of Mekkeh differ from the other Arabs in pronouncing these three words with C: (Yoo, T, M:) Lh says that the Arabs agree in omitting the C in these three instances; and he does not except the people of Mekkeh: (M:) it is of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of mafoEuwlapN, (Msb,) from baraOa QllRehu Alxaloqa, meaning xalaqahumo: (Fr, T:) or, if derived from AlbaraI [“earth” or “dust”], it is originally without C: (Fr, T, S:) pl. baraAyaA and bariyRaAtN. baAriYN, (K,) or baAriYN mino maraDihi, (Lh, S, M,) [Recovering from his disease, sickness, or malady: or] convalescent; or becoming sound, or healthy, at the close of his disease, but being yet weak; or recovering, but not completely, his health and strength: [see 1:] (M, K:) as also bariYoCN↓: (Lh, M, K:) but whether the latter be properly used in this sense is disputed; while the former is said to be the act. part. n. of 1 in all its senses: (TA:) pl. biraMCN, (M, K,) like as SiHaAHN is pl. of SaHiyHN, accord. to Lh, so that he holds it to be pl. of bariIoCN; or it may be pl. of baAriYN, like as jiyaAEN is pl. of jaAYiEN, and SiHaAbN of SaAHibN. (M.) bariIoCN↓ is sometimes written and pronounced bariIRN [in all its senses]. (Kz.) ― -b2- See also bariyoCN. ＝ -A2- AlbaAriYu, applied to God, The Creator; (T, S, Msb;) He who hath created the things that are created, not after any similitude, or model; (Nh;) or He who hath created those things free from any incongruity, or faultiness, (Mgh, and Bd in ii. 51,) and distinguished, one from another, by various forms and outward appearances: (Bd:) or the Former, or Fashioner; syn. AlmuSawRiru [q. v.]. (M.)

barobaTN [The Persian lute;] a certain musical instrument (Lth, Msb) of the Eajama [or Persians]; (Msb;) i. q. EuwidN: (Lth, K:) an arabicized word, (K,) from baribato, (IAth,) or baribaTo; meaning “the breast of the duck, or goose;” because of its
resemblance thereto; (K;) for baro in Persian, signifies the “breast;” (TA;) [and bato and baTo or baTRo, like the Arabic baTRN, “a duck,” or “goose;”] or because the player upon it places it against his breast: (IAth:) or it is said to be arabicized because it is the name of a musical instrument of the Ejm. (Msb.)

burovunN, of the lion, (AZ, T,) and of any animal of prey, (AZ, As, T, S, M, K,) and of birds, (As, S,) [The toe; i. e.] what corresponds to the UiSobaE of a man; (AZ, As, T, S, M, K;) [in the Lex. of Golius, as on the authority of the S, and in that of Freytag, idem quod Anmlp in homine; but this is a mistake, app. occasioned by a mistranscription in a copy of the S;] and the mixolab is its claw, i. e., nail: (AZ, As, T, S:) or the paw (kafR), (M, K,) altogether, (M,) with the OaSaAbiE [or toes]: (M, K:) or the claw, i. e. nail, of the lion, (Lth, T, M, K,) likened to the instrument for perforating leather; (Lth, T;) and of [all] animals of prey, and of birds that do not prey, corresponding to the Zufor of man: Th says, of man, it is [termed] the Zufor; of animals having the kind of foot called xufR, the manosimo; of solidhoofed animals, the HaAfir; of cloven-hoofed animals, the Zilof; of beasts and birds of prey, the mixolab; and of birds that do not prey, and of dogs and the like, the burovun; though it may be also used [in like manner] of all animals of prey: (Msb:) [but properly] it is of birds that do not prey, as the crow-kind, and the pigeon; (M;) and sometimes, of the [lizard called] DabR, (S, M,) and of the rat, or mouse, and of the jerboa: (M:) and is, in the pl. form, (M, TA,) which is baraAvinu, (T, S, M, TA,) metaphorically applied, by Sá'ideh Ibn-Jueiyeh, to the fingers of a man gathering honey [deposited by wild bees in a hollow of a rock]. (M, * TA.) ― -b2- burovunu AlOasadi also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon camels, (K, TA,) in the form of the claw of the lion. (TA.) ― -b3- This, also, is the name of a sword of Marthad Ibn-'Alas. (K.) ― -b4- [burovunapN seems to signify the same as burovunN or baraAvinu: for] Temeem are termed in a trad. the burovumap and burojumap of the tribes of Mudar; and El-Khattábee says that it should be the burovunap, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The claw, or] the claws; meaning thereby their impetuous valour, and strength: but brvmp may be a dial. var. of brvnp, or the m may be substituted for the n for the purpose of assimilation [to brjmp]. (TA.)

5 tabarRajato tbrj tbrjt
5. tabarRajato She (a woman) showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, (S, Msb, K,) and beauties of person or form or countenance, (S, Msb,) to men, (S, K,) or to strangers, or men distantly related to her; (Msb;) to do which is culpable; but to do so to the husband is not: (TA:) or she showed her face: or she showed the beauties of her neck and face: or she did so exhibiting a pretty look: (TA:) or she showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, and what excites a man's lust. (A boo-Is-hák, TA.) Fr, referring to verse 33 of ch. xxxiii. of the Kur, says that in the time when Abraham was born, the women used to wear a shirt of pearls, not sewed at the two sides; or, as some say, they used to wear garments which did not conceal their persons. (TA.)

burojN brj rj
burojN [Gr. πύργος, (Golius,) A tower;] an angle, syn. rukon, (S, K,) of a fortress, (S,) or of a city: (TA:) and sometimes a fortress itself: (S, K:) so called from its conspicuousness and construction and height: (TA: [see 1:]) or the primary signification of brj is strength; whence Oaboraju in a sense explained below: (Har p. 286:) pl. [of mult.] buruwjN and [of pauc.] OaboraAjN: (S:) the buruwjN of the wall of a city or fortress are chambers (buyuwt [meaning towers]) built upon the wall: and such chambers (bywt) built upon the sides of the angles of a qaSor [i. e. pavilion or palace &c.] are sometimes thus called. (Lth.) [Hence,] buroju HamaAmK [A pigeon-turret; a pigeon-house; being generally constructed in the form of a turret, or of a sugar-loaf;] a lodging-place of pigeons: pl. as above. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) [A sign of the Zodiac;] one of the buruwj of the heaven; (S, K;) which are twelve in number; every one having a distinct name: (TA:) the Arabs in ancient times did not know them: (Ham p. 560:) pl. OaboraAjN as well as buruwjN: (Msb, TA:) these are meant by the buruwj mentioned in the Kur xv. 16 and xxv. 62 and lxxxv. 1: (Bd, Jel:) or in the last of these instances, (Bd,) by the brwj in the heaven are meant the Mansions of the Moon: (Bd, Msb:) or the stars or asterisms or constellations: (TA:) or the great stars or asterisms or constellations; (Bd, Msb;) and so, accord. to Zj, in the second of the said passages of the Kur: (TA:) or the gates of heaven: (Bd, Msb:) or, as some say, i. q. quSuwr [i. e. pavilions &c.]. (TA.)

barajN Such a constitution of the eye that the white entirely surrounds the black, (S, M, K,) no part of the black being concealed: (S, M:) or width of the eye: or width of the white of the eye, and largeness of the eyeball, and beauty of the black part: or clearness of the white and black parts theeeof: (M, TA:) or width of the eye, and largeness of the eyeball: (Ham p. 560:) or width of the eye with intense whiteness of the person: (TA:) and distance between the eyebrows. (L, TA.) [See also balajN.] ＝ -A2- Goodly, elegant, or pretty; beautiful of face: or [so in copies of the K, and in the TA, but in the CK “and”] shining, or splendid; conspicuous; and well known. (K.)

burojumapN (in the Ham p. 352 burojumN) is the sing. of baraAjimu (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and burojumaAtN; (T, TA;) and signifies [A knuckle, or finger-joint;] the outer, or the inner, joint, or place of division, of the fingers: and (as some say, TA) the middle toe of any bird: (K:) or baraAjimu signifies all the finger-joints; (A'Obeyd, K;) as also rawaAjimu [a mistranscription for rawaAjib]: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or the parts of the fingers that are protuberant when one clinches his hand: (Ham ubi suprà:) or the backs of the finger-bones: (K:) or the finger-joints (S, Mgh) that are between the OaXaAjiE and the rawaAjib; (S;) i. e. (S, Mgh) [the middle knuckles; (see OaXojaEu and raAjibapN;)] the heads of the sulaAmayaAt, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) on the back, or outer side, of the hand, (S, Msb,) which become protuberant when one clinches his hand: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or, as in the Kf, the heads of the slAmyAt; and their inner and outer sides are termed the rawaAjib: (Msb:) accord. to the T, the wrinkled parts at the joints of the fingers; the smooth portion between which is called raAjibapN: or, as in another place, in the backs of the fingers; the parts between them being called the rawaAjib: in every finger are three burojumaAt, except the thumb: or, as in another place, in every finger are two of what are thus termed: it is also explained as signifying the joints in the backs of the fingers, upon which the dirt collects. (TA.) The phrase AlOaxocu biAlbaraAjimi, meaning The seizing
with the hand, is one requiring consideration [as of doubtful character]. (Mgh.) [See also burovunN.]

1 bariHa brH
1. bariHa is syn. with zaAla [in two senses; i. e. as an attributive verb, and also as a non-attributive verb; as will be shown by what follows]. (S, A, Mgh.) [Using it as an attributive verb,] you say, laA OaboraHu HatRaI taqoDiIa HaAjatiI I will not go away, or depart, or withdraw, (laA OazuwlN, and laA OatanaHRaIi,) until thou accomplish my want: from bariHa AlmakaAnu, inf. n. baraAHN, he went away, or departed, from the place; syn. zaAla minohu: and to be distinguished from the phrase in the Kur [xviii. 59, similar as to words,] mentioned below. (Mgh.) You say, bariHa makaAnahu, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
baraHa
, (K,) inf. n. baraAHN (S, L, K) and buruwHN (L, TA, and Ham p. 250) and baraHN, (L,) or baroHN, (as in a copy of the TA,) He went away, or departed, from his place; (S, L, K, and Ham ubi suprà;) and he became in the baraAH [or wide, uncultivated, or uninhabited, tract]. (S, L, K.) And maA bariHa makaAnahu He did not quit his place. (Msb.) And bariHa [alone], aor.
baraHa
, inf. n. baraAHN, It (a thing) went away, or departed, (zaAla,) from its place; (Msb;) as also tbrRH↓. (L.) In the phrase laA baraAHa [There is, or shall be, no quitting of place, or going away, or departing], the noun is in the accus. case, as in laA rayoba: but it is allowable to put it in the nom. case, so that lA is used in the manner of layosa; (S, K;) as in the following saying of Saad Ibn-Málik, [in the TA, in one place, Ibn-Náshib,] in a poem of which the rhyme is with refa, (S, IAth,) alluding to El-Hárith Ibn-'Abbád, who had withdrawn himself from the war of Teghlib and Bekr the sons of Wáïl: (IAth, TA:)
faOanaA Qbonu qayosK laA baraAHu mano farRaEano niyraAnihaA
[Whoso fleeth from its fires, (i. e. niyraAni AlHarobi the fires of the war,) let him do so: but as for me, I am the son of Keys: to me there is not, or shall not be, any quitting of place]. (S, IAth. [See also Ham p. 250, where, for man farRa, we find mano SadRa whoso turneth away.]) [Hence,] bariHati AlrRiyHu biAltRuraAbi The wind carried up, raised, or swept up and scattered, [lit. went away with,] the dust. (Msb.) [Hence also, accord. to some,] bariHa AlxafaMCu, (T, S, K, &c.,) and baraHa, (Ibn-ElLihyánee, Z, and TA, [thus written in a copy of the A,]) (tropical:) The state of concealment departed, or ceased: or (tropical:) what was in a state of concealment became apparent; from baraAHN meaning “what is open and apparent” of land: or (tropical:) what I was concealing became apparent: (T, TA:) or (tropical:) the affair, or case, became manifest, (S, A, K,) and its concealment ceased, (A,) [or] as though the secret departed, and ceased: (S:) or, as some say, (assumed tropical:) the secret became apparent: (TA in art. xfI:) or, lit., the low ground became high and apparent; meaning (assumed tropical:) what was concealed became revealed: (Har pp. 133—4:) the first who said it was Shikk the Diviner. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b2- [Using it as a non-attributive verb,] you say, laA OaboraHu OafoEalu celika I will not cease, or I will continue, (laA OazaAlu,) to do that: (S, A: *) and maA bariHa yafoEalu kacaA [he ceased not to do thus; or] he persevered in, or kept to, doing thus: (Msb:) and maA bariHa zayodN qaAYimFA [Zeyd ceased not to be, or he kept, or continued, standing]: in this case, the verb is of the category of kaAna; (Mgh;) relates to time; and requires a predicate: and its inf. n. is baraAHN. (Ham p. 250.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xviii. 59], laA OaboraAHu HatRaI Oaboluga majomaEa AlbaHorayoni, but the predicate is suppressed: it may be maA naHonu fiyhi kacelika [i. e. I will not cease in that wherein we are thus engaged until I reach the place of meeting of the two seas]: (Mgh:) or it means laA OazaAlu Oasiyru [I will not cease journeying]: (Bd, Jel:) or lA AbrH here may mean I will not depart (laA Oazuwlu) from that upon which I am intent, namely journeying and seeking; and I will not relinquish it; so that it does not require the predicate. (Bd. [He gives a third explanation, paraphrastic and strained, which I omit.]) ＝ -A2- baraHa, (S, K,) aor.
baraHa
, (L, TA, [but it is implied in the K that it is
baruHa
, which is contr. to rule,]) inf. n. buruwHN, It (a gazelle, S, K, and a bird, and any wild animal, that is hunted or shot, TA) turned its left side towards the spectator, passing by (S, K *) from the direction of his right hand towards that of his left hand: (S:) or passed by from the direction of the spectator's left hand towards that of his right hand: (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, IF, L, Msb, in art. snH:) [the former appears to be accord. to the usage of the Hijázees; and the latter, accord. to that of the Nejdees, in general: see baAriHN:] contr. of sanaHa. (S.) ＝ -A3- baraHa, aor.
baruHa
, [contr. to rule,] (K,) inf. n. baroHN, (TA,) He was angry. (K.) When a man has been angry with his companion, one says, maA OaXadRa maA baraHa Ealayohi [How violently angry was he with him!]. (L.)

2 barRaHato biya AlHumRaI brHt by AlHmI brHt by AlHmy
2. barRaHato biya AlHumRaI The fever affected me with its severity, violence, or sharpness, termed buraHaMCu. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) from buraHaMCu, (S, K,) brRH bihi, inf. n. taboriyHN, It (an affair, an event, or a case,) affected him severely; afflicted, distressed, or harassed, him: (S, K:) said also of anxiety; or disquietude, or trouble, of mind: (A:) and of a beating, meaning it hurt him severely, or greatly. (Msb.) Also said of a man, meaning He importuned him, or pressed him, with annoyance, or molestation: (A, TA:) he annoyed him, or molested him, by importuning or pressing; as also AbrH↓: (TA:) he annoyed him, or molested him, by distressing importunity or pressing: (T, TA:) and he punished, tormented, or tortured, him. (TA.) taboriyHN signifies The act of annoying, molesting, or hurting: (Mgh:) and in a trad., (in which it is forbidden, TA,) the killing, or putting to death, in an evil [or a cruel] manner; such as throwing live fish, and lice, into the fire. (Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- barRaHa QllRehu Eanoka May God remove from thee AlbaroH [i. e. difficulty, distress, affliction, &c., or the difficulty, &c.]. (A, TA.)

4 AbrHhu ObrH ObrHh AbrHh AbrHp brH
4. AbrHhu He made him, or caused him, to go away from, depart from, or quit, his place. (A, * L.) ＝ -A2- He, or it, pleased, or rejoiced, him; excited his admiration and approval; induced in him wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy. (S, K.) One says also, maA OaboraHa hecaA AlOamora How greatly does this affair, or event, please, or rejoice! how greatly does it excite admiration and approval! or how greatly does it induce wonder, or admiration, and pleasure, or joy! (S.) ― -b2- He treated him with honour, or honoured him, and magnified him: (S, K:) or, as some say, he found him to be generous, or noble. (TA.) ― -b3- He judged him, or it, i. e. a man, (A, TA,) and a horse, (A,) or anything, (TA,) to be excellent, or to excel, (A, TA,) and wondered at, or admired, him, or it. (A.) ＝ -A3- AbrH also signifies He exceeded the usual bounds, degree, or mode. (As, S, * TA.) You say, OaboraHota karamFA, and luWomFA, (A, TA,) Thou hast done a thing exceeding the usual bounds [in generosity, or nobleness, and in meanness, or ignobleness]; or extravagant; or excessive. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2.

baroHN brH
baroHN Difficulty, distress, affliction, or adversity; evil, or mischief; (K, TA;) annoyance, molestation, or hurt; severe punishment; trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue; (TA;) a difficult, a distressing, an afflictive, or adverse, and a wonderful, thing or event: (Ham p. 135:) and annoyance, or molestation, by distressing importunity or pressing; a subst. from 2: (T, TA:) and binotu baroHK, [and app. Aibonu baroHK also,] a calamity, misfortune, or disaster; or a great, or terrible, thing, affair, or case; (TA;) as also binotu baAriHK↓, and Aibonu bariyHK↓; (K;) pl. banaAtu baroHK and banuw baroHK. (TA.) [See also taboriyHN.] You say, laqiytu minohu baroHFA baAriHFA↓ I experienced from him, or it, [great] difficulty, distress, affliction, or adversity; [great] annoyance, molestation, or hurt; (S, A, * K; *) a phrase having an intensive signification, (K, TA,) like layolN Oaloyalu [and layolN laAYilN]; and so baroHFA mubarRiHFA↓. (TA.) When used as an imprecation, the more approved way is to put the two words in the accus. case: but sometimes they are put in the nom. case; as in the saying of a poet, baroHN laEyonaka baAriHN↓ [May great difficulty, &c., befall thy two eyes!]. (TA.) You say also, laqiytu minohu banaAti baroHK, (S, A,) and baniy baroHK, (S,) I experienced from him, or it, difficulties, distresses, afflictions, or adverse events; and calamities, misfortunes, or disasters: (S:) and, in the same sense, lqyt mnh AlbiraHiyna↓, and AlburaHiyna↓, (S, K,) and AlbaraHiyna↓; (K;) or, accord. to some copies of the K, AlbiroHayni↓, and AlburoHayoni↓, and AlbaroHayoni↓, as duals; but the former reading is the more correct: (TA:) [MF disapproves of the form baraHiyna, and it is not mentioned in the
L; but the dual form baroHayoni is there mentioned:] it seems as though the sing. of bariHiyna [or buraHiyna] were biraHapN [or buraHapN], and that the pl. is formed by the termination wn to compensate for the rejection of the p, as is virtually the case in OaraDuwna; [or because the signification is regarded as that of a personification;] and that the pl. only is used. (L.) It is said in a prov., binotu baroHK XarakN EalaI raOosika [Calamity is, or be, a snare upon thy head]. (TA.)

bariHN: see mubarRiHN.

SaroHapa baroHapa, or SaroHapF baroHapF, &c.: see art. SrH.

buroHapN The best of anything: (TA:) and [particularly] one of the best of she-camels: (S, K:) or, of he-camels: (T:) pl. buraHN. (T, S, K.) You say, hecihi buroHapN mina AlburaHi, (S, K, *) or huwa buroHapN mina AlburaHi, (T,) This is a she-camel, (S, K, *) or he is a camel, (T,) of the best of camels. (T, S, K.)

baroHay a word that is said when one misses the mark in shooting or casting; like as maroHay is said when one hits the mark. (S, ISd, A, K.)

buraHaMCu brHMC
buraHaMCu Severity, violence, or sharpness, (As, A, TA,) or vehement molestation, (S, K,) of a fever (As, A, S, K) &c.: (S, K:) [a paroxysm; used in this sense by modern physicians:] and vehement distress of mind arising from the oppression caused by inspiration or revelation; such as is said to have affected the Prophet; [but most probably a paroxysm of that species of catalepsy which physicians term ecstasy;] occurring in a trad. AlbiraHiyna and AlburaHiyna &c.: see baroHN

baraAHN brAH rAH
baraAHN inf. n. of bariHa, q. v.; whence the phrase laA baraAHa, explained above. (S, L, K.) ＝ -A2- A wide, or spacious, tract of land, (S, A, K,) kaving in it no seed-produce nor trees: (S, K:) or land having in it no building nor habitation: (Ham p. 237:) and applied as an epithet to land, signifying wide, or spacious, open, or conspicuous, and having in it no herbage nor habitation: and what is open, uncovered, and wholly apparent, of land: (TA:) or a place having no trees nor other things to cover or conceal it; as though such things had departed; (Mgh;) a place free from trees &c.: (Msb:) or an elevated and open tract of land. (Har p. 134.) ― -b2- Habiylu baraAHK is an appellation given to (tropical:) A lion: and (assumed tropical:) a courageous man: as though each of them were bound with ropes, (K, TA,) and did not quit his place. (TA.) ＝ -A3- An affair, a thing, or a case, that is plain, evident, or manifest; (K, TA;) or open, or public. (TA.) You say, jaMCanaA biAlOamori baraAHFA [He told us, or did to us, the thing] plainly [or openly]. (S.) And jaMCa biAlkufori baraAHFA wa biAlXRarRi SuraAHFA [He uttered, or committed an act of, infidelity plainly, or openly, and evil, or mischief, unmixedly]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Counsel, or an opinion, that is disapproved, or deemed evil. (K.) ＝ -A4- baraAHi, (El-Mufaddal, S, A, &c.,) and baraAHu, with damm and without tenween, (AZ, El-Mufaddal,) a name of The sun: (S, A, &c.:) determinate [and the former indecl.]: the sun is so called because of the spreading of its light, and its conspicuousness; or, being applied to the sun when it sets, brAH means baAriHapN; like as kasaAbi, a name applied to a hunting-bitch, means kaAsibapN. (TA.) You say, dalakato baraAHi The sun set [or declined from the meridian]. (A, TA.) For this phrase, occurring at the end of a verse cited by Ktr, Fr reads dalakato biraAHi; rAH being pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of raAHapN, meaning the “hand” [or “palm of the hand”]: (S, TA:) accord. to which reading, the poet means The sun had set, or had declined from the meridian, while they put their hands, or the palms of their hands, over their eyes, looking to see if it had set, or had declined from the meridian: or he who says, dalakati AlXRamosu biraAHi means the sun had almost set: the two readings barAH and birAH are mentioned by A'Obeyd and Az and Hr and Z and others: AZ says, dlkt biraAHK, with tenween, and baraAHN, without tenween. (TA.) [See also raAHapN, in art. rwH.]
