(TA.) ― -b3- See also baroHN. ＝ -A3- qawolN bariyHN A saying by which one pronounces a person to have said, or done, right. (L.)

baAriHN bArH
baAriHN, (S, K, &c.,) as also baruwHN↓ and bariyHN↓, (K,) applied to a gazelle, (S,) or what is hunted or shot, (K, TA,) of gazelles and birds and wild animals [in general], (TA,) Turning his left side towards the spectator, (S,) passing from the direction of the right hand of the latter towards the direction of his left hand: (S, K:) or turning his right side towards the spectator, passing from the direction of the latter's left hand towards that of his right: (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee, IF, A, * L, Msb, * in art. snH:) contr. of saAniHN: (S, * TA:) pl. bawaAriHu. (L in art. snH.) The Arabs [who apply the epithet in the latter sense] regard the bArH as an evil omen, and the sAnH as a good omen; because one cannot shoot at the former without turning himself: (S:) but some of them hold the reverse: (Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee and L in art. snH:) the people of Nejd hold the sAnH to be a good omen; but sometimes a Nejdee adopts the opinion of the Hijázee [which is the contrary]. (IB in that art.) The first of these epithets is also applied to a bird as meaning Inauspicious; ill-omened. (A.) It is said in a prov., mano liI biA lsRaAniHi baEoda AlbaAriHi (TA) i. e. [Who will be responsible to me] for a fortunate, or lucky, event, after an unfortunate, or unlucky? (K in art. snH:) applied in the case of a man's doing evil, and its being said, “He will at a future time do good to thee:” originally said by a man on the occasion of gazelles' passing before him in the manner of such as are termed baAriHap, and its being said to him, “They will present themselves to thee in the manner of such as are termed saAnHap.” (TA.) And in another prov. it is said, UinRamaA huwa kabaAriHi AlOarowaI [It, or he, is only like the mountain-goat passing in the manner of such as is termed bArH]: for it dwells on the tops of the mountains, and men scarcely ever see it passing with the right or left side towards them save once in the course of ages: (S, K:) applied in the case of an extraordinary occurrence: (K:) [or in the case of a benefit conferred by a man who very rarely confers benefits on others: (Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 35:)] or when a man has delayed, or been tardy in, visiting [but has come at last]. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, fitolapN baAriHapN i. q. XazorapN [i. e. (tropical:) A manner of twisting contrary to that which is usual: see Xazara]. (A.) ― -b3- And hecihi faEolpN baAriHapN (tropical:) This is an action that has not happened rightly. (A.) ― -b4- [Hence,] binotu baAriHN: and [perhaps] laqiytu minohu baroHFA baAriHFA: and baroHN liEayonaka baAriHN: see baroHN. ― -b5- [And hence, perhaps, because of its evil effect; or because it comes, accord. to some, from the left, i. e. northerly direction, or, accord. to others, from the right, i. e. southerly direction; or] from baroHN as signifying “a difficult, a distressing, an afflictive, or adverse, and a wonderful, thing, or event;” (Ham p. 135;) baAriHN signifies also A hot wind: (S:) or a hot wind in the SayofN [i. e. summer or spring]: (K:) or a hot wind coming from the direction of El-Yemen: (Ham p. 135:) or a wind that carries up, raises, or sweeps up and scatters, the dust: (Msb:) pl. bawAriHu: (S, K, &c.:) or the bwArH are hot north, or northerly, winds in the Sayof: (AZ, Az, S:) this Az found to be the sense in which the term was used by the Arabs in his time: (TA:) or violent winds that carry with them the dust by reason of their violence: (TA:) or this name (the pl.) was given by the Arabs to all winds in the time of the stars of the qayoZ [or summer]: they mostly blow in the time of the stars of Libra; [app. meaning when Libra is on, or near, the meridian at nightfall, agreeably with a statement in modern Arabic almanacs, that the periods of the beginning and end of the winds thus called are the 30th of May and the 9th of July;] and these winds are what are termed the samaAYim [pl. of samuwmN]. (Ibn-Kunáseh, TA.) ― -b6- AlbawaAriHu is also said by some to signify AlOanowaMCu [pl. of nawoCN, q. v.]; as mentioned by AHn; but he repels their assertion. (TA.)

AlbaAriHapu AlbArHh AlbArHp bArH bArHp
AlbaAriHapu The next, or nearest, past, or preceding, night; yesternight: (S, A, Mgh, * Msb, * K:) from bariHa signifying zaAla [“he, or it, went away” &c.].
(S, A.) [In modern Arabic, Yesterday; as also AlbaAriH.] It has no dim. formed from it. (Sb, in S, in art. Oms; and TA.) You say, laqiytuhu AlbaAriHap [I met, or met with, him, or it, last night, or yesternight]: and laqiytuhu AlbaAriHapa AlOuwlay [I met, or met with, him, or it, the night before last; this being the sense in which the phrase is now used by the learned: but the vulgar expression is OawRal AlbaAriHap, generally pronounced OawRal AamobaAriHaho or OawRal AamobaAriHo, agreeably with a peculiarity of the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, or of Teiyi and Himyer, by the substitution of Aamo for Aalo: see art. Am]. (S) From daybreak to the time when the sun declines from the meridian, one says, raOayotu AllRayolapa fiI manaAmiI [I saw to-night in my sleep (such a thing)]; but when the sun has declined, one says, raOayotu AlbaAriHapa [I saw last night, or yesternight]: (AZ, Th: [and the like is said in the Mgh and Msb:]) or one says, kaAna kacaA wa kacaA AllRayolapa [Such and such things happened to-night] until the sun is somewhat high and the day has become bright; but after this, one says, kaAna AlbaAriHapa [It happened last night, or yesternight]. (Yoo, Seer.) The Arabs say,
maA OaXobaha AllRayolapa biA lbaAriHapi
How like is this night wherein we are to the former night that has departed! (TA:) [or, this night to yesternight!]: originally occurring in a poem of Tarafeh: used as meaning “how like is the child to the father!” and applied to [any] two things resembling each other. (Har p. 667.)

OaboraHu c
OaboraHu is formed [from baraHa for barRaHa] by the rejection of the added letter: [for a word of this kind is regularly formed only from an unaugmented triliteral-radical verb:] or it is like OaHonaku, having no proper verb. (L.) You say, hecaA OaboraHu EalaIRa mino caAka (A, * L, Msb *) This is more difficult, distressing, or afflicting, to me than that. (L, Msb. *) And hecaM AlOamoru OaboraHu mino hecaA This affair, event, or case, is more difficult, or distressing, than this. (S.) And qataluwhumo OaboraHa qatolK [They slew them with a most severe slaughter]. (S.)

taboriyHN tbryH
taboriyHN [inf. n. of 2, used as a simple subst.,] is said by some to be sing. of tabaAriyHu, and has been used as such by post-classical authors, but is not of established authority: accord. to others, the latter has no sing.: (MF:) the pl. signifies Difficulties, distresses, afflictions, or adversities: [see also baroHN:] or the difficulties, or obligations, incurred by troublesome, or inconvenient, means of obtaining subsistence: (TA:) and tabaAriyHu AlXRawoqi the burning, or fierce burning, [or the burnings, &c.,] of the yearning, or longing, of the soul, or of longing desire. (S, K.)

OnaA mubarRaHN biI c
OnaA mubarRaHN biI I am importuned, or pressed, with annoyance, or molestation. (A, TA.) [See the verb (2).]

mubarRiHN mbrH
mubarRiHN and bariHN↓, applied to an affair, an event, or a case, signify the same; (K, TA;) i. e. Severe, afflicting, distressing, or harassing: (TA:) and the former, to a beating, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) meaning the same; (TA;) or hurting (S, Mgh) severely: (S:) and to a man, meaning annoying, or molesting, by importuning, or pressing. (TA.) [See 2.] laqiytu minohu baroHFA mubarRiHFA: see baroHN.

yaboruwHN ybrwH
yaboruwHN, (K,) thus correctly written, with the I before the b; [not byrwH, as in the CK; in Chald. יַבְרוּחַ, the word corresponding to the sing. of the Hebr. דּוּרָאִים in Gen. xxx. 14 and 16, accord. to the paraphrase of Onkelos;] or yaboruwHN SanamiIRN [the idol-like ybrwH]; (TA;) The root, or lower part, of the wild lufRaAH [or mandrake, not to be confounded with another plant to which the name of lufRaAH, q. v., is also applied], (K,) which is known by the names of faAwaAniyaA and Euwdu AlSRaliybi [names now given to the peony], and called by MF tufRaAHu AlbarRi, [or the wild apple, but perhaps this is a mistranscription for lufRaAHu AlbarRi,] said by him to be an appellation used by the vulgar; (TA;) resembling the form of a man; (K;) and of two sorts, male and female; called by the people of Greece Eabodu AlsRalaAmi: (TA:) it torpifies, (K,) and strengthens the two appetites [namely that of the stomach and that of the generative organ): (TA:) if ivory is cooked with it for six hours, it renders it soft; and if a part affected by [the disease termed] baraX is rubbed with its leaves for a week, (K,) without interruption, (TA,) it removes it without causing ulcers, or sores: (K:) the root of the wild lufRaAH is the yaborwH: it has the form of a human being; the male like the male, and the female like the female; and they pretend that he who pulls it up dies; wherefore, when they desire to do so, they tie a dog or some other animal to it. (Kzw, voce lufRaAH.)

1 baruda brd rd
1. baruda, aor.
baruda
, inf. n. buruwdapN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and barada, aor.
baruda
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. barodN; (M, Msb;) It (a thing, S, Msb, and the latter said of water, Msb) was, or became, cold, chill, or cool; [see barodN below;] (S, M;) its heat became allayed. (Msb.) The latter verb is also used transitively, as will be shown below. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baruda maDojaEahu [lit. His bed, or place of sleep, became cold; meaning] (tropical:) he went on a journey. (A.) ― -b3- barada also signifies (tropical:) He died; (As, T, S, A, K;) because death is the non-existence of the heat of the soul; (L;) or it is allusive to the extinction of the natural heat; or to the cessation of motion. (MF.) For ― -b4- barada, (MF,) aor.
baruda
, (Mgh,) inf. n. barodN, (MF,) likewise signifies (assumed tropical:) It was, or became, still, quiet, or motionless; (Mgh, MF;) for instance, a slaughtered sheep or goat [&c.]. (Mgh.) And (assumed tropical:) It (beverage of the kind called nabiyc) became still, and without briskness. (TA, from a trad.) You say, ruEiba fabarada makaAnahu [(assumed tropical:) He became frightened, and remained motionless in his place; makaAnahu meaning fiI makaAnahu: and hence,] (tropical:) he became amazed, or stupified. (A.) And baradato Eayonuhu (assumed tropical:) The pain in his eye became allayed, or stilled. (L.) And barada OamorunaA (assumed tropical:) Our affair, or case, became easy. (TA, from a trad. [See also baAridN.]) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. barod, [which see below,] (assumed tropical:) He slept. (T.) ― -b6- And hence, (tropical:) It remained, or became permanent, or fixed, or settled. (T.) So in the saying, lamo yaborudo biyadiI minohu XayoCN (tropical:) There did not remain, or become permanent or fixed or settled, in my hand, thereof, anything. (T, L. *) You say also, barada OasiyrFA fiI Oayodiyohimo (tropical:) He remained safely a captive in their hands. (A.) And barada fiI Oayodiyhmo salomFA (tropical:) He became a permanent captive, remaining in their hands, not to be ransomed nor liberated nor demanded. (L.) And barada Almawoti EalaImuSoTalaAhu (tropical:) Death fixed, or settled, [upon his face and extremities, or] upon his limbs, or upon his arms and legs and face and every prominent part, which become cold at the time of death, and which are warmed at the fire. (AHeyth, L.) And barada Almawoti Ealayohi [(tropical:) Death became impressed upon him;] the marks, or signs, of death became apparent upon him. (A.) ― -b7- [And hence, app.,] (tropical:) It (a right, or due,) became incumbent, or obligatory, (M, K, TA,) and established. (TA.) You say, barada liI HaqRiI EalaI fulaAnK (tropical:) My right, or due, became incumbent, or obligatory, on such a one, and established against him. (M, * A, * TA.) And maA barada laka EalaI fulaAnK (tropical:) What hath become incumbent, or obligatory, to thee, on such a one, and established against him? or what hath become owed, or due, to thee, by, or from, such a one? as also maA caAba laka Ealayohi. (S.) And barada liI Ealayohi kacaA mina AlmaAli (tropical:) Such an amount of the property, or of property, became incumbent, or obligatory, to me, on him, and established against him; or became owed, or due, to me, by, or from, him. (S.) ― -b8- Also, (K,) aor.
baruda
, inf. n. barodN, (TA, [but see the next sentence,]) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, weak; and so burida, a verb like EuniIa. (K.) And, inf. n. buraAdN and buruwdN, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, languid, (K,) or weak and languid, from leanness or disease: (M:) or weak in the legs, from hunger or fatigue. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) And barada muxRuhu, (A, K,) aor.
baruda
, inf. n. barodN, (TA,) (tropical:) He was, or became, lean, or emaciated; (A, K;) and so baradato EiZaAmuhu. (A, TA.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) It (a sword [or the like]) was, or became, blunt. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- baradahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
baruda
, (Msb,) inf. n. barodN; (K;) and brRdhu↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. taboriydN; (S;) He made it, or rendered it, (for ex., water, M, Msb, K,) cold, chill, or cool: (S, &c.:) but the latter has an intensive signification [he made it, or rendered it, very cold, or very cool]: (Msb:) or both signify, (K,) or the former signifies, (M, TA,) he mixed it with snow: (M, K:) one does not say Abrdhu↓, except in a bad dialect. (S.) barRidiyhi, being used by a poet for balo ridiyhi, has been erroneously supposed to mean “Make thou it hot.” (M.) You say, baradanaA AllRayolu, (aor. and inf. n. as above, M,) and barada EalayonaA, The night affected us with its cold. (M, K.) And saqayotuhu XarobapF baradato fuWaAdahu, (S, M, *) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) I gave him to drink a draught
that cooled his heart: (S, M:) or baradotu bihaA fuWaAdahu [with which I cooled his heart]. (So in the T.) And fuWaAdaka biXarobapK barRido↓ Cool thy heart by a draught. (A.) And AisoqiniI sawiyqFA Oaborudo bihi kabidiI [Give thou me to drink swyq with which I may cool my liver]. (T.) And barada Eayonuhu biAlokuHoli, (A'Obeyd, T, M,) or biAlobaruwdi, (S, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) [He cooled his eye with the collyrium, or] he applied the cooling collyrium to his eye, (T, * S, M, * Msb, K, *) and allayed its pain. (M.) The following words, cited by IAar,
baraduwA gawaAriba OayonuqK Hudobi
[lit. They cooled the fore parts of the humps, or the backs, of humped she-camels], mean (tropical:) they put off from them their saddles, that their backs might become cool. (M.) You say also, barRido↓ Zahora farasika saAEapF (tropical:) Relieve thy horse from riding [lit. cool his back] awhile. (A.) And laA tubarRido↓ Eano fulaAnK (tropical:) Do not thou alleviate the punishment [in the world to come] due to the offence of such a one by thy reviling him, or cursing him, when he has acted injuriously to thee. (T, S, * M, * A, * L.) And barada Alxuboza, (T, L, K,) biAlomaMCi, (T,) He poured [cold] water upon the bread, (T, L, K,) and moistened it [therewith: see baruwdN]. (T, L.) ― -b2- burida (a verb like EuniIa, K) It (a company of men) was hailed upon. (S, M, K.) And buridati. AlOaruDu The land, or ground, was hailed upon. (S.) ＝ -A3- barada, (S, M, &c.,) aor
baruda
, (TA,) inf. n. barodN, (Mgh, TA,) also signifies He filed (M, Mgh, K) iron, (S, M, &c.,) and the like, (M,) with a miborad.(S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A4- baradahu and Abrdhu↓ He sent him as a bariyd [or messenger on a postmule or post-horse]. (K.) And barada barydFA, (M,) and Abrdhu↓, (A,) He sent a bryd. (M, A.) And Uiloyahi Abrd↓, (S,) or Alyh bariydFA Abrd↓, (T, TA.) He sent to him a bryd. (T, S.)

2 barRada
2: see baradahu, in four places. ― -b2- brRdhu Ealayohi (tropical:) He made it incumbent, or obligatory, on him. (M, A.) ― -b3- And brRdhu, (K, TA, but omitted in the CK,) inf. n. taboriydN; (TA;) and Abrdhu↓; (M, K;) (tropical:) It (a thing, M) made him, or rendered him, weak; weakened him; (K;) or made him, or rendered him, weak and languid. (M.) ＝ -A2- [brRd also signifies, as is indicated in the TA voce HubaAHibN, It (a locust) spread forth its wings; which are termed its burodaAni: see burodN.]

4 Abrd Obrd Abrd brd
4. Abrd He entered upon a cold, or cool, time: (Mgh, Msb:) he entered upon the last part of the day: (M, K:) he entered upon the time when the sun had declined: (Mohammad Ibn-Kaab, T:) and he entered upon the cool season, at the end of the summer. (Lth, T.) [Hence,] OaboriduwA biAlTRaEaAmi Delay ye to eat food until it is cool: occurring in a trad. (El-Munáwee.) And OaboriduwA biAlZRuhori (T, A, Mgh, Msb) Defer ye the noon-prayers until the cooler time of the day, when the vehemence of the heat shall have become allayed. (Mgh, Msb.) And Oaborido Eanoka mina AlZRahiyripa Stay thou until the mid-day heat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (M, and L in art. fyH.) ― -b2- Abrdlahu He gave him to drink what was cold, or cool. (M, K.) You say also, saqayotuhu faOaboradotu lahu, meaning I gave him to drink what was cold, or cool. (A'Obeyd, S.) ― -b3- Abrdhu He brought it cold, or cool. (M, K.) ― -b4- See baradahu, first sentence. ― -b5- And see 2. ＝ -A2- See also 1, in four places; last three sentences.

5 tbrRd fiyhi tbrd fyh tbrd fyp
5. tbrRd fiyhi He descended into it, (i. e., into water, TA,) and washed himself in it, to refresh himself by its coolness. (M, K.) See also 8. ― -b2- tbrRd also signifies (assumed tropical:) He became weakened. (TA.)

8 Abtrd Obtrd Abtrd Qbtrd
8. Abtrd He washed himself with cold water: (S:) and likewise, (S,) or AbtrdAlmaMCa, (K,) he drank water to cool his liver: (S, K:) or the latter signifies he poured the water cold upon himself, (M, K,) meaning, upon his head: (M:) and biAlomaACi tbrRd↓, (T, A,) and Abtrd, (A,) he washed himself with water, or with the water. (T.)

10 Astbrd Ealayohi lisaAnahu Astbrd Elyh lsAnh Astbrd Elyh lsAnp
10. Astbrd Ealayohi lisaAnahu (tropical:) He let loose his tongue and used it like a file against him. (A.)

barodN brd rd
barodN and buruwdapN↓ [originally inf. ns.] Cold; coldness; chill; chilness; cool, as a subst.; coolness; the former, contr. of HarRN; (S, M, A, Msb;) and the latter, of HaraArapN. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence] the former, (tropical:) Pleasantness; enjoyment; ease; comfort: as in the saying, nasoOaluka AljanRapa wa barodahaA (tropical:) We ask of Thee Paradise and its pleasantness, &c. (L.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Sleep: (T, S, M, A, K:) [an inf. n. used as a subst.:] so in the Kur lxxviii. 24: (S, M, K:) for sleep cools a man: (TA:) or, accord. to I'Ab, it there means the coldness, or coolness, of beverage. (T.) You say, manaEa Albaradu Albaroda (assumed tropical:) The hail prevented sleep. (A.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) Saliva: (Th, T, M, K:) so, accord. to Th, in the saying of El-'Arjee,
wa Uino XiYoti lamo OaToEamu nuqaAxFA wa laA barodaA
And if thou desire, I will not taste sweet water, nor saliva [from any lips but thine]. (T, M, * TA. [But this is cited in the S as an ex. of barod signifying sleep.]) ― -b5- See also baAridN. ― -b6- [Hence,] AlbarodaAni: see AlOaboradaAni, voce Oaboradu.

burodN brd rd
burodN A kind of garment; (S;) a kind of striped garment: (M, K:) accord. to some, of the description termed waXoIN [or variegated]: (M:) or particular kinds thereof are distinguished by such terms as burodu EaSobK and burodu wa XoIK: (Msb:) also, (as a coll. gen. n., TA,) garments of the kind called OakosiyapN, [pl. of kisaMCN,] which are wrapped round the body; (K;) one of which is called burodapN↓: (M, K:) or, as Lth says, the burod is [a] well-known [garment], of the kind called buruwdu AlEaSobi and buruwdu AlwaXoIi; (T;) but the burodapN↓ is a garment of the kind called kisaMCN, four-sided, black, and somewhat small, worn by the Arabs of the desert: (T, S, Mgh, * Msb, * TA:) or this latter (the brdp) is a striped garment of the kind called XamolapN: (T:) or it is an oblong piece of woollen cloth, fringed: (M:) Sh says, I saw an Arab of the desert wearing a piece of woollen cloth resembling a napkin, wrapped round the body like an apron; and on my saying to him, What dost thou call it? he answered, burodap: (T:) [the modern brdp, in every case in which I have seen it, I have observed to be an oblong piece of thick woollen cloth, generally brown or of a dark or ashy dust-colour, and either plain, or having stripes so narrow and near together as to appear, at a little distance, of one colour; used both to envelop the person by day and as a night-covering: the brdp of Mohammad is described as about seven feet and a half in length, and four and a half in width, and in colour either OaxoDar or OaHomar, i. e. of a dark or ashy dust-colour or brown; for such are the significations of these two epithets when applied to a garment of this kind, and in some other cases:] the pl. of burodN is OaborudN (M, K) and OaboraAdN [both pls. of pauc.] and buruwdN (S, M, K) and buradN, (IAar, T,) or this last is pl. of burodapN, (S, M,) and biraAdN, like as qiraATN is pl. of quroTN, or this, also, is pl. of burodapN, like as biraAmN is pl. of buromapN. (M.) ― -b2- cuwburodK, as opposed to cuw kisaMCi, means (assumed tropical:) A rich man. (S in art. Ej.) ― -b3- waqaEa bayonuhumaA qadRu buruwdK yumonapK, (so in copies of the K, in the TA yumanapK,) or buruwdK vamiynapK, (so in a copy of the A,) (tropical:) [There happened between them two the rending of buruwd of the fabric of El-Yemen, accord. to the reading in the K, or of costly buruwd, accord. to the reading in the A,] means they arrived at a great, or severe, state of affairs; (K;) or is said of two men who have contended together in vehement altercation so that they have rent each other's garments; (A;) [accord. to the reading in the K,] because yumanN, [in the CK yumon,] which are buruwd of El-Yemen, are not rent save on account of some great, or severe, thing, or affair. (K.) ― -b4- humaA fiI burodapi↓ OaxomaAsK means (assumed tropical:) They two do one deed; or act alike; (IAar, M, K;) and resemble each other, as though they were in one burodap: (IAar, M:) or they two have become near together, and in a state of agreement. (K in art. xms, q. v.) ― -b5- And salaba AlSRahobaMCa burodatahaA↓(tropical:) He, or it, deprived the wine of its colour. (A.) ― -b6- And burodaA AljaraAdi, (T,) or Aljunodabi, (S,) (assumed tropical:) The two wings [of the locust, or of the species called jndb]. (T, S.) ― -b7- And burodapu↓ AlDRaOoni(assumed tropical:) A certain sort of milk. (K.)

baradN brd rd
baradN Hail; what descends from the clouds, resembing pebbles; (M, Msb;) frozen rain; (Lth, T;) what is called HabRu AlgamaAmi (S, A, Msb, K) and HabRu Almuzoni (Msb) [i. e. the grains, or berries, of the clouds: a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, signifying a hailstone].

baridN brd rd
baridN Possessing coldness or coolness: an epithet applied to the [plant called] SilRiyaAn. (S.) ― -b2- saHaAbN baridN, (T, S, M, K,) and Oaboradu↓, (S, K,) Clouds containing hail (T, S, M, K *) and cold. (T.) You say also saHaAbapN baridapN A cloud containing hail (T, S, M, A *) and cold; (T;) but not sHAbp barodaMCu. (M.)

barodapN brd brdh brdp rd rdp
barodapN: see baAridN: ＝ -A2- and see also baradapN. ＝ -A3- hiIa laka barodapa nafosahaA She is purely thine; (Fr, A'Obeyd, T, S, M;) syn. xaAliSapF: (M:) A'Obeyd explains it by xaAliSFA, (T, S, M,) not in the fem. form, (TA,) on the authority of Fr. (T.) ― -b2- huwa liI barodapa yamiyniI,
(A'Obeyd, M,) or huwa libarodapi yamiyniI, (S,) He, or it, is known to me. (A'Obeyd, S, M.) ＝ -A4- barodapu a proper name applied to The ewe. (K.)

burodapN brd brdh brdp rd rdp
burodapN: see burodN, in five places.

baradapN brd brdh brdp rd rdp
baradapN (T, S, M, A, &c.) and barodapN↓ (T, M, K) Indigestion; a malady arising from unwholesome food: (S, M, A, L, Msb, K:) or heaviness of food to the stomach: (IAar, T, L:) so termed because it makes the stomach cold. (T, L, Msb.) It is said in a trad., OaSolu kulRi daMCK Albaradapu [The origin of every disease is indigestion]. (T, S, M, * A.) ＝ -A2- Also, the former, The middle of the eye. (K.)

buradaMCu brdMC
buradaMCu An ague; i. e. a fever attended by a cold fit, (K,) or by shivering. (TA.)

barodiyRN brd brdI brdy rd rdI
barodiyRN A well-known kind of plant, (S, M, * K,) of which the kind of paper termed qiroTaAs is made; (TA in art. qrTs, q. v.;) [namely, papyrus; and] of which mats are made; (Msb;) [app. meaning rushes in general: but the former is generally meant by it in the present day, and is probably the proper signification: anciently, mats, as well as ropes and sails &c., were made of the rind of the papyrus; and even small boats were constructed of its stalks bound together; and of such, probably, was the ark in which the infant Moses was exposed: it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. barodiyRapN. (M, TA.) Hence, qaTonu AlbarodiIR The cotton of the papyrus, which, resembling wool, is gathered from the stalk, and, mixed with lime, composes a very tenacious kind of cement. (Golius, from Ibn-Maaroof.) ― -b2- [Also, a rel. n. from the same, meaning Of, or belonging to, or resembling, the plant so called. Hence the saying,] lahaA saAqN barodiyRapN [She has a shank like a papyrus-stalk]. (A.)

burodiIRN brd brdI brdy rd rdI
burodiIRN One of the most excellent sorts of dates: (S, Msb:) an excellent sort of dates, (AHn, M, K,) resembling the baroniIR: (AHn, M:) or a sort of dates of El-Hijáz. (TA.)

barodaAnN brdAn
[barodaAnN Feeling cold or chilly or cool: fem. with p: perhaps post-classical; for I have not found it mentioned in any of the lexicons.]

buraAdN brAd
buraAdN: see baAridN. ＝ -A2- Also Weakness of the legs, from hunger or fatigue. (Ibn-Buzurj, T.) [See also 1.]

baruwdN brwd rwd
baruwdN: see baAridN. ― -b2- Beverage that cools the heat of thirst. (T.) ― -b3- Also, (T, L, K,) and maboruwdN↓, (T, M, A, L, K,) Bread upon which water is poured; (T, L, K;) which is moistened with cold water: (A:) eaten by women to make them fat. (M, A, L.) The subst. applied to such bread is bariydN↓ (A.) ― -b4- baruwdN [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates] also signifies Cold water which one pours upon his head. (M.) ― -b5- Anything with which a thing is rendered cold, or cooled. (S, M.) ― -b6- A collyrium which cools the eye; (Lth, T, M, Msb;) also termed baruwdu AlEayoni. (T, S.) ― -b7- baruwdu AlZRilRi (assumed tropical:) Pleasant in social intercourse: applied alike to the male and the female. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b8- vawobN baruwdN A garment without nap: (K:) and a garment that is not warm nor soft. (TA.)

bariydN bryd
bariydN: see baruwdN. ＝ -A2- Also A mule appointed [for the conveyance of messengers] in a ribaAT [or public building for the accommodation of travellers and their beasts, or in a sikRap, which is a house or the like specially appropriated to messengers and the beasts that carry them: thus it signifies a postmule: afterwards, it was applied also to a posthorse, and any beast appointed for the conveyance of messengers]: (Mgh:) [this is what is meant by the words in the S and K, Albariydu AlmuratRabu:] it is a word of Persian origin, (Z in the Fáïk,) arabicized, from buriydaho dumo, (Z in the Fáïk, and Mgh,) i. e. “docked,” or “having the tail cut off;” for the post-mules (bigaAlu Albariydi) had their tails cut off in order that they might be known: (Z in the Fáïk:) [or perhaps it is from the Hebrew פֶּרֶד “a mule:”] or it is applied to the beast appointed for the conveyance of messengers (daAbRapu Albariydi) because he traverses the space called bariyd [defined below: but the reason before given for this appellation is more probable: it is like the Lat. “veredus”]: (T, Msb:) pl. burudN (Z, Mgh, Msb) and burodN, which is a contraction of the former, like as rusolN is of rusulN. (Z.) You say, Humila fulaAnN EalaI Albariyid [Such a one was borne on the postmule or post-horse]. (S.) Imra-el-Keys speaks of a bryd of the horses of Barbar. (S.) ― -b2- Having been originally used in the sense first explained above, it was afterwards applied to A messenger borne on a post-mule [or post-horse]: (Z in the Fáïk, and Mgh:) or messengers on beasts of the post: (M, K:) or a messenger that journeys with haste: (A:) or [simply] a messenger: (S, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (M, * Z.) Hence the saying, AlHumRaI bariydu Almawoti Fever is the messenger of death: (T, Msb:) because it gives warning thereof. (T.) Hence also Albariydu applied to The animal called AlfuraAniqu, (said to be the jackal, but some say otherwise, TA,) because he gives warning before [the approach of] the lion. (T, S, K.) And SaAHibu Albariyid [The master of the messengers that journey on post-mules or post-horses]. (S.) [And xayolN Albariyid, occurring in many histories &c., The post-horses, that carry messengers and others.] ― -b3- Also, having been applied to a messenger on a post-mule [or post-horse], it then became applied to The space, or distance, traversed by the messenger thus called; (Mgh, Msb; *) the space, or distance, between each sikRap and the sikRap next to it; the skRp being a structure of either of the kinds called bayot and qubRap, or a ribaAT [explained above], in which the appointed messengers lodge; (Z in the Fáïk;) the space, or distance, between two stations, or places of alighting; or two parasangs, or leagues; (M, K;) [six miles;] each parasang, or league, being three miles, and each mile being four thousand cubits: (TA:) or twelve miles; (S, A, Msb, K;) i. e. four parasangs, or leagues: (Mgh, TA:) [for] the space, or distance, between each station termed sikRap and the next to it is either two parasangs or four: (Z in the Fáïk:) the distance of twelve miles is [also] termed sikRapu Albariyid: (T:) the pl. is as above. (T, Z.) A journey of four burud, or forty-eight miles, renders it allowable to shorten prayers; which miles are of the Háshimee measure, such as are measured on the road to Mekkeh. (T.) ― -b4- Also The course, or pace, of a camel along the space thus called: so in the following verse of Muzarrid, in praise of 'Arábeh El-Owsee:
fadatoka EaraAba Alyawoma OumRiI wa xaAlatiI
wa naAqatiIa AlnRaAjiI Uilayoka bariyduhaA
[May my mother, and my maternal aunt, and my she-camel that is swift in her course to thee from one station to another, be ransoms for thee, O 'Arábeh, (the name being contracted,) this day!]. (S.)

buraAdapN brAd brAdh brAdp
buraAdapN Filings; (M, Mgh, K;) what falls from iron [&c.] when filed. (S.)

buruwdapN brwd brwdh brwdp rwd
buruwdapN: see barodN.

barRaAdapN brAd brAdh brAdp
barRaAdapN A vessel which cools water: (M, K:) or a kawRaAzap [app. meaning either a stand, or a shelf, upon which mugs (kiyzaAn, pl. of kuwz,) are placed; erroneously in the K, kuwRaArapN, and kuwaArapN, as I find it in different copies;] upon which water is cooled: (Lth, T, K: *) but [Az says,] I know not whether it be a classical or a post-classical word. (T.) Hence the saying, baAtato kiyzaAnuhumo EalaI AlbarRaAdapi Their mugs passed the night upon the brRAdp. (A, TA.)

baAridN Ord bOrd bArd
baAridN (S, M, Msb, K) Cold; chill; cool; (S, Msb;) applied to water [&c.]; (M, K;) as also barodN↓, [originally an inf. n., like EadolN, used as an epithet,] (M, K,) and baruwdN↓, (S, M, K,) and buraAdN↓; (M, K;) but the last two are intensive forms [signifying very cold or chill or cool]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Anything loved, beloved, liked, or approved. (TA.) [Hence,] EayoXN baArdN (tropical:) An easy and a pleasant life, or state of life. (ISk, * T, * M, A, L, K.) And layolapN baAridapN AlEayoXi, and AlEayoXi barodapu↓, [the latter written in the TT baradapu AlEyX,] (tropical:) A night of easy and pleasant life. (M, L.) And ganymapN baAridapN: see the latter word. ― -b3- samuwmN baAridN (tropical:) A hot wind that is constant, continual, permanent, settled, or incessant. (S, L.) ― -b4- liI Ealayohi OalofN baAridN (tropical:) A thousand [pieces of money &c.] are incumbent, or obligatory, on him, to me, and established against him; or are owed, or due, to me, by, or from, him. (S, M. *) ― -b5- jaMCa fulaAnN baAridFA muxRuhu, and baArida AlEiZaAma, (tropical:) Such a one came in a lean, or an emaciated, state: in the contr. case, one says, HaArRaA muxRuhu, and HaArRa AlEiZaAmi. (A, TA.) ― -b6- [baAridN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Blunt; applied to a sword and the like: see 1. ― -b7- And, contr., (assumed tropical:) Sharp: for you say,] murohafaAtN bawaAridu [pl. of baAridapN, meaning] (assumed tropical:) Sharp, or cutting, swords: (TA:) or slaying swords. (S.)

baAridapN Ord bOrdh bArd bArdh bArdp
baAridapN (assumed tropical:) Spoil acquired without fatigue; (IAar, T;) also termed ganiymapN baAridapN; and to this is likened, by the Prophet, fasting in winter. (T.) Also (assumed tropical:) Gain made by merchandise at the time of one's buying it. (IAar, T.)

Oaboradu c
Oaboradu [More, and most, cold, or chill, or cool]. ― -b2- [Hence,] AlOaboradaAni and AlbarodaAni↓ The morning,
between daybreak and sunrise, and the evening, between sunset and nightfall; (T, S, M, K;) also called AlEaSoraAni (S, K) and AlSRaroEaAni and AlrRidofaAni: (T:) or (as in the S, but in the M and K “and”) the morning-shade and evening-shade: (S, M, K:) so called because of their coldness, or coolness. (TA.) ― -b3- See also baridN. ― -b4- vaworN Oaboradu A bull upon which are spots, or patches, of white and black: (S, M:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (M.) ― -b5- And AlOaboradu The leopard: fem. with p: (T, K: [but in the TT, the fem. is written like the masc.:]) pl. AlOabaAridu. (T, K.) The female is also called Alxayovamapu. (T.)

Uiboradapu Obrd Obrdh Abrdh Abrdp brd
Uiboradapu, (S, M, &c.,) with kesr (S, Mgh, K) to the C and the r (Mgh, TA,) [in the CK Aiboradap,] Cold in the belly, or inside; (M, K;) a well-known malady, arising from the prevalence of cold and humidity, and preventing one, by languor, from performing the act of coition: (S, Mgh:) and a dripping of the urine, which prevents a man's taking pleasure in women. (T, L.) ― -b2- Also Coldness of the damp earth, and of rain. (M, L.) An Arab says, UinRahaA labaAridapN Alyawoma [Verily it (the morning, AlgadaApu, L) is cold to-day]; and another says to him, layosato bibaAridapK UinRamaA hiIa Uiboridapu AlvRaraI [It is not cold: it is only the coldness of the damp earth]. (S, L.)

muboradN mbrd
muboradN [pass. part. n. of 4]. You say, OaroDN muboradapN: see maboruwdN.

muboridN mbrd
muboridN [act. part. n. of 4]. You say, jiYonaAka muboridiyna We came to thee when the heat had become allayed. (T.) ＝ -A2- Also One sending, or who sends, a bariyd [or burud, i. e., a messenger on a post-mule or posthorse, or messengers on post-mules or post-horses]. (S.)

miboradN mbrd
miboradN (S, K, &c.) A file; (M;) syn. suwhaAnN; (M, K;) which is a Persian word: (M:) pl. mabaAridu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaEala lisaAnihi Ealayohi muboridFA (tropical:) [He made his tongue like a file upon him; i. e.] he annoyed him, or hurt him, with his tongue, and vituperated him. (A.) [See a saying of Moosà Ibn-Jábir voce jinRN.]

maboradapN mbrd mbrdh mbrdp
maboradapN [A cause of coldness or coolness]. You say, hecaA AlXRaIoCu maboradapN lilobadani [This thing is a cause of coldness, or coolness, to the body]: and As relates that he said to an Arab of the desert, “What induceth thee to take a sleep in the morning while the sun is yet low?” and he answered, UinRahaA maboradapN fiI AlSRayofi masoxanapN fiI AlXRitaMCi [Verily it is a cause of coolness in the summer, and a cause of warmth in the winter]. (S, A.)

mubarRadN mbrd
mubarRadN: see what follows.

maboruwdN mbrwd
maboruwdN Made, or rendered, cold or chill or cool: (S, Msb, K:) [and mubarRadN↓ signifies the same in an intensive manner:] applied to water [&c.: or signifying mixed with snow: see baradahu]. (K.) ― -b2- XajarapN maboruwdapN A tree deprived of its leaves by the cold. (AHn, M.) ― -b3- OaroDN maboruwdapN (M, A, K) and muboradapN↓ (K) Land, or ground, hailed upon: (M, K:) or snowed upon. (A, TA.) ― -b4- See also baruwdN.

barodaEapN brdEh brdEp rdE
barodaEapN: see barocaEapN.

barocaEN c
barocaEN: see what next follows.

barocaEapN c
barocaEapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and barodaEapN (Msb, K) A [cloth of the kind called] Hilos which is put beneath the [saddle called] raHol (S, Mgh, Msb, K) of the camel: (Mgh:) pl. baraAciEu (Mgh, Msb) and baraAdiEu (Msb.) Ru-beh says, [using the sing. without the p as a coll. gen. n.,]
wa taHota OaHonaMCi AlrRiHaAli AlbarocaEu↓
[And beneath the curved pieces of wood of the camels' saddles are the bardha'ahs]. (TA.) ― -b2- This is the primary signification: but in the conventional language of our time, it is applied to An ass's saddle; the thing upon which one rides on an ass, like the saroj to the horse; (Msb;) [i. e. a pad, or stuffed saddle; generally stuffed with straw; and used for a mule as well as for an ass;] or an ass's brcEp is a saddle like the raHol and qatab. (TA voce UikaAfN, q. v.) ＝ -A2- barocaEapN also signifies Land which is neither hard nor soft: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.)

baraAciEiIRN c
baraAciEiIRN A maker of baraAciEu, pl. of barocaEapN: a rel. n. similar to OanomaATiIRN. (TA.)

Q. 1 barocana c
Q. 1. barocana, (M, K,) inf. n. barocanapN, (T,) He (a horse) went in the manner of the birocawon, q. v. (T, M, K.) ― -b2- He (a man) was, or became, heavy, or sluggish: whence IDrd thinks birocawonN to be derived: (M, Msb:*) but this opinion is of no account. (M.) ― -b3- He was unable to reply, (T, K,) when asked respecting a thing. (T.) ― -b4- He subdued, overpowered, or overcame: (K: [expl. by qahara and galaba; but I think that the right reading may be quhira and guliba, meaning he was, or became, subdued, &c.:]) said of a man. (TA.)

birocawonN c
birocawonN [A horse of mean breed, or of coarse make; a jade: but commonly applied to a hack, or hackney; a horse for ordinary use, and for journeying:] a daAbRap, (S, K,) not in an absolute sense, but of a particular sort, namely, (MF,) a horse that is not of Arabian breed: (T, MF:) or a heavy, or sluggish, dAbRp: (so in a copy of the S:) or a coarse horse: (Towsheeh, TA:) or a horse of coarse make, hardy so as to endure travel upon the mountain-roads and rugged ground, not of Arabian breed, mostly brought from Er-Room [meaning Asia Minor or Greece]: (TA, from the Expos. of the 'Irákeeyeh of Es-Sakháwee:) or a horse of large and coarse make, with thick limbs; whereas those of Arabian breed are light of flesh, lank in the belly, and more slender in the limbs: (El-Bájee, TA:) or a Turkish horse; opposed to Arabian: (Mgh, Msb:) or a pacinghorse; syn. rahawaAnN: (TA voce himolaAjN:) fem. with p; (Ks, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) sometimes; but without p it is applied to the female as well as the male: (IAmb, Msb:) pl. baraAciynN (T, S, Mgh, K.)

mubarocinN c
mubarocinN An owner of a birocawon: (K:) or a rider thereon. (TA.)

1 baraza brz rz
1. baraza, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
baruza
, (S, TA,) inf. n. buruwzN, (S, Msb, TA,) He (a man, S) went, or came, or passed, out, or forth; he issued. (S, A.) He (a man, TA) went, or came, or passed, out, or forth, into the field, plain, or open tract or country: (K:) or did so to satisfy a want of nature: (TS, TA:) as also, in the former sense, (K,) or in the latter, (S,) tbrRz↓; (S, K, TA;) and bariza; (Sgh, TA;) and so, in the former sense, brRz↓ inf. n. taboriyzN; (Har p. 510;) [and in the latter sense, bArz↓ accord. to an explanation of its part. n. mubaArizN in Har p. 566:] or tbrRz↓ signifies he voided his excrement, or ordure. (Mgh, Msb.) You say, barazaUilaI Alqironi fiI AlHarobi He went, or came, out, or forth, into the field to his adversary in battle or war. (TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, (a man, TA, or thing, Msb, or anything, Fr,) appeared, or became apparent, (Fr, Sgh, Msb, K,) after concealment, (Fr, K,) or after obscurity; (Sgh;) as also bariza (Sgh, K.) ― -b3- [It was, or became, prominent, or projecting: often used in this sense.] ＝ -A2- baruza, (Msb, K,) inf. n. baraAzapN, (Msb,) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed barozN q. v.: (Msb, K:) and in like manner, baruzato, inf. n. as above, she (a woman) was, or became, such as is termed barozapN (A.)

2 brRzhu brz brzh brzp rz rzp
2. brRzhu, (inf. n. taboriyzN, S, K,) He made it apparent, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, or manifested, it; (S, A, K;) namely, a writing, or book, (A,) or other thing; (S, A;) as also Abrzhu↓: (A, Msb:) or AlkitaAba Abrz↓ signifies he put forth, or produced, the writing, or book; syn. Oaxorajahu: (TA:) and [as it often signifies in the present day,] published, it; syn. naXarahu. (K, TA.) [See also 4 below.] It is said in the Kur [xxvi. 91 and lxxix. 36], wa burRizati AljaHiymu, meaning And Hell shall be uncovered. (A.) ― -b2- brRz raAkibahu He (a horse) saved his rider. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] brRz Alfarasu, (S, Msb,) or brRz EalaI Alxayoli, (K,) inf. n. taboriyzN, (Msb,) The horse outstripped (S, Msb, K) the [other] horses (Msb, K) in the race-ground: (Msb:) it is said of a horse that outstrips in a race: and, accord. to some, the like is said of whatever outstrips: (TA:) and brRz EalaI AlgaAyapi [He (a horse) passed beyond the goal]. (A.) ― -b3- Hence, brRz fiI AlEilomi, inf. n. as above, He surpassed, or excelled, his fellows in knowledge. (Msb.) And [simply] brRz He surpassed his companions (S, K) in excellence, or in courage. (K.) And brRz EalaI OaqoraAnihi [He surpassed, or excelled, his fellows, or his opponents]. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also 4, last signification.

3 bArzhu fiI AlHarobi bArzh fy AlHrb
3. bArzhu fiI AlHarobi, (A, Msb,* K*) inf. n.
mubaArazapN and biraAzN (S, A, Msb, K,) He went, or came, out, or forth, in the field, to [encounter] him (i. e. his adversary) in battle, or war. (K,* TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

4 Abrzhu Obrz Obrzh Abrzh Abrzp brz
4. Abrzhu He made, or caused, him (a man) to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth: (S:) [or to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth, into the field, plain, or open tract or country: (see 1:)] and he made, or caused, it (a thing) to go, or come, or pass, out, or forth; or he put it, or took it, or drew it, out, or forth; syn. Oaxorajahu; as also Astbrzhu↓. (K.) See also 2, in two places. ＝ -A2- Abrz He determined, resolved, or decided, upon journeying: (IAar, K:) the vulgar say brRz↓ (TA.)

5 tabarRaza
5: see 1, in two places.

6 humaA yatabaArazaAni hmA ytbArzAn
6. humaA yatabaArazaAni They two (meaning two adversaries) go, or come, out, or forth, into the field, each to [encounter] the other, in battle or war. (K,* TA.) ― -b2- tbArzA They both separated themselves, each from his company, and betook themselves each to the other. (K.)

10 Uisotaboraza
10: see 4.

barozN brz rz
barozN A man characterized by pleasing or goodly aspect, and by intelligence: fem. with p: (S, TA:) or a man of open condition or state: (TA:) or pure in disposition; (TA;) abstaining from what is unlawful and indecorous; (S, A, Msb:) of great dignity or estimation: (Msb:) fem. with p: (A, Msb:) pl. fem. barozaAtN: (A:) or, as also baroziIRN↓ a man who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and in whose intelligence, (K,) or, as in some copies of the K, in whose excellence, bifaDolihi, but this is app. a mistranscription, or, as some say, in whose abstinence from what is unlawful and indecorous, (TA,) and his judgment, confidence is placed: (K:) and barozapN a woman whose good qualities or actions, or whose beauties, are apparent: (K:) or open in her converse; syn. mutaAjirapN: or, as in some correct lexicons, disdainful of mean things; syn. mutajaAlRapN: or of middle age, (kaholapN,) who is not veiled or concealed like young women: (TA:) or of great dignity or estimation: (AO, TA:) or who goes or comes forth to people, and with whom they sit, and of whom they talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and is intelligent: (TA:) or who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous, and goes or comes forth to men, and talks with them, and is advanced in age beyond those women who are kept concealed: (Mgh, Msb:) or open in her converse, (mutajaAhirapN,) of middle age, (kaholapN,) of great dignity or estimation, who goes or comes forth to people, and with whom they sit and talk, and who abstains from what is unlawful and indecorous: (K:) or in whose judgment, and her abstaining from what is unlawful and indecorous, confidence is placed: (TA:) or who does not veil her face from a man and bend her head down towards the ground. (IAar, on the authority of Ibn-EzZubeyr.)

baroziIRN brzI brzy rz
baroziIRN: see barozN

baraAzN brAz
baraAzN A field, plain, or wide expanse of land, (S, Msb, K,) without trees; (Msb;) as also biraAzN↓; but this latter form is rare: (Msb:) or an open tract of land destitute of herbage and trees and without hills or mountains: (Mgh, Msb:) or a place in which is no covert of trees or other things: (Fr, S:) an open place in which is no covert of trees or other things: (Fr, S:) an open place in which is no covert. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] xaraja UilaI AlbaraAzi (tropical:) He went forth to satisfy a want of nature. (A.) And UicaA OaraAda AlbaraAza OaboEada (tropical:) [When he desired to satisfy a want of nature, he went far off]: a trad.; respecting which El-Khattábee says that the relaters of traditions err respecting the word, pronouncing it with kesr, for biraAzN↓ is an inf. n.: but (SM says that) authorities differ as to this point. country of the Arabs are more than a hundred; and are distinguished by particular adjuncts, as buroqapN AlOavomaAdi and buroqapu AlOajaAwili &c. (K.) baruwqN a she-camel raising her tail, and feigning herself pregnant, not being so; as also muboriqu↓: (S, K:) and baAriqN↓ a she-camel Putting her tail between her thighs, making it to cleave to her belly, not being pregnant: (IAar, TA:) pl. of the first buroqN (TA;) and of the second mabaAriyqu. (S, K.) The Arabs say, daEoniI mino takocaAbika wa taOovaAmika
XawalaAna Albaruwqi [Let me alone and cease from they lying and thy sin like the she-camel's raising of her tail and feigning herself pregnant when she is not so]: XwlAn being in the accus. case as an inf. n.: i. e., thou art in the predicament of the she-camel that raises her tail so as to make one imagine her to be pregnant when she is not so. (TA.) The pl. buroqN is also applied to scorpions, as meaning Raising their tails like the she-camel termed brwq (TA.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a man, Fearful, or timid; (JK;) or cowardly. (TA.)

barwaqN A certain kind of plant (JK, S) which camels do not feed upon except in cases of necessity; (JK;) a small, feeble tree, which, when the sky becomes clouded, grows green: (K:) n. un. witIh p: (S, K:) it was described by an Arab of the desert to AHn as follows: a feeble, juicy plant, having slender branches, at the heads of which are small envelopes (qamaAEiylu SigaArN) like chick-peas, in which is a kind of black grain: its feebleness is such that it withers on the spot when the sun becomes hot upon it: and nothing feeds upon it; but men, when they are afflicted with dearth, or drought, express from it a bitter juice, then work it together, or knead it, with habiyd [or colocynths, or the pulp, or seeds, thereof], or some other thing, and eat it; but it is not eaten alone, because it occasions excitement: it is one of the plants that are plentiful in time of drought and scarce in time of fruitfulness; when copious rain falls upon it, it dies; and when we see it to have become abundant, and coarse, or rough, we fear drought: accord. to another of the Arabs of the desert, the barowaqap is a bad kind of herb, or leguminous plant, that grows among the first of the herbs, or leguminous plants: it has a reed like the sbAT [so I render lhA qSbp mvl AlsbAT, but I thing that the right reading is, lahaA quDubN mivolu AlsRiyaATi it has twigs like whips, agreeably with the description next preceding, in which it is said to have slender branches,] and a black fruit, or produce. (TA.) Hence, OaXokaru mino barowaqapK [More grateful than a barwakah]; (S, K;) because it grows green when it sees the clouds, (S,) or by means of the least moisture falling from the sky: (TA:) a prove. (S.) And OaDoEafu mino barowaqapK [Weaker than a barwakah]. (TA.)

baworaqN, (JK, Mgh,) with fet-h to the b (Mgh,) or buwraqN., with damm, (K,) A certain, thing, or substance, that is put into dough, (JK, Mgh, TA,) and causes it to become inflated; (Mgh;) or into flour; (TA voce buwrakN;) [or this is a particular kind thereof, as appears from what follows: accord. to Golius, nitrum and aphronitrum: but] it is of four kinds; maAYiIRN [or the water-kind], and jabaliIRN [or the mountain-kind], and OaromaniIRN [or Armenian], and miSoriIRN [or Egyptian], which is the naToruwn [q. v., i. e. natron]: (K:) the best thereof is the ArmnI; and this is said to be meant by the term when it is used absolutely: this is called also bwrqu AlSRaAgapi [a term now applied to borax, as is bwrq alone, and miloHu AlSRaAgapi], because it polishes silver well [or because of its use in soldering]: the dust-coloured kind thereof is called bwrqu AlxabRaAziyna [the bwrq of the bakers, or makers of bread]: the nTrwn is the red kind thereof: and there is a kind thereof having an oily quality: and a kind consisting of thin butyraceous fragments; and this, if light and hard, is the UiforiyqiI: and the best thereof is that which is produced in Egypt: (TA:) bruised, or powdered, the belly is smeared with it, near to a fire, and it expels worms: and moistened with honey or with oil of jasmine, the male organs of generation are anointed with it, for it is excellent for the venereal faculty. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also A man in whom one does not trust, or confide: pl. bawaAriqu. (JK.)

Oaboraqu c
Oaboraqu A rope (Habol) having two colours; (S, O;) twisted with a black strand and a white strand: (JK:) and in like manner, (JK,) a mountain (jabal, JK, K) in which are two colours, (K, TA,) black and white: (TA:) and (so in the S, but in the K “ or,”) anything having blackness and whiteness together. (S, K.) You say tayosN OaboraqN and EanozN baroqaMCu [A black and white he-goat and she-goat]: (S, K:) and XaApN baroqaMCu a ewe whose white wool is cleft, or divided, by black flocks [or streaks]: (K:) Oaboraqu and baroqaMCu applied to sheep or goats are like Oabolaqu and baloqaMCu applied to beasts of the equine kind, and OaboqaEu and baqoEaMCu to dogs. (Lh, TA.) ― -b2- baroqaMCu is also a name given to An eye; (S, M;) because it has blackness and whiteness mingled in it: (M, TA:) dual baroqaAwaAni. (TA.) And EayonN baroqaMCu signifies An eye black in the iris, with whiteness [of the rest] of the bulb. (TA.) ― -b3- rawoDapN baroqMCu A meadorc, or garden, in
which are two colours. (TA.) ― -b4- See also buroqapN. in seven places. ― -b5- Oaboraqu also signifies A certain bird. (Tekmileh, K.) ― -b6- And [the pl.] buroqN is used as a name for The [locusts, or crickets, termed] janaAdib. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A certain Persian medicine, good for the memory. (Sgh, K.)

OabaAriyqu (S, Msb) [and sometimes OabaAriqapN]. ＝ -A2- A sword such as is termed barRaAq↓; (K;) i. e. (TA) a sword that shines, gleams, or glistens, much, or intensely: (S, Kr:) or simply a sword: or, as some say, a bow: (JK:) or it signifies also a bow in which are talaAmiyE [or places differing in colour from the rest, and, app., glistening]: (K:) thus, accord. to Az, in a verse of ' Amr Ibn-Ahmar: but correctly, accord. to Sgh, it has there the first of the significations explained in this sentence: and it is said, also, that sayofN UiboriyqN signifies a sword having much lustre, and much diversified with wavy marks or streaks, or in its grain. (TA.) ― -b2- A woman who is beautiful, and splendid, or brilliant, (Lh, JK, K, TA,) in colour [or complexion]: (Lh, TA:) or, as some say, who shows her beauty intentionally. (TA.) [See also barRaAqapN (voce barRaAqN).]

3 bArk Ealayohi bArk Elyh bArk Elyp
3. bArk Ealayohi He kept, or applied himself, constantly, or perseveringly, to it; (Lh, K;) namely, an affair, (TA in art. HfZ,) or commerce, or traffic, &c. (Lh, TA.) ＝ -A2- bArk QllRehu fiyka, (Fr, S, Msb, K,) and laka, and Ealayoka, (S, K,) and baArakaka, (Fr, S, K,) inf. n. mubaArakapN, (TK,) [God bless, beatify, felicitate, or prosper, thee;] God put in thee, (TA,) give thee, make thee to possess, (T, K,) barakap [i. e. a blessing, good of any kind, prosperity or good fortune, increase, &c.]. (TA, TK.) baAriko EalaI muHamRidK wa EalaI Mli muHamRadK (in a trad., TA,) means Continue Thou, or perpetuate Thou, (O God,) to Mohammad and to the family of Mohammad the eminence and honour which Thou hast given them: (K, TA:) [or still bless or beatify, or continue to bless or beatify, Mohammad &c.: though it may well be rendered simply bless or beatify &c.:] Az says that it is from baraka said of a camel, meaning “he lay down upon his breast in a place and clave thereto.” (TA.) And AallRehuma baAriko lanaA fiI Almawoti, in another trad., means [O God, bless us] in the state to which death will bring us. (TA.) The Arabs say to the beggar, buwrika fiyka [Mayest thou be blest; and, in the present day, AallReh yubaArik fiyk God bless thee]; meaning thereby to repel him; not to pray for him: and by reason of frequency of usage of this phrase, they have made buwrik↓ a noun: a poet [in Har XryX AlEdwI (app. Sherees, not Shereesh, El-'Adawee), in the TA Aboo-Fir'own,] says,
taZunRu OanRa buwrikFA yakofiyniI
UicaA xarajotu baAsiTFA yamiyniI
[She imagines that the saying “Mayest thou be blest” will suffice me when I go forth stretching out my right hand for an alms]. (Har p. 378. [This verse is differently cited in the TA; for there, instead of tZnR and xrjt, we find tuHibRu and gadawotu.]) ― -b2- [You also say of a man, bArk fiyhi, and lahu, &c., meaning He blessed him; i. e. he prayed God to bless him.] ― -b3- See also 6.

4. Abrkhu He made him (namely, a camel,) to lie down [or kneel and lie down] upon his breast. (S, K.) You say, Oaborakotuhu fabaraka I made him to lie down upon his breast, and he lay down upon his breast: but this is rare: the more common phrase is Oanoxatuhu faQsotanRAxa. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also 8. ＝ -A3- maA Oaborakahu [How blessed is he, or it!] is an instance of a verb of wonder with a passive meaning [and irregularly derived]. (TA.)

5 tbrRk bihi tbrk bh tbrk bp
5. tbrRk bihi i. q. tayamRana bihi [He had a blessing; and he was, or became, blest; by means of him, or it: so accord. to explanations of tabarRuko in the KL: but very often signifying he looked for a blessing by means of him, or it; he regarded him, or it, as a means of obtaining a blessing; he augured good from him, or it; tymRn bh being opposed to taXaORama bh; as in the K in art. Tyr, and in Bd in xvii. 14, &c.]: (S, K:) and tbArk↓ biAlXRayoCi He augured good from the thing. (Lth, K.) One says so of a man. (K in art. msH.) And one says, tbrRk biQsomi QllRehi [He looked for a blessing by means of uttering the name of God, or saying bisomi QllRehi]. (Ksh, on the bsmlp; &c.)

6 tbArk bArI bArk tbAr tbArk
6. tbArk, accord. to Zj, is an instance of tafaAEala [as quasi-pass. of faAEala, i. e., of baAraka, like as tabaAEada is of baAEada,] from Albarakapu; and so say the lexicologists [in general]. (TA.) [Hence,] tbArk QllRehu means [Blessed is, or be, God; or] hallowed is, or be, God; or far removed is, or be, He from every impurity or imperfection, or from everything derogatory from his glory; (K) or highly to be exalted, or extolled, is God; or highly exalted, or extolled, be He; (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA;) greatly to be magnified is God; or greatly magnified be He: (TA:) or i. q. baAraka↓, like qaAtala and taqAatala, except that faAEala is trans. and tafaAaEala is intrans.: (S:) accord. to IAmb, it means [that] one looks for a blessing by means of [uttering] his name (yutabarRaku biQsomihi) in every affair, or case: accord. to Lth, it is a phrase of glorification and magnification: (TA:) or tbArk signifies He is abundant in good; from Albarakapu, which is “abundance of good:” or He exceeds everything, and is exalted above it, in his attributes and his operations; because Albarakapu implies the meaning of increase, accession, or redundance: or He is everlasting; syn. daAma; from buruwku AlTRayori EalaI AlmaMCi [“the continuing of the birds at the water”]; whence Albirokapu, because of the continuance of the water therein: the verb is invariable [when thus used, being considered as divested of all signification of time, or used in an optative sense]; and is not employed [in any of the senses above] otherwise than in relation to God: (Bd in xxv. 1:) it is an attributive peculiar to God. (K.) ― -b2- tbArk biAlXRaIoCi: see 5.

8. Abtrk He (a man) threw his barok [i. e. breast upon the ground (as the camel does in lying down), or upon some other thing]. (S.) ― -b2- He (a sword-polisher) leaned upon the polishing-instrument, (K,) on one side. (TA.) And He (a horse) inclined on one side in his running. (TA: [accord. to which, this is from what next follows.]) ― -b3- He hastened, or sped, and strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in running: (S, K:) and baraka↓, inf. n. buruwkN, (K,) or, as some say, this is a subst. from the former verb, (TA,) He strove, laboured, or exerted himself. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a cloud) rained continually, or incessantly: (TA:) and Abtrkt AlsRamaMCu (assumed tropical:) the sky rained continually; as also barakat↓, (K,) and Abrkt↓; but Sgh says that the first of these three is the most correct. (TA.) And Abtrkt AlsRaHaAbapu (tropical:) The cloud rained vehemently. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Abtrk fiI EiroDihi, and Ealayohi, (tropical:) He detracted from his reputation, censured him, or impugned his character, and reviled him, (K, TA,) and laboured in vituperating him. (TA.) AbtrkwA fiI AlHarobi (tropical:) They fell upon their knees in battle, and so fought one another. (K, TA. [See barakaMCu, below.]) ＝ -A2- Aibotarakotuhu I prostrated him, or threw him down prostrate, and put him beneath my barok [i. e. breast]. (S.)

satiety: (TA:) or all the camels of the people of an encampment, that return to them from pasture in the evening, or afternoon, to whatever number they may amount, even if they be thousands: (K:) one thereof is termed baArikN↓; (K;) the two words being like tajorN and taAjirN; (TA;) fem. baArikapN↓: (K:) pl. buruwkN, (S, K,) i. e., pl. of barokN. (Ham p. 145.) ― -b2- Hence, barok AlXRitaMCi (tropical:) The first part of winter; (L, TA; *) and the main part thereof. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) One who does not take part with others in the game called Almayosir [q. v.], (As, T, S, M, K,) nor contribute with them anything, (TA,) by reason of his avarice, (Har p. 382,) though he eats with them of the flesh-meat thereof; (As, TA;) but sometimes he shuffles, or deals forth, (yufiyDu,) the gaming-arrows for the players: (S in art. jmd:) likened to the barama of the OaraAk, because he is of no use: (Har ubi suprà:) and baramapN↓ occurs in the same sense; [the man so termed being likened to a baramap of the ArAk; or] the p being added to give intensiveness to the meaning: (M:) the pl. is OaboraAmN. (T, S, M, K.) And hence, (tropical:) Avaricious, or niggardly; mean, or sordid: (Har ubi suprà:) or heavy, or sluggish; (K, TA;) destitute of good. (TA.) It is said in a prov., OaboramFA qaruwnFA (tropical:) [Art thou (takuwnu being understood after) one taking no part with others in the game of Almysr, as is implied in the S, or art thou] heavy, or sluggish, (K, TA,) destitute of good, (TA,) yet eating two dates at once each time? (S, K, TA.)

burohaAnN An evidence, or a proof: (T, S, Msb, K, and Ham p. 7:) and a demonstration; i. e. the manifestation of an evidence or proof: (Msb:) or a decisive and manifest evidence or proof: (TA:) or the firmest, strongest, or most valid, evidence or proof; which is such as ever necessarily implies truth, or veracity, as its consequence, or concomitant; for evidences, or proofs, are of five sorts; whereof this is one; another is that which ever necessarily implies falsity, or falsehood, as its consequence, or concomitant; another, that which is nearer to truth, or veracity; another, that which is nearer to falsity, or falsehood; and another, that which is intermediate between these two: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [pl. baraAhiynu:] some say that the n in this word is augmentative; (Msb, and Ham p. 7;) that it is of the measure fuEolaAnN, from Albrh [app. Albarohu] signifying the “act of cutting:” (Ham ubi suprà:) others, that it is radical: Az mentions both of these opinions: J confines

IJ] says that he holds it to be of the measure fuEolaAlN, like quroTaAsN and quronaAsN, the n not being augmentative, as is shown by the verb above mentioned: (Ham ubi suprà:) but [it has been stated above that] this verb is said, on the authority of IAar, to be post-classical. The mtbAryAn whose food is forbidden, in a trad., to be eaten, are They who vie with each other in order that each may render the other unable to equal him in respect of the repast prepared by him for his guests: and the doing of this is disliked because of the rivalry and ostentation that are involved in it. You say also, bazaA Ealayohi, aor. as above, meaning tTAwl [i. e., thus followed by Elyh, He held up his head with an assumption of superiority over him; behaved haughtily towards him; exalted himself above him; or overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, him]. And bazaAhu, aor. as above, (K,) inf. n. bazowN, (TA,) He overcame, or subdued, him; and laid violent hands upon him, or assaulted him; as also AbzI↓ bihi: (K:) or this last signifies he overcame him, and subdued him: (S:) and bazaAhu, he wronged him; or treated him wrongfully, or injuriously: and AbzAhu↓ may signify the same; or this may mean he induced him to become OabozaI, q. v.: (Ham p. 502:) and accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, AbzI↓ signifies he pressed heavily upon his adversary, or imposed on him that which he was unable to do, or to bear, in order to treat him wrongfully, or injuriously. [As such,] He spread it; spread it out, or forth; expanded it; extended it; (S, Msb, K, B;) as also bsRThu↓: (K:) and he made it wide, or ample: these are the primary significations; and sometimes both of them may be conceived; and sometimes, one of them: and the verb is also used, metaphorically, as relating to anything which cannot be conceived as composed or constructed: (B:) and baSoTN is the same as basoTN, (S, and K in art. bST,) in all its meanings. And basaTa ciraAEayohi, and basRaTahumaA↓, (assumed tropical:) He spread his fore arms upon the ground; the doing of which [in prostrating oneself] in prayer is forbidden. (TA.) And basaTa yadahu (M, Msb, K) (tropical:) He stretched forth, or extended, his arm, or hand; (M, K;) as in the saying basaTa UiliIRa yadahu bimaA OuHibRu waOakorahu (tropical:) [He stretched forth, or extended, towards me his arm, or hand, with, i. e. to do to me, what I liked and disliked]: (M, TA: *) or he stretched forth his hand opened. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [v. 31], laYino basaTota UilaIRa yadaka litaqotulaniy (assumed tropical:) [Assuredly if thou stretch forth towards me thy hand to slay me]. (M, TA.) basoTu Alyadi and AlkafRi is sometimes used to denote assaulting and smiting: [as in the last of the exs. given above; and] as in the words of the Kur [lx. 2], wayabusuTuwA Uilayokumo Oayodiyahumo waOalosinatahumo biAlsRuwoCi (tropical:) [And they will stretch forth towards you their hands and their tongues with evil]; (TA;) i. e., by slaying, (Bd, Jel,) and smiting, (Jel,) and reviling. And sometimes to denote giving liberally: (TA:) [as in] basaTa yadahu fiI AlUanofaAqi (tropical:) He [stretched forth his hand, opened, or] was liberal or bountiful or munificent [in expenditure]: (Msb:) see basiyTN, below. (TA.) And sometimes to denote taking, or taking possession, or seizing: as in the saying, (TA,) busiTato yaduhu Ealayohi (tropical:) [His hand was stretched forth against him]; i. e. he was made to have dominion over him by absolute force and power. (K, TA.) And sometimes to denote seeking, or demanding: [as in basaTa kafRayohi fiI AldRuEaMCi (tropical:) He expanded his two hands in supplication; a common action, in which the two hands are placed together like an open book upon a desk before the face, in supplicating God:] see baAsiTN, below. (TA.) ― -b2- [An arm's length.] See baAsiTN ― -b3- AimoraOapN basoTapN. A woman beautiful and sleek in body: and in like manner, ZaboyapN a gazelle that is so. (M.)

(TA.) And yaduhu bisoTN↓ (S, K,) like TiHonN in the sense of maToHuwnN, and qiTofN in the sense of maqoTuwfN, (TA,) and busuTN↓ (Z, K,) like OunufN and sujuHN, (Z,) and (Z, K) by contraction, (Z,) busoTN↓, (Z, K,) and mabosuwTapN↓, (TA,) (tropical:) His hand is liberal; syn. muTolaqapN, (S, K, TA,) and TaloqN; (TA;) or he is large in expenditure. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [v. 69], balo yadaAhu mabosuwTataAni↓; (TA;) and accord. to one reading, bisoTaAni↓; (S, K;) and accord. to another, with damm, [as though it were busoTaAni↓,] (Z, K, TA,) [but it is said that] in this case it is used as an inf. n., [and therefore busoTaAnN↓, for an inf. n. is applied as an epithet to a dual and a pl. subst. without alteration,] like guforAnN and ruDowaAnN; or, accord. to some, it is most probably [basoTaAnu↓,] like raHomaAnu; and Talhah Ibn-Musarrif read bisaTaAni↓: (TA:) the meaning is, (tropical:) Nay, his hands are liberal, or bountiful; the phrase being a simile; for in this case there is no hand, nor any stretching forth. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., limusiIoCi AlnRahaAri HatRaI yatuwba yadaA QllRehi busoTaAni↓ biAllRayoli walimusiIoCi AllRayoli HatRaI yatuwba biAlnRahaAri, (K, * TA,) or, accord. to one relation, bisoTaAni↓, (TA,) meaning (tropical:) God is liberal in forgiveness to the evil-doer of the day-time until he repent [in the night, and to the evil-doer of the night-time until he repent in the day]: for a king is said to be AlyadimabosuwTu↓ when he is (tropical:) liberal in his gifts by command and by sign, although he gives nothing thereof with his hand, nor stretches it forth with them at all. (Sgh. TA.) ― -b6- basiyTN also signifies AllRsaAnimunobasiTu↓, (Lth,) or munobasiTN bilisaAnihi, (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) [Free, or unconstrained, in tongue, or with his tongue,] applied to a man: (M:) fem. with p. (K.) ― -b7- AlbasiyTu is also the name of A certain kind of metre of verse; (S, M, * K;) namely, the third; the measure of which consists of musotafoEiluno faAEiluno eight [a mistake for four] times: (K:) so called because of the extension of its OasobaAb, commencing with a sabab immediately followed by another sabab, as is said by Aboo-Is-hák. (M.) ― -b8- [basiyTN is also used in philosophy as signifying (assumed tropical:) Simple; uncompounded.]

And again, in the Kur [xiii. 15], kabaAsiTi kafRayohi UilaI AlmaMCi liyaboluga (tropical:) Like the supplicator of water, making a sign to it [with his two hands], in order that it may [reach his mouth, and so] answer his prayer; (K, * TA;) or, but it will not answer his prayer. (O, TA.) ― -b3- AlbaAsiTu (assumed tropical:) God, who amplifies, or enlarges, or makes ample or plentiful, the means of subsistence, to whomsoever He will, (K, TA,) by his liberality and his mercy: (TA:) or who diffuses (yabosuTu) the souls in the bodies at the time of [their] being animated. , (M,) inf. n. busuwlN, He (a man, TA) frowned, contracted his face, or looked sternly or austerely or morosely; or, doing so, grinned, or displayed his teeth; or contracted the part between his eyes; (Eabasa;) by reason of courage, or of anger; as also tbsRl↓: (M, K:) and [so in the M, but in the K “or”] tbsRl↓ wajohuhu, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) or tbsRl↓ [alone], (so in other copies of the K, and in the TA,) His face, or he, was, or became, odious, and excessively foul or unseemly or hideous, in aspect: (M, K:) and liI tbsRl↓ He (a man) was displeasing, or odious, in aspect to me. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence], (M, K,) inf. n. busuwlN, (TA,) said of milk, and of nabiyc [or must &c.], (tropical:) It was, or became, strong: (K: [in the CK, basRala is here erroneously put for basala; and wabasRalahu, which should next follow, is omitted:]) or, said of the former, it was, or became, displeasing, or odious, in taste, and sour; and, said of the latter, it was, or became, strong, and sour. (M, TA.) Also, said of vinegar, (assumed tropical:) It, having been left long, became altered, or corrupted, in flavour. (Az in art. Hcq, TA.) And, said of flesh-meat, (assumed tropical:) It stank, or became stinking. (AHn, M, TA.) ＝ -A3- bisula, [aor.
basula
,] inf. n. basaAlapN (S, M, Msb, K) and basaAlN, [respecting which latter see what follows in the next sentence,] (M, K,) He was, or became, courageous, or strong-hearted, on the occasion of war, or fight: (S, M, Msb, K:) from basolN meaning “forbidden,” or “prohibited;” because he who has this quality defends himself from his antagonist, as though it were forbidden to him [the latter] to do him a displeasing, or an evil, deed. waOaHolaI mina AltRamori AljaniIRi wa fiyhimu
basaAlapu nafosK Uino Ouriyda basaAluhaA
[And sweeter than fresh-gathered dates, and in them is courageousness of soul, if courageousness thereof be desired]: but bsAlhA may be here altered by curtailment from basaAlanuhaA. (M.) You say, maA Oaboyana basaAlatahu [How manifest is] his courage! (TA.) ― -b2- See also 4.

4. UibosaAlN [inf. n. of Absl] i. q. basolN as explained in the first sentence of this art.; i. e., The act of preventing, hindering, withholding, debarring, (Bd in vi. 69,] forbidding, or prohibiting. (S, K, and Bd ubi suprà.) ＝ -A2- Abslhu (inf. n. as above, TA) He pledged, or gave in pledge, him, or it, (M, Msb, K,) likacaA [and bikacaA, as will be shown below, both meaning for such a thing]: and he gave in exchange, or as an equivalent, him, or it, likacaA [and app. bikacaA also, as above, for such a thing]; syn. EarRaDahu: (M, K:) and he gave him up, delivered him, delivered him over, or consigned him, to destruction, (S, K,) or to punishment. (Az, TA.) 'Owf Ibn-El-Ahwas says,
waUibosaAliy baniIRa bigayorijuromK baEawonaAhu wa laA bidamK muraAqi
[And my giving in pledge, or as an equivalent, or giving up to destruction, my sons, not for a crime that we have committed, nor for blood that has been shed by us]: (S, M, TA:) for he had given his sons in pledge for others, seeking peace, or reconciliation. (S, TA.) Oano tubosala bimaA kasabato, in the Kur [vi. 69], means Lest a soul should be given up, or delivered, &c., (AO, S, Bd, Jel, TA.) to destruction, (Bd, Jel, TA,) or to punishment, (Az, TA,) for that which it hath done, (Az, Bd, Jel, TA,) of evil: (Bd:) or be given in pledge. (Bd, TA.) And OuwleYika AlRaciyna OubosiluwA bimaA kasabuwA, in the same [ubi suprà], means, in like manner, Those who are given up, or delivered, &c., (to punishment, Bd) for their sins: (El- Hasan, Bd, * TA:) or who are given in pledge: (Msb, TA:) or are destroyed: or, as Mujáhid says, are disgraced, or put to shame, by the
exposure of their sins: or, as Katádeh says, are imprisoned. (TA.) ― -b2- Abslhu liEamalihi and biEamalihi He left him to his work, not interfering with him therein. (M, K.) ― -b3- Absl nafosahu lilomawoti, (M, K,) as also Astbsl↓ [alone], (M, K, and Ham p. 291), and tbsRl↓, and bsl↓, [which last may be either basala or basula, or perhaps it is a mistranscription for Oabosala,] (Ham ibid.,) He disposed and subjected his mind, or himself, to death, (M, K, Ham,) and felt certain, or sure, of it: (Ham, TA:) and in like manner, lilDRarobi [to beating, i. e., to being beaten]: (TA:) and lilomawoti Abtsl↓ He submitted himself to death: (TA:) and Astbsl↓ He threw himself into war, or battle, or fight, desiring to slay or be slain, (S K,) inevitably. (S.) ＝ -A3- maA Oabosalahu How courageous, or stronghearted, is he, on the occasion of war, or fight! (TA.)
