inf. n. basomN (S, M, Msb, K) and mabosamN; (K, * TA;) [He smiled;] these verbs signify less than DaHika [so that they are properly explained by the Latin subrisit]: (S, Msb:) or he opened his lips like him who displays to another his teeth: (Lth, TA:) or he laughed in the least degree and in the most beautiful manner: (M, K:) or he laughed a little without any sound: (Msb:) or tabasRumN is the beginning of DaHikN [or laughter]: (Towsheeh, and Neseem er-Riyád, in TA art. DHk, q. v.:) accord. to Zj, it is the utmost degree of laughing of the prophets. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlsRaHaAbu Abtsm↓ Eani Albaroqi (M,) or tbsRm Eanohu (TA,) i. q. AinokalRa Enh [i. e. (tropical:) The clouds displayed a faint flashing of lightning]. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And tbsRm AlTRaloEu (tropical:) The extremities of the TlE [i. e. the spadix, or the spathe, of the palm-tree,] burst asunder. (TA.)

8 Uibotasama
8: see 5, in two places.

basRaAmN bsAm sAm sAmy
basRaAmN (S M, K) and mibosaAmN↓ (S, K) epithets from basama, (M, K,) applied to a man, (S, M,) meaning kaviyru AltRabasRumi [That smiles much]. (S.)

baAsimN bAsm bQsm Qsm
baAsimN part. n. of basama [meaning Smiling]. (K, TA.)

mabosimN mbsm
mabosimN i. q. vagorN (S, K,) meaning The front teeth: (TK:) [and sometimes, perhaps, the mouth:] so called as being the place of AltRabasRum [or smiling: pl. mabaAsimu]. (TA.) One says, [of women or girls,] hunRa gurRu AlmabaAsimi [They are white in the front teeth]. (TA.)

mibosaAmN mbsAm
mibosaAmN: see basRaAmN

Q. 1 basomala bsml sml
Q. 1. basomala, (T, S, &c.,) inf. n. basomalapN, (S, Msb,) He said, (S, Msb, K, KL,) or wrote, (T, Msb,) bisomi QllRehi [In, or with, the name of God I recite, or read, or I begin, &c.]: (T, S, Msb, K, KL:) or bisomi QllRehi AlrRaHomaAni AlrRaHiymi [In, or with, the name of God, the Compassionate, the Merciful]: (KL:) a verb of the kind termed manoHuwt i. e. compounded of two [or more] words; like Hamodala and Hawoqala and Hasobala &c.: (Msb, TA:) said by some to be post-classical, not heard from the chaste Arabs; but authorized by many of the leading lexicologists, as ISk and Mtr; and occurring in the poetry of 'Omar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah [who is said to have been born in the year of the Flight 23]. (TA.)

mubasomalN mbsml
mubasomalN Discourse, (TA,) or amorous behaviour, and coquettish boldness, (Msb,) accompanied by the saying bisomi QllRehi: (Msb, TA:) occurring in a verse of 'Omar Ibn-Abee-Rabee'ah [referred to above]. (TA.)

4 Absn Absn
4. Absn, said of a man, He was, or became good, or beautiful, in respect of his sajiyRap [i. e. natural disposition], accord. to the copies of the K, but correctly, as explained by IAar, his saHonap [i. e. aspect, or colour, &c.]. (TA.)

basanN bAs bsn sn
basanN an imitative sequent to HasanN: (S, M, K:) [or it may signify Beautiful in aspect &c., from the verb above; or the verb may be from this word:] or, in the opinion of Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee, originally basRN inf. n., used in the sense of the pass. part. n., of basRa AlsRawiyqa, meaning “he moistened, or stirred about, the swyq with clarified butter, or with olive-oil, to complete, or perfect, its goodness; ” one of the two s s being suppressed, and n being added; so that it means complete, or perfect. (MF. [But this derivation seems to be extremely far-fetched.])

1 baXRa c
1. baXRa, first pers. baXiXotu, aor. yabaXRu, (S, K,) and, accord. to a relation of a verse of Ru-beh, yabiXRu, so that perhaps baXaXotu was also said, (TA.) inf. n. baXaAXapN (S, A, K) and baXRN (A, K) and baXiyXN, (TA,) He was, or became, cheerful in countenance. (S, A, K.) You say, baXiXotu bihi I was, or became, cheerful in countenance [by reason of meeting] with him: (S:) or baXRa bihi (TK,) inf. n. baXRN (Lth, K) and baXaAXapN, (K,) signifies he rejoiced in him, or was pleased with him, namely, a friend, (Lth, K,) at meeting: (Lth:) or he showed joy, or pleasure, at meeting him. (TK.) You say
also, biI laqiytuhu fatabaXobaXa↓ [app. meaning I met him and he became cheerful in countenance by reason of meeting with me]; originally tabaXRaXa↓; the middle X being changed into b: (Yaakoob, S:) or bihi tabaXobaXa↓ signifies he was, or became, sociable, or companionable, or cheerful, with him; and held loving communion with him: syn. Mnasahu, and waASalahu: (K:) but when said of God, it means (tropical:) He regarded him with favour, and honoured him, (IAmb, K,) and received him graciously, and drew him near to Him. (IAmb.) ― -b2- Also baXRa lahu, (TK,) inf. n. baXRN (IDrd, K) and baXaAXapN, (K,) He presented a favourable aspect to him; or met him kindly, namely, his brother; syn. Oaqobala Ealayohi: (K:) he behaved laughingly towards him; without shyness, or aversion; or boldly; or in a free and easy manner; or cheerfully; syn. DaHika Uilayohi, (IDrd, K,) and AinobasaTa. (IDrd.) ― -b3- And baXRa lahu fiI AlmasoOalapi, (TK,) inf. n. baXRN (IAar, A, K) and baXaAXapN, (A, K,) He was courteous, or gracious, to him in asking. (IAar, A, K.) ― -b4- And baXRa liI bixayori (tropical:) He gave me [something good]. (A, TA.)

4 AbXRt AlOaroDu c
4. AbXRt AlOaroDu (tropical:) The land had tangled, or luxuriant, plants, or herbage: (As, K:) or produced its first plants, or herbage. (K.)

5 tabaXRaRa
5: see 1.

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: see 1, in two places.

rajulN haXRN baXRN c
rajulN haXRN baXRN A man [brisk, lively, or sprightly; or joyful; and] cheerful in countenance; pleasant [therein]; (S, TA;) as also baXRaAXN↓. (TA.) [See also art. hX.]

baXiyXN c
baXiyXN The face, or countenance. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, fulaAnN muDiIoCu AlbaXiyXi Such a one is bright in countenance. (Ibn-'Abbád.)

baXRaAXN c
baXRaAXN: see baXRN.

OabaXRu c
OabaXRu [More, and most, cheerful in countenance]. You say, maA raOayotu OabaXRa minohu biAllRaAqiI [I have not seen any one more cheerful in countenance than he to the meeter]. (A.)

1 baXara c
1. baXara, aor.
baXura
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. baXorN; (S, Msb, K;) and AbXr↓, (A,) inf. n. UiboXaArN; (K;) He pared (S, A, Msb, K) a hide, (S, A, Msb,) removing its baXarap, (S,) or face, or surface, (A, Msb,) or the skin upon which the hair grew: (TA:) or, as some say, removing its inner part with a large knife: or, accord. to Ibn-Buzurj, some of the Arabs say, baXarotu AlOadiyma, aor.
baXira
, meaning I removed from the hide its baXarap; and OaboXarotuhu↓ as meaning I exposed to view its baXarap that was next to the flesh; and Mdamotuhu I exposed to view its Oadamap upon which the hair grew. (TA.) [But see OadamapN.] ― -b2- Hence the saying in a trad., mano OaHabRa AlquroMna qaloyaboXuro, accord. to him who recites it thus, with damm to the X; meaning (assumed tropical:) Whoso loveth the Kur-án, let him make himself light of flesh, [by not eating more than will be sufficient, and so prepare himself] for [reading, or reciting,] it, [like as one prepares a horse for running,] because eating much causes one to forget it. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, baXara AlOaroDa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) (assumed tropical:) It (a swarm of locusts) stripped the ground; (TA;) ate what was upon the ground, (S, K,) i. e., upon its surface; as though the exterior of the ground were its baXarap. (TA.) ― -b4- And baXara, aor.
baXura
, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He clipped his mustache much, so that the baXarap (i. e. the exterior of the skin, TA) became apparent. (K, TA.) This the Muslim is commanded to do. (TA.) ― -b5- baXaraniI fulaAnN biwajohK HasanK Such a one met me with a cheerful countenance. (S.) See also 2, in two places. ― -b6- And see 3. ＝ -A2- baXira, aor.
baXara
; (IAar, S, Msb, K;) and baXara, aor.
baXira
, (IAar, K,) inf. n. baXorN and buXuwrN; (TA;) and AbXr↓, [which is the most common, though extr. in respect of analogy, as being quasi-pass. of baXara, like AHjm and AHnj and AErD and AqXE and AkbR and Anhj, (mentioned by MF in art. Hnj as the only other instances of the kind,) and Axlj, (added in the TA in art. xlj,)] (S, A, Mgh, K,) inf. n. UiboXaArN; (S;) and AstbXr↓; (S, A, Msb, K;) and tbXRr↓; (A;) [originally, He became changed in his baXarap (or complexion) by the annunciation of an event: see baXRarahu: and hence,] he rejoiced, or became rejoiced; (IAar, S, A, Msb, K;) bikacaA [at, or by, such a thing; or at, or by, the annunciation of such a thing]. (IAar, S, K. *) You say, OataAniI OamorN baXirotu bihi An affair happened to me whereat I rejoiced, or whereby I became rejoiced. (S.) And bimawoluwdK OaboXara↓ He rejoiced [at the annunciation of a new-born child]. (S.) And bixayorK OaboXiro↓ Rejoice thou [at the annunciation of a good event]. (S, K.) And in the same sense OaboXiruwA↓ is used in the Kur xli. 30. (S.)

2 bXRrhu c
2. bXRrhu (S, A, Msb, &c.,) the form used by the Arabs in general, (Msb,) inf. n. taboXiyrN; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) and baXarahu↓, aor.
baXura
, (S, Mgh, Msb,) of the dial. of Tihámeh and the adjacent parts, (Msb,) inf. n. baXorN and buXuwrN (S, K) and buXorN, (TA,) or this last is a simple subst.; (Msb;) and AbXrhu↓; (S, A, Mgh, K;) and AstbXrhu↓; (K, TA;) are syn.; (S, K, &c.;) originally signifying He announced to him an event which produced a change in his baXarap [or complexion]: and hence, (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee,) he announced to him an event which rejoiced him: (A, El-Fakhr Er-Rázee:) so in common acceptation [when not restricted by an adjunct that denotes its having a different meaning: see buXoraI and an ex. below in this paragraph]: (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee:) or he rejoiced him [by an annunciation]: (Msb:) and he announced to him an event which grieved him: [or he grieved him by an annunciation:] both these significations are proper. (El-Fakhr Er-Rázee.) You say, bXRrhu biAlOamori [generally meaning He rejoiced him by the annunciation of the event]; and bihi baXarahu↓, aor. and inf. ns. as above; &c. (TA.) And baXRarotuhu bimawoluwdK [I rejoiced him by the annunciation of a new-born child]. (S.) And it is said in the Kur [iii. 20, &c.], baXRirohumo biEacaAbK OaliymK [Grieve thou them by the annunciation, or denunciation, of a painful punishment]. (S.) You say also, of a she-camel, baXRarato biAllRaqaAHi, meaning (assumed tropical:) She made it known that she had begun to be pregnant. (TA. [See also 4.])

3 bAXr AlmaroOapa c
3. bAXr AlmaroOapa, (K, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAXarapN (S, Mgh, TA) and biXaArN, (TA,) He was, or became, in contact with the woman, skin to skin: (TA:) he enjoyed [contact with] her skin: (Msb:) he became in contact with her, skin to skin, both being within one garment or piece of cloth: (K:) he lay with her, [skin to skin; or in the sense of] inivit eam: (S, K:) i. q. waTiYahaA, both fiI Alfaroji and xaArijFA minohu: (TA:) [and so baXarahaA↓ inf. n. baXorN; for] baXorN and mubaAXarapN are syn. [in the sense of congressus venereus, as is shown by an ex. in the S.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- bAXrhu AlnRaEiymu (tropical:) [Enjoyment attended him; as though it clave to his skin]. (A.) ― -b3- fabaAXaruwA rawoHa Alyaqiyni, or ruwHa Alyqyn, is a metaphorical expression, [app. meaning (tropical:) And they felt the joy and happiness that arise from certainty,] occurring in a trad. of 'Alee. (TA.) ― -b4- bAXr AlOamora, (S, A, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAXarapN, (S,) (tropical:) He superintended, managed, or conducted, the affair himself, or in his own person: (S, K, TA:) or (tropical:) he was present, himself, at the affair: (A, TA:) or, [properly,] he managed, or conducted, the affair with his baXarap, i. e., his own hand: (Mgh, * Msb:) and hence a later application of the verb in the sense of laAHaZa (assumed tropical:) [He regarded, or attended to, the thing, or affair, &c.]. (Msb.)

4 AbXr c
4. AbXr: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] AbXr AlOamoru wajohahu The affair made his countenance beautiful and bright: in the K we read, OaboXara AlOamora HasRanahu wa naDRarahu; but this is a mistake. (TA.) Agreeably with this explanation, AA renders a reading in the Kur [xlii. 22], celika QlRaciI yuboXiru QllRehu EibaAdahu, meaning That is it with which God will make beautiful and bright the face of his servants: so in the L. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2. ― -b4- [Hence,] OaboXarati AlnRaAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel conceived, or became pregnant: (K:) as though she rejoiced [her owner] by announcing her conception. (TA. [See 2, last sentence.]) ― -b5- And OaboXarati AlOaroDu (tropical:) The earth put forth its herbage appearing upon its surface. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter part, in four places.

5 tabaXRara
5: see, latter part.

6 tbAXr Alqawomu c
6. tbAXr Alqawomu The people, or company of men, announced, one to another, a joyful event, or joyful events. (S.) And humo yatabaAXaruwna bicelika AlOamori They rejoice one another by the annunciation of that event. (TA.)

10 AstbXr c
10. AstbXr: see 1, latter part. ＝ -A2- AstbXrhu He demanded of him a reward for an annunciation of joyful tidings. (M.) ― -b2- See also 2.

buXorN c
buXorN: see buXoraI. ― -b2- It is also a contraction of buXurN, which is pl. of baXuwrN (TA) or baXiyrN. (TA in art. nXr.)

biXorN c
biXorN Cheerfulness, or openness and pleasantness,
of countenance: (Mgh, Msb, K, * TA:) and happiness, joy, or gladness. (Har p. 192.) You say, huwa Hasanu AlbiXori He is cheerful, or open and pleasant, in countenance. (S.)

baXarN c
baXarN: see baXarapN ― -b2- [Hence,] AlbaXaru (assumed tropical:) Mankind: (S, Msb, K:) and the human being: (Msb, K:) applied to the male and to the female; and used alike as sing. and pl. (Msb, K, TA) and dual: (TA:) so that you say, huwa baXarN He is a human being, and hiIa baXarN She is a human being, and humo baXarN They (more than two) are human beings, and humaA baXarN They two are human beings: (TA:) but sometimes it has the dual form; (Msb, K;) as in the Kur xxiii. 49; (Msb, TA;) though the Arabs may have used the dual form in the sense of the sing.: (MF:) and sometimes it has a pl., namely, OaboXaArN. (K.) This is a secondary application of the word: (Msb:) i. e., this signification is tropical; or, as some say, the word is so much used in this sense as to be, so used, conventionally regarded as proper; the sense not depending upon its having another word connected with it: but in the S and K, and by the generality of authors, this signification is given as proper. (MF.) Some say that a human being is thus called because his baXarap is bare of hair and of wool. (MF.) [Hence,] Oabuw AlbaXari [The father of mankind; meaning] Adam. (K.)

baXarapN c
baXarapN (Lth, S, M, A, Mgh, Msb) and baXarN↓, (S, K,) or the latter is pl. of the former, (Msb, K,) [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which the former is the n. un.,] like qaSabahu and qaSabN, (Msb,) and OaboXaArN is pl. of baXarN, (K,) [The external skin; the cuticle, or scarf-skin; the epidermis;] the exterior of the skin (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) of a human being; (S, A, K;) and, as some say, of other creatures, (K,) such as the serpent; but this is generally disallowed: (TA:) or baXarapN signifies the exterior of the skin of the head, in which grows the hair; as also OadamapN and XawaApN: (Aboo-Safwán:) or the upper skin (Lth, M) of the head (M) and of the face and body of a human being; (Lth, M;) that upon which the hair grows: (M:) or, as some say, that which is next the flesh. (M.) It is said in a prov., UinRamaA yuEaAtabu AlOadiymu cuw AlbaXarapi: see OadiymN. ― -b2- baXarapN sometimes means The complexion, or hue: and fineness, or delicacy. (TA.) ＝ -A2- baXarapu AlOaroDu (tropical:) The herbage appearing upon the surface of the earth. (S, A, K.) You say, maA OaHosana baXaratahaA (tropical:) How goodly is its herbage appearing upon its surface! (S, A.) And baXarapN [alone] signifies (tropical:) Leguminous plants; herbs, or herbage. (TA.) ― -b2- baXarapN is used also as signifying (assumed tropical:) A man's hand. (Msb.) [See 3, last sentence.]

buXoraI c
buXoraI (imperfectly decl., because it terminates with a fem. alif which is inseparable from it, S) and biXaArapN↓ and buXaArapN↓ [but respecting this last see biXaArapN below] (S, Msb, K) and buXorN↓ (Msb) are substs. from baXRarahu (S, Msb, K) [originally signifying An annunciation which produces a change in the baXarap (or complexion) of the person to whom it is made: and hence, a joyful annunciation; joyful, or glad, tidings; good news]: and tabaAXiyru↓ [q. v. infrà] signifies the same as buXoraI: (S, K:) biXaArapN↓, when used absolutely, relates only to good; (S, Msb;) not to evil unless when expressly restricted thereto by an adjunct: [see 2:] (S:) its pl. is biXaAraAtN and baXaAYiru. (A.)

yaA buXoraAIa c
yaA buXoraAIa, in the Kur [xii. 19, accord. to one reading, (otherwise, as Bd mentions, buXoraAIo, or buXoraIRa, which is a dial. var. of the same, or buXoraI, which, as some say, was the name of a man,) meaning O my joyful annunciation, or joyful tidings, or good news!], is like EaSaAI: and in the dual you say, yaA buXorayaIRa. (S.) You say also, tataAbaEati AlbiXaAraAtu↓ and AlbaXaAYiru [The joyful annunciations followed consecutively]. (A.) See another ex. voce baXiyrN. ― -b2- See also biXaArapN.

baXariIRN c
[baXariIRN Human; of, or belonging to, or relating to, mankind or a human being.]

buXaArN c
buXaArN (assumed tropical:) The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people. (IAar, K.)

baXuwrN c
baXuwrN: see what next follows, in three places.

baXiyrN c
baXiyrN i. q. mubaXRirN↓, (S, Mgh, K,) [and so baXuwrN↓, as will be seen by an ex. in what follows,] One who announces to a people [or person] an event, either good or evil; (TA;) but meaning the former oftener than the latter: (Msb:) [an announcer of a joyful event, or joyful events: one who rejoices another, or others, by an annunciation:] pl. buXaraMCu (A) and buXurN, (TA in art. nXr,) or this is pl. of baXuwrN↓. (TA in the present art.) It is said in the Kur [vii. 55], wa huwa QlRaciI yurosilu QlrRiyaAHa buXurFA, and buXorFA, and buXoraI↓, and baXorFA; [accord. to different readings, meaning (assumed tropical:) And He it is who sendeth the winds announcing coming rain;] in which buXurN is pl. of baXuwrN↓, [syn. with baXiyrN and mubaXRirN, but both masc. and fem.,] (TA,) or of baXiyrN, (Bd,) or of baXiyrapN; (TA in art. nXr;) and buXorFA is a contraction of the same; and buXoraI is syn. with biXaArapN; and baXorFA is the inf. n. of baXarahu in the sense of baXRarahu (TA. [But the reading commonly followed in this passage is nuXurFA, with n: another reading is nuXorFA: another, naXorFA: and another, naXarFA.]) And AlmubaXRiraAtu↓, (A,) or mubaXRiraAtu AlrRiyaAHi, (S,) signifies (tropical:) Winds that announce [coming] rain: (S, A:) so in the Kur xxx. 45. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Goodly; beautiful; elegant in form or features; (S, K;) applied to a man, and to a face: (TA:) fem. with p; (S, K;) applied to a woman, and to a she-camel; (S;) and meaning, when applied to a she-camel, neither emaciated nor fat: or, accord. to Aboo-Hilál, neither of generous nor of ignoble breed: or, as some say, half-fattened: (TA:) pl. of the fem. baXaAYiru: (S:) and maboXuwrapN↓ signifies beautiful in make and colour; (IAar, K;) applied to a girl. (IAar.)

baXaArapN c
baXaArapN Goodliness; beauty; elegance of form or features. (S, K, TA.)

buXaArapN c
buXaArapN What is pared off from the face of a hide: what is pared off from its back is called tiHoliYN. (Lh.) ＝ -A2- See also biXaArapN: ― -b2- and see buXoraI.

biXaArapN c
biXaArapN; pl. biXaAraAtN and baXaAYiru: see buXoraI, in three places; and see also tabaAXiyru. ― -b2- Also A gift to him who announces a joyful event; and so buXaArapN↓: (K, * TA:) or the latter, which is like the EumaAlap of the EaAmil, has this signification; (IAth;) and so buXoraI↓; (M;) and biXaArapN [has the same meaning accord. to common usage, but, properly,] is a subst. in the sense explained above, voce buXoraI. (IAth.) You say, OaEoTayotuhu vawobiI biXaArapF I gave him my garment as a reward for the joyful annunciation. (TA from a trad.)

huwa OaboXaru minohu c
huwa OaboXaru minohu He is more goodly or beautiful, more elegant in form or features, and more fat, than he. (K.)

tubuXRirN c
tubuXRirN, in the hand writing of J tubaXRirN, [and so in my copies of the S,] a word of which there is not the like except in the instances of tunuwRiTN [or tunawRiTN], a certain bird, and waAdiI tuhulRika [or tuhalRika?] and waAdiI tuDulRila [or tuDalRila] and waAdiI tuxuyRiba [or tuxayRiba], (TA,) A certain bird, called the SufaAriyRap: (S, K:) n. un. with p. (K.)

tabaAXiyru c
tabaAXiyru, as though it were pl. of taboXiyrN, inf. n. of baXRara; (A;) a word which has not its like except in the instances of taEaAXiybu and taEaAjiybu and tafaATiyru [and tabaAkiyru and tabaAriyHu, and probably a few others]; (TA;) (tropical:) [Annunciations; foretokens; foretellers; foreshowers; prognostics; earnests; of what is good:] the beginnings of anything: (S, K:) the first of blossoms &c.: (TA:) the beginnings, (S, K,) or first annunciations, (A,) of daybreak; (S, A, K;) as also baXaAYiru↓: (TA:) it has no verb: (S:) and [is said to have] no sing.: but in a trad. of El-Hajjáj, taboXiyrN occurs as meaning (assumed tropical:) the commencement of rain. (TA.) One says, fiyhi maxaAyilu AlrRuXodi wa tabaAXiyruhu (tropical:) [In him are indications of right conduct, or belief, and its earnests]. (A.) See also buXoraI. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Streaks of the light of daybreak in the night. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Streaks that are seen upon the surface of the ground, caused by the winds. (Lth, K. *) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The colours of palm-trees when their fruit begins to ripen; (K;) as also tabaAkiyru. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Such as bear fruit early, or before others, of palm-trees. (K.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Marks of galls upon the side of a beast. (K.)

rajulN muWodamN muboXarN c

(TA.) ― -b6- Also, (K,) or baXiEu Alwajohi, (ISh, Msb,) (tropical:) Having a frowning, a contracted, a stern, an austere, or a morose, countenance. , inf. n. baXamN, He (a man, S, TA, or an animal, Msb) suffered, or became affected with, indigestion, (S, Msb, K,) in consequence of much eating: (Msb:) or he was heavy in consequence of food: (Ham p. 363:) or he became distressed, or oppressed, by eating much food. , (S, K,) or baSobaSa bicanabihi, (M,) inf. n. baSobaSapN, (TA,) He (a dog, S, M, K, and a beast of prey, and a gazelle, and a camel when urged on by the driver's singing, TA) wagged, or moved about, his tail; (S, K;) which a dog does by reason of cupidity, or fear; (TA;) as also tabaSobaSa↓: (S:) or he (a dog) struck with his tail. 4. AbSrhu, (Lh S M, A, &c.,) inf. n. UiboSaArN, (Msb,) He saw him, or it, (Lh, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) biruWoyapi AlEayoni by the sight of the eye; (Msb;) as also bihi baSura↓: (A:) or he looked (M, K) at, or towards, him, or it, (M,) trying whether he could see him, or it; (M, K;) as also bihi baSura↓, inf. n.baSarN and baSaArapN and biSaArapN; (M;) and bh baSira↓; (Lh, M;) and tbRSrhu↓; (M, K;) and bASrhu↓: (M:) or, accord. to Sb, baSura↓ [is used when no object of sight is mentioned, and] signifies he [saw, or] became seeing: and AbSrhu is said when one mentions that upon which his eye has fallen. baSorN: see baSorapN, in four places: and see buSorapN.

man, (TA,) and of a garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) You say vawobN jayRidu AlbuSori A thick garment or piece of cloth. (M.) SuborN, formed by transposition, signifies the same. (S in art. EayonN; but of the masc. gender: (TA:) pl. as above: (Kur ii. 6, &c.:) but the sing. is also used in a pl. sense [like samoEN]. (TA in art. smE.) See two exs. voce baSiyrpN.

baSorapN Soft stones; (AA, M, Msb;) i. q. kacRaAnu; (AA, M;) as also biSorN↓ (M, Msb) and baSorN↓; or, accord. to Zj, this last is not allowable: (Msb:) or soft stones in which is whiteness: (K:) or in which is some whiteness: (TA:) or soft stones inclining to white; as also biSorN↓, with kesr if without p: (S:) [i. e. whitish soft stones:] or soft white stone; as also biSorN↓ (M) and baSorN↓: (TA:) or glistening stones; as also biSorN↓: (Fr:) pl. biSaArN: (M:) and rugged ground: (K:) or stones of rugged ground; (TA;) as also biSorN↓ and baSorN↓ and buSorN↓: (Kz, TA:) or these three words, without p, signify thick, or rough, or rugged, stone: (K:) or the same three, hard, or strong, and thick, or rough, or rugged, stone: (Lh, M:) and baSorapN signifies, also, land that is as though it were a mountain of gypsum: (ISh, L:) or land of which the stones are gypsum; (M, TA;) as also baSarapN↓ and baSirapN↓; (so in a copy of the M, but accord. to the TA buSorapN↓ and biSorapN↓;) but the last is app. an epithet: (M: [see baSirapN, below; and buSorapN:]) also tough clay in which is gypsum; (TA;) and baSirapN↓ signifies tough clay: (M, TA:) or baSorapN, (M,) or baSorN↓, (TA,) tough and good clay, containing pebbles. (Lh, M, TA.)

buSorapN Srp bSr bSrh bSrp
buSorapN [in the TA, as on the authority of ISd, baSorapN↓,] Good red land. (M, K.) See also baSorapN.

biSorapN Srp bSr bSrh bSrp
biSorapN: see baSorapN.

baSarapN Srp bSr bSrh bSrp
baSarapN: see baSorapN.

OaroDN baSirapN c
OaroDN baSirapN Land in which are stones that cut the hoofs of beasts. (TA.) See also baSorapN, in two places.

baSiyrN bSyr
baSiyrN Seeing; i. q. muboSirN↓; (M, K;) contr. of DariyrN: (S:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufoEilN, (M,) or of the measure faAEilN [i. e. baASirN↓]: (TA:) pl. buSaraMCu. (M, K.) One says, UinRahu labaSiyrN biAlEayonayoni Verily he is one who sees with the two eyes. (Lh, M.) [Hence,] AlbaSiyru, as a name of God, The All-seeing; He who sees all things, both what are apparent thereof and what are occult, without any organ [of vision]. (TA.) And The dog; (M;) as also Oabuw baSiyrK: (Msb:) because it is one of the most sharp-sighted of animals. (M.) ― -b2- Endowed with mental perception; (B;) knowing; skilful; possessing understanding, intelligence, or skill: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) pl. as above. (A.) One says, OanaA baSiyrN bihi I am knowing in it, or respecting it. (Msb.) And UinRahu labaSiyrN biAlOaXoyaMCi Verily he is knowing, or skilful, in things. (Lh, M.) And rajulN baSiyrN biAlEilomi A man knowing, or skilful, in science. (M.) And huwa mina AlbuSaraMCi biAlitRjaArapi He is of those who are knowing, or skilful, in commerce. (A.) ― -b3- It is also an epithet applied to A blind man; (A'Obeyd, M, B;) and so Oabuw baSiyrK: (TA in art. Ewr:) so applied as meaning endowed with mental perception; (B;) or as meaning a believer; (A'Obeyd, M;) or as an epithet of good omen: (M:) and Oabuw baSiyrK is used as meaning AlOaEoXaI [the weaksighted, &c.,] for this last reason. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also baSiyrapN.

baSiyrapN bSyr bSyrh bSyrp
baSiyrapN Mental perception; the perceptive faculty of the mind; as also baSarN↓: (B:) knowledge; (Msb;) as also baSarN↓ (S, Msb) and AisotiboSaArN: (Msb:) understanding; intelligence; skill: (M, K:) AlbaSiyrapu signifies AlAi sotiboSaAru fiI AlXRaIoCi [which implies all the meanings above: see 10]: (S:) and Alqalobi baSaru↓ [in like manner] signifies mental perception or vision or view; idea, or opinion, occurring to the mind: (M, K:) the pl. of baSiyrapN is baSaAYru; (M, B;) and the pl. of baSarN↓, as syn. therewith, OaboSaArN. (B.) [Sometimes it is opposed to baSarN, as in the first and second of the following exs.] Oahuwnu mino EimaI AlbaSaAYiri EamaI AlOaboSaAri↓ [Blindness of the eyes is a lighter thing than blindness of the perceptive faculties of the mind]. (A.) When Mo'áwiyeh said to Ibn-'Abbás, yaAbaniI haAXimK tuSaAbuwna fiI OaboSaArikumo↓ [O sons of Háshim, ye are afflicted in your eyes], the latter replied, waOanotumo yaA baniI OumayRapa tuSaAbuwna fiI baSaAYirikumo [And ye, O sons of Umeiyeh, are afflicted in your perceptive faculties of the mind]. (M.) And the Arabs say, OaEomaI QllRehu baSaAYirapu May God blind his faculties of understanding! And one says, lahu firaAsapN caAtu baSiyrapK, and baSaAYira, (tropical:) He possesses true intuitive perception. (A.) And raOayotu Ealayoka caAta AlbaSaAYiri (tropical:) [I saw impressed upon thee the signs of perceptive faculties of the mind]. (A.) ― -b2- Also Belief, or firm belief, of the heart, or mind. (M, K.) And EalaI baSiyrapK According to, or agreeably with, knowledge and assurance: (TA:) and purposely; intentionally. (M, TA.) And EalaI gayori baSiyrapK Without certainty. (M, TA.) ― -b3- Constancy, or firmness, in religion. (TA.) ― -b4- An evidence, a testimony, a proof, an argument, or the like; as also maboSarapN↓ (S, K) and maboSarN↓. (K.) ― -b5- [And hence,] Blood, (M,) or somewhat thereof, (As, S, K,) by which one is directed to an animal that has been shot, or to the knowledge thereof: (As, AA, S, M, K:) or blood upon the ground; (AZ, S;) what sticks upon the ground, not upon the body: (M:) what adheres to the body is termed jadiyRapN: (AZ, S:) or a portion of blood of the size of a dirhem: (TA:) or what is of a round form, like a shield: or what is of an oblong form: or what is of the size of the firosin [or foot] of the camel: in all these explanations, blood being meant: or blood not flowing: or what flows thereof at one single time: (M:) or a portion of blood that glistens: (B:) and (as some say, M) the blood of a virgin: (M, K:) and blood-revenge: and a fine for homicide: (TA:) pl. baSaAYiru, as above: (S, M:) and baSiyrN↓, which occurs in a verse cited by AHn, may also be a pl. of baSiyrapN, applied to blood, [or rather a coll. gen. n., of which bSyrp is the n. un.,] like as XaEiyrN is of XaEiyrapN; or it may be for bSyrp, the p being elided by poetic license; or it may be a dial. var. of bSyrp, like as one says bayaADN and bayaADapN. (M.) ElAs'ar El-Joafee says,
raAHwA baSaAYiruhumo EalaI OakotaAfihimo
wabaSiyratiI yaEoduw bihaA EatadN waOaI
[They went with their blood upon their shoulderblades; but my blood, a ready and swift and strong horse runs with it]; meaning, they neglected the blood of their father, and left it behind them; i. e., they did not take revenge for it; but I have sought my blood-revenge: (S, M: *) but see another explanation in what follows. (S. [See also Ham p. 59.]) ― -b6- (tropical:) A witness: (Lh, S, * M, Mgh, K:) an observer and a witness. (A.)

bali AlUinosaAnu EalaI nafosihi baSiyrapN bl AlAnsAn Ely nfsh bSyrh bl AlAnsAn Ely nfsh bSyrp
bali AlUinosaAnu EalaI nafosihi baSiyrapN, in the Kur [lxxv. 14], means (tropical:) Nay, the man shall be witness against himself: (S, Mgh:) or it means that his arms, or hands, and his legs, or feet, and his tongue, shall be witnesses against him on the day of resurrection: (M:) Akh says that it is like the saying to a man, Oanota HujRapN EalaI nafosika: (S:) the p is added because the members are meant thereby; (B;) or to give intensiveness to the signification, (Mgh, B,) as in EalRaAmapN and raAwiyapN; (B;) or because the meaning is EayonN baSiyrapN. (Mgh.) You say also, AijoEaloniI baSiyrapF Ealayohimo (tropical:) Make thou me an observer of them and a witness against them. (Lh, * M, * A.) ― -b2- An example by which one is admonished: (K:) pl. baSaAYiru; which is said to be used agreeably with this interpretation
in the Kur xxviii. 43. (TA.) You say, OamaA laka baSiyrapN fiyhi (tropical:) Hast thou not an example whereby thou shouldst be admonished in him? (TA.) ＝ -A2- A shield: (AO, S, M, K:) or a glistening shield: or an oblong shield: (TA:) and a coat of mail: (AO, S, M, K:) and any defensive armour: (M, TA:) and baSaAYiru AlsRilaAHi any arms that are worn: and biSaArN, as well as baSaAYiru, is a pl. thereof. (TA.) Accord. to AO, the verse of El-Joafee cited above commences thus:
HamaluwA baSaAYirahumo EalaI OakotaAfihimo
and the meaning is, [They bore] their shields [upon their shoulder-blades]; or their coats of mail. (S.) ＝ -A3- An oblong piece of cloth (K, TA) of cotton or other material. (TA.) [See buSorN.] Such is hung upon the door of a dwelling. (TA.) And you say, raOayotu Ealayohi baSiyrapF, i. e. XuqRapF mulafRaqapF [app. meaning I saw upon him a garment composed of two oblong pieces of cloth joined and sewed together]. (TA.) ― -b2- What is between the two oblong pieces of cloth [i. e. between any two of such pieces] of a bayot [or tent]; (S, K;) and what is between the two pieces of a mazaAdap and the like; what is sewed, thereof, in the manner termed baSorN [inf. n. of baSara: see 1, last sentence]: (B:) pl. baSaAYiru: (S:) and baASirN↓ signifies [in like manner] what is joined and sewed together (mulafRaq) between two oblong pieces of cloth or two pieces of rag. (TA.)

baASirN USr bASr bUSr
baASirN: see baSiyrN. ― -b2- lamoHN baASirN (tropical:) An intent, or a hard, glance: (M, K:) or a very intent or hard glance. (S.) You say, Oarayotuhu lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) I showed him a very intent or hard glance: (S, M: *) bASrA being here used for the augmented epithet [muboSirFA]; (M;) or it is a possessive epithet, (Yaakoob, M,) like laAbinN and taAmirN, meaning cuw baSarK, from OaboSarotu, like mawotN maAYitN from OamatRu; and it means I showed him a severe thing. (S.) And laqiIa minohu lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) He experienced from him a manifest, or an evident, thing. (M. [See also art. lmH.]) And raOaI fulaAnN lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) Such a one beheld a terrible thing. (Lth, TA.) And OaraAniI AlzRamaAnu lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) Fortune showed me a terrifying thing. (A.) ― -b3- It is said in a prov., xayoru AlgadaMCi bawaAkiruhu waxayoru AlEaXaMCi bawaASiruhu, [the word bawaASiru being pl. of baASirapN↓,] meaning [The best kinds of morning-meal are those thereof that are early; and the best kinds of evening-meal are those thereof] in which the food is seen, before the invasion of night. (Meyd. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 442.) ― -b4- baASirapN [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates]: see baSarN. ＝ -A2- See also baSayrapN, last sentence.

baASirapN USr bASrh bASrp bUSrh bMSrp MSrp
baASirapN: see baSarN: and see baASirN.

baASuwrN bASwr
baASuwrN: see baAsuwrN.

binoSirN bnSr nSr
binoSirN: see art. bnSr.

OaboSaru c
OaboSaru [More, and most, sharp-sighted or clearsighted: see an ex. voce HayRapN].

maboSarN mbSr
maboSarN: see baSayrpN.

muboSarN mbSr
muboSarN and its fem. muboSarapN: see the next paragraph, in three places.

muboSirN mbSr
muboSirN: see baSiyrN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) A watcher, or guard, set in a garden. (A.) ― -b3- And AlmuboSiru (assumed tropical:) The lion, which sees his prey from afar, and pursues it. (K.) ＝ -A2- [Making, or causing, to see, or to have sight: and hence, giving light; shining; illumining: and conspicuous; manifest; evident; apparent: also making, or causing, to have mental perception, or knowledge, or skill.] waAlnRahaAra muboSirFA, in the Kur [x. 68, &c. (in the CK wAlnRhAru muboSarFA↓)], means, And the day [causing to see; or] in which one sees; (K;) giving light; shining; or illumining. (TA.) And falamRaA jaMCatohumo MyaAtunaA muboSirapF, also in the Kur [xxvii. 13], (assumed tropical:) And when our signs came to them, making them to have sight, or to have mental perception, or knowledge, or skill; expl. by tajoEaluhumo buSaraMCa: (Akh, S, K:) or giving light; shining; or illumining: (S:) or being conspicuous, manifest, or evident: or we may read muboSarapF↓, meaning having become manifest, or evident. (Zj, M.) And MtayonaA vamuwda AlnRaAqapa muboSirapF, also in the Kur [xvii. 61], (assumed tropical:) And we gave to Thamood the she-camel, by means of which they had sight, or mental perception, or knowledge, or skill: (Akh:) or a sign giving light, shining, or illumining; (Fr, T;) and this is the right explanation: (T:) or a manifest, or an evident, sign: (Zj, L, K:) and some read muboSarapF↓, meaning having become manifest, so as to be seen. (Zj, L.) And jaEalonaA Myapa AlnRahaAri muboSirapF, also in the Kur [xvii. 13], (tropical:) We have made the sign of the day manifest, or apparent. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- One who hangs upon his door a baSiyrap, i. e. an oblong piece of cloth (K, TA) of cotton or other material. (TA.)

maboSarapN mbSrh mbSrp
maboSarapN: see baSiyrapN.

musotaboSirN mstbSr
musotaboSirN One who seeks, or endeavours, to see a thing plainly or clearly [either with the eyes or with the mind]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b2- wakaAnuwA musotaboSiriyna, in the Kur [xxix. 37], means, And they were endowed with perceptive faculties of the mind, or of knowledge, or of skill: (Jel:) or they clearly perceived, when they did what they did, that the result thereof would be their punishment. (M.) And you say, huwa musotaboSirN fiI diynihi waEamalihi He is endowed with mental perception, or knowledge, or understanding, intelligence, or skill, in his religion and his actions. (TA.)

1 baSoTN bST
1. baSoTN, [inf. n. of baSaTa,] i. q. basoTN, in all its meanings: (K:) the s, with T, is changed into S because of the nearness of the places of utterance. (L.)

1 baSaEa bSE
1. baSaEa, aor.
baSaEa
, (K,) inf. n. baSoEN, (S,) He collected: (K:) [J says,] I have heard from certain of the grammarians that AlbaSoEu is syn. with AljamoEu, but I know not what is the truth of the matter. (S.) Hence what here follows. (TA.)

OaboSaEu c
OaboSaEu is a word used as a corroborative, and is pronounced by some with the pointed D, but this is not of high authority: you say, Oaxacotu HaqRiI OajomaEa OaboSaEa [I took my right, or due, altogether]: and [the pl. is OaboSaEuwna:] you say, jaMCa Alqawomu OajomaEuwna OaboSaEuwna [The people, or company of men, came all together]: and the fem. is baSoEaMCu: you say, jamoEaMCa baSoEaMCa: and [the pl. of baSoEaMCu is buSaEu: you say,] raOayotu AlnRisowapa jumaEa buSaEa [I saw the women all together]: it is a corroborative occurring in a particular order, never before AjmE. (S.) [See OabotaEu.]

1 baSaqa bSq
1. baSaqa, (Lth, JK, S, K,) [aor.
baSuqa
,] inf. n. baSoqN, (S,) i. q. bazaqa (Lth, S, * K) or basaqa (JK) [He spat]: it is the most chaste of these three verbs. (TA in art. bsq.) baSaqa fiI wajohihi [lit. He spat in his face,] means (assumed tropical:) he held him in contempt, or despised him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He milked a ewe when she was with young. (K.)

4 AbSqt AbSqt
4. AbSqt She (a ewe) excerned the milk [or biestings into her udder before bringing forth]; (JK, K;) like Absqt [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- AbSq is also said of the qaSad, or small juicy branches, in the [species of mimosa termed] EurofuT [app. as meaning They excerned a matter like spittle]. (TA.)

baSoqapN bSq bSqh bSqp
baSoqapN A [stony tract such as is termed] HarRap somewhat elevated; [as also basoqapN:] pl. biSaAqN. (AA, K.)

buSaAqN bSAq
buSaAqN Spittle, or saliva, that has gone forth from the mouth: as long as it is in the mouth, it is termed riyqN: (K:) [or saliva that flows: see buzaAqN:] i. q. buzaAqN (S, K) and busaAqN: (K:) but it is more chaste than either of these. (TA.) [buSaAqapN is app. its n. un. And hence,] ― -b2- buSaAqapu Alqamari White glistening stone: (S:) or stone of a clear white colour. (JK, K.) [Also written with s.] ＝ -A2- A species of palm-tree. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- The best of camels: both sing. and pl. (IDrd, K.)

baSuwqN bSwq
baSuwqN A ewe having the least quantity of milk. (K, TA.)

2 taboSiylN tbSyl
2. taboSiylN The act of stripping, or divesting; [like as when one strips an onion (baSalap) of its coats;] (K;) as also tabaSRulN↓. (Fr, K.) You say, baSRalotu AlrRajula Eino viyaAbihi [and tabaSRalotuhu↓] I stripped the man of his clothes. (TA.)

5 tbSRl tbSl
5. tbSRl It (a thing) was, or became, several fold, or many fold, like the coats of the baSal [or onion]. (Z, TA.) See also mutabRSRilN. ＝ -A2- It is also trans.: see 2, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] tabaSRaluwhu (assumed tropical:) They begged of him so much that all that he had became exhausted. (Sgh, K.)

baSalN bSl
baSalN [The onion; allium cepa: or onions, collectively:] what it signifies is well known: n. un. with p. (S, M, Msb, K.) Hence the prov., OakosaI mina AlbaSali [Having more coats, or coverings,
than the onion]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also Any kind of bulb, or bulbous plant.] baSalu AlzRaEofaraAni [The bulb of the saffron], which is buried in the ground, is like the baSal [or onion] commonly known. (Mgh.) baSal AlfaOori is the same as AlUisoqiylu and AlUisoqaAlu and AlEunoSalu, (K in art. sql,) also written AlEunoSulu, (K in art. ESl,) or baSalu AlEnSl, (KL voce zyzN, [and so as written by Golius,]) [Scilla, or squill; particularly scilla maritima, or officinal squill; called by all these names, except, perhaps, AlsqAl, in the present day;] also called ziyzN, and AlbaSalu AlbarRiIRu [the wild onion; but from what follows, it seems that there is a confusion here]. (KL ubi suprà.) baSalu AlcRiYobi, and bSl Alzyr, (Golius on the authority of Zeyn El-Attár,) or bSl Alrnd, (so in the TA in art. blbs,) i. q. blbws Bulbus esculentus, (Golius, from Zeyn El-Attár,) or Albalobuws, with fet-h, [thus generally written, though it would seem to be correctly bulobuws,] the leaves of which resemble those of the sacaAb [or rue]: (TA in art. blbs:) the balobuws is the wild onion (in Pers. PiyaAzo SaHoraAYiI). (KL voce blbws. [This last assertion suggests that Alzyr and Alrnd may be mistranscriptions for AlzRiyz; the zyz mentioned before.]) [baSalu AlqIoCa Bulbus vomitorius; mentioned by Golius; and by Dioscorides, (l. ii. c. 201,) as being emetic and diuretic.] ― -b3- Also, (K,) or baSalapN, (M,) (tropical:) A helmet (M, K) of iron, (K,) pointed in the middle; so called as being likened to what is first mentioned above. (M.) Lebeed likens helmets to baSal. (S.)

mutabaSRilN mtbSl
mutabaSRilN (ISh, K) and cuw tabaSRulK↓ (ISh, TA) A covering of any kind (qiXorN) consisting of many coats; thick; (ISh, K;) like the coats of the baSal [or onion]. (ISh, TA.)

buSomN OSm bSm
buSomN The space that is between the extremity of the little finger and that of the third finger [when they are extended apart]: (S, M, * K:) mentioned on the authority of AO, (S,) or on that of Aboo-Málik alone. (M.) The Eatab is the space between the third finger and the middle finger; the ratab, that between the middle finger and the first finger; [but see these two words;] the fitor, that between the first finger and the thumb; the Xibor, that between the thumb and the little finger; and the fawot, that between every two fingers, in length. (S.) ― -b2- cuw buSomK Thick, or coarse; applied to a man, (M, K,) or a garment, or piece of cloth: (K:) or you say vawobN lahu buSomN, meaning a garment, or piece of cloth, that is dense, or compact; close in texture. (M.)

buSaAnN bSAn
buSaAnN, (M, K,) so accord. to Ktr, (M,) and buSRaAnN, (K,) thus in some of the copies of the Jm of IDrd, (TA,) a name of The month rabiyEN AlOxiru, (M, K,) in the Time of Ignorance: (M:) pl. [of pauc.] OaboSinapN (M, K) and [of mult.] biSonaAnN; (M, TA;) the latter erroneously written in the copies of the K buSaAnaAtN: (TA:) so says Ktr; but other lexicologists hold that it is wabuSaAnN, like sabuEaAn, and wabiSaAnN, like XaqiraAn; and this is the correct opinion: Aboo-Is-hák says that it was so named because of the wabiyS, i. e. gleaming, of the weapons therein: (M:) but it is said in art. wbS of the K to be waboSaAn and wuboSaAn: and Sgh holds buSRaAnN to be correct because baSRa and wabaSa signify the same. (TA.)

1 baDaDota bD bDDt
1. baDaDota, and baDiDota, (S, TA,) and baDuDota also, (accord. to one copy of the S,) [third pers., accord. to rule, baDRa, (accord. to Golius and Freytag baDaDa or baDiDa, but these are irregular forms, and not admissible without authority,) aor., accord. to rule, of the first yabiDRu, and of the second yabaDRu, and of the third yabuDRu,] inf. n. baDaADapN and buDawDapN, (S, TA,) Thou (O man) wast, or becamest, such as is termed baDRN; i. e. thin-shinned and plump; &c.: (S:) or very white or fair, with fatness: or delicate and clear in complexion, and such that the least thing made a mark, or an impression, upon thee. (TA.) ＝ -A2- baDRa AlmaMCu, aor.

yabiDRu bAD bD ybD
yabiDRu, inf. n. baDiyDN (S, K) and buDuwDN and baDRN, (K,) The water flowed by little and little: (S, K:) or exuded upon a rock or the ground. (TA.) And baDRati AlrRakiyRapu, and baDRato bimaAYihaA, The well had, or yielded, little water; or its water became little. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting Tabook, waAlEayonu tabiDRu biXaIoCK mina AlmaMCi [The source, or spring, yielding scantily somewhat of water]. (TA.) And you say, baDRati AlEayonu, aor. as above, inf. n. baDRN and baDiyDN, The eye shed tears. (TA.) And, of a man when you characterise him as patient under affliction, maA tabiDRu Eayonuhu [His eye does not shed tears]. (TA.) And baDRati AlHalamapu The nipple streamed with milk. (TA.) It is said in a trad., maA tabiDRu bibalaAlK Having no milk dropping from it, or her. (TA.) And in another trad., saqaTa mina Alfarasi faUicaA huwa jaAlisN waEuroDu wajohihi yabiDRu maMCF OaSofara [He fell from the horse, and lo, he was sitting, with the side of his face exuding yellow water]. (TA.) One should not say, baDRa AlsRiqaMCu, nor Alqirobapu: but some say so, urging the authority of Ru-beh. (S.) And you say of a stone, and the like, baDRa, aor. as above, meaning Water flowed from it like sweat; water oozed from it. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence the saying, maA yabiDRu Hajaruhu (assumed tropical:) No good is obtained from him; (TA;) i. q. maA tanodaI SafaAtuhu: (S:) a prov. applied to the niggardly. (S, K.) [Hence also,] baDRa lahu, [aor., accord. to the TA, yabuDRu, but this is evidently a mistake,] (assumed tropical:) He gave him a little; as also lh AbDR↓, (Sh, K,) inf. n. UiboDaADN: (TA:) and baDRa lahu biXaIoCK (assumed tropical:) He did him a small benefit; as also naDRa. (As.)

4 AbDR lahu AbD lh AbD lp

10 AisotiboDaAEN AstbDAE
10. AisotiboDaAEN denotes a kind of matrimonial connection practised by people in the Time of Ignorance; i. e., A woman's desiring sexual intercourse with a man only to obtain offspring by him: a man of them used to say to his female slave or his wife, OarosiliI UilaI fulaAn faMsotaboDiEiI minohu [Send thou to such a one, and demand of him sexual intercourse to obtain offspring]; and he used to separate himself from her, and not touch her, until her pregnancy by that man became apparent: and this he did from a desire of obtaining generous offspring. (IAth, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in two places.

biDoEN bDE
biDoEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and baDoEN↓, (S, Msb, K,) some of the Arabs pronouncing it with kesr, (S, Msb,) [A number under ten; and an odd number, meaning] a number between two round, or decimal, numbers; (AZ, K;) from one to ten [exclusive of the latter]; and from eleven to twenty [exclusive of the latter]; so accord. to Mebremán; (K;) i. e. Mohammad Ibn-'Alee Ibn-Ismá'eel the Lexicologist, Mebremán being his surname: (TA:) or from three to nine; (S, Msb, K [in the first and last the ns. being in the fem. gender; but in the second, masc.];) so accord. to Katádeh; (Mgh;) from three to less than ten: (Fr [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or not less than three nor more than ten; (Sh [the first n. of number in the fem. gender, and the second masc.];) from three to ten: (Mgh [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or to seven: (Mujáhid, Mgh:) or to five: (AO, K [the n. of number in the fem. gender]:) or from one to four: (AO, O, K [the ns. of number in the masc. gender]:) or to five; an explanation ascribed to AO: (TA:) or from four to nine; (ISd, K [the ns. of number fem.];) and this is the signification preferred by Th: (TA:) or it signifies five: (Mukátil [this n. of number masc.]:) or seven; (Mukátil, K [in the K this n. of number being fem.];) so accord. to some: (AO:) or ten: (Ed-Dahhák [this n. of number masc.]:) or an undefined number; gayoru maHoduwdK; so says Sgh; [and the like is said in the Msb;] in the K, erroneously, gayoru maEoduwdK; (TA;) because it means a portion, (Sgh, K,) which is undefined: (Sgh, TA:) it also signifies, with ten, [in like manner; i. e. ten and a number under ten; or the like: as] from thirteen to nineteen. (Msb.) When used as signifying from three to nine, (Mgh, Msb,) or to ten, or to seven, (Mgh,) [or to signify some number under ten, without another n. of number,] it is masc. and fem. without variation: (Mgh, Msb:) you say biDoEu rijaAlK From three to nine [&c.] men: and biDoEu nisowapK from three to nine [&c.] women: (Msb:) and biDoEu siniyna from three to nine [&c.] years: (S:) and fiI biDoEi siniyna [in from three to nine, &c., years]: (Kur xxx. 3:) and falabiva fiI AlsRijoni biDoEa siniyna [And he remained in the prison from three to nine, &c., years]. (Kur xii. 42.) But when used to denote a number above ten, (Mgh, Msb,) with a masc. n. it is with p, (biDoEap↓,) and with a fem. n. it is without p: (ISk, Mgh, Msb, K:) you say biDoEapa EaXara rajulFA From thirteen to nineteen [&c.] men: and biDoEa EaXorapa QmoraOapF from thirteen to nineteen [&c.] women: (S, Mgh, * TA:) like as you say valaAvapa EaXara rajulFA and valaAva EaXorpa QmoraOapF. (Mgh.) When you have passed the word denoting ten, (S, K,) [i. e.] to denote a number above twenty, (Msb,) it is not used: (S, Msb, K:) you do not say biDoEN waEiXoruwna, (S, K,) but nayRifN waEiXoruwna; and so in the cases of the remaining numbers: (S:) or you do say biDoEN waEiXoruwna: (Sgh, K:) accord. to AZ, (Msb,) you say biDoEapN waEiXoruwna rajulFA (Mgh, Msb, K) meaning Twenty and odd men: (AZ, TA:) and biDoEN waEiXoruwna QmoraOapF (Mgh, Msb, K) meaning twenty and odd women: (AZ, TA:) but not the reverse: (K:) ISd says, we have not heard this, but there is no objection to it: (TA:) and Fr says, biDoEN is not mentioned save with ten and twenty to ninety; (IB, K;) not with what exceeds this: (IB:) you do not say biDoEN wamiAYapN nor biDoEN waOalofN, (IB, K,) but miAYapN wanayRifN [and OalofN wanayRifN]: (IB:) it occurs in trads. with EiXoruwna and with valaAvuwna. (TA.) ― -b2- biDoEN and baDoEN↓ also signify A part, or portion, of the night: (K:) a time thereof. (Lh.) You say, maDaI biDoEN mina AllRayoli [A part, or portion, of the night passed]. (TA.) J mentions it with S [in the place of D]; and explains it by jawoXN, q. v. (TA.)

1. baTira, aor.
baTara
, inf. n. baTarN, He exulted; or exulted greatly, or excessively; and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: or he exulted by reason of wealth, and behaved with pride and self-conceitedness, and boastfulness, and want of thankfulness: or he behaved with the utmost exultation, &c.: or he rejoiced, and rested his mind upon things agreeable with natural desire: syn. of the inf. n. OaXarN, (S, A, L, Msb, TA,) and maraHN; (L, TA;) the former of which signifies XidRapN AlmaraHi, (S, A,) and mujaAwazapu AlHadRi fiI maraHK: (A:) he was, or became, stupified, deprived of his reason, confounded, or amazed, (S, K, Er-Rághib,) bearing wealth ill, or in an evil manner, performing little of the duty imposed on him by it, and turning it to a wrong purpose: (Er-Rághib, TA, * TK:) this is said to be the primary signification: (TA:) he was, or became, stupified, or confounded, and knew not what to prefer nor what to postpone: (TA:) he was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed, by reason of fright: (As, S voce baHira:) he behaved exorbitantly, or insolently, with wealth, (K, TA,) or on the occasion of having wealth: and this, also, is said to be the primary signification: (TA:) he had, or exercised, little of the quality of bearing wealth [in a becoming, or proper, manner]: (K:) he behaved proudly: (TA:) he regarded a thing with hatred, or dislike, without its deserving to be so regarded: he was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly: (K:) accord. to some, he walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yanoZuru QllRehu yawoma AlqiyaAmapi mano jarRa UizaArahu baTarFA [God will not look, on the day of resurrection, upon him who drags along his wrapper of the lower part of the body in exultation and insolence, or pride: meaning one who wears too long a wrapper of the lower part of the body]. (TA.) ― -b2- baTirota EayoXaka (tropical:) [Thou exultedst, or exultedst greatly, or excessively, and behavedst insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully, &c., in thy manner of life,] is a phrase similar to raXidota Oamoraka; (S, TA;) and in like manner baTirato maEiyXatahaA, in the Kur [xxviii. 58]; in which the verb is not trans., but the subst. is put in the accus. case because of fiI understood before it. (Aboo-Is-hák.) ― -b3- laA OaboTaru AlginaI (assumed tropical:) I do not, or will not, domineer, or assume superiority, over others when I am rich. (Ham p. 517.) ― -b4- baTira AlnRiEomapa (tropical:) He held wealth, or the favour, or benefit, in light estimation, and was unthankful, or ungrateful, for it. (A.) ― -b5- baTira hidaAyapa Oamorihi (assumed tropical:) He refused the right direction as to the management of his affair, and was ignorant of it. (TA.) ― -b6- It is said in a trad., that pride is baTaru AlHaqRi, which means (tropical:) The considering as false, or vain, what God has pronounced to be the truth, or our duty; namely, the confession of his unity, and the obligation of rendering Him religious service: or the being confounded at considering truth, or duty, and not seeing it to be true, or incumbent: (TA:) or the disdaining the truth, or right, and not accepting it or not admitting it. (K.) ＝ -A2- baTarahu, aor.

[maboTiXN, or maboTaXN, A place of assault, or the like; sing. of mabaATiXu, of which the following is an ex.] salakuwA OaroDFA baEiydapa AlmasaAliki qariybapa AlmahaAliki wawuqicuwA bimabaATiXihaA wamaA OunoqicuwA mino maEaATiXihaA (tropical:) [They traversed a land whereof the roads were farextending, whereof the places of destruction were near, and they were prostrated, or left sick, in its places of assault, and were not saved from its places of thirst]. (A, TA.)

biTaAqapN TAq TAqp bTAqh bTAqp
biTaAqapN A piece of paper: (IAar, M, Sgh, TA:) in the K, AlHadaqapu is erroneously put for Alwaraqapu: (TA:) a ticket that is attached to a garment, or piece of cloth, (T, S, M, L, K,) bearing the mark, or inscription, of its price; (T, S, L, K;) or a ticket marked, or inscribed, with the weight, and the number, of a thing: (TA:) of the dial. of Egypt (T, S, L) and the neighbouring parts: (T, L:) so called, (K,) or said (by Sh, TA) to be so called, (S,) because it is tied by a twist, or thread, (biTaAqapF,) of the unwoven end of the cloth: (S, K:) but this is a mistake: (ISd, TA:) [in Greek, πιττάκιον, as observed by Freytag; and hence probably derived:] accord. to some, it is [niTaAqapF,] with n, because it tells (tanoTiqu) what is marked, or inscribed, thereon; but this is strange. (TA.) It is said in a trad., that a man will be brought on the day of resurrection, and ninety-nine scrolls, or records, inscribed with his sins will be produced; and there will be produced for him a bTAqp bearing the testimony that there is no deity but God, and it will outweigh the others. (TA.)

1 baTala Tl bTl
1. baTala, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
baTula
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. buTolN and buTuwlN and buTolaAnN, [of which the last seems to be the most common,] (S, Msb, K, KL, &c.,) It (a thing) was, or became, baATil, as meaning contr. of HaqR; (S;) [i. e.,] it was, or became, false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, (KL,) vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (KL, PS,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no account; (Msb;) it went for nothing, as a thing of no account, (S, Msb, K,) or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (K.) [It is said of an assertion or allegation and the like, and of a deed, &c.] Hence the saying in the Kur [vii. 115], wa baTala maA kaAnuwA yaEomaluwna [And what they were doing became vain, or null; or went for nothing, as a thing of no account]. (TA.) And cahaba damuhu buTolFA His blood went for nothing, [unretaliated, and uncompensated by a mulet,] as a thing of no account. (S, Msb.) And baTala damuhu [signifies the same; or] He was slain without there being obtained for him either blood-revenge or blood-wit. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- See also the inf. n. buTuwlN below, voce baTRaAlN. ― -b3- labaTula Alqawolu [How false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, &c., is the saying!] is said in wonder at that which is baATil. (TA.) ― -b4- baTala, (S, K,) or baTala mina AlEamali, (Msb,) aor.
baTula
, (TA,) inf. n. baTaAlapN (S, Msb, K, KL) and biTaAlapN, which is mentioned by one of the expositors of the Mo'allakát, and said to be the more chaste, and sometimes one says buTaAlapN, to make it accord with its contr. EumaAlapN, (Msb,) He (a hired man, or hireling,) was, or became, idle, unoccupied, or without work. (S, Msb, * K, KL. [See also 5.]) [Hence, yawomu baTaAlapK A day of idleness; a holiday.] ― -b5- biTaAlapN, with kesr, also signifies The being diverted from that which would bring profit in the present life or in the life to come. (TA.) ― -b6- See also 2. ― -b7- baTala fiI Hadiyvihi, (K,) aor.
baTula
; so it seems to be from the context in the K, but correctly baTila, aor.
baTala
, as in the Jm; (TA;) inf. n. baTaAlapN (K) [and app. buTuwlN also; see baTRaAlN]; He jested, or joked, or was not serious or in earnest, in his discourse; as also AbTl↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- baTula, aor.
baTula
, (Msb,) inf. n. baTaAlapN (S, Msb, K, KL) and biTaAlapN (Lth, Msb, TA) and buTaAlapN (TA) and buTuwlapN, (S, K, KL,) He (a man) was, or became, courageous, brave, or stronghearted, on the occasion of war, or fight; such as is termed baTalN, q. v.; (S, Msb, K, KL;) as also tbTRl↓: (K:) or this last signifies he affected courage, &c.; he made himself, or constrained himself to be, courageous, &c.; syn. taXajRaEa. (TA.) ― -b2- labaTula AlrRajulu [How courageous, &c., is the man!] is said in wonder at AltRabaTRul [i. e. courage, &c., or the affecting of courage, &c.]. (TA.)

2. AltRaboTiylu [inf. n. of bTRl] signifies fiEolu AlbTAlhi↓, [in which the latter word is written in the TA without any indication of the vowel of the b,] i. e. The pursuit of vain, or frivolous, diversion or sport, and foolish, or ignorant, conduct. (TA.) [See biTaAlapN, above, and the phrase next following it.] ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 AbTl ObTl AbTl bTl
4. AbTl He said, or spoke, what was false,
or untrue; (Mgh, Msb, K;) [contr. of OaHaqRa;] he lied: (Mgh:) he made a false, or vain, claim or demand; he claimed, or demanded, for himself that which was not right, or just. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- See also 1. ＝ -A2- AbTlhu [and vulgarly bTRlhu↓] He made it, or rendered it, [and he proved it to be,] baATil, i. e. false, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (S, * L, K, TA,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no account; (Msb, TA;) he nullified it, annulled it, abolished it, cancelled it; whether it was true or false, right or wrong, authentic or spurious, valid or null; (TA;) he made it to go for nothing, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that had perished or become lost. (K.) Hence, AbTl XahaAdatahu He annulled his testimony. (TA in art. zwr.) And liyuHiqRa AlHaqRa wa yuyoTila AlbaATila, in the Kur [viii. 8, meaning That He might establish that which is true, and annul that which is false]. (TA.)

5 tbTRlwA bayonahumo tbTlwA bynhm
5. tbTRlwA bayonahumo They took it by turns to say, or to do, that which was false, wrong, vain, futile, or the like; syn. tadaAluwA AlbaATila. (Az, K.) ― -b2- [tbTRl, said in the Mgh to be from AlbaTaAlapu, (see baTala, or baTala mina AlEamali,) app. signifies, as its part. n. (q. v. voce baTRaAlN) indicates, He became unoccupied and lazy.] ＝ -A2- See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.

buTolN Tl bTl
buTolN [originally an inf. n. of 1, and mentioned therewith, first sentence:] i. q. baATilN, q. v. (Ham p. 114.)

baTalN Tl bTl
baTalN, said to be the only epithet of its measure except HasanN; (TA in art. Hsn;) applied to a man, Courageous, brave, or strong-hearted, on the occasion of war, or fight; [commonly used as a subst., meaning a man of courage or valour, a brave man, a hero;] (S, Msb, K;) as also baTRaAlN↓; (K;) one whose wound goes for nothing, so that he does not care for it, (Lth, K,) and it does not withhold him from the exercise of his courage; (Lth, TA;) or the blood of whose adversaries goes for nothing with him, (K,) unrevenged: (TA:) or for this reason he is thus called; (TA;) or because life is annulled, or made to go for nothing, on the occasion of encountering him, and severe misfortunes are annulled by him, (Msb,) or by his sword, and made to be of no account: (TA:) and so baTalapN↓ applied to a woman; (S, Msb, K;) accord. to one of the expositors of the Hamáseh; (Msb;) but AZ says that this is not allowable: (IDrd, TA:) the pl. of baTalN is OaboTaAlN. (Msb, K.)

baTalapN Tl bTl bTlh bTlp
baTalapN: see baATilN: ＝ -A2- and see also baTalN.

baTolaAnu One whose powers have become weak: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)

buTRalaAtN bTl bTlAt
buTRalaAtN (pl. of buTRalN, TA) False, or vain, things; or unprofitable sayings. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) You say, jaMCa biAlbuTRalaAti He uttered false, or vain, things; &c. (El-Moheet, TA.)

baTRaAlN bTAl
baTRaAlN, applied to a man, signifies bayRinN cuw baATilK↓ AlbuTuwli↓ [app. meaning Having a vain, or false, object or pursuit; manifesting the having such an object or pursuit: or, accord. to an explanation of cw bATl by Bd in xxxviii. 26, i. q. muboTilN and EaAbivN, i. e. jesting, or joking; (see baTala fiI Hadiyvihi, or baTila;) or saying what is untrue: and playing, or sporting, and doing that in which is no profit; as also baATilN↓, q. v.]: (K:) one who jests, or jokes, in his discourse: one who is diverted from that which would bring profit in the present life or in that which is to come: (TA:) idle; unoccupied: (S, Msb:) or exceedingly, or extremely, idle: (KL:) or unoccupied and lazy; as also mutabaTRilN↓. (Mgh.) [In the present day it is commonly used as signifying Bad, worthless, and useless; applied to a man and to anything.] ＝ -A2- See also baTalN.

baATilN bATl
baATilN contr. of HaqRN; (S, K;) i. e. False, untrue, wrong or incorrect, fictitious, spurious, unfounded, unsound, (KL,) vain, unreal, naught, futile, worthless, useless, unprofitable, (KL, PS,) devoid of virtue or efficacy, ineffectual, null, void, of no force, or of no effect; (Msb;) that proves, when inquired into, or investigated, to be false, wrong, unfounded, unsound, or not established; applying to a saying, and [sometimes] to a deed: (TA:) [going for nothing, as a thing of no account, or as a thing that has perished or become lost: (see the verb, 1, first sentence:) often used as a subst., meaning a false, or vain, saying, or assertion, or allegation; a lie; a falsehood: and a false, or vain, deed, or action, or affair, or thing; &c.:] and buTolN↓ is syn. therewith, (Ham p. 114,) and so are OuboTuwlapN↓ and UiboTaAlapN↓: (K:) the pl. of baATilN is bawaATilu; (Msb;) and buTulN occurs as a pl. of the same; (Ham p. 360;) or its pl. is OabaATiylu, contr. to analogy, (S, Msb,) as though the sing. were UiboTiylN; (S;) or, accord. to AHát, this is pl. of OuboTuwlapN↓, or, as some say, of UiboTaAlapN↓, (Msb,) or, accord. to As and AHát and IDrd, of both these; (TA;) and signifies false, or vain, sayings and actions or deeds. (K in art. htr, &c.) You say, qado qulota baATilFA [Thou hast said a false, or vain, saying; a lie; a falsehood]; like as you say, qado qulota HaqRFA. (Ham p. 360.) And yaOokuluwna OamowaAla AlnRaAsi biAlbaATili [They devour the possessions of men by false pretence]. (Kur ix. 34.) And bayonahumo OuboTuwlapN↓ and UiboTaAlapN↓ [Between them is false, or vain, speech, or discourse, &c.]; syn. baATilN. (K.) ― -b2- The belief in a plurality of Gods: so explained as occurring in the Kur xlii. 23. (TA.) ― -b3- See also baTRaAlN, in two places. [Hence,] baATilFA In play, or sport; acting unprofitably; or aiming at no profit. (Jel in iii. 188 and xxxviii. 26.) ― -b4- AlbaATilu Iblees: so in the Kur [xxxiv. 48], where it is said, maA yubodiYu QlobaATilu wa maA yuEiydu [explained in art. bdO]: (Katádeh, K:) and again [xli. 42], where it is said, laA yaOotiyhi QlobaATilu mino bayona yadayohi wa laA mino xalofihi, [accord. to some,] meaning that Iblees shall not add to the Kur-án nor diminish therefrom: (TA:) baTalapN↓ [is its pl., and] signifies devils: (A, TA:) or enchanters. (O, K.)

muboTilN One who says a thing in which is no truth, or reality: (Er-Rághib, TA:) one who embellishes speech with lies: (Bd in xxx. 58:) one who says, or does, false, or vain, things. (Jel ibid.] [See also its verb, 4.]

mutabaTRilN mtbTl
mutabaTRilN: see baTRaAlN.

buTomN Tm bTm
buTomN (S, K) and buTumN, (K,) the latter allowable accord. to IAar, (TA,) The HabRap xaDoraMC [or fruit of the terebinth-tree, to which this latter appellation is given in the present day, i. e., of the pistacia terebinthus of the botanists]; (S, K;) so accord. to the people of El-'Áliyeh; and the like is said on the authority of As: (TA:) or the tree thereof; (K;) [which is called buTom in the present day;] so accord. to AHn; and he says, but no one has told me that it grows in the land of the Arabs; but they assert that the Dirow [meaning the cancamum-tree, also called kamokaAm, but said by IAar to be the HbRp xDrAC,] is nearly like it: (TA:) its fruit is heating, diuretic, strengthening to the venereal faculty, good for the cough, and for the [disease of the face called] laqowap, and for the kidney; and the overspreading of the hair with its dry and sifted leaves causes it to grow, and beautifies it. (K.)

1. baTuna, aor.
baTuna
, (K,) inf. n. baTaAnapN, (TA,) He (a man) was, or became, big, or large, in the belly, (K, TA,) in consequence of much eating. (TA.) ― -b2- And baTina, aor.
baTana
, inf. n. baTanN, He (a man) was, or became, big, or large, in the belly, in consequence of satiety, (S, TA,) and disordered therein: (TA:) he was, or became, in a state of repletion, or much filled with food. (TA.) ― -b3- ― -b4- And [hence,] baTina signifies also (tropical:) i. q. OaXira and baTira [He exulted, or exulted greatly, or excessively, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: &c.]. (TA.) ― -b5- buTina He (a man, S, TA) had a complaint of, or a disease in, or a pain in, his belly. (S, Msb, TA.) ＝ -A2- baTanahu, (S, K,) aor.
baTuna
, (S, TA,) inf. n. baTonN, (TA,) He struck, or beat, his belly; as also baTana lahu, (S, K,) accord. to some, or the l is added [only] in verse; (S;) and bTRnhu↓, (K,) inf. n. taboTiynN. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a disease) entered into him: [as though it penetrated into his belly: see 10:] in this sense it has for its inf. n. buTuwnN. (TA.) And baTanato bihi AlHumRaI The fever produced an effect within him. (TA.) ― -b3- He entered into it; namely, a valley; (S, TA;) in which sense it has for its inf. n. baTonN; and tbTRnhu↓ signifies the same: or the latter, he went about in it; namely, the valley; as also AstbTnhu↓. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) [He penetrated into it mentally;] he knew it; (Msb, K, TA;) namely, the news or story, or the state or case, of another: (K, TA:) (tropical:) he knew the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances thereof; (S, Msb, TA;) i. e., of a case, or an affair; (S,
TA;) as also AstbTnhu↓: (K, A, TA:) and tbTRnhu↓ (assumed tropical:) he entered into it so that he knew its inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances. (Ham p. 688.) ― -b5- baTana bifulaAnK, accord. to the S and M, but in the K mino fulaAnK, (TA,) (tropical:) He became one of his particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates, (S, K, TA,) entering into his affair [or affairs]: (TA:) or baTana bihi, aor.
baTuna
, inf. n. buTuwnN and baTaAnapN, means (assumed tropical:) he entered into his affair [or affairs]. (TA.) ― -b6- And baTana, (Msb, K,) aor.
baTuna
, said of a thing, (Msb,) It was, or became, unapparent, hidden, concealed, or covert; (K, TA;) contr. of Zahara. (Msb.) ― -b7- See also 4.

(K.) ― -b4- bTRn liHayatahu, inf. n. as above, He took, or cut off, from that part of his beard which was beneath the chin and lower jaw. (Sh, Nh, TA.) 4 AbTn AlbaEiyra AbTn AlbEyr
4. AbTn AlbaEiyra, (IAar, S, K,) inf. n. UiboTaAnN, (S,) He bound, or made fast, the camel's biTaAn [or belly-girth]; (S, K;) as also bTRnhu↓, accord. to the copies of the K; but this is a mistake for baTanahu↓, aor.
baTuna
, inf. n. baTonN; which last verb, however, though said by Az to be a dial. var., is disallowed by IAar and by AHeyth. (TA.) ― -b2- OaboTanotu AlsRiyofa kaXoHiI (S, TA) I put the sword beneath my waist. (TA.) And AbTn kaXoHahu sayofahu (assumed tropical:) He made his sword to be his biTaAnap↓ [app. meaning his secret companion]. (TA.) [This seems to be from the phrase next following.] ― -b3- OaboTanotu AlrRajula (assumed tropical:) I made the man to be one of my particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates; (S, TA; *) took him as a biTaAnap. (TA.) One says also, fulaAnFA duwnaka AisotaboTanotu↓ (Ham p. 688; [there rendered by xAmSth, app. a mistranscription for xaSaSotuhu; meaning (assumed tropical:) I took, or chose, such a one particularly, or specially, for my companion, in preference to thee: it is said in explanation of the phrase musotaboTinFA sayofiI, which seems to mean (assumed tropical:) taking my sword as my special companion, or putting it beneath my waist; so that sayofahu AstbTn↓ is similar to one, or both, of two phrases mentioned above in this paragraph.]) ― -b4- See also 2.

5 tbTRn ObTn bTn tbTn tbTnn
5. tbTRn He filled the [meaning his] belly. (Har p. 176.) ― -b2- tbTRn jaAriyapF (Sh, S, TA) He made his baTon to be in contact with that of a girl, skin to skin: (Sh, TA:) or inivit puellam; i. e. OawolaHa cakarahu fiyhaA. (TA.) ― -b3- tbTRn AlkalaOa He was, or became, in the middle, or midst, of the herbage: (TA:) or he went round about in the herbage. (S.) See also 1, in two places.

6 tbATn tbATn
6. tbATn It (a place) was far-extending; one part thereof being remote from another. (TA.)

8 AibotaTanotu AlnRaAqapa EaXarapa OaboTunK c
8. AibotaTanotu AlnRaAqapa EaXarapa OaboTunK I assisted the she-camel in bringing forth, or delivered her of her young, ten times. (S, TA. [Golius and Freytag render the verb by “ ventre enixa fuit: ” and the former renders the phrase above (incorrectly printed in his Lex.) by “ peperit camela decem vicibus. ”])

10 AstbTn Alfarasa AstbTn Alfrs
10. AstbTn Alfarasa He sought to find what young was in the belly of the mare. (TA.) ― -b2- AstbTn AlfaHolu AlXRuwRala The stallion covered the she-camels raising their tails, so that they conceived, or received his seed into their wombs; as though [meaning] he deposited his seed in their bellies. (TA.) ― -b3- AstbTnhu He, or it, entered [or penetrated] into his, or its, belly, or interior; [or was, or became, or lay, within it;] like as the vein enters [or penetrates] into [or lies within] (yasotaboTinu) the flesh. (A, TA.) You say, AisotaboTanotu AlXRaIoCa [I entered, or penetrated, into the thing, whether actually or mentally]. (S.) See 1, in two places. ― -b4- See also 4, in two places. ― -b5- AisotiboTaAnN also signifies The having, or holding, [a thing] concealed within. (PS.) [This explanation seems to be given to show that, in the opinion of the author of the PS, AisotaboTanotu AlXRaIoCa in the S means I had, or held, the thing concealed within.]

baTonN Tn bTn bTnn
baTonN The belly, or abdomen; i. e. the part of the body which is separated from the jawof [i. e. chest, or thorax,] by the HijaAb [i. e. midriff, or diaphragm]; containing the liver and the spleen and the stomach and the lower intestines &c.; (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán; ” [in which it is erroneously said to comprise also the lungs;]) contr. of ZahorN; (S, Msb, K;) of a man and of any animal: (TA:) of the masc. gender, (S, K,) and, accord. to AO, fem. also: (AHát, S:) pl. OaboTunN and buTuwnN (Az, Msb, K) and buTonaAnN; (K;) the first a pl. of pauc.; and the second [as also the third] a pl. of mult., applied to more than ten. (Az, TA.) [Hence,] cuw AlbaToni [What is in the belly: but generally meaning] excrement, ordure, or dung. (K, TA.) You say, OaloqaI caA baTonihi He (a man) ejected his excrement, or ordure. (TA.) And Oaloqato caA baTonihaA She (a woman, TA) brought forth; (K;) as also waDaEato caAta baTonihaA: (TA in art. cw:) and she (a hen) laid an egg. (K.) And navarato caA baTonihaA, (T and Mgh in art. nvr,) and [elliptically] navarato baTonahaA, (T and A and Mgh in that art.,) She (a woman) brought forth many children. (T in that art.) And it is said in a prov., (TA,) AlcRiYobu yugobaTu biciI baTonihi [The wolf is envied for what is in his belly]: for one never thinks him to be hungry, but only thinks him to be in a state of repletion, because of his hostility to men and cattle, (A'Obeyd, K,) though he is sometimes distressed by hunger. (A'Obeyd. [See various readings of this prov. in Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 500 and 501.]) maAtato fiI baTonK, a phrase occurring in a trad., means She (a woman) died in childbirth. (TA.) See also fulaAnN Qbonu baTonihi. baTanN. means (assumed tropical:) Such a one is solicitous for his belly. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. bnI.) [Many phrases in which the word baTon occurs will be found explained under other words of those phrases; as ZahorN, and Oaxaca, and EuSofuwrN, &c.] baTonu AlHuwti: see AlrRiXaMCu. ― -b2- Also The inside, or interior, of anything; syn. jawofN: and so baATinN↓; syn. daAxilN: (K:) pl. of the former as above. (TA.) Thus baTonu waAdK means The interior of a water-course or riverbed [or valley; i. e. its bottom, in which flows, occasionally or constantly, its torrent or river]. (MA.) And baTonu makRapa means The interior of Mekkeh. (Bd in xlviii. 24.) [Hence,] it is said of the Kur-án, likulRi MyapK minohaA ZahorN wa baTonN, meaning (assumed tropical:) To every verse thereof is an apparent sense and a sense requiring development. (TA.) [See ZahorN.] See also baATinN. [And its pl. buTonaAnN is also used as a sing., meaning The middle, or midst, of a thing: and the lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation. Thus,] buTonaAnu AljanRapi means The middle, or midst, of Paradise: (S, TA:) and buTonaAnu AlEaroXi, The lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation, of the ErX [vulgarly held to be the throne of God]. (TA.) You say also [baTonu AlkafRi and] AlkafRi baATinu↓ (assumed tropical:) The palm of the hand [opposed to ZahoruhaA and ZaAhiruhaA]: and [baTonu Alqadami and] Alqadami baATinu↓ (assumed tropical:) The sole of the foot [likewise opposed to ZahoruhaA and ZaAhiruhaA]: (Zj in his “ Khalk- el-Insán: ”) and baTonu AlHaAfiru (S in art. nsr) and AlHaAfiri baATinu↓ (M and K in that art.) (assumed tropical:) [The sole of the solid hoof;] the part of the solid hoof in which is the nasor, q. v. (S and M and K in that art.) baTonu AlrRaAHapi is well known [as another name for baTonu AlkafRi, explained above; for AlrRaAHap is often used as syn. with AlkafR]: and AlxufRi baATinu↓ is [said to be] (assumed tropical:) The part of the foot of a camel or the like that is next the leg: and one says, baATinu↓ AlUiboTi, [meaning (assumed tropical:) The armpit, or hollow of the inner side of the shoulder-joint,] but not baTonu AlUiboTi: (TA:) [and AlEunuqi baATinu↓ the throat.] The baTon of a feather is (tropical:) The long, (S,) or longer, (K,) [or wider, i. e. inner,] lateral half: pl. buTonaAnN; (S, K, TA;) which is explained as signifying the parts beneath the shaft: opposed to ZuhoraAnN, pl. of ZahorN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A low, or depressed, tract, or portion, of land, or ground; (S, TA;) and so baATinN↓: (TA:) [or a bottom, or low land; or a low, soft flat; i. e.] soft, plain, fine, low land or ground; opposed to ZahorN [q. v.]: (TA in art. Zhr:) pl. of the former, (S,) or of the latter, (K,) buTonaAnN, (S, K,) a pl. of mult., (TA,) and OaboTinapN, (K,) a pl. of pauc., and anomalous [as pl. of either]: (TA:) the former pl., in relation to land, is also used as a sing., like baTonN: (AHn, TA:) and accord. to ISh, buTonaAnu AlOaroDi signifies the low, or depressed, tract, or tracts, of land, of the plain, or soft, parts thereof, and of the rugged, and of the meadows, where water rests and stagnates: and such tracts are also called bawaATinu and buTuwnN. (TA.) ― -b4- baTonu AlsRamaMCi and Zahoru AlsRamaMCi both signify (assumed tropical:) The apparent, visible, part of the sky. (Fr, T voce ZahorN [q. v.].) ＝ -A2- Also
(tropical:) A tribe below that which is termed qabiylap: (S, Msb, K, TA:) or next below the EimaArap: (S and TA voce XaEobN, &c.:) or below the faxic and above the EmArp: (K: [but for this I have found no other authority:]) of the masc. gender: (TA:) or [properly] fem.: but if HayRN [said by some to signify a tribe, absolutely,] be meant thereby, it is masc.: (Msb:) or fem. if used in the sense of qabiylap: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaboTunN and [of mult.] buTuwnN. (Msb, K.) [See XaEobN.]

baTanN Tn bTn bTnn
baTanN Disease of the belly, (K, TA,) being a state of enlargement thereof arising from satiety; and so baTonN↓; whence the phrase maAta biAlbaToni He died by the disease of the belly. (TA.)

baTanN One whose object of care, or anxiety, is his belly: (K:) or who has an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food; (S;) whom nothing causes care, or anxiety, but his belly; (S, TA;) as also miboTaAnN↓: (TA:) or the former, (TA,) or ↓the latter, (S,) ever large, or big, in the belly in consequence of much eating: (S, TA:) or ↓both signify voracious; not ceasing from eating. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) One who exults, or exults greatly, or excessively, and behaves insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: (TA:) or who does so, being abundant in wealth. (K, TA.)

(TA.) [See also tagaDogaDa, in two places.] [Hence also,] nazRato bihi AlbaTinapu (assumed tropical:) Richness caused him to exult, or exult greatly, or excessively, and to behave insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. AlbaTinapu i. q. AldRuburu [The back, hinder part, posteriors, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- baTinaAtu AlwaAdiI The roads, or beaten tracks, of the valley. (TA.)

[of pauc.] OaboTinapN and [of mult.] buTonN. (K.) [Hence,] Ailotaqato HaloqataA AlbiTaAni [The two rings of the belly-girth met]: said of a case, or an affair, that has become severe, strait, or distressing. (S.) ErD.]) And maAta fulaAnN wahuwa EariyDu AlbiTaAni, meaning, accord. to A'Obeyd, (assumed tropical:) Such a one died broad in the fleshy parts (AlmalaAHim); nothing of him having gone. (TA. A man having the pair of provision-bags full]; meaning (assumed tropical:) a man who conceals his travel-ling-provision in a journey, and eats that of his companion. AlbuTayonu AlbTyn bTyn
AlbuTayonu One of the Mansions of the Moon; (S, K;) namely, the Second; (Kzw, &c.;) three small stars [e and p and n], (S, K,) disposed in the form of an equilateral triangle, (S,) as though they were three stones whereon a cooking-pot is placed, and forming the belly of the Ram; (S, K;) the appellation being made a diminutive because the Ram consists of many stars in the form of a ram; [so I here render Hamal though it properly signifies a lamb;] the XazaTaAni being its two horns; and the buTayon, its belly; [or, accord. to our configuration of Aries, the rump;] and the vurayRaA, its rump, or tail; (S;) three obscure stars, forming the points of a triangle, in the belly of the Ram, between the XaraTaAni and the vurayRaA; (Kzw, Mir-át ez-Zemán, &c.;) the three stars of which two are on the tail and one on the thigh of the Ram, forming an equilateral triangle. (Kzw in his description of Aries.) [See manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.] The Arabs assert that it has no nawoC [here meaning effect upon the weather], except wind. (TA.)
