(assumed tropical:) He is one who possesses knowledge of the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of the case, or affair, of such a one. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A particular, or special, intimate, friend, or associate; (S, K, TA;) one who is particularly distinguished by entering into, and becoming acquainted with, the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of one's case or affair; (TA;) an intimate and familiar friend or associate; (Zj, TA;) a confidential friend, who is consulted respecting one's circumstances: (TA:) it is from the same word in the sense first explained above, relating to a garment, or piece of cloth: (Mgh, Er-Rághib:) and is used in a pl. sense, as meaning intimate and familiar friends or associates, to whom one is open, or unreserved, in conversation, and who know the inward state or circumstances [of one's case or affair]: (Zj, TA:) or one's family; and one's particular, or special, intimates, friends, or associates. (Mgh.) You say, huwa biTaAnatiI (tropical:) [He is my particular, or special, intimate, &c.]: and humo biTaAnatiI and Oaholu biTaAnatiI (tropical:) [They are my particular, or special, intimates, &c.]. (A, TA.) See also 4. ― -b4- Coupled with EalaAwap, it signifies What is put beneath [the things that compose the main load of a camel], such as a water-skin and the like. (TA.) ― -b5- See also baATinapN.

baATinN bATn
baATinN Unapparent; hidden; concealed; covert: (K, TA:) [and inward; inner; interior; internal; intrinsic; esoteric: in all these senses] contr. of ZaAhirN. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- baATinu OamorK [The inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances, of a case or an affair]; (TA, &c.;) [and so OamorK baTonu↓; whence the phrases,] OaforaXaniI Zahora Oamorihi wabaTonahu (assumed tropical:) [He displayed, or laid open, to me the outward state or circumstances of his case or affair, and the inward state or circumstances thereof]; and huwa mujarRibN baTona AlOumuwri (assumed tropical:) [He is one who possesses experience of the inward, or intrinsic, state or circumstances of affairs], as though he hit their bellies by his knowledge of their true, or real, states or circumstances. (TA.) ― -b3- AlbaATinu [The internal, inward, or intrinsic, state, condition, character, or circumstances, of a man: and the heart, meaning the secret thoughts; the recesses of the mind; the state of mind; the inward, or secret, disposition of the mind: opposed to AlZRaAhiru. ― -b4- Also,] an epithet applied to God, meaning He who knows the inward, or intrinsic, states or circumstances of things: (S:) or He who knows the secret and hidden things: or He who is veiled from the eyes and imaginations of created beings. (TA.) ― -b5- [baATinFA Covertly; secretly.] ― -b6- See also baATinapN, in eight places. ― -b7- biTaAnapN also signifies A water-course, or place in which water flows, in rugged ground: pl. buTonaAnN (K) and buTonN. (TA.)

baZara
, inf. n. baZarN,] said of a woman, [She had a baZor (q. v.), or a long baZor; or] she was uncircumcised. (Msb.) [But see baZarN, below.] ― -b2- And baZir, inf. n. baZarN, He had what is termed a buZaArap [q. v.] in his upper lip. (S.)

baZorN Zr bZr
baZorN, (Lh, T, S, M, &c.,) also pronounced baDorN, (T,) and buZaArapN↓ [which see below] (Lh, T, S, M, K) and baZaArapN↓ (M, K) and bayoZarN↓ (Lh, T, M, K) and bunoZurN↓, (K,) A certain thing, (S, M, Mgh, K,) or piece of flesh, (A,) between the two sides of the vulva (AlUisokataAni, S, M, K, or AlXRuforaAni, A, or XuforaA Alfaroji, Mgh) of a woman, (M, A, Mgh, K,) which is cut off in circumcision, (A,) not yet cut off; (S;) a piece of flesh between the two sides of the vulva (AlXRuforaAni) of a woman; i. e. the prepuce (quloqap) that is cut off in circumcision; (Msb;) also called kayonN and raforafN and nawofN (Lh, T) and qunobN [which last properly signifies the “ prepuce, ” or “ sheath, ” of a beast or horse or the like]; (A and K in art. qnb;) and likened to a cock's comb: (Msb in art. Erf:) [the last of these explanations plainly shows that what is meant thereby is the prepuce of the clitoris; which, it seems, in the Arabian and Egyptian races, and others throughout Eastern Africa, and still more so in the Hottentot race, grows to an extraordinary size; and this may be the reason why the bZr is described by some travellers as a caruncle for which we have no name: or it may, perhaps, be a distinct excrescence from the prepuce of the clitoris: it has been described to me as a caruncle a little in front of the meatus urinarius: many of the Egyptians assert that it is the clitoris itself that is amputated, (as Ludolph also does in his Comment. to his Ethiop. Hist. p. 273, finding fault with those who say otherwise;) and they affirm that this is done for the purpose of lessening the libidinous passion: such, indeed, appears to be the case in some instances, but not generally; and it may have led to a misapplication of the term bZr in post-classical times: an analogous practice, one still more barbarous, is said to have obtained among an African race hence called the Colobi: see barobaru: Abu-l-Kásim Ez-Zahráwee speaks of the amputation of the redundance of the bZr when preternaturally large, and also of an excrescence in the vulva: the former he describes in such a manner as plainly shows that he means thereby the clitoris: the latter, in terms apparently indicating a preternatural elongation of the lower part of the prepuce of the clitoris; as “ an excrescence of flesh at, or in, the mouth of the vulva, such as fills it up, and sometimes protrudes externally, like a tail, wherefore the ancients term it the caudal disease AlmrD AlcnbI; and this, ” he says, “ should be amputated, like as the bZr is amputated ” when preternaturally large: (Albucasis de Chirurgia, pp. 314 and 316:) in some of our medical books, the term “ caudatio ” is defined as “ an elongation of the clitoris; ” inconsistently with the foregoing description of “ the caudal disease: ”] the pl. [of mult.] of baZorN is buZuwrN, (M, Msb, K,) and [pl. of pauc.] OaboZurN. (Msb.) yaA Qbona muqaTRiEapi AlbuZuwri [O son of her who amputates bZwr!] is an expression of contumely employed by the Arabs whether the mother of the person addressed be really a circumciser of females or not. (TA.)

(T.)

Hvrm;) having a long (T, M) and projecting (M) upper lip, with a protuberance in the middle of it. (T, M.) ― -b3- Accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) Clamorous; long-tongued. (Mgh.) 1 baEovN Ev bEv
1. baEovN signifies The removing of that which restrains one from free action. (TA.) [And hence,] ― -b2- baEavahu, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
baEava
, (A, K,) inf. n. baEavN (Mgh, L, Msb, TA) and baEavN, (L, TA,) He sent him; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely, a messenger; (Msb;) and, when said of God, an apostle; (A;) [and when said of a man, a letter, &c.;] as also AbtEvh↓: (S, A, Msb, K:) [or] the former is said of anything that goes, or is sent, by itself; and of anything that will not go, or be sent, by itself, as a letter, and a present, one says, baEava bihi: (Msb:) [thus,] baEavahu signifies he sent him, or it, alone, by himself, or by itself; and baEava bihi, he sent him, or it, by, or with, another, or others: (L:) but El-Fárábee says that the former of these two has another signification, which will be found below; and that the latter signifies he sent him, or it. (Msb.) Hence, Duriba Ealayohimu AlbaEovu The being sent to the war was appointed them and imposed upon them as an obligation. (Msb.) You say, baEavahu likacaA [He sent him for such a thing or purpose]. (A, TA.) [And baEava Uilayohi bikacaA He sent to him such a thing; lit., he sent to him a messenger with such a thing.] And baEava Aljunoda UilaI Algazowi [He sent the army to the war]. (TA.) And baEava Ealayohimu AlbalaMCa [He sent upon them trial, or affliction;] he caused trial, or affliction, to befall them. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (A, L, TA,) inf. baEovN (Mgh, L, TA) and baEavN (L) and taboEaAvN [an intensive form], (TA,) He roused him, excited him, or put him in motion or action; (A, L, Mgh, TA;) namely, anything; (TA;) [i. e. any person or animal; and particularly,] an animal lying down, or a person sitting. (L, TA.) You say, baEava AlnRaAqapa
He roused, or put in motion or action, the she-camel; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) i. e., loosed the cord that bound her shank to her arm, and dismissed her; or he roused her, or made her to rise, she being lying down. (TA.) It is said in a trad. respecting 'Áïsheh, fabaEavonaA AlbaEiyra fUicaA AlEiqodu taHotahu [And we made the camel to rise, and to, the necklace was beneath him]. (TA.) You say also, baEavahu EalaI AlOamori, (A,) or AlXRaIoCi, (L,) He roused him, excited him, or put him in motion or action, to do the affair, or thing: (A:) or he incited him, urged him, or instigated him, to do the thing. (L.) ― -b4- Also, accord. to El-Fárábee, (Msb,) or baEavahu mino manaAmihi, (S, A, K,) inf. n. baEavN and baEavN, (TA,) He roused him, or awoke him, from his sleep; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also AbtEvhu↓. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b5- baEovN (S, K, TA) and baEavN (TA) also signify The quickening, vivifying, or revivifying, of the dead; the raising of the dead to life; (S, K, * TA;) by God, (TA,) on the day called yawomu AlbaEovi (S, TA) the day [of resurrection,] when those who are in the graves shall be raised. (A, Mgh.) You say, baEava QllRehu Alxaloqa, and AlmawotaI, God quickened, vivified, revivified, or raised to life, mankind, and the dead. (TA.) ＝ -A2- baEiva, aor.
baEava
, (inf. n. baEavN, TK,) He (a man, TA) was sleepless, or wakeful. (K, * TA.) [See baEivN.]

You say, AnbEv likacaA [He went, being sent, or he rose, and went away. or he rose to go forth, for such a thing or purpose]. (A, TA.) And AnbEv fulaAnN liXaOonihi Such a one rose, and went away, to perform his affair. (TA.) And AnbEv fiI AlsRayori He hastened, made haste, sped, or was quick or swift, in going, journeying, or pace. (S.) And AnbEv AlXRayoCu, i. e. AinodafaEa [The thing became impelled, or propelled; or went quickly, or swiftly, as though impelled or propelled; &c.]; as also tbERv↓. (TA.) And AnbEv biXarRK [He broke forth with evil, or mischief]. (JK in art. bwq.) ― -b2- [He became roused, excited, incited, urged, instigated, or put in motion or action.] You say, AnbEvt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel became roused, or put in motion or action, and rose: (L, Mgh, TA: *) quasi-pass. of baEava AlnRaAqapa [q. v.]. , inf. n. buEodN; (S, L, Msb, K;) and baEida, aor.

, inf. n. baEadN; (L, K;) and AbEd↓, inf. n. UiboEaAdN, which is also trans.; (Msb;) and tbAEd↓; (S, Msb, K;) and AstbEd↓; (S, K, &c.;) He, or it, was, or became, distant, remote, far off, or aloof: he went, or removed, or retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off: he alienated, or estranged, himself: he stood, or kept, aloof: contr. of qaruba: (S, L:) [but baEuda generally has the first of these significations; and AbEd↓, the others, as also tbAEd↓ and AstbEd↓:] it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that baEida, as well as baEuda, is thus used; but some deny this; and some assert that they may be employed alike, but that baEuda is more chaste than baEida thus used. (TA.) [You say also, of a desert, and a tract of country, and the like, baEuda, meaning It extended far.] And zayodN Eani Almanozili AbEd↓, meaning tbAEd↓ [i. e. Zeyd went, or removed, to a distance, or far, from the place of alighting or abode]. (IKt, Msb.) And minRiI tbAEd↓, and AbtEd↓, and tbERd↓, [He went, or removed, to a distance, or far, from me; he alienated, or estranged, himself from me; he shunned, or avoided, me;] (A;) and EanRiI tbAEd↓ [and baEuda EnRI signify the same]. (Msb in art. kXH.) And UicaA OaraAca OaHadukumo AlHaAjapi OaboEada↓, (L, Msb,) a trad., (Msb,) meaning When one of you desires to accomplish that which is needful, (i. e. to ease nature,) he goes far, or to a great distance. (L.) And fiI Almacohabi OaboEadotu↓, meaning tabaAEadotu↓, (Msb,) I went far, or to a great distance, to the place of ease, i. e., to ease nature. (L.) ― -b2- [baEuda referring to a saying or the like, and an event, means It was far from being probable or correct; it was improbable, extraordinary, or strange: (see baEiydN, and see also 10:) often occurring in these senses.] And fiI nawoEihi AbEd↓ It reached the utmost point, or degree, in its kind, or species. (IAth.) And AbEd fiI AlsRawomi He exceeded the due bounds in offering a thing for sale and demanding a price for it, or in bargaining for a thing. (Mgh in art. qdm.) ― -b4- [baEuda is often used, agreeably with a general rule, in the manner of a verb of praise or dispraise; and in this case is commonly contracted into buEoda, like Husona; as in the phrase, in a verse of Imrael-Keys, buEoda maA mutaOamRalI (in which mA is redundant) Distant, or far distant, was the object of my contemplation! or (as explained in the EM p. 52) how distant, &c.!] ― -b5- baEida, aor.
baEada
, inf. n. baEadN; (S, L, Msb, K;) and baEoda, aor.
baEuda
, inf. n. buEodN; (L, K;) also signify He, or it, perished: (S L, Msb:) he died: (K:) it is the general opinion of the leading lexicologists that both these verbs are used as signifying “he perished,” and both occur in different readings of v. 98 of ch. xi. of the Kur: the former is said to be used in this sense by some of the Arabs; and the latter, by others; but some disallow the latter in this sense; and some say that the former is more chaste than the latter thus used: (TA:) or both signify he became far distant from his home or native country; became a stranger, or estranged, therefrom: (L, TA:) or the Arabs say, baEida AlrRajulu and baEuda in the sense of tbAEd, when not reviling; but when reviling, they say, baEida, only. (Yoo, TA.) You say, laA taboEadN wa Uino baEudota EanRaI [Mayest thou not perish though thou be distant from me!] (A.) [And as an imprecation against a man, you say, baEidota, meaning Mayest thou perish! (See the printed edition of the Ham, pp. 89 and 90, where baEidotaAIa hlkt is an evident mistake for aEidota OaI halakota.)] And buEodFA lahu May God alienate him, or estrange him, from good, or prosperity! or, curse him! 10 AstbEdhu OstbEdh AstbEdh AstbEdp QstbEd QstbEdh
10. AstbEdhu He reckoned it, or esteemed it, (namely, a thing, K, or a saying, A,) baEiyd [i. e. distant, or remote; or if a saying or the like, far from being probable or correct, improbable, extraordinary, or strange]; (S, A, K;) as also AbEdhu↓. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, first sentence, in two places.

baEodu Ed bEd
baEodu an adv. n. of time, signifying After, or afterwards: and allowable also, accord. to some of the grammarians, as an adv. n. of place, signifying after, or behind: (TA:) contr. of qabolu: (S, A, K:) it is a vague adv. n., of which the meaning is not understood without its being prefixed to another noun [expressed or implied]; denoting after-time. (Msb.) When it occurs without any complement, (S, K,) a noun or the like which should be its complement being intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter, (S, * TA,) it is indecl., (S, K,) because it resembles a particle, (TA,) and has damm for its termination to show that it is indecl., since it cannot have damm by any rule of desinential syntax because it cannot occur as an agent nor as an inchoative or enunciative. (S.) Sb, however, mentions [as exceptions to this rule] the phrases mino baEodK [Afterwards] and OafoEalu hecaA baEodFA [I will do this afterwards], as having been used by the Arabs. (K, * TA.) [The latter of these phrases is common in the present day. Another exception to the rule above-mentioned will be found in what follows.] Accord. to the primary rule, it is used as a prefixed n. governing its complement in the gen. case; (S;) [i. e., it is used in the manner of a preposition;] and when thus used, it is decl., (K,) because it does not in this case [always] resemble a particle. (TA.) You say, jaMCa zayodN baEoda EamorKw Zeyd came after 'Amr. (Msb.) And raOayotuhu baEodaka and mino baEodika [I saw him after thee]. (L.) The words of the Kur [xxx. 3], QllRehi QloOamoru mino qabolu wa mino baEodu, meaning To God belonged the command before that the Greeks were overcome and after that they had been overcome, [thus read when the complements of qbl and bEd are intended to be understood as to the meaning thereof but not as to the letter,] are also read mino qaboli wa mino baEodi, when each complement is intended to be understood as to the meaning and the letter, and also mino qabolK wa mino baEodK, meaning To God belongeth the command first and last, [when neither complement is intended to be understood either as to the letter or as to the meaning,] but the first of these readings is the best. (L.) [You say also, baEoda celika and mino baEodi celika After that: and baEoda Oano faEalotu and mino baEodi Oano faEalotu and baEoda maA faEalotu and mino baEodi maA faEalotu After I did, or after my doing, such a thing: &c.] Also jiYotu baEodayokumaA, meaning baEoda kumaA, I came after you two. (K.) And hecaA mimRaA layosa baEodahu gaAyapN fiI Aljawodapi, and fiI AlrRadaMCap, This is of the things after, or beyond, which there is not any extreme degree in respect of goodness, and in respect of badness: and, by way of abridgement, layosa baEodahu [with nothing following this]: and hence, app., the saying of Mohammad, waUino kaAna layosa biAlRaciI laA baEoda lahu, meaning [And though] it be not in the utmost degree in respect of goodness: bEd being thus used as a decl. noun. (Mgh.)

baEodiI Ed Edy bEd bEdI bEdy bEdyy
[baEodiI and the like are also frequently used as meaning baEoda EahodiI and the like; as in the phrase, qado tagayRarota baEodI Thou hast become altered since I knew thee, or saw thee, or met thee, or was with thee. And similar to this are many phrases in the Kur; as, for instance, in ii. 48,] vumRa QtRaxacotumu QlEijola mino baEodihi Then ye took to yourselves the calf as a god, or an object of worship, after him, namely Moses, i. e., after his having gone away. (Bd.) OamRaA baEodu (S, K, &c.) is [an expression denoting transition;] an expression by which an address or a discourse is divided; (S;) used without any complement to bEd, which in this case signifies the contr. of qabolu: (TA:) you say, OamRaA baEodu faqado kaAna kacaA, meaning [Now, after these preliminary words, (Abu-l- 'Abbás in TA voce xiTaAbN,) I proceed to say, that such a thing has happened: or] after my prayer for thee: (K:) or after praising God: (TA:) the first who used this formula was David; (K;) or Jacob; (TA;) or Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí; (K;) or Kuss Ibn-Sá'ideh; or Yaarub Ibn-Kahtán. (TA.) ― -b2- You also use the dim. form, saying buEayodahu↓ [A little after him, or it], when you mean by it to denote a time near to the preceding time. (Msb.) You say also, bayonK raOayotuhu buEayodaAti↓, (S, K,) and baEiydaAtihi↓, (K, TA, [in the CK buEayodaAtih,]) I saw him a little after a separation: (S, K:) or, after intervals of separation: (S, L:) or, after a while. (A'Obeyd, A.) And UinRahaA lataDoHaku bayonK buEayocaAti↓ Verily she laughs after intervals. (L.) [See also art. byn.] buEayodaAt↓ is used only as an adv. n. of time. (S, L.) ― -b3- baEodu also sometimes means Now; yet; as yet. (TA.) [It is used in this sense mostly in negative phrases; as, for instance, in lamo yamuto baEodu He has not died yet. The following is one of the instances of its having this meaning in affirmative phrases: sumRiya AlHawoliIRu mino OawolaAdi Albaqari tabiyEFA liOanRahu yanobaEu OumRahu baEodu The yearling of the offspring of cows is called tbyE because he yet follows his mother: occurring in the Mgh &c., in art. tbE.] ― -b4- It occurs also in the sense of maEa; as in the words of the Kur [ii. 174 and v. 95], famani QEotadaI baEoda celika, i. e., (as some say, MF,) maEa clk [And whoso transgresseth notwithstanding that; lit., with that]. (Msb.) ― -b5- It has been said that it also means Before, in time; thus bearing two contr. significations: that it has this meaning in two instances; in the Kur [lxxix. 30], where it is said, wa QloOaroDa baEoda celika daHaAhaA [as though signifying And the earth, before that, He spread it forth]; and [xxi. 105] where it is said, walaqado katabonaA fiI QlzRabuwri mino baEodi QlcRikori [as though meaning And verily we wrote in the Psalms before the Kur-án]: (MF, TA:) but Az says that this is a mistake; that God created the earth not spread forth; then created the heaven; and then spread forth the earth: (L, TA:) and Alckr in the latter of these instances means the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: (Bd:) or Alzbwr means the revealed Scriptures; (Bd, Jel;) and Alckr, the Preserved Tablet, (Bd,) [i. e.] the Original of the Scriptures, which is with God. (Jel.)

buEodN Ed bEd
buEodN [as an inf. n. used in the manner of a subst. signifies] Distance, or remoteness; (S, A, L, K; *) and so baEadN↓, (L, K,) accord. to most of the leading lexicologists, (TA, [see baEoda,]) [and buEodapN↓, for] you say, bayonanaA buEodapN, meaning [Between us two is a distance] of land or country, or of relationship. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Remoteness from probability or correctness; improbability, or strangeness: see baEuda. Hence the phrase, hecaA mina AlbuEodi bimakaAnK This is improbable, or extraordinary, or strange: often occurring in the TA &c.] ― -b3- Also i. q. buEodN↓: (L, K:) this latter (S, L, Msb, K) and buEodN, (L, K,) accord. to most of the leading lexicologists, as, for instance, in the Kur xi. 98, (TA, [see baEida,]) signifying Perdition; (S, L, Msb;) or death. (K.) ― -b4- Judgment and prudence; as also buEodapN↓: so in the phrase, UinRahu lacuw buEodK, and buEodapK, Verily he is possessed of judgment and prudence: (K:) or penetrating, or effective, judgment; depth, or profundity; far-reaching judgment. (TA.) [See also OaboEadu.] cuw AlbuEodapi↓ also signifies A man who goes to a great length, or far, in hostility. (L.) ― -b5- A cursing; execration; malediction; as also biEaAdN↓. (K.) You say, buEodN lahu, as well as buEodFA lahu: see 1, last sentence but one. (TA.)

baEiydN Eyd bEyd
baEiydN Distant; remote; far; far off; (S, L, K; *) as also buEaAdN↓, and baAEidN↓: (L, K:) pl. (of the first, S, L) buEodaAnN (S, L, K) and (of the first also, L, TA) buEudN (L, K) and biEaAdN (TA) and (of the first and second, L) buEadaMCu (L, K) and of the third, baEadN↓, [but this (which is also used as a sing. epithet, as will be shown in what follows,) is properly a quasi-pl. n.,] like as xadamN is of xaAdimN. (S.) As signifying Distant with respect to place, it is correctly used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and dual and pl.; (L, and TA in this art. and in art. qrb, in which latter see the authorities;) but not necessarily; like its contr. qariybN: (L:) you say, hiIa baEiydN minoka [She is distant from thee; or it is] as though you said, makaAnuhaA baEiydN:
(L:) also maA Oanota minRaA bibaEiydK [Thou art not distant from us ], and maA Oanotumo minRaA bibaEiydK [Ye are not distant from us]: and in like manner, maA Oanota minRaA bibaEadK↓, and maA Oanotumu minRaA bibaEadK↓. (S, TA.) [But it receives, sometimes, the fem. form when used in this sense; for] jalasotu baEiydFA minoka and baEiydapN minoka are phrases mentioned as signifying I sat distant, or remote in place, or at a distance, or aloof, from thee; makaAnFA [and naAHiyapF or the like] being understood. (L.) You say also, manozilN baEadN↓ A distant, or remote, place of alighting or abode. (K.) And tanaHRa gayora baEiydK (S, K) and gayora baAEidK↓ and gayora baEadK↓ (K) [Retire thou not far;] meaning be thou near: (S, K:) [or] the second and third of these phrases mean retire thou not in an abject, or a mean, or contemptible, or despicable, state. (S, A.) And AinoTaliqo yaA fulaAnu gayora baAEidK↓ [Depart thou, O such a one, not far;] meaning mayest thou not go away! (L.) [And raOayotuhu mino baEiydK I saw him, or it, from afar: and jaMCa mino baEiydK He came from afar: and the like. And baEiydN as applied to a desert and the like, meaning Far extending.] And buEodN baAEidN↓ A far distance. (K.) [And niyRapN baEiydapN A distant, far-reaching, or far-aiming, intention, purpose, or design.] And fulaAnN baEiydu AlhimRapi [Such a one is far-aiming, or faraspiring, in purpose, desire, or ambition]. (A.) And hiIa baEiydapu AlEahodi [She was known, or seen, or met, a long time ago]: in this case, the fem. form, with p, must be used. (L.) And qawolN baEiydN [A saying far from being probable or correct; improbable; far-fetched; extraordinary, or strange]. (A.) And OamorN baEiydN An extraordinary thing or affair or case, of which the like does not happen or occur. (L.) ― -b2- Also Distant with respect to kindred or relationship: in which sense, the word receives the fem. form, [as well as the dual form, and pl. forms, like its contr. qariybN,] by universal consent. (TA.) [Its pl.] buEadaMCu signifies Strangers, that are not relations. (IAth.) You say also, fulaAnN mino buEodaAni AlOamiyri [meaning Such a one is of the distant dependents, or subjects, of the governor, or prince]. (S.) And UicaA lamo takuno mino qurobaAni AlOamiyri fakuno mino buEodaAnihi [If thou be not of the particular companions, or familiars, of the governor, or prince, then be of his distant dependents, or subjects]; i. e., be distant from him, that his evil may not affect thee. (AZ, A.) ― -b3- raOayotuhu baEiydaAti bayonK: see baEodN in the latter half of the paragraph. ― -b4- See also baAEidN.

OaboEadu c
OaboEadu More, and most, distant or remote; further, and furthest: by poetic licence written OaboEadRu: (L:) [pl. OabaAEidu; as in the saying,] fulaAnN yasotajirRu AlHadiyva mino OabaAEidi OaToraAfihi [Such a one draws forth talk, or discourse, or news, or the like, from its most remote sources]. (A.) ― -b2- More, and most, extreme, excessive, egregious, or extraordinary, in its kind. (IAth.) [Hence, perhaps,] UinRahu lagayoru OaboEada [in the CK OaboEadK] and buEadK↓ Verily there is no good in him: (K:) or, no depth in him in anything: (IAar:) [or, he is not extraordinary in his kind: see also buEodN:] said in dispraising one. (TA.) And maA Einodahu OaboEadu and buEadN↓ [He has not what is extraordinary in its kind: or] he possesses not excellence, or power, or riches: or he possesses not anything profitable: (L, K:) said only in dispraising one: (AZ:) or it may mean he possesses not anything which one would go far to seek; or, anything of value: or what he possesses, of things or qualities that are desirable, is more extraordinary than what others possess. (MF.) ― -b3- Remote from good: [which is the meaning generally intended in the present day when it is used absolutely as an epithet applied to a man; but meaning also remote from him or those in whose presence this epithet is used, both as to place and as to moral condition:] and, from continence: (L:) and stupid; foolish; or having little, or no, intellect or understanding; syn. HaAYinN: (so in a copy of the S and in the L and TA:) or treacherous, or unfaithful; syn. xaAYinN (So in two copies of the S and in a copy of the A.) It is used as an allusion to the name of a person whom one would mention with dispraise; as when one says, halaka AlOaboEadu [May such a one, the remote from good, &c., perish!]: with respect to a woman, one says, halakati AlbuEodaI. (En-Nadr, Az.) One says also, kabRa QllRehu AlOaboEada lifiyhi, meaning [May God cast down prostrate such a one, the remote from good, &c., upon his mouth! or,] cast him down upon his face! (S.) [It is a rule observed in decent society, by the Arabs, to avoid, as much as possible, the mention of opprobrious epithets, lest any person present should imagine an epithet of this kind to be slily applied to himself: therefore, when any malediction or vituperation is uttered, it is usual to allude to the object by the term AlOaboEad, or AlbaEiyd, as meaning the remote from good, &c., and also the remote from the person or persons present. See also AlOaxiru, which is used in a similar manner.] ― -b4- A more distant, or most distant, or very distant, relation; (Lth;) contr. of Oaqorabu: (Msb:) pl. OabaAEidu (Lth, S, A, Msb, K) and OaboEaduwna; (Lth;) contr. of OaqaAribu (Lth, S, K) and Oaqorabuwna. (Lth.)

And it is said in a prov., Oanota kaSaAHibi AlbaEorapi [Thou art like the owner of the piece of bEr, or Oanota fiI mivoli SaAHibi AlbaEorapi Thou art in a condition like that of the owner of the piece of bEr; (meaning the person for whom it was intended;) applied to him who reveals a thing relating to himself; (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 85;)] originating from the fact that a man had a suspicion respecting some one among his people; so he collected them to search out from them the truth of the case, and took a piece of bEr, and said, “I am about to throw this my piece of bEr at the person whom I suspect;” whereupon one of them withdrew himself quickly, and said, “Throw it not at me;” and confessed. baEoDN ED bED
baEoDN Some, or somewhat or some one, (lit. a thing,) of things, or of a thing: Th says that it signifies thus accord. to all the grammarians; (Msb, TA;) except Hishám, as will be seen hereafter: (TA:) or a part, or portion, (A, Msb, K,) of a thing, (Msb,) or of anything; (A, K;) whether little or much: (TA:) accord. to both these explanations, it may denote the greater part; as eight of ten: (Msb:) [thus it signifies some one or more; and it relates to persons and to other things:] pl. OaboEaADN; (S, IJ, K;) but ISd doubts whether IJ had an authority for this. (TA.) You say, baEoDu AlXRarRi Oahowanu mino baEoDK [Some kinds of evil are easier to be borne than some]. (A.) And jaAriyapN HusRaAnapN yuXobihu baEoDuhaA baEoDFA [A very beautiful girl, parts of whom resemble other parts]. (A.) [And Daraba baEoDuhumo baEoDFA Some of them beat some; i. e. they beat one another.] And labivonaA yawomFA Oawo baEoDa yawomK [We have tarried a day or part of a day]. (Kur xviii. 18.) And one says to a man of a company of men, “ Who did this? ” and he answers, OaHadunaA or baEoDunaA [Some one of us]; meaning himself. (A.) The article Al should not be prefixed to it, (K, * TA,) because it is originally a prefixed n., and as such determinate either literally or virtually, so that it does not admit another cause of being determinate; (TA;) contr. to what is said by IDrst (K, TA) and Ez-Zejjájee; for they said AlbaEoDu and AlkulRu; which, properly, as ISd says, is not allowable; and it is said in the O that IDrst, in this matter, was at variance with all the people of his age: (TA:) AHát says that the Arabs did not say AlkulRu nor AlbaEoDu, but that people used these expressions, even Sb and Akh in their two books, by reason of their little knowledge in this way: (K, * TA:) a remark, says MF, which is extr., and needs no comment: (TA:) [for who surpassed Sb and Akh in knowledge respecting matters of this kind?] AHát also relates his having told As that he had seen in the book of [that celebrated and chaste author] Ibn-ElMukaffa', AlEilomu AlkaviyrN wa lekinRa Oaxoca AlbaEoDi xayorN mino taroki AlkulRi [Science is large; but the acquiring of part is better than the neglecting of the whole]; and that As disapproved of it most strongly, saying that the article Al is not prefixed to baEoDN and kulRN because they are determinate without it: (TA:) Az, however, says that the grammarians allow its being prefixed to these two words, (Msb, TA,) though As disallows it, (TA,) because they are meant to be understood as prefixed ns.; (Msb;) or because the article is meant to be a substitute for the noun to which they should be prefixed; or, in the case of baEoDN, because this word is equivalent to juzoCN, which receives the article Al. (MF.) It is related of AO, that he assigned also to baEoDN the contr. meaning of All; or the whole: adducing as a proof thereof the words of the Kur [xl. 29], yuSibokumo baEoDu QlRaciI yaEidukumo as meaning All of that with which he threateneth you will befall you: and the saying of Lebeed.
Oawo yaEotaliqo baEoDa AlnRufuwsi HimaAmuhaA
[as meaning Or their death shall cling to all living creatures: or, accord. to another relation, Aw yarotabiTo, which means the same as Aw yEtlq]: thus also AHeyth explains the above-cited verse of the Kur; and thus Hishám explains the saying of Lebeed, erroneously asserting that bED is here a pl.: (TA:) but with respect to the former instance, the Prophet had threatened them with two things, the punishment of the present world and that of the world to come; so he says, “ This punishment will befall you in the present world; ” which is part (bED] of the two threats; without denying the punishment of the world to come: or, as Aboo-Is-hák says, he mentions the part to indicate the necessary consequence of the whole: and as to the saying of Lebeed, by bED Alnfws he means himself. (TA [app. from ISd].)

(TA.) ― -b2- bgRl, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He was impotent and weak, or languid, and fatigued, (JK, K, TA,) in going, or pace. (TA.) ― -b3- bgRlt AlUibilu, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) (tropical:) The camels went a pace between that termed hamojalap and that termed Eanaq: (S, * K, TA:) and hence bagolN↓ is derived accord. to IDrd: (TA:) or they went in a certain manner, with wide step: (JK:) [see also 5:] or the inf. n. signifies the going in a gentle manner: and one says, OaEoyaA fabagRala, i. e. [he was fatigued, so] he went an easy, but a quick, pace; syn. hamolaja. (TA.) ＝ -A2- bagRalahumo, (inf. n. as above, TA,) (tropical:) He made their children to be base-born, or ignoble, (K, TA,) by marrying among them; (IDrd, TA;) as also bagalahumo↓, aor.
bagala
: (K:) from bagolN; because the bgl [or mule] is unable to equal the heat, or course, of the horse. (TA.)

5 tbgRl tbgl
5. tbgRl He (a camel) became like the bagol [or mule] in the width of his step. (TA.) [See also 2.]

bagolN bgl gl
bagolN The mule; i. e. the animal generated between the he-ass and the mare [or sometimes between the horse and the she-ass]; (TA;) also called bagRaAlN↓; so in a verse of Jereer: (S, Sgh:) pl. OabogalN [a pl. of pauc.] (JK) and OabogaAlN, [also] a pl. of pauc., (Msb,) and bigaAlN, (JK, S, Msb, K,) a pl. of mult.; (Msb;) and quasi-pl. n. maboguwlaMCu↓, (K,) meaning a number of mules (bigaAl) together: (JK, * S:) the female is termed bagolapN; (S, Msb, K;) pl. bagalaAtN and bigaAlN. (Msb.) See 2, in two places. You say TariyqN fiyhi OabowaAlu AlbigaAli [A road in which is the urine of mules]; meaning (assumed tropical:) a difficult road. (TA.) And fulaAnapu OaEoqaru mino bagolapK [Such a woman is more barren than a she-mule]. (TA.) And Albagolu nagolN wa huwa lahu OaholN [The mule is a bastard, and he is a relation to him]; meaning (assumed tropical:) he is a bastard. (TA.) And as the mule suggests the idea of evil disposition, or perverseness, and roughness, you say, in describing him who is low, or ignoble, huwa bagolN nagolN (assumed tropical:) [he is a mule, a bastard]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) The people of Egypt say, AiXotaraI fulaAnN bagolapF HasonaMCa, meaning (tropical:) [Such a one bought a beautiful] female slave: and fiI bayoti baniI fulaAnK bigaAlN [(tropical:) In the house of the sons of such a one are slaves, or female slaves]: and AiXotarayotu mino bigaAli Alyamano wa lekino bigaAliI AlvRamano [(tropical:) I bought of the slaves, or female slaves, of El-Yemen, but for a high price]. (TA.)

bagRaAlN bgAl bgl gAl gAly
bagRaAlN [n. un. of bagRaAlapN↓, which is a coll. gen. n., like HamRaArapN and jamRaAlapN, but explained by Freytag as meaning “ he who possesses many mules; ”] An owner, or attendant, (Sb, S,) of mules, (Sb, TA,) or of the mule. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also bagolN, with which it is syn.

bagRaAlapN bgAl bgAlh bgAlp bgl gAl
bagRaAlapN: see what next precedes.

entry.key: huwa mina AlvRawori Oabogalu wa mina AlHimaAri Oavoqalu

superEntry.entry:
huwa mina AlvRawori Oabogalu wa mina AlHimaAri Oavoqalu c
huwa mina AlvRawori Oabogalu wa mina AlHimaAri Oavoqalu (assumed tropical:) [He is more mulish than the bull, and more heavy, or sluggish, than the ass]. (TA.)

maboguwlaMCu mbgwlMC
maboguwlaMCu: see bagolN.

1 bagamato bgmt
1. bagamato, aor.
bagima
(S, K) and
bagama
and
baguma
, (K,) inf. n. bugaAmN (JK, S, K) and buguwmN; (JK, K;) and tbgRmt↓; (K;) She (a gazelle) uttered a cry: (S:) or uttered her softest, or gentlest, cry (JK, K) to her young one: (K:) and sometimes it is said of a [wild] cow: (TA:) so too bagama said of a male gazelle: and the verb is also used transitively, said of a female gazelle uttering this cry to her young one. (JK.) Also, (S, K,) ↓both verbs, (K,) She (a camel) uttered a cry without clearness: (S:) or uttered a broken, or an interrupted, not a prolonged, yearning cry, to, or for,
her young one: (K:) or uttered a weak cry, below that [grumbling cry] which is termed rugaMC. (Ham p. 233.) [See an ex. in a verse of Dhu-rRummeh cited voce UilRaA.] And bagama and tbgRm↓ said of the vayotal and UiyRal and waEil, [all of which words are said to signify the mountain goat,] He uttered a cry. (K.) ― -b2- bagamahu, (S, K,) and bagama lahu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He spoke to him obscurely, not expressing clearly to him the meaning of his speech to him; (S, K;) taken from the bugaAm of the she-camel; because it is a cry not uttered clearly. (TA.)

3 baAogama
3: bAgmhu, (K,) inf. n. mubaAgamapN, (S,) (tropical:) He talked with him with a soft, or gentle, voice: (S, K, TA:) or AlmubaAgamapN is like AlmunaAgamapu, and means the speaking [with another] faintly; taken from the bugaAm [see 1] of the gazelle and the she-camel: (Ham p. 233:) or the holding amatory and enticing talk, or conversation, with another, with a soft, or gentle, voice. (TA.)

5 tabagRama
5: see 1, in three places.

6 tabaAogama
6: [tabaAgamato They (gazelles) uttered cries, or their softest or gentlest cries, one to another.] One says, mararotu birawoDapK tatabaAgamu fiyhaA AlZRibaMCu [I passed by a meadow in which the gazelles were uttering cries, &c., one to another]: and bigizolaAnK yatabaAgamona [by gazelles uttering cries, &c., one to another]. (TA.)

bugomapN bgmh bgmp gm gmp
bugomapN A thing like the qilaAdap, [a necklace,] with which women ornament themselves. (TA.) [But this is apparently post-classical, from the Turkish buwgomaqo. In the present day, it is applied to A necklace of pearls.]

bugaAmN bgAm gAm
bugaAmN The crying, or cry, of the female gazelle, and of the she-camel, as explained above: see 1. (S.)

baguwmN bgwm
baguwmN A female gazelle uttering, or that utters, the cry termed bugaAm. (S, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A woman having a soft, or gentle, voice. (JK, TA.)

maboguwmN mbgwm
maboguwmN A young gazelle, and a young camel, to which the cry termed bugaAm is addressed by its mother. (JK.) ― -b2- One says, also, bugaAmN maboguwmN [A cry &c. uttered]; like as one says, qawolN maquwlN. (TA.)

1 bagaA AlXRaIoCa c
1. bagaA AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. bagowN, He looked at the thing [to see] how it was; (K;) as also bagaI, (K in art. bgI,) inf. n. bagoIN. (TA in that art.)

1 bagaI bgI bgy gy
1. bagaI, (S, K, &c.,) aor.
bagiIa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. bugaMCN, (S, Mgh, K, &c.,) or this is a simple subst., and the inf. n. is bagoIN, (Msb,) [but, if this be correct, the former is generally used for the latter,] and bugFI, (Lh, K,) but the first is better known, and is the chaste form, and some say, bigFI, (TA,) and bugoyapN and bigoyapN, (K,) accord. to Th, but others hold these two to be simple substs., and some mention also bagoyapN, with fet-h, (TA,) and bugaAyapN, (As, S, TA,) He sought; sought for, or after; sought, desired, or endeavoured, to find, and take, or get; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.;) a stray-beast, (As, S, TA,) or any other thing, (S, Mgh, * Msb, * K, * TA,) good or evil; (Lh, TA;) as also AbtgI↓ and tbgRI↓ (S, Msb, K) and AstbgI↓: (K:) or AbtgI↓ signifies he sought, &c., diligently, studiously, sedulously, or earnestly: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and bagaI signifies also he loved, or affected, a thing: (MF, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the inf. n. signifies the seeking to exceed the just bounds in respect of that which one aims at, or endeavours after, whether one actually exceed or do not; and sometimes it is considered in relation to quantity; and sometimes, in relation to quality. (TA.) You say, bagaAhu biXarRK [He sought him with an evil purpose; or sought to do him evil]. (S and K in art. Eqb.) ― -b2- And bagaAhu He sought, &c., a thing for him; like bagaI lahu. (Lh, Mgh, * K. *) You say, bagaAhu AlXRaIoCa He sought, &c., the thing for him; (S, K;) as also AlXRaIoCa AbgAhu↓: (K:) thus you say, AiboginiI kacaA or kcA OaboginiI↓ and Aiboga liI kcA Seek thou for me such a thing; (TA;) and DaAlRatiI OaboginiI↓ Seek thou for me my stray-beast: (Mgh:) or AlXRaICa AbgAhu↓ signifies He aided, or assisted, him to seek the thing: (Ks, K:) or kacaA OaboginiI↓ signifies Seek thou for me such a thing; and also Aid thou me to seek such a thing. (JK.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 47], yaboguwnakumu Alfitonapa They seek, or desire, for you discord, or dissension; or they seeking, &c.: and in the same [iii. 94], taboguwnahaA EiwajFA Ye seek, or desire, for it, namely, the way [of God], crookedness; or ye seeking, &c.: the first objective complement of the verb being in the accus. case because of the suppression of the preposition l. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] bagaAniI daMCF It procured to me disease; it caused disease to befall me. (Ham p. 794.) And UinRahu lacuw bugaAyapK Verily he is one who makes much gain: (JK, K:) but in the M, cuw bugaAyapK lilokasobi, meaning a seeker of gain. (TA.) And maAbugiIa lahu Good was not appointed to betide him. (TA.) ― -b4- bagaI EalaI Oaxiyhi, inf. n. bagoIN, He envied his brother; he wished that a blessing, or cause of happiness, or an excellence, might become transferred from his brother to himself: so says Lh, who holds this to be the primary signification of the verb. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlbagoIu EiqaAlu AlnRaSori [Envy is the shackle of aid from God against an enemy or a wrongdoer]. (TA.) ― -b5- Hence, (Lh, TA,) bagoIN signifies The acting wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically; (Lh, S, TA;) because the envier so acts towards the envied; his endeavour being to cause, by guile, the blessing of God upon him to depart from him: (Lh, TA:) or the seeking, or endeavouring, to act corruptly, wrongly, or unjustly: (Az, TA:) or the exceeding the due bounds, or just limits, in any way: (S:) accord. to Er-Rághib, it is of two kinds: one of these is approved, and this is the passing beyond the bounds of equity to exercise beneficence, and beyond the bounds of obligatory duties to do what is not obligatory: the other is disapproved, and this is the passing beyond the bounds of that which is true, or right, to do that which is false, or wrong, or to do acts of a doubtful nature: but in most instances it is that which is disapprove. (TA.) You say, bagaI Ealayohi, (S, K,) and bgI EalaI AlnRaAsi, (Az, Msb,) aor.
bagiIa
, (K,) inf. n. bagoIN, (Msb, K,) He exalted himself against him, or above him; overpowered, or oppressed, him; (Fr, S, K;) acted wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards him; and deviated from the right way: (K:) and he acted wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, towards men, or the people, (Az, Msb,) and sought to annoy them, or hurt them. (Az, TA.) Lh mentions, on the authority of Ks, the saying, maA liI walilobagi baEoDikumo EalaI baEoDK [What have I to do with wrongful conduct, the wrongful conduct of one of you towards another?], for walilobagoIi; ISd thinks, because of the difficulty found in pronouncing the kesreh after the I. (TA.) bagaI also signifies He occupied himself with corrupt, wrong, or unjust, conduct: [accord. to Fei,] from the same verb [in a sense to be mentioned below,] said of a wound. (Msb.) Also, aor.
bagiIa
, (TA,) inf. n. bagoIN, (Az, TA,) He magnified himself; or behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently: (Az, TA:) because he who does so passes beyond the bounds of his proper station to a station that does not belong to him. (TA.) ― -b6- And [hence,] bagaI fiI miXyatihi, (K,) inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) He [app. a horse, and perhaps a man also,] was proud, or self-conceited, and quick, in his gait: (K:) or bagoIN in a horse, (S, TA,) or in the running of a horse, (JK, TA,) is the being proud, or self-conceited, with exceeding briskness or liveliness or sprightliness. (JK, S, TA.) ― -b7- And bagati AlsRamaMCu, (S, K,) inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) The sky rained vehemently: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or exceeded, in rain, the limit of what was wanted. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And bagaI AlwaAdiI The valley flowed with water reaching to a place to which it had not reached before. (S, TA.) ― -b8- bagato, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) said of a woman, (Th, IKh, S, Msb, and so in some copies of the K,) or of a female slave, (so in other copies of the K,) but it is not restricted to the latter, (TA,) aor.
bagiIa
, (JK, Msb,) inf. n. bigaMCN, (IKh, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, TA,) or bagoIN, (ISd, K,) [but the former, only, is commonly known,] She committed fornication, or adultery; she prostituted herself; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because she who does so transgresses her proper bounds; (TA;) as also baAgato↓, (IKh, S, * Msb, K,) inf. n. bigaMCN (IKh, K) and mubaAgaApN, (K,) said of a female slave: (Msb:) or mbAgAp signifies the committing fornication, or adultery, with another. (KL.) It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 33], walaA tukorihuw fatayaAtikumo EalaI AlbigaMCi [And compel not ye your young women to prostitute themselves]. (Mgh.) And you say, xarajati AlmaroOapu tubaAgiI↓ [The woman went forth for prostituting herself]. (S.) Accord. to the Jema etTefáreek, bigaMCN signifies The knowing of a woman's committing fornication or adultery, or prostituting herself, and approving, or being content: but this, if correct, is an amplification in speech. (Mgh.) ― -b9- bagaI AljuroHu, (JK, S, Msb,) aor.
bagaIa
, inf. n. bagoIN, (JK,) The wound swelled, (S,) and became in a corrupt state, (JK, S, Msb,) and produced thick
purulent matter. (JK.) And baraOa juroHuhu EalaI bagoIK His wound healed having somewhat of corruption in it. (S.) ― -b10- bagaI, (K,) aor.
bagiIa
, inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) also signifies He lied; said what was untrue. (K.)

maA nabogiI mA nbgI mA nbgy
maA nabogiI, in the Kur [xii. 65], is said to mean We do not lie: and we do not act wrongfully: or it may mean what do we seek, or desire? (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. bagoIN, (TA,) He looked at a thing [to see] how it was; (K;) and so bagaA, inf. n. bagowN: mentioned by Kr. (TA.) ― -b3- And, (K,) with the same inf. n., (TA,) He looked, watched, or waited, for a person or thing. (Kr, K.)

3 baAogaIa
3: see 1, latter part, in two places. ＝ -A2- Lh mentions the saying, addressed to a pretty woman, UinRaki lajamiylapN walaA tubaAgiI, as meaning Verily thou art pretty, and mayest thou not be smitten by the [evil] eye: (TA in this art.:) but accord. to some, the verb in this instance belongs to art. bwg or art. byg. (TA in art. bwg.)

4 OabogaIa
4: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- AbgAhu AlXRaIoCa also signifies He made him, or caused him, to seek the thing; to seek for it, or after it; to seek, or desire, or endeavour, to find, and take, or get, it. (S.)

5 tabagRaIa
5: see 1, first sentence.

6 tabaAgawoA tbAgwA
6. tabaAgawoA They acted wrong fully, injuriously, or tyrannically, one towards another; exalted themselves, one against, or above, another; overpowered, or oppressed, one another. (S, TA.)

7 AnbgI Onbg OnbgI Onbgy Onbgyy AnbgI Anbgy QnbgI
7. AnbgI is said in the S to be quasi-pass. of bagayotuhu, like as Ainokasara is of kasarotuhu; and Esh-Shiháb says of the aor. that it is quasi-pass. of bagaAhu, aor. yabogiyhi, in the sense of Talabahu: (TA:) [Fei says,] it has been asserted that AnbgI is quasi-pass. of bagaI; but a verb of the measure AnfEl is not used as a quasi-pass. unless it implies effort, and the consequence of an action, as in the case of kasarotuhu, of which the quasi-pass. is Ainokasara; which AnbgI does not: some, however, allow its being thus used: (Msb:) accord. to Zj, it is as though it were syn. with AinoTalaba, as quasi-pass. of Talaba, and means It was, or became, suitable, fit, meet, or proper; (Zj, TA;) [or right, and allowable; and good: or very requisite: (see explanations of exs. following:) or it behooved: and] it was, or became, facilitated, or easy; (Er-Rághib, K;) and practicable, or manageable. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Accord. to some, this verb is not used in the pret. tense, but only in the aor.: it is reckoned among verbs imperfectly inflected: (Msb, TA:) but the pret. is mentioned by AZ and Sb and Zj, and by ElKhattábee on the authority of Ks; and was often used by Esh-Sháfi'ee: it is, however, very rare. (TA.) You say, yanobagiI laka Oano tafoEala kacaA [It is suitable to thee, or is fit, meet, or proper, &c., for thee, or it behooveth thee, that thou shouldst do such a thing]. (S, TA.) And, accord. to Zj, AinobagaI lifulaAnK Oano yafoEala, as meaning It was, or became, suitable to such a one, or fit, meet, or proper, for him, that he should do, or to do, such a thing. (TA.) And maA yanobagiI laka Oano tafoEala hecaA, (Lh, K,) and mA yubotagaI↓, (K, TA,) with fet-h to the g, (TA,) and mA QnobagaI, and mA QbotugiIa↓; (Lh, K;) of which four phrases, the first is given by Lh as explanatory of the third and fourth, and means, accord. to Esh-Shiháb, It is not right, proper, fit, or meet, nor allowable, for thee that thou shouldst do this, or to do this; and it is not good for thee &c.; but he adds that only the aor. has been heard from the Arabs in this sense. (TA.) And yanobagiI Oano yakuwna kacaA It is very requisite that it should be so, or that such a thing ought be; [or it ought to be so, or such a thing ought to be; it behooves that it should be so, or such a thing behooves;] it is not well that such a thing should be neglected, or left undone. (Msb.) And Ks is related to have heard, from the Arabs, the phrase, maA yanobagiI Oano yakuwna kacaA, meaning It is not right that it should be so, or that such a thing should be: or it is not good &c. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xxxvi. 69], wamaA EalRamonaAhu AlXRiEora wamaA yanobagiI lahu, i. e. [And we have not taught him poetry, or versification], nor is it right, proper, fit, or meet, for him: (Bd:) or nor is it easy to him, (Bd, Jel, Er-Rághib,) or practicable to him. (Bd, Er-Rághib.)

8 UibotagaIa
8: see 1, first sentence, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 7, in two places.

10 UisotabogaIa
10: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- You say also, AstbgI Alqawoma fabagawohu and bagawoA lahu [He asked the people, or company of men, to seek a thing for him, and they sought it for him]. (Lh, K.)

bagoIN bgI bgy gy
bagoIN [originally an inf. n. (see 1)] Much of rain; or much rain: in [some of] the copies of the K, AlbTr is erroneously put for AlmTr: (TA:) [and in some, AlbagiIRu for AlbagoIu: in a MS. copy, I find AlbagiIRu Alkaviyru mina AlmaTari: and in the CK, AlbagiIRu Alkaviyoru mn AlnRaZari:] or bagoIu AlsRamaMCi signifies the main portion, (As, S,) or the vehemence, and the main portion, (Lh, JK, TA,) of the rain of the sky. (As, Lh, JK, S, TA.) Hence the saying, dafaEonaA bagoIa AlsRamaMCi xalofanaA (As, S, TA) or EanRaA (Lh, TA) [lit. We drove away the main portion, or the vehemence, and the main portion, of the rain of the sky behind us or from us; meaning it was driven away behind us or from us, or it departed; as is shown in art. dfE].

bugoyapN bgy bgyh bgyp gy gyp
bugoyapN: see what next follows.

bigoyapN bgy bgyh bgyp gy gyp
bigoyapN and bugoyapN↓ (JK, S, Msb, K) and bagiyRapN↓ (K) A thing sought; (JK, K;) as also bagaAyapN↓ [originally an inf. n. (see 1)]: (JK:) or a thing wanted, needed, or required; an object of want or need; a want, or needful or requisite thing or affair: (S, Msb:) as in the saying, liI fiIbaniI fulaAnK bagoyapN and bugoyapN [I have among the sons of such a one an object of want]: (S:) or the first signifies a state that one seeks; and the second, a thing itself that one wants: (As, S, Msb: *) and the first, (JK,) or third, (K,) signifies also a stray beast that is sought: (JK, K:) the pl. of the second is bugFI. (JK.) AirotadRato EalaI fulaAnK bigoyatuhu [The thing that he sought was refused to such a one] is said of one who finds not what he seeks. (TA.).

baguwRN bgw
baguwRN: see what next follows.

bagiIRN bgI bgy gy
bagiIRN, accord. to some, of the measure faEiylN; accord. to others, of the measure faEuwlN, originally baguwIN; [if of the former, originally meaning “ sought; ” and if of the latter, originally meaning “ seeking; ”] and therefore [in either case] not admitting the affix p: (TA:) A fornicatress, an adulteress, or a prostitute; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also baguwRN↓ [of the measure faEuwlN, and therefore anomalous, like nahuwRN]: (M, K:) bagiIRN is not applied to a man, (Lh, Msb,) nor bagiyRapN to a woman: (Lh, TA:) pl. bagaAyaA. (S, Mgh, Msb.) [See an ex. voce mahorN.] ― -b2- Also A female slave, (JK, S, K,) whether she be a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute or not; (TA;) not meant to imply revilement, though originally applied to female slaves because of their prostitution of themselves: (S:) or a free woman who is a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute: so in the K: but correctly, or a fornicatress or an adulteress or a prostitute, whether free or a slave: (TA:) and a female singer, though chaste; because of fornication's being originally attributable to such a person: (Msb:) pl. as above. (JK, S, TA.) One says, qaAmato EalaI ruWusihimu AlbagaAyaA [The female slaves stood over their heads]. (S.) ― -b3- bagaAyaA also signifies The scouts, or companies of scouts, that precede an army: (S, K, TA:) but the sing. of this is bagiyRapN↓. (TA.)

bagiyRapN bgy bgyh bgyp gy gyp
bagiyRapN: see bigoyapN. ＝ -A2- Also, pl. bagaAyaA: see bagiIRN, last sentence.

bugaAyapN bgAyh bgAyp gAyp
bugaAyapN: see bigoyapN.

baAgK bAg bAgy
baAgK Seeking; seeking for, or after; seeking, desiring, or endeavouring, to find, and take, or get: pl. bugaApN and bugoyaAnN (K) and bugRaMCN. (TA: [there mentioned as a pl., but not said to be of baAgK, nor explained.]) baAgK wahaAdK, lit. A seeker of [stray] camels and a guide of the way, mentioned in a trad. respecting the Hijreh (as said by A booBekr to a man who asked him “ Who are ye? ”), alludes to the seeking of religion and the guiding from error. (TA.) One says, farRiquwA lihecihi AlUibili bugoyaAnFA yuDibRuwna lahaA, i. e. [Disperse ye, for these camels, seekers] to scatter themselves in search thereof. (S.) ― -b2- Acting wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically, [&c.,] towards others: pl. bugaApN. (Msb. [See 1.]) gayora baAgK, in the Kur ii. 168, [&c.,] means Not being a revolter from the Muslims, (Jel,) or, against the Imám: (TA:) or it means not desiring to eat for the sake of enjoyment: or not seeking to exceed the limit of his want: (Az, TA:) or not seeking what he should not seek. (Er-Rághib, TA.) fiYapN baAgiyahN A company of men revolting from the just Imám. (K.) firoqapN baAgiyapN A party occupying itself with corrupt, wrong, or unjust, conduct. (Msb.) ― -b3- A camel that does not impregnate, or get with young. (Kr, K.) ― -b4- A horse that is proud, or self-conceited, with exceeding briskness or liveliness or sprightliness: (JK, Ham p. 210:) [but] Kh disallows its being thus used. baqarN a gen. n., (S, Msb,) a word of well-known meaning, (S, Msb, K,) [The bovine genus; the ox, or bull, and cow; and oxen, or bulls, and cows; neat; black cattle;] applied to the domestic and the wild: (TA:) [but the wild have also distinctive appellations, as will be seen below:] n. un. baqarapN, (S, Msb, K, [but in the K it is said that baqarN is pl. of baqarapN,]) which is applied to the male and the female; (S, Msb, K;) the p being added only to restrict it to unity: (S, Msb:) the pl. of baqarN is OaboqurN [a pl. of pauc.]; (M,) and OaboqaArN, meaning herds of oxen, or bulls, or cows: (Msb and TA in art. (Mgh.) ― -b2- baqaru AlwaHoXi [and Albaqaru AlwaHoXiIRu signify The wild ox, or bull, and cow; and wild oxen, or bulls, and cows, collectively: n. un. baqarapu AlwaHoXi and Albaqarapu AlwaHoXiyRapu; masc. and fem.: in Egypt, these appellations are applied to the antilope defassa of modern zoologists: so says Sir Gardner Wilkinson; and to this, I believe, they generally apply in the poems &c. of the early Arabs: it is a species of bovine antelope: in Barbary, it seems that the animal thus called is another species of bovine antelope, or perhaps a variety of the former; it is said to be what is termed by Pallas antilope bubalis; by others, alcephalus bubalis, or acronotus bubalis; and this is said to come occasionally to the Nile: but the Arabic appellations given above are employed with much laxity: thus we find baqaru AlwaHoXi explained as meaning] a kind of animal of which there are four different species: the first called mihiA [i. e. mahFA, a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is mahaApN]; the second, Ayl [i. e. UiyRalN]; the third yHmwr [i. e. yaHomuwrN], or yAmwr [i. e. yaOomuwrN]; the fourth, vyvl [or vayotalN], and also wEl [i. e. waEolN]: (Ed-Demeeree, cited by De Sacy, erroneously written by him “ Domaïri, ” in his Chrest. Ar. sec. ed. ii. 435 et seq.:) or what is called in Persian kwzn [or Gawazono (see also UiyRalN in art. Awl)]; it has a great horn, with branches; an additional branch growing upon its horn every year; and its horn is solid, thus differing from the horns of other animals, for their horns are hollow: when it hears singing, and the sounds of musical instruments, it listens thereto, and then it takes no care to guard itself from the arrows, by reason of its intense delight therein: when it raises its ear, it hears sounds; and when it relaxes it, it hears not anything. (Kzw: also cited by De Sacy, ubi suprà.) The Arabs regard baqar [meaning bqr AlwHX] as ominous of evil, because of the sharpness of their horns. (Ham p. 285.) ― -b3- miloCu masoki Albaqarapi [The quantity that fills the hide of the bull, or cow,] means (tropical:) a large quantity. (K, TA.) ― -b7- baqarN is also applied to (tropical:) A family, or household; those who dwell with a man, and whose maintenance is incumbent on him. (TA.) You say, jaACa fulaAnN yajurRu baqarahu (tropical:) Such a one came dragging along his family, or household. (A, * TA.) 7. AnbqE He went away quickly; (K;) and ran. (TA.)

8 AubotuqiEa lawonuhu AbtqE lwnh AbtqE lwnp
8. AubotuqiEa lawonuhu, with damm, i. q. AunotuqiEa, and AumotuqiEa; (the former in some copies of the K; the latter in others; and both in the TA;) i. e. His colour changed, (TA,) by reason of grief, or sorrow. (Har p. 244.) The last of these three verbs is the best. (Har ubi suprà.)

baqoEapN bqE bqEh bqEp
baqoEapN A place in which water remains and stagnates; (K;) [and which is not a usual place of watering: (see baAqiEapN:) this is what is meant, app., by its being said that] biqaAEN, which is its pl., signifies the contr. of maXaAriEu [or watering-places to which men and beasts are accustomed to come]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

buqoEapN bqE bqEh bqEp
buqoEapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and baqoEapN↓, (AZ, Msb, K,) but the former is the more common, (Msb,) and more chaste, (TA,) A piece, part, portion, or plot, (Mgh, Msb, K,) of land, or ground, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) differing [in any manner,] in colour, (Mgh,) or in appearance, or external state or condition, (K,) from that which adjoins it, or is next to it: (Mgh, K:) this is the primary signification: (Mgh:) [a patch of ground:] pl. biqaAEN, (S, K,) or this is pl. of baqoEapN, (Msb, TA,) and the pl. of buqoEapN is buqaEN. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) You say OaroDN fiyhaA buqaEN mina AljaraAdi [meaning Land in which are bare places occasioned by the locusts]. (Lh, K.) And fiI AlOaroDi mino nabotK In the land are small portions of herbage. (AHn.) And buqoEapN mino kalaO A patch of herbage. (TA in art. bqTF.) ― -b2- [The former also signifies A spot; or small portion of any surface, distinct from what surrounds it.] And the pl. buqaEN Places in a garment, or piece of cloth, which has been dyed, remaining undyed. (Mgh.) And buqaEu AlmaMCi Places in a garment, or piece of cloth, which has been washed, in which the water remains, undried. (Mgh.) ― -b3- huwa Hasanu AlbuqoEapi Einoda AlOamiyri (tropical:) He has a good station with the prince, or commander. (TA.) [See also julobapN.]

OaroDN baqiEapN c
OaroDN baqiEapN, Land in which are buqaEN mina AljaraAdi [meaning bare place occasioned by the locusts]: (Lh, K:) and land of which the herbage is unconnected [or in patches]. (TA.)

OaSaAbahu xuroCu baqaAEi c
OaSaAbahu xuroCu baqaAEi, like qaTaAmi, [indecl.,] and decl., (K,) and imperfectly decl., so that you say also baqaAEK, and baqaAEa, (AZ, TA,) Dust and sweat came upon him, and discolorations produced thereby remained upon his body: (AZ, K:) by bqAE is [lit.] meant land, or a land: so says AZ: and Ealayohi xuroCu baqaAE is said to mean upon him is sweat which has become white upon his skin, like what are termed lumaEN. (TA.)

baqiyEN bqyE
baqiyEN A place in which are roots of trees of various kinds: (S, K:) or a wide, or spacious, place: or a place in which are trees: (Msb:) or a wide, or spacious, piece of land; but not so called unless containing trees; (TA;) though baqyEu Algaroqadi continued to the name of a burialground of El-Medeeneh after the trees therein had ceased to be. (Msb, * TA.)

baAqiEapN bAqEh bAqEp
baAqiEapN A bird (K, TA) that is cautious, or wary, and cunning, or wily, that looks to the right and left when drinking, (TA,) that does not come to drink to the maXaAriE [or watering-places to which men and beats are accustomed to come], (K, TA, [but in the CK, for mXArE is put maXArib,]) and the frequented waters, (TA,) from fear of being caught, but only drinks from the baqoEap, i. e., the place in which water remains and stagnates. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) Any one that is cautious, or wary, cunning, or wily, and skilful: (TA:) (tropical:) a man possessing much cunning: (K, TA:) [accord. to some] so called because he alights and abides in [various] parts (biqaAE) of the earth, and often traverses countries, and possesses much knowledge thereof: to such, therefore, is likened (tropical:) a man knowing, or skilful, in affairs, who investigates them much, and is experienced therein; the p being added to give intensiveness to the signification: (TA:) and (tropical:) sharp, or quick, in intellect; knowing; whom nothing escapes, and who is not to be deceived, beguiled, or circumvented: (K, TA:) pl. bawaAqiEu. (TA.) You say, maA fulaAnN UilRaA baAqiEapN mina AlbawaAqiEi (tropical:) Such a one is none other than a very cunning man of the very cunning. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune, (S, TA,) that befalls a man. (TA.)

OaboqaEu c
OaboqaEu, applied to a guraAb [or bird of the crowkind], In which is blackness and whiteness; (S, TA;) and so applied to a dog: (Lh, TA voce Oaboraqu, q. v.:) or, applied to the former, having whiteness in the breast; and this is the worst [or most ill-omened] of the crow-kind: (TA:) [it is this species, accord. to some, which is called guraAbu Albayoni: (see art. byn:)] or, applied to a grAb &c., party-coloured, or pied: (Msb:) or the whitewinged grAb: (ISh, TA in art. Hcf:) pl., when thus applied, buqoEaAnN, (TA,) or biqoEaAnN, with kesr; the quality of a subst. being predominant in it; but when it is regarded as an epithet, [in which case the fem. is baqoEaMCu,] its pl. is buqoEN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened to such a bird, (tropical:) Anything bad, evil, wicked, mischievous, [ill-omened,] or the like. (TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Leprous. (IAar, K.) ― -b4-

buqoEaAnu AlXRaOomi c
buqoEaAnu AlXRaOomi, (S, K,) with damm, (K,) mentioned in a trad., (S,) (assumed tropical:) The servants and slaves of Syria; because of their whiteness and redness, (S, K,) or blackness; (S;) or because of their whiteness and redness and blackness likened to a thing such as is termed OaboqaEu; (TA;) or (K) because they are of the Greeks and the Negroes: (S, K:) or so called because of the mixture of their colours; their predominant colours being white and yellow: A'Obeyd says that what is meant is whiteness and yellowness, and they are thus called because of their difference of colours and their being begotten of two races: but Kt says, AlbuqoEaAnu signifies (assumed tropical:) those in whom is blackness and whiteness; and one who is white without any admixture of blackness is not called AbqE: how then should the Greeks be called bqEAn when they are purely white? and he adds that he thinks the meaning to be, the offspring of Arabs, who are black, [which is not to be understood literally, but rather in the sense of swarthy,] by female slaves of the Greeks, who are white. (TA.) ― -b2- buqoEN is also applied to Waterers (suqaApN); because their bodies become sprinkled with the water, so that some parts thereof are wetted. (K.) ― -b3- raOayotu qawomFA buqoEFA (tropical:) I saw a people wearing patched garments; said by El-Hajjáj; (K, TA;) and thus explained by him; i. e., by reason of their evil condition. (TA.) ― -b4- cawodN buqoEu AlcRuraI A herd of camels having white humps. (TA.) ― -b5- AlOaboqaEu The mirage; because of its varying, or assuming different hues.
(TA.) ― -b6- OaroDN baqoEaMCu Land containing [or diversified with] small pebbles. (TA.) ― -b7- sanapN baqoEaMCu (tropical:) A barren, or an unfruitful, year: (S, K:) or a year in which is fruitfulness and barrenness. (S, Msb, K.) And EaAmN OaboqaEu (tropical:) A year in which the rain falls in places of the land, not universally. (TA.) And EaAmN OubayoqiEu↓, (K,) the dim. form being used to denote terribleness, (TA,) (tropical:) A year of little rain. (K, TA.)

OubayoqiEu c
OubayoqiEu, dim. of OaboqaEu, which see, last sentence.

huwa mubaqRaEu AlrRijolayoni hw mbqE Alrjlyn
huwa mubaqRaEu AlrRijolayoni He has his legs wetted by water in some places, so that their [general] colour is different from the colour of those places. (TA.)

1 baqala bql ql
1. baqala: see 4, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] said of a boy's face, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
baauqa
, inf. n. buquwlN, (S,) (tropical:) It put forth its beard, (S, TA,) or hair; (K;) as also Abql↓ and bqRl↓; (K;) or this last is not allowable: (S:) similar to AixoDarRa said of a boy's mustache. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And said of a camel's tush, (tropical:) It cut, or came forth. (ISk, S, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, TA) appeared: (K, TA:) derived from baqolN, q. v. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He collected [plants, or herbs, of the kind termed] baqol for his camel. (Fr, K.) ― -b2- baqala Albaqola He cut the bql: so in the “ Mufradát. “ (TA.)

2 bqRl bql ql
2. bqRl, inf. n. taboqiyilN, He (a pastor) left camels to pasture upon baqol (TA.) ― -b2- And, [hence, app.,] inf. n. as above, i. q. saAsa (Sgh, K.) You say, bqRl AldRaAyRapa, i. e. saAsahaA, meaning He tended, or took care of, the beast well. (TK.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

4 Abqlt AlOaroDu c
4. Abqlt AlOaroDu The land produced [plants, or herbs, of the kind termed] baqol: (Msb:) or produced its bql: (S:) or produced plants, or herbage: (K:) or became green with plants, or herbage: (Mgh:) and baqalat↓ signifies the same: (IDrd, K:) both are chaste words. (IDrd, TA.) In like manner one says also of a place, Abql, (JK, Msb,) from baqolN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Abql AlrRimovu The [tree, or shrub, called] rmv became green; as also baqala↓: (K:) or it put forth what resembled young wingless locusts, and the greenness of its leaves became apparent. (S. [See also HanaTa.]) And Abql AlXRajaru The trees put forth their baAqil [q. v., app. buds,] in the days of the rabiyE [or spring], before their leaves became apparent: (JK:) or they put forth, in the time of the rbyE in their sides, what resembled the necks of locusts. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 1. ＝ -A2- Abql Alqawomu The people, or company of men, found [plants, or herbs, such as are termed] baqol. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also 8. ＝ -A3- Abql wajohahu (tropical:) He (God) made his (a boy's) face to put forth its hair, (K, TA,) meaning, its beard. (TA.)

5 tbqRl bql tbql
5. tbqRl He went forth seeking [plants, or herbs, of the kind called] baqol. (K.) ― -b2- See also 8, in three places.

8 Abtql AlHimaAru Abtql AlHmAr
8. Abtql AlHimaAru and tbqRl↓; (S;) or Abtqlt AlmaAXiyapu, (K,) or AlUibilu, (JK,) and tbqRlt↓; (JK, K;) The ass, or the beasts, or camels, pastured upon [plants, or herbs, of the kind called] baqol: (S, K:) or became fat from pasturing upon bql. (JK.) ― -b2- And Abtql Alqawomu The people, or company of men, had their cattle pasturing upon baqol; as also tbqRlwA↓ and AbqlwA↓: (K:) or they pastured their cattle upon bql. (JK.)

baqolN bql ql
baqolN a word of which the meaning is well known; (S;) [Leguminous, or tender, plants; such as we term herbs; i. e. plants, or vegetables, that may be gathered, with the hand, or depastured down to the ground, and that are only annuals;] plants which are neither shrubs nor trees; (Lth, JK, * Mgh;) such as, when depastured, have no stem remaining; thus differing from trees and shrubs, which have stems remaining [when they have been depastured]: (Lth, Mgh:) or the herbs, or herbage, produced by [the rain, or the season, called] the rabiyE: (Mgh:) or whatever herbs, or plants, grow from seed, (AHn, Mgh, K,*) not upon a permanent Oaruwmap [i. e. root-stock, or root]: (AHn, K:) and accord. to this definition may be explained the saying that the cucumber is of the things termed buquwlN [pl. of baqolN, meaning sorts, or species, of baqol], not of those termed fawaAkihu: (Mgh:) or the kind of which the root and branch do not last in the winter: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, it is said, (S, Mgh,) any plants, or herbs, whereby the earth becomes green: (S, IF, Mgh, Msb:) [pl. of pauc. OaboqaAlN: the pl. of mult. has been mentioned above:] the n. un. is with p, i. e. baqolapN. (S, K.) Hence the prov., laA tunobitu Albaqolapa UilRaA AlHaqolapu [Nothing produces the leguminous, or tender, plant, or herb, but the clear and open piece of good land]: (TA:) [i. e., only a good parent produces good offspring: (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 516:)] it is said to be applied to the case of a vile saying proceeding from a vile man. (TA in art. Hql.) The saying baAEa AlzRaroEa wa huwa baqolN means [He sold the seedproduce] when it was green, not yet ripe. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Albaqolapu, also, and Albaqolapu AlHamoqaMCu, (S,) or baqolapu AlHamoqaMCi, (K,) or all these, (TA,) signify the same as AlrRijolapu [i. e. Purslane; called by these names in the present day]; (S, K;) and so Albaqolapu AllRayRinpu and Albaqolapu AlmubaArakapu: or this last, i. q. AlhinodabaMCu [i. e. wild and garden succory, or endive]. (K.) ― -b3- baqolapu AlOanoSaAri i. q. Alkuronubu [or Alkuronabu, q. v., the name now given to Cabbage: in the CK Alkuronabu]. (K.) ― -b4- baqolapu AlxaTaATiyfi [Chelidonium, or celandine; thus called in the present day;] i. q. AlEuruwqu AlSRuforu. (K.) ― -b5- baqolapu Almaliki i. q. AlXRaAhotaraju [Fumaria officinalis, or common fumitory]. (K.) ― -b6- Albaqolapu AlbaAridapu i. q. AllRabolaAbu [now commonly applied to the Dolichos lablab of of Linnæus; but Golius explains the former appellation by hedera, i. e. ivy, though only as on the authority of the K]. (K.) ― -b7- Albaqolapu AlcRahabiyRapu i. q. AlqiTofu [or AlqaTafu, a name now given to Atriplex, or orache: Golius explains the former appellation by spinachium seu atriplex; and the latter, in its proper art., by atriplex herba, and androsœnum]. (K.) ― -b8- Albaqolapu AlyahuwdiyRapu [Sonchus, or sow-thistle; thus called in the present day]. (TA voce xubRaAzN, q. v.) ― -b9- Albaqolapu AlyamaAniyRapu [Blitum, or blite; and particularly the species called strawberry blite;] a certain herb. (K.) ― -b10- AlbaqolapN AlOutorujiyRapu [Citrago, or balmgentle;] a certain herb. (K.) ― -b11- baqolapu AlDRabRi and baqolapu AlrRumaApi and baqolapu AlrRamoli and [in the CK “ or ”] baqolapu AlbaraAriI and Albaqolapu AlHamoDaMCu, (K, TA,) or baqolapu AlHaAmiDapu, (CK,) are also Certain herbs. (K.) ― -b12- buquwlu AlOarojaAEi A certain plant proved by experience to remove pains from the belly. (K, TA.)

baladN baqilN bld bql
baladN baqilN and muboqilN↓ [A country, or region, or district, producing plants, or herbs, of the kind termed baqol. (JK.) And OaroDN baqilapN, (Msb, K,) [in the CK baqolapN, but it is] like fariHapN, (TA,) and baqiylapN↓ and muboqilapN↓, (JK, Msb, K,) Land producing baqol: (Msb:) or producing plants, or herbage: (K:) and the first and ↓second of these, (K,) and baqRaAlpN↓, erroneously written in the copies of the K baqRaAlapN, without teshdeed, (TA,) and maboqalapN↓ and maboqulapN↓, (K,) land having, or containing, baqol (K, * TA) of [the rain, or season, called] the rabiyE: (K:) or maboqalapN↓ [used alone, as a subst.,] signifies a land having, or containing, baqol; (JK;) or a place of baqol: (S:) and baAqilN↓ [app. as meaning producing baqol] is applied as an epithet to a place; (JK, Msb;) but not muboqilN↓; (JK;) or this last sometimes occurs, thus applied. (IJ, IB.)

buqolapN bql bqlh bqlp ql qlp
buqolapN The [plants, or herbs, termed] baqol of [the rain, or season, called] the rabiyE. (JK, K, TA.)

OaroDN baqiylapN c
OaroDN baqiylapN: see baqilN, in two places.

buquwliIRN bql bqwlI bqwly qwl
[buquwliIRN Of, or relating to, the plants, or herbs, termed baqol: from the pl. buquwlN.]

baqRaAlN bqAl
baqRaAlN [properly A green-grocer; i. e.] a seller of taraho [Persian for baqol]: and [by extension of its application] a shop-keeper: (KL:) or a seller of dry fruits: (Ibn-Es-Sem'ánee, TA:) vulgarly, a seller of eatables [of various kinds, and particularly of dried and salted provisions, cheese, &c.; a grocer]; correctly, badRaAlN. (AHeyth, T in art. bdl, K.) ― -b2- OaroDN baqRaAlpN: see baqilN.

baAqlN Oql bOql bAql
baAqlN: see baqilN. ― -b2- Also, as an epithet applied to the [tree, or shrub, called] rimov, (S, K,) Becoming green: (K:) or putting forth what resemble young wingless locusts, and showing the greenness of its leaves: they did not say muboqilN↓ [in this sense], in like manner as [it is commonly asserted that] they did not say muwrisN, from Oaworasa, but waAirsN. (S.) ― -b3- Also What comes forth, or come forth, in the sides of trees, in the days of the rabiyE [or spring], before their leaves become apparent. (JK.) [See 4.]

baAqilRFI Oql bOqly bOqlyy bAqlI bAqly
baAqilRFI and baAqilaMCN, (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the former with teshdeed and the latter without tesh-deed, (S, Mgh, Msb,) and baAqlFI, (K,) [every one with tenween when it has not the article Al,
for] the n. un. is with p, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e. baAqilRaApN and baqilaMCapN (S, Mgh, Msb) [and baqilaApN] or the sing. and pl. are alike, (El-Ahmar, K,) [and if so, the word may be fem., as Ibn-Buzurj, cited in the TA voce hinodabN, asserts baqilaMC to be, and therefore in every case without tenween,] i. q. fuwlN [Beans; or the bean; faba sativa of Jussieu; vicia faba of Linnæus]; (JK, K;) a name of the dial. of the Sawád [of El-'Irák]; its produce is called Aljirojiru; (TA; [but see jarojiyrN; and see turomusN;]) [or it is applied to the plant and to its produce;] a certain well-known HabR [or grain]: (Mgh:) the eating of it produces exhalations (K) of a gross kind, (TA,) and bad dreams, and sadar, (K,) i. e. vertigo, (TA,) and anxiety, and gross humours; but it is good for the cough, and for rendering the body fruitful (taxoSiyb Albadan); when properly qualified [app. by seasoning or by some admixture] (UicaA OuSoliHa), it preserves the health; and in its green state, together with ginger, it has the utmost effect in strengthening the venereal faculty: (K:) the pl. is bawaAqilu: and the dim. of bAqRlI is buwayoqilapN↓ and buwayoqiloyapN↓, the latter with the l quiescent because kesreh is disapproved in so long a word; [both forms indicating that bAqlRI is held to be fem.;] and that of bAqlMC is buwayoqilaMC [with or without tenween accord. as it is held to be masc. or fem.], or, if one will, he [who holds bAqlMC to be fem.] may say buwayoqlapN↓, suppressing the augmentative meddeh, and adding p to indicate the fem. gender; and that of bAqlRAp is buwayoqilaApN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- AlbaAqilRaI AlqboTiIRu [app. the same as AlbAqRlI AlmiSoriIRu mentioned in the K voce turomusN, &c., i. e. The Egyptian bean; an appellation said to be applied by some in the present day to the colocasia; but what it properly denotes is doubtful;] a certain plant, the grain of which is smaller than the fuwl [or bean]: (K:) the people of Egypt know it by the name of AljaAmisap, with jym, and with the unpointed syn: he who says that it is the turomus is in error. (Ibn-Beytár, cited by De Sacy in his “ Relation de l'Égypte par Abd-allatif, ” q. v., p. 97.)

baAqilRiIRN Oql bOqly bOqlyy bAqlI bAqly
baAqilRiIRN and baAqilaAYiIRN rel. ns. of baAqilRI and baAqilaMC, respectively. (Mgh.)

baAquwlN bAqwl
baAquwlN, (JK, A, O,) or buwqaAlN↓, (K,) A mug (kuwzN) having no Eurowap [or handle]; (JK, O, K;) i. q. kuwbN: (A, TA:) [in Spanish bokal, (Golius,) which favours the form in the K; but the Spanish word may be from buwqaAlapN, if from the Arabic:] pl. bawaAqiylu. (JK, A, TA.)

buwqaAlN bwqAl
buwqaAlN: see what next precedes.

buwqaAlapN A kind of drinking-vessel, like a TaAs, or like a kaOosi; syn. TarojahaArapN. (IAar, TA.) [See also baAquwlN.]

buwayoqilapN: see baAqilRKI, in four places.

buwayoqilaApF bwyqlAh bwyqlAp
buwayoqilaApF: see baAqilRKI, in four places.

buwayoqilaApN bwyqlAh bwyqlAp
buwayoqilaApN: see baAqilRKI, in four places.

muboqilN mbql
muboqilN: see baqilN, in three places: ― -b2- and see baAqilN.

maboqalapN mbqlh mbqlp
maboqalapN: see baqilN, in three places.

maboqulapN mbqlh mbqlp
maboqulapN: see baqilN, in three places.

baqRamN bqm qm
baqRamN [Brazil-wood; the wood of the Braziltree, a species of Cæsalpinia;] a well-known dye; (S, Msb;) i. q. EanodamN; (S;) [or rather the wood from which a well-known dye is prepared;] the wood of a certain great tree, the leaves of which are like those of the almond, and having a red stem, the decoction of which is used as a dye: it consolidates wounds, stops a flow of blood from any member, and dries up ulcers; and its root, or lowest part, is an instantaneous poison: (K:) the word is said by some to be Arabic; (Msb;) others say that it is arabicized; (S, Msb, TA;) [perhaps from the Persian baqamo, or bakamo;] and that the only other words of the same measure in the Arabic language are proper names, and four in number, (S TA,) or seven: (TA:) if used as a proper name, it is imperfectly decl., because determinate and of the measure of a verb. (S.)

1. baqaAhu biEayonihi, [aor.
baquwa
,] inf. n. baqaAwapN [and baqowapN, as will be seen from what follows, like raHomapN], He looked, (Lh, JK, ISd, K,) or looked long, or glanced lightly, (JK,) at him, or it; (Lh, JK, ISd, K;) and so with I for the last radical: (JK:) and baqaAhu [alone], with w and with I for the last radical, (K in art. bqI,) first pers. baqawotuhu and baqayotuhu, (Lh, TA,) he looked at him, or it: (Lh, K:) or he watched, or observed, him, or it: (K in art. bqI:) and bqwth I looked, watched, or waited, for him, or it: (K:) a dial. var. of baqayotuhu, which is the more approved. (TA.) [Hence,] Auboquhu baqowataka maAlaka and baqaAwataka maAlaka Guard thou, or preserve thou, him, or it, as thou guardest, or preservest, thy property. (M, Tekmileh, K.)
