baqowaI and buqowaI: see art. bqI.

1 baqiya bq bqI bqy bqyy qyAC
1. baqiya aor. yaboqaI, inf. n. baqaMCN (JK, S, Msb, K) and baAqiyapN; (Msb; [but see this latter below;]) [and accord. to the CK, baqFI and baqoIN; but this is a mistake; wabaqaI w baqoyFA being there erroneously put for baqaI baqoyFA, explained by what here follows;] and baqaI, [by some written baqaA,] (JK, S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (JK,) inf. n. baqoIN, (K,) of the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab, (TA,) or of that of Teiyi, (JK, S, TA,) who in like manner say baqato instead of baqayato, (S, TA,) and the like is done in other verbs of the same class, (S, Msb,) whether the kesreh and the I be original, as in baqiIa and nasiIa and faniIa, or accidental, as in the pass. verbs hudiIa and buniIa; (Msb;) [He, or] it, namely, a thing, remained, continued, lasted, endured: and was, or became, permanent, or perpetual; or continued, lasted, or existed, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever: syn. daAma, and vabata; (Msb;) contr. of faniIa: (K:) baqaMCN signifies a thing's remaining, continuing, lasting, or enduring, in its first state, to a period determined by the will of God, either with respect to its corporeal substance, as in the case of a heavenly orb, or with respect to its kind only, as in the case of the human and other animal races; and the continuing, lasting, or existing, for ever, either by self, as in the instance of God alone, or otherwise, and thus either with respect to the corporeal substance, as in the case of an inhabitant of Paradise, or with respect to kind only, as in the case of the fruits of the inhabitants of Paradise. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Hence,] daAru AlbaqaMCi [The abode of everlasting existence;] the world to come. (T in art. dwr.) The verb is said of a thing; and in like manner of a man, as in baqiIa zamaAnFA TawiylFA, i. e. He lived [or continued in life] a long time. (S.) [You say also, baqiIa EalaI HaAlihi He, or it, remained, or continued, in his, or its, state, or condition; i. e., as he, or it, was. And baqiIa EalaI AlXRidRapi He endured, or bore up against, difficulty, distress, or adversity.] And baqiI mina AlXRaIoCi baqiyRapN [A remain, remainder, remnant, relic, or residue, of the thing remained.] (S.) And baqiIa minohu kacaA Such a thing remained, over and above, and behind, thereof; as also tbqRI↓. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- baqaAhu, with I and with w for the last radical, (K,) first pers. baqayotuhu (Lh, S) and baqawotuhu, (Lh, TA,) aor. of the former
baqiIa
, (S,) inf. n. baqoIN, [of the former verb,] (K,) He looked at him, or it: (Lh, S, K:) or [so in the K, but in the S “ and, ”] he watched, or observed, him, or it: (S, K:) and baqayotuhu I looked, watched, or waited, for him, or it; (TA in art. bqw;) as also baqawotuhu; (K in that art.;) but the former is the more approved. (TA in that art.) [See also art. bqw.] You say also, fulaAnN yaboqiI AlXRaIoCa bibaSarihi Such a one looks at the thing, and watches, or observes, it. (JK.) And it is said in a trad., baqayonaA rasuwla QllRehi We looked, watched, or waited, for the Apostle of God. (S.)

4 AbqAhu Obq ObqAh ObqI AbqAh AbqAp Mbq MbqAh
4. AbqAhu (S, Msb, K) and bqRAhu↓ and tbqRAhu↓ (S, K) all signify the same, (S,) and AstbqAhu↓ likewise, (K,) He made, or caused, [and he suffered,] him, or it, to remain, continue, last; to be, or become, permanent, or perpetual; to continue, last, or exist, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever; he continued it; he perpetuated it. (Msb, K *) You say, AbqAhu QllRehu [God preserved him, or prolonged his life; or may God preserve him, or prolong his life; or] God made him, or caused him, or may God make him, or cause him, to continue in life. (S.) And OaboqaI OaSola AlXRaIoCi wajaEala vamarahu fiI sabiyli QllRehi He made the thing itself to remain unalienable, not to be inherited nor sold nor given away, and assigned the profit arising from it to be employed in the cause of God, or of religion. (TA in art. Hbs.) And Oaboqayotu maA bayonanaA I was sparing of marring, i. e., forbore from marring much, or exceedingly, that [state of union or amity] which subsisted between us. (K.) And naEolayoka waQboculo qadamayoka baqRi↓ [Pre-
serve thou, or spare thou, thy sandals, and use freely, or unsparingly, thy feet]: a prov. (Meyd. See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 149.) And tabaqRaho↓ watawaqRaho Preserve thou the soul (AlnRafosa Aisotaboqi↓), expose it not to destruction, [meaning preserve thyself,] and guard against evils, or calamities: a trad.: the h in each verb is that of pausation. (TA.) [And AbqI mina AlXRaIoCi baqiyRapF He left, or reserved, of the thing, a remain, remainder, remnant, &c.:] and mina AlXRaIoCi AstbqI↓ He left a portion of the thing; (S, K;) as also tbqRI↓; whence the prov., used to incite to liberality, laA yanofaEuka mino zaAdK tabaqRK↓ Leaving a portion of travel-ling-provision will not profit thee. (JK.) [And AbqI AlXRaIoCi and AstbqAhu↓ He reserved the thing for a future time or use &c.] And AstbqAhu↓ as meaning [He spared him; he let him live;] he left him alive; (S, K;) [as also AbqAhu; for] men say to their enemies when the latter have overcome, OaboquwnaA wa laA tasotaOoSiluwnaA [Spare ye us, and destroy us not entirely]: (TA:) [or AbqAhu, in a case of this kind,] and AbqI Ealayohi and AstbqAhu↓ signify He pardoned him, [and forbore to slay him,] when slaughter was his due: (TA:) and AstbqAhu↓ signifies also He pardoned, or forgave, his fault, wrong action, or lapse into sin, and preserved his love, or affection. (JK, TA. *) And [hence,] Oaboqayotu EalaI fulaAnK signifies also I showed mercy to such a one [by sparing him, or letting him live, or by pardoning him, or otherwise]; had mercy on him; pitied, or compassionated, him; syn. OaroEayotu Ealayohi and raHimotuhu. (S.) One says, laA OaboqaI QllRehu Ealayoka Uino Oaboqayota EalaIRa [May God not show mercy to thee if thou show mercy to me: a prov., said in derision to one who affects to show mercy when unable to take revenge]. (S, Meyd.) And laA tuboqi UilRaA EalaI nafosika [Show not mercy save to thyself: another prov., similar to the former]. (Meyd.) And it is said, in a trad., of the fire [of Hell], laA tuboqiI EalaI mano taDarRaEa UilayohaA, i. e. It will not pity [him who abases himself to it: or rather it will not spare &c.: and in like manner, laA tuboqiI walaA tacaru, in the Kur lxxiv. 28, is generally understood as meaning It (namely, Hell,) will not spare, nor leave unburned]. (TA.)

buqoyaA bqy bqyA
buqoyaA (JK, S, Msb, K, &c.) and baqoyaA↓ (TA) and baqowaI↓ (JK, S, Msb, K) and buqowaI↓ (Th, K) and ↓ (JK, K,) the ↓third and ↓fourth with I changed into w, like as w is changed into I in dunoyaA and EuloyaA and quSoyaA, (ISd, TA,) [substs. in the sense of UiboqaMCN, inf. n. of 4, signifying The making, or causing, and suffering, to remain, continue, last, &c.; preservation of a person in life, and of a thing in being; and the sparing, letting live, or leaving alive;] substs. from OaboqaAhu: (Msb, K:) or [the showing mercy by sparing or letting live, or by pardoning, or otherwise; having mercy; pitying, or compassionating;] substs. from Oaboqayotu EalaI fulaAnK. (S.) Thus one says of a pilgrim, that he put gum, or something glutinous, upon his head, and so caused his hair to become compacted, buqoyaA Ealayohi to preserve it in the state in which it was (expl. by UiboqaMCF Elyh), lest it should become shaggy, or dishevelled, &c. (L in art. lbd.) And one says, naXadotuka QllReha waAlbuqoyaA and AlbaqowaI↓ [I conjure, or beg, or beseech, thee by God and by the preservation of thy life]. (JK.) And maA liI Ealayoh raEowaI walaA baqowaI↓ [I have no mercy nor pity to bestow upon him]. (JK. [There expl. by the words OaIo OaroEayotu Ealayohi waOaboqayotu; but OaIo is evidently a mistranscription for mino, i. e. from.]) A poet (El-La'een ElMinkaree, TA) says,
famaA buqoyaA EalaIRa tarakotumaAniI
walekino xifotumaA Sarada AlnRibaAli
[And it was not to show mercy by sparing me that ye two left me; but ye feared the transpiercing of the arrows]. (S.) And another says, on his having refused to accept an offer of seven bloodwits,
OucakRaru biAlbuqoyaA EalaI mano OaSaAbaniI
wabuqoyaAIa OanRiI jaAhidN gayoru muWotaliI
i. e. Am I required [or exhorted or reminded] to show mercy to him who slew my relation, when the mercy that I show to him is that I am labouring to slay him, and not falling short, or being remiss: by bqyAI is meant UiboqaAYiI Ealayohi; though AlUiboqaMC is not Aljahod: the meaning is, that this is done by me in lieu of that: AlbuqoyaA is a subst. from AlUiboqaMC, syn. therewith; and the w prefixed to it is a denotative of state. (Ham p. 119. [This verse is also cited in the TA, but with the substitution of biAlbaqowaI↓ and wabaqowaAI for the corresponding words above.] AlbaqiyRapa↓ is said by men to their enemies when the latter have overcome; meaning [We ask, or beg, the being spared, or mercy, or quarter; a verb, whereby it is governed, being understood: or] OaboquwnaA walaA tasotaOoSiluwnaA [spare ye us, and destroy us not entirely]. (TA.)

baqiyRapN bq bqy bqyh bqyp qyAC
baqiyRapN A remain, remainder, remaining portion, remnant, relic, residue, or the remains, or rest, of a thing; (KL, PS, &c.;) a subst. from baqiIa as signifying “ it remained over and above, ” and “ it remained behind: ” pl. baqaAyaA and baqiyRaAtN: (Msb:) baAqiyapN↓, also, [pl. bawaAqK and baAqiyaAtN,] has the same meaning as baqiyRapN; (TA;) [i. e., as explained above; and so has baAqK↓, for XaIoCK baAqK &c.] You say, baqiIa mina AlXRaIoCi baqiyRapN [explained before: see 1]. (S.) [And humo baqiyRapu AlsRayofi, and baqaAyaA AlsRayofi, They are those who have been spared by the sword]. ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN mino baqiyRapi Alqawomi Such a one is of the best of the people, or company of men: because a man reserves the most excellent of the things that he produces. (Bd in xi. 118.) And fulaAnN mino baqiyRapi Oaholihi Such a one is of the most excellent of his people, or family. (Ham p. 78.) And fulaAnN baqiyRapu Alqawomi Such a one is the best of the people, or company of men: pl. baqaAyaA. (Kull p. 96.) ― -b3- Ouwluw baqiyRapK, in the Kur xi. 118, hence means Persons possessed of excellence: [see a phrase mentioned voce balalN:] or possessing a relic of judgment and intelligence: (Bd:) or persons of religion and excellence: (Jel:) or persons of understanding (K, TA) and discrimination: (TA:) or persons of obedience: (TA:) or having the quality of preserving themselves (Az, Bd, K, *) from punishment, (Bd,) by their holding the approved religion: (Az, TA:) and this last explanation is confirmed by another reading, which is AwlwA baqoyapK↓ [possessing a quality of watching, or observing, and hence, of guarding, or preserving]; baqoyap being the inf. n. of un. of baqaAhu, aor. yaboqiyhi, signifying “ he watched, ” or “ observed, ” &c., “ him, ” or “ it. ” (Bd.) See also buqayaA, in two places. baqiyRapN is also a subst. from Oaboqayotu maA bayonanaA [explained before: see 4: app. meaning Forbearance from marring much, or exceedingly, the state of unity, or of amity, subsisting between two persons, or parties: and such may be its meaning in the phrase above-mentioned (AwlwA bqyRp)]. (K.) ― -b4- baqiyRapu QllRehi, in the Kur xi. 87, [after the command, in the next preceding verse, to give full measure and weight,] means God's sustenance that remains for you after your giving full measure [and weight]: (Jel:) or that which God has preserved for you, of what is lawful, (Fr, Bd,) after [your] keeping aloof from that which he has forbidden you: (Bd:) or the good state, or condition, remaining for you: (Zj, K:) or the fear (muraAqabap) of God; accord. to some: (Fr, TA:) or the obedience of God, and (as Aboo-'Alee says, TA) the looking for his recompense: (K, TA:) or baqiyRapN and baAqiyapN↓ signify any religious service whereby one seeks to obtain the recompense of God; and such is the meaning of the former in this instance. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b5- See also baAqiyapN.

baAqK bAq bAqy
baAqK part. n. of baqiIa [in all its senses; Remaining, continuing, lasting, or enduring: and permanent, or perpetual; or continuing, lasting, or existing, incessantly, always, endlessly, or for ever: &c.: see 1]. (Er-Rághib, TA.) AlbaAqiI, a name of God, [as also, pleonastically, AlbaAqiI AlOabadiIRu, means The Everlasting, or] He whose existence will have no end. (TA.) See also baqiyRapN. ― -b2- AlbaAqiI also signifies The HaASil [or net produce, or perhaps simply the produce,] of the [tax termed] xaraAj, and the like. (Lth, JK, TA.)

baAqiyapN bAqy bAqyh bAqyp
baAqiyapN: see baqiyRapN, first sentence. ― -b2- AlbaAqiyaAtu AlSRaAliHaAtu [in the Kur xviii. 44, and xix. 79,] means Any righteous, or good, work, (K, TA,) of which the recompense remains: (TA:) or acts of obedience,
(Bd and Jel in xix. 79,) or good works, (Bd in xviii. 44,) of which the fruit remains for ever: (Bd in both those places, and Jel * in the former:) and, as included therein, [so Bd, but in the K “ or, ”] the five prayers; (Bd, K;) and the performance of the pilgrimage; and the keeping the fast of Ramadán; (Bd in xviii. 44;) and [so Bd, but in the K “ or, ”] the saying, suboHaAna QllRehi wa AlHamodulilRehi wa laA UilRaA QllRehu wa QllRehu Oakobaru; (Bd and Jel in xviii. 44, and K;) to which some add, wa laA Hawola wa laA quwRapa UilRaA biQllRehi: (Jel ibid.:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib, the correct meaning is any religious service whereby one seeks to obtain the recompense of God: see also baqiyRapN, last explanation. (TA.) ― -b3- baAqiyapN is sometimes put in the place of an inf. n.; (S, K;) or it is an inf. n.; (Msb;) syn. with baqaMCN; (S, Msb, TA;) with which baqiyRapN↓, also, is syn. (TA in art. srE.) So in the Kur [lxix. 8], fahalo taraI lahumo mino baAqiyapK [And dost thou see them to have any continuance?]; (S, TA;) so says Fr: (TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, baqiyRapK [i. e. a remnant]: (TA:) or jamaAEapK baAqiyapK [a company remaining]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or nafosK baAqiyapK [a soul, or person, remaining]: (Bd, Jel:) or the p is an intensive affix; (Jel;) [or a restrictive to unity;] i. e. one remaining; (Jel, TA;) and this is also allowable and good: one says, likewise, maA baqiyato baAqiyapN wa laA wa qaAhumo mina QllRehi waAqiyapN [One remaining remained not, nor did one preserver preserve them from God]. (TA.)

4 qado OabokaOa AldRarRa c
4. qado OabokaOa AldRarRa, occurring in a verse, [see Ham p. 758,] is asserted by Aboo-Riyásh to mean He (the milker) has found the milk to be little in quantity; like as OaHomadahu signifies “ he found him to be such as is praised: ” ISd holds that it may signify he has made the milk to be little in quantity [app. by his niggardness]; but he confesses his not having heard the verb used in this sense by any one. 2 bkRthu bkI bkp bkt bkth bktp bktth kt
2. bkRthu, inf. n. tabokiytN, He reprehended, reproved, blamed, chid, or reproached, him, for an affair, or for a crime or the like; (S, A, Msb, K;) accord. to some, with justice; (TA;) or he did so severely; (S, * TA;) and threatened him; (TA;) and declared his deed to be evil; (Msb;) as when one says, “ O wicked man! wast thou not ashamed? didst thou not fear God? ” (TA:) and sometimes this is done by using an enunciative phrase, such as the saying of Abraham, [mentioned in the Kur xxi. 64,] “ Nay, the chief of them, this, did it; ” for thus he said to reprove their worship of idols; (Msb;) and it may be by means of the hand, and a staff or stick, and the like. (Hr, TA.) ― -b2- He accused him, to his face, (Aisotaqobalahu, q. v.,) of that which he disliked, or hated; (As, A, K;) as also bakatahu↓, (As, K,) aor.
bakuta
, inf. n. bakotN. (TA.) ― -b3- He overcame him, biAlHujRapi [with the argument, allegation, or plea]; (S, A, K;) as also bakatahu↓; (A, TA;) and both, he obliged him to be silent by reason of his inability to reply. (Lth, TA.)

mubakRitN 1
mubakRitN A woman who usually brings forth a male child after a female. (K, TA.) [Such a woman is app. thus called because supposed to reproach her husband for his having been displeased with her on her bringing forth a female.]

1 bakara c and gadaA
1. bakara gadaA both [properly] relate to the beginning of the day: (AZ, Msb:) the former of these verbs, (T, S, A,) aor.
bakura
, inf. n. bukuwrN; (T, S;) and bkRr↓, (T, S, A,) inf. n. tabokiyrN; (T, S;) and Abkr↓, and Abtkr↓, (S, A,) and bAkr↓; (S;) all signify the same; (S;) He (a traveller, A) went forth early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise; syn. xaraja fiI Albukorapi: (T, A:) or Abkr↓, inf. n. UibokaArN, signifies he entered upon that time: (T:) one should not say bakura nor bakira in the sense of bkRr [&c.]. (S.) ― -b2- You say also, bakara Uilayohi, and Ealayohi, and fiyhi, inf. n. as above; and bkRr↓, and Abkr↓, and Abtkr↓; and bAkrhu↓; meaning OataAhu bukorapN [i. e. He came to him, or it, early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise: and he did it at that time: or bakara &c. with fiyhi following may be rendered he occupied himself at that time in doing it]. (K.) ― -b3- And [hence,] bakara Uilayohi, [and Ealayohi,] aor. and inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and bakira Alyh, aor.
bakara
; (ISd, K; * [but see a remark respecting this verb above;]) and Alyh bkr↓, (S, Msb, TA,) and Elyh; (TA;) and Alyh Abkr↓, (S, K,) and Elyh; [and Abkrhu↓;] and bAkrhu↓; (TA;) signify also (assumed tropical:) He hastened [or betook himself early] to it, or to do it, at any time, (S, Msb, K, TA,) morning or evening. (TA.) You say, bakarotu EalaI AlHaAjapi (assumed tropical:) [I hastened to do, or accomplish, or attain, the thing needed], inf. n. as above: and in like manner, EalaI Alwirodi Oabokarotu↓ (assumed tropical:) [I hastened to come to water]: (AZ, S:) and Alwiroda Abkr↓, (TA,) and AlgadaMCa, (AZ, S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He hastened to come to water, and to take the morning-meal. (TA.) Lebeed says,
baAkarotu jaAjatahaA AldRajaAja bisuHorapK
meaning (assumed tropical:) I hastened to be before the crowing of the cock, at the close of night, in obtaining what was wanted [of it, namely, of wine,] by me: (TA:) HAjthA being for HaAjatiI UilayohaA, i. e., UilaI Alxamori. (EM p. 170: but the first word is there written baAdarotu.) [See also 2, below.] ― -b4- [It is also said that] bkr [app. bakira,] inf. n. bkr, [app. bakarN,] signifies (assumed tropical:) He possessed the quality of applying himself early, or of hastening; expl. by kaAna SaAHiba bukuwrK. (Msb.) [But see bakurN.]

2 bkRr mbkt
2. bkRr, inf. n. tabokiyrN: see 1, in three places: and see 8. You say also, bkRr UilaI AljumoEapi (tropical:) He went forth to the [prayers of] Friday at the commencement of the time thereof. (A.) And bkRr [alone], inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He came to prayer at the commencement of its time. (K, TA.) And bkRr biAlSRalaApi (tropical:) He performed the prayer at the commencement of its time: (A, Mgh, Msb, TA:) he was regardful of it, and performed it early. (TA.) And bakRiruwA biSalaApi Almagoribi (tropical:) Perform ye
the prayer of sunset at the setting of the [sun's] disc. (S.) And bakRarati AlnRaxolapu biHamolihaA (tropical:) [The palmtree was early with its fruit]. (A.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He was, or became, or went, before; preceded; had, or took, precedence; syn. taqadRama; and so Abkr↓ and tbkRr↓. (K, TA.) You say, bakRarotu fiI kacaA (tropical:) I was, or became, or went, before, &c., in such a thing; syn. taqadRamotu. (IJ, IB, TA.) And bkRr EalaI OaSoHaAbihi (assumed tropical:) [He was, or became, or went, before his companions; preceded them; or had, or took, precedence of them]. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- bkRrhu EalaI OaSoHaAbihi signifies jaEalahu yubakRiru Ealayohimo (assumed tropical:) [He made him to be, or become, or go, before his companions; to precede them; or to have, or take, precedence of them]; and so Ealayohimo Abkrhu↓. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also 4. ― -b3- bkRr AlfaAkihapa: see 8.

3 baAokara
3: see 1, in four places.

4 Oabokara
4: see 1, in seven places: and see 2 as meaning taqadRama. ― -b2- Abkr also signifies He had camels coming to water early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- It is also trans. of bakara: (S, Sgh, Msb:) you say, Oabokarotu gayoriI [I made another to go forth early in the morning, in the first part of the day; or between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise: and I made another to go to a person &c. at that time; and to betake himself to an action at that time: and (assumed tropical:) to hasten, or betake himself early, to a thing at any time, morning or evening: and gayoriI bakRarotu↓ app. signifies the same]. (S.) ― -b2- You say also, Abkrhu EalaI OaSoHaAbihi: see 2.

5 tabakRara
5: see 2.

8 Abtkr Obtkr Abtkr Qbtkr
8. Abtkr: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) He arrived [at the mosque on the occasion of the Friday-prayers] in time to hear the first portion of the xuTobap: (S, K:) or he heard the first portion of the xuTobap; (A, Msb;) [and] Abtkr AlxuTobapa has this meaning. (Mgh.) waQbotakara mano bakRara↓, occurring in a trad., (S, Msb,) respecting [the prayers of] Friday, (S,) means (tropical:) Whoso hasteneth, (S, Msb,) and arriveth in time to hear the first portion of the xuTobap, (S,) or heareth the first portion thereof: (Msb:) or whoso hasteneth, going forth to the mosque early, and performeth the prayer at the first of its time: or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, whoso hasteneth to the Fridayprayers, before the call to prayer, and arriveth at the commencement of their time: or both the verbs signify the same, and the [virtual] repetition is to give intensiveness and strength to the meaning. (TA. [See 2.]) ― -b3- You say also, Abtkrhu, meaning (tropical:) He took, (A, Msb,) or obtained possession of, (S, TA,) its baAkuwrap, (S, TA,) i. e., (TA,) the first of it: (A, Msb, TA:) which is the primary signification [of the trans. verb]. (TA.) ― -b4- And Abtkr, K,) or Abtkr AlfaAkihapa, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and bakRarahaA↓, (TA,) (tropical:) He ate the first that had come to maturity of fruit, or of the fruit. (A, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b5- And hence, (Mgh,) Abtkr AljaAriyapa (tropical:) He took the girl's virginity: (A, Mgh:) or he did so before she had attained to puberty. (Msb in art. qD, and TA in art. xDr.) ― -b6- And Abtkr EajiynFA (assumed tropical:) [He took, or made use of, fresh dough for preparing bread]. (K in art. grD.) ＝ -A2- And Aibotakarato, (Abu-l-Beydà,) or Abtkrt biwaladihaA, (AHeyth,) She brought forth her first offspring: (AHeyth, Abu-l-Beydà:) or the former signifies she (a woman) brought forth a male at her first birth. (K.)

bakorN bkr bkrp kr
bakorN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and bukorN↓, (K,) but this latter is hardly to be found in any of the lexicons, (MF,) and bikorN↓, (ISd, TA,) A youthful he-camel; one in a state of youthful vigour: fem. with p; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and also bakorN, without p: (TA:) the term bakorN, applied to a camel, corresponds to fatFI, applied to a human being; and bakorapN, to fataApN; and qaluwSN, to jaAriyapN; and baEiyrN, to UinosaAnN; and jamalN, to rajulN; and naAqapN, to maroOapN: (AO, S:) or the offspring, or young one, of a she-camel; (K;) thus indefinitely explained: (TA:) or a camel in his sixth year (vaniIRN) [and] until he becomes a jacaE: [but it seems that the reverse must be meant; for a jcE, of camels, is one in his fifth year:] or a camel in his second year [and] until he enters his sixth year: or a camel in his second year, or that has entered his third year, or that has completed his second year and entered his third year; syn. Aibonu labuwnK: (K:) and a camel that has just entered upon his fourth year: and a camel in his fifth year: (IAar, Az:) or a camel that has not entered his ninth year: (K:) and sometimes it is metaphorically applied to a human being; [meaning (tropical:) a young man;] and bakorapN to (tropical:) a young woman: (TA:) the pl. (of pauc., S) is OabokurN; (S, K;) and Oubayokiruwna↓ occurs as pl. of the dim. of OabokurN; (S, TA;) and (pl. of mult., S, TA) bikaArN, (S, Msb,) like as firaAxN is pl. of faroxN; (S;) or this is pl. of bakorapN; (Msb, K;) and there are other pls. of bakorN, namely, bukoraAnN (K) and bikaArapN; (S, Msb, K;) and [quasi-pl. n.] bakaArapN↓. (K.) Hence the well-known prov., (TA,) SadaqaniI sinRa bakorihi, and sinRu bakorihi, meaning He hath told me what is in his mind, and what his ribs infold: a saying originating from the following fact: a man bargained with another for a youthful camel (bakor), and said, “ What is his age (sinRuhu)? ” the other answered, “ He is in his ninth year: ” then the young camel took fright and ran away: whereupon his owner said to him, hidaEo hidaEo; and this is an expression by which are quieted young ones, (K,) of the camel; (TA;) so when the purchaser heard it, he said, SdqnI snR bkrh [He hath told me truly the age, or as to the age, of his youthful camel: or the age of his youthful camel has spoken truly to me]: if snR is in the accus. case, the meaning [of the verb] is EarRafaniI, (K,) and snR is in the accus. case as a second objective complement; (TA;) or xabara sinRi is meant; [in the CK, erroneously, xabara;] or fiI sinRi; the prefixed noun [xabara] or the proposition [fiI] being suppressed [and snR being therefore in the accus. case]: but if snR is in the nom. case, veracity is attributed to the [animal's] age, by an amplification: (K:) or, as some say, the buyer said to the owner of the camel, “ How many years has he? ” and he told him; and he looked at the teeth of the camel, and found him to be as he had said; whereupon he said, SdqnI sinRu bkrh. (Har p. 95.)

bukorN bkr bkrp kr
bukorN: see bakorN.

bikorN bkr bkrp kr
bikorN A virgin; (S, K;) and a man who has not yet drawn near to a woman; (TA;) contr. of vayRibN, applied to a man as well as to a female: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. OabokaArN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) A pearl unpierced. (MF.) And (assumed tropical:) A bow when one first shoots with it. (TA.) And (tropical:) A cloud abounding with water: (K, TA:) likened to a virgin, because her blood is more than that of her who is not a virgin: and the phrase saHaAbN bikorN is sometimes used. (TA.) And naArN bikorN (tropical:) Fire not lighted from another fire. (As, A.) ― -b3- Also She that has not yet brought forth offspring: (AHeyth:) and a cow that has not yet conceived: (K:) or a heifer (K, TA) that has not yet conceived: (TA:) and a woman, (S, K,) and a she-camel, (As, K,) that has brought forth but once: pl. OabokaArN and bikaArN: (TA:) or a she-camel in her first state or condition. (Ham p. 340.) ― -b4- And [hence,] (tropical:) A grape-vine that has produced fruit but once: (A, K:) pl. OabokaArN. (A.) ― -b5- Also i. q. bakorN, q. v. (ISd, TA.) And [hence,] OabokaAru AlOawolaAdi (assumed tropical:) Young children. (TA, from a trad.) And OabokaAru AlnRaHoli (assumed tropical:) Young bees. (TA.) Whence, Easalu OabokaArK (tropical:) Honey produced by young bees: or this means honey of which the preparation has been superintended by virgin-girls. (A, * TA.) ― -b6- Also (tropical:) The first-born of his, or her, mother (S, Msb, K) and father; (Msb, K;) applied alike to the male and the female: (S:) and sometimes to that which is not the offspring of human beings; (TA;) the first-born of camels; (S;) and of a serpent: (TA:) pl. OabokaArN. (TA.) You say, hecaA bikoru Oabawayohi (tropical:) This is the first-born of his parents. (TA.) And OaXadRu AlnRaAsi bikorN Qbonu bikorayoni (A) or bikoru bikorayoni (M, TA) (tropical:) [The strongest of men is the first-born of a man and woman each a first-born]. ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The first of anything; (K;) as also baAkuwrapN↓: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) an action that has not been preceded by its like. (K.) You say, maA hecaA AlOamoru minoka bikorFA wa laA vaniyFA (tropical:) This thing, or affair, is not thy first nor thy second. (A, TA.) ― -b8- HaAjapN bikorN (tropical:) A want, or needful thing, recently sought to be accomplished or attained: (TA:) or that is the first in being referred to him of whom its accomplishment is sought. (A, TA.) ― -b9- DarobapN bikorN (tropical:) A cutting blow or stroke, (S, K,) that kills (K) at once, (TA,) not requiring to be struck a second time: (S, A:) pl. DarabaAtN OabokaArN; occurring in a trad., in which it is said that such were the blows of 'Alee; (S, TA;) but in that trad., as some recite it, the latter word is mubotakiraAtN↓. (TA.)

bakarN bkr bkrp kr
bakarN: see bukorapN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see also bakorapN.

rajulN bakurN fiI HaAjatihi rjl bkr fy HAjth rjl bkr fy HAjtp
rajulN bakurN fiI HaAjatihi, [in the CK, erroneously, bakorN,] and bakirN↓, (S, K, * TA,) like HacurN and HacirN, (S,) and bakiyrN↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A man possessing the quality of applying himself early, or of hastening, or having strength to apply himself early, or to hasten, (SaAHibu bukuwrN, S, or qawiIRN EalaI Albukuwri, K,) to do, or accomplish, the thing that he needs, or wants: (S:) bakurN and bakirN [and bakiyrN] are [said to be] possessive epithets; for they have no simple triliteral verb. (TA.) [But see 1, last sentence.]

bakirN bkr bkrp kr
bakirN: see what next precedes.

bakorapN bkr bkrh bkrp kr krh krp
bakorapN (S, Msb, K) and bakarapN↓ (Msb, K) The thing upon which [passes the rope wherewith] one draws water (S, Msb, K) from a well [or the like]; (S;) [ i. e. the sheave of a pulley;] a round piece of wood, in the middle [of the circumference] whereof is a groove (K, TA) for the rope, and in the interior [or centre] whereof is an axis upon which it turns: (TA:) or a quick maHaAlap [or large sheave of a pulley]: (M, K:) [but MF disapproves of this last explanation: sometimes, by a synecdoche, it is used to signify a pulley complete:] the pl. is bakarN↓, (S, Msb, K,) a pl. of the former, anomalous, like HalaqN pl. of HaloqapN, and HamaON pl. of HamoOapN, (S,) or of the latter; (Msb;) or a coll. gen. n., of which bakarapN is the n. un.; (MF;) and bakaraAt, (S, Msb, K,) a pl. of the former [as well as of the latter]. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, app., the former signifies also (assumed tropical:) A small ring, like a bead, in the ornamental part of a sword: (Mgh:) [and the pl.] bakaraAtN signifies (assumed tropical:) the rings that are attached to the ornamental part [of the scabbard] of a sword, (K,) resembling the [rings called] qatax [which are worn upon the fingers or toes] of women. (TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, perhaps,] (assumed tropical:) An assembly, a company, or a congregated body. (IAar, K.) ― -b4- jaAWuwA EalaI bakorapi Oabiyhimo is a prov., (TA,) meaning (tropical:) They came together, not one remaining behind, (S, TA;) they came all of them, (AA, IJ, A, TA,) without exception: (TA:) or they came in a multitude, and all together, none remaining behind: (TA:) or they came in succession, one after, or at the heels of, another: (AO:) or they came in one way, or manner: (As:) [accord. to some, from bkrp as explained in the next preceding sentence; and, if so, ElI is used in the sense of maEa, or muXotamiliyna is understood before it: or it is from bkrp signifying “ a youthful she-camel; ” and thus implies that they were few: (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 312:) or] from bakRarotu fiI kacaA meaning “ I was, ” or “ became, ” or “ went, ” “ before in such a thing; ” so that it signifies that they came from first to last: (IJ:) or from bkrp in the first of the senses explained in this paragraph; though in this case there is no bkrp in reality. (AO, S. *)

bukorapN bkr bkrh bkrp kr krh krp
bukorapN and bakarN↓ The early morning, or first part of the day; (Bd and Jel in xix. 12 and xxxiii. 41 and xlviii. 9, as relating to the former word; and K; *) between the time of the prayer of daybreak and sunrise; syn. gudowapN; and UibokaArN↓ is a subst. in the same sense, (K,) accord. to the lexicologists, as Sb says; but he adds that he holds it to be [only] the inf. n. of Oabokara: (TA: [and the like is said in the S with reference to its occurrence in the Kur iii. 36 and xl. 57:]) pl. [of pauc.] of the first, OabokaArN, and [of mult.] bukarN. (T, Msb.) You say, Oatayotuhu bukorapN (S, A, Msb) and bakarFA↓, (A,) meaning baAkirKA↓ [I came to him early in the morning, &c.]. (S, A, Msb.) But if you mean the bukorapN of a particular day, you say, Oatayotuhu bukorapa, making the noun imperfectly decl.; [meaning I came to him early in the morning, &c., of this day;] and in this case it is not to be used otherwise than as an adv. n. of time. (S.) If you say baAkirFA↓, using this word as an epithet, you use baAkirap for the fem. (TA.) You say also, siro EalaI farasika bukorapF and bakarFA↓ [Go thou on thy horse early in the morning, &c.]; like as you say, saHarFA. (S, TA. [But in two copies of the S, for sro, I find siyra.])

bakarapN bkr bkrh bkrp kr krh krp
bakarapN: see bakorapN.

bakuwrN bkwr bkyr kwr kwrp
bakuwrN (A, K) and baAkuwrN↓ (K) and baAkirN↓ (A) and mubokirN↓ (K) (tropical:) Rain that falls in the first of its season: (A:) or that comes (TA) in the commencement of [the season of] the wasomiIR [q. v.]: (K, TA:) and that comes in the end of the night, or the beginning of the day. (TA.) You say also saHaAbapN midolaAjN bakuwrN (tropical:) [A cloud that comes in the latter part of the night, in the first of its season, bringing rain]: (A:) and saHaAbapN mibokaArN↓ a cloud that comes in the end of the night. (TA.) ― -b2- Also bakuwrN (S, A, Msb, K) and bakiyrapN↓ (S, K) and baAkuwrapN↓ (Msb, K) and baAkirN↓ (A) and mibokaArN↓ (A in art. Axr and K) (tropical:) A palm-tree (naxolapN, A) that comes to maturity first, (S, Msb, K,) before the other palm-trees: (S:) or that produces its fruit early; (A;) contr. of miYoxaArN (A in art. Axr:) pl. (of the first, Msb, K) bukurN; (S, Msb, K; [in the CK bukorN;]) and [pl. of baAkirN↓ or baAkirapN] bawaAkiru (K voce tabaAXiyru) baAkuwrapN↓ is fem. of baAkuwrN, (K, TA,) which signifies (assumed tropical:) Anything that hastens its coming (TA) and its attaining to maturity. (K, TA.) You say also OaroDN mibokaArN↓ (assumed tropical:) Land that produces plants, or herbage, quickly. (K.)

bakiyrN bkyr kyr
bakiyrN, and its fem., with p: see bakurN and bakNwrN

bakaArapN bkArh bkArp kAr kArh
bakaArapN Virginity: (S, K:) the virginity, or maidenhead, of a woman. (Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also bakorN

baAkirN Okr Okrp bOkr bAkr
baAkirN [part. n. of bakara]: see bukorapN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see bakuwrN, in three places: ― -b2- and see an ex. of the pl. of its fem. baAkirapN, i. e. bawaAkiru, voce baASirN ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Fruit when first ripe: pl. bikaArN, like as SiHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN. (TA.)

baAkuwrN bOkwr bAkwr bkyr kwr
baAkuwrN, and its fem. baAkuwrapN: see bakuwrN, in three places.

baAkuwrapN bOkwrh bAkwrh bAkwrp bkyr kwr
baAkuwrapN [as a subst.]: see bikorN. ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) or baAkuwrapN AlfaA kihapi, (A, Msb,) (tropical:) The first of fruit: (S:) or the first that comes to maturity, of fruit: (A, Msb, K:) or fruit that hastens to come forth: (AHát, Msb:) pl. bawaAkiyru and baAkuwraAtN. (Msb.) ― -b3- The pl. bawaAkiyru also signifies (assumed tropical:) Winds that announce [coming] rain. (A in art. bXr)

UibokaArN ObkAr AbkAr bkr
UibokaArN: see bukorapN.

OubayokirN c
OubayokirN dim. of OabokirN, pl. of pauc. of bakorN: see its pl. Oubayokiruwna voce bakorN.

tabaAkiyru tbAkyr
tabaAkiyru (assumed tropical:) The colours of palm-trees when the fruit begins to ripen. (TA voce tabaAXiyru.)

mubokirN mbkr
mubokirN: see bakuwrN.

mibokaArN mbkAr
mibokaArN: see bakuwrN, in three places.

DrabaAtN mubotakiraAtN DrbAt mbtkrAt
DrabaAtN mubotakiraAtN: see bikorN. last sentence.

1 bakima Obkm b bkm km
1. bakima aor.
bakama
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. bakamN, (S, K,) He was OaxorasN [meaning dumb, either by natural conformation or from inability to find words to express what he would say]; (S, Msb, K; *) bakamN being syn. with xarasN, as is also bakaAmapN [accord. to rule an inf. n. of bakuma, which may also have the same signification as bakima, as well as another to be explained below]: (K:) or he had not understanding to reply, (T, Msb, TA,) nor ability to frame speech well, (T, TA,) though possessing the faculty of speech: [see Oabokamu:] (T, Msb, TA:) or he was dumb, and moreover unable to find words to express what he would say, and weak in understanding, silly, or stupid: (K:) or he was dumb and deaf and blind by birth. (Th, K.) ― -b2- bakuma, aor.
bakuma
, (inf. n. bakaAmapN, TK,) He refrained, (Lth, K) or, as some say, broke off, or ceased, (TA,) from speaking, intentionally, (Lth, K, TA,) or from ignorance. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He cut himself off, or desisted, from marriage, or sexual intercourse, either from ignorance or intentionally. (K, TA.)

5 tbkRm Ealayohi AlkalaAmu tbkm Elyh AlklAm
5. tbkRm Ealayohi AlkalaAmu His speech was, or became, impeded; he was unable to speak freely. (A, K.)

bakiymN bkym kym
bakiymN: see what follows, in two places.

OabokamN c
OabokamN (T, S, Msb, K, &c.) and bakiymN↓ (S, K) i. q. Oaxorasu [meaning Dumb, either by natural conformation or from inability to find words to express what he would say]: (S, Msb, K:) or not having understanding to reply, (IAar, T, Msb, TA,) nor ability to frame speech well, (T, TA,) though possessing the faculty of speech; whereas Axrs signifies speechless, or destitute of the faculty of speech, by natural conformation, (T, Msb, TA,) like the beast that lacks the faculty of articulation; (T, TA;) unable to find words to express what he would say; unable to reply: (AZ, TA:) or dumb by natural conformation: (IAth, TA:) fem. bakomaMCu: (TA:) pl. bukomN (Msb, K) and bukomaAnN, (K,) both pls. of Oabokamu, like as SumRN and SumRaAnN are pls. of OaSamRu; and the pl. of bakiymN↓ is OabokaAmN. (TA.) In the Kur ii. 166, bukomN means persons in the condition of him who has been born dumb: or, as some say, deprived of their intellects: (Zj, TA:) or ignorant and ignoble; because not profiting much by the faculty
of speech, so that they are as though they had been deprived of it. (IAth, TA.) The phrase fitonapN SamRaMCu bakomaMCu EamoyaMCu, occurring in a trad., [lit.] meaning [A sedition, or the like,] deaf, dumb, blind, applies to a ftnp that does not withdraw, or become removed: or, as some say, to one which, by reason of the confusion attending it, and the perishing of the sound and the sick therein, is likened to the deaf and dumb and blind who does not pursue the right course to a thing, but goes at random like the weak-sighted she-camel. (TA.)

1 bakaI bk bkI bky ky
1. bakaI, aor.
bakiIa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. bukaMCN and bukFA (S, Msb, K) and mabokFI, (Har p. 11,) He wept; i. e. he lamented, or grieved, shedding tears at the same time; and he lamented, or grieved, alone; and he shed tears alone: (Er-Rághib, TA:) accord. to some, the preferable opinion is, that there is no difference between bukaMCu and bukFA: (TA:) or the former means the crying, or uttering of the voice [of lamentation], (S, IKtt, Msb, TA, &c.,) that accompanies AlbukaMC [so in copies of the S and in the TA, but correctly AlbukaA]; (S, IKtt, TA;) and the latter (bukFA), the shedding of tears: (S, IKtt, Msb, TA, &c.:) or the former, i. e. with medd, means the shedding of tears by reason of lamentation, or grief, and raising of the voice, or crying, [at the same time,] when the voice is predominant, being like rugaMCN, and vugaMCN and other words of the same form applied to denote the uttering of a cry or of the voice; and the latter, [the shedding of tears &c.] when lamentation, or grief, is predominant: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or by the former is meant the crying, or uttering of the voice [of lamentation]; and by the latter, the lamenting, or grieving. (Kh, TA.) tabokaMCN and tibokaMCN [may be inf. ns. of bakaI or of bakRaI↓, and] signify the same as bukaMCN: or much bukaAC [or weeping, &c.]: (K:) MF asserts that tibokaMCN (with kesr) and the former of these explanations are unknown; but both the word and the explanation are mentioned by Lh, as used in a form of words uttered by Arab women of the desert to fascinate men: ISd, however, says that it should be tabokaMC, because it is an inf. n. of a class formed to denote muchness [of the attribute signified by the verb], like tahocaArN and taloEaAbN &c.; and IAar says that tabokaACN, with fet-h, has the latter of the two significations assigned to it above. (TA.) balo bl
balo is a particle of digression: (Mughnee, K:) or, accord. to Mbr, it denotes emendation, wherever it occurs, in the case of a negation or an affirmation: (T, TA:) or it is a word of emendation, and denoting digression from that which precedes; as also bano, in which the n is a substitute for the l, because bl is of frequent occurrence, and bn is rare; or, as IJ says, the latter may be an independent dial. var. (M.) When it is followed by a proposition, the meaning of the digression is either the cancelling of what precedes, as in waqaAluwA QtRaxaca QlrRaHomenu waladFA suboHaAnahu balo EibaAdN mukoramuwna [And they said, “ The Compassionate hath gotten offspring: ” extolled be his freedom from that which is derogatory from his glory! nay, or nay rather, or nay but, they are honoured servants (Kur xxi. 26)], or transition from one object of discourse to another, as in qado OafolaHa mano tazakRaI wa cakara Qsoma rabRihi faSalRaI balo tuWoviruwna QloHayaApa QldRunoyaA [He hath attained felicity who hath purified himself, and celebrated the name of his Lord, and prayed: but ye prefer the present life (Kur lxxxvii. 14-16)]: (Mughnee, K: *) and in all such cases it is an inceptive particle; not a conjunctive. (Mughnee.) When it is followed by a single word, it is a conjunction, (S, * Msb, * Mughnee, K,) and requires that word to be in the same case as the word before it: (S:) and if preceded by a command or an affirmation, (Mughnee, K,) as in AiDorabo zayodFA balo EamorFA [Beat thou Zeyd: no, 'Amr], (Msb, Mughnee, K,) and qaAma zayodN balo EamorNw [Zeyd stood: no, 'Amr], (M, Mughnee, K,) or jaMCaniI Oaxuwka balo Oabuwka [Thy brother came to me: no, thy father], (S,) it makes what precedes it to be as though nothing were said respecting it, (S, * Msb, * Mughnee, K,) making the command or affirmation to relate to what follows it: (S, * Msb, * Mughnee:) [and similar to these cases is the case in which it is preceded by an interrogation: see Oamo as syn. with this particle:] but when it is preceded by a negation or a prohibition, it is used to confirm the meaning of what precedes it and to assign the contrary of that meaning to what follows it, (Mughnee, K,) as in maA qaAma zayodN EamorNw [Zeyd stood not, but 'Amr stood], (Mughnee,) or maA raOayotu zayodFA balo EamorFA, [I saw not Zeyd, but I saw 'Amr], (S,) and laA yaqumo zayodN balo EamorNw [Let not Zeyd stand, but let 'Amr stand]. (Mughnee.) Mbr and 'Abd-El-Wárith allow its being used to transfer the meaning of the negation and the prohibition to what follows it; so that, accord. to them, one may say, maAzayodN qaAYimFA balo qaAEidFA [as meaning Zeyd is not standing: no, is not sitting], and balo qaAEidN [but is sitting]; the meaning being different [in the two cases]. (Mughnee, K. *) The Koofees disallow its being used as a conjunction after anything but a negation [so in the Mughnee, but in the K a prohibition,] or the like thereof; so that one should not say, Darabotu zayodFA balo UiyRaAka [I beat Zeyd: no, thee]. (Mughnee, K.) Sometimes laA is added before it, to corroborate the meaning of digression, after an affirmation, as in the saying,
wajohuka Albadoru laA bali AlXRamosu lawo lamo
yuqoDa lilXRamosi kasofapN wa Oufuwlu
[Thy face is the full moon: no, but it would be the sun, were it not that eclipse and setting are appointed to happen to the sun]: and to corroborate what precedes it, after a negation, as in
wa maA hajarotuka laA balo zaAdaniI XagafFA
hajorN wa baEodN taraAxaI laA UilaI Oajali
[And I did not abandon thee, or have not abandoned thee: no, but abandonment and distance, protracted, not to an appointed period, increased, or have increased, my heart-felt love]. (Mughnee, K. *) ― -b2- Sometimes it is used to denote the passing from one subject to another without cancelling [what precedes it], and is syn. with wa, as in the saying in the Kur [lxxxv. 20 and 21], waQllRehu mino, wa raAYihimo muHiyTN balo huwa quroMnN majiydN [And God from behind them is encompassing: and it is a glorious Kur-án: or here it may mean UinRa, as in an ex. below]: and to this meaning it is made to accord in the saying, lahu EalaIRa diynaArN balo dirohamN [I owe him a deenár and a dirhem]. (Msb.) ― -b3- In the fol-
lowing saying in the Kur [xxxviii. 1],waQloquroMni ciI QlcRikoribali QlRaciyna kafaruwA fiI EizRapK waXiqaAqK, it is said to signify UinRa; [so that the meaning is, By the Kur-án possessed of eminence, verily they who have disbelieved are in a state of pride and opposition;] therefore the oath applies to it. (Akh, S.) ― -b4- Sometimes the Arabs use it in breaking off a saying and commencing another; and thus a man commences with it a citation, or recitation, of verse; in which case, it does not form any part of the first verse, but is a sign of the breaking off, or ending, of what precedes. (Akh, S.) ― -b5- Sometimes it is put in the place of rubRa, (S, Mughnee,) as in the saying of the rájiz,
balo mahomahK qaTaEotu baEoda mahomahK
[Many a far-extending desert have I traversed, after a far-extending desert]. (S: [and a similar ex. is given in the Mughnee.]) ― -b6- What is deficient in this word [supposing it to be originally of three letters] is unknown; and so in the cases of halo and qado: it may be a final w or I or they may be originally balR and halR and qadR. (Akh, S.)

[Using syns. of balalN in the sense explained above,] you say, Tawayotu AlsRiqaMCa EalaI bululatihi↓, (S, K,) and bulalatihi↓, (K,) or balalatihi↓, (T, M,) I folded the skin while it was moist, (T, S, M, K,) before it should break in pieces, (T,) or lest it should break in pieces. (S, TA.) And TawaAhu EalaI bilaAlihi↓, and buluwlihi↓, (tropical:) He feigned himself heedless of, or inattentive to, his vice, or fault; like as one folds a skin upon its fault [to conceal that fault]. (T.) (T.) ― -b2- Abundance of herbage; or of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (TA.) ― -b3- See also balRN. ― -b4- maA OaHosana balalahu How good is his adornment of himself! or his manner of undertaking a task, or taking upon himself a responsibility! (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, He (a man) was, or became, bright in countenance: or fair, beautiful, and wide in countenance: or (assumed tropical:) open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance: or (assumed tropical:) liberal with acts of beneficence: or (tropical:) generous, beneficent, and open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance: see the part. n. Oabolaju, below.] ― -b3- And [hence,] aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, TA) was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy. (K, TA.) And balija bihi AlSRadoru faraHFA (tropical:) The bosom became dilated with joy thereat. (A.) And balija baEoda maA Harija (tropical:) [It (the bosom) became dilated with joy after it had been contracted with grief]. (TA.) ― -b4- [And hence,] aor. and inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and balaja, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.

, inf. n. buluwjN; (S, Msb;) and Anblj↓, (S, K,) or Abtlj↓; (so in copies of the A and Msb;) and tblRj↓; (S, A, K;) and Ablj↓; (Msb, K;) (assumed tropical:) It (the dawn, or daybreak,) shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (S, A, Msb, K.) And AlXRamosu Oabolajati↓ (assumed tropical:) The sun shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (TA.) And AlXRaIoCu AblAjR↓ (assumed tropical:) The thing shone, was bright, or shone brightly. (TA.) ― -b5- And hence, (Msb,) balaja AlHaqRu, and balija; (Msb;) or Ablj↓; (A, TA;) (tropical:) The truth became apparent, (A, Msb, TA,) manifest, evident, or clear. (A, Msb.) And AblAjR↓, inf. n. AiboliyjaAjN, (S, and so the inf. n. is written in a copy of the K: in another copy of the K it is written AibolijaAjN [inf. n. of AbljR↓], and the verb is written AbljR in a copy of the S: accord. to the CK, the inf. n. is AiboliylaAjN [of which the verb is Ablwlj↓]:) said of anything, (S, TA,) signifies (tropical:) It was, or became, apparent, manifest, evident, or clear. (S, K,
TA.) ＝ -A2- balaja, aor.
balija
, (K,) inf. n. balojN, (TA,) He opened; syn. fataHa. (K.)

Oabolaju c
Oabolaju A man having a clear, a conspicuous, or a white, space between the eyes, not having the eyebrows joined: (ISh, TA:) or having such a space between the eyebrows, (K, * TA,) not having the eyebrows joined: (S, TA:) or having a wide space, or a space clear of hair, between the eyebrows: fem. balojaMCu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Bright of countenance; the Prophet being said by UmmMaabad to have been Oabolaju Alwajohi; by which she did not mean the balaj of the eyebrows, for she described him as having joined eyebrows: (A'Obeyd, S, TA:) or fair, beautiful, and wide in countenance, whether long or short: or [alone, or] followed by balojN↓, (assumed tropical:) open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance; (TA;) and so ↓the latter alone: (K:) or ↓the latter, (tropical:) open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance, with beneficence: (TA:) or the former, and ↓the latter, and baliyjN↓, (assumed tropical:) liberal with acts of beneficence: (TA:) or the first, (tropical:) generous, beneficent, and open and pleasant, or cheerful, in countenance; although having joined eyebrows. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Shining, bright, or shining brightly; applied to the dawn, or daybreak; (S, A, Msb;) and so baliyjN↓, applied to a thing [of any kind]: (TA:) and the former, anything (assumed tropical:) apparent, manifest, evident, or clear; (K;) thus applied to a face, and to the dawn, (TA,) and to the truth, (Msb, TA,) and to an affair or event, or a case, &c. (TA.) It is an act. part. n. of balija. (Msb.) You say, AlHaqRu Oabolaju wa AlbaATilu lajolajN (tropical:) The truth is apparent, manifest, evident, or clear; [and falsity is a cause of embarrassment, or hesitation, to the speaker;] (S, A; *) i. e., the latter is agitated to and fro, without having utterance: (S in art. lj:) or the truth is lucid and direct; and falsity is confused and indirect. (TA in that art.) And HujRapN balojaMCu (assumed tropical:) A manifest, an evident, or a clear, proof or argument. (Msb.)

Ouboluwju AlsRukRari, with damm, [meaning Sugar-candy, and loaf-sugar, thus applied in the present day,] is an arabicized term [from the Persian Mboluwjo]: (K, TA:) in one copy of the K, it is said that OuboluwjN, with damm, is [syn. with] AlsRukRarN [sugar]: by the people [who are makers] of AlHasaA and AlqaTiyf, [see these words, the latter of which is a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p, pl. qaTaAYifN,] it is called ONmolNwjN. (TA.)

(M, K.) ＝ -A2- balRadati AljibaAli (tropical:) The mountains appeared low to the eye by reason of the darkness of the night: so in the L, confirmed by a citation from a poet: in the A, AlbilaAdu tabalRadati↓ (tropical:) The countries, or regions,
appeared short [in extent] to the eye by reason of the darkness of the night. (TA.)

SafRaqa (M, K) biAlkafRi. (TA.) [See balodapN.] ― -b8- [And hence, app.,] (tropical:) He felt, or expressed, grief, sorrow, or regret. baladN Old bld ld
baladN (which is masc. and fem., Msb) and balodapN↓ both signify the same; (M, A, Msb, K;) namely, [A country, land, region, province, district, or territory: and a city, town, or village: or] any portion of the earth, or of land, comprehended within certain limits, [thus I render musotaHiyzap, and in like manner it is rendered in the TK,] cultivated, or inhabited, or uncultivated, or uninhabited: (M, Msb, * K:) or the former signifies any place of this description; and the latter, a portion thereof: (T:) or the former is a generic name of a place [or country or region or province] such as El-'Irák and Syria; and the latter signifies a particular portion thereof such as [the city or town of] El-Basrah and Damascus; (M, K;) or these are post-classical applications: (TA:) or the former, a tract of land, or district, which is an abode, or a place of resort, of animals, or genii, even if containing no building: (Nh:) or a land, or country, absolutely: and also a town, or village, syn. qaroyapN: but this latter is a conventional adventitious application: ('Ináyeh, TA:) and the latter, a land, country, or territory, [belonging to, or inhabited by, a people,] syn.

OaroDN c
OaroDN: (S, TA: [a meaning assigned in the K to baladN; but this appears to be a mistake occasioned by the accidental omission of the word AlbalodapN:]) you say, hecihi balodatunaA [This is our land, &c.] like as you say, hecihi baHoratunaA: (S, TA:) the pl. (of the former, S, Msb) is bulodaAnN (S, M, Msb) and (of the same, S, or of the latter, Msb) bilaAdN: (T, S, M, Msb:) [which latter, regarded as pl. of balodapN in a more limited sense than baladN, is often used as meaning provinces collectively; i. e. a country:] bulodaAnN is syn. with kuwarN [which signifies districts, or tracts of country; quarters, or regions; and also, cities, towns, or villages]. (T.) Albaladu and Albalodapu↓ are names applied to Mekkeh; (M, K;) in like manner as AlnRajomu is a name applied to the Pleiades. (M.) [So too Albaladu AlOamiynu and Albaladu AlHaraAmu &c.] baladN mayRitN means A tract of land without herbage, or pasture: (Msb:) and baladN alone, a [desert, a waterless desert, or such as is termed] mafaAzapK. (TA voce tA; under which see an ex.) ― -b2- baladN also signifies Land which has not been dug, and upon which fire has not been kindled. (M, K.) ― -b3- A [house, or dwelling, such as is termed] dAr: (M, K:) of the dial. of ElYemen. (M.) Sb mentions the saying, hecihi AldRaAru niEomati Albaladu [This house, excellent, or most excel-lent, is the dwelling!]; in which Albld is made fem. because it is syn. with AldAr. (M.) ― -b4- A burial-ground: (M, K:) or, as some say, (M, but in the K “and,”) a grave, or sepulchre: (M, K:) pl. as above. (M.) ― -b5- Dust, or earth; and so yalodapN↓. (T, M, K.) ― -b6- The place in which an ostrich lays its egg, in sand. (S, M, L, K.) And hence, bayoDapu Albaladi The egg of the ostrich, which it abandons in the place where it lays it, in the sand, or in a desert: (M, L:) also called AlbaladiyRapi↓ and caAtu Albaladi. (M.) You say, fulaAnN bayoDapu Albaladi [(tropical:) Such a one is like the egg of the ostrich, &c.], meaning such a one is unequalled, or unparalleled: said in dispraise and in praise: (M, * L:) allowed by A'Obeyd to be used in praise: and said by El-Bekree to be applied to him who is separated from his family and near relations. (TA.) [See also art. byD.] You also say, huwa OacalRu mino bayoDapi Albaladi (S, M, A) (tropical:) He is more object, or vile, than the egg of the ostrich, which it abandons (S, TA) in the desert, and to which it does not return. (TA.) [See again art. byD.] Also huwa OaEazRa mino bayoDapi Albaladi (tropical:) [He is more highly esteemed than the egg of the ostrich, which it lays in the sand]; because the ostrich spreads its wings over it and sits upon it. (A in art. frx.) [See more in art.

byD.] ― -b2- A trace, mark, or vestige, (T, S, M, K, [in the K mentioned in two places, but in the latter of these omitted in the CK,]) of a house, or dwelling: (TA:) and a mark remaining upon the body: (A'Obeyd, T:) pl. OabolaAdN. (S, A'Obeyd, M, K.) ― -b3- The origin, or an element, (EunoSur,) of a thing. (Th, M, K.) ― -b4- See also the next paragraph, in three places: ― -b5- and see bulodapN.

Smt.] ― -b3- And [hence, app.,] Albalodapu One of the Mansions of the Moon, (M, K,) [namely, the Twenty-first Mansion,] a patch of the sky, (K,) containing no stars, (M, K,) or containing only small stars, (T, * M,) between the naEaAYim and saEod AlcRaAbiH: (M, K:) sometimes the moon declines from it, and takes as its mansion the qilaAdap: it [app. AlqlAdp, accord. to the K, but accord. to the TA Albldp,] consists of six stars resembling a bow, (K,) in the sign of Sagittarius (Alqawos): (T:) or Albldp is one of the Mansions of the Moon, consisting of six stars of Sagittarius (Alqws), which the sun enters on the shortest day of the year: (S:) [see manaAzilu Alqamar, in art. nzl: in the K it is also said that Albaladu↓ is a Mansion of the Moon; but this appears to be a mistake, occasioned by the accidental omission of the word Albalodapu; though Albaladu would seem to be an appropriate name for the mansion next after the nEAYm:] IF says that Albalodapu is a star, or an asterism, (najomN,) said to be the balodap, i. e. breast, of the Lion; not meaning the mansion thus called in the sign of Sagittarius: El-Hareeree finds fault with him for using this expression, [the bldp of the Lion,] but Ibn-Dhafr replies that it occurs in the language. (S.) ― -b5- Also (S, M, L, TA, [in the K balad↓, by the accidental omission of the word Albalodapu,]) The pit between the two collar-bones, with the part around it: or the middle thereof, i. e., of that pit: (M, K:) or the third of the falak (which are six in number) of that part of a horse's breast which is called the zawur: or the part called raHaI AlzRawori: (M:) or [so accord. to the M, but accord. to the K “and,”] the breast, syn. Sador, (S, M, A, K,) of a camel, (M, A,) or of that which has a foot like the camel's, and of a solid-hoofed animal, (M,) and of a man: (A:) and the part immediately beneath the two prominent portions of flesh of the breast of a horse, extending to the arms. She (the camel) was made to lie down, and threw her breast upon [a tract of] ground. (S, M.) And you say, fulaAnN waAsiEu Albalodapi Such a one is wide in the breast. (S.) ― -b6- Also (tropical:) The palm of the
hand. (M, A, TA. [In the K, by the accidental omission of the word Albalodapu, this meaning is assigned to baladN↓.]) You say, Daraba balodatahu EalaI balodatihi (tropical:) He smote the palm of his hand upon his breast. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also bulodapN, in two places: ＝ -A3- and see balaAdapN.

(M, Msb, K.) [The pl.] bulusN is also applied to Large sacks of musuwH [i. e. hair-cloths], in which figs are put, [or, more probably, in which straw is put, for AltRiyn, which I find in two copies of the S and in the TA, can hardly be doubted to be a mistranscription of AltRibon], and upon which is paraded he who is made a public example that others may take warning from him, and the subject of a proclamation [acquainting the spectators with his offence]: whence the imprecation, OaraAniyka QllRehu EalaIAlbulusi [May God show me thee upon the large haircloth-sacks]. (S, TA.)

balasaAnN blsAn lsAn
balasaAnN [The balsam-tree; or the species that produces the balsam of Mekkeh; i. e., the amyris opobalsamum;] a certain kind of tree, (M,) or shrub, resembling the HinRaMC, (K,) having many leaves, inclining to white, in odour resembling the sacaAb [or rue], (TA,) the berry of which has an unguent, (Lth, M, TA,) which is hot, (Lth, TA,) and its unguent is in great request: (Lth, K, TA:) its unguent [opobalsamum] is more potent than its berry [carpobalsamum], and its berry is more so than its wood [xylobalsamum] : the best of its wood is the smooth, tawny-coloured, pungent and sweet in odour: it is hot and dry in the second degree; and its berry is a little hotter than it: its wood opens stoppages of the nose, and is good for the sciatica and vertigo and headache, and clears cloudiness of the eye, and is good for asthma and oppression of the breath, and for flaccidity of the womb, used by fumigation; it is also beneficial in cases of barrenness, and counteracts poisons and the bite of vipers: (the Minháj, TA:) it is said in the K and in the Minháj, and by most of the physicians and those who treat of drugs, that it grows only at 'Eyn-Shems, in the neighbourhood of El-Káhireh, the place called ElMatareeyeh; but MF observes that this is strange, as it is well known that it is mostly found in the district of El-Hijáz, between the Harameyn and El-Yembo', whence it is conveyed to all countries: the truth, however, is, that it ceased to grow at ' Eyn-Shems in the latter part of the eighth century [of the Flight], and it was endeavoured [successfully] to be made to grow in El-Hijáz. (TA.) [See also De Sacy's “ Abd-allatif, ” p. 89.]

1 buluwgN blwg
1. buluwgN [inf. n. of balaga] and UibolaAgN [inf. n. of Ablg↓, but it seems that AblAg is here a mistranscription for balaAgN, which is, like buluwgN, an inf. n. of balaga, and this observation will be found to be confirmed by a statement immediately following this sentence,] signify The reaching, attaining, arriving at, or coming to, the utmost point of that to which, or towards which, one tends or repairs or betakes himself, to which one directs his course, or which one seeks, pursues, endeavours to reach, desires, intends, or purposes; whether it be a place, or a time, or any affair or state or event that is meditated or intended or determined or appointed: and sometimes, the being at the point thereof: so says Abu-1-Kásim in the Mufradát. (TA: [in which it is said, in the supplement to the present art., that balaAgN signifies The reaching, attaining, arriving at, or coming to, a thing.]) You say, balaga AlmakaAna, (S, K,) and Almanozila, (Msb,) [aor.
baluga
,] inf. n. buluwgN (S, K) [and balaAgN, as shown above], He reached, attained, arrived at, or came to, (S, Msb, K,) the place, (S, K,) and the place of abode: (Msb:) and (so in the S, but in the K “ or, ”) he was, or became, at the point of reaching it, attaining it, &c. (S, K.) fabalagona Oajalahuna, in the Kur [ii. 232], means And they have fully attained, or ended, their term. (Msb.) But faUicaA balagona OajalahunRa, in the same [lxv. 2], means And when they are near to attaining, or ending, their term: (S, TA:) or are at the point of accomplishing their term. (Msb, TA.) It has the first of the meanings explained above in the phrase, balaga OaXudRahu [Kur xii. 22 &c., He attained his manly vigour, or full maturity, &c.]. (TA.) And in balagaOarobaEiyna sanapF [Kur xlvii. 14, He attained the age of forty years]. (TA.) And in balaga maEahu AlsRaEoIa [Kur xxxvii. 100, He attained to working with him]. (TA.) In the Kur [iii. 35], occurs the phrase, waqado balaganiIa Alkibaru [When old age hath come to me, or overtaken me]: and in another place [xix. 9], wa qado balagotu mina Alkibari EutiyRFA [And I have reached the extreme degree of old age: so explained in the Expos. of the Jel]: phrases like OadorakaniIa Aljahodu and Oadorakotuhu. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say also, maA balaga lazimahu celika baAligFA↓ with the accus. case as a denotative of state; meaning [That clave to him, or adhered to him, &c.,] rising to its highest degree or point; from balaga Almanozila, explained above. (Msb.) [But maA balaga baAligFA↓ more frequently means Whatever point, degree, amount, sum, quantity, number, or the like, it may reach, attain, arrive at, come to, or amount to.] And balaga fulaAnN mabolagahu↓ and mabolagatuhu↓ [Such a one reached, or attained, his utmost point or scope or degree]. (TA.) And balaga fiI AlEilomi AlmabaAliga↓ [He attained, in knowledge, or science, the utmost degrees of proficiency]. (TA.) And balaga fiI Aljawodapi mabolagFA↓ [It reached a consummate degree in goodness]. (S, K, * TA.) And balaga mina Aljawodapi mabolagFA↓ [He attained a consummate degree of goodliness]: said of a boy that has attained to puberty. (O, TA.) And balaga gaAyatahu fiI AlTRalabi [He did his utmost, or used his utmost power or ability, in seeking to attain an object]. (Msb in art. jhd.) And balaga OaqoSaI majohuwdi baEiyrihi fiI AlsRayori [He exerted the utmost endeavour, or effort, or power, or strength, of his camel, in journeying]. (S in art. nkv.) And balaga jahoda daAbRatihi i. q. jahadahaA [He jaded, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied, his beast]: (K in art. jhd:) and in like manner, balaga maXaqRatahu and balaga minohu AlmaXaqRapa i. q. jahadahu [and XaqRa Ealayohi, i. e. He, or it, jaded him, harassed him, &c.; ditressed him, afflicted him, oppressed him, overpowered him: thus in each of these instances, as in many similar cases, the verb with the inf. n. that follows is equivalent to the verb of that inf. n.]. (Msb in art. jhd.) [And, elliptically, balaga minohu i. q. balaga minohu AlmXaqRapa, explained above: and often meaning It took, or had, an effect upon him; it affected him: frequently said of wine and the like: and of a saying; as in the Ksh and
Bd in iv. 66, where yabolugu minohumo is followed by wayuWaviru fiyhi as an explicative: see also baliygN.] And balagota minRaA Albulagiyna, (S, K,) and Albilagiyna, and kulRa mabolagK: (K:) see Albulagiyna below. And balagotu mina AlOamori AlmaXaqRapa [I experienced distress from the affair, or event]. (TA in art. mD.) [See also an ex. voce UibidN. balaganiI also signifies It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told me; or it came to my knowledge, &c.: and in this case it is generally followed by OanRa, or by Oano as a contraction of OanRa: for exs., see these two particles. And in like manner, balaganiI Eanohu Information has come to me, or information came to me, from him, or concerning him, that such a thing has happened, or had happened.] And balaga said of a letter or writing, inf. n. balaAgN and buluwgN, It reached, arrived, or came. (Msb.) And said of a plant, or of herbage, It attained its full growth: (TA:) and of a tree, such as a palm-tree &c., its fruit became ripe: (AHn, TA:) and of fruit, it became ripe. (Msb.) baluga
,] (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. balaAgapN, (S, Msb,) He was, or became baliyg, i. e. faSiyH [more properly signifying chaste, or perspicuous, in speech, but here meaning eloquent]; (S, * Msb, K;) and sharp, or penetrating, or effective, in tongue; (Msb;) attaining, by his speech, or diction, the utmost scope of his mind and desire. 3 bAlg bAlg
3. bAlg, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. mubaAlagapN (JK, K, &c.) and bilaAgN, (K.) He exceeded the usual, or ordinary, or the just, or proper, bounds, or degree, in a thing; acted egregiously, or immoderately, or extravagantly, therein: (KL:) he strove, or laboured; exerted himself, or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, laboriously, sedulously, earnestly, with energy or effectiveness; took pains, or extraordinary pains: (K, TA:) he did not fall short of doing what was requisite, or what he ought; did not flag, or was not remiss: (S, K, TA:) he exerted unsparingly his power or ability, or effort or endeavour, or the utmost thereof: (Msb:) he accomplished, or did, or attained, the utmost of his power or ability, or effort or endeavour; he did his utmost: (JK:) fiI OamorK [in an affair]: (S, K, TA:) or fiI kacaA, meaning in the pursuit of such a thing. (Msb.) [bAlg fiI kacaA may be rendered as above, or He did such a thing much, exceedingly, egregiously, extraordinarily, immoderately, extravagantly, excessively, vehemently, energetically, superlatively, excellently, consummately, thoroughly. Hence mubaAlagapN in explanations of words; meaning Intensiveness; muchness; extraordinariness; excessiveness; vehemence; energy; emphasis; hyperbole; &c.; and sometimes, frequentative signification. Thus, Uisomu mubaAlagapK means A noun of intensiveness; or an intensive epithet: as XakuwrN “ very thankful, ” or “ very grateful; ” and HamRaAdN “ a great praiser, ” or “ a frequent praiser. ”]

(JK, Msb, TA.) You say, fiI hecaA bulogapN, and balaAgN↓, and tabalRugN↓, In this is a sufficiency, or enough. (Msb, TA.) And it is
said in the Kur [xxi. 106], liqawomK UinRa fiI hecaA labalaAgFA↓ EaAbidiyna Verily in this is a sufficiency [for a people serving God]: (Bd, TA:) or a means of attaining the object sought after, or desired. (Bd.)

bilagonN: see balaAgapN. ＝ -A2- Also A calumniator, or slanderer: (Kr, TA:) or one who conveys people's discourse to others. (TA.)

Albulagiyna Alblgyn
Albulagiyna, (S,) or Albilagiyna, (JK,) or both, (K,) Calamity, misfortune, or disaster: (S, K:) or distress, or affliction. (JK.) Hence the saying of 'Áïsheh to 'Alee, (S, K,) when she was taken prisoner [by him], (S,) balagota minRaA Albulagiyna, (S, K,) and Albilagiyna, (K,) i. e., AldRaAhiyapa; meaning balagota minRaA kulRa mabolagK↓ [Thou hast distressed us, or afflicted us, in the utmost degree]: (K:) it is said to mean that the war harassed her, and distressed her in the utmost degree. (TA.) It is like AlburaHiyna [and AlbiraHiyna] and AlOaTowariyna; all meaning calamities, misfortunes, or disasters: (A'Obeyd, TA:) and is as though they said xaTobN bilagN [and bulagN], meaning baliygN, and then formed the pl. thus because they considered calamities [as personified, i. e.,] as rational beings having purpose, or design. (IAth, TA.) It is invariably thus, terminating with I and n: or one may say in the nom. case Albulaguwna, and in the accus. and gen. Albulagiyna. (O, K. *) You say also, balaga bihi Albilagiyna [lit. He caused him to come, i. e. he brought him, to calamity, misfortune, or disaster, or to distress, or affliction]; meaning he went to the utmost point in reviling him, and annoying him, or molesting him. (IAar, TA.)

balaAgN blAg lAgy
balaAgN is a subst. from taboliygN and UibolaAgN, meaning The bringing, conveyance, delivery, or communication, (S, K, &c.,) of a message [&c.]. (Jel in iii. 19, &c.) [It often occurs in the Kur as meaning The communication, or announcement, of what is revealed.] ― -b2- In a trad., in which it is said, kulRu raAfiEapK rafaEato UilayonaA mina AlbalaAgi, [in the CK rufiEato ElynA,] it means What is communicated, or announced, (maA balaga,) of the Kur-án and of the [statutes, or ordinances, &c., termed] sunan: or the meaning is, mino cawiI AlbalaAgi, i. e., AltRaboliygi, [of those who have the office of communicating, or announcing,] the simple subst. being put in the place of the inf. n.: (K, TA:) but some relate it differently, saying mina AlbulRaAgi↓ [of the communicators, or announcers,] like HudRaAv in the sense of muHadRivuwn: (TA:) and some say, mina AlbilaAgi↓, meaning mina AlmubaAligiyna fiI AltRaboliygi, i. e. of those who do their utmost in communicating, or announcing. (Hr, K.) [See this trad. cited and explained more fully in the first paragraph of art. rfE.] ― -b3- hecaA balaAgN lilnRaAsi, in the Kur [xiv. last verse], means This Kur-án contains a sufficient exposition, or demonstration, for men. (TA.) ― -b4- See also bulogapN, in three places.

baliygN blyg
baliygN i. q. faSiyHN [properly signifying Chaste in speech, but here meaning eloquent]; (S, * Msb, K;) sharp, or penetrating, or effective, in tongue; (Msb;) one who attains, by his speech, or diction, the utmost scope of his mind and desire; (K, * TA;) [possessing the faculty of balaAgap; (see baluga;)] as also balogN↓, and bilogN↓, and bilagN↓, and balDAgaI↓, like sakaAray, [in the CK like sukaAray,] and bulaAgay↓, like HubaAray: (K:) or balogN↓ signifies a man who does not commit mistakes often in his speech: (JK:) the pl. of baliygN is bulagaMCu. (TA.) Applied to a saying, [&c.,] it also signifies Effectual, or producing an effect. (Ksh and Bd and Jel in iv. 66.) ― -b2- [Also Surpassing in any quality: and superlative.] It is also applied to a calamity or the like [as meaning Great, severe, distressing, or afflictive]. (IAth.)

baAligN Reaching, attaining, arriving at, or coming to, a place [or time, or an affair or a state or an event that is meditated or intended or determined or appointed; reaching, &c., to the utmost point or degree: and sometimes, being at the point of reaching &c.: see 1, first sentence]. (TA.) You say also, jayoXN balogN↓, meaning baAligN [An army reaching, or arriving at, its appointed place]. (K, TA.) And Oamoru QllRehi balogN↓, i. e. baAligN, (S, K,) meaning [The decree of God] reacheth, or attaineth, its intended object: (K:) from the saying in the Kur [lxv. 3], UinRa QllReha baAligN Oamorahu (S) Verily God attaineth his purpose. (Bd, Jel.) And baAligN fiI AlHumoqi Reaching the utmost point, or degree, in stupidity, or foolishness. (TA.) And lazimahu celika baAligFA maA balaga: see 1: and see the sentence there next following it. (Msb.) OayomaAnN baAligapN, in the Kur lxviii. 39, means Firm covenants: (Jel:) or covenants confirmed by oaths in the utmost degree: (Bd:) or rendered obligatory for ever; sworn to, that they shall be constantly observed: or that have reached their utmost point: (Th, TA:) or yamiynN baAligapN means [an oath, or a covenant,] confirmed. (TA.) ― -b2- Attaining, or having attained, to puberty, virility, ripeness, or maturity; applied to a boy: (T, IKoot, IKtt, Msb:) and in like manner, without p, applied to a girl; (T, IAmb, Msb, K;) thus applied, with the mention of the noun qualified by it, by Esh-Sháfi'ee (T, Msb) and other chaste persons, of the Arabs; (T, TA;) or baAligapN; (IKoot, Msb;) or the latter is also thus applied, with the mention of the noun which it qualifies, (T, Msb, K,) not being wrong because it is the original form; (T, TA;) and seems to be necessarily used when the noun which it qualifies is not mentioned, to prevent ambiguity. (Msb.) ― -b3- A good, a goodly, or an excellent, thing. (S, K.)

mabolagN [The place, and the time, which a person, or thing, reaches, attains, arrives at, or comes to: the utmost point to which, or towards which, one tends, or repairs, or betakes himself; to which one directs his course; or which one seeks, pursues, endeavours to reach, desires, intends, or purposes; whether it be a place, or a time, or any affair or state or event that is meditated or intended or determined or appointed: (see 1, first sentence:)] the utmost point, or scope, or degree, of knowledge [and of any attainment]: (Bd and Jel in liii. 31:) [the utmost degree of proficiency: a consummate degree of goodness and of any other quality: the age of puberty, virility, ripeness, or maturity: the sum, amount, or product, resulting from addition or multiplication: a sum of money: and particularly a considerable sum thereof: and] cash, or ready money, consisting of dirhems and of deenárs: in this sense, post-classical: pl. mabaAligu. Oabolaqu c
Oabolaqu, applied to a horse, fem. baloqaMCu, Black and white: (S, K:) or white in the hind legs as high as the thighs: (ISd, K:) pl. buloqN: which is applied by Ru-beh to mountains: but the Arabs apply the epithet Ablq to a beast of the equine kind, and Oaboraqu to a mountain (TA) and to a sheep or goat: (Lh, TA in art. brq:) the former is also applied to a rope. (JK.) Talaba AlOabolaqa AlEaquwqa (which is a prov., TA) means He sought an impossible thing; because Ablq is applied to a male, and Eqwq means pregnant: or AlAblq AlEqwq means the dawn; because it breaks, (lit., cleaves,) from EaqRahu signifying XaqRahu. (K.)

baloqaEN blqE lqE
baloqaEN and baloqaEapN↓ A land that is vacant, or void; destitute of herbage or pasturage, and of human beings, &c.; (S, K;) in which is nothing: (S:) or the former signifies a vacant, or void, place: (Mgh:) [or instead of using the former alone, you say OaroDN baloqaEN; for] you say manozilN baloqaEN [a vacant, or void, place of alighting or abiding], (S, TA,) and daArN baloqaEN [a vacant, or void, house &c.], without p, when it is an epithet, (S, TA,) applied to a mase. subst. and to a fem.; (TA;) but if it be a subst., you say, AinotahayonaA UilaI malosaMCa baloqaEapK↓ [we came at last to a smooth, vacant, or void, land]: (S, TA:) and baloqaEapN↓ also signifies a land in which are no trees, either in sands or in plain or level tracts: (TA:) or a vacant land, in which is no one, whether there be in it herbage or not, and whether plain or not: (Ham p. 445:] pl. balaAqiEu. (S, Mgh, K.) It is said in a trad., Alyamiynu AlfaAjirapu tacaru (S, Mgh, TA; but in the second and third of these, in the place of tacaru, we find tadaEu;) The false oath causes the places of abode to become void, or vacant; i. e., by reason of its evil influence, the possessions and their possessors perish; (Mgh;) or the [false] swearer becomes poor, and the property that was in his house goes away; (Sh;) or God renders him in a state of disunion, and changes the blessings which He had conferred upon him: (TA:) accord. to another relation, the words of the trad. are Alyamiynu Algamuwsu Alx. (Mgh.) You say also, diyaArN baloqaEN [Vacant, or void, places of abode]; as though the places were one place: (TA:) and Ru-beh says,
faOaSobaHato daArahumu balaAqiEaA
[And their abode became vacant]: (TA:) and it is said in a trad., OaSobaHati AlOaroDu balaAqiEa [as though meaning the land became altogether vacant]; the pl. being used to render the meaning intensive, as in the phrases OaroDN sabaAsibu and vawobN OaxolaAqN; (IAth, TA;) or because every portion thereof is considered as being blqE. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, without p and ↓with p, (tropical:) A woman devoid of every good quality. (K, TA.) ― -b3- IF says that the l in baloqaEN is augmentative. (TA.)
