baloha Oblh bl blh blp
baloha is an indecl. word with fet-h for its termination, like kayofa, and means daEo [Let alone, or say nothing of]; (S;) [i. e.] it is a noun for daEo; indecl.; (Mughnee, K;) a verbal noun, meaning daEo and Outoruko; (IAth, TA;) and the noun that
follows it, when it is thus used, is in the accus. case; (Mughnee, K;) i. e. it is indecl., with fet-h for its termination, when the noun following it is in the accus. case; so that you say, baloha zayodFA [Let alone Zeyd, or say nothing of Zeyd]; like as you say, ruwayoda zayodFA: (IB, TA:) and it is also an inf. n. in the sense of AltRaroku; likewise with fet-h for its termination, but decl.; and when it is thus used, the noun that follows it is in the gen. case; (Mughnee, K;) or it is put in the place of an inf. n., meaning taroka [which is virtually the same as Autoruko and daEo], and is prefixed to a noun in the gen. case; so that you say, baloha zayodK, i. e. taroka zayodK [which is virtually the same as baloha zayodFA explained above; for taroka zayodK is originally Autoruko zayodFA tarokFA, like as faDaroba AlrRiqaAbi in the Kur xlvii. 4 is originally fQDoribuwA AlrRiqaAba DarobFA]; (IAth, TA;) for in this case it cannot be regarded as a verbal noun, since verbal nouns are not prefixed to other nouns, governed by them in the gen. case: (IB, TA:) and it is also a noun syn. with kayofa [How?]; likewise with fet-h for its termination, indecl.; and when it is thus used, the noun that follows it is in the nom. case. (Mughnee, K.) A poet says, describing swords, (S, Mughnee,) namely, Kaab Ibn-Málik, (S,)
tacaru AljamaAjima DaAHiyFA haAmatuhaA
baloha AlOakufRa kaOanRahaA lamo tuxolaqi
[They leave the skulls with their crowns lying open to the sun (let alone, or say nothing of, the hands) as though they had not been created]: (S, Mughnee:) he says, when they cut, or cut off, the crowns, then let alone, or say nothing of, the hands (fadaEi AlOakufRa): i. e., they are more fit for cutting off the hands: (TA:) Akh says that blh is here in the place of an inf. n.; that it is as when you say, Daroba zayodK: but AlAkfR may be in the accus. case; so that the meaning may be daEi AlOakufRa: (S:) the verse is thus recited in two different ways: and also baloha AlOakufRu [how then must be the case of the hands?]. (Mughnee.) And hence the prov., tuHoriquka AlnRaAru Uino taraAhaA baloha Oano taSolaAhaA, i. e. The fire will burn thee if thou see it from a distance: then let alone, or say nothing of, (fadaEo,) thy entering into it. (TA.) A strange instance occurs in the Saheeh of El-Bukháree, in the explanation of the MlLmL of the chapter of AlsRajodap [the 32nd ch. of the Kur]: he says, God says [by these three letters], OaEodadotu liEibaAdiy AlSRaAliHiyna maA laA EayonN raOato walaA OucunN samiEato wa laA xaTari EalaI qalobi baXarK cuxorFA mino balohi maA QTRalaEotumo Ealayohi: (Mughnee, K: *) or mA OaTalaEotuhumo Ealayohi: (so in some copies of the K:) thus blh is used as a decl. word, governed in the gen. case by mn, and deviating from the three meanings [explained above]: (Mughnee, K:) but the reading commonly known is, ElI qlb bXr baloha ma OaTolaEotuhumo Elyh; and this is the reading in the work of J, [the S,] and in the Nh, and other lexicological works: (TA:) it has been explained by gayor; [so that the meaning of the sentence as first related above is, I have prepared for my righteous servants what eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath it occurred to the mind of man, as a treasure for the future, (obviously taken from Isaiah lxiv. 4, quoted by St. Paul in 1 Cor. ii. 9,) save, or except, that with which ye have become acquainted, or that with which I have acquainted them; and the same, with the omission of “ as a treasure for the future, “ is the meaning of the sentence as related in the S and Nh &c.;] (Mughnee, K;) i. e. siwaI, as in the S; (TA;) and this corroborates, (Mughnee,) or is agreeable with, (K,) the opinion of those who reckon blh as an exceptive word: (Mughnee, K:) and as meaning Oajalo [app. a mistranscription for Oajol; i. e., it has been explained also as meaning I have done all this because of my promise to them; (mino Oajoli maA OaTolaEotuhumo Ealayohi because of that with which I have acquainted them;) and thus it may have been read by SM, for he has written Ajl without any syll. signs; and has given no other ex. of blh in the sense here intended except one commencing with the words, baloha AnRiI lamo Oaxuno EahodFA, which may mean because I have not broken a covenant, or yea, verily I have not &c., accord. as we read OanRiI or UinRiI]: or as meaning kufRa [or rather kufRa Eano] and daEo [let alone, or say nothing of; but this explanation must relate to the sentence as given in the S and Nh]: (K, but omitted in an excellent copy of that work:) or, accord. to El-Ahmar, it means, in this trad. [as commonly known], kayufa [how? which seems to be the least suitable of all these explanations]. (TA.) IAmb relates, on the authority of others, that baloha is also syn. with EalaI: [but I think that this is a mistake, arising from a misunderstanding of what here follows:] Fr says that he who makes it to govern a gen. case regards it as used in the manner of EalaI, and similar particles governing the gen. case. (TA.) ― -b2- maA balohaka means maA baAluka [What is thy state, or condition, or case?]: (K, TA:) or maA laka [which often has this meaning: see the letter l]. (So in some copies of the K.)

balahN and balaAhapN↓ [both properly inf. ns.; see 1;] The attribute, or quality, denoted by the epithet OabolahN [q. v.]; (S, K;) i. e. heedlessness: (K:) or heedlessness of evil; (JK in explanation of the former, and K;) &c.; (K;) and bulahoniyapN↓ signifies the same; and stupidity and languor. (JK.)

bulahoniyapN, (K,) or balahoniyapu AlEayoXi, (JK,) or mina AlEayoXi, (S,) (tropical:) An easy and a plentiful, (S, K, TA,) or a pleasant and heedless, (JK, TA, *) state, or condition, of life: (JK, S, K, TA:) from EayoXN Oabolahu [q. v.]: (Har p. 216:) the word blhnyp is rendered quasi-coordinate to the quinqueliteral-radical class by A at the end, which is changed into I because of the kesreh before it: (S in art. blhn:) it is like rufagoniyapN and rufahoniyapN: IB says that it should be mentioned in art. blh, and means EayoXN Oabolahu; the n and I being augmentative, to render it quasicoordinate to xubaEovinapN: it is mentioned in the K [and S] in arts. blhn and blh: (TA in art. blhn:) the n is augmentative accord. to Sb. (S in the present art.) One says, laA zilota mulaqRFI bitahoniYapK mubaqRFI fiIbulahoniyapK (tropical:) [Mayest thou not cease to be greeted with congratulation, and made to continue in an easy and a plentiful state of life]. (A, K.) ― -b2- See also balahN.

balaAhapN blAhh blAhp blh
balaAhapN: see balahN.

Oabolahu c
Oabolahu Heedless: (K:) or heedless of evil (K, TA) by reason of his goodness: (TA:) or simple, foolish, or of little sense, without discrimination: (K:) or weak in intellect: (Msb:) accord. to En-Nadr, (TA,) one whose evilness is dead, (K, TA,) so that he is not cognizant of it: (TA:) good in disposition; having little cognizance, or understanding, of subtilties; or having little skill therein: (K:) or one whose predominant quality is freedom of the bosom, or heart, or mind, from evil affections; (S, K, TA;) and good opinion of men: (TA:) simple-hearted: (TK:) naturally disposed to goodness, and therefore heedless of evil, not knowing it: (T, TA:) or heedless with respect to the present world and its people and their corruptness and malevolence, but intelligent and skilled in the law with respect to that which is commanded and that which is forbidden: (Ah- mad Ibn-Hambal, TA:) fem. balohaMCu: (S, Msb, K: *) pl. bulohN: (S, Msb:) and bulahaMCu↓, a pl., [as though the sing. were baliyhN,] signifies dull, stupid, or wanting in intelligence: but this is post-classical. (TA.) Hence, XaAbRN Oabolahu [A youth, or young man, who is heedless, &c.], because of his inexperience in affairs: the epithet is applied to a youth in like manner as freedom from care, or thought, and like as insanity, are attributed to him. (S.) And xayoru OawolaAdinaA AlOabolahu AlEaquwlu (tropical:) [The best of our children is the heedless, &c., that has much intelligence]; (S, Msb;) a saying of Ez-Zibrikán Ibn-Bedr; (S;) meaning such as, by reason of his bashfulness, is like the Ablh, (S, Msb,) so that he feigns heedlessness, and passes over things, (Msb,) though he has much intelligence; (S;) or such as is thought to be stupid, but, when examined, is found to be [very] intelligent. (IAth, TA in art. Eql.) And Oakovaru Oaholi AljanRapi Albulohu, a trad., meaning Most of the people of Paradise are the buloh [or heedless, &c.,] with respect to the present world, because of their being little concerned thereby, while they are intelligent with respect to the world to come; (S;) or they are thus termed because they are heedless of their affairs in the present world, and unskilful in the management thereof, and busy themselves with their affairs relating to the world to come. (TA.) ― -b2- balohaMCu, applied to a woman, Generous, strong-hearted, (maziyrapN, for Almariyrapu in the copies of the K is a mistake for Almaziyrapu, with zAI, TA, [app. here meaning bold,]) inexperienced in affairs, and simple, or unintelligent. (K, * TA.) ISh cites a poet as applying this epithet to a young girl with whom he had sported, and who acquainted him with her secrets, by reason of her inexperience, and want of cunning, not knowing what that implied against her. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) That does not take fright, and flee from a thing, (ISh, A, K,) by reason of staidness,
(ISh, K,) or heaviness, (A,) as though she were stupid. (ISh, A, K.) One does not say jamalN Oabolahu. (ISh, TA.) ― -b4- XabaAbN Oabolahu (tropical:) Soft, or delicate, youth; (T, A, K;) as though he who enjoys it were heedless of nocturnal accidents or calamities. (A, K.) ― -b5- And EayoXN Oabolahu (tropical:) A soft, or delicate, or pleasant, or plentiful and easy, life: (K, TA:) or a life in which are few anxieties: (CK:) or a life in which are few griefs, or sorrows. (S.) [See also bulahoniyapN.]

And in the same [ii. 118], waUica QbotalaI↓ UiboraAhiyma rabRuhu bikalamaAtK [And when his Lord tried Abraham by certain words, meaning commands and prohibitions]. (TA.) And you say, laA tubolinaA↓ UilRaA biQlRatiI hiIa OaHosanu [Try Thou not us save by those things that are best]; (T;) from a trad. (TA.) [See also 4 and 8 below.] ― -b2- [Hence,] balawotuhu also signifies (tropical:) I smelt it. (T in art. bwl, and A and TA.) ― -b3- [And balaAhu He knew it, or became acquainted with it. (See baAlK.)] ― -b4- See also 4, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- baliI, aor.

(M in art. blI.)

3 laA OabaAliyhi c
3. laA OabaAliyhi is from AlblMC, [inf. n. of balaAhu,] so that it signifies [properly] I shall not, or I do not, care for him, mind him, heed him, or regard him, so as to share with him my trial and his trial: (Ham p. 94:) [and hence,] one says thus, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or maA OabaAliyhi, (M, K,) and laA OabaAliIbihi, (Mgh, Msb,) or maA OubaAliI bihi, (MF, TA,) but the verb is more chastely made trans. without the preposition bi, (A, TA,) inf. n. mubaAlaApN (M, Mgh, Msb, K) and bilaMCN (M, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, balAC]) and baAlapN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) said by some to be a quasi-inf. n. and by others to be an inf. n., (MF, TA,) [in the T it is said to be a subst., from AlmubaAlaApu,] originally baAliyapN, like EaAfiyapN from EaAfaAhu, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) and baAlN, [which is more strange,] (M, K,) meaning [merely] I shall not, or I do not, care for, mind, heed, or regard, him, or it; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) I shall not be, or I am not, disquieted by him, or it: (Mgh, Msb:) or, as some say, laA OubaAliyhi is formed by transposition from laA OubaAwiluhu, from AlbaAlu, i. e. I will not, or I do not, cause him, or it, to move, or occur to, my mind; nor give, or pay, any attention to him, or it: (Z, TA: [and the like is said in the T:]) or the proper [or literal] meaning is, I will not, or I do not, contend with him for superiority in goodness, or excellence, by reason of my little care, or regard, for him: (Mgh:) or it was employed to denote the contending with another for superiority in glory, or excellence, as will be shown by the citation of a verse in the latter portion of this paragraph; and then, in consequence of frequency of usage, came to denote contempt, or mean estimation: (Ham p. 31:) or its original meaning is, I will not, or I do not, strive with him to be first; neglecting him, or leaving him to himself; from tabaAlaI Alqawomu as explained below; see 6. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., laA yubaAliyhimu QllRehu baAlapF, or, accord. to one reading, laA yubaAliI bihimo baAlapF, meaning God will not hold them to be of any value or weight. (TA.) And in another, heWulMCi fiI AljanRapi walaA OubaAliI waheWulaMCi fiI AlnRaAri walaA OubaAliI, said to mean [These will be in Paradise, and] I shall not disapprove; [and these will be in the fire of Hell,] and I shall not disapprove. (Az, TA.) And one says, laA OubaAliI maA SanaEota [I shall not, or I do not, care for what thou didst, or hast done]. (IDrd, TA.) And maA OubaAliI Oaqumota Oamo qaEadota [I care not whether thou stand or sit]: and maA OubaAliI biqiyaAmika waEadamihi [I care not for thy standing and thy not doing so]. (Mughnee in art. A.) And maA baAlayotu bihi (AZ, Msb, TA) I did not care for, mind, or regard, him, or it. (TA.) And baAlaI biAlXRaIoCi [He cared for the thing; or] he was disquieted by the thing. (T.) The verb is sometimes thus used, in an affirmative manner; (Ham p. 94; [and the like is said in the TA;]) though some say that it is not; (Msb;) but it is not unless it occurs with a negative in the former part of the sentence or in the latter part thereof; as when one says, maA baAlaI bika Sadiyquka walekino baAlaI Eaboduka [Thy friend cared not for thee, but thy slave cared]; and as in the saying of Zuheyr,
laqado baAlayotu maZoEana OumRi OawofaI
walekino OumRu OawofaI laA tubaAliI
[Verily I cared for the departure of Umm-Owfà, but Umm-Owfà cares not]. (Ham p. 94.) One says also, lamo OubaAli and lamo Oubalo [I did not care, &c.]: (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K: [but in the CK the latter of these is omitted:]) in the latter the A [of prolongation] is suppressed for the purpose of alleviating the utterance, like as I is suppressed in the inf. n. [or quasi-inf. n.] baAlapN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) originally baAliyapN, (S, Msb,) and in laA Oadori: (S:) or the A is suppressed in this case to avoid the concurrence of two quiescent letters; (Kh, Sb, M, IB;) not for the purpose of alleviating the utterance; (IB, TA;) for this is done because the l is made quiescent. (Kh, Sb, M.) And, accord. to Kh, (Sb, M,) some of the Arabs say, lamo Oubalihi [I did not care for him, or it], (Sb, M,) or lamo Oubali, [in the CK, erroneously, lm Aaboli,] with kesr to the l; (K, TA;) [for lm OubaAlihi, or lm OubaAli;] only suppressing the A, as they do in EulabiTN [for EulaAbiTN]. (Sb, S, M.) ― -b2- IAar says that baAlaI, inf. n. mubaAlaApN, is like OabolaI↓ meaning He exerted himself in a description of a war, or battle, or of generous conduct; as when one says, OabolaI celika Alyawoma balaMCF HasanFA [He exerted himself well, that day, in a description of war, &c.]: and he cites the following verse [to which reference has been made above]:
waOanota qadomatRa mina AlhuzaAli
[What hath happened to me that I see thee standing exerting thyself in a description of generous qualities, when thou hast become like one dead by reason of leanness?]: he says that he [the poet] heard him [whom he thus addresses] saying, “ We have eaten and we have drunk [with guests], and we have done [such and such things]; ” enumerating, or recounting, generous qualities or actions, and lying in doing so: (T, TA:) in another place he says that tubaAliI means looking to see which of them [or of thee and others] is best in bAl [i. e. state, or condition], while thou art dying: (TA:) he says, also, that baAlaAhu, inf. n. mubaAlaApN, signifies he contended with him for superiority in glory, or excellence; (T, TA; *) and [it is said that] tbAlI
in the verse here cited means thus contending; syn. tufaAxiru: (Ham p. 31:) and accord. to IAar, baAlaAhu also signifies he contended with him in contradiction. (T, TA.)

4 AblAhu Obl OblAh OblI AblAh AblAp
4. AblAhu, inf. n. UibolaMCN: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] AblAhu QllRehu UibolaMCF HasanFA, (T,) or balaMCa HasanFA, (S,) God did to him a good deed. (T.) [And hence,] it is said in the Kur [viii. 17], waliyuboliIa AlmuWominiyna minohu balaMCF HasanuA (TA) And that He might confer upon the believers a great benefit, or favour, or blessing: (Bd:) or a good gift; meaning spoil. (Jel.) And Oabolayotuhu maEoruwfFA [I conferred upon him a favour, or benefit]. (S.) Zuheyr says,
jazaI QllRehu biA lUiHosaAni maA faEalaA bikumo
waOabolaAhumaA xayora AlbalaMCi AlRaciI yaboluw
(T, * S,) meaning, AlcI yaboluw bihi EibaAdahu, (T,) or AlcI yaxotabiru bihi EibaAda, (S,) i. e. [May God recompense with beneficence what they two have done to you,] and do to them two the best of the deeds wherewith He tries [the thankfulness of] his servants. (T.) ― -b3- AblAhu also signifies He made him to swear; [as though he tried his veracity by so doing;] (M, K;) or so AblAhu yamiynFA. (TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b4- And He swore to him: (M, K:) or this, (TA,) or AblAhu yamiynFA, [as above,] (T, S,) he swore [or swore an oath] to him, and thereby soothed, or placated, his mind. (T, S, * TA.) ― -b5- And hence, (TA,) He informed him, acquainted him, or told him. (IAar, M, K, TA.) ― -b6- [And hence, He manifested it; revealed it; made it manifest, apparent, evident, clear, or plain; whence a phrase in a verse cited voce muDomarN; and the phrase] maA lamo yuboli AlEucora, i. e. As long as he does not manifest, show, or make apparent, the excuse: but the verb [in this sense] is originally doubly trans.: one says, Oabolayotu fulaAnFA EucorFA, meaning I manifested to such a one an excuse so that I was not to be blamed after it; properly signifying I made such a one to be acquainted with my excuse, and to know the manner thereof; (Mgh;) and thus it is explained in the A: (TA: [in like manner, also, it is explained in the T:]) [or] AblAhu EucorFA signifies He gave him an excuse which he accepted: (M, K:) and in like manner, AblAhu juhodahu [He gave him his endeavour, or energy, in an acceptable manner]; and naAYilahu [his gift]. (M.) Hence, AblI Eucorahu signifies also He strove, laboured, or exerted himself, [and thus manifested his excuse,] in work. (Mgh.) And hence, AblI fiI AlHarobi He manifested, or showed, his might, valour, or prowess, in war, or fight, [and he strove, laboured, or exerted himself, therein, (Eucorahu being understood,)] so that men proved him and knew him. (Mgh.) See also 3, where another explanation of AblI is given, in the latter portion of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- AblI AlvRawoba [He wore out the garment;] trans. of baliIa; (T, S, M, K;) as also balRaAhu↓; (M, K;) belonging to the present art. and to art. blI. (M.) One says to the mujidR [i. e. him who makes, or puts on, a new garment], Oaboli wa yuxolifu QllRehu [Wear out thy garment, and God will replace it with another; or, may God replace &c.]. (S.) And Oaboli wa OajidRa waQHomida AlkaAsiI Wear out, and make new, [or put on new,] and praise the Clother [meaning God]. (S in art. jd.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlsRafaru balRaAhu↓ [Journeying, or travel, wore him, or wasted him]; namely, a man; (M, K; but in the copies of the latter, balaAhu↓ [which I think an evident mistranscription];) as also Ealayohi blRI↓; and AblAhu: (M:) and so AlhamRu [anxiety], (M, K,) and the like, (M,) and AltRajaAribu [tryings, or trying events]: (K:) and AblAhA AlsRafaru (T, S) or blRAhA↓ (thus in a copy of the S) [journeying, or travel, wore her, or wasted her]; namely, a she-camel. (T, S.) El-'Ajjáj says,
waAlmaroCu yuboliyhi balaMCa AlsRirobaAlo
karRuAllRayAliI waQxotilaAfu AlOaHowaAlu
[And man, the returning of the nights time after time, and the alternation of states of being, wear him out as the wearing out of the shirt]: (S, M: *) he means, UibolaMCa AlsirobaAl, or fabaliIa balaMCa AlsRirobaAl. (M.) And Ibn-Ahmar says,
labisotu OabiI HatRaI tamalRayotu Eumorahu
wabalRayotu OaEomaAmiI wa balRayotu xaAliyaA
he means I lived the period that my father lived [so that I had long enjoyment of his life, and I outwore my paternal uncles, and I outwore my maternal uncle]: or, as some say, I lived with my father for the length of his life &c. (M, TA. * [In the latter, tabalRayotu↓ is put in the place of tamalRayotu; and hence it is there said that tabalRaAhu is like balRaAhu: but I think that tblRyt is a mistranscription.]) ― -b3- Oabolayotu and balRayotu↓ also signify I bound the foreshank of a she-camel to her arm at the grave of her [dead] master, and left her without food or water until she died; or I dug for her a pit, and left her in it until she died. (S, TA. [See baliyRapN, and mubalRFI.])

8 AbtlAhu AbtlAh AbtlAp QbtlAh QbtlI
8. AbtlAhu: see 1, in three places. [Hence, AubotiliIa bikacaA (vulg. AibotalaI) He was tried, proved, or tested, by, or with, such a thing; generally meaning he was afflicted thereby, or therewith; as, for instance, by, or with, a disease.] ― -b2- Also He asked, or sought, or desired, of him information, or news, or tidings. (M, K.) And AbtlI signifies also He conjured, or adjured, and asked if any had knowledge; syn. AisotaHolafa and AisotaEorafa [explained by what here follows]. (M, K, TA. [In the CK, both the verb and the explanation are here wrong: the former is written AuboliIa; and the latter, AsotuHolifa w AsotuEorifa.]) A poet says,
tabagRaI OabaAhaA fiI AlrRifaAqi wa tabotaliI
wa Oawoday bihi fiI lujRapi AlbaHori tamosaHu
[She seeks for her father among the travellingcompanions, and conjures, or adjures, and asks. if any have knowledge, when a crocodile has destroyed him in the depth of the great river: tabagRaI is for tatabagRaI]: he means that she says to them, “ I conjure you, or adjure you, by God, (naAXadotukumo QllReha,) [tell me,] do ye know any tidings of my father? ” (M, TA.) But Aboo-Sa'eed says that ttblI here means tries, proves, or tests; and that AlAibotilaMCu signifies the trying, proving, or testing, whether by an oath or otherwise. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also He desired it; he sought it.] It is said in a trad., AlnRacoru maA QbotuliIa bihi wajohu QllRehu, i. e. [The vow that a man makes to be binding, or obligatory, on himself is that whereby the recompense of God] is desired, or sought. (TA.) ― -b4- And He chose him, made choice of him, or elected him. (Sh and T, from a trad.)

balaMCN (T, S, Msb) and balowaI↓ (T, S, M, Msb, K) and baliyRapN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and bilowapN↓, (S, M, K,) with kesr, (S, K,) and biloyapN↓, (so in a copy of the S, beside the third,) thus in the handwriting of Aboo-Zekereeyà, in the place of the third, (TA,) substs. (T, M, Msb, K) from balaAhu QllRehu, (T, Msb,) or from AibotalaAhu QllRehu, [which is the same in meaning,] (M,) or from balawotuhu, (K,) are one [in their signification; which is A trial, as meaning a probation, or a test; and as meaning particularly a trouble or an affliction of any kind by which one's patience or any other grace or virtue is tried, proved, or tested]; (S;) and the pl. (S, TA) of baliyRapN↓ (TA) is balaAyaA, of the measure faEaAYilu
changed to faEaAlaI: (S, TA:) [or] balaMCN is [properly, or originally,] an inf. n., (S, M, K,) and signifies the act of trying, proving, or testing, by, or with, good, and by, or with, evil: (S, M:) it is evil and good: (T, M: *) a trial, or an affliction, (T, K,) which is its original meaning; (T;) and a [probationary] benefit, favour, or blessing, (T,) or a [probationary] gift; (K;) the former of these requiring patience, and the latter being the greater of the two [as being commonly the more dangerous to the soul]; (TA;) [but the latter meaning is generally indicated only by the addition of an epithet: thus] balaMCN HasanN means a great benefit, or favour, or blessing, of God; (Bd in viii. 17;) or a good gift of God: (Jel ibid.:) balaMCN also means grief; as though it tried the body: (Er-Rághib, K:) and the imposition of a difficult, or troublesome, thing; a requirement; an exaction; because it is difficult, or distressing, to the body; or because it is trying. (K.) balaMCi (like qaTaAmi, S, K) is syn. with AlbalaMCu: (S, M, K:) occurring in the saying, nazalato balaMCi EalaI AlkufRaAri [Trial, or affliction, befell the unbelievers]: (S, M, * K: *) mentioned by El-Ahmar, as heard by him from the Arabs. (S.)

baliyRapN: see balaMCN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A she-camel that has her fore shank bound to her arm at the grave of her master, and is left without food until she dies: (T:) or a she-camel, (M in arts. blw and blI, and K,) or a mare, or beast of the equine kind, (M in art. blw,) that is bound at the grave of her master, (M, K,) he being dead, and is left without food or water (M) until she dies (M, K) and wastes away; for they used to say that her master would be raised from the dead upon her: (M:) or a she-camel which, in the Time of Ignorance, had her fore shank bound to her arm at the grave of her master, and was left without food or water until she died: or for which was dug a pit, wherein she was left until she died: for they used to assert that men would be raised from the dead riding upon the balaAyaA, [pl. of baliyRapN in the sense above explained, (T, TA,)] or walking if their beasts whereon they rode were not bound, with the head turned backwards, at their graves: (S:) or a cow, or she-camel, or sheep, or goat, which, in the Time of Ignorance, they used to hamstring, or slaughter, at the grave: so in a trad. (TA.) Suh says that this custom proves that, in the Time of Ignorance, they held the doctrine of the resurrection of the body: but they who held it were the fewer number. (TA.) It is said that baliyRapN is originally mubolaApN↓ or mubalRaApN↓. (TA.) Et-Tirimmáh says,
manaAzilu laA taraI AlOanoSaAba fiyhaA
walaA Hufara AlmubalRaI lilomanuwni
[Places of abode in which thou wilt not see the stones, or other things, that have been set up to be worshipped, nor the pits of the beast left by the grave of the master to die]; meaning places of abode of the people of El-Islám, exclusively of the pagans. (S.) IAar says that baliIRN↓ and baliyRapN signify Such as is wearied, or jaded, and emaciated, and dying. (TA.)

(TA.)

balaI bl blI bly ly
balaI is a particle; (S, Msb, Mughnee;) contr. of laA: (S:) not a noun: (Sb, S:) it is a replicative; (S, Mughnee;) an affirmative of what is said [in that to which it is a reply]; (S, Msb;) [with very few exceptions] relating only to a negation, which it annuls: (Msb, Mughnee:) the final letter is a radical: or, accord. to some, the word is originally balo, [after which an affirmation is to be understood,] and the final letter is augmentative: and some of these say that this letter is a denotative of the fem. gender, because it is [often] pronounced with imáleh. (Mughnee.) It is a reply to an interrogation in which is a negative, (T, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) and affirms what is said to thee [in that interrogation]; (M, K;) whether it be an interrogation in the proper sense, (Mughnee,) as when you say to another, Oalamo tafoEalo kacaA [Didst thou not such a thing?], and he replies, balaI [meaning Yes, or yea, or ay, I did], (T,) or as when one says, Oalayosa zayodN biqaAYimK [Is not Zeyd standing?], and you reply, balaI [Yes, he is]; or be meant to convey reproof, (Mughnee,) as in the Kur [lxxv. 3 and 4], OayaHosabu AlUinosaAnu Oano lano najomaEa EiZaAmahu balaI [Doth man think that we will not collect his bones? Yes], (Msb, Mughnee,) i. e., we will collect them; (Msb;) or be meant to make a person confess, or acknowledge, a thing, (Mughnee,) as in the Kur [vii. 171], Oalasotu birabRikumo qaAluwA balaI [Am I not your Lord? They said, Yea]. (M, Mughnee.) It is also a reply to a simple negation, (Msb, Mughnee,) as when I say, maA qaAma zayodN [Zeyd did not stand, or has not stood], and you reply, balaI as an affirmative [meaning Yes, he did, or he has]. (Msb.) It occurs in the Kur [xxxix. 60], where it is said, balaI qado jaMCatoka MyaAtiI [Yea, my signs have come to thee], preceded by that which is not literally a negation, but which has the force of a negation; for the preceding saying, lawo OanRa QllReha hadaAniI [If God had directed me aright, or would that God &c.], is like the saying, maA hudiytu [I was not directed aright]. (M.) It also occurs in the books of traditions, in some instances, as a reply to an interrogation without a negative; but these instances are rare, and not to be followed in rendering revelation. (Mughnee.) Az says that when a man says to another, OalaA taquwmu [Wilt thou not stand?], and the latter replies, balaI, he means balo Oaquwmu [Nay, I will stand], adding the alif [written I] to make the pause good; for if he said, balo, the other would expect something more to be said after it. (TA.) It is said that the pronunciation termed imáleh is allowable in the case of balaI; and if so, its final radical letter is I: and some of the grammarians say that this pronunciation of blI is because, by reason of its completeness and independence of meaning, so that it requires nothing after it, it resembles independent nouns, in the cases of which this pronunciation is allowable. (M.)

bano is a dial. var. of balo, (M, K,) and so is laA bano of laA balo; or, as some say, formed by substitution [of n for l; not peculiar to any dialect]. (M.) One says, bano waQllRehi laA Mtiyka [Nay, by God, I will not come to thee]: Fr says that it is of the dial. of Benoo-Saad and Kelb; and that he had heard the Báhilees say, laA bano, meaning balo [or laA balo]: but IJ says, I do not trace up bano [to any authority] as being an independent word of a particular dialect. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [bonu and boni and bona, for Qbonu &c.: see art. bnI.]

bunRN bAn bn bnn
bunRN [Coffee-berries, whether green or roasted, whole or reduced to powder by pounding or grinding;] expl. in the K as XaIoCN yutRaxacu kaAlmurRiIRi [a certain thing that is taken like the condiment termed murRiyR, which is used to give relish to food or to quicken the appetite]; Ibn-Es-Sim'ánee says, huwaXaIoCN fiI AlkawaAmiyxi [app. meaning it is a thing reckoned among what are termed kwAmyx, pl. of kaAmaxN, which signifies the same as murRiIRN, for it seems that fI is here used in the sense of mino, or it may be a mistranscription for mino]; the physician Dáwood says, it is the produce of certain trees in El-Yemen; the berries thereof are put into the earth in McaAr [the Syrian month corresponding to March, O. S.], and it increases, and is gathered in Oabiyb [the Coptic month commencing on the 25th of June, O. S.; the 7th of July, N. S.]; it grows to the height of about three cubits, on a stem of the thickness of the thumb, and has a white flower, which is succeeded by a berry like the hazel-nut; sometimes it is cut like beans; and sometimes, when it is divested of its covering, it divides into two halves: it has been proved to be good for alleviating humidities, and cough, and phlegm, and defluxions, and for opening obstructions, and causing a flow of the urine: when roasted, [and pounded or ground,] and well cooked, [i. e. boiled in water,] it is now commonly known by the name of qahowap. (TA.) [Golius, I think, has misunderstood the explanation of this word in the K: after having given that explanation, and rendered it by “ res quæ sumitur instar AlmrI Múrriji, ” he adds, “ Pers. AbkAmh Abcâma dictæ: hæc sorbitio est rei ex hordeo et frumento paratæ multa cura et arte, quam Malajesa et Halimæus describunt. ” He then mentions the signification of coffee-berries as a second and distinct meaning.]

binRN bAn bn bnn
binRN A place having a fetid odour. (Fr, T, K.) ＝ -A2- It also signifies TiroqN mina AlXRaHomi (T, K) and AlsRimani (K, TA: in the CK AlsRamoni:) [said in the TA to mean quwRapN minohumaA, i. e. Strength arising from fat and from fatness: but I think that waAlsRimani has been added in the K in consequence of a misunderstanding, and that the meaning is a layer of fat; this meaning seeming to be indicated by the ex. here following, and corroborated by significations of several conjugates of TiroqN, as TariyqapN and TaraqN and TiraAqN &c.] One says (T, K) of a beast (daAbRap) when it has become fat, (T,) rakibahaA binRN EalaIbinK (T, K *) and TiroqN EalaI TiroqK (T) [clearly I think, meaning Layer upon layer, of fat, has accumulated upon it.]

banRapN bn bnh bnp
banRapN A sweet, or pleasant, odour; (As, AA, T, S, M, K;) such as that of the apple (T, M) and the like, (M,) or the quince: (T:) Sb says that it is a name for a sweet, or pleasant, odour, like xamoTapN: (M, * TA:) and an unpleasant odour; (As, T, S;) a fetid odour; (M, K;) whence banRapN Algazoli [the odour of the yarn] occurring in a saying of 'Alee, respecting a weaver; (M;) which shows that A'Obeyd erred in asserting it to have only the first of the foregoing significations; (IB, TA;) which Suh, in the R, assigns also to bunaAnapN↓: (TA:) the odour of sheep, or goats, (S, M,) or of camels or cattle; (Z, TA;) and of the dung of gazelles; (S, K;) and of the lodging-places of sheep or goats and of oxen or bulls or cows and of gazelles: (T, M:) and sometimes the lodgingplaces themselves, of sheep or goats: (M, TA:) pl. (in all the senses, M) binaAnN. (T, S, M, K.)

bunRiIRN A seller of bunR [or coffee-berries]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [vulgarly pronounced binRiI,] A species of fish; (K;) [the cyprinus Bynni of Forskål; described by him in his Descr. Anim. p. 71;] it is white, and is the best kind [of fish], and abundant in the Nile. (TA.)

banaAnN bnAn
banaAnN The fingers; syn. OaSaAbiEu: (M, Msb, K:) but whether it means peculiarly the ASAbE of the hand, or those of the foot also, [i. e. the toes,] is disputed: (TA:) or the ends, or extremities, thereof: (S, M, Msb, K:) said to be so called because by their means are ordered those circumstances whereby man continues in existence; from OabanRa biAlomakaAni: (Msb:) mentioned in the Kur viii. 12 because therewith one fights, and defends himself: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it there signifies all the limbs, or members, of the body: (Aboo-Is-hák, M:) or the fingers, or toes, and any other parts of all the limbs, or members: (Zj, TA:) or it means in the Kur the XawaI; (Lth, T, TA;) so in lxxv. 4; (M;) i. e. the arms or hands and the legs or feet: (Lth, T, TA:) accord. to El-Fárisee the meaning of the words in the Kur lxxv. 4 is, we are able to make their extremities like those of the camel, so that they should not profit by them in handicraft: (M, TA:) the n. un. is with p; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) meaning, accord. to Lth, a single UiSobaE [i. e. finger, or toe]; or, accord. to AHeyth, the whole ASbE; or, as some say, the highest Euqodap [or joint] of the ASbE: (T:) the pl. of pauc. is banaAnaAtN; but a pl. of mult. is sometimes used as one of pauc.; and hence the saying of the rájiz,
xamosa banaAnK qaAniYi AlOaZofaAri
[Five fingers, or ends of fingers, intensely red from the dye of hinnà in the nails], meaning xamosFA mina AlbanaAni: and one says, banaAnN muxaDRabN [Fingers, or ends of fingers, dyed, or much dyed, with hinnà]; for every pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] between which and its sing., or n. un., there is no difference but p [added in the latter] may be treated as sing. and masc. (S.) Lth cites as an ex. of the n. un.,
layosa liHaIRK fawoqahumo banaAnaho
laAhumRa Oakoramota baniI kinaAnah
meaning [O God, Thou hast honoured the sons of Kináneh: there belongs not to any tribe] excel-lence of the measure of a finger above them. (T, TA.)

Applied to a mixture of urine and dung (Eabas) upon the tail [of a camel &c.], it may mean Cleaving, and sticking: or it may be from banRapN signifying “ a fetid odour ” [so as to mean having a fetid odour]: thus, in this case, it may be either a part. n. or a possessive epithet. banojN bnj
banojN [Hyoscyamus, or henbane;] an arabicized word, [said to be] from [the Persian] banoko; [but see a quotation from Hammer-Purgstall, near the close of this paragraph;] a certain plant, (Mgh,
and Har p. 365,) having an intoxicating kind of grain, or, as some say, (Mgh,) of which the leaves and peel and seeds torpify: (Mgh, Har:) it is said, in the Kánoon, (Mgh,) by Aboo-'Alee [Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna], (Har,) that it is a poison which confuses the intellect, and annuls the memory, and occasions insanity and [the disorder termed] xunaAq [or quinsy]; (Mgh, Har;) and it is red, and white: (Har:) a certain plant having a kind of grain that confuses the intellect, and occasions alienation of the mind, or insanity; and sometimes it intoxicates, when a man drinks it after it has been dissolved; and it is said to occasion forgetfulness: (Msb:) a certain torpifying plant, well known; different from HaXiyXu AlHaraAfiyXi; disordering the intellect (muxabRiTN liloEaqoli), rendering insane, allaying the pains of humours and pustules, and the earache, (K, TA,) applied as a liniment or as a poultice; (TA;) the worst kind (K, TA) for use (TA) is the black; then, the red; and the safest kind is the white. (K, TA.) [Kzw says that the leaves of the garden-hemp (qinRab busotaAniIR, or XahodaAnaji, the latter of which properly signifies hemp-seed,) are the banoj which, when eaten, disorders the intellect. And ElIdreesee applies the appellation HaXiyXiyRap to the “ Assassins. ” This establishes the correctness of De Sacy's opinion, that the appellation “ Assassins ” is derived from the vulgar pl. HaXRaAXiyn, (hemp-eaters, or persons who intoxicate themselves with hemp,) for HaXRaAXiyn is syn. with HaXiyXRap, and the sect called by us the “ Assassins ” are expressly said by the Arabs to have made frequent use of banoj. Baron Hammer-Purgstall, correctly regarding banoj as hyoscyamus (or henbane), makes the following important observations, “ ‘ Bendj, ’ the pl. of which in Coptic is ‘ nibendj, ’ is without doubt the same plant as the ‘ nepenthe, ’ which has hitherto so much perplexed the commentators of Homer. Helen evidently brought the nepenthe from Egypt, and bendj is there still reputed to possess all the wonderful qualities which Homer attributes to it. ” (Trébutien, “ Contes Inédits des Mille et une Nuits, ” tome i. p. 12, note.)] The phrase Xariba Albanoja is used by ElKarkhee [as meaning He drank the bnj] because it is mixed with water; or [as meaning he took, or swallowed, the bnj,] according to the conventional language of the physicians. (Mgh.)

mubanRijN mbnj
mubanRijN One who employs a stratagem by means of food containing banoj [in order to obtain some advantage over another, by stupifying him therewith; as the “ Assassins ” used to do]. (Mgh.)

banodN bnd nd
banodN is a Persian word arabicized, originally signifying A knot, or tie. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) (tropical:) [Any of] the stops that are put between the beads of the suboHap to mark the place where the performer of tasobiyH pauses on the occasion of a thing's diverting his attention: so in the Comm. on the Tohfeh by the seyyid 'Omar El-Basree: (MF, TA:) app. post-classical and recent. (TA.) ― -b3- A dam; a thing that stops, or dams, [water, or] from water (AlRaciI yusokiru mina AlmaMCi). (K. [In the CK, yusokaru is put in the place of yusokiru. In this sense, also, it is of Persian origin.]) ― -b4- A stratagem, a trick, or an expedient, of which one makes use: (T, K:) a snare by which one snares men: (TA in art. qmT:) pl. bunuwdN. (T.) You say, fulaAnN kaviyrN Albunuwdi Such a one abounds in, or practises much, stratagems, tricks, or expedients, (Lth, T, A,) and mischievous, or calamitous, acts. (A.) In this sense, also, it is an arabicized Persian word. (TA.) ― -b5- An enigma. (TA.) ― -b6- A pawn that is tied (munoEaqidN, in the CK mutaEaqRidN,) by a queen in the game of chess: as though it confined and tied itself. (TA.) ― -b7- Also a Persian word, arabicized, (S, A,) signifying A large banner, standard, or ensign: (En-Nadr, S, A, K:) or a banner, or standard, or an ensign, of a general, or leader, (T, M,) of the Greeks, (M,) under which are ten thousand men, (T, M,) or less, or more: (T:) or a banner, or standard, or an ensign, of horsemen: (El-Hujeymee, T:) [in barbarous Latin bandum; and in Spanish, bandera; as mentioned by Golius; and in modern Arabic banodiyrN:] pl. as above: (S, M:) it has no pl. of pauc. (M.) ― -b8- [The pl.] bunuwdN also signifies, in Greece, [Provinces, or districts;] what are called OajonaAdN in Syria, and OaEoraADN in El-Hijáz, and kuwarN in El-'Irak, and maxaAliyfN in El-Yemen. (Yákoot.)

(Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

bunoduqN bndq
bunoduqN [The hazel-nut; or hazel-nuts; so in the present day;] a certain thing that is eaten; (Msb;) i. q. jilRawoz: (IDrd, K:) or, as some say, like jlRwz; brought from an island; the best whereof is the fresh, heavy, white, and sweet in taste; the old being bad: it is beneficial as a remedy for palpitation, parched with anise-seed; and for poisons, and wasting of the kidneys, and burning of the urine; and with pepper, it excites the venereal faculty; with sugar, it removes cough; and the shell thereof, burnt, and applied as a collyrium, sharpens the sight: (TA:) they assert that the suspending it upon the upper arm preserves from scorpions, (K,) i. e., from their stinging: (TA:) the moistening of the top of the head of a child with the powder of it when burnt, together with oil, removes the blueness of its eyes and the redness of its hair: and the Indian kind thereof is an antidote very beneficial to the eyes: (K, TA:) but in some copies of the K, [and so in the CK,] instead of liloEayonayoni, we here find liloEinRiyni [for the impotent in respect of the venereal faculty]: (TA:) [it is said in the Msb that most hold the n to be augmentative: but this is not the case; for] the word is Persian [arabicized, from funoduqo]: (K:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p: pl. banaAdiqu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence, Bullets, i. e.] certain things that one shoots, (S, Msb, K,) made of clay: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb, K:) the latter signifies a piece of clay, made round, which one shoots, or casts; or i. q. julaAhiqN: (Mgh:) it is said in the Shifá el-Ghaleel to be an arabicized word: (TA:) pl. as above. (S, Msb.) [See a prov. voce HidaOapN. Hence qawosu Albunoduqi The crossbow. In modern Arabic, bunoduq is also applied to Balls of any kind of the size of hazel-nuts: n. un. with p.]

bunoduqiIRN bndq bndqI bndqy bndqyy
bunoduqiIRN A garment, or piece of cloth, of fine, delicate, or thin, linen. (Sgh, K.) [SM says,] It is most probably, in my opinion, so called in relation to the land of AlbunoduqiyRap [or Venice]. (TA.) [In modern Arabic, A Venetian sequin: pl. banaAdiqapN.] bunodaqaAniIRN [app. a post-classical word,] A maker of cross-bows (qisiIR Albunoduq). (El-Makreezee's Khitat, art. xTR AlbndqAnyRyn.)

banafosajN bnfsj
banafosajN, of the measure qaEalRalN, like safarojalN, (Msb,) [an arabicized word, from the Persian banafoXa; The violet; viola odorata of Linn: and accord. to Forskål (Flora AEgypt. Arab. p. ciii.) applied in El-Yemen to the “ iris: ” and (p. cxx.) “ tagetes dubia? ”] what is thus called is well known: the smelling it in its fresh state is beneficial to those who are heated by wrath (AlmaHoruwriyn), and the continual smelling of it induces good sleep: the conserve made of it is beneficial for the pleurisy (caAtu Aljanobi), and for inflammation of the lungs (caAtu AlrRiYapi), and for cough, and for headache. (K.)

[or rather the coll. gen. n.] is binaqN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, TA:) Th mentions banaAYiqN and binaqN, and says that the latter is a pl. pl.; [i. e., pl. of the former;] but this is unintelligible: (TA:) banaAYiqN is pl. of baniyqapN, (JK, S, &c.,) and syn. with daxaAriySN. (JK.) AZ cites, from Mejnoon,
kamaA DamRa OazoraAra AlqamiySi AlbanaAYiqN
(S, IB,) which is an inverted phrase; the meaning being,
kamaA DamRa OazoraAru AlqamiySi AlbanaAYiqaA
[Like as the buttons of the shirt draw together the gores: if the last word mean the gores]: or, if the bnyqp of the shirt be really its jrbRAn, the meaning is intelligible [without inversion]; for its jrbRAn is the part around the neck, upon which are sewed the buttons; and when one desires to draw it together, he puts its buttons into the loops, and so draws together the bosom [of the shirt, with its buttons,] to the uppermost part of the chest. (IB, TA.) Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee explains AlbnAYq, here, as meaning the loops into which the buttons are inserted; and accord. to this explanation the meaning is plain, not requiring the supposition of inversion nor of deviation from the usual way: but the first explanation is that which is generally given. (TA.) In the saying,
qado OagotadiI wa AldRahoru cuw baniyqi↓
[in the last word of which, p is elided; lit., Sometimes I go forth early in the morning, when the time has a baniyqap;] Lth says that the whiteness of the dawn is likened to the whiteness of the bnyqp; citing another verse, in which a shirt is described as having white bnAYq. (TA.)

1 banaAhu bAny bnAC bnAh bnAp bnI bnyp nAhy
1. banaAhu, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
baniIa
, (M, Msb,) and

, but the former is the more common, (M,) [or rather the only form commonly known,] inf. n. binaMCN (T, S, M, Mgh, K) and binFA (T, and TA as from the M [but it is not in the transcript of the M in the TT]) and banoIN and bunoyaAnN and binoyapN and bnaAyapN, (M, K,) He built it; framed it; constructed it; contr. of hadamahu; (M, K;) namely, a house, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or tent, (S, * Msb,) &c.; (Msb;) as also AbtnAh↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) and bnRAhu↓; (M, K;) or the last has teshdeed given to it to denote muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects; and hence you say, bnRI quSuwrFA [He built palaces, or pavilions: or he raised them high: see the pass. part. n. below]. (S, TA.) AHn speaks of a kind of plank as being used fiI binaMCi AlsRufuni [in the construction of ships]: but binaMCN is originally used only in relation to that which does not grow; as stone, and clay, and the like. (M.) You say also, banaI OaroDFA, for banaI fiI OaroDK [He built in, or upon, land]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] banaI EalaI Oaholihi, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) or EalaI QmoraOatihi, (Mgh,) and banaI bihaA also, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) accord. to IDrd (Mgh, Msb) and IJ, (M,) and occurring in traditions and elsewhere, though said in the S to be vulgar, (IAth, MF,) and said to be so by ISk, (T, Msb,) and by some said to be not allowable, (M,) but the former is the more chaste, (Msb,) inf. n. binaMCN; (S, TA;) as also AbtnI↓, (K,) i. e. AbtnI ElyhA, (ISk, Msb,) or AbtnI bihaA, (IJ, M,) He had his wife conducted to him on the occasion of the marriage: (ISk, T, S, Msb, K:) or he went in to his wife [for the first time]: (Mgh, Msb:) originating from the fact that the bridegroom used, on that occasion, to pitch a tent for her, (ISk, T, S, Mgh, Msb,) a new tent, (Mgh, Msb,) and furnish it with what was requisite, (Msb,) or a new tent was set up for him, (Mgh, Msb,) in honour of him. (Msb.) [See also bayotN.] ― -b3- binaAyapN is sometimes used in relation to nobility: (M, K:) and the verb thus used is banaI, as above, (T, M,) having [also] binFI for its inf. n., (IAar, T,) and binaMCN; held by many to be tropical, but by some to be proper. (MF.) Lebeed says,
fasamaA Uilayohi kaholuhaA wa gulaAmuhaA
fabanaI lanaA rafiyEFA samokuhu
(M) And He (namely, God,) hath built for us a house of nobility of lofty pitch, and its (the tribe's) middle-aged and its youth have risen to it: i. e., all of them have attained to high degrees. (EM, p. 180.) ― -b4- banaI badanahu It (food) fattened his body, (K,) and made it large: (TA:) and banaI laHomahu, (T, M, K,) aor.
baniIa
, (TA,) inf. n. binaMCN, (M,) or banoIN, (TA,) It (food) made his flesh to grow, (T, M, K,) and to become large. (T, TA.) ― -b5- banaI AlrRajula He reared, brought up, or educated, the man; (M, K;) as also AbtnAhu↓. (M.) ― -b6- [banaI kalimapF, inf. n. binaMCN, He formed a word. ― -b7- And He made a word indeclinable, so as to end invariably with a quiescent letter or with a particular vowel.] binaMCu kalimapK [when the former word is considered as the inf. n. of the pass. form buniIa, generally] signifies A word's keeping always the same mode of termination, ending with a quiescent letter or with a particular vowel, not by reason of any governing word: (M, K:) as though the word resembled a fixed, immoveable building. (M.) [You say, buniyato EalaI AlsRukuwni It was made indeclinable, with a quiescent letter for its termination; and EalaI AlfatoHi with fet-h for its termination; &c. ― -b8- And in like manner you say, banaI AlqaSiydapa EalaI AlbaMCi, &c., He made the qSydp to have b, &c., for its rhyme-letter, or its chief rhyme-letter.] ＝ -A2- banati Alqawosu EalaI watarihaA The bow clave to its string (T, S, K) so that it (the latter) almost broke. (T, S.) [See the part. n. below.]

4 AbnAhu ObAn Obn ObnAh ObnnAh AbnAh AbnAp Qbn QbnAh Mb
4. AbnAhu He made him to build, frame, or construct, a house, or tent: (S:) or he gave him a building: or he gave him that wherewith to build a house: (M, K:) and AbnAhu bayotFA he gave him a house, or tent, to build or frame or construct. (T.) It is said in a prov., AlmiEozay tubohiI walaA tuboniI [Goats rend, or make holes, and render vacant, and do not afford materials for fabricating tents]; i. e., they do not yield hair of which a tent is fabricated; (T, S; *) for the tents of the Arabs [of the desert] are of the kind called TiraAf, made of skin, and Oaxobiyap, made of wool or of camels' fur, and not of XaEar [by which is especially meant goats' hair], (S,) or, as is found in the handwriting of Aboo-Sahl, of wool or of skin: (TA:) or the meaning is, goats rend tents, or pierce them with holes, by their leaping upon them, (T and S in art. bhw,) so that they cannot be inhabited, (S in that art.,) and do not aid in the fabrication of tents; for the goats of the Arabs of the desert
have short hair, not long enough to be spun; whereas the goats of the cold countries, and of the people of the fertile regions, have abundant hair, and of this the Akrád [or Kurdees] fabricate their tents. (T.) ― -b2- [Hence,] He introduced him to his wife [on the occasion of his marriage]: whence the saying of 'Alee, mataI tubonyiniI, accord. to IAth properly meaning mataI tajoEaluniI OaboniI bizawojatiI [When wilt thou make me to have my wife conducted to me? or, to go in to my wife?]. (TA.)

(T, TA.) And tbnRI, said of a camel's hump, It became fat. (M.) ＝ -A2- tbnRAhu He adopted him as a son: (S, K:) or he asserted him to be, or claimed him as, a son: (M:) and tbnRI bihi signifies the same. (Zj, TA.)

baAnK bOn bAn bAny bMn Mn
baAnK [Building, framing, or constructing]: accord. to A'Obeyd, its pl. is OabonaMCN; and in like manner, OajonaMCN is pl. of jaAnK: and hence the prov., OabonaAWuhaA OajonaAWuhaA, (M,) or OajonaAWuhaA OabonaAWuhaA, i. e. The injurers thereof, meaning this house (hecihi AldRaAr), by demolishing it, are the builders thereof. (S in art. jnI.) ISd says, I am of opinion that these two pls. are not used except in this prov.: and J says, in art. jnI, I think that the prov. is originally junaAtuhaA bunaAtuhaA; but IB affirms that it is not so: and he says that the prov. is applied to him who does, or makes, a thing without consideration, and commits a fault therein, which he repairs by undoing what he has done or made: it originated from the fact that the daughter of a certain king of El-Yemen, during his absence on a military expedition, built, by the advice of others, a house, which he, disliking it, commanded them to demolish. (TA in art. jnI. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 294.]) ― -b2- A bridegroom: from banaI EalaI Oaholihi [q. v.]. (TA.) And hence, Any one going in to his wife. baAniyapN fem. of baAnK [q. v.]. ― -b2- Also sing. of bawaAnK, (TA,) which signifies The ribs of [the breast, or of the part thereof called] the zawor: (M, K:) or the bones of the breast: or the shoulder-blades
and the four legs: (TA:) and the legs of a she-camel. (M, K.) One says, [likening a man to a camel lying down,] OaloqaI bawaAniyhu, meaning He took up his abode, and settled, (T, M, K,) in a place; like OaloqaI EaSaAhu. (T, M.) OaloqaI AlXRaOomu bawaAniyahu [meaning Syria became in a settled state] occurs in a trad. as related by A'Obeyd: and if he said bawaAYinahu, it would be allowable; bawaAYinu being pl. of bwAn, [i. e. buwaAnN or biwaAnN,] which is a name for any tent-pole except in the middle of the bayot, which has three poles. (T.) And it is said in another trad., Oaloqati AlsRamaMCu biraka bawaAniyhaA, meaning The sky cast down the rain that it contained. (TA.)

AibonN ObAn Obn Obnn Abn bAn bnI Qbn Mb
AibonN, meaning A son; (M, Mgh, K;) because he is the father's building, made to be so by God; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and (tropical:) a son's son; and (tropical:) a descendant more remote; (Msb;) is with a conjunctive A [when not immediately preceded by a quiescence, written QbonN]; (Zj, T, M;) [and when immediately preceded by the proper name of a man and immediately followed by the proper name of his parent, written without the A, as in zayodu bonu EamorKw Zeyd the son of 'Amr (in which case it should also be observed that the former proper name is without tenween); unless the words compose a proposition, as in zayodN Qbonu EamorKw Zeyd is the son of 'Amr; or in the case of an interrogation, as in halo zayodN Qbonu EamorKw Is Zeyd the son of 'Amr?]: the pl. is banuwna↓ (T, S, Mgh, Msb) in the nom. case, and baniyna in the accus. and gen.; (Mgh;) and OabonaMCN, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is a pl. of pauc.: (Msb:) [and hence it is argued that] the sing. is of the measure faEalN with the final radical letter elided and the conjunctive A prefixed; (M;) originally banaIN, (M, K,) with I, as we judge, because [the aor.] yaboniI is more common than yabonuw: (M:) or originally banawN, (S, Msb, K,) with two fet-hahs, because it has banuwna for a pl., and the perfect pl. does not admit of change [in its vowels beyond that which is here made in banuwna for banawuwna]; (Msb;) and because it has for a pl. OabonaMCN, like as jamalN has OajomaAlN; (S;) and the elided letter is w, (Akh, T, S,) as in OabN and OaxN, (S,) because w is more commonly elided than I; (Akh, T;) or because the fem. is binotN and [that of OaxN is] OuxotN; for we do not see this h [or t] affixed in the fem. except when w is elided in the masc., as is shown by OaxawaAtN and hanawaAtN; (S;) though bunuwRapN is not a decisive proof that the last radical is w, for a reason stated above in the explanation of it: (T:) or, as some say, it is originally binowN, with kesr to the. b, like HimolN, because they say binotN, and a change [of a vowel] in a case of this kind is rare: (Msb:) [but J says,] it may not be of the measure fiEolN nor fuEolN, because it has banuwna with fet-h to the b, for a pl.; nor of the measure faEolN, because this has [generally] for its [broken] pl. OafoEulN or fuEuwlN: (S:) Zj says that it is originally binoIN or binowN, or it may be originally banFA; that it is app. the last accord. to those who say banuwn; and that OabonaMCN may be pl. of the measure faEalN and of fiEolN; that binotN favours its being of the latter; but that it may be of the measure faEalN changed to fiEolN, as faEalN is changed to fuEolN in the case of OuxotN. (T.) Beside the pls. mentioned above, AibonN has a quasi-pl. n., namely OabonaI↓, of the same measure as OaEomaI; (Mgh, TA; *) a sing. denoting the pl.: or, as some say, AibonN has for pls. OabonaMCN and OabonaI. (TA.) Lh mentions the phrase, heWulaMCi OabonaA OabonaAYihimo [or OabonaI AbnAYhm These are the sons of their sons.]. (M.) Sometimes m is affixed to AibonN [so that it becomes AibonumN↓ or AibonamN at the beginning of a sentence, and QbonumN↓ or QbunamN in other cases]: the word is then doubly declinable [like AimoruWN or QmoruON]: you say, hecaA QbonumN [This is a son], and raOayotu QbonamFA [I saw a son], and mararotu biQbonimK [I passed by a son]; making the n similarly declinable to the m; and the A is with kesr in every case [when the word commences a sentence, whether you make the word doubly declinable or not]: (AHeyth, * S:) [for] some make it singly declinable, leaving the n with fet-h in every case [as the r in AimoraON or QmoraON]; saying, hecaA Qbonamuka [This is thy son], and raOayotu Qbonamaka [I saw thy son], and mararotu biQbonamika [I passed by thy son]. (AHeyth, TA.) Hassán says,
waladonaA baniI AlEanoqaMCi waQbonaIo muHarRiqK
faOakorimo binaA xaAlFA waOakorimo binaA QbonamaA↓
[We begot the sons of El-'Ankà, and the two sons of Moharrik; and how generous are we as a maternal uncle! and how generous are we as a son!], (S, K, *) i. e., QbonaA: the m is augmentative, and the hemzeh [or rather A] is that of conjunction. (K.) And Ru-beh says,
fahoIa tunaAdiI biOabiI waQboniymaA↓
bukaMCa XakolaI faqadato HamiymaA
[As the weeping of a bereft woman, who has lost a relation, therefore she calls out, With my father would I ransom thee, and a son]; meaning QbonimaA. (TA.) The fem. of AibonN is AibonapN↓ or QbonapN [with the conjunctive A when not commencing a sentence] and binotN↓ [meaning A daughter; and (assumed tropical:) any female descendant]: (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) accord. to Sb, (M,) AibonapN is formed from AibonN by affixing h [or p]; but not so binotN; for this is formed by affixing I as a letter of quasi-coordination, and then substituting for it t: (M, K:) [but if the t be substituted for I, it seems more probable that the I is the final radical:] or, as some say, the t is substituted for w: (M:) [Mtr says,] the t is substituted for the final radical: (Mgh:) accord. to Ks, it is originally with h [or p], because it has a fem. meaning: (IAar, Msb:) [my own opinion is most agreeable with this of Ks; and with that of Zj, which will be mentioned below; or, perhaps, is identical with that of Zj: I think it most probable that, as AibonN is generally held to be originally banaIN or banawN, so AibonapN and binotN are both originally banayapN or banawapN, and that binotN is formed from AibonapN by suppressing the alif, transferring its kesreh to the b, making the n quiescent, and changing the p into t, which is therefore said to be not the sign of the fem. gender, either because it is not p, but is a substitute for p, or because it is preceded by a quiescent letter:] AHn says that the t is substituted for the final radical letter, which is w; and that it is not the sign of the fem. gender, because the letter [next] before it is quiescent: this [he says] is the opinion of Sb, and is the right opinion; for he says that if you were to use it as the proper name of a man, you would make it perfectly decl.; and if the t were to denote the fem. gender, the name would not be perfectly decl.: (TA:) and the same is said respecting the t in OuxotN: (TA in art. Axw:) this t remains in a case of pause (Ks, IAar, S, Msb) as in the case of the connexion of the word with a word following: (S:) but one should not say AibinotN, (Th, T, S.) because the A is required only on account of the quiescence of the b, and is therefore dropped when this is made movent: (S:) Zj says that, in forming the pl. of binotN [and of AibonapN], the sing. is reduced to its original form, which is faEolapN [as I find it written in the transcript from the T in the TT, but it may be a mistake for faEalaPN,] with the last radical letter suppressed: (T in TT:) the pl. is banaAtN (T, S, Msb) alone: (S:) [and this is generally treated as a fem. pl. of the perfect, or sound, kind, although the t in binotN is said to be not a sign of the fem. gender; so that you say, raOayotu banaAtika I saw thy daughters; but sometimes] one says, raOayotu banaAtaka, with fet-h [as the case-ending], treating the t as a radical letter. (S.) It is said in the Bári' that when men and women are mixed together, the masc. pl. is made predominant; so that one says, banuw fulaAnK [meaning The sons and daughters, or the children, of such a one]; and even, AimoraOapN mino banI tamiymK [A woman of the children of Temeem]; and accordingly, if banuw fulaAnK is applied to denote the persons to whom a legacy is left, the males and the females are included therein. (Msb.) ― -b2- When Aibon is applied to that which is not a human being, (IAmb, Msb,) to an irrational being, (Msb,) it has for its pl. banaAt: (IAmb, Msb:) thus the pl. of Aibonu maxaADK [A young male camel in his second year] is banaAtu maxaADK: (Mgh, Msb:) that of Aibonu labuwnK [A male camel that has entered upon his third year] is banaAtu labuwnK: (Msb:) and that of Aibonu naEoXK [Any one of the stars of the tail of Ursa Major or of that of Ursa Minor] is banaAtu naEoXK; but sometimes, by poetic licence, banuw naEoXK: and hence, or to make a distinction between the males and the females, the lawyers say, banuw AllRabuwni. (IAmb, Msb.) ― -b3- banaAtN↓ also signifies (tropical:) Dolls with which young girls play: (S, Mgh, K:) sing. binotN. (Mgh.) It occurs in this sense in a trad., in which 'Áïsheh speaks of her playing therewith (S, Mgh) when, being nine years of age, she was conducted as a bride to Mohammad. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Aibon is often prefixed to some other noun (T, M, Msb) that particularizes its signification, because of a close connexion between the two meanings: (Msb:) and so is binot↓. (T, M.) [Most of the
compounds thus formed will be found explained in the arts. to which belong the nouns that occupy the second place. The following are among the more common, and are therefore here mentioned, as exs. of different kinds.] ― -b5- Aibonu AlTRiyni [The son of earth, or clay, meaning] Adam. (T.)

Aibonu AllRayoli Abn Allyl
Aibonu AllRayoli and Aibonu AlTRariyqi The thief, or robber. (T.) Also the former, The wayfarer, or traveller; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so Aibonu AlsRabiyli. (Msb, Er-Rághib.) Aibonu HarobK A warrior: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and Aibonu AlHarobi [the warrior; or] he who suffices for war, and who defends. (Msb.) Aibonu AldRunoyaA The rich man. (Msb.) ― -b2- Aibonu MwaI [The jackal;] a certain beast of prey. (TA.) Aibonu EirosK The suroEuwb [or weasel]. (TA.) ― -b3- Aibonu OadiymK A skin for water or milk made of one hide; and Aibonu Oadiymayoni one made of two hides; and Aibonu valaAvahi MdimapK one made of three hides. (T.) ― -b4- Aibonapu Aljabali The echo. (T.) ― -b5- banaAtu biYosK and banaAtu TabaqK and banaAtu baroHK and banaAtu Oawodaka Calamities, or misfortunes. (T.) ― -b6- Ru-beh said of a man who was mentioned to him, kaAna UiHodaI banaAti masaAjidi QllRehi; as though he asserted that He was one of the pebbles of the mosque [or rather of the mosques of God]. (S.)

OubayonK c
OubayonK, of the same measure as OuEayomK, is the dim. of OabonaI, which is like OaEomaI, (Sb, IB, Mgh,) and is quasi-pl. of AibonN. (Mgh.) Mohammad is related, in a trad., to have said, OubayoniI laA taromuwA jamorapa AlEabaqabipi HatRaI taToluEa AlXRamosu [O little (meaning dear) sons, cast not ye the pebble of the 'Akabeh (see jamorapN) until the sun rise], (TA,) or OubayoniIRa Alx [O my little sons &c.]: (Mgh, TA:) IAth says that the hemzeh is augmentative; and that there are differences of opinion respecting the form of the word and its meaning: some say that it is the dim. of OabonaI, like OaEomaI, a sing. word denoting a pl. meaning, or, accord. to some, a pl. of AibonN, as well as OabonaMCN: some say that it is the dim. of AibonN; [and if so, we must read OubayoniI my little son;] but this requires consideration [more especially as it is followed by a pl. verb]: AO says that it is the dim. of baniIRa, pl. of AibonN with the affixed pronoun of the first pers. [sing.]; and this requires us to read OubayoniIRa. (TA.) J says, in the S, that the dim. of OabonaMCN [pl. of AibonN] is OubayonaMCN↓, and, if you will, Oubayonuwna↓; and he cites a verse in which occurs the expression Oubayoniyka, [in the gen. case, meaning thy little sons,] and adds, it is as though its sing. were UibonN, with the disjunctive A, whence the dim. OubayonN↓, in the pl. Oubayonuwna: but he should have said, as though its sing. were OabonaI, like OaEomaI, originally Oabonawu. (IB, TA.)

mibonaApN mbnAh mbnAp mbnI
mibonaApN (T, S, M, K) and mabonaApN (M, K) A niToE [like binaMCN, which see for an explanation]: (S, M, K:) and a sitor [i. e. curtain or the like]: (K:) or a thing in the form of a sitor: (M:) or a [tent of the kind called] qubRap, made of skins, or hides: (IAar, T:) or a thing of skins, or hides, of like form to the qubRap, which a woman places in, or at, the side of her tent (fiI kisori bayotihaA), and in which she dwells; and may-be she has sheep, or goats, and is content with the possession of these, exclusively of the other sheep, or goats, for herself and her garments [and app. for making of their skins her mbnAh]; and she has a covering (UizaAr) [extended] in the middle of the bayot [or tent], within, to protect her from the heat, and from the violent rain, so that she and her clothes are not wetted: (Aboo-'Adnán, T:) or, accord. to As, a mat (HaSiyrN), or a niToE, which the trafficker spreads upon the things that he sells: and they used to put the mats (AlHuSur) upon the OanoTaAE [pl. of niToE], and go round about with them [in the market]: the mbnAp is thus called because it is made of skins joined together: (T:) also a receptacle of the kind called Eayobap: (M, K:) such is said to be its meaning: (S:) pl. mabaAnK. (T.)

1. buhita, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the most chaste form of the verb in the sense here following, (S, TA,) and that which most commonly obtains, and the only form allowed by Th and IKt; (TA;) and bahita, (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.

; (TA;) inf. n. bahotN; (JK, K;) He was, or became, confounded, perplexed, or amazed, and unable to see his right course; (JK, S, Msb, K;) not knowing what to prefer nor what to postpone: (TA in art. AXr:) he looked at a thing that he saw with a look of wonder: (A, TA:) he was, or became, affected with wonder: (JK:) he was, or became, cut short, (AnoqaTaEa, K, TA,) and was silent, being confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course: (TA:) he (an adversary in a dispute or litigation) was overcome by an argument, an allegation, or a plea. (L.) All these forms occur in different readings of the saying in the Kur [ii. 260], fabuhita QlRaciI kafara and fabahita &c., (IJ, TA,) explained in the Wá'ee as meaning, And he who disbelieved remained in confusion, or perplexity, not seeing his right course, looking as one in wonder: (Lb, TA:) but accord. to him who reads fabahata, the word AlcI may hold the place of a noun in the accus. case [as will be seen from what follows]. (IJ, TA.) ＝ -A2- bahatahu, aor.
bahata
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. bahotN, (S, K,) He, or it, caused him to become confounded, perplexed, or amazed, not seeing his right course: (Zj, Msb: [Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, assigns this meaning to bhRthu↓:]) or took him unawares, or by surprise, or unexpectedly, or suddenly. (S, K.) Zj cites as an ex. of the former meaning the saying in the Kur [xxi. 41], taOotiyhimo bagotapF fatabohatuhumo, i. e., It shall come upon them suddenly, or unawares, and cause them to become confounded, &c.: (TA: and so Bd and Jel explain it:) or, and shall overcome them: (Bd:) J cites the same as an ex. of the latter of the two meanings in the preceding sentence; but his doing so requires consideration; for the meaning which he gives is taken from the word bgtp; not from Albahotu. (MF, TA.) [But it is said also that] mubaAhatapN [inf. n. of bAhthu↓] signifies The taking, or coming upon, [one] unawares, by surprise, or unexpectedly. (JK.) ― -b2- bahatahu, aor.
bahata
, (S, A, K, &c.,) inf. n. bahotN and bahatN and buhotaAnN, (S, K,) or the last is a simple subst., (Msb,) He calumniated him; slandered him; accused him falsely; said against him that which he had not done: (S, A, K:) [or he did so in such a manner as to make one to be confounded, or perplexed, or amazed, at the falsity
of the charge, and not to see his right course: (see buhotaAnN, below:)] he lied against him; forged a lie, or lies, against him; and i. q. qaAbalahu biAlkacibi [he accused him to his face falsely, or with falsehood]; (TA;) Albahotu signifies AisotiqobaAluka OaxaAka bimaA layosa fiyhi [thy accusing thy brother, or fellow, to his face, of that which is not in him]: (JK:) and bahatahaA, aor.
bahata
, inf. n. bahotN, he accused her falsely of adultery; and forged a lie against her. (Msb.) [See also AigotaAbahu.] In the saying of Abu-n-Nejm,
subRiI AlHamaApa waQbohatiI EalayohaA
[Revile thou the mother-in-law, and calumniate her, or forge lies against her], ElI is [said by J to be] redundant, or pleonastic; for one does not say, baEata Ealayohi, but only bahatahu. (S.) Upon this, F says, in the K, that faQbohatiI ElyhA [thus in the K] is a mistake; that J is in error, and that the right reading is faQnohatiI ElyhA, with n: but this assertion made by F depends upon the authority of relaters of the verse in which the word in question occurs. (MF.) IB says that AbhtI may be here rendered trans. by means of ElI because it is syn. with AifotariI, which is so rendered trans., in like manner as is done in other instances, of which he gives an ex. from the Kur [xxiv. 63], yuxaAlifuwna Eano Oamorihi, meaning yaxorujuwna En Amrh: he adds that, accord. to J, En in this ex. should be considered redundant; but that En and ElI are not used redundantly like b. (TA.) ― -b3- bahata AlfaHola Eani AlnRaAqapi He removed the stallion from the she-camel in order that a stallion of more generous race might cover her. (TA.)

(TA.) buhotaAnFA waUivomFA mubiynFA, in the Kur iv. 24, is said to mean Falsely accusing of adultery, and acting in a manifestly sinful or criminal manner: (Bd:) or it means acting wrongfully &c. And yaA illobahiytapi↓, with kesr to the [prep.] l, [i. e., O, come to my aid, or succour, on account of the calumny! &c.; for it is] a phrase used in calling for aid, or succour. (S.) [And if you would express wonder, you say, yaA allobahiytapi↓, with fet-h to the prep. l, i. e. O the calumny! &c.]

bahuwtN [A great, or frequent, calumniator, slanderer, or false-accuser; as also bahRaAtN↓, mentioned in the S only as an epithet applied to him who calumniates, slanders, or accusely falsely;] an intensive epithet from Albahotu; (IAth;) [i. e.] an intensive form of the act. part. n. from AlbuhotaAn [inf. n. of bahatahu]: (Mgh:) or i. q. mubaAhitN↓; (K;) i. e., one who confounds, or perplexes, or amazes, the hearer, by what he forges against him: (TA:) and one who falsely accuses a woman of adultery, and forges a lie against her: (Msb:) pl. buhutN (IAth, Mgh, Msb, K) and buhotN, and, accord. to the K, also buhuwtN; but ISd and MF hold it to be pl. of baAhitN, not of bahuwtN; the former observing, that a word of the measure faAEilN is one of those which have a pl. of the measure fuEuwlN, but not so one of the measure faEuwlN; and that, as to the saying of A'Obeyd, that EucuwbN is pl. of EacuwbN, it is a mistake; for it is only pl. of EaAcibN, and the pl. of EacuwbN is EucubN. (TA. [But see art. Ecb.])

bahiytN, see mabohuwtN, in two places.

bahRaAtN: see bahuwtN: ＝ -A2- and see mabohuwtN.

baAhitN: see mabohuwtN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also act. part. n. [of bahatahu; signifying Causing to become confounded, &c.: and calumniating, &c.:] from AlbuhotaAnu: (Mgh:) buhuwtN, as mentioned above, is held by ISd and MF to be a pl. of this word; not of bahuwtN, q. v. (TA.)

mabohuwtN mbhwt
mabohuwtN Confounded, perplexed, or amazed, and unable to see his right course: (S, K:) [other (similar) meanings may be seen from explanations of buhita:] accord. to Ks and the S and Sgh and the K, one should not say baAhitN↓ nor bahiytN↓; but there is no reason in analogy why he who says bahata, like naSara and manaEa, should not say thus: (TA:) Lb says, in the Expos. of the Fs, that they said baAhitN↓ and bahRaAtN↓ [which latter is an intensive form] and bahiytN↓, which [last] may be considered as having the meaning of the measure mafoEuwlN, like mabohuwtN, or that of the measure faAEilN, like baAhitN; but the former is the more agreeable with analogy, and the more probable. (MF, TA) ― -b2- Also Calumniated, slandered, or falsely accused. (S.)

, (AZ, S, Msb, &c.,) inf. n. bahaAjapN (AZ, S, L, K) and bahojapN (AZ, L, [but some seem to regard this as a simple subst.,]) and bahajaAnN, (L,) He, or it, was, or became, beautiful, or goodly: (AZ, S, L, Msb, K:) or beautiful in colour: or beautiful and bright or splendid: or it (a plant) was, or became, beautiful and bright; and he (a man) was, or became, characterized by a laughing, or happy, appearance of the beautiful parts of the face, as the cheeks, and the lines of the forehead: or by the appearance of joy, gladness, or happiness; or by a joyful, glad, or happy, aspect, or appearance. (L.) You say also, bahija AlnRabaAtu, with kesr, meaning (assumed tropical:) The plant, or herbage, was, or became, beautiful [&c.]. (TA, [but this is probably a tropical signification, from bahija in the sense here following.]) ― -b2- bahija, (S, A, L, K,) with kesr, (S,) aor.
bahaja
, (K,) inf. n. bahajN; (L;) and Abthj↓; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) He was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) You say, bahija bihi, (S, A,) and lahu; (TA;) and Abthj↓ bihi; (A, Msb;) He rejoiced in it, or at it; or became rejoiced by it, or at it. (S, A, Msb, TA.) [See also 10.] ＝ -A2- bahaja, (S, K,) aor.
bahaja
; (K;) and Abhj↓; (S, A, K;) the latter of which is the more approved; (TA;) It (a thing, TA, or an affair or event, S, A) rejoiced; or made joyful, glad, or happy; (S, A, K;) a person. (S, A.)

bahara
, (K,) inf. n. buhuwrN, (TA,) (tropical:) The moon overcame with its light the light of the stars. (S, K, TA.) And baharati AlXRamosu AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) The light of the sun overspread the earth. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] bahara, aor.
bahara
, (TA,) inf. n. bahorN and buhuwrN, (K,) (tropical:) It shone, or shone brightly: (K, TA:) and AlsRaHaAbapu tabahRarati↓ (tropical:) The cloud shone, or shone brightly. (K.) ＝ -A2- baharahu, (S, A,) aor.
bahara
, inf. n. buhorN, (S,) also signifies (tropical:) It (a load, or burden, S, A, and running, A) [caused him to be out of breath; interrupted his breathing; (see buhorN;)] caused to pant, or breathe [shortly or] uninterruptedly. (K.) ＝ -A3- baharahaA, (JK,) or baharahaA bibuhotaAnK, (TA,) inf. n. bahorN, (K,) He reproached her, or accused her, falsely; (JK;) he aspersed her; calumniated her; or brought a false accusation against her. (K, * TA.) You say, baharahaA bikacaA He reproached her falsely with, or accused her falsely of, such a thing. (JK.) [See also 8.]

AibohiyraArN, (S,) The night reached its middle point; (As, S, A, K;) from buhorapN signifying the “ middle ” of a thing: (A:) or reached the point when all its stars appeared and shone: (Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer:) or became thickly dark: (K:) or for the most part passed: (S, K:) or reached the point when about one third of it remained.
