bahorN bhr hr
bahorN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, Msb, K.) You say, bahorFA lahu, an imprecation, meaning May he be overcome! (A:) or i. q. taEosFA lahu [may he fall, having stumbled! or stumble and fall! &c.]: (AA, S, K:) and thus used [app. in the latter sense] as an imprecation, accord. to Sb, it has no verb, but is put in the accus. case on the supposition of a verb. (TA.) One says also, quhorFA wabuhorFA↓, with damm to each. (TA in art. qhr.) And bahorFA maA OasoxaAhu [May he fall, having stumbled! &c.: how bountiful is he!], like as one says taEosFA lahu [when not meaning it to be understood as an imprecation]. (A.) ― -b2- It also signifies Distance, or remoteness: (K:) and remoteness from good or prosperity. (TA.) ― -b3- Disappointment. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- Wonder; syn. EajabN. (K.) One says, bahorA meaning EajabFA [for OaEojabu EajabFA I do wonder: or wonderful!]. (S.) So [sometimes] in the phrase bahorFA lahu [I do wonder at him, or it]. (IAar, TA.) ― -b5- Love. (K.) Accord. to some, bahorFA lakumo means Love to you. (JK.) ― -b6- AlOazowaAju valAavapN zawoju bahorK wazawoju dahorK wazawoju mahorK is a saying of the Arabs, meaning Husbands are three: a husband who overcomes the eyes by his goodliness, (S,) or a husband of noble race, though he may be of little wealth; (TA;) and a husband prepared for the accidents, or calamities, of fortune; and a husband from whom a dowry is got, (S,) or a husband who has not nobility of race, and who therefore doubles the dowry to make himself desired. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) Distress that affects the breath or respiration, syn. karobN, (K, TA,) [particularly] of a camel when he is spurred on, or of a man when a labour above his power is imposed upon him. (TA.)

buhorN bhr hr
buhorN: see bahorN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The state of being out of breath; interruption of the breath, by reason of fatigue, (K, TA,) [or by bearing a heavy load, (see 1,)] or by hard work, and by running: (TA:) a panting, or breathing [shortly or] uninterruptedly. (S, A, TA,) ＝ -A2- Wide-spreading land; a wide tract of land; as also buhorapN↓ [q. v.]. (K.) ― -b2- A country, or district; or a city, or town; syn. baladN: (K:) or the middle thereof. (TA.) ― -b3- The middle, and best part, (sirR, and xayor, for the former of which words we find XarR erroneously put in the copies of the K, TA,) of a valley; as also buhorapu↓ [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

buhorapN bhr bhrh bhrp hr hrp
buhorapN Plain, or even, or soft, land or ground: or a wide tract of land between mountains. (L.) ― -b2- See also buhorN, in two places. ― -b3- The middle (S, A, K) of a valley, and of the night, and of a horse, (S, K,) and of a camel's saddle, (TA,) and of a ring, (K,) or of a thing. (A.)

bahaArN bhAr hAry
bahaArN A certain plant, of sweet odour; (K;) the [plant called] EaraAr, which is also called Eayonu Albaqari; [buphthalmum, or ox-eye;] it is the bahaAru AlbarRi, a crisping, or curling, plant, having a yellow flower; growing in the days of the spring (AlrRabiyE), and called EaraArapN: (S:) As says, The EaraAr is the bahaAru AlbarRi: and Az says, The EaraArap is the xasowap; and I regard bhAr as a Persian word. (TA.) ― -b2- Perfume. (Msb.) ― -b3- And hence applied to The flowers of the desert. (Msb.) ― -b4- And Anything goodly, or beautiful, and bright, or shining. (K, TA.)

buhaArN bhAr hAry
buhaArN A certain thing with which one weighs; (S, Msb, K;) the weight of three hundred pounds: (Fr, IAar, A'Obeyd, S, K:) thought by A'Obeyd to be not Arabic, but Coptic; (S;) having this signification in Coptic; (JK;) but thought by Az to be pure Arabic: (TA:) or four hundred pounds: or six hundred: or a thousand: (K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) one half of a load (K, TA) borne by a camel, (TA,) containing four hundred pounds, (K, TA,) in the dial. of Syria: (TA:) or a load borne by a camel: (Kt:) or a camel-load of household-goods or furniture and utensils: (As:) and commodities, or utensils, or the like, of the sea; expl. by mataAEa AlbaHori [perhaps a mistranscription for mataAEa AltRajori or AltRujuri, commodities, or goods, of the merchants: the poet Bureyk El-Hudhalee speaks of camels bearing buhaAr]. (JK, K.) It is said that Talhah the son of 'Obeyd-Allah left a hundred buhaAr, in each bhAr of which was three hundred-weight of gold (S, TA) and silver; (TA;) bhAr being thus made to signify a receptacle: (S, TA:) accord. to As and Kt, the meaning is, a hundred camel-loads. (TA.)

bahiyrN bhyr hyr
bahiyrN and mabohuwrN↓ (A, K) and manobahirN↓ (A) [and mubotahirN↓] (tropical:) Out of breath; having his breath interrupted, by reason of fatigue [or running, or by hard work, or bearing a heavy load; see 1 and 7]; panting, or breathing [shortly or] uninterruptedly. (A.)

baAhirN bAhr
baAhirN [act. part. n. of 1, Overcoming; &c. And particularly,] (assumed tropical:) Overcoming in light. (JK.) [Hence,] qamarN baAhirN (tropical:) A moon that overcomes with its light the light of the stars. (S, A.) And AlbaAhiru (tropical:) The moon; because it outshines the stars: (Msb:) or the full moon. (JK.)

Oaboharu c
Oaboharu [The aorta; so in the present day;] a certain vein [or artery], (S, A, K,) in the back, (K,) lying within, or at the inner side of, the back-bone (A'Obeyd, A, TA) and the heart, (A'Obeyd, TA,) the severing of which causes death: (A'Obeyd, S, A:) it is name given to each of two veins [or arteries, or the two portions of the aorta which are called the aorta ascendens and aorta descendens,] which issue from the heart, and from which then branch off all the other arteries: (S:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) the wariyd [i. e. either the carotid artery or the external jugular vein] of the neck: (K:) and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) [the vein in the arm called] the OakoHal: (K:) or, accord. to the more full description of IAth, a certain vein [or artery] arising from the head, and extending to the foot, and having arteries which communicate with most of the extremities and the body: what is in the head is called the naAmRap; and hence the saying, Oasokata QllRehu naAmRatahu, meaning “God killed him,” or “may God kill him!” and it extends to the throat, and is there called the wariyd; and to the chest, and is there called [especially] the Oabohar [meaning the aorta ascendens]; and to the back, and is there called the watiyn [meaning the aorta descendens]; and the heart is suspended to it; and it extends to the thigh, and is there called the nasaA; and to the shank, and is there called the SaAfin: the C in it is augmentative. (TA.) You say, qaTaEa Oaboharahu [It severed his aorta]; meaning (tropical:) it (pain) destroyed him. (A.) ― -b2- Also The back: (K:) or the place of the vein [or artery] so called. (As, in art. xdE of the S.) One says, fulaAnN XadiydN AlOabohari Such a one is strong in the back: (TA:) or strong in the place of the vein [or artery] called the Abhr. (As, ubi suprà.) ― -b3- And The back of the curved part of the extremity of a bow: (K:) or the part between the TAYif and the kuloyap: (S, K:) in the bow is its kabid, which is the part between the two extremities of its string or the like; then, next to this, the kuloyap; then, next to this, the Oabohar; then, the TaAYif; then, the siYap, which is the curved part of the extremity. (As.) ― -b4- And A tent-pole. (JK.) ― -b5- And The shorter side of a feather: (K:) [or] so OabaAhiru [which is the pl.]: (JK:) [or] the latter signifies the feathers (Lh, S) of the wing (Lh) of a bird (Lh, S) next after those called AlxawaAfiI, (Lh,) [and] next [before] those called AlkulaI: (S:) the first of them are those called AlqawaAdimu, (S,) four in number, in the fore part of the wing; (Lh;) the next, AlmanaAkibu, (Lh, S,) also four; (Lh;) the next, AlxawaAfiI, (Lh, S,) also four; (Lh;) the next, AlOabaAhiru, (Lh, S,) also four; (Lh;) and the next, AlkulaI [which are also four]. (S.)

mabohuwrN: see bahiyrN.

mubotahirN mbthr
mubotahirN: see bahiyrN.

munobahir: see bahiyrN.

Q. 1 buhorija bhrj hrj
Q. 1. buhorija, in the pass. form, (Kt, Msb,) inf. n. bahorajapN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) was taken otherwise than by, or in, the right way: (Msb:) or (tropical:) it was turned away, or conveyed by turning away, (Kt, K, TA,) from the beaten way or road, (Kt, TA,) or from the direct, or right, main road. (K, TA.) And bahoraja bihimo (tropical:) It (the road, A) lead them otherwise than in the beaten track. (T, A, TA.) [See bahorajN, from which the verb is derived.] ― -b2- (tropical:) It (a man's blood) was made to be of no account, to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; was made allowable to be taken or shed. (Mgh.) And bahoraja damahu (tropical:) He made his blood to be of no account, &c. (TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) OamaA Uico bahorajotaniI falaA OaXorabuhaA OabadFA (K, * TA) (tropical:) Verily, since thou hast made me [meaning my offence] to pass unnoticed, or hast taken no account of me, (hadarotaniI,) by annulling in respect of me the prescribed castigation, (K, TA,) I will not drink it (i. e. wine) henceforth: (TA:) said by Aboo-Mihjen (K, TA) Eth-Tha- kafee, (TA,) to Ibn-Abee-Wakkás. (TA.) ― -b4- You say also, bahoraja AlmakaAni (assumed tropical:) He made the place free to the people in general to pasture their beasts in it. (IAar, L.)

Q. 2 tabahoraja bhrj tbhrj
Q. 2. tabahoraja It (a place) became, or was made, free to the people in general to pasture their beasts in it. (IAar, L.)

bahorajN bhrj hrj
bahorajN an arabicized word, (T, S, Mgh, L, TA,) from nabahoraho, (T, Mgh, L, TA,) which is Persian; (L, TA;) or, as some say, it is an Indian word, originally nabaholaho, meaning Bad, whence the Persian nabahoraho, and hence the arabicized bahorajN; (TA;) applied to a dirhem, as meaning bad; (Kr, S;) false; (S, El-Marzookee;) adulterated; (Shifá el-Ghaleel, El-Marzookee;) of bad silver; (A, Mgh, L, Msb;) with which one cannot buy: (IAar, TA:) or, as some say, in which the silver is predominant: or, accord. to IAar, of which the die has been falsified: (Mgh:) or not coined in the government-mint: (Lb, TA:) and muboharajN↓ signifies the same, applied to a dirhem; (Lh, A, Mgh;) and so nabahorajN↓; (Lh, El-Marzookee;) but [Mtr says,] I have not found it with n, except on the authority of Lh (Mgh;) and IKh says that it is a word of the vulgar: (TA:) the pl. [of bhrj] is bahaAriju, and [of nbhrj,] nabahorajaAtu. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, metaphorically, (Mgh,) (tropical:) Bad; (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) and false, or of no account; (S, A, Mgh, K;) applied to a thing (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb) of any kind: (A, Mgh, L:) anything rejected; not received or accepted; rejected as wrong or bad; as also nabahorajN↓: (TA:) and a thing is termed mubahorajN↓ when it is as though it were cast away, and not an object of emulous desire or envy, or not in request. (El-Marzookee, TA.) You say, kalaAmN bahorajN (tropical:) Bad language. (A, L.) And EamalN bahorajN (tropical:) A bad action. (A, L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Allowed or allowable [to any person, to be taken or let alone, or to be possessed or made use of or done]; made allowable, free, or lawful. (K.) You say, damN bahorajN (tropical:) Blood made to be of no account, to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; allowed to be taken or shed; (A, L;) as also mubahorajN↓. (K.) And makaAnN bahorajN (assumed tropical:) A place free to the people in general to pasture their beasts in it. (IAar, L.) And maMCN mubahorajN↓ (assumed tropical:) A water left free to those who come to water at it. (A, K, * TA.)

mubahorajN mbhrj
mubahorajN: see bahorajN, in four places.

nabahorajN bhrj nbhrj
nabahorajN: see bahorajN, in two places.

1 bahaZahu bhZ bhZh bhZp
1. bahaZahu, aor.
bahaZa
, inf. n. bahoZN, It (a load, or burden,) oppressed him by its weight, and he was unable to bear it: (S, M, TA:) or pressed heavily upon him, and distressed him. (T, TA.) [And hence,] (tropical:) It (an affair, M, K, or anything, T) oppressed him by its weight, (T, M,) and he was unable to bear it: (M:) or overpowered him, and pressed heavily upon him, and distressed him; (Jm, K;) and so bahaDahu, as heard by Aboo-Turáb from an Arab of the desert; but no one has followed him in this. (Az, TA.) You say also, bahaZa AlrRaAHilapa He loaded the riding-camel heavily, and fatigued it. (K.)

OamorN baAhiZN c
OamorN baAhiZN A distressing, grievous, or difficult, affair. (S, CK, but wanting in two MS. copies of the K.) And baAhiZN [alone], (CK, but wanting in two MS. copies of the K,) or baAhiZapN↓, (O, TA,) (tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune. (O, K, TA.)

baAhiZapN bAhZ bAhZh bAhZp
baAhiZapN: see baAhiZN.

mabohuwZN mbhwZ
mabohuwZN Oppressed by the weight of a load, and unable to bear it. (S.) [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) Any one having a thing required of him which he is unable to do, or which he cannot find. (TA.) And qironN mabohuwZN (assumed tropical:) An opponent, or an adversary, overcome, or vanquished. (TA.)

1 bahiqa bhq
1. bahiqa, aor.
bahaqa
, inf. n. bahaqN, It (the body) was, or became, affected with [the disease termed] bahaqN. (Msb.)

bahaqN bhq
bahaqN [The mild species of leprosy termed “alphus,” or “vitiligo alba;” in Hebrew בֹּהַק;] a whiteness, less than what is termed baraSN, that comes upon the external skin of a man; (JK;) a whiteness that affects the skin, (S,) or body, (Mgh, Msb,) differing from the colour of the latter; (S, Msb;) not from what is termed baraS, (S, Mgh,) or not baraS: (Msb:) and, accord. to IF, a blackness that affects the skin; [i. e. the species of leprosy termed “melas,” or “lepra maculosa nigra;”] or a colour differing from that of the skin: (Msb:) a thin whiteness that affects the exterior of the cuticle, by reason of a bad state of the temperament of the part, inclining to coldness, and the predominance of the phlegm over the blood: the black [species] thereof alters (yugayRiru, in the CK yaEotariI,) the skin to blackness, by reason of the mixing of the black bile with the blood. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] bahaqu AlHajari (assumed tropical:) [Lichen, or liverwort;] a certain plant; (K;) i. e. HazRaAzu AlHajari [more commonly called HazRaAzu AlSRaxori]: (TA:) or i. q. Aljawozu Aljanoduma, (K, TA,) or Aljawoza janoduma, (CK,) [evidently from the Persian jawozi Ganoduma explained in Johnson's Pers. Ar. and Engl. Dict. as “sandix-gum, juniper:” but SM says that] this is a certain plant, the body [or substance] of which is muHabRab [app. meaning composed of globules or the like; probably a particular species of lichen, with spherical cells]. (TA.)

Oabohaqu c
Oabohaqu, applied to a man, Affected with [the disease termed] bahaqN: (JK, Msb:) fem. bahoqaMCu. (Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] so applied, (assumed tropical:) Very white. (TA.)

1 bahala AlnRaAqapa bhl AlnAqh bhl AlnAqp
1. bahala AlnRaAqapa, [aor.
bahala
, inf. n. baholN,] He left the she-camel without a SiraAr [bound upon her udder to prevent her being sucked]; (Bd in iii. 54;) as also AblhA↓: (S:) or he left her to be milked; or allowed her being milked: (Z, TA:) and ↓the latter, he loosed her SiraAr, and left her young one at liberty to such her; (K;) and he left her to herself (K, TA) to be milked by any one who pleased. (TA.) ― -b2- And bahalahu, (S, K,) aor.
bahala
, (K,) [inf. n. baholN,] He left him (S, K) to his own will, or wish, (S,) or to his own opinion, or judgment; (K;) as also Abhlhu↓: (S, K:) or the former is said in relation to the free man; and ↓the latter, in relation to the slave; (Zj, K;) and signifies also [simply] he left him to himself. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Hence, (TA,) baholN signifies [also] The act of cursing. (S, Msb, K.) You say, bahalahu, aor.
bahala
, inf. n. baholN, He cursed him. (Msb.) And bahala QllRehu fulaAnFA May God curse such a one! (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- bahilato, aor.
bahala
, inf. n. bahalN, She (a camel) had her SiraAr loosed, and her young one left to suck her. (K.)

3 mubaAhalapN mbAhlh mbAhlp
3. mubaAhalapN The act of cursing each other: (S, Mgh, Msb:) inf. n. of bAhlhu He cursed him, being cursed by him: (Msb:) [or rather] baAhalotuhu signifies I joined with him in imprecating the curse of God upon whichever of us did wrong. (JK.) Hence the saying of Ibn-Mes'ood, mano XaMCa baAhalotuhu OanRa suwrapa AlquSoraI nazalato baEoda Albaqarapi [Whosoever will, I will contend with him by imprecating the curse of God upon whichever of us is wrong, that the shorter chapter of “Women” came down from heaven after the chapter of “The Cow”]: or, accord. to one recital, he said laA Eanotuhu: for when they differed respecting a thing, they used to come together, and say, QllRehi EalaI baholapu↓ AlZRaAlimi minRaA [The curse of God be upon such of us as is the wrongdoer!]. (Mgh.) bAhl baEoDuhumo baEoDFA and tbRhlwA↓ and tbAhlwA↓ all signify They cursed one another: (K:) [or] they joined in imprecating a curse upon such of them as was the wrongdoer: (TA:) and AbthlwA↓ signifies the like: whence, vumRa nabotahilo, in the Kur [iii. 54], (Bd, TA,) as some explain it, (TA,) meaning vumRa natabaAhalo↓, i. e., Then let us imprecate a curse upon such of us as is the liar. (Bd. [But see also 8 below.])

4 Oabohala
4: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- [The inf. n.] UibohaAlN also signifies The sending forth, or letting flow, the water upon what has been sown, (JK, K, TA,) after having finished the sowing. (JK, TA. [In the CK, nacarotahu is erroneously put for bacarotahu.])

5 tabahRala
5: see 3.

6 tabaAohala
6: see 3, in two places.

8 Uibotahala
8: see 3. ― -b2- [Hence,] Abthl, (S, Msb, K,) or Abthl fiI AldRaEaMCi, (JK,) (tropical:) He humbled, or abased, himself; or addressed himself with earnest, or energetic, supplication; syn. taDarRaEa; (S, Msb, K;) UilaI QllRehi to God: (Msb:) he strove, or was earnest, or energetic, in prayer, or supplication; (JK, K;) and was sincere, or without hypocrisy, therein; (S, K;) with a striving, or an earnestness, or energy, like that of the mubotahiluwna [properly so called, i. e., persons who join in imprecating a curse upon such of them as is the wrongdoer]. (TA.) It is said that vumRa nabotahilo, in the Kur [iii. 54, of which one explanation has been given above, (see 3,)] means (tropical:) Then let us be sincere, or without hypocrisy, in prayer, or supplication; (S, TA;) and let us strive, or be earnest, or energetic: (TA:) or let us humble, or abase, ourselves; &c.; syn. nataDarRaEo. (Jel.)

10 AstblhA OstblhA AstblhA QstbAl Qstblh QstblhA
10. AstblhA He milked her (namely, a camel,) without a SiraAr. (K. [See 1, first sentence.]) ― -b2- He (a young camel) pulled off her OaSirRap [pl. of SiraAr] to suck her, namely, his mother. (JK.) ― -b3- Astbhl AlrRaEyRapa He (the ruler) left the people, or subject, to themselves, (Lh, K,) to do what they would; not restraining them. (Lh, TA.) ― -b4- AisotabohalatohaA AlsRawaAHilu (S) and Astblthm AlbaAdiyapu (K) (assumed tropical:) The shores, and the desert, left them at liberty in their abodes therein, no Sultán reaching them, so that they did what they pleased. (S, * K.)

baholapN bAhl bhl bhlh bhlp
baholapN (S, Mgh, K) and buholapN↓ (S, Msb, K) A curse: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) from bahala AlnRaAqapa in the sense first explained above. (Bd in iii. 54.) You say, Ealayohi baholapu QllRehi and buholatuhu↓ The curse of God be on him! (S.) For another ex., see 3.

buholapN bAhl bhl bhlh bhlp
buholapN: see what next precedes, in two places.

baholalapN bhllh bhllp hll hllp
baholalapN The quality of shrinking from foul things, and of generosity, or nobleness. (JK.)

buholuwlN bhlwl
buholuwlN One that shrinks from foul things, and is generous, or noble; applied to a man (Ibn- 'Abbád, JK) and to a woman: (JK:) pl. bahaAliylu. (Ibn-'Abbád, JK.) A lord, chief, or prince, combining all good qualities. (Seer, K.) ― -b2- A great, or frequent, laugher. (S, K.)

baAhilN Ohl bOhl bAhl bMhl Mhl
baAhilN A she-camel having no SiraAr upon her, (S, K, TA,) so that any one who will may milk her: (TA:) or one having no nose-rein upon her, (K, TA,) so that she pastures where she will: (TA:) or also one having no EiraAn [which is a piece of wood inserted in the partition between the nostrils]: (S:) and (so in the S, but in the K “or”) one having no mark, or brand, upon her: (JK, S, K:) pl. buhRalN (JK, S, K) and buhulN: (JK, K, TA: [the latter in the CK like burodN:]) and mubohalapN↓ signifies left in the state of her that is termed baAhil, (S,) or having her SiraAr loosed, and her young one left at liberty to suck her: (K:) and mabaAhilu↓ is applied in the same sense [as its pl.]. (S, K. [In the CK the latter is written mubaAhilN, as a sing.]) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oatayotuka baAhilFA gayora caAti SiraArK, said by an Arab woman to her husband; (S;) by the wife of Dureyd Ibn-Es-Simmeh, to him, on his desiring to divorce her; meaning (assumed tropical:) I made
my property lawful to thee. (TA.) ― -b3- baAhiluwna (assumed tropical:) People at liberty in their place of abode, no Sultán reaching them, so that they do what they please. (K.) ― -b4- And the sing., (tropical:) Going to and fro without work. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A pastor without a staff: (JK, K:) or, walking without a staff. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A man without a weapon. (IAar, TA.) ― -b7- And baAhilapN (assumed tropical:) A woman having no husband; (JK;) syn. OayRimN. (K.)

OabohalN c
OabohalN The produce, or fruit, of a certain tree, which is the EaroEar [a name applied to the cypress and to the juniper-tree]: (S:) so says Ibn-Seenà [Avicenna] in the Kánoon; and he adds that it is of two species, small and great, both brought from the country of the ruwm: one species of the tree thereof has leaves like those of the sarow [or common, evergreen, cypress], has many thorns, and grows, or spreads, wide, (yasotaEoriDu,) not growing tall: the leaves of the other are like those of the TarofaMC [or tamarisk], the taste thereof is like [that of] the sarow, and it is drier, and less hot: (TA:) or it is the produce of a kind of great tree, the leaves of which are like [those of] the TrfAC, and the fruit of which is like the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree called sidor]; and it is not [the fruit of] the ErEr, as J imagined it to be: the smoke thereof expels quickly the young in the womb: used as a liniment, with vinegar, it cures what is termed daMC AlvRaEolab [alopecia]: and with honey, it cleanses foul ulcers. (K.) [In the present day, it is applied to the juniper-tree; as is also EaroEar; and particularly to the species thereof called the savin. See qaTiraAnN.]

mubohalapN mbhlh mbhlp
mubohalapN and mabaAhilu [its pl.]: see baAhilN.

2 bhRmwA Albahomi bhmwA Albhm
2. bhRmwA Albahomi, inf. n. tabohiymN, They separated the bhm [i. e. lambs, or kids, or both,] from their mothers, (S, K,) and pastured them alone. (S.) ＝ -A2- bhRmwA biAlmakaAni, inf. n. as above, They stayed, or remained, in the place; (K, TA;) did not quit it. (TA.) ― -b2- Also bhRm, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He continued looking at a thing without his being relieved by doing so. (JK.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He was silent, and confounded, or perplexed, when asked respecting a thing. (JK.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He did not fight, or engage in conflict. (JK.)

4 Abhm Ob Obhm Abhm Mb Mbhm
4. Abhm, (K,) inf. n. UibohaAmN, (JK,) (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, or an affair,) was, or became, dubious, confused, or vague, (JK, K, TA,) so that one knew not the way, or manner, in which it should be engaged in, done, executed, or performed; (JK, TA;) as also Astbhm↓; (JK, K, TA;) for which grammarians often use Anbhm↓; but this has not been heard in the [classical] language of the Arabs: (MF, TA:) [said to be] from bahiymN denoting a colour, whatever it be, except that which is termed Xuhobap, in which is no colour differing therefrom. (Har p. 50.) ＝ -A2- He closed, or locked, a door; (S, Mgh, TA;) [or, so that one could not find the way to open it; (see mubohamN;)] and stopped it up. (TA.) [And hence,] one says of the thumb, tubohimu AlkafRa, meaning It closes upon [the palm of] the hand, as a cover. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) He made a thing, or an affair, to be dubious, confused, or vague, (JK, TA, *) so that there was no way, or manner, of knowing it, (TA,) or so that one knew not the way, or manner, in which it should be engaged in, done, executed, or performed: (JK:) [in the former sense, or meaning (assumed tropical:) he made it to be dubious, confused, or vague,] said of speech, or language, (K in art. gmD, &c.,) and of information, or news, or a narration; (Msb;) contr. of OawoDaHa; (TA in art. gmD;) i. q. lmo yubayRino. (Msb.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He made, or held, a thing to be vague, or indefinite. (Mgh.) ― -b4- And, said of a prohibited thing, (assumed tropical:) He made it, or held it, to be not allowable in any manner, nor for any cause: (Az, TA:) or to be prohibited unconditionally. (Mgh.) [See mubohamN.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He made a man to turn away, or withdraw, or retire, (JK, K,) Eano kacaA from such a thing, (JK,) or Eani AlOamori from the affair. (K.) ＝ -A3- Abhmt AlOaroDu The land produced what is termed buhomaI: (JK, K:) or produced much thereof. (S.)

5 tabahRama
5: see 10.

7 Uinobahama
7: see 4.

10 Uisotabohama
10: see 4. ― -b2- You say, Astbhm Ealayohi AlOamoru (tropical:) The affair was as though it were closed against him, so that he knew not the way in which to engage in it, or execute it; syn. Ourotija Ealayohi. (TA.) And Astbhm Ealayohi, (K,) or Astbhm Elyh AlkalaAmu, (S, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Speech was as though it were closed against him; or he was, or became, impeded in his speech, unable to speak, or tongue-tied; (S, * K, TA;) syn. Aisotagolaqa; (S;) and Elyh kalaAmuhu tbhRm↓ [signifies the same]; syn. Ourotija; (JK, S; *) on the authority of AZ. (S.) And Astbhm Alxabaru (assumed tropical:) The information, or narration, was dubious, confused, vague, or difficult to be understood or expressed; or was not to be understood or expressed; as though it were closed [against the hearer or speaker]; syn. Aisotagolaqa, and AisotaEojama. (Msb.)

bahomN b bhm bhym hm
bahomN is pl. of bahomapN↓, (S, Msb, K,) as are also bahamN↓ and bihaAmN, (K,) [or rather bahomN is a coll. gen. n., and bahomapN↓ is its n. un., and bahamN↓ is a quasi-pl. n., and] bihaAmN is pl. of bahomN, (S, Msb,) and bihaAmaAti is a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of bihaAmN]: (K:) bahomapN↓ signifies A lamb, and is applied to the male and the female; (S, Msb;) or, accord. to a trad. in which it occurs, it is a name for the female; (IAth, TA;) but bihaAmN, which is applied to lambs when they are alone, as sixaAlN is to kids when they are alone, is also applied to lambs and kids together: (S, * Msb:) or, accord. to IF, bahomN signifies young lambs or goats: (Msb:) and accord. to AZ, (Msb,) or A'Obeyd, (TA,) bahomapN↓ is applied to a lamb or goat, whether male or female, after the period when it is termed saxolapN, which is when it is just brought forth; (Msb, TA;) and its pl. is Abhm: (Msb: [so in my copy of that work, as though meant for OabohumN; but perhaps a mistranscription for Albahomu:]) or it is applied to a lamb or goat when just brought forth, i. e., before it is termed saxolapN: (Mgh: [and this is agreeable with its application in a trad. cited by IAth:]) or to the young one, not, as in the K, young ones, (TA,) of the sheep, and of the goat, and of an animal of the bovine kind (K, TA) both wild and not wild, alike to the male and the female, while small; or, as some say, when it has attained to youthful vigour: (TA:) Lebeed applies bihaAmN to the young ones of [wild] animals of the bovine kind: (S, TA:) accord. to Th, bahomN signifies young kids. (TA.) ― -b2- saEodu AlbihaAmi One of the Mansions (K, TA) of the Moon: (TA:) or two stars which are not of the Mansions of the Moon. (S and L and K in art. sEd, q. v.)

bahamN b bhm bhym hm
bahamN: see bahomN, in two places.

bahimN b bhm bhym hm
[bahimN an epithet of which only the fem. form is mentioned. You say] OaroDN bahimapN Land abounding with what is termed buhomaI: (AHn, K:) the word bhmp is a possessive epithet. (TA.)

bahomapN bhmh bhmp bhym hm hmp
bahomapN: see bahomN, in four places.

buhomapN bhmh bhmp bhym hm hmp
buhomapN A rock, or great mass of stone or of hard stone, (K, TA,) that is solid, not hollow. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, accord. to some, (TA,) or because his condition is such that one knows not how to prevail with him, (Ham pp. 334 and 610,) A courageous man, (K, and Ham ubi suprà,) or a horseman, (AO, S,) to whom one knows not the way whence to gain access, or whence to come, (AO, S, K,) by reason of his great might, or valour: (AO, S:) or, as in the Nawádir, rajulN buhomapN signifies a man who will not be turned from a thing that he desires to do: (TA:) it is not applied as an epithet to a woman: (IJ, TA:) pl. buhamN. (S, A.) You say, huwa buhomapN mina Albuhami, meaning (assumed tropical:) He is a courageous man, of those to whom the approach is as though it were closed against his adversaries. (A, TA.) Accord. to IJ, it is an inf. n. used as an epithet, though having no verb. (TA.) [Hence,] it applies to one and to a number of persons. (Ham p. 494.) [For] it signifies also ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) An army: (S, K:) or courageous men, or courageous men clad in armour; because one knows not the way in which to fight with them: or, as some say, a company of horsemen: (TA:) pl. as above. (K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A difficult affair or case; (K, TA;) such that one cannot find the way to perform it, or manage it: pl. as above. (TA.) You say, waqaEa fiI buhomapK laA yutRajahu lahaA (assumed tropical:) [He fell into a difficult, or an embarrassing, case, which one knew not the way to manage]. (TA.) The pl. is also explained as meaning (assumed tropical:) Dubious, confused, or vague, affairs or cases. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Blackness. (TA.) ― -b6- And Albuhamu (assumed tropical:) The three nights in which the moon does not [visibly] rise. (TA.)

buhomaI bhmI bhmy bhmyy bhym hm
buhomaI, a word both sing. and pl., (Sb, S, K,) its alif [written I] being a denotative of the fem. gender, wherefore it is without tenween; (Sb, S;) or [it is written buhomFI, with tenween, for it is a coll. gen. n., and] its n. un. is buhomaApN, (S, K, and so in the JK,) its alif, some say, being a letter of quasi-coordination; but Mbr says that this is not known, and that the alif in a word of the measure fuEolI is nought but a denotative of the fem. gender; (S;) and the n. un. bhmAp is anomalous; (El-'Ash-
moonee's Expos. of the Alfeeyeh of Ibn-Málik, § AltOnyv;) [A species of barley-grass; app. hordeum murinum, or common wall-barley-grass;] a certain plant, (Lth, JK, S, K,) well known; (K;) the sheep and goats, (Lth, TA,) or the camels, (JK,) are vehemently fond of it as long as it is green; (Lth, JK, TA;) but when it dries up, its prickles bristle out, and it repugns; (Lth, TA;) it is of the herbs (buquwl) that are termed OaHoraAz [app. here meaning slender and sweet] when fresh and when dry, and comes forth at first undistinguishably as to species, from the earth, like as does corn; then it becomes like corn, and puts forth prickles like those [that compose the awn, or beard,] of the ear of corn, which, when they enter the noses of the sheep or goats and the camels, cause pain to their noses, until men pull them out from their mouths and their noses; and when it becomes large, and dries up, it is a pasture that is fed upon until the rain of the next year falls upon it, when its seed that has fallen from its ears germinates beneath it. (AHn, TA.)

bahiymN bhym hAYm
bahiymN Black: (K:) pl. buhumN. (TA.) And [app. used also as a subst., signifying] A black ewe (K, TA) in which is no whiteness: pl. as above and buhomN. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a horse, to the male and the female, (S, * Mgh, * K,) Of one, unmixed, colour; in which is no colour differing from the rest: (S, Mgh, K:) pl. buhumN. (S.) laA OagarRu wa laA bahiymN [Not having a star, or blaze, on the forehead or face, nor of one, unmixed, colour, or not white nor black, (some such proposition as “This is a horse” being understood before lA,)] is a prov. applied to a dubious, confused, or vague, affair or case. (TA.) ― -b3- A colour of one kind, (JK,) in which is no colour differing from the rest, (JK, and Har p. 50,) whatever colour it be, except that which is termed Xuhobap: (Har ubi suprà:) or a colour that is clear, pure, or unmixed, not resembling any other, (AA, K, * TA,) whether it be black or any other colour, (AA, TA,) except, as Z says, that which is termed Xuhobap. (TA.) ― -b4- A night in which is no light (JK, TA) until the dawn. (TA.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A sound, or voice, in which is no trilling, or quavering, or reiteration in the throat or fauces. (JK, K, * TA. *) ― -b6- Perfect, or complete, in make; as also mubohamN↓: pl. buhomN: so in the phrase in a trad. (respecting the day of resurrection, TA), yuHoXaru AlnRaAsu buhomFA, i. e. Mankind shall be congregated perfect, or complete, in make, without mutilation, or defect: (JK:) or the meaning here is, sound, or healthy: (S:) or not having any of the diseases or noxious affections of the present state, as blindness, and elephantiasis, and leprosy, and blindness of one eye, and lameness, &c.: (A'Obeyd, K, * TA:) or naked; (JK, K;) not having upon them anything to conceal them: (JK:) or not having with them anything (S, TA) of worldly goods or commodities. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) Unknown. (El-Khattábee, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also UibohaAmN.

bahiymapN bhym bhymh bhymp hAYm
bahiymapN [A beast; a brute;] any quadruped, (Akh, M, Msb, K,) even if in the water, (Akh, M, K,) [i. e.,] of the land and of the sea; (Msb;) and (so in the Msb, but in the K “or”) any animal that does not discriminate: (Zj, Msb, K:) pl. bahaAYimu. (S, Msb, K.)

bahiymiI bhym bhymI bhymy hAYm hymAn
[bahiymiI Of, or relating to, beasts, or brutes.]

bahiymiyRapN bhymy bhymyh bhymyp
[bahiymiyRapN The nature of beasts, or brutes.]

Oabohamu c
Oabohamu: see mubohamN, in two places. ― -b2- Also i. q. OaEojamu [app. as meaning Destitute of the faculty of speech or articulation, like the beasts]. (K.)

UibohaAmN UbhAm AbhAm
UibohaAmN The thumb, and the great toe; (M, K;) the greatest UiSobaE, (JK, T, S,) that is next to the forefinger, having two joints, so called because it closes upon [the palm of] the hand, as a cover; (T, TA;) the greatest of the OaSaAbiE in the hand and in the foot: (M, K:) of the fem. gender, (S, Msb,) accord. to common repute; (Msb;) and sometimes masc.: (Lh, M, K:) and bahiymN↓ signifies the same; mentioned by Az in the T, and by others; but Az adds that one should not say bihaAmN: (TA:) the pl. of AbhAm is OabaAhiymu (JK, S, M, Msb, K) and OabaAhimu, (M, K,) which latter is used by poetic license for the former, (M,) and UibohaAmaAtN. (Msb.) OaqoSaru mino UibohaAmi AlDRabRi [Shorter than the great toe of the (lizard called) DbR], and mn AbhAm AlqaTaApi [than the back toe of the (bird called) qTAp], and mn AbhAm AlHubaAraI [than the back toe of the (bird called) HbArI], are proverbs of the Arabs. (Har p. 335.)

mubohamN mbhm
mubohamN, applied to a door, Closed, or locked, (JK, K,) so that one cannot find the way to open it: (JK, TA:) and stopped up: (TA:) or having a lock upon it, with which it is fastened. (Mgh.) ― -b2- A wall in which is no door. (TA.) ― -b3- A chest having no lock [by means of which it may be opened]. (IAmb, TA.) ― -b4- I. q. muSomatN [as meaning Solid; not hollow; in the CK OaSomatu, which signifies the same]; as also Oabohamu↓: (K:) having no fissure in it: and ↓the latter, applied to a heart is said to mean (assumed tropical:) impenetrable by admonition. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A thing, or an affair, made to be dubious, confused, or vague; (JK;) [such that there is no way, or manner, of knowing it; (see the verb;)] or such that one knows not the way, or manner, in which it should be engaged in, done, executed, or performed: (JK, S, Mgh, TA:) (assumed tropical:) speech, or language, [that is dubious, confused, or vague,] such that there is no way, or manner, of knowing it: (Mgh, TA:) applied to a road, (assumed tropical:) unapparent, or hardly apparent: (TA:) and, applied to the ordinance respecting the making up for the days in which one has broken a fast, [and to many other cases,] (assumed tropical:) undefined; in this instance meaning, as to whether the days may be interrupted, or whether they must be consecutive. (Mgh.) [Hence,] mubohamaAtN (assumed tropical:) Difficult things, or affairs, such that one cannot find the way to perform them. (TA.) And AlOasomaMCu Almubohamapu, so termed by the grammarians, (assumed tropical:) The nouns of indication, (S, K,) such as hecaA and heWulaMCi and caAka and OuwlaAYika: (S:) accord. to Az, AlHuruwfu Almubohamapu signifies (assumed tropical:) the particles which have no derivatives, and of which the roots are not known, as AlRaciI and maA and mano and Eano and the like. (TA.) ― -b6- Applied to a vow, and to [certain ordinances respecting] marriage and divorce and emancipation, (assumed tropical:) From which there is no getting out, or extricating of oneself; as though they were closed doors with locks upon them: (Mgh:) and, applied to prohibited things, (assumed tropical:) not allowable in any manner, (T, K, TA,) nor for any cause; (T, TA;) or prohibited unconditionally; (Mgh;) as the prohibition of [the marriage with] the mother, and the sister, (T, Mgh, * K, TA,) and the like: (T, TA:) such a woman is said to be mubohamapN EalaI AlrRajuli (assumed tropical:) [absolutely prohibited to the man; as though she were closed against him, or inaccessible to him]. (Msb. [But in this last work it seems to be mvbohimapN, which is not agreeable with common usage.]) In the copies of the K, buhomN and buhumN are given as pls. of this word: but it seems that there is an omission or a misplacement in the passage; for these are said to be pls. of bahiymN, as shown above. (TA.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) In a state of swooning or insensibility, speechless, and without discrimination; in consequence of a blow [&c.]. (TA.) ― -b8- See also bahiymN.

musotabohimN Eani AlkalaAmi mstbhm En AlklAm
musotabohimN Eani AlkalaAmi (assumed tropical:) Debarred from the faculty of speech. (Niftaweyh, TA.)

1. bahaA, (JK, Msb, K,) aor. yabohaA, (JK,) or yabohuw; (Msb, K;) and bahuwa, aor. yabohuw; and bahiIa, aor. yabohaI; (S, * K;) and bahaI, [first pers. bahayotu,] aor. yabohaI; (K;) inf. n. bahaMCN and bahaMCapN; (JK, TA;) He (a man, S) or it, was, or became, characterized by, or possessed of, bahaMC, meaning beauty, or goodliness [&c.]. (JK, S, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- bahawotuhu and bahayotuhu: see 3. ＝ -A3- bahiIa, (S, K,) aor.
bahawa
, (K,) inf. n. bahFA, (TA,) It (a tent, S, K) was, or became, empty, or vacant: (K:) or it was, or became, rent, or pierced with holes, and rendered vacant. (S, TA.) ＝ -A4- bahiIa bihi i. q. bahaOa bihi [q. v.]. (JK.) And bahaWuwA bihi occurs in a trad., as they relate it, for bahaWuwA bihi. (A'Obeyd, TA in art. bhO.)

2 bhRAhu bhAh bhAp
2. bhRAhu, inf. n. tabohiyapN, He made it wide, or ample; or widened it; and made it; namely, a bayot [i. e. tent, or house]. (K.)

3 bAhAhu bAhAh bAhAp bAhI
3. bAhAhu, (TA,) [and bAhI bihi, as will be seen from what follows,] inf. n. mubaAhaApN, (S, TA,) He vied, or competed, with him, or contended with him for superiority, in beauty, or goodliness, or in glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excellence; he emulated, or rivalled, him therein; or, simply, he vied with him; syn. baAraAhu; (TA in art. bhj;) and faAxarahu. (S, * TA.) Hence, in a trad. respecting 'Arafeh, tubaAhiI bihimu AlmalaAYikapu [The angels vie with them]. (TA.) You say, baAhaAniI fabahawotuhu↓ (Lh, JK, K *) and bahayotuhu↓ (Lh, JK) i. e. [He vied, or competed, with me, or contended with me for superiority, in beauty, or goodliness, &c.,] and I became, (Lh,) or I was, (JK,) more beautiful, or goodly, [&c.,] than he, (Lh, JK,) or I surpassed him in beauty, or goodliness [&c.]. (K.)

4 AbhI Obh ObhI Obhy Obhyy AbhI Abhy bhy Mbh Mbhy Mbhyy
4. AbhI He (a man) was, or became, beautiful, or handsome, in face. (K.) ＝ -A2- AbhAhu [He deprived
it of beauty, or goodliness; the A being a privative, as it often is, like the Greek a: this is probably the primary signification: (see Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 604:) and hence, ― -b2- ] He made it empty, or vacant: (K:) or he rent it, or made holes in it: (JK:) or he rent it, or made holes in it, and rendered it vacant: (S:) namely, a tent. (JK, S, K.) Hence the saying, AlmiEozaI tubohiI wa laA tuboniI [explained in art. bnI]: (JK, S:) applied to him who injures and does not profit. (JK.) ― -b3- He emptied it; namely, a vessel. (A'Obeyd, JK, S, K.) ― -b4- AbhI Alxayola He freed the horses from service (JK, S, K) in warfare; (S, K;) i. e. he did not go to war upon the horses: (TA:) or he divested the horses of their furniture, and did not ride them: or he supplied the horses amply with fodder, and gave them rest: but the first is the-approved explanation. (TA.)

6 tabaAhawoA bAhI tbAhI tbAhwA
6. tabaAhawoA They vied, or competed, or contended for superiority, one with another, [in beauty, or goodliness, or] in glorying, or boasting, or in glory, or excellence; they emulated, or rivalled, one another therein; or, simply, they vied, one with another; syn. tafaAxaruwA. (S, K.)

8 yabotahiI ybthI ybthy
8. yabotahiI occurs in a verse of El-Aashà for yabotahiYu. (O, TS, L, on the authority of As, in art. bhO, q. v.)

bahowN bhw hw
bahowN Ampleness; or an ample state, or condition: so in the saying, huwa fiI bahowK mina AlEayoXi [He is in an ample state, or condition, of life]: and this is [said to be] the primary signification. (As, TA.) ― -b2- Anything ample, wide, or spacious. (K.) [Hence,] naAqapN bahowapN Aljanabayoni A she-camel wide in the two sides. (TA.) ― -b3- A wide, or spacious, tract of land, (K, TA,) in which are no mountains, between two elevated tracts. (TA.) ― -b4- A wide covert, or hiding-place, of a [wild] bull, (JK, K, TA,) which he makes for himself at the foot of the kind of tree called OaroTFI [q. v.]: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OabohaMCN and [of mult.] buhuwRN and [quasi-pl.-n.] bahiIRN. (K.) ― -b5- Any vacant, or intervening, space. (TA.) ― -b6- The interior of the chest, or breast, (K, TA,) of a man and of any beast: (TA:) or the space that intervenes between the two breasts and the uppermost part of the chest (K, TA) is called bahowu AlSRadori: (TA:) or the part between [or within] the extremities of the ribs that project over the belly: (TA:) and in her that is pregnant, (JK, K,) whatever she be, (JK,) the resting-place of the fœtus, between the two haunches: (JK, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OabohaMCN and OabohK and [of mult.] buhiIRN and [quasi-pl. n.] bahiIRN [in the TA bihiIRN, which seems to be a mistake]. (K) ― -b7- A tent that is placed in advance, before the other tents: (JK, S, TA:) pl. OabohaMCN. (JK.) In a trad., Arabs are spoken of as removing with their OabohaMC. (TA.)

bahK b bh bp
bahK [originally bahiwN]: see bahiIRN, in two places.

bahaMCN bhMC
bahaMCN Beauty, or goodliness: (S, Msb, K:) beauty of aspect, of mien, or of external state or condition: (Msb:) a beautiful aspect, that excites admiration, and satisfies the eye: (TA:) and, as an attribute of God, (Msb,) greatness, or majesty. (Msb, Har p. 271.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The froth of milk: (JK:) or the glistening of the froth of milk. (K.) ＝ -A2- As an epithet applied to a she-camel, it belongs to art. bhO [in which it is explained]. (S.)

bahiIRN bhI bhy
bahiIRN Possessing the quality, or attribute, of bahaMC [i. e. beauty, or goodliness, &c.]; (JK, S, Msb;) the beauty of which, (JK,) or the pleasing appearance of which, (TA,) satisfies the eye; (JK, TA;) as also bahK↓ and baAhK↓: the fem. of bahiIRN is bahiyRapN; of which the pl. is bahiyRaAtN and bahaAyaA: and the fem. of bahK↓ is bahiyapN; and the pl. is OabohiyaMCu. (TA.)

baAhK bAh bAp
baAhK: see bahiIRN. ＝ -A2- Also, applied to a bayot [or tent (see bahiIa)], Empty, or vacant; (JK, S, K;) containing nothing: (S:) or containing little furniture, or few goods or utensils. (TA.) ― -b2- biYorN baAhiyapN A wide-mouthed well. (K.)

OabohaI c
OabohaI [More, and most, beautiful, or goodly;] surpassingly, or superlatively, beautiful, or goodly: fem. buhoyaA; which is applied to a woman, and, by Honeyf El-Hanátim, to a she-camel. (Az, TA.) [Hence,] one says, UinRa hecaA labuhoyaAIa [This is my superlatively beautiful quality; or] this is of the things in which I vie with others. (AA, ISk.)

1 bahaIa bhI bhy
1. bahaIa, as an intrans. v.: and bahayotuhu: see art. bhw.

bawRN bw
bawRN A skin of a young unweaned camel stuffed (Lth, T, S, M, K) with straw (Lth, T, M, K) or with vumaAm [i. e. panic grass] (M, K) or with dry herbage, (M,) to which a she-camel is made to incline (Lth, T, S) when her young one has died: (S:) it is brought near to the mother of the young camel [that has died], in order that she may incline to it, and yield her milk (M, K) over it. (M.) ― -b2- Also A she-camel's young one. (M, K.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) Stupid; foolish; having little sense, or intellect; as also bawRiIRN↓; (IAar, T, K;) applied to a man: (IAar, T:) fem. bawRapN. (K.) ― -b4- And AlbawRu, (K,) or bawRu AlOavaAfiI, (Lth, T, S, M,) (tropical:) Ashes: (Lth, T, S, M, K:) so called [as being lifeless,] by way of comparison [to the stuffed skin of a young camel]. (M.)

bawRiIRN bwI bwy
bawRiIRN: see above.

bawobaApN bwb bwbAh bwbAp
bawobaApN, mentioned in this art. in the S, and also, as well as in art. bwb, in the K: see the latter art.

juwozu bawRaA jwz bwA
juwozu bawRaA, also written jawozu bawRaI: see art. jwz. ＝ -A2- xayoru bawRaMCu: see art. xyr.

1 baMCa Uilayohi bMC Alyh bMC Alyp
1. baMCa Uilayohi, (M, Mgh, * Msb, * K,) aor. yabuwoCu, (M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. bawoCN, (M, Mgh,) He returned, went back, or came back, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) to it, (M, K, *) namely, a thing: (M:) or he withdrew [from a person or persons, or a place,] to it, or him; or, perhaps, he made himself solely and peculiarly a companion, or an associate, to him, or it; syn. AinoqaTaEa [q. v.]: (K:) but in some copies of the K, the latter explanation is connected with the former by wa [and] instead of Oaw. (TA.) wabaAWuwA bigaDabK mina QllRehi [in the Kur ii. 58 and iii. 108] means And they returned with anger from God; (Akh, S, Bd in ii. 58, and Jel in the same and in iii. 108;) i. e. the anger of God came upon them: (Akh, S:) or they returned deserving anger from God: (Bd in iii. 108:) or they became deserving of anger from God: from baMCa fulaAnN bifulaAnK such a one was deserving of being, or fit to be, slain in retaliation for such a one, (Ksh and Bd in ii. 58,) because his equal: (Ksh ibid.:) the primary signification of bawoCN being [said to be] that of equalling, or being equal with. (Bd in ii. 58.) [See a similar phrase, also from the Kur, below.] ― -b2- buWotu bihi Uilayohi [I returned with it to him: and hence,] I returned it, took it back, or brought it back, to him; (M, K;) as also OabaOotuhu↓, (Th, M, K,) and buWotuhu, (Ks, M, K,) but this last is rare. (M.) ― -b3- baMCa biUivomihi, aor. and inf. n. as above, (T, S,) signifies, accord. to Akh, He returned [laden] with his sin: (S:) or, accord. to As, he acknowledged it, or confessed it: (T:) or, accord. to others, (TA,) baMCa bicanobihi, (T, * M, Msb, K,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawoCN and bawaMCN, (M, K,) he bore, or took upon himself, the burden of his sin, or crime, or offence; syn. AiHotamalahu; (Aboo-Is-hák, T, M, K, TA;) and became [as though he were] the abiding-place thereof: (TA:) or he became burdened, or laden, with it: (Msb:) or he became, or made himself, answerable, responsible, or accountable, for it, by an inseparable obligation; syn. Ailotazama bihi; for the primary signification of bawaMCN is [asserted to be] luzuwmN [i. e. adhesion, &c.]; and it is afterwards used in every case [so as to imply a meaning of this kind] according to the exigency of that case; as is said in the Nh, and expressly stated by Z and Er-Rághib: (TA:) or he acknowledged it, or confessed it. (M, K.) UinRiI Ouriydu Oano tabuwoCa biUivomiI wa Uivomika, in the Kur v. 35, means Verily I desire that thou return [laden] with the sin committed against me in slaying me, and thy sin which thou hast committed previously: (Jel:) or I desire that thou shouldst bear (taHomila) my sin if I were to extend my hand towards thee, and thy sin in extending thy hand towards me: or the sin committed against me in slaying me, and thy sin for which thine offering was not accepted: and each noun is in the place of a denotative of state; i. e., [it means] that thou return involved in the two sins; bearing them: and perhaps the speaker may have meant, if that must inevitably take place, I desire that it may be thine act, not mine; so that the real meaning is, that it should not be his, not that it should be his brother's: or by the UivomN may be meant the punishment thereof; for the desire of the punishment of the disobedient is allowable: (Bd:) accord. to Th, the meaning is, if thou have determined upon slaying me, the sin will be in thee, not in me. (M.) fabaAWuwA bigaDabK EalaI gaDabK
[in the Kur ii. 84] is explained by Aboo-Is-hák as meaning So they bore the burden of anger upon anger; syn. AiHotamaluwA; this being said by him to be the proper signification of the verb: or, as some say, the meaning is, [they bore the burden of] sin for which they deserved the fire [of Hell] following upon sin for which they deserved the same: or they returned [laden with anger upon anger]: (T:) or they became deserving of anger upon anger. (Ksh.) [See a similar phrase, also from the Kur, above.] It is said in a form of prayer, OabuwoCu Uilayoka biniEomatika, meaning I acknowledge, or confess, to Thee thy favour [towards me, as imposing an obligation upon me]. (Mgh.) You say also, baMCN biHaqRihi; (S;) and bidRimihi; (M, K;) He acknowledged, or confessed, [himself to be answerable, responsible, or accountable, for] his right, due, or just claim; (S;) and so [for] his blood: (M, K:) the verb expresses acknowledgment, or confession, always of something for which its agent is, as it were, indebted, or answerable; not the contrary. (S.) ― -b4- baMCa bikafRiI, in a poem of Sakhr-el-Gheí, means It [referring to a sword] became in my hand; my hand became to it a mabaMCap, i. e. maOowFI [or place of abode]; it returned, and became in my hand: or, accord. to Ibn- Habeeb, i. q. AisotaqalRa [app. a mistranscription for AisotaqarRa it rested, or remained; the verb bMC in this phrase being from bawaMCN signifying luzuwmN, explained above]. (Skr p. 16.) ＝ -A2- baMCN also signifies It (a thing, TA) suited, matched, tallied, corresponded, or agreed. (K.) [Hence,] baMCa fulaAnN bifulaAnK (inf. n. bawaMCN, TA) Such a one was the like, or equal, of such a one, to be slain [in retaliation] for him: (T:) or became his like, or equal, so that he was slain [in retaliation] for him: (Mgh:) and was slain for him, (AZ, T, S,) and his blood became a compensation for the blood of the other: (T:) or was deserving of being, or fit to be, slain in retaliation for him, (Ksh and Bd in ii. 58,) because his equal: (Ksh ibid.:) or was slain for him, and so became equal with him; (K, * TA;) as also OabaMCahu↓, and baAwaOahu↓. (M, K.) One says, buWobihi, i. e. Be thou of such as are slain [in retaliation] for him. (S.) And it is said in a prov., baMCato EaraAri bikaHolK 'Arári became slain for Kahl: these were two cows, which smote each other with their horns, and both died: the proverb is applied to any two that become equal. (S in this art.; and the same and K in art. Er. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 151.]) ― -b2- baMCa damahu bidamihi, (T, * M, K,) inf. n. bawoCN and bawaMCN, (M,) He made his blood equal with [or an equivalent for] his [i. e. another's] blood [by shedding the former in retaliation]. (M, K.) And baMCahu, [or baMCahu bihi,] (M,) or bh OabaMCahu↓, (T, S,) and bh AisotibaMCahu↓, (S,) He slew him [in retaliation] for him; (T, S, M;) i. e., the slayer for the slain. (S.) fulaAnFA bifulaAnK OabaMCa↓ [He slew such a one in retaliation for such a one] is said when the Sultán has retaliated for a man upon another man: and OabaMCahu↓, inf. n. UibaMCapN, signifies he (the Sultán, or another,) slew him in retaliation. (T.) ＝ -A3- baMCa signifies also He exalted himself, or was proud: app. formed by transposition [of the second and third radical letters, the I being changed into A,] from baOaI. (Fr, T.)

2 bwROhu manozilFA c
2. bwROhu manozilFA He lodged him in an abode; (Fr, T, M, K;) as also bwRAhu fiI manozilK, (M, K,) and manozilFA AbMChu↓: (T, * M, K:) or, as also bwRO lahu manozilFA, (the latter mentioned by Fr, T,) he prepared for him an abode, (S, Mgh,) and assigned, or gave, him a place therein: (S:) and bawRaOotuhu dArFA and bwRAtu lahu dArFA I lodged him in a house: (Msb:) and bawRaOotuka bayotFA I took for thee a house: and tabawRaM↓ liqawomikumaA bimiSora buyuwtFA [in the Kur x. 87] means take ye two, for your people, in Egypt, houses: (Akh, T:) or tabawRuWN↓ [or tabawRuWu makaAnK] signifies a man's putting a mark upon a place, when it pleases him, that he may abide there: (El-'Itreefee, T:) or tbwROhu↓ he put it [a place] into a right, or proper, state; and prepared it: (Sh, * T:) or bayotFA tbwRO↓ he took a house as a place of abode, or as a dwelling: (Msb:) or manozilFA tbwRO↓ he looked for the best place that could be seen, and the most level, or even, and the best adapted by its firmness, for his passing the night there, and took it as a place of abode; (Fr, T;) or he took for himself a place of abode; (T, Mgh;) or he alighted and sojourned in a place of abode: and AstbMChu↓ he took it as a mabaMCap [or place of abode]: (S:) and bwRO AlmakaAna and bihi AbMC↓ (K) and tbwRO↓ [i. e. tbwRO bihi] (Sh, T, K) he alighted in the place, and stayed, or dwelt, in it: (Sh, T, K:) or bh AbMC↓ he stayed, or dwelt, in it, i. e., a place: (Akh, T:) and AlmakaAna tbwRO↓ he alighted and abode in the place: (M:) [whence, in the Kur lix. 9,] QldRaArawa QloUiymaAna waQlRaciyna tabawRaWuwA↓ [and they who have made their abode in the City of the Prophet and in the faith]; the faith being likened to a place of abode; or the meaning may be makaAna AlUiymaAni [the place of the faith]. (M.)

bawRaOahumo manozilFA c

(AZ, TA.) ＝ -A2- [Hence, (see baMCapi,)] bwRO (inf. n. tabowiyoCN, K) (assumed tropical:) Inivit [feminam]: and he married [a woman]; took [her] in marriage: syn.

nakaHa kH nkH
nakaHa: (M, K:) and also tazRawaja. (TA. [There mentioned as a distinct signification.]) The verb is trans. in these two senses. (TK.) ＝ -A2- bwRO AlrumoHa naHowahu He directed the spear towards him; (T, S;) and (T) confronted him with it; (T, M, K;) and prepared it, or made it ready [to thrust it towards him]. (TA.)

4. OabaOotuhu: see buWotu bihi Uilayohi, near the beginning of this art. ― -b2- AbMC AlUibila, (T, S, O, L, and so in some copies of the K, in other copies of which we find AbMC biAloUibili,) inf. n. UibaMCapN, (T,) He brought back the camels to the mabaMCap (T, S, O, L) or maEoTin, (K,) both of which signify the place where they are made to lie down, at the watering-place. (L.) And AbMC AlUibila, (T, M,) inf. n. as above, (T,) He made the camels to lie down [in the mabaMCap], one beside another. (T, M.) And AbMC Ealayohi maAlahu He drove back, or brought back, to their nightly resting-place, for him, his cattle, (S, M, TA,) i. e., his camels, or his sheep or goats. (S, TA.) And [hence,] OabaMCa QllRehu Ealayohimo naEamFA laA yasaEuhaA AlmuraAHu [God bestowed upon them cattle (i. e. camels &c.) which the nightly resting-place thereof would not contain]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 2, in four places. ― -b4- AbMC AlOadiyma He put the skin, or hide, into the tanning liquid. (K.) In the O, the action is ascribed to a woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AbMC minohu He fled from him. (M, K.) ― -b2- falaApN tubiIoCu fiI falaAopK A desert that extends (lit. goes away) into a desert, (T, S, K,) by reason of its amplitude. (TA.) ＝ -A3- OabaOotuhu I made him to acknowledge, or confess. (M.) [It seems to be indicated in the M that one says, OabaOotuhu bidami fulaAnK, meaning I made him to acknowledge, or confess, himself to be answerable, responsible, or accountable, for the blood of such a one.] ＝ -A4- See also 1, (towards the end of the paragraph,) in four places.

5 tabawRaAa
5: see 2, in eight places. ― -b2- AlrRajulu yatabawRaOu mino Oaholihi kamaA yatabawRaOu mino daArihi The man possesses mastery, or authority, and power, over his wife, like as he possesses the same over his house; syn. yasotamokinu minohaA. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- See also 10.

6 tabaAwaM tbAwM
6. tabaAwaM They two (namely, two slain men, M) became equal [by being slain, one in retaliation for the other]. (M, K.) It is said in a trad., Oamarahumo Oano yatabaAwaWuwA; incorrectly related as being yatabMCawoA; (S, Mgh;) meaning He (the Prophet) ordered them that they should be equal in retaliation, in their fighting: (Mgh:) the occasion of the order was this: there was a conflict between two tribes of the Arabs, and one of the two tribes had superior power over the other, so they said, “ We will not be content unless we slay, for the slave of our party, the free of their party; and for the woman, the man: ” A'Obeyd holds the former reading to be the right. (T.)

10 AstbMChu AstbMCh AstbMCp
10. AstbMChu: see 2. ― -b2- In the following verse of Zuheyr Ibn-Abee-Sulmà,
walamo OarajaAra bayotK yusotabaMCu
falamo Oara maEoXarFA OasaruwA hadiyRFA
ISk says that the hadiIR is one who is entitled to respect, or honour, or protection; and that ystbMC is syn. with yutabawRaOu↓, meaning whose wife is taken as a wife [by another man]: but Aboo-'Amr EshSheybánee says that ystbMC is from AlbawaMCu, meaning “ retaliation: ” [and accord. to this interpretation, which is the more probable, the verse may be rendered, And I have not seen a company of men who have made captive one entitled to respect, or honour, or protection, nor have I seen one who has begged the protection of the people of a house, or of a tent, slain in retaliation:] for, he says, he came to them desiring to beg their protection, and they took him, and slew him in retaliation for one of themselves. (T.) See 1, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b3- AisotabaOotu AlHakama, and biAloHakam, I asked the judge to retaliate upon a slayer; to slay the slayer for the slain. (M.)

baMCN bcMC
baMCN: see baMCapN. ＝ -A2- A libidinous man. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.) ＝ -A3- The name of the letter b, q. v.; as also baA: pl. of the former baMCaAtN; and of the latter OabowaMCN. (TA ubi suprà.) The dim. is buyayRapN, meaning A little b: and a b faintly pronounced: [and app. buwayRapN also, as the medial radical is generally held to be w:] and in like manner is formed the dim. of every similar name of a letter. (Lth, on the letter HaMC, in TA, bAb AlAlf AllynRp.)

baMCapN bMCh bMCp
baMCapN: see mabaMCapN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and baMCN↓, (IAar, T, S, M, K,) and baAhapN, with the C changed into h, (TA,) and baAhN, (IAar, T, Msb,) with A and h, but IKt asserts this last to be a mistranscription, (Msb, TA,) [though it is of very frequent occurrence,] and IAmb says that baMCapN is sing., or n. un., of baMCN, and baMCN [or baMCapN] has for pl. baMCaAtN, (TA,) (tropical:) Coïtus conjugalis: and marriage: syn. jimaAEN (T, Msb) and nikaAHN (As, Fr, T, S, M, Mgh, K) and tazowiyjN: (T:) from baMCapN signifying a place of abode; [see mabaMCapN;] (T, S, * Mgh, Msb;) because it is generally in a place of abode; (Mgh, Msb;) or because the man possesses mastery, or authority, and power, over his wife, like as he possesses the same over his house: (S, Mgh, Msb: see 5:) baMCapN is applied [also] to the marriage-contract; because he who takes a woman in marriage lodges her in a place of abode. (T.) [See also baAhN, in art. bwh.] It is said in a trad., mani QsotaTaAEa minokumu AlbaMCa pa faloyatazRawjo He who is able, of you, to marry, let him marry: (T:) or a prefixed noun is here suppressed; the meaning being, he who finds [or is able to procure] the provisions (muWan) of marriage, let him marry. (Msb, TA.) And one says, fulaAnN HariySN EalaI AlbaMCapi Such a one is vehemently desirous of marriage. (As, T.)

biyoYapN c
biyoYapN a subst. from bawRaOahu manozilFA. (M, K.) [See 2; and] see also mabaMCapN. ― -b2- A mode, or manner, of taking for oneself a place of abode: (M:) and [hence,] a state, or condition. (AZ, T, S, M, K.) You say, UinRahu laHasanu AlbiyoYapi Verily he has a good mode, or manner, of taking for himself a place of abode: (M:) or verily he is of good state or condition. (S.) And baAta bibiyoYapi He passed the night in an evil state or condition (AZ, T, S, * M.) bawaMCN Equal; equivalent; like; alike; a match; (Akh, T, S, M, Mgh, K;) and particularly, if slain in retaliation for another. (M.) It is applied to one, and to two, and to more: so that you say, fulaAnN bawaMCN fulaAnN Such a one is the equal, &c., of such a one if slain in retaliation for him: (M:) and huwa bawaMCN He is an equal, &c.; and so hiIa she: and humo bawaMCN They are equals, &c.; and so hunRa they, referring to females: (Mgh:) and humo bawaMCN fiI hecaA AlOamori They are equals in this affair. (T.) Hence, in a trad. of 'Alee, respecting witnesses, Uaca kaAnuwA bawaMCN When they are equals in number and rectitude. (Mgh.) And maA fulaAnN lifulaAnK bibawaMCN Such a one is not an equal, &c., to such a one. (T.) And damu fulaAnK bawaMCN lidami fulaAnK The blood of such a one is an equivalent for the blood of such a one. (S.) And AljiraAHaAtu bawaMCN Wounds are to be retaliated equally: a trad. (T, Mgh.) And Alqawomu EalaI bawaMCi The people, or company of men, are in a state of equality. (T.) And qusima AlmaAlu bayonahumo EalaI bawaMCK The property was divided among them equally. (T. [A similar ex. is given in the Mgh, and explained in the same manner; but there I find Eano bawaMCK; perhaps a mistranscription.]) And kalRamonaAhumo faOajaAbuwA Eano bawaMCK waAHidK [in a copy of the M EalaI bwMC wAHd] We spoke to them, and they replied with one reply: (T, S, O, K: *) i. e., their reply was not discordant: Eano being here used in the sense of bi. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Retaliation. (T.) [See 1, near the end of the paragraph: as well as in other places.] It is related in a trad., that Jaafar Es-Sádik, being asked the reason of the rage of the scorpion against the sons of Adam, said, turiydu AlbawaMCa [It desires retaliation]; i. e., it hurts like as it is hurt. (TA.)

baAYiIRN c
baAYiIRN and baAwiyRN↓ rel. ns. of baMCN and baA the names of the letter b; (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp;) and bayawiIRN↓ is a rel. n. of the same. (M in art. b.)

baAwiIRN bAwI bAwy
baAwiIRN see baAYiIRN.

bayawiIRN bywI bywy
bayawiIRN see baAYiIRN.

mabaMCapN mbMCh mbMCp
mabaMCapN The nightly resting-place of camels; (T;) the resting-place of camels, where they are made to lie down, at the watering-place; (T, S, * M, * L, K; *) and of sheep or goats likewise; also termed mutabawRaON↓: (L, TA:) or the place to which camels return; (Mgh;) as also baMCapN↓: (Mgh, Msb:) this is the primary signification. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) A place of abode (T, S, M, K) of a people, in any situation; (T, S;) as also mubawRaON↓ (Bd and Jel in x. 93) and biyoYapN↓ (M, K) and baMCapN↓; (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, * K;) which last is hence applied in another sense, explained before, voce bMCapN: (Mgh, Msb:) or a place where people alight and abide next to a valley, or to the face, or front, of a mountain, where it rises from its base; [see bawRaOahumo manozilFA;] as also baMCapN↓. (T.) [Hence,] huwa raHiybN AlmabaMCapi (assumed tropical:) He is largely bountiful. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The covert of the wild bull. (S, K. *) ― -b4- A nest of bees in a mountain: (M, K:) or, accord. to the T, the nightly resting-place of bees; not there restricted by mention of the mountain. (TA.) ― -b5- The part of the womb where the child has its abode; (M;) the part thereof which is the child's mutabawRaO↓. (K.) ― -b6- A well has what are termed mabaMCataAni, which are The place where the water returns to [supply the place of] that which has [before] collected in the well [and been drawn], (M,) or the place where the water collects in the well; (TA voce maMCabapN;) and the place where stands the driver of the saAniyap [q. v.]. (M.) [See also mavaAbapN; and mavaAbN.]

HaAjapN mubiyoYapN c
HaAjapN mubiyoYapN A want that is vehement, or pressing, (K, TA,) and necessary. (TA.)

mubawRaON c
mubawRaON see mabaMCapN, in three places.

mutabawRaON c
mutabawRaON see mabaMCapN, in three places.

1 baAba lahu bAb lh bAb lp
1. baAba lahu, aor. yabuwbu, (M, K,) quasi-inf. n., if there be such a verb, biwaAbapN, with the w not changed into I because it is not an inf. n. properly speaking, but a subst., (Lth, T,) He was, or became, a door-keeper, or gate-keeper, to him; (M, K;) namely, a Sultán (M) [or other person].

2 bwRb bwb wyb
2. bwRb [app., (assumed tropical:) He practised what are termed OabowaAbu AlHarobi, meaning the expedients, tricks, or stratagems, of war, battle, or fight. ― -b2- And hence,] (assumed tropical:) He charged upon, attacked, or assaulted, the enemy. (AA, T.) ＝ -A2- bawRabotu AlOaXoyaMCa (assumed tropical:) I made the things to be divided into distinct OabowaAb [meaning kinds, or sorts; or I disposed, arranged, distributed, or classified, the things under distinct heads]. (Msb.) And bwRb AlOabowaAba (assumed tropical:) [He disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order, the kinds, sorts, classes, chapters, heads, or the like]. (TA voce OaSRala, q. v.) And bwRb AlmuWalRifu kitaAbahu (assumed tropical:) [The author disposed, or divided, his book in, or into, distinct chapters]. (A.) [See baAbN.]

5 tbwRb bwb tbwb
5. tbwRb, (A,) or tbwRb bawRaAbFA, (S, M, K,) He took for himself a door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (S, M, A, K.)

baAbN Ob Ub bOb bUb bAb bMb Mb
baAbN, originally bawabN, (M, Msb,) A door; a gate; a place of entrance: and the thing with which a place of entrance, such as a door or gate, is closed; of wood &c.: (MF, TA:) pl. OabowaAbN (S, M, Msb, K) and biybaAnN (M, K) and OabowibapN, (S, M, K,) [a pl. of pauc., said to be] only used for conformity with another word mentioned therewith, as in the saying (of Ibn-Mukbil, so in a copy of the S),
hatRaAku OaxobiyapK wa lRaAju OabowibapK
[A frequent render of tents, a frequent enterer of doors], (S, M,) not being allowable when occurring alone; (S;) but IAar and Lh assert that it is a pl. of bAb without its being used for conformity with another word; (M;) and this is extr.; (M, K;) for bAb is of the measure faEalN, and a word of this measure has not a pl. of the measure OafoEilapN [by rule]. (M.) You say, baAbN AldRaAri [The door of the house]; and baAbu Albayoti [the door of the house, and of the chamber, and of the tent]; (Msb;) and baAbu Albaladi [the gate of the town or city]. (The Lexicons &c. passim.) And Bishr Ibn-Abee-Házim assigns a bAb to a grave; calling the latter a bayot. (M.) It is also applied to an opening, or a channel, made for water, to irrigate seed-produce: pl. OabowaAbN. (Mgh.) [And in Egypt, it is applied also to A sepulchral chamber, grotto, or cave, hewn in a mountain; from the Coptic βηβ: pl. biybaAnN only.] ― -b2- Hence, i. e. in a secondary application, the primary signification being “ a place of entrance, ” it is used as meaning (tropical:) A means of access, or of attainment, to a thing: (B, Kull, TK:) as in the saying, hecaA AlEilomu baAbN UilaI Eilomi kacaA (tropical:) This science is a means of attainment to such a science. (B, TK.) ― -b3- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) An expedient, a trick, a stratagem, or a process, by which something is to be effected pl. OabowaAbN: as in OabowaAbu AlHarobi the expedients. &c.
of war, battle, or fight; and baAbN mina AlnRujuwmi a process of the science of the stars, meaning astrology or astronomy; and baAbN mina AlsRiHori a process of enchantment; see an ex. voce siHorN. Compare Matt. xvi. 18, πύλαι ᾅδου οὐ κατισχύσουσιν αύτης, probably meaning “ the stratagems of Hell shall not prevail against it. ”] ― -b4- [Also (assumed tropical:) A mode, kind, sort, class, or category.] Suweyd Ibn-Kuráa uses metaphorically the pl. OabowaAb in relation to rhymes; saying,
Oatayotu biOabowaAbi AlqawaAfiI kaOanRamaA
Oacuwdu bihaA sirobFA mina AlwaHoXi nuzRaEaA
(tropical:) [I gave utterance to the various kinds of rhymes as though I were driving with them a herd of wild animals desirous of the males, or of their wonted places of pasture]. (M, L.) [You say also, huwa mino hecaA AlbaAbi (assumed tropical:) It is of this mode, kind, sort, class, or category: a phrase of frequent occurrence in lexicons &c. See also baAbapN.] ― -b5- [Also (assumed tropical:) A chapter; and sometimes a section, or subdivision, of a chapter; of a book or writing;] conventionally, (assumed tropical:) a piece consisting of words relating to matters of one kind; and sometimes, to matters of one species: (Kull:) pl. OabowaAbN. (A.) See also baAbapN. ― -b6- [Also (assumed tropical:) A head, or class of items or articles, in an account, or a reckoning; as in the saying,] bayRanotu lahu HisaAbahu baAbFA baAbFA (assumed tropical:) [I explained, or made clear, to him his account, or reckoning, head by head, or each class of items or articles by itself]; a phrase mentioned by Sb: (M:) [or, sometimes,] baAbN (M, K) and baAbapN↓ (T, M, K) are used in relation to Huduwd [which here means the punishments so termed], and to an account, or a reckoning, (T, M, K,) and the like, (T, M,) as signifying the extreme term or limit; syn. gaAyapN; (M, K;) but IDrd hesitated respecting this, and therefore it is not mentioned in the S. (TA.)

baAbapN Obh bObh bAb bAbh bAbp bMbh Mb Mbh
baAbapN (assumed tropical:) A mode, or manner; syn. wajohN: (ISk, K:) pl. baAbaAtN. (K.) [See also baAbN, which has a similar, and perhaps the same, signification.] Hence, hecaA mino baAbatiI means (assumed tropical:) This is of the mode, or manner, that I desire; (TA;) this is suitable to me: (IAmb, TA:) and hecaA XaIoCN mino baAbatika, (S,) or hecaA baAbatuka, (A,) (assumed tropical:) this is a thing suitable to thee: (S, A:) and hecaA baAbatuhu (assumed tropical:) this is suitable to him. (K.) Accord. to most of the critics, it is tropical. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN Oahowanu baAbaAtihi Alkacibu (assumed tropical:) Such a one, the lightest of the kinds (OanowaAE) of his wickedness is lying. (A.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A habit: a property; a quality; nature; natural disposition: or a practice; or an action: syn. xaSolapN. (Abu-l-'Omeythil, TA.) [Hence, perhaps, the last of the exs. cited above from the A.] ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A condition; syn. XaroTN: as in the saying, hcaA baAbapu hecaA (assumed tropical:) [This is the condition of this]. (M, K. *) ― -b4- baAbaAtu AlkitaAbi (assumed tropical:) The lines of the book or writing: (M, A, K:) or it may mean its OabowaAb↓ [i. e. chapters, or sections of chapters]: (M:) this has no sing.: (A, K:) [ISd says,] I have not heard any sing. of it. (M.) ― -b5- See also baAbN; last signification.

bawobaApN bwb bwbAh bwbAp
bawobaApN A desert; or a desert in which is no water; syn. falaApN: (T, IJ, M, K:) as also mawomaApN; (T, MF;) the b being changed into m, as is often the case. (MF.) [It is mentioned in the S, and again in the K, in art. bw, as syn. with mafaAzapN.]

biwaAbapN bwAb bwAbh bwAbp
biwaAbapN The office, or occupation, of a door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (M, K.) [See 1.]

bawRaAbN bwAb
bawRaAbN A door-keeper, or gate-keeper. (S, * M, Msb, K, TA.)

OabowaAbN mubawRabapN c
OabowaAbN mubawRabapN (assumed tropical:) [Kinds, sorts, classes, chapters, heads, or the like, disposed, arranged, distributed, classified, or set in order,] is a phrase similar to OaSonaAfN muSanRafapN. (S.) You say also kitaAbN mubawRabN (assumed tropical:) [A book disposed in, or divided into, distinct chapters]. (A.)

baAjN bAj
baAjN; pl. OabowaAjN: see art. bOj. AZ mentions it as without C: ISk, as with C. (ISd, TA.)

1 baAHa OH bAH bOH
1. baAHa, (A, Msb, K,) aor. yabuwHu, (Msb,) inf. n. bawoHN, (A, Msb,) It (a secret, A, or a thing, Msb) became apparent, or manifest. (A, Msb, K.) You say, baAHa maA katabotu [What I concealed became apparent]. (A.) And OaEuwcu biQllRehi mXno bawoHi AlsRirRi wakaXofi AlsRitori [I seek protection by God from the appearing of the secret, and the removing of the veil, or covering]. (A.) ＝ -A2- baAHa bihi, (S, A, Msb, K,) [aor. as above,] inf. n. bawoHN and buWuwHN and buWuwHapN, (K, TA,) He revealed, or disclosed, it; (S, A, Msb, K;) namely, a secret, (S, A, K,) or a thing; (Msb;) as also AbAHhu↓. (A, Msb, K.) It (the former) is said to be from AlUibaAHahu↓ [the inf. n. of the latter] signifying The showing a thing to the beholder in order that he who will may take it. (TA.) You say, sirRFA fabaAHa bihi OabaAHahu↓ He revealed to him a secret, and he (the latter) [revealed it, i. e.,] did not conceal it. (TA.) And buHo biQsomika wa laA takoni Eanohu [Reveal thou thy name, and make not a mere allusion to it]. (A.)

4 AbAH ObAH AbAH
4. AbAH, inf. n. UibaAHapN: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- UibaAHapN and AisotibaAHapN↓ are used as syn.: but it is said that the former signifies The making a thing allowable, or free, to him who desires it, or seeks it: and the latter, the taking a thing as allowed, allowable, free, or lawful. (MF.) You say, AbAH AlXRaIoCa He made the thing allowable, or free. (L.) And AbAH maAlahu He gave permission either to take or let alone his property; made it allowable, or free, either way one might choose to take. (Msb.) And OabaHotuka AlXRaIoCa I made, or have made, the thing allowable, free, or lawful, to thee, (S, L, K, TA,) to take it, [or let it alone,] or do it, [or make use of it,] or possess it; but not by the law of the religion, for to do this belongs to God and his apostle; except in the language of this law. (MF, TA.) [Hence it is said that] UibaAHapN bears a signification similar to that of nuhobaI [i. e. Spoliation; a taking of spoil; or the taking a thing as spoil; a signification more properly belonging to the inf. n. of 10, q. v.]. (L.)

10 AstbAHhu AstbAHh AstbAHp QstbAH QstbAHh QstbAHp
10. AstbAHhu He deemed it, or esteemed it, to be allowed, allowable, free, or lawful; namely, the property of another: (A:) or he took it as allowed, allowable, &c. (A, * MF.) See 4. ― -b2- He took it as spoil, or plunder. (TA.) ― -b3- He made an attack upon it; namely, the property of another. (Msb.) ― -b4- He took him captive, making him as a lawful possession to him. (TA.) ― -b5- And AisotabaAHahumo, (K,) or AisotabaAHuwhumo, (S,) He, or they, extirpated, or exterminated, them. (S, K.)

buwHN bwH
buwHN has the following various significations assigned to it in explanations of the saying, Aibonuka Qbonu buwHika yaXorabu mino SabuwHika: (S, TA:) The penis: (S, K, Har p. 336:) the faroj [or pudendum, app. meaning, of a woman]: (K, Har p. 328 on the authority of AO:) the nafos [meaning one's self]: (IAar, T, S, Meyd, L:) coitus; syn. waToCN (S) or jimaAEN: (K:) and accord. to the last but one of these renderings, [and virtually accord. to the others also,] the saying means Thy son is the son of thyself, [who drinks of thy morningdraught]; (T, TA;) he whom thou hast begotten, not he whom thou hast adopted: (IAar, and Mtr in Har p. 328:) or bwH, here, is pl. of baAHapN; (A, TA, Har p. 336;) and the meaning is, he who has been born within the courts of thy house; (A;) or, in the court of thy house, (TA, Har,) not in the house of another: (TA:) or bwH is here a subst. from baAHa AlXRaIoCi; and the meaning is, thy son is he whom thou hast openly acknowledged (buHota bihi), and whom his mother hath also, agreeably with thee: (Har p. 328:) [accord. to some,] it signifies also i. q. OaSolN [i. e. origin; or race, or stock, which it may mean in the saying above: or original, or primary, state, or condition]; (K, Har p. 328;) [for] one says, rajaEa UilaI buwHihi [He returned, or reverted, to his original, or primary, state, or condition]. (Har p. 328.)

baAHapN OH bAH bAHh bAHp bOHh
baAHapN The court; or a spacious vacant part, or portion, in which is no building; syn. saAHapN, (S A, K,) and EaroSapN; (A, TA;) of a house or dwelling: (S, TA:) pl. buwHN [q. v.]. (A, TA.) Hence [is said to be derived] buHobuwHapu AldRaAri [mentioned in art. bH]. (TA.) One says also, naHonu fiI baAHapi AldRaAri, meaning We are in the middle, or midst, or best part, of the abode, or district, or country; i. e. OawosaTihaA. (TA.) And hence, accord. to Fr, tabaHobaHa [explained in art. bH]. (Az, TA.) It is said in a trad., layosa lilnRisaMCi mino baAHapi AlTRariyqi XaIoCo, meaning [Women have no right] in the middle of the road. (TA.) ― -b2- Also The main part or body of water: (K:) applied by most of the lexicologists to the sea. (TA.) [In the present day applied to A deep part of the sea, distant from land; the deep; the main, or main sea.] ― -b3- And Many palm-trees. (Aboo-Sárim El-Bahdalee, IAar, K.)

Oamarahu bimaEoSiyapK bawaAHFA c
Oamarahu bimaEoSiyapK bawaAHFA He ordered him to disobey, or rebel, openly. (K.) The last word occurs in this sense in two trads.; but in one of them, accord. to one recital, it is baraAHFA. (TA.)

huwa baWuwHN bimaA fiI Sadorihi c
huwa baWuwHN bimaA fiI Sadorihi He is one who reveals, or discloses, what is in his bosom; as also bayoHaAnN and bayRaHaAnN; (K;) the I being originally w. (TA.)

mubaAHN mbAH
mubaAHN Allowed or allowable [to be taken, or let alone, or done, or made use of, or possessed; see 4]; made allowable, free, or lawful; contr. of maHoZuwrN. (S, A.)

AlmubiyHu AlmbyH
AlmubiyHu The lion. (K.)

1 baAxati AlnRaAru bAxt AlnAr
1. baAxati AlnRaAru, (S, A, L, K,) aor. tabuwxu, inf. n. bawoxN and buWuwxN and bawaxaAnN, (L,) The fire abated; or became allayed: (S, L, K: *) or became extinguished, or quenched. (A.) And bAx AlHarRu The heat abated, or became allayed. (S, A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baAxati AlHumRaI (assumed tropical:) The fever abated, or became allayed. (S.) And bAx Eanohu Alwirodu (tropical:) His fever abated, or remitted. (A, TA.) And bAx gaDabuhu (tropical:) His anger abated, or became assuaged. (S, * A, K. *) And bayonahumo HarobN maA yabuwxu saEiyruhaA (assumed tropical:) Between them is war of which the fire does not become extinguished, or quenched. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] bAx likewise signifies (tropical:) He became fatigued, (S, L, K,) and out of breath. (L) You say, EadaA HatRaLI baAxa (S, A, L) (tropical:) He ran until he became fatigued (S, L) and out of breath. (L.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) flagged; or became remiss, or languid. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, inf. n. buWuwxN, (assumed tropical:) It (flesh-meat) became altered, or changed in odour or otherwise for the worse, (K, TA,) And corrupted, or tainted. (TA.)

4 AbAx AbAx
4. AbAx He extinguished, or quenched, fire. (A, K.) And He (God) abated, or allayed, the heat. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AbAx AlnRAYirapa bayonahumo (tropical:) [He extinguished, or assuaged, the discord, or rancour, or enmity, that was between them]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And Oabixo Eanoka mina AlZRahiyripa (assumed tropical:) Stay thou until the midday-heat shall have become allayed, and the air be cool. (IAar, TA in art. fyH and in the present art.)

buwxN bwx
buwxN A state of confusion, or perplexedness. (S, K.) You say, humo fiI buwxK mino Oamorihimo They are in a state of confusion, or perplexedness, with respect to their affair, or case. (S, K. *) And it is said in a prov., waqaEuwA fiI duwkapK wa bawxK, meaning They fell into evil, or mischief, and altercation. (Meyd, TA.)

1 baAda Ud bUd bAd bAdy
