1. baAda, inf. n. bawodN and bawaAdN: see art. byd.

1 baAra bAr bMr Mr
1. baAra, (S, M, Msb,) aor. yabuwru, (Msb,) inf. n. bawaArN (Lth, T, S, M, K) and baworN, (M, K,) or buwrN, (Msb,) He, (S,) or it, (Msb,) perished. (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K.) You say, baAduwA wa baAruwA [They became extinct, and perished]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baArati AlOaroDu (tropical:) The land was, or became, in a bad, or corrupt, state, and uncultivated; (K, * TA;) was unsown. (A.) ― -b3- And baAra Eamaluhu (assumed tropical:) His work was, or proved, vain, or ineffectual: such is the signification of the verb in the Kur xxxv. 11. (S, K.) ― -b4- And baAra, (T, S, &c.,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawaArN, (Msb,) (tropical:) It (a thing, Msb, or commodity, T, S, A, Mgh) was, or became, unsaleable, or difficult of sale, or in little demand: (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb:) because a thing, when neglected, becomes of no use, and thus resembles that which perishes. (Msb.) ― -b5- And baArati AlsRuwqu, (T, M,) inf. n. baworN and bawaArN, (K,) (tropical:) The market was, or became, stagnant, or dull, with respect to traffic. (T, M, K.) ― -b6- And baArati AlOayRimu, (A,) inf. n. bawaArN, (T, S, K,) (tropical:) The woman without a husband was not desired, or sought for: (A:) or remained in her house long without being demanded in marriage. (T, K.) ― -b7- [baAra is also used as an imitative sequent of HaAra; like as baAYirN is of HaAYirN: see exs. in art. Hwr.] ＝ -A2- baAra AlnRaAqapa, (T, S, A, K,) aor. as above, (T, S, A,) inf. n. baworN, (S,) He brought the she-camel to the stallion to see if she were pregnant or not: (T, S, A, K:) for if she is pregnant, she voids her urine in his face (S, K) when he smells her. (S.) ― -b2- Also He (the stallion) smelt the she-camel to know if she were pregnant or not; (T, S, M, K;) and so AbtArhA↓. (S, M.) ― -b3- Hence the saying, buro liI maA Eanoda fulaAnK (tropical:) Try thou, or examine, and learn, for me, what is in the mind (nafos S) of such a one. (S, A. *) You say, baArahu, (T, S, M, K,) aor. as above, (T, S,) inf. n. baworN; (T, M, K;) and AbtArhu↓, (M,) inf. n. AibotiyaArN; (S, K;) meaning (tropical:) He tried him; assayed him; proved him by experiment or experience; examined him. (T, S, M, K.) ElKumeyt says,
pi UimRaA QbotihaArFA w UimRaA QbotiyaAraA↓
qabiyHN bimivoliIa naEotu AlfataA
(T, S) (tropical:) It were foul in the like of me to characterize the damsel either by false accusation or by trying, with speaking truth, to elicit what is in her mind (maA EinodahaA [i. e. maA fiI nafosihaA, agreeably with an explanation given above]): (S, TA:) or AbtyArA↓, which is without C, here signifies by asserting with truth my having had sexual intercourse with her: (TA:) [for] AbtArhA signifies he asserted with truth that he had had sexual intercourse with her; and AbthrhA “ he asserted the same falsely: ” (A 'Obeyd, T:) and the former signifies also he had sexual intercourse with her (K, TA) by force; he ravished her: (TA:) or AbtAr signifies he charged, or upbraided, a person with that which was not in him; and Abthr “ he charged, or upbraided, with that which was in him. ” (TA in art. bhr.)

4 AbArhu ObAr ObArh AbArh AbArp bArI bYr MbArh
4. AbArhu He (God) destroyed him; caused him to perish. (S, M, A, K.)

8 Uibotawara
8: see 1, in four places.

OaroDN baworN c
OaroDN baworN, (A 'Obeyd, T, &c.,) in which the latter word is an inf. n. [of 1] used as an epithet, (IAth,) (tropical:) Land not sown; (A 'Obeyd, T, S, IAth;) as also bawaArN↓, [likewise an inf. n. used as an epithet,] of which the pl. is buwrN: (A, IAth:) or land before it is prepared for sowing (AHn, M, K) or planting: (AHn, M:) or land that is left to lie fallow one year, that it may be sown the next year: (K:) and OaroDN baAYirN↓, (Zj, M, K,) and baAYirapN↓, (Zj, K,) and buwrN↓, [which is originally an inf. n.,] (K,) or AlOaroDi buwru↓, [in which the former word may be pl. of bawaArN, mentioned above,] (M,) (tropical:) land that is in a bad state, and uncultivated, (K, * TA,) unsown, (M, TA,) and not planted: (TA:) or left unsown. (Zj, M.) You say also, OaSobaHato manaAziluhumo buwrFA↓ (assumed tropical:) Their abodes became void, having nothing in them. (Fr, T.) ― -b2- See also buwrN.

buwrN bcr bcwr
buwrN A bad, or corrupt, man; (S, A, K;) and one (M, K) in a state of perdition; (S, M, A, K;) in whom is no good; (S, K;) originally an inf. n., (Fr, T,) and [therefore, as an epithet,] applied also to a female, (AO, T, S, M, K,) and to two persons, and more: (AO, T, M, K:) [but see what here follows:] baAYirN↓, also, signifies bad, or corrupt; destitute of good; (Zj, M;) a man in a state of perdition; (AO, T, S;) and its pl., (K,) or rather quasi-pl., (M, TA,) is baworN↓, (M, K,) like as nawomN is of naAYimN, and SawomN of SaAYimN; (M, TA;) and another pl. of the same is buwrN, (AO, T, S, M,) like as HuwlN is of HaAYilN, or, accord. to some, as Akh states, this is a dial. var., not a pl., of baAYirN. (S.) ― -b2- See also baworN, in three places. ＝ -A2- UinRahumo lafiI HuwrK wa buwrK (A, TA [but in the latter, jwr is put for Hawr]) Verily they are in a state of deficiency, or detriment. (TA.) See also baAYirN. [And see HaworN.] You say also, cahaba fulaAnN fiI AlHawAri wa AlbawaAri↓ Such a one went away in a defective and bad state. (L, TA in art. Hwr.)

baAriIRN Ory bOry bAr bArI bAry bAryy bMry Mr Mry
baAriIRN and buwriIRN↓ and baAriyRapN↓ (As, S, M, K) and buwriyRapN↓ (M, K) and baAriyaMCu↓ and buwriyaMCu↓, (S, M, K,) all arabicized words, from the Persian, (M,) A woven mat, (M, K,) made of reeds; (S;) what is called in Persian buwriyaA: (As, K:) or a rough HaSiyr [or mat]. (Msb in art. brI [to which the words belong accord. to Fei, and the same is asserted to be the case by some others].) [The pl. is bawaAriIRu.] It is said in a trad., kaAna laA yaraI baOosFA biAlSRalaApi EalaI AlbuwriIRi↓ explained as meaning He did not see any harm in praying upon a mat made of reeds. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, (M,) A road; syn. TariyqN: (K, M:) [so, perhaps, in the trad. cited above:] arabicized. (K.)

buwriIRN bwr bwrI bwry wrI
buwriIRN: see baAriIRN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A kind of fish; [a species of mullet, the mugil cephalus of Linnæus, of the roe and milt of which is made what the Italians call botargo, and the Arabs baTaArix, and, accord. to Golius, bwtrgA;] so called from a town in Egypt, named buwrapu, (K,) between Tinnees and Dimyát, of which there are now no remains. (TA.)

baAriyRapN Ory bOryh bAr bAryh bAryp bMryh bMryp Mry
baAriyRapN: see baAriIRN.

buwriyRapN bwry bwryh bwryp
buwriyRapN: see baAriIRN.

baAriyaMCu bAryMC
baAriyaMCu: see baAriIRN.

buwriyaMCu bwryMC
buwriyaMCu: see baAriIRN.

bawaArN bwAr
bawaArN, an inf. n. of 1: see buwrN, last sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] bawaAri, like qaTaAmi, [an indecl. noun,] Perdition: (El-Ahmar, S, M, K:) as in the saying, nazalato bawaAr EalaI AlkufRaAr Perdition fell upon the unbelievers. (El-Ahmar, S, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also baworN.

bawaAriIRN bwAr bwArI bwAry
bawaAriIRN A seller of mats of the kind called baAriIRN &c. (K.)

baAYirN c
baAYirN: see buwrN. ― -b2- You say also rajulN HaAYirN baAYirN, (T, S, M, A, K,) and fiI HuwrK wa buwrK↓, (A,) meaning A man who does not apply himself rightly, (T, S, TA,) or has not applied himself rightly, (K,) to anything; (T, S, K;) erring; losing his way; (T;) who will not do right of his own accord, nor obey one directing him aright: (K:) it may be from the signification of laziness, or sluggishness, and it may be from that of perdition: (M:) [or] bAYr is here an imitative sequent of HAYr. (S.) [Respecting the latter phrase, see also art. Hwr.] ― -b3- See also baworN, in two places.

faHolN mibowarN fHl mbwr
faHolN mibowarN A stallion-camel that knows the state of the female, whether she be pregnant or not. (M, A, K.)

mubiyrN mbyr
mubiyrN A destructive man, acting exorbitantly in destroying others. (TA, from a trad.)

baAzN Oz bOz bAz bAzy
baAzN i. q. baAzK; [see art. bzw;] (S, K;) a dial. var. of the latter; (S;) as also baOozN: (IJ, TA:) dual.

baAzaAni bAz bAzAn
baAzaAni: (K:) pl. [of pauc.] OabowaAzN and [of mult.] biyzaAnN: (S, K:) the dual of baAzK is baAziyaAni; (K;) and the pl. is buzaApN (S, K) and bawaAzK. (K.)

1 baAsahu Os bOsh bAs bAsh bAsp bMsh Ms
1. baAsahu, aor. yabuwsuhu, (S,) inf. n. bawosN, a Persian word, arabicized, (S, A, K,) He kissed him. (S, A, K.) You say also, baAsa lahu AlOaroDa He kissed the ground to him. (A, TA.)

mabuwsN mbws
mabuwsN Kissed: you say, Alyawoma bisaATuka mabuwsN wa gadFA Oanota maHobuwsN [To-day thy carpet is kissed, and to-morrow thou art imprisoned]. (A.)

1 baAXa c
1. baAXa, aor. yabuwXu, inf. n. bawoXN, He mixed, or confounded. (Fr.) See also XaAba, in art. Xwb. ― -b2- He associated with bawoX, meaning, people of the lowest or basest or meanest sort. (IAar.) ― -b3- baAXuwA, (K,) inf. n. as above, (A, K,) They (mixed people, A, K, of the lowest or basest or meanest sort, TA) cried out, or vociferated; or did so calling for aid or succour; or in distress and impatience; or in fear. (A, K.)

2 bwRXwA c
2. bwRXwA, inf. n. tabowiyXN, They became mixed, or confused: (K:) or numerous, and mixed or confused: (TA:) and tbwRXwA↓ signifies the same. (K.)

5 tabawRaXa
5: see 2.

bawoXN c
bawoXN A mixed or confused assembly or company: (A, K:) or an assembly, or a company, of mixed or confused people: (S:) or only of different tribes: or a multitude of men: as also buwXN↓, in these several senses: (K:) and, accord. to the women of Temeem, of beasts also: (Aboo-'Adnán, TA in art. hwX:) or people of the lowest or basest or meanest sort: (IAar:) or a family, or household: (ISd:) and [it is said by F that] it also signifies sons of the same father, when assembled together: (K:) resembling a contr. signification to that mentioned above, which restricts the application to such as are of different tribes: but it is said in the O, that banuw AlAbAC, [app. a mistake for banuw AlOabi, meaning sons of the same father,] when assembled together, are not called by this name: (TA:) OawobaAXN is a pl. of this word, formed by transposition. (S.) You say, jaAWuwA fiI hawoXK wa bawoXK They came in assemblage and multitude. (A.) And jaMCa mina AlnRaAsi AlhawoXu wa AlbawoXu The multitude of the people came: (AZ:) or the assembly and family or household. (ISd.) And tarakotuhumo hawoXFA bawoXFA I left them [in great numbers and] in confusion. (K.) And bawoXN baAYiXN↓, (S, K,) or baAYiXN↓ buwXN↓, (CK,) [app. A numerous, or large, assembly of mixed or confused people.] And jaMCa biAlbawoXi AlbaAYiXi↓ He came with multitude, or the multitude. (TA.)

buwXN c
buwXN: see bawoXN, in three places.

bawoXiIRN c
bawoXiIRN A poor man having a numerous family or household: (S, K:) or having a family or household: (Aboo-Sa'eed:) and one of the baser and common sort of men: as also buwXiIRN↓. (K.)

buwXiIRN c
buwXiIRN: see what next precedes.

baAYiXN c
baAYiXN: see bawoXN, in three places.

1 baAEa bAE
1. baAEa, (S, TA,) aor. yabuwEu, (TA,) inf. n. bawoEN, (S, K, TA,) He extended his arms to their full reach; expl. by basaTa baAEahu; (TA;) and the inf. n. by madRu AlbaAEi; with a thing; as also tbwRE↓. (K.) ― -b2- He (a camel) stretched forth his fore legs to the full (madRa OabowaAEahu); as also tbwRE↓; and in like manner a gazelle: (TA:) and he (a horse) stepped far, or took long steps, in his running; (S, K;) and in like manner one says [baAEat] of a she-camel. (S.) You say, marRa yabuwEu, and yatabawRaEu↓, He went along stretching forth his fore-legs to the full extent of his step. (L.) ― -b3- baAEa biAlmaAli, aor. yabuwEu, (TA,) inf. n. bawoEN, (Lth, K,) He extended his arm, or hand, [liberally, or bountifully,] with the property. (Lth, K, TA.) You say also, buEo buEo, meaning (assumed tropical:) Stretch forth thine arms, or hands, (baA Eayoka,) in acts of obedience to God. (IAar.) And lilomasaAEiI tabawRaEa↓ (tropical:) He stretched forth his arms (madRa baAEahu) [to attain means of honour and elevation]. (TA.) And maA yudoraku tabawRuEuhu↓ (assumed tropical:) The point to which he has reached is not to be attained: (K, TA:) and, as Lh says, laA taboluguwna tabawRuEahu↓ (assumed tropical:) Ye will not, or shall not, reach the point to which he has attained: originally, his length of step. (TA.) ― -b4- UicaA baAEa QnobaAEa↓ When he accomplishes his want, he goes away. (Har p. 592.) ＝ -A2- baAEa AlHabola, (Msb, TA,) first pers. buEotuhu, (S,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, Msb, TA,) He measured the rope by the bAE [or fathom]; (Msb;) he extended his bAE [or arms stretched to the full reach] with the rope; (S;) or he extended the rope with his bAE; or, which is nearly the same in meaning, he extended his arms with the rope until it became a bAE [or fathom in measure]; (TA;) like as you say, Xabarotuhu from AlXRiboru. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] yabuwEu AlOaroDa He traverses the ground with wide step and quick motion. (Ham p. 720.)

5 tabawRaEa
5: see 1, in six places: ― -b2- and see 7.

7 AnbAE OnbAE AnbAE QnbAE
7. AnbAE and tbwRE↓, said of a rope, signify the same [app. It was measured by the bAE, or fathom]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- AnbAEt AlHayRapu The serpent extended itself, after gathering itself together and coiling itself, in order to spring. (Lh, K.) ― -b3- Also AnbAE, said of a man, He leaped, or sprang, after being still: or he made an assault; or leaped, or sprang, and made a violent seizure. (TA.) [Hence,] muxoranobiqN liyanobaAEa Silent in order to leap, or spring, (K, and S in art. xrbq,) when he finds an opportunity; (S in that art.;) on account of a misfortune which he desires [to effect]; (S, K, in that art.;) or in order to make an assault: (TA:) or looking, or waiting, for an opportunity to leap, or spring, upon his enemy, or the object of his want, when able to do so; and in like manner, muxoranoTimN liyanobaAEa: (TA in art. xrbq:) a prov., (K,) applied to a man who is silent respecting a misfortune [which he desires to effect]; (TA;) or applied to a man who is long silent until he thinks his object inadvertent, and who is possessed of cunning: (As, TA in art. xrbq:) accord. to one relation, liyanobaAqa, i. e. to bring about, or effect, a baAYiqap, meaning a calamity, or misfortune: (K:) or lynbAE may be for layonabaE, from nabaEa AlmaMCu. (Har p. 62.) [Hence also,] AnbAE AlXRujaAEu mina AlSRafRi The courageous man went, or came, out, or forth, from the rank. (AAF.) ― -b4- AnbAE liI fiI siloEatihi He treated me in an easy manner in the sale of his commodity, or article of merchandise, and strained himself (AimotadRa) to give his consent to it. (K, TA.) And hence, AinobayaAEN↓, as used by Sakhrel-Ghei in describing the conduct of a man towards a beautiful woman, or, accord. to one relation, AibotiyaAEN↓, The acting, or behaving, towards another, boldly, in a free and easy manner, or without shyness; syn. AinobisaATN; as also bayoEN (TA.) ― -b5- AnbAE also signifies He ran in a gentle manner, with a bending and a twisting of himself; from baAEa, aor. yabuwEu. (Ahmad Ibn-'Obeyd.) ― -b6- And he went away. (Har p. 592: see 1.) ― -b7- And It (sweat) flowed: (Msb, K:) or, as El-Fárábee says, extended. (Msb.) 'Antarah says, describing the sweat of a she-camel,
yanobaAEu mino ciforaI gaDuwbK jasorapK
[Flowing, or extending, from the part behind the ear of a she-camel quickly angered, spirited, or tall, or tall and bulky, or strong, and bold to
endure travel]: ynbAE being originally yanobawiEu; or, as most of the lexicologists say, originally yanobaEu, the A being inserted after the fet-hah of the b to render its sound full. (TA.)

8 AibotiyaAEN AbtyAE QbtyAE
8. AibotiyaAEN: see 7, in the latter half of the paragraph.

baAEN bAE
baAEN A fathom; the space that is between [the extremities of] the two hands when they are extended to the right and left; (Msb;) the measure of the extension of the two arms (S, K, TA) with what is between them of the body; (TA;) as also bawoEN↓ and buwEN↓; (K;) the last of the dial. of Hudheyl: (TA:) said by AHát to be of the masc. gender: (Msb:) pl. OabowaAEN (Msb, K) and biyEaAnN. (Ham p. 475.) ― -b2- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) The body, including the limbs; [because a fathom in height;] as in the phrase rajulN Tawiylu AlbaAEi (assumed tropical:) A man tall in the body; which has also another meaning, to be seen below: but you do not say, qaSiyru AlbaAEi as meaning short in the body. (TA.) ― -b3- [Also The arms; and particularly when extended to their full reach; as also the pl.: and in like manner, the fore legs of a beast: see several examples in the first paragraph of this art.] ― -b4- [And hence, (tropical:) Reach; power; or ability.] You say, huwa qaSiyru AlbaAEi (tropical:) He is lacking in power, or ability: a phrase which has also another meaning, to be seen below. (TA.) And qaSura baAEuhu Eano celika (tropical:) He was unable to attain, or to do, or effect, that: in this case, bwE↓ is not used. (TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) Reach, power, or ability, in the means, or causes, of attaining honour; or in generous, or honourable, qualities or actions: (TA:) (tropical:) eminence; nobility; honour; generosity: (Lth, S, K:) in which senses, bwE↓ is not used. (Lth.) A poet says,
lahu fiI Almajodi saAbiqapN wa baAEu
[He has precedence and eminence in glory, honour, dignity, or nobility]. (Lth.) And rajulN Tawiylu AlbaAEi (tropical:) A man of large generosity. (TA.) And qaSiyru AlbaAEi (tropical:) Niggardly: a phrase which has also another meaning, mentioned above. (TA.)

bawoEN bwE
bawoEN and buwEN: see baAEN, in four places. ＝ -A2- The former also signifies A place that is broken, or crushed, (makaAnN munohaDimu,) in a small ravine (liSob) of a mountain. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

baAEapN bAE bAEh bAEp bAYE
baAEapN The court (saAHap) of a house: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) a dial. var. of baAHapN. (TA.)

bawRaAEN bwAE wAEy
bawRaAEN (assumed tropical:) A large-bodied camel. (TA.)

baAYiEN c
baAYiEN A young gazelle that stretches forth its fore legs to the full (yabuwEu) in going along: (K, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: (TA:) pl. buwEN (K) and bawaAYiEu. (TA.) And OabowaAEu↓, a determinate noun, is applied to The ewe, because she does so in going along: and she is called to be milked thereby; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) by saying, OabowaAEu OabowaAEu. (Ibn-'Abbád.) You say also naAqapN baAYiEapu A she-camel that steps far, or takes long steps: pl. bawaAYiEu. (TA.) And farasN bayRiEN↓, (K,) originally bayowiEN, (TA,) A horse that steps far, or takes long steps. (Z, K.)

bayRiEN byE
bayRiEN: see baAYiEN.

OabowaAEu c
OabowaAEu: see baAYiEN.

munobaAEN mnbAE
munobaAEN Anything that flows; or extends: (Msb:) anything sweating, or exuding sweat. (TA.)

1 baAqa bAq bAqy
1. baAqa, (K,) aor. yabuwqu, inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) He came with, or brought, or effected, evil, or mischief, and altercations. (K.) ― -b2- baAqati AldRaAhiyapu The calamity, misfortune, or disaster, befell, betided, or happened. (Msb.) And baAqatohumu AldRahiyapu, (S,) or AlbaAYiqapu, (JK, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S,) The calamity, misfortune, or disaster, befell them, or smote them; (S, K;) as also Ealayohimo AnbAqt↓: (JK, * K:) and Ealayohimo baAYiqapu XarRK AnbAqt↓ A calamity, &c., burst upon them; syn. Ainofataqato; (S, K; *) like AnbAjt, (S,) from which IF thinks it to be changed: (TA:) and Ealayohimu AldRahoru AnbAq↓ Fortune assaulted them, or assailed them, with calamity, like as the sound issues from the trumpet (Albuwq): (S:) and buqotuhumo [I assaulted them, or assailed them, with a calamity, &c.]. (JK.) And in like manner, one says, baAqatohumo baWuwqN, (S, TA,) inf. n. bawoqN and buWuwqN, A vehement calamity or misfortune or disaster befell them, or smote them. (TA.) ― -b3- Also baAqa, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) He wronged a man; treated him wrongfully, or unjustly: or he came upon a people, or company of men, suddenly, or unawares, without their permission; as also AnbAq↓: (K:) [or,] as some say, baAquwA Ealayohi they slew him: (TA:) and bihi AnbAq↓ he wronged him. (K.) And baAqa bika He (a man, JK) came up, or forth, upon thee, from a low, or depressed, place. (JK, K.) And baAqa bihi He encompassed, or surrounded, him. (JK, K.) And baAqa Alqawomu Ealayohi, (K,) inf. n. bawoqN, (TA,) The people, or company of men, gathered themselves together against him, and slew him wrongfully: (K, * TA:) but some say that it means, as explained before, they slew him. (TA.) And baAqahumo, (Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K,) aor. as above, (JK,) inf. n. bawoqN, (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA,) He stole from them; robbed them. (Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K.)

7 Uinobawaqa
7: see 1, in five places. muxoranobiqN liyanobaAqa, a prov., thus related by some, instead of liyanobaAEa, means Silent in order to bring about, or effect, a baAYiqap, i. e., a calamity, or misfortune: (K in art. bwE, q. v.:) or, to launch forth, and manifest what is in his mind. (TA.) You say also, AnbAq EalayonaA biAlkalaAmi He broke forth upon us with evil speech. (JK.) And AnbAq biAlDRaHika He broke forth with laughter. (JK.) And AnbAqt AlmaTorapu The shower of rain poured forth with vehemence. (TA.) And AnbAq AlmaMCu The water became copious, or much in quantity. (JK.)

bawoqN bwq
bawoqN Abundance of rain; as also buwqN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

buwqN bwq
buwqN [A trumpet;] a certain thing in which one blows; (IDrd, S, Mgh, K;) in which one blows as in a musical pipe: (Kr, K:) [mostly used in war, but] mentioned by a poet, cited by As, as used by the Christians: (S:) IDrd says, The Arabs used this word, but I know not its origin: Esh-Shiháb says, in the 'Ináyeh, that it is arabicized, from [the Persian] buwriI: (TA: [but this is obviously improbable:]) pl. buwqaAtN (Mgh, Msb) and biyqaAnN (Msb [in my copy of the Mgh, erroneously, biyaqaAtN]) [and OabowaAqN, a pl. of pauc., commonly used in the present day]. nafaxa fiI Albuwqi [He blew the trumpet, lit., in the trumpet,] means [also] (tropical:) he spoke that in which was no profit. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) One who does not conceal a secret; (Lth, JK, K;) as also bawoqN↓. (K.) ― -b3- Also A certain thing in which the miller blows; (JK, K;) accord. to the copies of the K, resembling a minoqaAb; but this is a mistake: (TA:) it is a thing resembling a [shell of the kind called] minoqaAb, the hole of which is twisted; and sometimes the miller blows in it, raising his voice; and what he means thereby is known. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also bawoqN.

baAqapN Oqp bOqp bAqh bAqp
baAqapN A bundle of herbs, or leguminous plants. (S, K.) [And in modern Arabic, A bunch of flowers.]

buwqapN bwq bwqh bwqp wqp
buwqapN A shower, fall, or storm, of rain, (JK, S,) that has burst forth with a dash: (S, TA:) or such as is vehement; or disapproved, disliked, or deemed evil: (K:) pl. buwaqN. (JK, K.)

baWuwqN c
baWuwqN, or daAhiyapN baWuwqN, A vehement calamity or misfortune or disaster. (TA.) ― -b2- And the former, applied to a man, Thievish; a great thief. (JK.)

baAYiqapN c
baAYiqapN A calamity, misfortune, or disaster; (JK, S, Msb, K;) a vehement evil or mischief; (Msb;) a trail that befalls a people: (TA:) pl. bawaAYiqN. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., laA yadoxulu AljanRapa mano laA yaOomanu jaArahu bawaAYiqahu, meaning, accord. to Katádeh, [He will not enter Paradise whose neighbour is not secure from] his wrongful, or injurious, conduct: or, accord. to Ks, his malevolent, or mischievous, dispositions, and his evil conduct. (S.) IF says, in the “ Makáyees, ” that bwq is not an accredited root, and that there is not, in his opinion, any correct word belonging to it. (TA.) [But this is a strange assertion.]

1 baAla Ul Al bUl bAl bAly bMl Ml
1. baAla, (T, S, &c.,) aor. yabuwlu, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. bawolN (M, Msb) and mabaAlN, (Msb,) [He urined, discharged his urine, made water, or staled;] said of a man, (M, Msb,) and of a beast, (Msb,) &c. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] baAla bawolFA XariyfFA faAxirFA (tropical:) He (a man) begat offspring resembling him (El-Mufaddal, T, TA) in form and natural dispositions. (El-Mufaddal, TA.) ― -b3- A poet, using the verb metaphorically, says,
baAla suhayolN fiI AlfaDiyxi fafasado
(tropical:) [Canopus made water in the beverage prepared from unripe dates, and it became spoiled, or marred]: (M:) meaning, that when Canopus
rises [aurorally, which it does, in central Arabia, early in August, the making of that beverage is stopped, for] the season of unripe dates has passed, and they have become ripe. (L in art. fDx.) baAla suhayolN is also a prov., said when winter has come. (MF in art. xrt.) [See suhayolN.] ― -b4- bawolN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The having vent, so as to flow forth: (K:) whence bawRaAlN as an epithet applied to a wine-skin: see this word below. (TA.) ― -b5- And baAla (assumed tropical:) It melted, or dissolved: (K:) said of fat. (TA.)

2 bwRl OaSola AlXRajarapi c
2. bwRl OaSola AlXRajarapi (K in art. qzH) [He made water upon the root, or stem, of the tree: or] he put urine at the root of the tree to render its fruit abundant. (TK in that art.)

3 laA OubaAwiluhu c
3. laA OubaAwiluhu, from AlbaAlu, I will not, or I do not, cause him, or it, to move, or occur to, my mind. (Z, TA in art. blw. See laA OubaAliyhi in that art.)

4 AbAl Alxayoli AbAl Alxyl
4. AbAl Alxayoli, and AstbAlhA↓, [He, or it, made, or caused, the horses to stale: or] he stopped the horses for the purpose of [their] staling. (TA.) One says, (in threatening, PS,) lanubiylanRa Alxayola fiI EraSaAtikumo [We will assuredly make the horses to stale in your courts]. (S.) And it is said in a prov., OaHomirapN baAla HimaArN faQsotabaAla↓ An ass staled, and caused some (other) asses to stale: applied to a case in which people help one another to do what is disagreeable. (Meyd.)

10 AstbAl AstbAl QstbAl
10. AstbAl He desired, or required, to make water. (KL.) ― -b2- See also 4, in two places. ― -b3- El-Farezdak says,
wa UinRa AlRaciI yasoEaI liyufosida zawojatiI
kasaAEK UilaI Ousodi AlXRaraI yasotabiyluhaA
meaning [And verily he who strives to corrupt my wife is like one betaking himself to the lions of Esh-Sharà (a certain road abounding with those animals)] to receive their urine in his hand. (S.)

baAlN Ul Al bUl bAl bAly bMl Ml
baAlN A state, condition, or case; syn. HaAlN (T, S, Msb, K) and XaOonN: (T:) or a state, condition, or case, for which one cares; wherefore one says, maA baAlayotu bikacaA, inf. n. baAlapN, meaning “ I cared not for such a thing: ” (TA:) or a thing [or things] for which one cares: (Har p. 94:) and AlbaAlu signifies also baAlu AlnRafosi, i. e. care, or concern; and hence is [said to be] derived baAlayotu, having for its inf. n. baAlapN. (T.) One says, maA baAluka What is thy state, or condition, or case? (S.) [See the Kur xii. 50 and xx. 53: and see an ex. in a verse cited in this Lex. voce Uiyhi.] When it was said to a man, in former times, “ How hast thou entered upon the morning? ” he used to reply, bixayorK OaSolaHa QllRehu baAlakumo [With good fortune: may God make good your state, or condition]. (Ham p. 77.) wa yuSoliHu baAlahumo, in the Kur [xlvii. 6], means And He will make good their state, or condition, in the present world: (I'Ab, T:) or their means of subsistence in the present world, together with their recompense in the world to come. (M.) One says also, huwa raxiIRu AlbaAli He is in ample and easy circumstances (T, Msb) of life; (T;) he is not straitened in circumstances, nor troubled: (T:) or he is in an easy, or a pleasant, state or condition: (TA in art. rxw:) or he is easy, or unstraitened, in mind: (S:) [for] AlbaAlu, (T, M, K,) or raxaMCu AlbaAli, (TA,) signifies ampleness and easiness of life: (T, M, K, TA:) or AlbAl signifies an easy, or unstraitened, state of the mind. (S.) And huwa kaAsifu AlbaAli He is in an evil state or condition: (TA:) or he is straitened in his hope, or expectation: for AlbAl is said to signify hope, or expectation: (T:) so says El-Hawaázinee. (TA.) And layosa hecaA mino baAliI This is not of the things for which I care. (S.) And it is said in a trad., kulRu OamorK ciI baAlK lamo yubodaOo fiyhi biHamodi QllRehi fahuwa Oabotaru, i. e., Every honourable affair, for which one cares, and by which one is rendered solicitous, [in which a beginning is not made by praising God, is cut off from good, or prosperity:] or every affair of importance, or moment. (TA in two places in this art.) ― -b2- Also The heart, or mind; syn. qalobN, (T, S, Msb, K,) and xaladN, (Ham pp. 76 and 77,) and nafosN, (AZ, T,) and xaATirN. (M, K, Kull p. 179.) You say, xaTara bibaAliI, (Msb, Kull ubi suprà,) and EalaI baAliI, (Kull ibid.,) i. e., [It (an affair, or a thing, Kull) occurred to, or bestirred itself in, or moved,] my heart, or mind. (Msb, Kull.) And lamo yaxoTuro bibaAliI celika AlOamoru, i. e., [That affair did not occur to, or] did not move me, or distress me. (T.) And maA yaxoTuru fulaAnN bibaAliI, i. e. [Such a one does not occur to, or move,] my heart, or mind. (S.) ― -b3- [And hence, Mind, or attention. You say, OaEoTiniI baAlaka Give me thy mind, or attention. And] laA OuloqiI Uilayohi baAlFA [I will not, or I do not, give, or pay, any attention to him, or it]. (Z, TA in art. blw.) ＝ -A2- [The whale;] a great fish, (S, K,) of the fish of the baHor [here meaning sea]; (S;) a certain bulky fish, called jamalu AlbaHoru; (M;) it is a fish fifty cubits long: (MF:) [Kzw describes it as being from four hundred to five hundred cubits in length, and says that it sometimes shows the extremity of its fin, like a great sail, and its head also, and blows forth water rising into the air higher than an arrow can be shot: these and other exaggerated particulars he mentions in his account of the Sea of the Zenj: and in a later place he says, that it eats ambergris, and dies in consequence; and a great quantity of oil is procured from its brain, and used for lamps:] the word [in this sense] is not Arabic: (S:) in the O it is said to be arabicized, from [the Persian] waAlo. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The spade (marR [in the CK erroneously written murR]) with which one works in land of seed-produce. (M, K.) ＝ -A4- See also baAlapN, in three places.

bawolN bwl
bawolN, originally an inf. n., (Msb,) [Urine; stale:] pl. OabowaAlN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- OabowaAlu AlbigaAli The seminal fluid of mules. (As, TA.) And hence, as being likened thereto, because it is fruitless, (As, TA,) (assumed tropical:) The saraAb [or mirage: in the CK AlXRarAbu]. (As, K, TA.) It is also applied to the road of El-Yemen, which is not travelled but by mules: see also art. bgl. (TA.) ― -b3- bawolu AlEajuwzi (assumed tropical:) Cow's milk. (TA.) ― -b4- bawolN signifies also (tropical:) Offspring. (M, K, TA.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) A large number. (K, TA.) ― -b6- See also Oabowalu.

baAlapN cAl bcAlh bcAlp
baAlapN A [flask, or bottle, such as is called] qaAruwrap: (M, K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] baAlN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- A [bag such as is called] jiraAb, (T,M, K,) small and large, in which mush is put: (T:) or (M [in the K “ and ”]) the receptacle of perfume: (S, M, K:) a Persian word, (S, M,) arabicized; (S;) in Persian biyolah, (T, S, M,) or baAlah: (M:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] baAlN↓. (T.) ― -b3- It is said to signify also An odour; a smell; (T;) on the authority of Aboo-Sa'eed Ed-Dareer; (TA;) from balawotuhu meaning “ I smelled it, and tried, proved, or tested, it; ” originally balowapN; the w being transposed, and changed into A. (T.) ― -b4- And A staff with a pointed iron at the end, used by the hunters of El-Basrah, who throw it at the game: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] baAlN↓. (T, TA.) ― -b5- And hence it is applied by the vulgar to A small elongated sword. (TA.) ＝ -A2- It is also an inf. n. of baAlaI, which see in its proper art. (TK.)

bawolapN bwl bwlh bwlp wlh
bawolapN The origin (manobit [so in copies of the K accord. to the TA)] or daughter (binot [so in some copies of the K]) of a man; (K;) on the authority of El-Mufaddal. (TA.)

biylapN byl bylh bylp
biylapN a subst. from baAla, (S, M, K,) [meaning A discharging of urine, making water, or staling: or a mode, or manner, thereof; as appears probable from its form, and from J's adding that it is] like jilosapN and rikobapN; (S;) [and also from the following phrase:] UinRahu laHasanu Albiylapi [Verily he is one who has a good mode of discharging his urine]; from Albawolu. (M.)

buwalapN bwl bwlh bwlp wlh
buwalapN That discharges much urine; syn. kaviyru Albawoli; (M, K;) applied to a man; (M;) and so bawRaAlN↓ applied to a camel. (TA.)

bawaAlN bwAl wAly
bawaAlN A disease occasioning much, or frequent, bawol [or discharging of urine]: (M, K:) a disease that attacks sheep, or goats, such that they discharge urine until they die. (Ham p. 77.) You say, Oaxacahu buwaAlN He was taken with much, or frequent, bawol [or discharging of urine]. (S.)

bawRaAlN bwAl wAly
bawRaAlN: see buwalapN. ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A wine-skin from which the wine runs out. (TA.) ― -b3- And XaHomapN bawRaAlapN (assumed tropical:) A piece of fat that quickly melts or dissolves. (IAar, TA.)

Oabowalu mino kalobK c
Oabowalu mino kalobK More frequent in making water than a dog: or it may mean more abundant in offspring. (Meyd. [Freytag adds, in his Arab. Prov. i. 199, on the authority of Sharaf-ed-Deen, that bwl↓ (i. e. bawolN) may signify urine or coitus or offspring.])

mabaAlN mbAl mbAly
mabaAlN [The place of urine, or of the urinary discharge; meaning] the faroj [or pudendum of a man and of a woman]: whence the phrase, mabaAlN, fiI mabaAlK occurring in a trad. (TA,)

mabowalapN mbwlh mbwlp
mabowalapN [A diuretic; a provocative of urine]. You say, kavorapu AlXRaraAbi mabowalapN, (S, K, *) i. e., Much beverage occasions a discharging of urine. (TA.)

mibowalapN mbwlh mbwlp
mibowalapN [A urinal;] a vessel (kuwz) in which one makes water. (S, K,*)

buwmN bwm
buwmN and buwmapN A certain bird; [namely, the owl;] each word applying to the male and the female: (S, K:) or the former signifies the male, or males, (so in different copies of the M,) of the haAm [or owl-kind]; and the latter is its n. un.: (M, TA:) said by Az to be genuine Arabic: (TA:) pl. of the former OabowaAmN. (IB, TA.)

buwmN bawRaAmN bwm bwAm
buwmN bawRaAmN [An owl, or male owls,] that cries, or that cry, much. (TA.)

1 baAnahu Onp bOn bOnh bOnp bAnh bAnp bMnh Mn
1. baAnahu, aor. yabuwnu, (S in art. byn, Msb, K,) inf. n. bawonN, (Msb, TA,) i. q. baAnahu aor. yabiynu, (S ubi suprà K,) inf. n. bayonN, (TA,) meaning He excelled him; (S* ubi suprà, Msb;) he surpassed him in excellence and in manly virtue: so in the Iktitáf. (TA.)

baAnN bOn bAn bAny bMn Mn
baAnN [a coll. gen. n., The ben-tree; a species of moringa; so in the present day;] a kind of tree, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) well known: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Mgh, Msb:) its seed, or grain, [called HabRu AlbaAni and jawozu AlbaAni and fusotuqu AlbaAni, the glans unguentaria, or nux unguentaria, or ben-nut,] has a good, or pleasant, [fragrant] oil, (K,) called duhonu AlbaAni [oil of ben], (S, Mgh, Msb,) and simply baAnN, the prefixed noun being suppressed: (Mgh:) [Az says,] it is the pl. of baAnapN. which is a certain tree having a fruit, or produce, which is perfumed with aromatics, after which its oil is expressed, of a good [or fragrant] quality: (T in art. bnI: its seed, or grain, is good for [removing] the [affections of the skin termed] baraX and namaX and kalaf and HaSaf and bahaq and saEafap and the mange, or scab, and for the peeling of the skin, applied in the form of a liniment with vinegar; and for hardness of the liver and the spleen, made into a beverage with vinegar; and a mivoqaAl thereof, drunk, is an emetic, which loosens crude phlegm: (K:) AHn says, (TA,) it is a kind of tree that grows tall, in a straight, or an erect, manner, like as grows the [species of tamarisk called] Oavol, and its leaves are [of the kind termed] hadab, like those of the Avl, but its wood has no hardness: the n. un. is with P: Aboo-Ziyád says, it is of the [trees called] EiDaAh, and has long hdb, intensely green; it grows upon [hills, or what are termed] haDob; and its fruit resembles the pods of the [species of kidney-bean called] luwbiyaMC, except that its greenness is intense; and in it is a seed, or grain, from which is extracted the oil of the bAn: on account of the straightness of its growth and of the growth of its braches, and their length and tenderness, the poets liken thereto the tender girl of tall and beautiful, or just, stature; saying kaOanRahaA baAnapN [As though she were a ben-tree], and kaOanRahaA guSonu baAnK [As though she were a branch of the ben-tree], &c.: thus does Keys Ibn-El-Kha- teem: (M in art. byn:) and so does Imra-el- Keys. (TA.) [See an ex. voce barahorahapN.] ― -b2- [It is also applied in the present day to A species of willow, the salix Aegyptia of Linnæus, properly called in Arabic xilaAf: and this is said to be meant by modern Arab poets when they liken an elegant girl to a twig of the bAn; but probably from their erroneously supposing this tree to be meant in the same case by the older poets.]

bawonN bwn wn
bawonN Excellence: an excellent quality; (S in art. byn, Msb;) as also bawonapN↓: (IAar; T:) or the distance, space, or interval, between tow things; as also buwnN↓. (M, K.) You say, bayonahumaA bawonN baEiydN (T, S, Msb*) and bayonN baEiydN (T, S) [Between them two (meaning two men) is a wide distance]; i. e. between their tow degrees of rank or dignity, or between the estimations in which they are commonly held: (Msb:) the former phrase is the more chaste: (S:) when corporeal distance is meant, one says, bayonahumaA bayonN, with I; (Msb;) or in the case of [literal] distance, one says, UinRa bayonahumaA labayonFA; not otherwise. (S.)

buwnN bwn wn
buwnN: see bawonN.

bawonapN bwn bwnh bwnp wn
bawonapN: see bawonN ― -b2- Also Mutual separation. (IAar, T.)

1 baAhahaA bAhhA
1. baAhahaA, (JK, K,) [aor. yabuwhu,] inf. n. bawohN, (TA,) He lay with her; syn. jaAmaEahaA; (K;) like baAkahaA. (JK.) ＝ -A2- baAha lahu, aor. yabuwhu, (JK, K,) inf. n. bawohN; (K;) as also baAha lahu, aor. yabaAhu, (JK,* K,) inf. n. bayohN; (K;) His attention became roused to it; (K;) he knew it, or understood it; or knew, or had knowledge, of it; was cognizant of it: (JK, TA:) like baOaha, and Oabaha or Oabiha. (TA.) And maA buhotu lahu; as also maA bihotu lahu; I did not know it, or understand it; or did not know,or had not knowledge, of it; was not cognizant of it: (JK, S,- K:) the inf. n. of the former is bawohN; and that of the latter, bayohN. (TA.)

baAhN bAh bAp
baAhN a dial. var. of baMCapN (IAar, S) and of baMCN, (IAar, TA,) signifying Coitus: (S K:*) and marriage: (K, * TA:) as also baAhapN↓: (TA:) or a share of coitus; (JK, TA;) occurring in this sense in a trad., in which a woman is mentioned as having adorned herself for it: (TA:) also venereal passion: (TA in art. xfX:) [or the venereal faculty; as when one says of a drug or some other thing, yaziydu fiI AlbaAhi It increases the venereal faculty:] IKt says, of this word, baAhN, [though it is of very frequent occurrence,] that it is a mistranscription [app. meaning for baMCN]. (Msb and TA in art. bwO.) [See also baMCapN.]

baAhapN bAhh bAhp bMhp Mhp
baAhapN: see baACN. ＝ -A2- Also The court of a house; or a spacious part, or portion, of a house, in which is no building; (JK, K, TA;) where people alight, or lodge: (JK:) a dial. var. of baAHapN. (TA.)

baAhiIRN bAhI bAhy
baAhiIRN That strengthens the venereal [faculty or] appetite. (TA in art. jzr, &c.)

2 bayRayotu AlXRaIoCa c
2. bayRayotu AlXRaIoCa, (T, K,) inf. n. taboyiIRN, (K,) I made the thing apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous. (As, T, K*) ＝ -A2- Also, (K, as in the TA,) or AlXRaICa, ↓,tabRayayotu (M, and so in several copies of the K,) [both confirmed by what follows,] i. q. taEamRadotuhu [meaning I directed myself, or my course, or aim, to, or towards, the thing; made for it, or towards it; made it my object; &c.]. (M, K.) ― -b2- In the saying, HayRaAka QllRehu wa bayRaAka, the phrase HyAk AllRh means May God make thee to have dominion: (S, M:) or may God prolong thy life: (M:) and byRAk means AiEotamadaka biAltRaHiyRapi [may He bring thee prolongation of life; lit. may He direct himself to thee, or the like, with the gift of prolongation of life]; (As, S;) or qaSadaka biAltRaHiyRapi [which is the same]: (IAar, T:) or AiEotamadaka biAlomuloki [may He bring thee dominion]; (M;) so too says IAar: (TA:) or may He make thy state, or condition, to be good: (TA:) or may He make thee to laugh: (T, S, M, K:) so some say, accord. to As: (T:) and it is related that these words were addressed to Adam, in consequence of his having remained a hundred years without laughing after his son had been slain: (T, S:) so says A'Obeyd, on the authority of Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr: (T:) or it means may He bring thee near [unto Himself]: (Aboo-Málik, As, T, M, K:) or may He bring thee: (IAar, S, M:) or may He prepare for thee an abode; i. q. bawRaOaka, (K,) or bawRaOaka manozilFA; the verb being here altered in order to assimilate it to the preceding verb, HayRaA: (El-Ahmar, T, S:) this explanation was approved by As: (S:) the meaning intended thereby is, may He lodge thee in an abode in Paradise: (TA:) or, as some say, the verb in this case is an imitative sequent to that preceding it: (A'Obeyd, S K: *) but this is naught: (K:) A'Obeyd says that in his opinion it is not an imitative sequent, because an imitative sequent is scarcely ever coupled with what precedes it by w. (S.) As an ex. of bayRaA in the sense of qarRaba, Aboo-Málik cites this verse:
Aalokiboda waAlmaloHaMCa wa AlsRanaAmaA
bayRaA lahumo Uico nazaluwA AlTRaEaAmaA
[He brought near to them, i. e., placed before them, when they alighted, the food, namely, the liver, and the flesh of the back extending from the withers to the rump, and the hump]. (T.) And IAar, explaining byRAk as meaning qSdk bAltHyRp, cites the following verse:
OaEoTaI EaTaMCa AllRaHizi AllRaYiymi
OabaA tamiymi lamRaA tabRayayonaA↓
(T.) Accord. to J, the meaning in this instances may be agreeable with the explanation of byRAk by AEtmdk bAltHyRp [so that the verse may be rendered When we betook ourselves with salutation to the father of Temeem, or, as the verse is cited in the S, to the brother of Temeem (OaxaA tmym), he gave the gift of the niggardly, the mean]: or it may mean we brought: and the verb admits of the same double rendering in other instances. (TA.) ＝ -A3- bayRayotu baMCF HasanapF and HasanFA [I made, or wrote, a beautiful b]. (TA in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp.)

5 tbyRA tbyA
5. tbyRA It was, or became, apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous, being near; syn. tabayRana mino qurobK. (As, T.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places.

AlbaIRN OlbI Olby AlbI Alby by lbI
AlbaIRN The low, ignoble, mean, or contemptible, man; as also Aibonu bayRaAna↓, (IAar, T, K) and Abn hayRaAna, (IAar, T,) and Abn baIR, (K,) or haIRu bonu baIR, and hayRaAnu bonu bayRaAna↓: (Lth, T:) or the last two signify he whose stock and branch are unknown: (M:) or the same two, he who is unknown, and whose father also is unknown: (K in art. hI; and so the latter of them is explained in the S, both there and in the present art.:) and one says, maA OadoriI OaIRu haIRi boni baIRK huwa, meaning I know not what man he is.. (S.) Accord. to some, (Lth, T,) haIRu bonu baIRK was one of the sons of Adam, that went away in the earth when the rest of his children dispersed themselves, and no trace of him was afterwards perceived. (Lth, T, K.)

Aibonu bayRaAna Abn byAn
Aibonu bayRaAna: see AlbaIRu, in two places.

bayawiIRN bywI bywy
bayawiIRN rel. n. of baMCN or baA: whence qaSiydapN bayawiyRapN [as also baAYiyRapN and baAwiyRapN] A qSydp of which the rawiIR is b. (M in art. b.)

Albiyabo Albyb byAnw
Albiyabo see OabN, in art. Abw.

1 baAta bAt bMt Mty
1. baAta, (T, S M, &c.,) aor. yabiytu and yabaAtu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. bayotuwtapN (Lth, T, S A, Msb, K) and mabiytN (Msb, K) and mabaAtN (Msb) and bayotN and bayaAtN, (K,) has two meanings: in that which more commonly obtains, the action is restricted to the night: (Msb:) it is by night, or in night; not in sleep: (M:) you say, baAta yafoEalu kacaA, meaning He did such a thing by night, or at night: (S, Msb, K:) [or he was in the night, or at night, or during the night, doing such a thing: and he passed, or spent, the night, or a night, or a part thereof, or, as will be seen below, he entered upon the night, doing such a thing:] like as one says, ZalRa yafoEalu kacaA as meaning “ he did such a thing by day, ” or “ at day-time: ” (S, Msb;*) IKoot and Es-Sarakustee and IKtt say that it has this meaning, and not “ he slept: ” (Msb:) [F adds,] wa layosa mina AlnRawomi, (K,) which is said to mean, “ and the action is not one of sleep; ” so that when one sleeps by night, or at night, it is not correct to say, baAta yanaAmu: or, accord. to some, “ its meaning is not that of sleeping; ” so that one may say, baAta zayodN naAYimFA [Zeyd was in the night, &c., or passed, or spent, the night, &c., sleeping]: (MF:) [Fei says,] it is only when one remains awake in the night: and hence the saying in the Kur [xxv. 65], waQlRaciyna yabiytuwna lirRabihimo sujRadFA waqiyAmFA [And those who pass the night prostrating themselves to their Lord and standing up in prayer]: (Msb:) Fr says that baAta AlrRajulu means The man remained awake all the night, engaged in acts of obedience or of disobedience: (T, Msb:) [or it means the man entered upon the night; or he was in the night, or at night, or during the night, in any state, or engaged in any action; for] Zj says, (M,) baAta is said of any one whom the night has overtaken, (M, K, *) whether he have slept or not slept: (M:) and Lth says, Albayotuwtapu signifies the entering upon the night: one says, bitRu OaSonaEu kacaA wa kacaA [I entered upon the night doing such and such things]: and he adds, (T,) he who says baAta as meaning he slept commits an error; for you say, bitRu OuraAEiI AlnRujuwma [I entered upon, or passed, the night] looking at the stars: and how can he be sleeping who is looking at them? (T, Msb:) but Mullà 'Abd-El-Hakeem, in his Commentaries on the Mutowwal, says that baAta sometimes means he remained, continued, stayed, or dwelt, and he alighted and abode, by night, or at night, whether he slept or not: (MF:) and Ibn-Keysán says that it may be used in the same manner as naAma [he slept]; and also, [as will be explained below,] in the same manner as kaAna. (TA.) You say, baAta bayotuwtapF SaAliHapF (T) or TayRibapF (A) [He passed, or entered upon, the night, or a night, in a good manner]. And bitRu Alqawoma and bitRu bihimo and bitRu Einodahumo [I passed, or entered upon, the night, or a night, with, or at the abode of, the people, or company of men: the last of these phrases is the most common]. (A 'Obeyd, M, K.) ― -b2- Secondly, it is used in the sense of SaAra [He became]; (Msb;) or in the same manner as kaAna [he was]. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) One says, baAta bimawoDiEi kacaA He became [or was] in such a place; whether in night-time or in day-time. (Msb.) And hence the saying of the lawyers, baAta Einoda QmoraOatihi layolapF He became [or was] with his wife one night; [which is the same as he passed a night &c.; though this, it will be observed, is not in this instance the signification of the verb alone;] whether sleeping or not. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Thus it is used both as a “ complete, ” i. e. an attributive, verb, and also as an “ incomplete, ” i. e. a non-attributive, verb.] ― -b4- baAta, aor. yabiytu, (T, A,) inf. n. bayotN, (T, M, K,) also signifies (tropical:) He married, or took a wife: (T, A:) [see bayotN below:] or (assumed tropical:) he gave in marriage; syn. of the inf. n. tazowiyjN. (Kr, M, K.)

2 byRt Albayota byt Albyt
2. byRt Albayota He constructed, or built, the bayot [i. e. tent, or house, &c.]. (M.) ＝ -A2- byRt AlOamori, [inf. n. as below,] He did, or performed, the thing, or affair, by night, or at night: (M:) and he thought, or meditated, upon it, considering its end, or issue, or result, (Zj, T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) or entered into it, (Zj, T,) by night, or at night. (Zj, T, S, M, &c.) And one says, buyRita bilayolK, (T, A,) meaning the same as dubRira bilayoli [It was thought, or meditated, upon, &c., by night, or at night]: (T:) [for] buyRita AlXRaIoCu also signifies [simply] the thing was thought upon, and considered as to its end, issue, or result; syn. qudRira. (S.) Accord. to El-Marzookee, they say of a thing that is not done deliberately, and with good consideration of its issue or result, hecaA OamorN qudRira bilayolK; [in the text from which this is taken, without the syll. signs;] and hence the saying in the Kur [iv. 83], bayRata TaAYifapN minohumo gayori QlRaciI taquwlu [A part of them meditateth by night upon doing otherwise than that which thou sayest; as is indicated in the M, where this is cited; and in like manner, yubayRituwna, in the continuation of the same passage of the Kur, is explained in the T as meaning yudabRiruwna, and yuqadRiruwna, (i. e. mina AlsRuwoCi,) layolFA]: but Aboo-Hilál says that a thing is meditated upon in the night in order that one may apply himself to it with strong purpose, and not be diverted by other things, so that it may be done with more firmness; and he cites the same passage of the Kur. (Ham p. 130.) And hence, in the Kur [iv. 108], Uico yubayRituwna maA laA yaroDaI mina Alqawoli When they meditate, &c., (S, M, Bd, Jel,) by night, (S, M,) [what He will not approve, of speech,] and prepare it [in their minds] (yuzawRiruwnahu [see art. zwr]). (Bd.) It is said in a trad., laA SiyaAma limano lamo yubayRiti AlSRiyaAma There is no fasting to him [meaning his fasting is null] who does not purpose it from the night. (TA. [See another reading, voce batRa.]) And you say, bayRata AlnRiyRapa He decided upon the purpose, or intention, by night, or in night-time. (Msb.) And bayRata raOoyahu He thought upon his opinion, and concealed it, or conceived it, in his mind. (TA.) ― -b2- bayRatahumo, (inf. n. taboyiytN, (Msb, TA,) He came upon them, (Mgh, but the verb is there pl.,) or made a sudden attack upon them, and engaged with them in conflict, (Msb,) or made a great slaughter among them, or engaged with them in vehement conflict, (S, M, K,) namely, the enemy, (S, Mgh, K,) or a people, (M,) by night: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K:) he came upon them (the sons of such a one) in the night, and made a sudden attack upon them, while they were heedless: (T:) he attacked them (the people of a house or place of abode) by night: he went to them (the enemy) in the night, without their knowledge, and took them by surprise. (TA.) ― -b3- kaAna laA yubayRitu maA lAFA walaA yuqayRiluhu He used not to retain property until night, nor to retain it until noon, when it came to him; but used to hasten the dividing of it. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b4- See also 4. ＝ -A3- byRt AlnRaxola He trimmed, or pruned, the palm-trees, by cutting off the stumps of the branches, or by cutting off the straggling branches, not in the best part thereof. (K.) ＝ -A4- See also 5.

4 AbAthu ObAt ObAth AbAth AbAtp Mby
4. AbAthu, inf. n. UibaAtapN, He (God) made him, or caused him, to pass, or spend, the night, [or a part thereof,] or to enter upon the night. (T, M, K.) You say, OabaAtaka QllRehu HasanapF [May God make thee to pass, or enter upon, the night with happiness], (S,) and UibaAtapF HasanapF [in a good manner of doing so]. (T, A.) And [in like manner,] bayRataka↓ QllRehu fiI EaAfiyapK [May God make thee to pass, or enter upon, the night in health and safety]. (A.) And OabaAtahu QllRehu OaHosana biytapK God made him to pass, or enter upon, the night in the best manner of doing so. (M, K. *)

5 tbyRthu Eano HaAjatihi tbyth En HAjth tbyth En HAjtp
5. tbyRthu Eano HaAjatihi [so in the TA and in a MS. copy of the K: in the CK bayRatahu↓:] He withheld,
or debarred, him from the thing that he wanted. (K.)

10 Uisotaboyata
10: [AstbAt seems to signify He asked for, or required, biyt, or biytap i. e. food: (see musotabiytN:) and also to have the contr. signification; i. e. ― -b2- He possessed food: for you say,] laA yasotabiytu layolapF He possesses not a night's food. (T, K.) And laA yasotabiytu He has not food. (A.)

bayotN byt bytt
bayotN [signifies A tent; properly, having more than one pole; but often applied without this restriction: and also a house; a chamber; an apartment; a closet; and the like]: a bayot is [a tent] of [goats'] hair (XaEar), (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) or of wool: (Mgh:) a byt of hair [i. e. hair-cloth] is that kind [of tent] which has more than one pole: the word is masc.: and applies to small and large: (M:) tents of goats' hair are peculiar to people of cold countries and of fertile regions, where the goats have abundant hair; for the goats of the Arabs of the desert have short hair, not long enough to be spun: (T in art. bnI:) a xibaMC is a small byt of wool or of hair: a byt is what is larger than a xbMC: next is the miZalRap, which is larger than the byt; but the term byt is also applied to a mZlRp when it is large and murawRaq [i. e. furnished with a riwaAq, q. v.]: (T:) Ibn-El-Kelbee says that the Arabs have six kinds of byt; namely, a qubRap, which is of skins, or tanned hides; a miZalRap, of hair; a xibaMC, of wool; a bijaAd, of soft hair (wabar); a xayomap, of trees; an Ouqonap, of stone; and a sawoT, of hair; or this is the smallest of them: El-Baghdádee says that the xbAC is a byt made of soft hair (wabar), or of wool, or of hair [commonly so called] (XaEar), upon two poles, or three; and that a byt is [a tent] upon six poles, or more, to the number of nine: in the Towsheeh it is said that the term xbAC is applied to a byt of any kind: (TA:) a byt is also [a structure] of clay, or tough or cohesive clay or earth; (A, K;) [and of baked bricks; and of stone;] the name being likewise applied to a structure of a kind other than the structures which are called Oaxobiyap [or tents]; (M;) signifying a habitation [of any kind; an abode; a dwelling]: (Msb:) a man's house; syn. daArN: (T:) [and particularly a chamber; i. e.] a single roofed structure (Mgh, Kull) having a place of entrance; manozilN being applied to what comprises more than one [such] byt, and a roofed SaHon [or vacant part, and a kitchen, inhabited by a man with his family]; and daArN, that which comprises more than one [such] byt and more than one [such] manozil and a [court, or] SaHon without a roof: (Kull:) the pl. is buyuwtN, (S, M, K, &c.,) also pronounced biyuwtN, (TA,) and OaboyaAtN, (S, M, K,) the latter a pl. of pauc.; (TA;) and pl. pl. buyuwtaAtN (M, Mgh, K) and OabaAyiytu (Sb, S, M, K) and OaboyaAwaAtN, (Fr, M, K,) which last is extr.: (M:) the dim. is buyayotN↓, also pronounced biyayotN↓; (S, K;) and the vulgar say, buwayotN, (S,) which is not allowable. (K.) You say, huwa jaAriI bayota bayota, (T, S, M,) He is my neighbour [tent to tent, or house to house, i. e.,] by contiguity [of our habitations]: byt byt being made indecl. with fet-h for the termination because they are two nouns made one: (S:) Sb says that some of the Arabs make them [thus] indecl., like xamosapa EaXara, and some make the former a prefixed noun governing the latter in the gen. case, [saying bayota bayotK,] except when used as a denotative of state: (M:) one says also, bayotFA libayotK, and bayotN libayotK; (Fr, T;) which last, or bayotN UilaI bayotK, is the original form. (Har p. 353.) banaI fulaAnN EalaI QmoraOatihi [lit. Such a one constructed a tent over his wife,] means such a one had his wife conducted to him on the occasion of his marriage, and brought her, or had her brought, into a pitched tent, having conveyed thither the utensils and furniture and other things that they required. (T.) And Oaholu bayotu AlnRabiIRi [The people of the house of the Prophet,] means the Prophet's wives and his daughter and 'Alee: and so Oahola Qlobayoti [i. e. yaxuSRu Oahola Albayoti He means particularly, or peculiarly, the people of the house], in the Kur xxxiii. 33: banuw and maEoXar and Oahol and Ml, as prefixed nouns, being, as Sb says, the nouns most frequently occurring in the accus. case [for the reason indicated above, or, as the Arabian grammarians express it,] EalaI AlAixotiSaASi. (M.) ― -b2- It also signifies A [pavilion, palace, or mansion, such as is called] qaSor: (T, K:) whence the saying of Gabriel, baXRiro xadiyjapa bibayotK mino qaSabK, i. e. [Rejoice thou Khadeejeh by the announcement of] a pavilion (qSr) of hollow pearls, (T, TA,) or of emerald. (TA. [See also art. qSb.]) buyuwtFA gayora masokuwnapK [Uninhabited houses], in the Kur xxiv. 29, means buildings for the reception of travellers, or for merchants and their goods, and the shops of the merchants and places in which things are sold, the entering of which is allowed by their owners: or ruins which a man enters for the purpose of easing nature. (M.) And the buyuwt which God has permitted to be raised, mentioned in the same chapter, verse 36, are Mosques, or places of worship: or, accord. to El-Hasan, Jerusalem (bayotu Almaqodisi); the pl. being applied to it as a mark of honour. (Zj, M.) Albayotu [The House] applies particularly to (tropical:) the Kaabeh [of Mekkeh]; (K;) as also bayotu QllRehi [the House of God]; (AAF, M;) and Albayotu AlHaraAmu [the Sacred House]; (T;) and Albayotu AlEatiyqu [the Ancient House]; (S and K &c. in art. Etq;) and accord. to some, Albayotu AlmaEomuwru, q. v. (Bd in lii. 4.) [bayotu AlmaAli signifies The treasury of the state. And bayotu AlmaMCi is a euphemism for The privy; because water is put there for the purpose of ablution: also called bayotu AlfaraAgi, &c.] ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The ark of Noah: so in the Kur lxxi. last verse. (T.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A grave; (M, IAth, K;) app. by way of comparison. (M.) So in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr: kayofa taSonaEu UicaA maAta AlnRaAsu HatRaI yakuwnu Albayotu biAlwaSiyfi, meaning How will thou do when men shall die so that the grave shall be sold for the [servant-] boy? (IAth.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The habitation of the surofap, which it constructs in a beautiful manner, (A'Obeyd, M,) of fragments of sticks; (Yaakoob, M;) and of the SayodanaAniIR, which it makes in the interior of the earth, and covers over: (A'Obeyd, M:) and (assumed tropical:) the burrow, or hole, of the DabR &c.: and (assumed tropical:) the web of the spider: all, app., as being likened to the bayot of a man. (M.) ― -b6- (tropical:) A man's household. (S, K, TA.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The wife (As, IAar, T, M, A) of a man. (M, A.) So in the saying,
OakibarN gayRaraniI Omo bayotu
[Hath old age altered me, or a wife?]: (As, T:) or here it means a household. (S.) ― -b8- The nobility of the Arabs; (T, Msb, K; *) as when one says, bayotu tamiymK fiI baniI HanoZalapa [The nobility of Temeem is in the sons of Handhaleh]: (T, Msb: *) or the family that comprises the nobility of a tribe; as Mlu HiSonK of the fazaAriyRuwn, and Mlu AljudRayoni of the XayobaAniyRuwn, and Mlu Eabodi AlmadaAni of the HaAriviyRuwn; which three were asserted by Ibn-El-Kelbee to be the highest of the families thus called of the Arabs: (M:) [see a verse of El-Lahabee cited voce OaxoDaru:] pl. buyuwtN and buyuwtaAtN, (T, M,) the latter being pl. of the former. (T.) You say, huwa mino Oaholi AlbuyuwtaAti He is of the people of nobility: and mino bayotK kariymK [of a generous, or noble, house, or family]. (A.) [See also banaI.] ― -b9- A noble person: (M, Mgh, K:) pl. buyuwtN and buyuwtaAtN. (Mgh.) You say, fulaAnN bayotu qawomihi Such a one is the noble person of his people. (Abu-l-'Omeythil El-Aarabee, M.) ― -b10- (tropical:) The [furniture termed] faroX, (A, Mgh, K,) or mataAE, (TA,) of a tent or house, (Mgh, K,) or that is sufficient for a tent or house. (A.) You say, tazawRajotu fulaAnapa EalaI bayotK (tropical:) I married, or took as a wife, such a woman for [my giving] furniture sufficient for a tent or house, (A,) or furniture of a house or tent. (Mgh.) [See 1, last sentence.] ― -b11- A bayot of poetry, (T, S, M, Msb,) or of the poet, (K,) is (tropical:) [A verse; i. e.] what consists of certain known divisions [or feet] called OajozaMCu AltRafoEiyli; being termed byt metaphorically, because of the conjoining of its component parts, one to another, in a particular manner, like as those of a tent are conjoined in its construction; (Msb;) because it consists of words collected together in a regular manner, and so resembles a tent, which is composed of a saqof and kifaMC and riwaAq and Eumud: (T:) it is derived from the same word signifying a xibaMC [or tent], and applies to the small and the great, as the rajaz and the Tawiyl; and is [said to be] thus called because it comprises words like as the tent comprises its inhabitants; wherefore its component parts are termed OasobaAb and OawotaAd, as being likened to the AsbAb and AwtAd of tents: (M:) pl. OaboyaAtN and buyuwtN, (M, A, Msb,) the latter mentioned by Sb and IJ, (M,) [but rare,] and [pl. pl.] OabaAyiytu: (A:) Abu-l-Hasan says that if the byt of poetry be likened to the byt which is a tent or other kind of structure, there is no reason why it should not have the same pl. forms as the latter has. (L.) By the following words of a poet,
wabayotK EalaI Zahori AlmaTiIRi banayotuhu
biOasomara maXoquwqi AlxayaAXiymi yaroEufu
[Many a byt upon the back of the camel have I
constructed with a lawny thing slit in the nose and bleeding], is meant, many a byt of poetry have I written with the reed-pen. (S.) [Albayota, written after a quotation of a part of a verse of poetry, means AiqoraOi Albayota Read thou the verse.] bayotu AlqaSiydapi [The chief verse of the poem] is a phrase employed when a person composes a poem in praise of any one from whom he would obtain some object of desire and want, being applied to that verse of the poem in which the author's want is mentioned: and is a proverbial expression relating to that which is extraordinary and strange, and used in denoting the superiority of a part of a thing over the whole of it [regarded as a whole]: [hence,] one says, fulaAnN OawRalu Aljariydapi wabayotu AlqaSiydapi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one is the first of the detachment of horsemen, and the chief verse of the poem]. (Har p. 441.)

biytN byt bytt
biytN: see biytapN, in two places.

biytapN byt byth bytp bytth
biytapN a subst. from baAta: and signifying A manner or mode, and state, or condition, of passing, or entering upon, the night. (M.) [See 4; last sentence.] ＝ -A2- Food, or victuals; and so biytN↓: (A, K:) [or particularly, of a night: for] you say, layolapK maA lahu biytu↓, (S M, A, K.) and biytapN layolapK, (T, S, M, A,) mina Alquwti, (T,) He has not a night's food, or victuals. (T, S, M, A, K.)

bayaAtN byAt
bayaAtN A coming upon the enemy by night; (Mgh;) a sudden attack upon, and conflict with, the enemy by night; (Msb;) a great slaughter (S, M) among the enemy, (S,) or a people, (M,) and vehement conflict with them; (S, M;) a coming upon people in the night, and making a sudden attack upon them, while they are heedless; (T;) an attack upon a people by night; a going to the enemy in the night, without their knowledge, and taking them by surprise: (TA:) a subst. from 2; (S, M, Mgh, Msb;) like salaAmN from salRama. (Mgh.) ― -b2- OataAhumu AlOamoru bayaAtFA The thing, or event, happened, or came, to them in the latter part of the night. (T.)

buyayotN byyt
buyayotN, also pronounced biyayotN, dim. of bayotN, q. v. (S, K.)

bayRuwtN byt bywt
bayRuwtN That has remained throughout a night [and so become stale; stale from being a night old]; as also baAYitN↓: both, in this sense, [but the latter more usually,] applied to bread. (S, K.) ― -b2- Cold, or cool, water, (M, K,) that has become so from its having remained throughout a night: (M:) or water that remains during the night beneath the sky: (Ham p. 553:) or water that has been cooled in the leathern bag by night; and in like manner, milk; for [Az says,] I heard an Arab of the desert say, AisoqiniI mino bayRuwti AlsRiqaMCi, meaning Give thou me to drink of the milk that has been milked at night and left in the skin so that it has become cold, or cool, by night. (T.) In the saying,
faSabRaHato HawDa qirFI bayRuwtaA
the meaning seems to be, qiraI HawoDK bayRuwtaA, i. e., [And they (app. camels) came in the morning to] the collected water of a trough, which water had remained throughout the night and so become cold, or cool; the phrase being inverted. (M.) ― -b3- OamorN bayRuwtN (assumed tropical:) An affair, or event, for which, or on account of which, one passes the night in anxiety or grief. (S, K.) ― -b4- hamRN bayRuwtN (assumed tropical:) Anxiety, or grief, that has remained during the night in the bosom. (M.) ― -b5- sinRN bayRuwtapN A tooth that does not fall out, or become shed. (K.)

baAYitN c
baAYitN [Passing, or spending, the night, or a night, or a part thereof; or entering upon the night; &c.;] act. part. n. of 1. (Msb.) ― -b2- See also bayRuwtN.

mabiytN mbyt
mabiytN A place in which one passes, or enters upon, the night. (M, A.)

mutabayRitapN mtbyth mtbytp
mutabayRitapN A woman who has obtained a bayot [i. e. tent or house, or the furniture thereof,] and a husband. (M, K.)

musotabiytN mstbyt
musotabiytN Poor, or needy; [as though meaning asking for, or requiring, biyt or biytap, i. e. food; or possessing food, and nothing beside;] syn. faqiyrN [q. v.]. (IAar, T, K.)

bayoHaAnN byHAn
bayoHaAnN and bayRaHaAnN: see baWuwHN, in art. bwH.

1 baAda Ud bUd bAd bAdy
1. baAda, aor. yabiydu, inf. n. bayodN (T, S, M, &c.) and buyuwdN (S, M, L, Msb, K) and bayaAdN (M, L, Msb, K) and bayoduwdapN (Lh, M, L, K) and bawaAdN (L, K) and bawodN, (CK,) the last but one disapproved by MF, (TA,) [and the last equally doubtful,] He, or it, perished; (T, S, A, Mgh, L, Msb;) went away; passed away; became cut off, or extinct; came to an end. (M, L, K.) ― -b2- baAdati AlXRamosu, inf. n. buyuwdN, The sun set. (Sb, M, K.)

4 OabaAdahumo c
4. OabaAdahumo He (God) destroyed them; (T, S, A, Mgh, * Msb;) caused them to go away, pass away, become cut off or extinct, or come to an end. (M. *)

bayoda byd yd
bayoda, (T, S, M, L, Mughnee, K,) as also baAyada↓, (L, K,) or baAYida, (so in the Mughnee and in a MS. copy of the K and in the CK, and in a MS. copy of the K omitted,) a noun inseparably prefixed to OanRa with its complement, (Mughnee,) used as syn. with gayor, (Ks, T, S, M, &c.,) but never otherwise than in the accus. case, nor as an epithet, nor otherwise than as an exceptive in a case in which the thing excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made. (Mughnee.) You say, huwa kaviyru AlmaAli bayoda OanRahu baxiylN He is possessed of abundant, or much, wealth, but he is niggardly. (ISk, S, M, A, Msb, Mughnee.) ― -b2- Also as syn. with EalaI, (M, K,) as some say; (A'Obeyd, M;) but to render it in the former manner is preferable. (M.) Accord. to some, (L,) it is syn. with EalaI in the following trad.: naHonu AlMxiruwna AlsRaAbiquwna yawoma AlqyaAmapi bayoda OanRahumo Ouwtuw AlkitaAba mino qabolinaA wa OuwtiynaAhu mino baEodihimo [We, the latter people, shall be those who will precede on the day of resurrection, although they were given the Scripture before us, and we were given it after them]: (T, L:) El-Umawee holds it to be so: (T:) but Ks says that it here signifies gayor [as in the former ex.]: (T, L: [and so says IHsh in the Mughnee:]) accord. to one recital, it is bAyad; (L;) or baAYida; so in the Musnad of the Imám Esh-Sháfi'ee: (Mughnee:) IAth says, I have not found this in the classical language in the sense of EalaI: some say that it is biOayodK, i. e. by means of strength, or power; and that the meaning is, we shall be those who will precede to Paradise on the day of resurrection by means of strength, or power, given us by God. (L.) ― -b3- Also, [accord. to some,] as meaning mino Oajoli: (L, Mughnee, K:) as in the saying of Mohammad, OanaA OafoSaHu AlEarabi bayoda OanRiI mino qurayoXK wanaXaOotu fiI baniI saEodK [I am the most chaste in speech of the Arabs because I am of the tribe of Kureysh and I grew up among the children of Saad]: (T, L: [in the Mughnee given somewhat differently:]) but Ibn-Málik and others say that it here, also, means gyr, after the manner in which the latter is used in the saying [of a poet],
walaA Eayoba fiyhimo gayora OanRa suyuwfahumo
bihinRa fuluwlN mino qiraAEi AlkataAYibi
[And there is no blemish in them, save that their swords have in them notches from the conflicting of the troops]. (Mughnee.) This manner of praising is termed by Abu-l-'Abbás Mohammad Ibn-Yezeed AisotivobaAtN. (Ham p. 474.) ― -b4- mayoda is also a dial. var. of the same. (A'Obeyd, T, Mughnee.)

bayodaMCu bydMC
bayodaMCu A desert; or a waterless desert: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or one that is plain, or level, in which horses are made to run: (M:) or one wherein is nothing: (TA:) so called, accord. to IJ, because it [often] destroys him who alights, or sojourns, in it: (M, Msb: *) or a plain tract, slightly elevated, with few trees, and without herbage, extending to the distance of a day's journey, or half a day's journey, or less, rugged and hard, and only in a country of mould, or clay: (ISh:) pl. biyodN: (S, M, Msb, K:) it has a pl. of a form proper to epithets because it is originally an epithet: (M:) by rule it should be bayodaAwaAtN. (M, K.)

bayodaAnapN bydAnh bydAnp
bayodaAnapN A she-ass; a subst. applied to that animal: (S:) or a wild she-ass: (M, K:) or one that inhabits a desert (bayodaMC); (T, K;) [an epithet;] not a subst. applied to the animal; J being in error in asserting it to be such: (K:) the [wild] she-ass is thus called, accord. to most of the lexicologists, because it inhabits the bydAC; and if so, the n is an augmentative letter: or, accord. to some, because it is large in the body (Albadan); and if so, the n is a radical letter: (L:) the pl. is bayodaAnaAtN. (L, K.)

baAyada bOyd bAyd yd
baAyada, or baAYida: see bayoda.

biyorN byr
biyorN; pl. of pauc. OaboyaArN: see biYorN, in art. bOr.

waqaEa fiI HaASi baASi wqE fy HAS bAS
waqaEa fiI HaASi baASi, and HayoSa bayoSa, &c.: see art. HyS

bayoSN byS
bayoSN Difficulty; straitness; (IAar, K;) as also biySN↓. (K.) See above.

biySN byS
biySN: see above.

1 baADahu bAD bADh bADp
1. baADahu, (S, K,) first pers. biDotu, (M,) aor. yabiyDu, for which one should not say yabuwDu, [though it would be agreeable with a general rule respecting verbs denoting surpassingness,] (S, O,) He surpassed him in whiteness. (S, M, O, K.) ＝ -A2- baADato, (S, M, Msb, K, except that in the M and Msb we find the masc. form, baADa, followed by AlTRaAYiru,) aor. tabiyDu, (Msb,) inf. n. bayoDN, (M, Msb,) said of an ostrich, (M,) or a hen, (K,) or any bird, (S, M, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) She laid her eggs, (M, Msb, TA,) or egg. (Msb.) ― -b2- baADa AlsRaHaAbu (tropical:) The clouds rained. (IAar, O, K.) A poet says, [using a phrase from which this application of the verb probably originated,]
baADa AlnRaEaAmu bihi fanafRara Oaholahu
UilRaA Almuqiyma EalaI AldRawaI AlmutaOafRini
(IAar,) i. e. (tropical:) The nEAm, meaning the naEaAYim, [or Twentieth Mansion of the Moon,] sent down rain upon it, and so put to flight its occupants, except him who remained incurring the risk of dying from disease, wasting away: [the last word being in the gen. case, by poetic license, because the next before it is in that case; like xaribK in the phrase hecaA juHoru DabRK xaribK:] the poet is describing a valley rained upon and in consequence producing herbage; for the rain of the asterism called AlnEAYm is in the hot season, [when that asterism sets aurorally, (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl,)] whereupon there grows, at the roots of the HaliIR, a plant called naXor, which is poisonous, killing beasts that eat of it: the verse is explained as above by El-Mohellebee: (IB:) or, as IAar says, the poet means rain that falls at the nawoC [by which we are here to understand the setting aurorally] of AlnEAYm; and that when this rain falls, the wise flees and the stupid remains. (O.) ― -b3- baADa biAlmakaAni (tropical:) He remained, stayed, or abode, in the place [like as a bird does in the place where she lays her eggs]. (O, K.) ― -b4- baADati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The earth produced kamoOap [or truffles, which are thus likened to eggs]: (A, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) the earth produced the plants that it contained: or (assumed tropical:) it became changed in its greenness to yellowness, and scattered the fruit, or produce, and dried up. (M, TA.) ― -b5- baADa AlHarRu (tropical:) The heat became vehement, or intense. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A3- baADa Alqawoma; &c.: see 8, in three places.

2 byRD byD
2. byRD, (S, M, K,) inf. n. taboyiDN, (S,) He whitened a thing; made it white; (S, M;) contr. of sawRada. (K.) He bleached clothes. (M.) [He whitewashed a wall &c. He tinned a copper vessel or the like.] You say, bayRaDa QllRehu wajohahu [lit., God whitened his face: or may God whiten his face: meaning (tropical:) God rendered his face expressive of joy, or cheerfulness; or rejoiced, or cheered, him: or may God &c.: and also God cleared his character; or manifested his honesty, or the like: or may God &c.: see the contr. sawRada]. (TA.) And byRD lahu [He left a blank space for it; namely, a word or sentence or the like: probably post-classical]. (TA in art. Xms; &c.) ― -b2- [He wrote out fairly, after having made a first rough draught: in this sense, also, opposed to sawRada: probably post-classical.] ― -b3- (tropical:) He filled a vessel: (M, A, K: *) or he filled a vessel, and a skin, with water and milk. (S, O.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He emptied (A, K) a vessel: (A:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (K.)

3 bAyDhu 4
3. bAyDhu, (S, M,) inf. n. mubaAyaDapN, (TA,) He contended with him for superiority in whiteness. (S, M.) ― -b2- baAyaDaniI fulaAnN (tropical:) Such a one acted openly with me; syn. jaAharaniI: from AlnRahaAri bayaADu↓ [the whiteness of day, or daylight]. (A, TA.)

4 OaboyaDato c and OabaADato
4. OaboyaDato OabaADato She (a woman) brought forth white children: and in like manner one says of a man [OaboyaDa and OabaADa, meaning He begat white children]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also 9, in two places.

8 AbtAD OyD bOyDh bAyDh bAyDp
8. AbtAD He (a man, S) put upon himself a bayoDap [or helmet] (S, K, TA) of iron. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AbtADhumo He entered into their bayoDap [or territory, &c.]: (A, TA:) and AbtADwA Alqawoma They exterminated the people, or company of men; they extirpated them; (M, K; *) as also baADuwhumo↓: (M:) and AubotiyDuwA [originally AubotuyiDuwA; in the CK, incorrectly, AbtayaDuwA;] They were exterminated, or extirpated, (K, TA,) and their bayoDap [or quarter, &c.,] was given up to be plundered: (TA:) and AibotaDonaAhumo We smote their byDp [or collective body, &c.,] and took all that belonged to them by force; as also biDonaAhumo↓: and biyDa↓ AlHaIRu The tribe was so smitten &c. (TA.)

9 AbyDR ObyD AbyD bAD byD QbyD
9. AbyDR, (S, M, Msb, K,) and, by poetic license, AiboyaDaDRa, [of which see an ex. voce xafaDa, and see also 9 in art. Hw,] (M, TA,) inf. n. AiboyiDaADN, (S, Msb,) It was, or became, white; (S, M, Msb;) contr. of AisowadRa; (K;) as also AbyADR↓, inf. n. AiboyiyDaADN;. (S;) contr. of AisowaAdRa; (K;) and OabaADa↓: which ↓last also signifies it (herbage or pasture) became white, and dried up. (M, TA.) [You say also, AbyDR wajohuhu, lit., His face became white: meaning (tropical:) his face became expressive of joy, or cheerfulness; or he became joyful, or cheerful: and also his character became cleared; or his honesty, or the like, became manifested: see 2.]

11 UiboyaAoDRa
11: see 9.

bayoDN byD
bayoDN: see bayoDapN, in three places.

bayoDapN byD byDh byDp
bayoDapN An egg (Msb) of an ostrich, (Mgh,) and of any bird, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the like, i. e. of anything that is termed SamuwxN [or having merely an ear-hole] as distinguished from such as is termed OacuwnN [or having an ear that is called OucunN]: so called because of its whiteness: (TA:) n. un. of bayoDN↓: (S, M, * Msb, K:) pl. [of the former] bayoDaAtN (M, Sgh, K) and bayaDaAtN, which latter is irreg., (M, Sgh,) and only used by poetic license; (Sgh;) and (of bayoDN, M) buyuwDN. (M, K.) You say, Oaforaxati AlbayoDapu The egg had in it a young bird. (ISh.) And Oaforaxa bayoDapu Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) What was hidden, of the affair, or case, of the people, or company of men, became apparent. (ISh.) [See also art. frx.] bayoDapu Albaladi signifies The egg which the ostrich abandons. (S, M, K.) And hence the saying, huwa OacalRu mino bayoDapi Albaladi (tropical:) He is more abject, or vile, than the egg of the ostrich which it abandons (S, A, * K) in the desert. (TA.) You say also, huwa bayoDapu Albaladi in dispraise and in praise. (IAar, Aboo-Bekr, M.) When said in dispraise, it means (tropical:) He is like the egg of the ostrich from which the young bird has come forth, and which the male ostrich has cast away, so that men and camels tread upon it: (IAar, M:) or he is alone, without any to aid him; like the egg from which the male ostrich has arisen, and which he has abandoned as useless: (TA:) or he is an obscure man, or one of no reputation, whose lineage is unknown. (Ham p. 250.) And when said in praise, it means (tropical:) He is like the ostrich's egg in which is the young bird; because the male ostrich in that case protects it: (IAar, M:) or he is unequalled in nobility; like the egg that is left alone: (M:) or he is a lord, or chief: (IAar, M:) or he is the unequalled of the balad [or country or the like], to whom others resort, and whose words they accept: (K:) or he is a celebrated, or wellknown, person. (Ham p. 250.) [See also art. bld. And for another meaning of bayoDapu Albaladi see below.] ― -b2- (tropical:) A helmet of iron, (AO, S, * M, * Mgh, * K, *) which is composed of plates like the bones of the skull, the edges whereof are joined together by nails; and sometimes of one piece: (AO:) so called because resembling in shape the egg of an ostrich: (AO, M, Mgh: *) in this sense, also, n. un. of bayoDN↓. (S, K: [in the CK, for wAlHadiydu we should read wAlHadiydi.]) This may be meant in a trad. in which it is said that a man's hand is to be cut off for his stealing a bayoDap. (Mgh.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A testicle: (S, K:) pl. biyDaAnN. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The bulb of the saffron-plant [&c.]: as resembling an egg in shape. (Mgh.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) [A tuber: for the same reason.] ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A kind of grape of Et-Táïf, white and large. (M.) ― -b7- (tropical:) The core of a boil: as resembling an egg. (M.) ― -b8- (tropical:) The fat of a camel's hump: for the same reason. (M.) ― -b9- bayoDapu Albaladi, in addition to its meanings mentioned above, also signifies (assumed tropical:) The white truffle: (O, K:) or simply truffles; syn. AlkamoOapu; (TA;) or these are called AlOaroDi bayoDu↓. (A.) ― -b10- bayoDapN also signifies (tropical:) The continent, or container, or receptacle, (Hawozap,) of anything. (S, K, TA.) And [hence] bayoDapu AlUisolaAmi (tropical:) The place [or territory] which comprises El-Islám [meaning the Muslims]; like as the egg comprises the young bird: (Mgh:) or this signifies the congregation, or collective body, of the Muslims. (AZ, M.) And bayoDapu Alqawomi
