(tropical:) The quarter, tract, region, or district, of the people, or company of men: (S, K:) the heart; or midst, or main part, of the abode thereof: (S, TA:) the principal place of abode (OaSol) thereof; (M, TA;) the place that comprises them; the place of their government, or regal dominion; and the seat of their dEwp [i. e. diEowap or kindred and brotherhood]: (TA:) the midst of them: (M:) or, as some say, their [kinsfolk such as are termed] EaXiyrap: (TA:) but when you say, OataAhumu AlEaduwRu fiI bayoDatihimo, the meaning is [the enemy came to them in] their principal place of abode (OaSol), and the place where they were congregated. (TA.) And bayoDapu AldRaAri (tropical:) The midst of the country or place of abode or the like: (AZ, M, TA:) the main part thereof. (TA.) And bayoDapu Almuloki i. q. Hawozatuhu (assumed tropical:) [The seat of regal power: or the heart, or principal part, of the kingdom]. (S and K in art. Hwz.) ― -b11- bayoDapu Alxidori (M, A, K) (tropical:) The damsel (M, K) of the xdr [or curtain &c.]: (K: [in the CK, jaAriyatuhaA is erroneously put for jaAriyatuhu:]) because she is kept concealed within it. (TA.) You say also, hiIa mino bayoDaAti AlHijaAli (tropical:) [She is of the damsels of the curtained bridal canopies]. (A, TA.) bayoDapN is used by a metonymy to signify (tropical:) A woman, by way of likening her thereto [i. e. to an egg] in colour, and in respect of her being protected as beneath the wing. (B.) [See Kur xxxvii. 47.] ― -b12- bayoDapN also signifies (assumed tropical:) White land, in which is no herbage; opposed to sawodapN: (TA:) and biyDapN↓, with kesr, white, smooth land; (K;) thus accord. to IAar, with kesr to the b: (Sh:) and OaroDN bayoDaMCu↓ signifies smooth land, in which is no herbage; as though herbage blackened land: or untrodden land: as also bayoDapN. (M.) ― -b13- bayoDapu AlnRahaAri The whiteness of day; [daylight;] i. q. bayaADuhu↓; (K;) i. e. its light. (Har p. 222.) You say, Oatayotuhu fiI bayoDapi AlnRahaAri I came to him in the whiteness of day. (TA.) ― -b14- bayoDapu AlHirRi (assumed tropical:) The vehemence, or intenseness, of heat. (M.) And bayoDapu AlqayoZi (tropical:) The most vehement, or intense, heat of summer, or of the hottest period of summer, from the [auroral] rising of AldRabaraAn to that of suhayol; [i. e., reckoning for the commencement of the era of the Flight, in central Arabia, from about the 26th of May to about the 4th of August, O. S.;] (A, * TA;) as also AlqayoZi bayoDaMCu↓. (A, TA.) And bayoDapu AlSRayofi (assumed tropical:) The main part of the Syf [or summer]: (M, TA:) or the vehement, or intense, heat thereof. (Ham p. 250.)

bayDapN byD byDh byDp
bayDapN: see bayoDapN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

bayaADN byAD
bayaADN Whiteness; contr. of sawaAdN; in an animal, and in a plant, and in other things; and, accord. to IAar, in water also; (M;) the colour of that which is termed OaboyaDu: (S, Msb, * K:) they said bayaADN and bayaADapN↓, (S, M, K,) like as they said manozilN and manozilapN: (S:) bayaADapN being applied to a whiteness in the eye. (M.) You say, hecaA OaXadRu bayaADFA mino kacaA [This is whiter than such a thing]: (S, K: *) but not OaboyaDu mnohu↓: (S:) the latter is anomalous; (K;) [like Oasowadu minohu; q. v.;] but it was said by the people of El-Koofeh, (S, K,) who adduced as authority the saying of the rájiz,
jaAriyapN fiI diroEihaA AlfaDofaADi
OaboyaDu mino Ouxoti baniI UibaADi
[A damsel in her ample shift, whiter than the sister of the tribe of Benoo-Ibád]: Mbr, however, says that an anomalous verse is no evidence against a rule commonly approved: and as to the saying of another,
UicaA AlrRijaAlu XatawoA waQXotadRa Oakoluhumu
faOanota OaboyaDuhumo sirobaAla TabRaAxi
[When men experience dearth in winter, and their eating becomes vehement, thou art the whitest of them, or rather the white of them, in respect of cook's clothing, having little or nothing to do with entertaining them], the word in question may be considered as an epithet of the measure OafoEalu that is followed by mino to denote excess: but it is only like the instances in the sayings huwa OaHosanuhumo wajohFA and Oakoramuhumo OabFA, meaning Hasanuhumo wajohFA and kariyimuhumo OabFA; so it is as though he said faOanota muboyaDRuhumo sirobaAlFA; and as he has prefixed it to a complement which it governs in the gen. case, what follows is in the accus. case as a specificative. (S.) This latter verse is by Tarafeh, who satirizes therein 'Amr Ibn-Hind; and is also differently related in respect of the first hemistich, and the first word of the second. (L, TA.) ― -b2- bayaADu AlnRahaAri: see 3; and see bayoDapN, near the end of the paragraph. ― -b3- bayaADN is also used elliptically for cuw bayaADK; and thus means (assumed tropical:) White clothing; as in the saying, fulaAnN yalobasu AlsRawaAda waAlbayaADa Such a one wears black and white clothing. (Mgh.) [Hence, also, it has other significations, here following.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Milk. (K.) See an ex., voce sawaAdN. ― -b5- [(assumed tropical:) The white of an egg.] ― -b6- bayaADu AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) That part of land wherein is no cultivation nor population and the like. (M.) ― -b7- bayaADu Aljilodi (assumed tropical:) That part of the skin upon which is no hair. (M.) ― -b8- (tropical:) bayaADN also signifies (tropical:) A man's person; like sawaAdN; syn. XaxoSN; as in the saying, laA yuzaAyilu sawaAdiI bayaADaka (tropical:) My person will not separate itself from thy person. (As, A, TA.)

bayuwDN bywD
bayuwDN A hen that lays many eggs; (S, M, A, * K; *) as also bayRaADapN↓: (M:) [but in the Msb it is evidently used as signifying simply oviparous:] pl. (of the former, S, M *) buyuDN (S, M, A, K) and biyDN, (S, M, K,) the latter in the dial. of those who say rusolN for rusulN, the b being with kesr in order that the I may remain unchanged; (S, M;) but sometimes they said buwDN. (M.)

bayaADapN byAD byADh byADp
bayaADapN: see bayaADN.

baAYiDN c
baAYiDN A hen, (Az, K,) or bird, (S, Msb,) and the like, (Msb,) laying an egg or eggs: (Az, S, * Msb, K: *) without p because the cock does not lay eggs: (Az, TA:) or it is applied also to a cock, (M, TA,) and to a crow, (M, A, TA,) [as meaning begetting an egg or eggs,] in like manner as one uses the word waAlidN. (M, TA.)

bayRaADN byAD
bayRaADN A bleacher of clothes; as a kind of rel. n.; not as a verbal epithet; for were it this, it would be mubayRiDN. (M.) ― -b2- A seller of eggs. (M.) ― -b3- bayRaADapN: see bayuwDN.

OaboyaDu c
OaboyaDu White; contr. of Oasowadu; (A, K;) having whiteness: (Msb:) fem. bayoDaMCu: (Msb:) pl. biyDN, originally buyoDN, (S, Msb, K,) the damm being converted into kesr in order that the I may remain unchanged, (S, K,) [i. e.] to suit the I. (Msb.) In the phrase OaEoTiniI OaboyaDRaho, mentioned by Sb, as used by some of the Arabs, meaning OaboyaDa, [i. e. Give thou to me a white one,] h is subjoined as it is in hunRaho for hunRa, and the D is doubled because the letter of declinability cannot have h subjoined to it; wherefore the letter of declinability is the first D, and the second is the augmentative, and for this reason it has subjoined to it the h whereof the purpose is to render plainly perceivable the vowel [which is necessarily added after the doubled D]: Aboo-'Alee says, [app. of the h,] that it should properly have neither fet-h nor any vowel. (M.) ― -b2- Applied to a man &c., it was sometimes used to signify White in complexion: but in this sense they generally used the epithet OaHomaru. (IAth, TA in art. Hmr.) They also said, fulaAnN OaboyaDu Alwajohi and fulaAnapu bayoDaMCu Alwajohi, meaning Such a man, and such a woman, is clear, in face, from freckles or the like, and unseemly blackness. (Az, TA.) And they used biyDaAnN, (S, K,) a pl. of OaboyaDu, (TA,) in the contr. of the sense of suwdaAnN, (S, K,) [i. e. as signifying Whites,] applied to men: (S:) though they applied the appellation Oabuw AlbayoDaMCi to the Abyssinian: (TA in art. Ewr:) or to the negro: and Oabuw Aljawoni to the white man. (ISk.) But accord. to Th, OaboyaDu applied to a man signifies only (tropical:) Pure; free from faults: (IAth, TA in art. Hmr:) or, so applied, unsullied in honour, nobility, or estimation; (Az, K;) free from faults; and generous: and so bayoDaMCu applied to a woman. (Az.) [In the lexicons, however, (see, for ex., among countless other instances, an explanation of baDRapN in the S,) and in other post-classical works, it is generally used, when thus applied, in its proper sense, of White; or fair in complexion.] ― -b3- katiybapN bayoDaMCu An army, or a portion thereof, upon which the whiteness of the [arms or armour of] iron is apparent. (M.) ― -b4- And bayoDaMCu alone, [as a subst.,] A piece of paper [without writing]. (Har p. 311.) ― -b5- AlOaboyaDu The sword: (S, A, K:) because of its whiteness: (TA:) pl. biyDN. (S.) ― -b6- Silver: (A, K:) because of its whiteness: like as gold is called AlOaHomaru [because of its redness]. (TA.) ― -b7- The saliva (rDAb) of the mouth. (Ham p. 348.) ― -b8- A certain star in the margin of the milky way. (A, K.) ― -b9- AlbayoDaMCu The sun: because of its whiteness. (M.) ― -b10- Waste, or uncultivated, or uninhabited, land: (K, * TA: [in the CK AljirAbu is erroneously put for AlxaraAbu:]) opposed to AlsRawodaMCu: because dead lands are white; and when planted, become black and green. (TA.) See also bayoDapN, near the end. ― -b11- Wheat: (K:) as also AlsRamoraMCu. (TA.) ― -b12- Fresh [grain of the kind called] sulot. (El-
Khattábee, K.) ― -b13- A certain kind of wood; that which is called AlHawaru: (K in art. Hwr:) because of its whiteness. (TA in that art.) [See HawarN.] ― -b14- The cooking-pot; as also OumRu bayoDaMCa. (AA, K.) ― -b15- The snare with which one catches game. (IAar, K.) ― -b16- AlOaboyaDaAni Milk and water. (ISk, S, M, A, K.) A poet says,
wamaA liIa UilRaA AlOaboyaDayoni XaraAbu
[And I have not any beverage except milk and water]. (ISk, S, M.) ― -b17- Bread and water: (As, M, K:) or wheat and water: (Fr, K:) or fat and milk. (AO, K.) ― -b18- Fat and youthfulness (AZ, IAar, M, A, K.) You say, cahaba OaboyaDaAhu His fat and youthfulness departed. (TA.) ― -b19- maA raOayotuhu muco OaboyaDaAni I have not seen him for, or during, two days: (Ks, M, A, K:) or two months. (Ks, M, K.) ― -b20- OayRaAmu AlbiyDi, (Msb, K,) or simply AlbiyDu, (Mgh,) for OayRaAmu AllRayaAliI AlbiyDi; [The days of the white nights;] i. e. the days of the thirteenth and fourteenth and fifteenth nights of the month; (Mgh, Msb, K;) so called because they are lighted by the moon throughout: (Msb:) or of the twelfth and thirteenth and fourteenth nights: (K:) but this is of weak authority, and extr.: the former is the correct explanation: (MF, TA:) you should not say AlOayRaAmu AlbiyDu: (Ibn-El-Jawá- leekee, IB, K:) yet thus it is in most relations of a trad. in which it occurs; and some argue for it; and the author of the K has himself explained AlOawaADiHu by AlOayRaAmu AlbiyDu. (TA.) ― -b21- sanapN bayoDaMCu (assumed tropical:) A year [of scarcity of herbage,] such as is a mean between that which is termed XahobaMC and that which is termed HamoraMC. (TA in art. Xhb.) ― -b22- kalaAmN OaboyaDu (tropical:) Language expounded or explained. (M.) ― -b23- kalRamotuhu famaA radRa EalaIRa sawodaMCa walaA bayoDaMCa (tropical:) I spoke to him, and he did not return to me a bad word nor a good one. (M.) ― -b24- yadN bayoDaMCu (assumed tropical:) A demonstrating, or demonstrated, argument, plea, allegation, or evidence. (M.) ― -b25- And (assumed tropical:) A favour, or benefit, for which one is not reproached; and which is conferred without its being asked. (M.) [See also yadN.] ― -b26- Almawotu AlOaboyaDu (assumed tropical:) Sudden death; (K, TA;) such as is not preceded by disease which alters the complexion: or, as some say, death without the repentance, and the prayer for forgiveness, and the accomplishment of necessary duties, usual with him who is not taken unawares; from bayRaDa signifying “ he emptied ” a vessel: so says Sgh: opposed to Almawotu AlOaHomaru, which is slaughter. (TA.) ― -b27- bayoDaMCu also signifies (assumed tropical:) A calamity, or misfortune: (Sgh, K:) app. as a term of good omen; like saliymN applied to one who is stung by a scorpion or bitten by a serpent. (TA.) ― -b28- bayoDaMCu AlqayoZi: see bayoDapN, last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- hecaA OaboyaDu mino kacaA; &c.: see bayaADN.

mabiyDN mbyD
mabiyDN A place for laying eggs. (ISd, TA in art. fHS.)

mubiyDapN mbyD mbyDh mbyDp
mubiyDapN A woman who brings forth white children: the contr. is termed musowidapN: (Fr, K:) but muwDiHapN is more commonly used in the former sense. (O.)

muboyaDRapN mbyD mbyDh mbyDp
[muboyaDRapN The fair copy, or transcript, made from a first rough draught; which latter is called musowadRapN: probably post-classical.]

mubayRiDN mbyD
mubayRiDN A man wearing white clothing. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, AlmubayRiDapu A sect of [the class called] the vanawiyRap, (S, K,) the companions of AlmuqanRaE; (S;) so called because they made their clothes white, in contradistinction to the musawRidap, the partisans of the dynasty of the 'Abbásees; (S, K, *) for the distinction of these was black: they dwelt in Kasr 'Omeyr. (TA.) [See also AlHaruwriyRapu.]

1 baAEahu bAE bAEh bAEp bAYE
1. baAEahu, (S, Mgh, &c.,) aor. yabiyEu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. bayoEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and mabiyEN, (S, Msb, K,) which latter is anomalous, (S,) the regular form being mabaAEN, (S, K,) has two contr. significacations: He sold it: and he bought it: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and AbAEhu↓ is a dial. var. of the same: (IKtt, Msb:) [but app. only in the former sense:] or this last signifies he offered it for sale; or exposed it to sale: (S, K:) and AbtAEhu↓, as well as baAEahu, signifies he bought it. (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K.) The primary signification of bayoEN is The exchanging, or exchange, of property; or the making an exchange with property; as in the phrases bayoEN raAbiHN [an exchange of property bringing gain], and bayoEN xaAsirN [an exchange of property occasioning loss]: and this is a proper signification when it relates to real substances: but it is tropically used to signify the making the contract [of sale and purchase]; because this is the means of giving [and obtaining] possession: [though this signification is what is termed HaqiyqapN EurofiyRapN, i. e., a sense so common as to be conventionally regarded as proper:] the phrase SaHRa AlbayoEu, or baTala, and the like, mean Safoqapu AlbayoEi; [i. e. The contract of sale, or purchase, was valid, or was null;] but the prefixed n. being suppressed, and its complement [alone] used for it, and this being masc., the verb is made masc. (Msb.) baAEa [mostly signifies He sold; and] is doubly trans., both by itself and by means of mino prefixed to the second object; (Mgh, Msb;) this prep. being thus used as a corroborative: (Msb:) you say, baAEahu AlXRaIoCa and baAEahu minohu [He sold to him the thing and He sold it to him]: (Mgh:) and biEotu zayodFA AldRaAra and biEotu mino zayodK AldRaAra [I sold to Zeyd the house: (see also an explanation of the phrase AisotabaEotuhu AlXRaIoCa: and see baAEahu mina AlsRuloTaAni: to which might be added countless similar instances; for when bAE signifies he sold, mino is generally prefixed to the noun or pronoun denoting the person to whom the thing is sold:)] and sometimes li is put in the place of mino; so that you say, biEotuka AlXRaIoCa and biEotuhu laka [I sold to thee the thing and I sold it to thee]; the l being redundant [when the verb has this meaning, though not when it has the contr. meaning, as will be seen below]. (Msb.) Of the contr. signification we have an ex. in the saying of ElFarezdak,
UinRa AlXRabaAba laraAbiHN mano baAEahaA
waAlXRayobu layosa libaAYiEiyhi tijaAru
[Verily youthfulness, he who buys it is a gainer; but hoariness, there are no traffickers for its sellers; the part. a. being here from the verb in the former sense]: (S, TA:) and [often in a case in which the verb is followed by l; as] in baAEa lahu AlXRaIoCa He bought for him the thing; (Mgh;) [the l not being redundant when the verb is used in this sense;] and as in the saying of Tarafeh,
wayaOotiyka bAloOaxobaAri mano lamo tabiEo lahu
bataAtFA walamo taDoribo lahu waqota mawoEidi
[And he will bring thee tidings for whom thou hast not bought travelling-provisions, and for whom thou hast not assigned an appointed time for his bringing them]: (TA:) and in the saying, baAEa dunoyaAhu biMxiratihi (tropical:) [He purchased his enjoyments of the present world at the expense of his enjoyments of the world to come]: (Z, TA:) and [in like manner] you say, zayodN AldRaAra AbtAE↓, meaning Zeyd bought the house: and ligayorihi AbtAEhA↓ He bought it for another person. (Msb.) The verb has this signification, also, in the trad., laA yabiEo baEoDukumo EalaI bayoEi Oaxiyhi [One of you shall not buy in opposition to the buying of his brother when an agreement has been manifested but the contract has not been concluded]; (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb; [but in the S and Msb and by IAth, the trad. is related thus; laA yaxoTubi AlrRajulu EalaI xiTobapi Oaxiyhi walaA yabiEo EalaI bayoEi Oaxiyhi; (see art. xTb;)]) as is shown by the relation of Bkh, AlrRajulu EalaI bayoEi Oaxiyhi laA yabotaAEu↓: (Mgh, Msb:) or it may here have the contr. meaning: (IAth:) Az says that the seller and buyer are equal in offence when either of them does thus to another. (TA.) [Similar to this is the saying, laA yasuwmu AlrRajulu EalaI sawomi Oaxiyhi: see art. swm. See also baAEa EalaI bayoEihi below, used in a tropical sense.] You say also, baAEa Ealayohi AlqaADiI, meaning The judge sold against his will; (Mgh;) sold without his consent. (Msb.) ― -b2- The pass. form is biyEa [It was sold: and it was bought]: (S, K:) optionally either [thus] with kesr to the b, or [buyoEa] with damm to the b, (S,) [or rather with a sound between that of damm and that of kesr, which pronunciation is termed UiXomaAmN;] and some say buwEa; (S, K;) changing the I into w: and thus in the cases of kiyla and qiyla and the like: (S:) [but Ibn-Málik requires damm or AXmAm in the passive of a verb of which the medial radical is I, and kesr or AXmAm in the passive of a verb of which the medial radical is w, to prevent the mistaking of an active verb for a passive in such cases as biEotu and sumotu: others, however, only prefer what Ibn-Málik absolutely requires in these cases. (See I'Ak p. 131.)] ― -b3- You say also, baAEahu mina AlsRuloTaAni, [lit. He sold him to the Sultán,] meaning (tropical:) he slandered him, or calumniated him,
to the Sultán. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And baAEa fulaAnN EalaI bayoEihi, [of which the lit. meaning has been shown above,] meaning (tropical:) Such a one superseded him, or occupied his place, in respect of honourable and elevated station or rank, and gained the mastery over him; (K, * TA;) and so HalRa biwaAdiyhi: (TA:) or baAEa fulaAnN EalaI bayoEi fulaAnK means (tropical:) such a one gained the mastery over such a one, and wrested from him that which he sought to obtain from him; and is an old proverb, applied by the Arabs to a man who contends with another, and seeks to obtain a thing from him by superior power or force, when he has succeeded in doing as above explained; and similar to it is the saying XaqRa fulaAnN gubaAra fulaAnK. (El-Mufaddal Ed-Dabbee, TA.) One also says, maA baAEa EalaI bayoEika OaHadN, meaning (assumed tropical:) Not any one has equalled thee. (TA.) ＝ -A2- bayoEN is also used in the sense of AinobisaATN. (TA in art. bwE. [See AinobaAEa in that art.])

3 baAyaEotuhu bAyE bAyEth bAyEtp
3. baAyaEotuhu, (S, Mgh, TA,) inf. n. mubaAyaEapN and biyaAEN, (TA,) is from AlbayoEu; and so is AltRabaAyuEu↓; (S, TA;) this being syn. with AlmubaAyaEapu. (K, TA.) You say, baAyaEaA and tabaAyaEaA↓, meaning They two sold and bought, each with the other: (TK:) and tabaAyaEonaA↓ [We sold and bought, one with another]: (Mgh:) and bAyEhu also signifies He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him. (TA.) [See 1; where a citation from the Msb indicates that this latter is the primary signification accord. to the author of that work.] ― -b2- It is also from AlbayoEapu; and so is AltRabaAyuEu↓: (S, TA: *) AlmubaAyaEapu and AltRabaAyuEu↓ from AlbayoEapu signifying The making a covenant, a compact, an engagement, or the like; as though each of the two parties sold what he had to the other, and gave him his own special property, and his obedience, and all that pertained to his case. (TA.) [Hence,] bAyE AlOamiyra He promised, or swore, allegiance to the prince; making a covenant with him to submit to him the judgment of his own case and of the cases of the Muslims [in general], not to dispute with him in respect of anything thereof, but to obey him in whatever command he might impose upon him, pleasing and displeasing: in doing which, it was usual for the person making this covenant to place his hand in the hand of the prince, in confirmation of the covenant, like as is done by the seller and buyer; wherefore the act was termed bayoEapN, an inf. n. [of un.] of baAEa. (Ibn-Khaldoon, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 256 — 7.) [And hence the phrases, buwyiEa biAlixilaAfapi and buwyiEa lahu biAlxilaAfapi He had the promise, or oath, of allegiance made to him as being Khaleefeh.] You say also, bAyEhu Ealayohi, inf. n. mubaAyaEapN, He made a covenant, a compact, an engagement, or the like, with him, respecting it, or to do it: and tbAyEwA↓ EalaI AlOamori [they made a covenant, &c., respecting, or to do, the thing, or affair]; like as you say OaSofaquwA Ealayohi. (TA.)

4 OaboyaEa
4: see 1, first sentence.

6 tabaAoyaEa
6: see 3, throughout.

7 UinobayaEa
7: AnbAE It was, or became, saleable, or easy of sale; it had an easy, or a ready, sale: (Ibn- 'Abbád, K:) as though quasi-pass. of baAEahu [and therefore primarily signifying it was, or became, sold, or bought]. (TA.)

8 UibotayaEa
8: see 1, in four places.

10 AisotabaEotuhu AlXRaIoCa c
10. AisotabaEotuhu AlXRaIoCa I asked him to sell the thing to me; expl. by saOalotuhu Oano yabiyEahu minRiI; (S, K; *) for instance, Eabodahu [his slave.] (Mgh.)

bayoEN byE
bayoEN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- It also signifies The hire, or hiring, of land. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A thing sold, or bought: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) a subst. in this sense: (Mgh, TA:) pl. buyuwEN: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) which is also used as a pl. of the inf. n., to signify Kinds of selling and buying. (Mgh.) See also biyaAEapN.

bayoEapN byE byEh byEp
bayoEapN [inf. n. of un. of baAEa. ― -b2- Hence,] A striking together of the hands of two contracting parties in token of the ratification of a sale. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And [hence,] The act of mubaAyaEap [or promising, or swearing, allegiance and obedience, as explained above, (see 3,)] and submission, or obedience. (Msb, TA.) Whence, OayomaAnu AlbayoEapi [The oaths of allegiance and obedience]; (Ibn-Khaldoon, in De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., 2nd ed., ii. 257; and Msb;) which the Khaleefehs exacted; (Ibn-Khaldoon;) and which El-Hajjáj appointed, including hard, or difficult, matters, relating to divorce and emancipation and fasting and the like. (Msb.)

biyEapN byE byEh byEp
biyEapN A mode, or manner, of selling or buying. (S, Mgh, K.) Hence, SaAHibu biyEapK [A person occupying himself in any kind of selling or buying]: occurring in a trad. of Ibn-'Omar. (Mgh, TA.) And UinRahu laHasanu AlbiyEapi [Verily he is good in the manner of selling or buying]. (S, Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- [A Christian church;] a place of worship (K) pertaining to the Christians: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) or, as some say, a synagogue of the Jews: (TA:) pl. biyaEN, (K, TA,) or biyoEN. (Msb: [but this I think a mistake: if correct, it is a coll. gen. n.])

bayuwEN byE bywE
bayuwEN: see bayRiEN.

bayaAEapN byAE byAEh byAEp
bayaAEapN An article of merchandise; (Lth, S, K;) as also bayoEN↓ [q. v. suprà]: (Mgh:) pl. of the former biyaAEaAtN. (K.)

bayRiEN byE
bayRiEN: see baAYiEN, in five places. ― -b2- Also A man who sells, or buys, well; and so bayuwEN↓: fem. of the former with p: pl. mase. bayRiEuwna, and pl. fem. bayRiEaAtN; neither the masc. nor the fem. having a broken pl. (TA.)

bayRaAEN byAE
bayRaAEN A man who sells, or buys, much. (TA.)

baAYiEN c
baAYiEN Selling, or a seller: and buying, or a buyer: (Msb, K, * TA:) as also bayRiEN↓: (K:) the former signification is the more obvious when bAYE is used without restriction: (Msb:) and bayRiEN↓ also signifies [accord. to some] a bargainer, or chafferer; (K, TA;) not a seller nor a buyer; but Esh-Sháfi'ee and Az deny that this epithet is applied to a man before he has concluded the contract: (L, TA:) the pl. of bAYE is baAEapN: (ISd, K:) and the pl. of byRE↓ is biyaEaMCu [or rather this is a quasi-pl. n.] and OaboyEaMCu: (K:) and Kr holds that baAEapN is pl. of byRE. (TA.) AlbayRiEaAni↓ signifies The seller and the buyer; (S, Mgh;) and so AlmutabaAyiEaAni↓. (TA.) It is said in a trad., biAlxiyaAri maA AlbayRiEaAni↓ lamo yatafarRaqaA, and in another, AlmutabaAyiEaAni↓, [The seller and the buyer have the option of cancelling the contract as long as they have not separated.] (TA.) ― -b2- AimoraOapN baAYiEN (tropical:) A woman who easily obtains a suitor; or who is much in demand; by reason of her beauty: (K, TA:) as though she sold herself: like naAqapN taAjirapN. (Z, TA.)

mabiyEN mbyE
mabiyEN Sold: and bought: as also maboyuwEN↓: (S, K:) in the latter sense syn. with mubotaAEN↓. (Msb.) Kh says that the letter suppressed in mabiyEN is the w of the measure mafoEuwlN, because it is augmentative: but Akh says that the letter suppressed is the medial radical; for when they made the I quiescent, they transferred its vowel to the letter before it, so that it became madmoomeh, [the word thus being altered to mabuyowEN,] then they changed the dammeh into kesreh because of the I after it, then the I was suppressed, and the w was changed into I, like the w of miyzaAnN, because of the kesreh: accord. to El-Mázinee, each of these sayings is good; but that of Akh is the more agreeable with analogy. (S.)

maboyuwEN mbywE
maboyuwEN: see mabiyEN.

mubotaAEN mbtAE
mubotaAEN: see mabiyEN.

mutabaAyiEN mtbAyE
mutabaAyiEN: see baAYiEN, in two places.

bayoluwnN bylwn
bayoluwnN [Fullers' earth, which is used for scouring cloths, and is sometimes used in the bath, instead of soap;] the yellow [or rather yellowish, or yellowish gray, and sometimes white, or whitish,] earth known by the name of Tafol. (TA, from Esh-Shiháb El-'Ajamee.)

1 baAna bOn bAn bAny bMn Mn
1. baAna, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) [aor. yabiynu,] inf. n. bayonuwnapN and buyuwnN (M, Mgh, K) and bayonN, (M, K,) It (a thing) became separated, severed, disunited, or cut off, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) Eani AlXRaIoCi from the thing. (Mgh.) And baAnato, (M, K,) or baAnato biAlTRalaAqi, (Msb,) She (a wife) became separated by divorce, (M, Msb, K,) Eani AlrRajuli from the man. (M, K.) And baAnatN said of a girl, [She became separated from her parents by marriage;] she married: (ISh, T:) as though she became at a distance from the house of her father. (ISh, TA.) And baAna, (M,) or baAna bimaAlK, aor. yabiynu, (T,) inf. n. buyuwnN (T, M) and bayonN, (M,) He became separated from his father, or mother, or both, by property [which he received from him, or her, or them,] (AZ, T, M,) to be his alone: (AZ, T:) and ElFárisee states, on the authority of AZ, that one]
says also, baAna Eanohu and baAnahu [the former app. meaning he became separated thus from him, i. e., from his father; and the latter being syn. with OabaAnahu, q. v.]. (M.) And baAna AlxaliyTu, inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, [The partner, or copartner, or sharer, &c., became separated from the person, or persons, with whom he had been associated.] (T.) And baAnato yadu AlnRaAqapi Eano janobihaA, inf. n. buyuwnN, [The fore leg of the she-camel became withdrawn, or apart, from her side.] (T.) And baAna, (S, M, Msb,) and baAnuwA, (K,) aor. yabiynu, (S,) inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He separated himself, or it separated itself; (S; [in one copy of which it is said of a thing;]) and they separated themselves: (K:) or it (a tribe, M, Msb) went, journeyed, went away, or departed; and went, removed, retired, or withdrew itself, to a distance, or far away, or far off. (Msb.) ― -b2- baAna, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yabiynu, (T, Msb,) inf. n. bayaAnN; (T, S, Mgh, K;) and AbAn↓, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. UibaAnapN; (T, Msb;) and byRn↓, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. taboyiynN; (S;) and tbyRn↓; and AstbAn↓; (T, S, M, &c.,) all signify the same; (T, M, Msb;) i. e. It (a thing, T, S, M, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Msb) was, or became, [distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and it was, or became, known. (K.) You say, baAna AlHaqRu [The truth became apparent, &c.; or known]; as also AbAn↓. (T.) And
AlSRuboHu liciI Eayonayoni qado bayRana↓
The dawn has become apparent to him who has two eyes: a prov.: (S, M:) applied to a thing that becomes altogether apparent, or manifest. (Har p. 542.) And it is said in the Kur [ii. 257], AlrRuXodu mina AlgaIRi qado tabayRana↓ [The right belief hath become distinguished from error]. (TA.) And the lawyers, correctly, use the phrase, kaSawotK laA minohu HuruwfN yasotabiynu↓ [Like a sound whereof letters are not distinguishable]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- [It seems to be indicated in the TA that baAna, aor. yabiynu, inf. n. bayonN and bayonuwnapN, also signifies It was, or became, united, or connected; thus having two contr. meanings; but I have not found the verb used in this sense, though bayonN signifies both disunion and union.] ＝ -A2- baAnahu, aor. yabiynu, inf. n. bayonN: see baAnahu, aor. yabuwnu, inf. n. bawonN, in art. bwn. ＝ -A3- See also 2, in two places.

2 byRn byn bynn yn
2. byRn, intrans., inf. n. taboyiynN: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- You say also, byRn AlXRajaru The trees, (K,) or the leaves of the trees, (TA,) appeared, when beginning to grow forth. (K, TA.) And byRn Alqaronu (tropical:) The horn came forth. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- byRn binotahu: see 4. ― -b2- byRnhu, (T, Msb, K,) inf. n. taboyiynN (T, S) and tiboyaAnN↓ (T, S, * K *) and taboyaAnN; (K;) the second of which three is an anomalous inf. n., (T, S, K,) for by rule it should be of the measure tafoEaAlN; (T, S;) but taboyaAnN is not known except accord. to the opinion of those who allow the authority of analogy, which opinion is outweighed by the contrary; (TA;) and tiboyaAnN is the only inf. n. of its measure except tiloqaMCN, (T, S,) accord. to the generality of the leading authorities; but some add timovaAlN, as inf. n. of mavRala; and El-Hareeree adds to these two, in the Durrah, tinoDaAlN, as inf. n. of naADalahu; and Esh-Shiháb adds, in the Expos. of the Durrah, tiXoraAbN, as inf. n. of Xariba Alxamora; asserting taXoraAbN also to have been heard, agreeably with analogy; [and to these may be added tabokaMCN and timoXaMCN, and perhaps some other instances of the same kind;] but some disallow tifoEaAlN altogether as the measure of an inf. n., saying that the words transmitted as instances thereof are simple substs. used as inf. ns., like TaEaAmN in the place of UiToEaAmN; (MF, TA;) and Sb says that tiboyaAnN is not an inf. n.; for, where it so, it would be taboyaAnN; but it is, from bayRanotu, like gaArapN from Oagarotu; (M, TA;) [He made it distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] he made it (namely, a thing, T, S, Mgh, or an affair, or a case, Msb) apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous; (S, Msb, K;) as also AbAnhu↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UibaAnapN; (Msb;) and tbyRnhu↓; (S, * Msb, K;) and AstbAnhu↓: (Mgh, Msb, K:) [byRnhu is the most common in this sense: and often signifies he explained it: and he proved it:] and ↓all these verbs signify also he made it known; he notified it: (K:) or Aisotabanotuhu↓ signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (Mgh,) I knew it, or became acquainted with it, [or distinguished it,] (S, Mgh,) clearly, or plainly; (Mgh;) and so tabayRanotuhu↓; (S, * Mgh;) [and bayRanotuhu, as appears from an ex. in what follows, from a verse of En-Nábighah:] binotuhu↓ and Oabanotuhu↓ and Aisotabanotuhu↓ and bayRanotuhu all signify the same as tabayRanotuhu↓ [app. in all the senses of this verb]: (M:) or, of all these verbs, baAna↓ is only intrans.: (Msb:) and Aisotabanotuhu↓ signifies I looked at it, or into it, (namely, a thing,) considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, in order that it might become apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain, to me: (T, TA:) and tbyRnhu↓ he looked at it, or into it, (namely, an affair, or a case,) considered it, examined it, or studied it, repeatedly, or deliberately, in order to know its real state by the external signs thereof. (T.) A poet says,
wamaA xifotu HatRaI bayRana AlXRirobu waAlOacaI
bqaAniYapK OanRiI mina AlHaIRi Oaboyanu↓
[And I feared not until the drinking, or the time of drinking, and molestation, made manifest, or plainly showed, by a deep-red (sun), that I was separated from the tribe: see qaAniYN]. (M.) And it is said in the Kur [xvi. 91], waOanozalonaA Ealayoka AlkitaAba tiboyaAnFA likulRi XaIoCK [And we have sent down to thee the Scripture to make manifest everything]; meaning, we make manifest to thee in the Scripture everything that thou and thy people require [to know] respecting matters of religion. (T.) See also bayaAnN, in the latter half of the paragraph. En-Nábighah says,
UilRaA AlOawaAriIRa mRaA OubayRinuhaA
[Except the places of the confinement of the beasts: with difficulty did I distinguish them]; meaning OatabayRanuhaA↓. (S.) You say also, maA tabayRana↓ yaOotiyhi, meaning He sought, or endeavoured, to see, or discover, what would happen to him, of good and evil. (M in art. bSr.) [See also 5, below.]

sabiyla Almujorimiyna sbyl Almjrmyn
sabiyla Almujorimiyna walitasotabiyna↓, in the Kur [vi. 55], means And that thou mayest the more consider, or examine, repeatedly, in order that it may become manifest to thee, the way of the sinners, O Mohammad: (T:) or that thou mayest seek, or endeavour, to see plainly, or clearly, &c.; syn. walitasotawoDiHa sabiylahumo: (Bd:) but most read, waliyasotabiyna syblu Almjrmyn; the verb in this case being intrans. (T.)

3 bAynhu bAYn bAyn bAynh bAynnh bAynp
3. bAynhu, (K,) inf. n. mubaAyanapN, (S,) He separated himself from him; or left, forsook, or abandoned, him: (S, TA:) or he forsook, or abandoned, him, being forsaken, or abandoned, by him; or cut him off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse, being so cut off by him; or cut him, or ceased to speak to him, being in like manner cut by him. (K.) [And It became separated from it.]

4 AbAn ObAn UbAn AbAn
4. AbAn, intrans., inf. n. UibaAnapN: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- AbAnhu, (inf. n. as above, TA,) He separated it, severed it, disunited it, or cut it off. (M, Msb, K, TA.) You say, Darabahu faOabaAna raOosahu (S, K) He smote him and severed his head, mino jasadihi from his body. (S, TA.) And AbAn AlmaroOapa He (the husband) separated the woman, or wife, by divorce. (Msb.) And AbAn binotahu, and byRnhA↓, (T, K,) inf. n. of the former as above, and of the latter taboyiynN, (TA,) He married, or gave in marriage, his daughter, (T, K,) and she went to her husband: (T:) from bayonN signifying "distance:" as though he removed her to a distance from the house, or tent, of her mother. (TA.) And AbAn Qbonahu bimaAlK, (M,) or AbAnhu OabawaAhu, (T,) He separated from himself his son, (M,) or his two parents separated him from themselves, (T,) by [giving him] property, (T, M,) to be his alone: (T:) mentioned on the authority of AZ. (T, M.) And AbAn AldRalowa Eano TiIRi AlbiYori He drew away the bucket from the casing of the well, lest the latter should lacerate the former. (M.) ― -b2- See also 2, in three places. ― -b3- [Hence, AbAn signifies also He spoke, or wrote, perspicuously, clearly, plainly, or distinctly, as to meaning; or, with eloquence: from bayaAnN, q. v.] And AbAn Ealayohi He spoke perspicuously, clearly, plainly, or distinctly, and gave his testimony, or evidence, or gave decisive information, against him, or respecting it. (TA.) [The verb thus used is for AbAn kalaAmahu, and XahaAdatahu.] One says of a drunken man, maA yubiynu kalaAmFA He does not speak plainly, or distinctly; lit., does not make speech plain, or distinct. (Ks, T in art. bt.) ― -b4- [maA Oaboyanahu How distinct, apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain, is it! See an ex. voce basula. ― -b5- And How perspicuous, or chaste, or eloquent, is he in speech, or writing! how good is his bayaAn!]

5 tbyRn ObAn bAn byn tbyn tbynn
5. tbyRn, intrans.: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- As a trans. verb: see 2, in seven places. ― -b2- [Hence,
AlOamora being understood,] He sought, or sought leisurely or repeatedly, to obtain knowledge [of the thing], until he knew [it]; he examined, scrutinized, or investigated: (Bd in xlix. 6:) he sought, or endeavoured, to make the affair, or case, manifest, and to settle it, or establish it, and was not hasty therein: (Idem in iv. 96:) or he acted, or proceeded, deliberately, or leisurely, in the affair, or case; not hastily: (Ks, TA:) or it has a signification like this: in the Kur ch. iv. v. 96 and ch. xlix. v. 6, some read fatabayRanuwA, and others fatavabRatuwA; and the meanings are nearly the same: AltRabayRunu was said by Mohammad to be from God, and AlEajalapN [i. e. "haste"] from the devil. (T.)

6 tbAynA bAyn tbAyn tbAynA tbAynnA
6. tbAynA They two (namely, two men, and two copartners,) became separated, each from the other: (M, TA:) or they forsook, or abandoned, each other; or cut each other off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; or cut, or ceased to speak to, each other. (K.) And tbAynwA They, having been together, became separated: (Msb:) or they forsook, or abandoned, one another; or cut one another off from friendly or loving communion or intercourse; or cut, or ceased to speak to, one another. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence, They two were dissimilar: and they two (namely, words,) were disparate; whether contraries or not: and they two (namely, numbers,) were incommensurable.]

10 AstbAn AstbAn QstbAn
10. AstbAn, intrans.: see 1. ＝ -A2- As a trans. verb: see 2, in six places.

baAnN bOn bAn bAny bMn Mn
baAnN a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p: see art. bwn.

bayonN byn bynn yn
bayonN has two contr. significations; (T, S, Msb;) one of which is Separation, or disunion [of companions or friends or lovers]. (T, S, M, Msb, K.) Hence, caAtu Albayoni as meaning Enmity, and vehement hatred: and the saying liUiSolaAHi caAti Albayoni, i. e. For the reforming, or amending, of the bad, or corrupt, state subsisting between the people, or company of men; meaning for the allaying of the discord, enmity, rancour, or vehement hatred: (Msb:) [but this has also the contr. meaning, as will be seen below: and it is explained as having a vague import; for it is said that] fiI UiSolaAHi caAti Albayoni means In the reforming, or amending, of the circumstances subsisting between the persons to whom it relates, by frequent attention thereto. (Mgh.) [Hence also,] guraAbu Albayoni [The raven of separation or disunion; i. e., whose appearance, or croak, is ominous of separation: said by some to be] the grAb termed OaboqaEu [i. e. in which is blackness and whiteness; or having whiteness in the breast]; (S, K;) so described by the poet 'Antarah: (S:) or that which is red in the beak and legs; but the black is called AlHaAtimu, because it makes [or shows] separation to be absolutely unavoidable, (Abu-1-Ghowth, S, K,) according to the assertion of the Arabs, i. e., by its croak: (Msb in art. Htm:) [or it is any species of the corvus:] Hamzeh says, in his Proverbs, that this name attaches to the grAb because, when the people of an abode go away to seek after herbage, it alights in the place of their tents, searching the sweepings: (Har p. 308:) but accord. to the Kádee of Granada, Aboo-'Abd-Allah Esh-Shereef, this appellation, so often occurring in poetry, properly signifies camels that transport people from one district, or country, to another; and he cites the following verses:
galiTa AlRaciyna raOayotuhumo bijahaAlapK
yaloHawona kulRuhumu guraAbFA yanoEaqu
maA AlcRanobu UilRaA liloOabaAEiri UinRahaA
mimRaA yuXatRitu jamoEahumo wayuqarRiqu
UinRa AlguraAba biyumonihi tudonuw AlnRawaI
watuXatRitu AlXRamola AljamiyEa AlOayonuqu
[Those have erred whom I have seen, with ignorance, all of them blaming a raven croaking: the fault is not imputable save to the camels; for they are of the things that scatter and disperse their congregation: verily the place that is the object of a journey is brought near by the raven's lucky omen; but the she-camels discompose the united state]: and Ibn-'Abd-Rabbih says,
zaEaqa AlguraAbu faqulotu Oakocabu TaAYirK
Uin lRamo yuSadRiqohu rugaMCu baEiyri
[The raven cried; and I said, A most lying bird, if the grumbling cry of a camel on the occasion of his being laden do not verify it]. (TA in art. grb.) ― -b2- Also Distance, (S, M, Msb, K,) by the space, or interval, between two things. (Msb.) You say, bayona Albaladayoni bayonN Between the two countries, or towns, &c., is a distance, of space, or interval: (Msb:) and bayonahumaA bayonN Between them two is a distance, with I when corporeal distance is meant: (Idem in art. bwn:) or UinRa bayonahumaA labayonN [Verily between them two is a distance], not otherwise, in the case of [literal] distance. (S.) And you say also, bayonahumaA bayonN baEiydN (T in art. bwn, S, M *) and bawonN baEiydN (T in art. bwn, S, M, * Msb * in art. bwn) Between them two [meaning two men] is a [wide] distance; (M;) i. e. between their two degrees of rank or dignity, or between the estimations in which they are commonly held: (Msb in art. bwn:) in this case, the latter is the more chaste. (S.) You also say, [using byn to denote An interval of time,] laqiytuhu buEayodaAti bayonK [I met him after, or a little after, an interval, or intervals,] when you have met him after a while, and then withheld yourself from him, and then come to him. (S, M, K. See also baEodu.]) ＝ -A2- Also Union [of companions or friends or lovers]; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) the contr. of the first of the significations mentioned above in this paragraph. (T, S, Msb.) [Hence caAtu Albayoni as meaning The state of union or concord or friendship or love subsisting between a people or between two parties; this being likewise the contr. of a signification assigned to the same expression above: whence the phrase, UifosaAdu caAti Albayoni (occurring in the S and K in art. Abr, and often elsewhere,) The marring, or disturbance, of the state of union or concord &c.: and] hence the saying, saEaI fulaAnN liUiSolaAHi caAti Albayoni mino EaXiyratihi [Such a one laboured for the improving of the state of union or concord &c. of his kinsfolk; but in this instance, the meaning given in the second sentence of this paragraph seems to be more appropriate]. (Ham p. 569.) ― -b2- caAtu bayonihimo may also be used as meaning The vacant space (saAHap) that is between their houses, or tents. (Ham p. 195.) ＝ -A3- bayon is also an adverbial noun, [as such written bayona,] (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) capable of being used as a noun absolutely: (M, K:) it relates only to that which has space, as a country; or to that which has some number, either two or more, as two men, and a company of men; and denotes [intervention in] the interval between two things, or the middle, or midst, of two things, (Er-Rághib, TA,) or the middle of a collective number: (S:) [thus it signifies Between, and amidst, and among:] its meaning is [therefore] vague, not apparent unless it is prefixed to two or more [words, or to a word signifying two or more], or to what supplies the place of such a complement: (Msb:) it must necessarily be prefixed, and may not be otherwise than in the manners just explained: (Mgh:) [i. e.] it may not be prefixed to any noun but such as denotes more than one, or to a noun that has another conjoined to it by w, (M,) not by any other conjunction, (M, Msb,) acc0ord. to the usage commonly obtaining. (Msb.) You say bayona AlrRajulayoni [Between the two men]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and AlmaAlu bayona Alqawomi [The property is between the company of men]: (M, Msb, Er-Rághib: *) and AlmaAlu bayona zayodK waEamorKw [The property is between Zeyd and 'Amr]: and huwa bayoniI wabayonahu [He, or it, is between me and him]: (M:) and jalasotu bayona Alqawomi I sat in the middle of [or amidst or among] the company of men: (S, K:) and bayonakumaA AlbaEiyra faxucaAhu, with AlbEyr in the accus. case, [See between you two the camel, therefore take him], a saying heard by Ks: (Lin art. End:) and fasada maA bayonahumo [The state subsisting among them became bad, or marred, or disturbed]: (S and K in art. myT:) and bayona AlOayRaAmi (M and K in art. ndr) and fiymaA bayona AlOayRaAmi (S and Msb in that art.) [In, or during, the space of (several) days]: and EawaAnN bayona celika, in the Kur [ii. 63], is an ex. of its being prefixed to a single word supplying the place of more than one; (Mgh, Msb;) the meaning being, Of middle age, between that which has been mentioned; namely, the faAriD and the bikor. (Bd.) Some allow that two words to the former of which bayona is prefixed may be connected by fa, citing as an evidence the phrase used by Imra-el-Keys, bayona AldRaxuwli faHawomali [as though meaning Between Ed-Dakhool and Howmal]: but to this it has been replied that Aldxwl is a name applying to several places; so that the phrase [means amidst Ed-Dakhool &c., and] is similar to the saying, AlmaAlu bayona Alqawomi [mentioned above, or jalasotu bayona Alqawomi, also mentioned above]. (Msb.) [You say also, bayona OaZohurihimo, and bayona Zahorayohimo &c., meaning In the midst of them. (See art. Zhr.) And bayona yadayohi, and bayona yadayohimo, meaning Before him, and before them. bayon is also often used absolutely as a noun: thus it is in the Kur lxxxvi. 7, yaxoruju mino bayoni AlSRulobi waAltRaraAYibi Coming
forth from between, or amidst, the spine and the breast-bones: and in xxxvi. 8 of the same, wajaEalonaA mino bayoni Oayodyhimo sadRFA And we have placed before them (lit. between their hands) a barrier.] It is said in the Kur [vi. 94], laqado taqaTRaEa bayonukumo, as some read; or bayonakumo, as others: (T, S, M:) the former means Verily your union hath become dissevered: (AA, T, S, M:) the latter, that which was between you; (maA bayonakumo, Ibn-Mes'ood, T, S, or QlRaciI kaAna bayonakumo, IAar, T;) or the state wherein ye were, in respect of partnership among you: (Zj, T:) or the state of circumstances, or the bond, or the love, or affection, [formerly subsisting] among you, or between you; or, accord. to Akh, bayonakumo, though in the accus. case as to the letter, is in the nom. case as to the place, by reason of the verb, and the adverbial termination is retained only because the word is commonly used as an adv. n.: (M:) AHát disapproved of the latter reading; but wrongly, because what is suppressed accord. to this reading is implied by what precedes in the same verse. (T.) ― -b2- [It is often used as a partitive, or distributive; as also maA bayona: for ex.,] you say, humo bayona HaAcifK waqaAcifK, (S and TA in art. qcf,) or humo maA bayona HaAcfK wqAcfK, (TA in art. Hcf,) i. e. [They are partly, or in part,] beating with the staff, or stick, and [partly, or in part,] pelting with stones; [or some beating &c., and the others pelting &c.] (S and TA, both in art. qcf, and the latter in art. Hcf.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce xayoTapN.] ― -b3- hecaA bayona bayona means This (namely, a thing, S, or a commodity, Msb) is between good and bad: (S, Msb, K:) or of a middling, or middle, sort: (M:) these two words being two nouns made one, and indecl., with fet-h for their terminations, (S, Msb, K,) like xamosapa EaXara. (Msb.) Alhamozapu AlmuxafRafapu [i. e. the hemzeh uttered lightly] is called hamozapN bayona bayona, (S, M, K, *) i. e. A hemzeh that is between the hemzeh and the soft letter whence is its vowel; (S, M;) or hamozapu bayoni bayonK, the first byn with kesreh but without tenween, and the second with tenween, (Sharh Shudhoor edh-Dhahab,) [i. e. the hemzeh &c.:] if it is with fet-h, it is between the hemzeh and the alif, as in saAala, (S, M,) for saOala; (M;) if with kesr, it is between the hemzeh and the yé, as in sayima, (S, M,) for saYima; (M;) and if with damm, it is between the hemzeh and the wáw, as in lawuma, (S, M,) for laWuma: (M:) it is never at the beginning of a word, because of its nearness, by reason of feebleness, to the letter that is quiescent, (S, M,) though, notwithstanding this, it is really movent: (S:) it is thus called because it is weak, (Sb, S, M,) not having the power of the hemzeh uttered with its proper sound, nor the clearness of the letter whence is its vowel. (M.) 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras says,
taHomiI HaqiyqatanaA wabaEo Du Alqawomi yasoquTu bayona bayonaA
i. e. [Thou defendest what we ought to defend, or our banner, or standard, while some of the people, or company of men,] fall, one after another, in a state of weakness, not regarded as of any account: (S:) or it is as though he said, between these and these; like a man who enters between two parties in some affair, and falls, or slips, or commits a mistake, and is not honourably mentioned in relation to it: so says Seer: (IB, TA:) or between entering into fight and holding back from it; as when one says, Such a one puts forward a foot, and puts back another. (TA.) ― -b4- bayonaA↓ and bayonamaA↓ are of the number of inceptive Huruwf: (M, K:) this is clear if by Hrwf is meant "words:" that they have become particles, no one says: they are still adv. ns.: (MF, TA:) the former is bayona with its [final] fet-hah rendered full in sound; and hence the A; (Mughnee in the section next after that of wA, and K;) [i. e.,] it is of the measure faEolaI [or faEolaA] from Albayon, the [final] fet-hah being rendered full in sound, and so becoming A; and the latter is bayona with maA [restrictive of its government] added to it; and both have the same meaning [of While, or whilst]: (S:) or the A in the former is the restrictive A; or, as some say, it is a portion of the restrictive mA [in the latter]: (Mughnee ubi suprà:) and these do not exclude bayona from the category of nouns, but only cut it off from being prefixed to another noun: (MF, TA:) they are substitutes for that to which bayona would otherwise be prefixed: (Mgh:) some say that these two words are adv. ns. of time, denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; and they are prefixed to a proposition consisting of a verb and an agent, or an inchoative and enunciative; so that they require a complement to complete the meaning. (TA.) One says, bayonaA naHonu kacelika Uico Hadava kacaA [While we were in such a state as that, lo, or there, or then, such a thing happened, or came to pass]: (M, Mgh, * K: *) and bayonamaA naHonu kacaA [While we were thus]: (Mgh:) and
bayonaA naHonu naroqubuhu OataAnaA
[While we were looking, or waiting, for him, he came to us]; (S, M;) a saying of a poet, cited by Sb; (M;) the phrase being elliptical; (S, M;) meaning bayona OawoqaAti naHonu naroqubuhu, (M,) i. e., bayona OawoqaAti riqobatinaA UiyRaAhu [between the times of our looking, or waiting, for him]. (S, M.) As used to put nouns following bayonaA in the gen. case when bayona might properly supply its place; as in the saying (of Aboo-Dhu-eyb, which he thus recited, with kesr, S),
bayonaA taEanRuqihi AlkumaApa warawogihi
yawomFA OutiyHa lahu jariIoCN salofaEu
[Amid his embracing the courageous armed men, and his guileful eluding, one day a bold, daring man was appointed for him, to slay him]: (S, K:) in [some copies of] the K, taEanRufihi; but in the Deewán [of the Hudhalees], tEnRqh: [in the Mughnee, ubi suprà, taEaAnuqihi:] the meaning is bayona taEaAnuqihi; the A being added to give fulness to the sound of the [final] vowel: (TA:) As used to say that the A is here redundant: (Skr, TA:) others put the nouns following both bayonaA and bayonamaA in the nom. case, as the inchoative and enunciative. (Skr, S, K.) Mbr says that when the noun following bynA is a real subst., it is put in the nom. case as an inchoative; but when it is an inf. n., or a noun of the inf. kind, it is put in the gen., and bynA in this instance has the meaning of bayona: and Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà says the like, but some persons of chaste speech treat the latter kind of noun like the former: after bynmA, however, each kind of noun must be in the nom. case. (AA, T.) [See an ex. in a verse cited towards the end of art. Ac.]

bayonaA byn bynA bynnA yn
bayonaA see bayonN

bayonamaA bynmA
bayonamaA see bayonN

biynN byn bynn yn
biynN A separation, or division, (T, M, K,) between two things, (T,) or between two lands; (M, K;) as when there is a rugged place, with sands near it, and between the two is a tract neither rugged nor plain: (T:) an elevation in rugged ground: (M, K:) the extent to which the eye reaches, (T, M, K,) of a road, (T,) or of land: (M:) a piece of land extending as far as the eye reaches: (T, S:) and a region, tract, or quarter: (AA, T, M, K:) pl. buyuwnN. (S, TA.)

bayaAnN byAn yAn
bayaAnN is originally the inf. n. of baAna as syn. with tabayRana, and so signifies The being [distinct or] apparent &c.; (Kull;) or it is a subst. in this sense: (Msb:) or a subst. from bayRana, [and so signifies the making distinct or apparent &c.,] being like salaAmN and kalaAmN from salRama and kalRama. (Kull.) ― -b2- Hence, conventionally, (Kull,) The means by which one makes a thing [distinct,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous: (S, Er-Rághib, TA, Kull:) this is of two kinds: one is [a circumstantial indication or evidence; or] a thing indicating, or giving evidence of, a circumstance, or state, that is a result, or an effect, of a quality or an attribute: the other is a verbal indication or evidence, either spoken or written: [see also bayRinapN:] it is also applied to language that discovers and shows the meaning that is intended: and an explanation of confused and vague language: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the eduction of a thing from a state of dubiousness to a state of clearness: or making the meaning apparent to the mind so that it becomes distinct from other meanings and from what might be confounded with it. (TA.) ― -b3- Also Perspicuity, clearness, distinctness, chasteness, or eloquence, of speech or language: (T, S:) or simply perspicuity thereof: (Har p. 2:) or perspicuity of speech with quickness, or sharpness, of intellect: (M, K:) or perspicuous, or chaste, or eloquent, speech, declaring, or telling plainly, what is in the mind: (Ksh, TA:) or the showing of the intent, or meaning, with the most eloquent expression: it is an effect of understanding, and of sharpness, or quickness, of mind, with perspicuity, or chasteness, or eloquence, of speech: (Nh, TA:) or a faculty, or principles, [or a science,] whereby one knows how to express [with perspicuity of diction] one meaning in various forms: (Kull:) [some of the Arabs restrict the science of AlbyAn to what concerns comparisons and tropes and metonymies; which last the Arabian rhetoricians distinguish from tropes: and some make it to include rhetoric altogether:] Esh-Shereeshee says, in his Expos. of the Maká- mát [of El-Hareeree] that the difference between bayaAnN and tiboyaAnN↓ is this: that the former denotes
perspicuity of meaning; and the latter, the making the meaning to be understood; and the former is to another person, and the latter to oneself; but sometimes the latter is used in the sense of the former: (TA:) or the former is the act of the tongue, and the latter is the act of the mind: (Har p. 2:) or the former concerns the verbal expression, and the latter concerns the meaning. (Kull.) It is said in a trad., UinRa mina AlbayaAni siHorFA (S) or lasiHorFA (TA) [Verily there is a kind of eloquence that is enchantment: see this explained in art. sHr]. The saying in the Kur [lv. 2 and 3], xalaqa QloUinosaAna EalRamahu QlobayaAna means He hath created the Prophet: He hath taught him the Kur-án wherein is the manifestation of everything [needful to be known]: or He hath created Adam, or man as meaning all mankind: He hath [taught him speech, and so] made him to discriminate, and thus to be distinguished from all [other] animals:(Zj, T:) or He hath taught him that whereby he is distinguished from other animals, namely, the declaration of what is in the mind, and the making others to understand what he has perceived, for the reception of inspiration, and the becoming acquainted with the truth, and the learning of the law. (Bd.) ― -b4- It is also applied to Verbosity, and the going deep, or being extravagant, in speech, and affecting to be perspicuous, or chaste, therein, or eloquent, and pretending to excel others therein; or some byAn is thus termed; and is blamed in a trad., as a kind of hypocrisy; as though it were a sort of self-conceit and pride. (TA.)

biYorN bayuwnN c
biYorN bayuwnN A well of which the rope does not strike against the sides, because its interior is straight: or that is wide in the upper part, and narrow in the lower: or in which the drawer of water makes the rope to be aloof from its sides, because of its crookedness: (T:) or deep and wide; (S, K;) because the ropes are wide apart from its sides; (S;) as also baAYinapN↓: (S, TA:) or that is wide between the two [opposite] sides: (M:) pl. [regularly of the latter epithet] bawaAYinu. (T, S.)

bayRinN byn bynn yn
bayRinN [Distinct, as though separate from others; and thus,] apparent, manifest, evident, clear, plain, or perspicuous; (T, S, Msb, K;) as also baAYinN↓ (T) and mubiynN↓: (T, S:) pl. [of mult.] OaboyinaMCu (S, K) and [of pauc.] bayinapN. (K.) Hence, AlkitaAbu AlmubiynN↓ [as applied to the Kur, q. v. in xii. 1, &c.,] The clear, plain, or perspicuous, book or writing or scripture: or, as some say, this means the book &c. that makes manifest all that is required [to be known]: (T:) or, of which the goodness and the blessing are made manifest: or, that makes manifest the truth as distinguished from falsity, and what is lawful as distinguished from what is unlawful, and that the prophetic office of Mohammad is true, and so are the narratives relating to the prophets: (Zj, T:) or, that makes manifest the right paths as distinguished from the wrong. (M, TA.) And kalaAmN bayRinN Perspicuous, clear, distinct, chaste, or eloquent, language. (T.) ― -b2- A man, or thing, bearing evidence of a quality &c. that he, or it, possesses. (S and K and other Lexicons passim.) ― -b3- A man (M) perspicuous, or clear, or distinct, in speech or language; or chaste therein; or eloquent; (ISh, T, M, K;) fluent, elegant, and elevated, in speech, and having little hesitation therein: (ISh, T:) pl. OaboyinaMCu (T, M, K) and buyanaMCu and [of pauc.] OaboyaAnN: (Lh, M, K:) the second of these pls. is anomalous: the last is formed by likening faEiylN to faAEilN: [for bayRinN is a contraction of bayiynN:] but the pl. most agreeable with analogy is bayRinuwna: so says Sb. (M.)

bayRinapN byn bynh bynnh bynp yn
bayRinapN An evidence, an indication, a demonstration, a proof, a voucher, or an argument, (Mgh, TA,) such as is manifest, or. clear, whether intellectual or perceived by sense; (TA;) [originally bayiynapN,] of the measure faEiylapN, from bayonuwnapN, [see 1, first sentence,] and bayaAnN [q. v.]: (Mgh:) and the testimony of a witness: pl. bayRinaAtN. (TA.)

baAYinN c
baAYinN In a state of separation or disunion; or separated, severed, disunited, or cut off; (M, * Msb;) as also Oaboyanu↓, occurring in a verse cited above, voce bayRina. [Hence,] AimoraOapN baAYinN A woman separated from her husband by divorce; (M, Msb, K;) as also mubaAnapN↓: the former without p: (Msb:) like TaAliqN and HaAYiDN: you say [to a wife] Oanoti baAYinN [Thou art separated from me by divorce.] (Mgh.) ― -b2- TalaAqN baAYinN is a tropical phrase; and so is TaloqapN baAYinapN; (Mgh;) [signifying the same as] taToliyqapN baAYinapN (S, M, Msb, K) (tropical:) A divorce that is [as it were] cut off; i. q. mubaAnapN↓ [in the second and third of these phrases, and mubaAnN↓ in the first]: (ISk, Msb:) bAYnp being here used in the sense of a pass. part. n.: (S, Sgh, Msb:) or it [is a possessive epithet, and thus] means having separation: this kind of divorce is one in the case of which the man cannot take back the woman unless by a new contract; (TA;) nor without her consent. (MF in art. bt.) ― -b3- qawosN baAYinapN, (S, M, K,) and baAYinN, (M, K,) A bow that is widely separate from its string: (S, M, K:) contr. of baAniyapN; (S, M;) this signifying one that is so near to its string as almost to stick to it: (S:) each of these denotes what is a fault. (S, M.) ― -b4- biYorN baAYinapN: see bayuwnN. ― -b5- naxolapN baAYinapN A palm-tree of which the racemes have come forth from the spathes, and of which the fruit-stalks have grown long. (AHn, M.) ― -b6- AlbaAYinu also signifies He who comes to the milch beast [meaning the she-camel, when she is to be milked,] from her left side; (S, K;) and AlmuEalRiI, he who comes to her from her right side: (S:) or the former, he who stands on the right of the she-camel when she is milked, and holds the milking-vessel, and raises it to the milker, who stands on her left, and is called AlmusotaEoliI: (T:) two persons are engaged in milking the she-camel; one of them holds the milking-vessel on the right side, and the other milks on the left side; and the milker is called AlmusotaEoliI and AlmuEalRiI; and the holder, AlbAYn: (M:) pl. buyRanN. (T.) It is said in a prov., Aisotu AlbaAYini OaEorafu, or, as some say, OaEolamu; meaning (assumed tropical:) He who has superintended an affair, and exercised himself diligently in the management thereof, is better acquainted with it than he who has not done this. (T. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 606.]) ― -b7- TawiylN baAYinN Excessively tall, far above the stature of tall men. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also bayRinN.

Talaba UilaI Oabawayohi AlbaAYinapa c
Talaba UilaI Oabawayohi AlbaAYinapa He asked, or begged, of his two parents, the separation of himself from them, by [their giving him] property, (AZ, T, M,) to be his alone. (T.)

Oaboyanu c
Oaboyanu: see baAYinN. ＝ -A2- fulaAnN Oaboyanu mino fulaAnK Such a one is more perspicuous, clear, distinct, chaste, or eloquent, in speech or language, than such a one. (S, TA.)

tiboyaAnN tbyAn
tiboyaAnN an anomalous inf. n. (T, S, K) of 2, q. v.: (T:) or a subst. used as an inf. n.; (MF, TA;) i. e., a subst. from 2. (Sb, M, TA.) See bayaAnN.

mubaAnN mbAn mbnI
mubaAnN; and its fem., with p: see baAYinN, in three places.

mubiynN mbyn
mubiynN Separating, severing, disuniting, or cutting off; (S, K;) as also muboyinN, like muHosinN: (K:) but [the right reading in the K may be wamubiynN kamuHosinK, meaning "and mubiynN is like muHosinN:" if not,] muboyinN is a mistake. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also bayRinN, in two places.

mabaAyinu AlHaqRi mbAyn AlHq
mabaAyinu AlHaqRi [in which the former word is app. pl. of mubiynapN] signifies The things that make the truth to be apparent, manifest, evident, clear, or plain; or the means of making it so; syn. mawaADiHuhu. (TA.)

1. baAha lahu, aor. yabaAhu, inf. n. bayohN; and maA bihotu lahu: see 1 in art. bwh.
